2284	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">  Printing Press and Publication (Declaration and Registration) Act (XXIII/73)</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>   33 DLR 406, 33 DLR 238</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Printing Press and Publication </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Printing Press and Publication (Declaration and Registration) Act (XXIII/73)</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p>Secs. 7 &amp; 12 District Magistrate given power to authenticate a newspaper declaration-In case of refusal an appeal lies with the Government —Proceeding for authentication is a quasi-judicial act.</p><p><em>Sk. Faziul Karim Salim Vs. Bangladesh ors. (1981) 33 DLR 406.</em></p><p>—When conditions embodied in clauses (a) of s.12 (2) of Act XXIII/73 are fulfilled authentication of declaration must he given. Ibid.</p><p>—Referring the matter of authentication of declaration to the Government by the Dy. Commissioner was wrong.   Ibid.</p><p><strong>S. 12 (1) (2)— </strong>Memo of the Deputy Commissioner was made by virtue of a colourable exercise of authority vested in him under sub-sections (1) &amp; (2) of section 12 of the Act XXIII of 1973. On that account the impugned memo must be held to have been made illegally without any lawful authority, with no legal effect and must be set aside. Ibid.</p><p> </p><p><strong>S. 12(2) clauses (a) to (h)</strong> The District Magistrate in dealing with authentication matters acts in quasi-judicial capacity—</p><p>—Personal hearing to the person making the declaration.</p><p><em>Motahar Hossain Siddiqui, Vs. Bangladesh &amp; another. (1981)33 DLR 238.</em></p><p>—Requirements of clauses (a) to (h) of section 12 (2) of Act XXIII of 1973 once being complied with the District Magistrate has no option but to authenticate the declaration.   Ibid.</p><p>—When a declaration has fulfilled all the requirements of clauses (a) to (h) of section 12(2) of Act XXIII/73, the Deputy Commissioner is under an obligation to authenticate the declaration without referring the matter to the Government. Ibid.</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>

2286	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">  Rent Control Act, 1959</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1961) 13 DLR 869</p><p><b>Subject:</b>   Rent Control </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Rent Control Act</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;">(XVI of 1959)</p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"> </p><p><strong>S. 17(e): Bonafide requirement for personal use may arise subsequently.</strong></p><p>A landlord or an owner of a house may have family members or other dependants who might grow in number and might also require more accommodation from time to time.</p><p>It is true that the owner concerned must have a bonafide necessity for using and occupying the entire house but while determining the question as to bonafide necessity, the desirability of allowing the land- lord for having better accommodation should not be ignored or overlooked.</p><p><em>Fazlur Rahman Vs. 2287	<h2 class="blog_entry-title"> Small Cause Courts Act, 1887 [Section 24-35]</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 310, (1967) 19 DLR 30, (1962) 14 DLR 404,  (1957) 9 DLR 357, (1970) 22 DLR 183, (1977) 29 DLR 380, (1980) 32 DLR (AD) 170, (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 310, (1954) 6 DLR 277, (1961) 13 DLR 140, (1962) 14 DLR 404, (1973) 25 DLR 142, (1983) 35 DLR</p><p><b>Subject:</b>   Small Cause Courts </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p align="center"> </p><p align="center"><strong> Small Cause Courts Act, 1887</strong></p><p align="center"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 24</strong>—S. 24 provides for an appeal only in certain cases under clause (II) or clause (h) of section 104 (I) C.P.C..</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Abdul Khaleq Mia Vs. Maya Debi (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 310.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 25</strong>—When a matter has been disposed of by the High Court on an application under section 25 of the Provincial Small Cause Courts Act, no question ci avc under clause 15 of the Letters Patent arises.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Jamiruddin Ahmed Vs. Md. Nurul Islam (1967) 19 DLR 30.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Appeal against suit—when does not lie.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In order to hold that so far as the Small Cause Courts Act is concerned no appeal would lie against the decision of the Court of first instance. The test, as provided in section 27 read with sec. 25 of the Provincial Small Cause Courts Act, is’ that the suit in question should not only be in the nature of Small Cause Courts suit but it must also be decided by a Court of Small Causes.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In the absence of a Munsif invested with Small Cause Courts power, a suit which is otherwise as a Small Cause Courts suit will have to be tried as an ordinary money suit and as against such a decision an appeal will lie.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Motiullah Shaikh Vs. Reazuddin Ahmed (1962) 14 DLR 404.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Judgment of the Small Cause Court—what it should contain.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Duty has been cast on the Provincial Small Cause Court to make its judgment intelligible, and to show that it had at least grasped the question to be decided by giving, even though very briefly, the reasons upon which its conclusion is based. To say merely that it has considered the evidence and it is satisfied that a particular plea cannot be believed is not sufficient.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Alauddin Mia &amp; anr. Vs. Abdul Latif &amp; ors. (1957) 9 DLR 357.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—When the High Court is called upon to determine as to whether the judgment is in accordance with law or not there must he something before the Court from whom it can satisfy it that the Small Cause Court at least applied its mind to all the questions in controversy between the parties in the suit</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Alauddin Mia &amp; anr. Vs. Abdul Latif &amp; ors. (1957) 9 DLR 357.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—S. 25</strong>—Nature of the suit when shows that question of title is involved and, in fact, the suit is tried as a title suit, the fact that the Munsif trying the suit had Small Cause Courts Power will not render the suit as Small Cause Courts suit—In such a suit appeal will lie.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If the frame of the suit well as the contents in the plaint show that L was in the nature of a title suit and the sam.1s,in fact been tried as a title suit, the mere fact that the Munsif trying that suit was invested with a Small Cause Courts power will not render the suit as a Small Cause Court suit and hence a regular appeal will lie against a judgment of such suit and a revision under Section 25 of the Small Cause Courts Act against the judgment of the learned Munsif will be infructous but in due course a regular appeal will lie against such judgment.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Faziluddin Patwari Vs. Mr. M. A. Razzaq, (1970) 22 DLR 183.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Suit for ejectment of a monthly tenant triable exclusively under the S.C.C. Act and though filed as a title suit, it is to be governed by the S.C. Court Act and, therefore, revision as against such a decision would lie under section 25 of the S.C.C. Act and not under section 115 C. P. Code—High Court exercises wider power under sec. 25 than under sec. 115— Right to move under sec. 25 of the S.C.C. Act not taken away even though the case was tried by an ordinary civil court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Fazlur Rahim Vs. Shamsul Huda (1977) 29 DLR 380.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—S. 25</strong> has given wider discretion to the High Court than in case of S. 115 of C.P. Code.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Fazilatunnessa Vs. Nowshad Ali (1977) 29 DLR 380.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—High Court may allow amendment of pleading at any stage of the proceeding. Ibid</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A revision u/s. 25 lies with a wider scope than that available u/s. 115 C. P. C.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A revision under section 25 of the Small Cause Courts Act lies if there is an error of law involved in the decision of the trial Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdus Sauar &amp; ors. Appellants Vs. Suresh</em> <em>Chandra Das &amp; ors. Respondents (1980) 32 DLR (AD) 170.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 25—High Court’s power of interference u/s. 25.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The trial Court from evidence drew a conclusion of fact which the learned Judge of the High Court Division reversed without positing any error of law. He merely drew a second conclusion of facts which section 25 of the Small Cause Act does not authorize him to do. The reversal of finding of fact by the learned Judge on this point cannot be sustained.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdus Sattar &amp; ors. Vs. Suresh Chandra Das &amp; ors.(1980) 32 DLR (AD) 170.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—When dealing with a case u/s. 25, Small Cause Court Act, the High Court is first of all to come to a finding that the decision of the court below suffers from an error of law, and then to sec whether the error of law has vitiated its decision and on so finding, the High Court can proceed to reverse the decision of the Trial Court. Ibid</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">S. 25—</span></strong>S. 25 give the jurisdiction to the High Court Division to satisfy that a decree or order by S.C.C. was according to law.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdul Khaleq Mia Vs. Maya Debi (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 310.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">S. 27—When the order passed by the trial Court was that of a Small Cause Court, his order is not appealable.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Shamsuddin Pradhan Vs. Josoda Kanta Sen &amp; ors. (1954) 6 DLR 277.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Section has no application when the suit tried by Munsif was beyond his jurisdiction to try it as a Small Cause suit.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A suit for refund of earnest money (paid by way of advance for purchase of immovable property) is triable by Small Cause Courts.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The Munsif was empowered to try a suit of the nature of Small Cause Courts upto Rs.300/-. The suit was filed before him for refund of earnest money valued at Rs. over 500/- and the Munsif, in consequence, tried the suit in his ordinary evil jurisdiction. A first appeal was taken against the decision of the Munsif to the Subordinate Judge.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Relying on the principle enunciated in (1954) 6 DLR 277 it was contended that the present suit being a suit of the nature of Small Cause Courts even though it was tried under the ordinary civil jurisdiction, no appeal lay against the decision of the Munsif. Overruling this contention it was held— The Munsif in the present case who tried the Suit was not invested with powers to try a suit of the nature of Small Cause exceeding in value of Rs. 300/- and as such he had jurisdiction to try the suit in the ordinary civil jurisdiction and the order passed by him was appealable.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Ahmad Haldar Vs. Betu Mohwz Bhawal (1961) 13 DLR 140.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Appeal against suit—when does not lie.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In order to hold that so far as the Small Cause Courts Act is concerned no appeal would lie against the decision of the Court of first instance. The test, as provided in section 27 read with section 25 of the Provincial Small Cause Courts Act, is that the suit in question should not only be in the nature of Small Cause Courts suit but it must also be decided by a Court of Small Causes. In the absence of a Munsif invested with Small Cause Courts power, a suit which is otherwise as a Small Cause Courts suit will have to be tried as an ordinary money suit and as against such a decision an appeal will lie.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Motiullah Shaikh Vs. Reazuddin Ahmed (1962) 14 DLR 404.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—When a small cause has been tried by a Court not invested with small cause court’s power, the decree passed by it is open to appeal.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Section 27 of the Provincial Small Cause Courts Act makes only a decree passed by a Court of Small Causes final. Where the Court of first instance was not such a Court the decree passed by it would not be final and would be appealable under section % of the Code of Civil Procedure.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Santosh Lal Gope Vs. Ahmed Ali (1973) 25 DLR 142.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 28A(1)—[</strong>See under section 23(1) in the case Shudhir Chandra Vs. Md. Alabaksh, in 18 DLR 208 above.]</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 28A(2)—</strong>With the insertion of section 28A(2), an order u/s. 28A(2) is not revisable u/s.25.—Therefore when order is passed by a District Judge u/s. 28A(2), sec. 25 does not confer any jurisdiction against such order.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdul Khaleq Mia Vs. Maya Debi (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 310.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 32(2)—</strong>Suit rightly instituted as a regular Suit must be tried as a regular suit, even though the Court trying it may at the time of its trial be invested with Small Cause Court powers.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Section 32(2) of the Provincial Small Cause Courts Act says that if a Suit is instituted in the ordinary Civil Court or proceedings arc commenced in such a Court the subsequent investment of such a Court with the powers of a Small Cause Court would not make the provision of sub-sec. (I) applicable. The words “suits instituted or proceedings commenced” in sub-sec.(2) mean when the plaint is presented or the application is put in. If at that time there is no Court of Small Cause in the locality and the suit or application is Filed in a Civil Court that sub-section would apply, even if the presiding judge of the Civil Court be later on invested with Small Cause Court powers.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A suit, if rightly instituted as a regular suit would continue to remain as a regular suit and must be tried as a regular suit, even though the officer trying it may at the time of its trial, but subsequent to the institution thereof, have been invested with the necessary Small Cause Court powers.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Mozammal Huq Vs. Chatku Shaikh (1956) 8 DLR 196.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 33—</strong>Question is whether section 144 of the C.P. Code is available to a Court of Small Causes.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Section 33 of the Act says that Small Cause Courts and Civil Courts are distinct and should be always treated as different Courts.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Trial provisions of the Civil Procedure Code are available to a Court of Small Causes except to the extent the Small Cause Courts Act or Code of Civil Procedure excludes specifically the provisions of the Code from its application to a proceeding before a Court of Small Causes. It therefore follows that the trial procedure prescribed in the Code shall be followed in all suits cognizable by a Court of Small Causes except to the extent excluded. Provisions of section 144 of the Code which has not been excluded is available to the Court of Small Causes and the power is to be exercised when language of section is attracted to the facts of the case before it.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sayeb Ali…Appellant Vs. Sree Gopal Chandra</em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> <em>Das and others…Respondents. (1980) 32 DLR (AD) 212.</em></span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Art. 8. Suit under section 149(3) B.T. is recognizable by the Small Cause Court.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A suit under section 149(3) of the B.T. Act bears the character of a suit for a declaratory decree. Such a suit is recognizable by the Small Cause Court under Arts.8 and 19 of Sch. II of the Provincial Small Cause Courts Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>M.H. Moharaja Sri B.B.M. Bahadur Vs. Abul Kamal (1949) 1 DLR 67.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—In this Article the word “house” has been used by legislature in contradistinction to “land”—and as such a Suit for the recovery of shop-rent is a suit recognizable by a Small Cause Court. <em>1956 PLR (Lah.) 532.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Art.19</strong>. A suit under sec.149(3) of the B.T. Act bears the character of a suit for a declaratory decree. Such a suit is cognizable by the Small Cause Court under Arts. (8) and (19) Sch. II of the Provincial Small Cause Courts Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>H.M. Maharaja Sri B.B.M. Bahadur Vs. Abul Kamal (1949) 1 DLR 67.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Art.</strong> <strong>31.</strong> Suit in which accounts were taken incidentally—not converted into accounts suit— Where a lump sum has been claimed by the plaintiff and that has been decreed and merely because accounting was entered into incidentally to see whether the claim of the plaintiff is true or not, that will not convert a suit into an account suit but it will remain a suit for recovery of specific amount.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Ijjat Ali Vs. Ram Chandra Mahajan &amp; ors (1956) 8 DLR 654</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Art. 19 Sch. 11</strong>—[Sec under section 15 in case of Habib Industries Vs. Pakistan, in 14 DLR (SC) 6Q above].</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Art.35 cl.(ii)—Conditions which must be satisfied in order to bring a suit within the exception.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In order to bring a suit within the exception provided by clause (ii) of Article 35 of the Provincial Small Cause Courts act and determine whether an act sued upon constitutes a crime or not, the nature of the allegations in the plaint are only relevant and the allegations must be such that, if those allegations are established, an offence under Chapter XVII of the Pakistan Penal Code would be made out. Where upon the facts as stated in the plaint, the case against the defendant is of an act merely wrongful or illegal but not necessarily penal so as to bring it within the provision of the Penal Code, the jurisdiction of the Small Cause Court is not at all excluded.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Majid Biswas &amp; ors. Vs. Adiluddin Shaikh. (1960) 12 DLR 380.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Art.35 Item II of the Second Schedule.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Suit for compensation involving acts which constitute offence of theft and trespass cannot be entertained by Small Cause Courts and s such not entertainable as Small Cause Courts suit.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The plaint says: “The defendants had desired to cultivate the land in suit in borga under the plaintiff for a stipulated period of one year. As the plaintiff did not settle the land to them, the defendants out of that grudge, forcibly cut away the paddy grown by the plaintiffs.”</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held</strong>: The above mentioned allegation constitutes an offence of theft, and the charge of tress- pass in this context would be for the purpose of committing an offence, namely theft. That being so, the allegation, if proved, constitutes also an offence of criminal trespass as defined in section 441 of the Penal Code.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Since the allegation as noticed, Constitutes the offence of ‘penal nature’ the suit cannot, by reason of the provisions of the Article 35, item II of the second schedule be entertained by the Small Cause Courts. It has to be treated as ordinary money suit.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdul Hakim Vs. Obedus Samad (1964) 16</em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> <em>DLR 304.</em></span></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2288	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Bangladesh Legal Proceedings Order, 1972</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1978) 30 DLR (SC) 123</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Bangladesh Legal Proceedings </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><u> </u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><u>Bangladesh Legal Proceedings Order (P0 90 of 1972)</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Article 2</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Provision of Article 2 of P0 90 of 1972 explained and held that suit u/s. 24(4) of the State Acquisition Act does not fall within the ambit of the provision of Article 2 of the Order.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">From the provisions of Art. 2 of the President’s Order No. 90 of 1972 it does not appear that they contain any prohibition against the enforcement of any right as can be claimed under the provisions of Article 2 of P0 90 of 1972. Under the provisions of Article 2 of the Order all legal proceedings whether in the form of suits, appeals or applications which challenged the legality or validity of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950 including any amendments thereto or the acquisition of any property made under any provision thereto were to abate. Further, if any order of injunction or interlocutory order has been made in such legal proceeding they were not to have any effect. No fresh legal proceeding challenging the legality or validity of any such law or acquisition can also be started.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>M/s.</em> <em>Farmers &amp; Co. Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh (1978) 30 DLR (SC) 123.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Suit for a declaration that the order f the Deputy Commissioner refusing to grant the certificate under section 204) of the Act was illegal, is not hit by Article 2 of the Presidents Order No. 90 of 1972. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Right to a grant of certificate enabling the appellant to retain land on conditions specified in the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act cannot be considered as enforcement of any right against acquisition by the Government. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2289	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Different Types of Suit</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  301—44 LW 427, 1935 AMU 67, (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 388,  (1969)21 DLR 41, (1969) 21 DLR (WP) 367, (1982) 34 DLR 219, (1958) 10 DLR 242, (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 275, (1972) 24 DLR 75</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Different Types of Suit</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Pre-emption Suit</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Doctrine of <em>lis pendens</em> applies also to preemption suits. 88 J.C. 202 —1925A. 502; 49A. 516—1927A. 336; 9 Luck 475—1934 0. 303; 24 IC. 32—17 OC 150; 89 IC 219—23 ALl 615. But it does not affect the validity of the sale affected by the vendee during the pendency of the pre-emption suit to a person possessing a right of pre-emption equal to that of the pre-emptor. <em>II L. 258—I 930 L. 356 (F.B.) See also 32 P.L.R. 283—1931 L. 435.</em> Persons claiming superior right to pre-empt, whether can claim notwithstanding us pendens. <em>27 A.LJ. 537—1929 A. 440.</em> Doctrine of <em>lis pendens</em> does not apply where pre-emptor had obtained decree before declaratory suit. <em>1929 L 589. See also 96 IC 450.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Suit for Dower</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Section applies to a suit for dower by a Mohamedan wife in which a claim is made for charge of possession of the property. Sec 4 C. 402; 19 A. 504. But see 130 IC. 113—193 1 0.63 where it was a mere money claim and the property left after transfer was ample. A transfer by a Mohammedan husband to his wife in discharge of his legal obligation to pay dower does not amount to a sale under <em>s.52. I Luck. 83—29 OC 108—1926 0. 186.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Administration Suit</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The doctrine of us picnics does not apply to administration suits. <em>1927 R 186; 5 R 266—103 I.C. 264; 2 R 4—79 IC 729; 1921 R 69; 27LW544</em>— Where the creditor of the deceased was unaware of the will left by him and a constituted claim by a residuary legatee under the will for a declaration of his rights, brought a suit against the widow of the deceased in possession of some of his properties and got a decree. Held, the decree was binding on the residuary legatee and was not affected by s. 52.54 M 212—1930 M 930—60 MU 97. Where a person purchased property from one of the heirs pending an administration suit, held, that the doctrine of us pen- dens applied. <em>7 R 734—1930 R 132.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Suit for Injunction</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The doctrine of us pendens applies to suits for injunction. The pendency of the suit under s.52 as it stands after the amendment of 1929, extends up to the complete satisfaction of the decree passed in the suit; and under the present law the injunction will go with the land and the decree can be executed against the legal representative and also against the transferee of the judgment-debtor. <em>1935 AMU 67.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Pauper Suit</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A transfer made after the application for leave to sue informa pauperis is filed but before it is registered as a suit is affected by the rule of us pendens. when the immovable property transferred is specifically in issue in the suit. The fact that the immovable property is not in issue at the stage of the enquiry into the pauperism does not make any difference so far as the applicability of the rule of us pendens is concerned. <em>1936 M. 853—71 M.L.J. 301—44 LW 427.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Mortgage Suits</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A suit brought by a mortgagee cannot be affected by the pendens because another mortgagee has already sued to enforce his own rights. Both have rights against the same owner and the title of each relates back to the date of his mortgage and is not created by the decree<em>. 30 N.L.R. 284—1934 N. 36.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Suit for Specific Performance</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The doctrine of us pendens applies to suits for the specific performance of agreements to sell immovable properties. Court sales and private sales equally come under the doctrine of us pendens. <em>34 CU 79—49 C 495; 31 (Born) LR 343—1929 (Born) 200; 26 (Born) LR 418.</em> As to the effect of in- ordinate delay in execution of a decree for specific performance, see. 1931 N. 138 under the old section.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Suit for Contribution</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Where a person purchases another’s property by private sale during the pendency of a contribution suit against such person in which a simple money decree without reference to any charge was passed, the purchase is not affected by the doctrine of us pendens and is not subject to the decree passed in suit. <em>165 IC 567—1936 P 571.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Suits for Maintenance</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">by Hindu widow asking for a charge on her husband’s property; <em>MU 520; 99 IC 564.</em> The doe- trifle of us pendens applies to maintenance actions, and under the explanation to s.52, as amended in 1929, the lis continues after the decree and tip to die sale in execution of the properties charged by the decree. A mortgage executed by the judgment-debtor after the decree and before the sale is therefore affected by us pendens. The fact that in a suit for maintenance by a Hindu widow a charge is claimed over all the family properties which are specified in the plaint would not make any difference in the application of the doctrine, if the properties are sufficiently designated so as to make them directly and substantially the subject-matter of the litigation. <em>1935 M. 867—69 M.LJ. 447</em>. The doctrine of us pendens embodied in s.52, applies to a sale made during the pendency of a suit for maintenance by a Hindu widow in which property sold is sought to be made a charge for the widow’s maintenance. <em>42 (Born) JR 883.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Interpleader Suit</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Where a person purchases property from one of the parties after a decree creating a charge is passed in an inter-pleader suit the transfer is pendente use. <em>33 L.W. 391—1930 M. 98&amp;—60 M.LJ. 79.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Revival of Suit</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Where a suit dismissed for default is revived within a reasonable time, there would be no suspension of us pendens. It will be considered to be a continuous proceeding. See 50 I.C. 727.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Eviction of a tenant from the suit premises when sought on the ground of rebuilding—Landlord to prove his such requirement as being bonafide which must contain an clement of need.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Abdur Rashid Bhuiyan Vs. Mosammat Rahima Khatun, (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 388.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Suit filed for cancellation of a deed on the ground of fraud—Ad-interim injunction prayed under Or.39, r.1 against disturbance of plaintiff’s possession—Injunction can validly be granted.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Kazi Shamauddi Vs. Mst. Nuren Nahar (1969)21 DLR 41.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Parties in a contract embodied a clause of limitation to sue each other within three months from the date of breach of such contract—Such term in contract is void and statutory period of limitation in circumstances, which is three years, will apply.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Islamic <em>Republic of Pakistan Vs. Nazar Din Khauack (1969) 21 DLR (WP) 367.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Limitation for filing a pre-emption case—by the mother guardian on behalf of her minor daughter having knowledge about transfer—case filed 7 years after accrual of right to institute the case—Pica of minority does not prevail.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">When a minor sues through her natural and legal guardian being a mother as a next friend the knowledge of the mother as guardian shall be deemed to be the knowledge of the minor.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Tarajannessa Vs. Wazed Ali Sikder (1982) 34 DLR 219.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Suit for malikana comes under the Art. 50 Cu <em>52 : 1929 PC 166: 33 CWN 809: 31 (Born) LR 891 PC.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Suit against a deft : for the value of goods mis- appropriated by his brother who was agent of the plaintiff on the ground that the defendant being joint with his brother had enjoyed the benefit thereof, is governed by this <em>Art. 120 L Act. 10 C. 860 PC.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A suit to set aside a consent decree where fraud is not alleged or proved is governed by this Art. <em>39 CWN 938:164 IC 561. 120 L Act.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A suit by minor to declare a decree void against him which was passed owing to the gross negligence of his guardian is governed by this Art. 120 L Act and Limitation commences from the (late when the gross negligence becomes known to the minor. 1936 (Mad) 804.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Suit for enforcing a charge against movable property pledged, is governed by this <em>Art. 22C, 21, 17 A. 284, 27 M. 528 F.B. 120 L.ACL.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A suit for money lent on a usufructuary mortgage the cause of action being the failure of the mortgagor to secure the mortgagee in possession, falls either under Art. 116 or this <em>Article 21 M. 242. 120 L.Act.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Suit by a reversioner that the alienation is not binding on him is governed by this Art. <em>1941 Cal 41 : 45 C.W.N. 141. 120 L.Acs.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Suit against a son governed by Mitakshara law to enforce father’s debt on the ground of pious obligation is governed by this Art. 120 L.Act 23 <em>A. 206, 42 C.1068, F.B., 28A. 508, 27 M. 243 F.B. 16 M. 99.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A suit for declaration of title against an order under s.146 Cr.P.C. is governed by this Art. 120 L.Act. 26 M.410, bus the cause of action is recurring one. <em>22 C.LJ. 283. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The plaintiff sued the defendant-company for non-delivery of goods in the following circumstances. The plaintiff having found that there was a shortage of goods started correspondence with the defendant company who sent a reply on 19.2.5 1 intimating the matter would be enquired into and further information would be communicated. Having in vain waited for about 16 months the plaintiff brought the suit for compensation on 12.6.52 against the defendant-company. It was contended on behalf of the defendants that the Suit was barred by limitation as the plaintiff was bound to bring his Suit within one year of the date on which he took delivery of the goods on 15.1.51.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held</strong>: The suit is not barred either under Article 30 or Article 31 of the Limitation Act. The defendants having failed to communicate the results of the enquiry, as assured by their letter, the suit was perfectly maintainable as having been brought within a reasonable time from the date of defendant’s letter dated 19.2.51. The expression “when the goods ought to be delivered” in Article 31 of the Limitation Act means when the plaintiff could have filed a suit without the risk of the suit being considered as premature. <em>Dada Ltd. Vs. R.S.N. Company. (1958) 1O DLR 242.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Plaintiff may sue for loss of goods either under Art. 30 or 31. of L Act</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Plaintiff may sue for loss as contemplated under Article 30 or he may sue in alternative within the meaning of Article 31 of the Limitation Act as well, <em>Dada Ltd. Vs. R.S.N. Company. (1958) 10 DLR 242.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Suits on Mortgage</strong>. In a suit on a mortgage, where a subsequent purchaser from the mortgagors impleadcd after Limitation, the whole suit is not liable to dismissal merely because the mortgage was joint and indivisible. In such cases the mortgage-debt should be apportioned between the defendants who arc barred and those who are not barred. <em>1903,30 Cal. 755; 1906,33 Cal. 1079 atp. 1093; 1928, 33 C.W.N.248.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Suit for Partnership Accounts</strong>. In a suit by a partner for partnership accounts all the partners are necessary parties, and, therefore, if any of them is implcadcd after time the whole suit fails. <em>1887, 14 Cal. 791; 1913, 18 C.W.N. 464.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Suit for possession.</strong> In a suit to recover joint property of two or more persons, if all the necessary parties are not impleaded within time, the whole suit fails. <em>1916, 36 md. Cas 77(Pa(.),foll. in 1916,36 md. Cas. 542 t’Pat).</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Suit against Dead Man</strong>: Joinder of Representatives after time. If a suit is brought against a person who is then dead, and hi legal representatives are subsequently joined a lndanls, the case is not excluded from the operative of section 22 L Act; and accordingly, if limitation has run out at the time of such joinder, the suit would be barred.<em>1885,12 (Cal) 330; 1907,6 CLj 383. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Suit by or against Legal Representative of Deceased:</strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> Proper Representative Joined After Time. Where the debtor has 1ied before suit and plaintiff sues A as the deceased legal representative and subsequently (A fbi being in fact such representative) the plaintiff brings the true representative on the record as defendant, the case is covered by section 22 L Act and is not excluded from its operation by clause 2 of that section. <em>See 1873 10 (Bom) HC 224; 1897, 21 (Born) 580.</em></span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Suit by or against Agent</strong> : Principal Joined after Time. When a suit is wrongly brought in the name of an agent, and after time has run out the principal is substituted as plaintiff, the suit is not barred. <em>1887, 14 Cal 400, (foil. in 1915, 20 C.W.N. 49.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Suit by or against a Firm or Partners</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">. Where a suit is brought by or against a Firm in the name of the Firm, the joinder of the partners (of the Firm) after limitation does not bar the suit, the case being one of mere misdescription. 1885, 7 (All) 284 at p. 287; 1892, 17 (Born) 413.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Suit by or against Minor.</span></strong> Wrong Description of Party. In case of a suit by or against a minor, the minor himself must be named as a plaintiff or defendant. If by an error the guardian (and not the minor) is named as the party suing or being sued, the mistake cannot be corrected after limitation for the suit has expired. <em>37 PR 1889; 1875, 12 (Born) IIC 17.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Suit by or against Idol or Temple</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">. A suit by or against an idol must, it seems, be brought in the name of the idol as represented by. the manager. If, however, the suit is brought in the name of the manager, the mistake may by corrected, and it would not amount to adding a new party within section <em>22 L Act. 1911, 33 (All) 735 (FB).</em></span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Suit by Executor:</strong> Beneficiary added after Time. In a suit brought by an executor for possession, if the beneficiaries are, by leave of the Court, substituted as plaintiffs, that is not, having regard to Order 31, rule 1, Civil Procedure Code, tantamount to substitution of new plaintiffs within section 22, Limitation Act. 1903, 7 CWN 817.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Suit by Insolvent:</strong> Official Assignee added after Time. A suit brought by an insolvent in his own name, after his adjudication, is not maintainable, and the substitution of the name of the Official Assignee at a later date amounts to the addition of a new plaintiff, within the meaning of section 22, Limitation Act. 1926, 28 Born. L.R. 554.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Suit by Unregistered or Unincorporated Society : Members Impleaded after Time. A Suit by an unregistered or unincorporated society must be brought in the names of all the members of the society. <em>1897, 20 All. 167. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Suit against Government: Secretary of Slate added after Lime, in a Suit against the Government, where the original defendant is an officer of the Government and the Secretary of the State for India is impleaded as a co-defendant after limitation, the suit against the latter is barred, <em>1901, 6 CWN 218.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Suit against Municipal Committee—</strong>Where, in a Suit brought against a Municipal Corn- mitten, a wrong official is name as the defendant, and after time has run out, the error is corrected and the name of the proper official substituted, the suit is not barred by section 22 L. <em>Act. 1879 2 All. 296 (distin, in 1901, 6 C.W.N. 218 and foil. in 1915, 20 C.W.N. 49, and relied on in 1925, 27 Born LR. (1122); in 1892, 16</em> Mad. 305 the question was left open.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Suit against Agent of Railway company</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> : Misdescription of Defendant’s name. W1erc a suit was instituted against “The Agent East Indian Railway Company,” Held: that the plaintiff was not entitled, after the period of limitation for the suit had expired, to amend the plaint by substitution of the “East Indian Railway Company,” for the defendant originally sued. “It is not a case of misdescription but if the amendment is allowed it will have the effect of adding a new party to the suit, and section 22 of the Limitation Act will apply.” <em>4 1923, 3 Pat. 230.</em></span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Suit against Debuttor Estate;</strong> Adding Shebait after time. When plaintiff asked for a decree against the debuttor estate and joined as defendant one A both as a receiver of the estate and in his personal capacity, but no one was joined to represent the estate as shebait and subsequently plaintiff amended the plaint and impleaded the said A (who was already on the record as defendant) also as a shebait and as representing the estate. Held—the effect of the amendment was merely to make the estate property represented and that no new defendant was introduced. <em>1905,32 Cal. 582, (on appeal, 1909,37 Cal. 229, PC.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Suit against Surety:</strong> Principal added after time. When in a Suit against the surety, the principal debtor is added after time, the suit is barred as regards the latter alone, and it may be decreed against the surety. See 1885, 12 Cal. 330.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A suit for partition of joint family property which was excluded from previous partition by fraud of some members is governed by this <em>Article 144 Act. 1934 (Born) 419 : 214 JC 273.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A suit by Hindu widow to recover possession of her deceased husband’s estate is governed by <em>Art. 144 60 MU. 619 : JR. 1931 P.C. 150: 1931 P.C. 84: 33 Bans. L.R. 904: 193! M.W.N.561: 53 C.LJ. 292:8 O.W.N.700:35 C.W.N. 465 :33 LW. 477: 12 Pat. L.T. 563 .‘ 131 J.C. 758 P.C.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Art.146A</strong>—Suit by local authority for the possession of any road or street—30 years, from the date of dispossession.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">To apply this Art. the local authority need not be the owner of the street or road, 25 M.635.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Suit for possession by Union Board against a trespasser from before the establishment of the Board is governed by <em>Art. 144. 1942 Cal. 151 : 45 C,W.N. 802:200 1.C. 386.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Art.147</strong>—Suit by a mortgagee for foreclosure or sale—60 years, from when the money becomes due. This Article applies to one class of mortgage in which alone a suit can be and always is brought for “foreclosure or sale” viz, to English mortgage. <em>11 C.W.N. 1005:30 M. 426:4 ALJ.625:9 Born. L.R. 1104:6 Cu 255, PC, 95 I.C. 100:1926 (All) 551. 48A, 302 :24 AU 295 :94 IC 849:1 926 (All) 493.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Suit on adjusted account comes under this Art. 64 L Act. 21 CWN 591, 63 IC 280.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Suit on a bond fixing date for payment and giving an option to the creditor to sue on default of punctual payment of interest falls under this Art. 66 L Act. 1941 Oudh 210 : 193 IC 481 FB.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A suit on a personal covenant under a registered bond is governed by Art. 116 and not by Art. 66 and the period of limitation are 6 years<em>. 52 M. 105 1929 Mad 53 FB, 1935 (Born) 203 : 156 I.C.</em> <em>286.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Art. 90</strong>—In a suit brought by the insurance company against its agents for neglect or misconduct the period of limitation is three years from the date when the neglect or misconduct becomes known to the insurance company. <em>Nacem Finance Limited Vs. Bashir Ahmed Rafique (1971) 23 DLR (SC) 81. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Suit dismissed as plaintiff failed to establish possession within 12 years of the institution of the Suit. The plaintiff having failed to establish his possession in the suit land within 12 years from the institution of the Suit he is not entitled to get any relief, the suit being barred by limitation. This conclusion is in accordance with law<em>. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Rajan Miak Vs. Abdur Rashid (1982) 34 DLR (AD)</em> <em>275. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Declaratory suit</strong>—Bar provided under Article 47, Limitation Act—Civil Court while deciding question of limitation can look into and ‘decide if orders passed in a proceeding under section 145 Cr.P.C. was without jurisdiction or not.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Serajul Hoque Mukhtar Vs. ARM Mustanesar Billah (1972) 24 DLR 75.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A suit by a person who was not a party to the proceedings under sec. 145 does not come under this Art. 47 L Act. 1941 (Pesh) 65: 196 IC 444.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A Suit by an assignee of the person bound by the order falls under this Art. but not by an assignee prior to the order. <em>1936 (Pat) 47 L Act 629:166 IC 29.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A suit for joint possession by a co-owner against the other co-owner whose exclusive possession is maintained under sec. 145 Cr.P.C. comes within this Art. <em>47 I Act. 1943 (Cal) 67: 46 CWN 817.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2290	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">East Bengal Premises Rent Control Ordinance, 1951 &amp; East Bengal Premises Rent Control Rules, 1953</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  7 DLR 56, 9 DLR 186, 9 DLR 102, 6 DLR 192, 6 DLR 410, 5 DLR 492,  8 DLR 272, 11 DLR 345.</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  East Bengal Premises Rent Control</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>East Bengal Premises Rent Control Ordinance</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;">(No. XXII of 1951)</p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"> </p><p>Under the Bengal House Rent Control Order, 1942, no permission of the Rent Controller was necessary to institute a suit for ejectment of a tenant who had been defaulter in payment of rent. The provisions to the contrary contained in the Calcutta Rent Ordinance, 1946, or in the E.B. Premises Rent Ordinance, 1951, were not made retrospective in their operation either by express word or by implication so as to apply to pending suits and appeals, and, therefore, did not affect the suit property instituted during the currency of the Bengal House Rent Control Order, 1942.</p><p><em>Sree Nath Bhuiya Vs. Gopal Ch. Chottopadhay (1955) 7 DLR 56.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>Sec 2(8), 11(1),11(3), proviso (i) and 14: </strong>Standard rent: Rent Controller’s jurisdiction exclusive—Tenancy liable to pay stipulated rent in the absence of standard rent fixed by Rent Controller.</p><p><em>Ishaque Miah Vs. Atul Ch. Dutta (1957) 9 DLR 186.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Sec 13 —</strong> This section clearly directs that before the application for a process for attachment of the judgment-debtor’s property can be issued, the decree-holder along with the petition must file an affidavit to the effect that the amount of the ex-parte decree is recoverable. When a decree-holder fails to put in such an affidavit, all proceedings on the basis of an application for attachment must be declared to be void and of no effect. <em>5 PLR (Dac.) 233.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>S.14 (i)(b) —</strong> Landlord to show contract with tenant prior to August, 1951, prohibiting him from sub-letting any portion of the premises occupied by him-Section 108 J of the Transfer of Property Act. <em>5 PLR (Dac) 458.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Sec 14 (3) —</strong> Sub-tenant has no right to stay where a decree for ejectment is passed against the tenant. No permission from the Rent Controller is necessary as against a sub-tenant.</p><p><em>Sk. Md. Amir Au Vs. Abdul Rahim (1957) 9 DLR 102.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Sec 14(3), 15(1), 15(2):</strong> Where a person does not claim that he is a sub-lessee or an under tenant of the sub-lessee but claims that he is a partner with the sub-lessee the provisions of sections 14(3), 15(1) and 15(2) of the Ordinance have no application.</p><p><em>Abul Fazal Md. Vs. Taj Mia (1954) 6 DLR 192.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>Sec 15</strong> <strong>—</strong> An order refusing to stay execution on the ground that section 15 of the E.B. Premises Rent Control Ordinance, 1951, does not apply, comes under section 2(2) read with section 47 of the Code, and is as such appealable.</p><p><em>Borhanuddin Mia Vs. Nagendra K. Bhowmik (1954) 6 DLR 410.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>Sec 30 Clause (6) —</strong> Final orders passed by District Judge under section 30(2), E.B. Premises Rent Control Ordinance, can be interfered by High Court.</p><p>Although the decision of the District Judge is final under clause 6 of section 30 of the East Bengal Premises Rent Control Ordinance, it does not. operate as a bar to an application under section 115 of the C.P.Code, for there is no provision in this Ordinance to the effect that not only the decision of the District Judge shall be final but that no shall have any jurisdiction to interfere in any with the order so passed by the District Judge. An application in revision under section 115 of the C.P.Code lies against an order of any Court subordinate to this Court in which the legislature has not provided for any appeal and unless there is any provision, express or implied, taking away this jurisdiction of this Court, it must be held that Court has jurisdiction to hear an application in vision directed against the decision of the District Judge passed in an appeal.</p><p>In order to get an ejectment decree in respect the premises under the Ordinance, two elements must be established, viz, the requirement is fide and that it is genuine.</p><p><em>Binkim Ch. Basak Vs. Ganish Ch. Basak (1953) 5 DLR 492.</em></p><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">East Bengal Premises Rent Control Rules, 1953</span></strong></p><p><strong>Rule-7. Object of deposit</strong></p><p>It is the office of the Rent Controller receives rent like any other counter for deposit nowhere in the rent Act ii is provided that before, sending out the deposit by money order the Rent Controller will first determine whether the allegations made in the application for deposit are true or false.</p><p>The whole object of allowing deposit of rent is to enable the tenant or the landlord to fall on the evidence of Lender as kept by the Rent controller’s office for the purpose of the subsequent determination of the question as to whether the ant is a defaulter or not.</p><p><em>Md. Akhtar Vs. Md. Abdus Sadeque. (1956) 8 DLR 272.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>Cross-objection is maintainable—Limitation for such cross-objection is one month.</strong></p><p>It is true that there is no provision for a objection in the Premises Rent Control Act, but Rule 5 of the Rules made by the Provincial Government under the Act makes the Code of Civil Procedure applicable to such proceedings, and, therefore, a cross objection will lie upon an appeal being filed.</p><p>The period of limitation for a cross—objection will be one month from the date of service of the notice of the appeal as provided in Order 41, rule 22 of the Code.</p><p><em>Sk. Pir Mohd. Vs. Sk. Aminuddin (1959) 11 DLR 345.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2291	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">East Bengal Service Tenants (Protection) Act, 1952</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1954) 6 DLR 326, </p><p><b>Subject:</b>  East Bengal Service Tenants (Protection) </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>East Bengal Service Tenants (Protection) Act (E.B. Act IX of 1952)</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 3</strong>—Section 3 of the E.B. Service Tenants (Protection) Ordinance, 1952, does not embrace the proceedings under section 12 of the E.B. State Acquisition and Tenancy Act. The Proceedings affected by section 3 of the Ordinance are applications for execution of a decree for ejectment or other proceedings relating thereto or a suit for ejectment. An application by the landlord under section 12 of the E.B. State Acquisition and Tenancy Act is neither an application for execution of a decree for ejectment, nor is it a suit for ejectment.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The word ‘thereto’, in section 3 of the Ordinance refers either to “application” or “decree for ejectment” not to “ejectment of a service tenant.” Section 3 of the Ordinance does not affect an application under application 12 of the E.B. Slate Acquisition and Tenancy Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Though the E.B. State Acquisition and Tenancy — gave occupancy right to the nankar tenant, the was conferred with effect from the date when the Act came into force. It has no retrospective effect and ‘1 not give any relief in respect of ejectment suit proceeding instituted before it came into force. 3 of the Ordinance are designed to give protection from such Suits and proceedings. It does not refer to a proceeding under section 12 of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Latif Ali Vs. Monwar Ali (1954) 6 DLR 326.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>No retrospective effect—Nankar tenants</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">By section II of the E.B. State Acquisition and Tenancy Act of 1950(East Bengal Act (XXVIII of 1951) nankar tenants have been given a right of occupancy with effect from 16th of May, 1951, the date when the Act came into force. Ibid</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2292	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Oaths Act, 1873</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  162 (DB). (Wahiduddin, J.), 12 DLR (SC) 261, 22 DLR(SC) 303.</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Oaths </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Oaths Act</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;">(X Of 1873)</p><p> </p><p>Scope of—Act is not concerned with compromise or adjustment—Procedural provision for proof of facts—When decree given on basis of statement made under the Act is compromise decree.</p><p>There can be no doubt that the Oaths Act does not concern itself with any agreement, compromise, or adjustment in a suit. It only provides for a procedure by which certain facts may be held to be conclusively proved as against the party which offers to be bound by the oath administered under the Act. But we cannot subscribe to the view that where a decree follows in respect of the whole or part of the subject—matter of a Suit on the basis of a statement made by a party, or a witness, on oath, in pursuance of the agreement of the parties to the suit, the decree should be regarded as a consent decree. But if the intention of the parties is not to obtain a decision of the whole or part of the subject—matter of the suit , but is only confined to finding a short cut for the proof of some or facts in controversy by means of a statement on oath, no decree can immediately follow such oath and the question of determining the nature of the decree in such a case does not really arise.</p><p><em>Lal Vs. Siddiq, PLD 1961 (WP) Lahore 823 = PLR 1962(2) W.P. 431 (DB) (Anwarul Haq, J.)</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>Ss. 8, 9, 11 — Advocate of party — If can undertake to abide by the oath of other party.</strong></p><p>Prima facie party to the judicial proceedings in sections 8 and 9 of the Oaths Act would include an advocate of the party also. It appears that an Advocate empowered by a party to enter into a compromise, etc. is fully competent to make an offer to abide by the special oath and in doing so he must be deemed to have been so instructed by his client.</p><p><em>Mewo Vs. Lal Khatoon, PLD 1962 (WP) Karachi 162 (DB). (Wahiduddin, J.)</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>S.9: Ex—parte Proceedings ordered on defendant’s failure to atten.d the Court to take oath proposed by the plaintiff—Misuse of power under Order 9, r.—12.C.P.C.</strong></p><p>The powers given by Order 9, rule 12, Civil Procedure Code cannot be employed to force an old and respectable person quite possibly from a sick bed, upon the demand of the plaintiff, to Court in order to take an oath in support ,r otherwise of the plaintiffs case. Indeed section 9 of the Oaths Act, which enables the Court to give effect to an offer by a party to be bound by the oath of the opposite party, clearly provides that “no party or witness shall be compelled to attend personally in Court solely for the purpose of answering such question” i.e. whether or not he will make the oath.</p><p><em>Md. Ismail Vs Abdul Khaleque (1960) 12 DLR (SC) 261.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>S.12. Oath (swearing on Quran) is similar to an agreement by contract—Consideration which weighs to repudiate a contract is also applicable in case of an oath.</strong></p><p><em>Mst. Asifa Sultana Vs. Honest Traders, (1970) 22 DLR(SC) 303.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2293	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Onus of proof</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  24 DLR 243,  26 DLR 70, 25 DLR (SC) 104, 21 DLR 78, 30 DLR (SC) 41, 28 DLR(SC) 109, 22 DLR 596, 21 DLR 78, 18 DLR 37, 15 DLR (SC) 389, 34 DLR 145, 34 DLR 225,  34 DLR 274.</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Onus of proof</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p> </p><p><strong>Onus of proof—On whom Lies</strong></p><p>Question of onus is important only in a case when a Court after considering the matter on the basis of the entire material, finds that the same is evenly balanced in between both the parties and a definite conclusion cannot be arrived at In such a case onus will be of paramount importance in determining the suit and if after considering the entire evidence in a case the Court comes to a definite conclusion, then in such a case the question of onus loses its importance and the same need not be further pursued.</p><p><em>Basiruddin Sarkar Vs. Jasimuddin Sarkar, p972)24 DLR 243.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>Onus —</strong></p><p>When evidence of both sides arc fully heard and digested, question of onus does not arise.</p><p><em>Md. Nurullah Chowdhury Vs. Golam Solaiman Kazi (1974) 26 DLR 70.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Onus of proof</strong> — question of proof loses its relevancy when all the relevant evidence is on record— This question is relevant when evidence on record is evenly balanced.</p><p><em>Mst. Qaiser Khatoon Vs’. Mvi. Abdul Khaleq, (1973) 25 DLR (SC) 104</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Onus or burden of proof—when arises:</strong></p><p>Question of onus or burden of proof as a determining factor cannot arise in cases where proof has been concluded and found on a consideration of the evidence.</p><p><em>Najmul Huq Faraji Vs. Panchanan Poddar,(1969) 21 DLR 78.</em></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Burden of proof</strong> — burden of proof as to particular fact.</p><p>Section 101 of the Evidence Act lays down that whoever desires any court to give judgment as to any legal right or liability dependent on the existence of facts, which he asserts must prove that those facts exist and section 103 of the Act provides that the burden of proof as to any particular fact lies on the person who wishes the Court to believe in its existence unless it is. Provided by any law that the proof of that fact shall lie on the particular person.</p><p><em>Ajufannessa vs. Safar Miah (1978) 30 DLR (SC) 41.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Assured to prove loss—burden after this I shifts to the insurer.</strong></p><p>Onus of proof is upon the assured, to prove that there was loss, and that the loss was proximately caused by a peril insured. He need merely prove that thq cause falls within the perils insured against. Once the assured has produced a prima facie evidence, the burden shifts to the insurers, if they wish to show, that it was in fact a cause either not covered or excepted by the policy which proximately caused the loss.</p><p><em>E.S. Insurance Vs. Rahman Trading (1976) 28 DLR(SC) 109</em>.</p><p> </p><p><strong>Contract of Insurance and Marine Insurance</strong>.</p><p>This country is governed by the principles of English Marine Insurance Act— Onus of proof in insurance cases.</p><p><em>Eagle Star Insurance Co. Ltd. vs. Rahmanja Trading Co. Chittagong (1976) 28 DLR (SC) 109</em>.</p><p><strong>  </strong></p><p><strong>Onus of proof:</strong></p><p>Initial onus of proving that the cargo carried under the bill of lading was delivered at the port of destination in damaged condition, is on the consignee (owner of the goods) The onus thereafter shifts on to the carrier first to prove that he took all reasonable care while the cargo was in his custody and then to prove that the cargo was damaged under circumstances beyond his control, which exonerates him from the liability of such damage under the provisions of the Act.</p><p><em>Muhammadi Steamship CG. Ltd. Vs. Province of East Pakistan, (1970) 22 DLR 596.</em></p><p> </p><p>Onus or burden of proof as a determining factor cannot arise in case where proof has been concluded and found on a consideration of die evidence.</p><p><em>Najmul Huq Faraji Vs Panchanan Poddar, (1969) 21 DLR 78.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Onus of proof</strong></p><p><strong>Prdanashin lady—document executed by an il1iterate pardanashin lady</strong>.</p><p>Pardanashin lady—Deed executed by an illiterate lady.</p><p> </p><p>Burden of the person relying on the document to prove that it was duly understood by the lady.</p><p>It is an established principle that in case of a document executed by an illiterate pardanashin lady the onus is on the party who relied on such a deed to satisfy the Court that it has been read over and explained to her, that it was understood by her and that she had independent and disinterested advice in the matter.</p><p>Mere execution, though unaccompanied by duress, protest or obvious signs of misunderstanding or want of comprehension, is in itself no real proof of a true understanding mind in the executants. Evidence m establishes such comprehension is most obviously found in proof that the deed was read over to the settler and, where necessary explained. The extent and character of the explanations required must depend on die circumstances. Length, intricacy, the number and complexity of the dispositions, of the unfamiliarity of the subject—matter are all reasons for requiring an increased amount and efficiency of explanation. Fraud, duress and actual undue influence are separate matter.</p><p><em>Suratunnassa Bibi Vs. Md. Naimuddin Mundal (1966) 18 DLR 37.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>—“Onus of proof”—When evidence on both sides are fully read and digested.</strong></p><p>It is well—settled that when the evidence on both ides bas been fully read and digested before reaching d conclusion, the question of error in placing the initial onus on one side or the other is not of real importance.</p><p><em>Badrul Haq Khan vs. The Election Tribunal (1963) 15 DLR (SC) 389.</em></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Onus of proof—Partition suit—</strong></p><p>Plaintiff must prove his case of hwing a successor-in-interest.</p><p><em>Gopal Chandra Vs Lasman Dasi (1987) 39 DLR (AD) 73.</em></p><p> </p><p>The onus was on the plaintiff to prove that his father Nagar was the son of Gout Majhi, but no paper was produced by him to substantiate his claim that his father Nagar was the son of Gour.   Ibid</p><p>Plaintiff raised no claim in law (in a suit for partition) nor he had any possession therein— His partition suit must fail. Ibid</p><p> </p><p>Onus of proof—Affirmative assertion in the plaint—Plaintiff to prove his case.</p><p>The law is that the person who pleads in the affirmative of the issues is to prove the same.</p><p><em>Gopal Chandra Mondol Vs. Lashman Dasi (1982) 34 DLR 145.</em></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Onus of proof</strong></p><p>Fraud, collusion, undue influence, where alleged—the onus .is on the party who alleges it as such.</p><p>There is a presumption of good faith in human transaction as there is a presumption of innocence in criminal matters.</p><p><em>Kiron Chandra Das Vs. Sirajul Hoque Patwari. (1982) 34 DLR 225</em>.</p><p> </p><p><strong>Onus of proof—When not relevant.</strong></p><p>When both sides adduce evidence the question of onus es its impo mourtls, weigh the evidence on record and come to a decision on the basis of preponderance of evidence.</p><p><em>Jainuddin Howlader &amp; ors. Vs. Nabab Au Mollah &amp; ors (1982) 34 DLR 274</em>.</p><p> </p><p>Onus— Question not of importance where lower Courts have come to a positive finding.</p><p>When the Senior Sub-Judge and the Additional District Judge had come to a positive finding on an issue, the question whether onus was placed on the plaintiff or the defendant lost its importance.</p><p><em>Malik ALLAH DITTA Vs. Malik ALLAH WASAYA, PLD 1956 Lahore 521.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2294	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Opium Act, 1878</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  1955 F C 383], 1952 Lah. 430]</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Opium </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Opium Act (I of 1878)</u></strong></p><p><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p><strong>S.5—Opium Orders, 1937, 0, 21. 66—Jurisdiction of Civil Court, how far barred.</strong></p><p>Although rules may be made to regulate the sale of opium, and as such sales are to be regulated by Licenses, rules may also be made as to the form of Licenses and the conditions governing them it is certainly beyond the power conferred by the Act to make a rule excluding the jurisdiction of a Civil Court to decide whether a certain license is in accordance with the Act. If, therefore 0. 21. 66, was intended to exclude any jurisdiction, it is to that extent ultra vires of section 5 of the Act:</p><p><em>[(Kayani. I.) West Punjab Government v. Akbar Hussain: PLD Lah. 430]</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>Ss. 9 &amp; 10</strong>—Possession of boxes containing poppy heads established—Burden of proving want of knowledge that the boxes contained poppy-heads is on accused. Where it is established that the accused was in possession of boxes which were found to contain poppy-heads, there is a presumption under section 10 that the accused has committed an offence under section 9. Burden is on the accused to prove that he did not know that the boxes contained poppy-heads. In the absence of evidence to discharge that burden the accused would be rightly convicted. 8 C W N 349 rel. 4 I C898; 13 I C 788 and A I R 1930 cal. 688 distinguished:</p><p><em>[(Akram, Shahabuddin and Mohd. Sharif, JJ) Nazir Ahmad v. Crown : PLO 1955 F C 383]</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>S. 23—Arrear of any fee or duty—Suit respecting, not competent in Civil Court.</strong></p><p>In respect of a demand under the Opium Act a suit is not competent in the civil Court. 73 PLR 1912 : AIR 1934 Lah. 157 (2); 27 Pun. Record 1876 and 54 Pun. Record 1885 ref:</p><p><em>[(Kayani, J.) West Punjab Government v. Akbar Hussain : PLD 1952 Lah. 430]</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2295	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Order XXIX (CPC)</h2>
