<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1961) 13 DLR 693</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Order</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Order XXIX (CPC)</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Suit by or against Corporation</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Or. 29, r. 1</strong> (High Court Rules, Part I, r. 4)</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Verification of affidavit—where the petitioner is a public trust.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Where a petitioner is a public trust a writ petition on behalf of the public trust when verified by the Estate Officer of the trust who is conversant with the facts of the case is a substantial compliance with the provision of rule 4 of Part 1 of the High Court Rules.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Kumudini Welfare Trust of Bengal Vs. The Province of East Pakistan (1961) 13 DLR 693.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2296	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Order XXVII (CPC)</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1961) 13 DLR (SC) 4,  (1970) 22 DLR (WP) 99</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Order</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Order XXVII (CPC)</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Suits by or against the Government or Public Officers in their official capacity</strong>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Or. 27, r. 1</strong>—Government’s responsibility when acting as a litigant to a suit—In a suit against Government the latter is not expected to raise all sorts of defences in a spirit of sheer litigiousness— Must not fight shy of admitting patent facts.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Muhammad Akbar Khan Vs. Province of West Pakistan (1961) 13 DLR (SC) 4.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Or. 27, r. 2</strong>—An Advocate when authorized by the Government to conduct case on its behalf becomes a recognized agent for purpose of appearance, act and applications under the CP Code.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Messrs. Nabi Baksh Vs. Pak. Secy. Ministry of Industries, Karachi (1970) 22 DLR (WP) 99.</span></em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2297	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Order XXX (CPC)</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1961) 13 DLR 66, (2968) 20 DLR 41</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Order </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Order XXX (CPC)</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Suits by or against Firms and Persons carrying on business in names other than their own.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Or. 30, r. 1</strong>—Sole-proprietor-—.Plaintiff suing in the name of the firm—Amendment correcting the description of the plaintiff does not substitute or add the plaintiff.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The plaintiff instituted the suit, describing himself as “Ismail Haji Sulaiman, a proprietary firm” instead of “Ismail Haji Sulaiman, a proprietor of the firm,” he being the sole owner of the firm. The defendants contended that the suit was not maintainable under Or. 30, r. I inasmuch as the plaintiff being the sole owner of the firm could not maintain the suit in the name of the firm. The Courts below upheld the defendants’ contention and dismissed the plaintiff’s suit and plaintiff’s prayer for amendment of the plaint was also disallowed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">On appeal to the High Court it was contended on behalf of the plaintiff-appellant that the description of the plaintiff in the plaint was a wrong description and by the amendment of the plaint by describing the plaintiff as lsmail Haji Sulaiman, a proprietor of the firm” the plaintiff is not substituted or added and as such the suit cannot be deemed to have been instituted on the date of amendment.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Held: In the present case it is clear that the plaintiff intended to sue in his own name and not in the name of the firm and the words “Ismail Haji Sulaiman, a proprietary firm” is a wrong scription and the amendment if allowed will not attract operation of section 22(1) of the Limitation Act, inasmuch as no plaintiff is being substituted or added thereby.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Ismail Haji Sulaiman Vs. M/s. Hansa Line (1961) 13 DLR 66.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Or. 30 r. 4</strong>—Partnership (consisting of 2 persons) is dissolved due to retirement of one of the partners during the pendency of the suit—Remaining partner competent to proceed with the Suit and upon a decree passed therein competent to execute the decree in the name of the partnership;</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Menon Trading Co. Vs. Hajee Gaffar Hajee habib Janoo (2968) 20 DLR 41.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>R. 9</strong>—Suits between co-partners: No suit lies as between partners or between firms having common partners for money or monies without asking for accounts <em>34 MU 408 : 45 IC 86 34 M 112, 28 Mad 344) Dis.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Each of the parties to a partnership Suit IS really in terra plaintiff and defendant and in both capacities comes before the court<em>. 167 PWR 1917: 42 IC 436, 78 167 Ret.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>R.10</strong>—.Suit against person carrying on business in another name : On the death of sole proprietor of a firm unless it carries on business which justifies a presumption that his heirs are its partners, a suit cannot be instituted under <em>Or.30,</em> r. 10 in the old manic. of the firm. R.10 will apply only if the business is carried on at the Lime when the suit is instituted. <em>89 IC 22 : 1926 All 161.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Or. 31, rr. 1-3—Suits by or against 1xecutors and Administrators.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">One of the several administrators of an estate can maintain a suit to recover rent with the consent of the other administrators who arc impleaded as profonna defendants <em>53 IC 478.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Under s. 82 of Pro. and Adm. Act and Or. 31, r.1 of this Code none but an executor is competent to prosecute a suit as representative of the deceased. <em>55 IC 504:2 UPLR Pat 31.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">All trustees, executors or administrators should be made defendants. 1934 (All) 1 1943 Born 32.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In a suit against a temple all the trustees arc necessary parties even though there is an agreement between them authorizing one of them to represent the temple<em>. 1922 Mad. 405, 55A 687.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2298	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Order XXXII (CPC)</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1965) 17 DLR 112, (1971) 23 DLR 45</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Order </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Order XXXII (CPC)</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Suits by or against Minors and Persons of Unsound Mind.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Or. 32, r. 1</strong>—The guardian or the next friend of the minor can bring a suit on behalf of the minor at any time during the minority of the ward.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Aalaz Mia Vs. Mohammad Mostafa (1965) 17 DLR 112.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Debutter property—Maintainability of suit— Non-joinder of deity as a party in a suit in respect of debutter property is fatal for maintenance of the suit.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Tejendra Chandra Dhar Vs. Rohini Ranjan Saha (1971) 23 DLR 45.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Suit by or against minor, procedure in—</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is the duty of the court to appoint a minor’s guardian <em>39A 8.26 CLJ 258.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—One of two joint promissors cannot plead the minority of the other and his consequent immunity is a bar to the promissee’s claim against him. 24 CLI 74 PC 34 M314 affirmed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—When minor is sued as major, the decree is a nullity, but if the minor has paid rent under the decree he cannot recover it. <em>27 CWN 549.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2299	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Order XXXIII (CPC)</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1974) 26 DLR 337, (1970) 22 DLR 230, (1983) 35 DLR 276, (1957) 9 DLR 412, (1968) 20 DLR (SC) 284</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Order </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Order XXXIII (CPC)</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Suits by Pauperis.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Or. 33—Plaintiff petitioner’s solvency is the sole question to determine whether the plaintiff would be allowed to sue asforma pauperis—The fact that plaintiffs father is a solvent man is not a matter which a court can take into consideration while determining an application under Order 33—When an error has been discovered by the High Court, the latter suo motu will pass necessary order to prevent gross injustice.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdul Hannan Vs. Saima Khanam (1974) 26 DLR 337.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The learned Munsif did not consider the report which he called froip the learned Deputy Commissioner, who opined that the plaintiff was a pauper. In an enquiry as to whether a person is a pauper or not the main element is to be considered if the said person is of sufficient means which may enable him to pay the prescribed court-fees.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdul Hannan Vs. Saima Khanam (1974) 26 DLR 337.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Or. 33, r. 1</strong>— Suit in forma pauperis—In considering whether a Hindu married woman whose husband’ is alive, has the means to pay the court- fee—Ornaments which arc ordinarily worn by her and which are considered as part of her wearing apparel should be exempted from such consideration:</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sm. Renu Prova Dey Vs. Sree Anil Kumar Dey, (1970) 22 DLR 230.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Or.33, rr. 2, 5(a)—</strong> Persons applying to sue as a pauper must make full disclosure of all his assets—Failure will lead to dismissal of the application.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mahamaya Dutta Vs. Radha Ballay Sarkar (1983) 35 DLR 276.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Or. 33, r.5(a</strong>)— Application for leave to sue as a pauper : Rule 5(a) provided that an application for permission to sue as a pauper will be rejected unless it conforms to the requirements of rules 2 and 3.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">An application for leave to sue as a pauper must disclose all assets; want of bonafides will entail rejection.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sailkupa Co. Op. Society Vs. Jahangir (1957) 9 DLR 412.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Or. 33</strong>—Pauper suits and pauper appeals— distinction between.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">An examination of the two Orders, namely Orders 33 and 44 of the C.P.Code respectively reveals some points of distinction between pauper suits and pauper appeals. A pauper suit which is initiated by an application under rule 2 of Order 33 C.P. Code, has to contain particulars like a plaint in a suit. It is thus a composite document consisting of the application to sue as a pauper and the plaint for the suit. If the application is granted, it is automatically deemed as a plaint to be numbered and registered as</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">such under rule 7 thereof. If it is rejected, one of the reasons for which may be, as stated in rule 5 of Order 33 CPC, that the allegations do not show a cause of action, the plaint goes with it, and nothing survives thereafter for the determination of the Court. The rejection of the application bars a subsequent application of like nature in respect of the same right to sue, but a suit can be instituted in the ordinary manner in respect of such right, subject to the law  limitation and subject to costs (if any) in cuffed by the Provincial Government and the opposite party in opposing the application for leave to sue as a pauper.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mst. Aisha Bibi Vs. Akbar Ali (1968) 20 DLR (SC) 284.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Or. 33, rr. 1-16. Suits by paupers.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Application</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A pauper application is a composite document containing an application for leave and a plaint, <em>1949 (Mad) 162.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">An application for probate or for letters of administration can be filed informa pauperis. <em>1938 (Mad) 486. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A respondent cannot file a review application in forma pauperis. <em>1933 Mad. 177.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Under r.2 the application should contain all particulars required in a plaint. <em>1935 Pat. 193.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The application must contain a schedule of the moveable as well as immovable properties. <em>9 CLJ 610: 74 IC 344.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2300	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Order XXXIV (CPC)</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1953) 5 DLR 290, (1956) 8 DLR 609,  (1951)3 DLR (PC) 212, (1960)12 DLR 261, (1962) 14 DLR 780</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Order</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><u>Order XXXIV (CPC)</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Suits relating to Mortgages of Immovable Property</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Or. 34—Decree on personal covenant—No specific prayer made : Where no specific prayer was made in the plaint for a decree on the basis of personal covenant in the mortgage bond the Court nevertheless would be justified in passing a money decree on the general prayer for further relieves, if there were enough materials on record for such a personal decree.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Kadam Rasul Vs. United Bank, India (1953) 5 DLR 290.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A mortgage decree, meaning of—Personal decree in a mortgage suit: A mortgage decree must be passed in accordance with the provisions of Order 34. Any decree passed in a mortgage suit is not necessarily a mortgage decree.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is open to the parties to a mortgage suit by consent, to have a decree in any form they like. The mortgagor may well waive the benefit of the provisions of a final decree and so also the mortgagee may relinquish his security and content himself with a simple money decree.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Personal decree in a mortgage suit—Nothing remains to be done after the passing of a personal decree.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Ramoni Kansa Lahiri Choudhury Vs. Brajendra K Roy Choudhury (1956) 8 DLR 609.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Or. 34, r. I</strong>—Suit by a prior mortgagee— sub-mortgagee of a subsequent mortgagee, a necessary party—Effect of omission to make subsequent mortgagee a party.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Village M and several other villages were successively mortgaged four times to different sets of persons. The 4th mortgagee created a sub-mortgage under his own mortgage.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The 3rd mortgagee in execution of a mortgage decree in a suit on his own mortgage, in which 2 prior mortgagees and the 4th mortgagee (but not the sub-mortgagee) were made defendants, put the village M to sale and the sale proceeds were applied in payment of the 2 prior mortgages and decretal dues of the 3rd mortgage. As regards the 4th mortgagee, the Court held “he had no rights and interests superior to those of the plaintiff—the 3rd mortgagee”.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Masur Subrameina Shastri Vs. Seshama Rajia (1951)3 DLR (PC) 212.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Or.34, rr.1-16—Suits relating to mortgage.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Application of the rules—</em>These rules arc based on well settled rules of equity which in the absence of any statutory provision to the contrary should be applied to suits on mortgages of movables also. <em>36 CWN 263.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The provisions of Or.34 do not apply to decrees pasted in accordance with award submitted by arbitrators on reference. <em>1930 Lah. 116: 121 IC. 79 : 1.R. 1930 Lah. 175, nor to compromise decree, 1935 Pal. 385.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The provisions of this rule do not apply to a mortgage in favour of a Co-operative Society, <em>1933 Nag. 211.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">R. 1. Parties to suits</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The object of Or. 34, r. It is that all claims affecting the equity of redemption should be disposed of in one and the same Suit. <em>1927 PC 32 : 31 CWN 670 :45 CU 395.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—All persons interested in the mortgage property must be made parties provided the plaintiff has notice. <em>32 CU 479 Pc.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—When a puisne mortgagee is not made party he is not bound by the decree. <em>38 CWN 1178, 40 A 407 PC, 42 (All) 364 PC, 42 CWN 1065, 45 CWN 705.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Or. 34. r. 14 Suit for sale.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">This rule does not apply where the mortgagee decree-holder gives up his charge under the decree and executes it as a mere money decree. 115 IC 829.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Where the mortgage has been declared to be a nullity and the mortgagee obtains a money decree in lieu of what was originally considered to be a mortgage, there being no mortgage subsisting rule 14 cannot apply. <em>1929 (All) 580, (39 (All) 36, 42 All. 566) Ret. on.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Under this rule, a mortgagee, in spite of having sued for a simple money decree in respect of a claim arising under the mortgage, is entitled to institute a suit for sale. <em>119 IC 90.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">This rule prohibits the mortgagee to secure the sale of the mortgaged property without first bringing a suit for sale. <em>1935 (L.ah) 672 : 16 (Lah) 640 FB.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">S. 20</span></strong><strong>—</strong>Suit against a foreign company which carries on no business it Pakistan, if would lie in a Pakistan Court—Company’s local agent, if and when will be liable.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The plaintiff company under a contract of sale purchased certain quantity of cotton yarn from a certain foreign company in Italy through their agent at Chittagong. When the cotton yarn reached Chittagong from Italy the Plaintiff company on taking delivery of them found a large shortage in the quantity of the cotton yarn and also found that the yam supplied was not of the standard specification.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Upon this, after claiming compensation through the agent and that having not been paid the plaintiff- company instituted a suit in a Sub-Judge Court at Chittagong, impicading the foreign company as well as their agent as parties to the suit for recovery of a certain sum of money representing ‘he total loss the plaintiff-company was alleged to have ustained. The question that arose for decision was whether the foreign company was carrying on their business in Pakistan through their agent so as to enable the Court at Chittagong to have jurisdiction to try the plaintiffs suit and whether the agent of the foreign- company at Chittagong was liable for the amount claimed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Held:</em> Elements necessary to constitute a residence, so far as a foreign company is concerned, in order to confer jurisdiction on the Court at Chittagong being absent in this case, the Court at Chittagong had no jurisdiction to entertain the claim as against the foreign-company and further there is nothing to show that the foreign company acted by the agent.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Bubna Mou &amp; Co. Vs. Modern Trading Co. (1960)12 DLR 261.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Suits to be instituted in the Court of lowest grade under whose local jurisdiction the defendant resides and the property are situated.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Rezai Karim Vs. AK Nurer Rahman (1962) 14 DLR 780.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2301	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Pardanashin Woman</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  12 1. DLR 603, 6 DLR 202, 21 DLR 977,  1954 Pesh. 39</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Pardanashin Woman</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong>Pardanashin Woman</strong></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Poor and illiterate though not pardanashin—Document executed by—</strong></p><p>According to the established principle, in cases of a document executed by an illiterate pardanashin lady, the burden lies on those who seek to hold the lady to the terms of her deed to satisfy the Court on evidence that the deed was actually executed by her with full understanding of what she was about to do; that she had full knowledge of the nature and effect of the transaction into which she is said to have entered and that she had independent and disinterested advice in the matter.</p><p>The onus of proving that the plaintiff had actually meant to execute a patta, and entered into the transaction fully aware of it and with full knowledge of its contents and significance is upon the defendants.</p><p>The object of the rule of law, which is applicable to pardanashin ladies, is to protect the weak and helpless, and consequently such a rule should not be restricted to that class only, but should apply to the case of a poor woman who is equally ignorant and illiterate though not a pardanashin in the strict sense of the term.</p><p>Simply because the sub—Registrar made certain enquiries from and asked her whether she had executed the particular document, and that she said that she affixed thumb impression on it, would not lead to the conclusion that the plaintiff had the idea of the nature of the document she executed.</p><p><em>Ayana Dasi Vs. Arena Bala Dasi.(1 960) 12 1. DLR 603.</em></p><p> </p><p>In the case of disposition by a pardanashin lady the onus lies on the person relying on the disposition to establish that the maker of the disposition comprehended it thoroughly and made it deliberately and of her own free will. To discharge this onus, it is not sufficient to show that the allegations made by the person attacking the disposition are untrue.</p><p>Mere proof that execution had been admitted by an illiterate pardanashin lady is not enough. The real point is that the disposition made must be substantially understood and must really be the menial act as its execution is the physical act of the maker.</p><p><em>Abdul Motlab Biswas Vs Matulla (1954) 6 DLR 202</em>.</p><p> </p><p><strong>Pardanashin Lady:</strong></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p>—Onus of proof of a document executed by her. In a case for setting aside a kabala in which the executant is Pardanashin lady the onus heavily lays on the person who claims interest through the disputed Kabala to prove that it was duly executed by the cxecutant.</p><p><em>Tamijur Rahaman Vs. Md. Altafur Rahman (1969) 21 DLR 977.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Pardanshin woman—Agreement with— When voidable.</strong></p><p>When the respondent (pardanashin woman) signed the document while under the appellant’s influence and protection and without independent advice when she was suffering great distress and was unfit to understand how adversely her rights were affected by it, and that in fact she did not understand its meaning and legal consequences. Held: that the agreement embodied in the document is voidabe:</p><p><em>[(Lord Normand) Parikh Atmaram Maneklal vs. Bai Hira : PLD 1948 P C 40]</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Pardanashin woman—Transfer of property by—Transferee must prove affirmatively that transfer was result of free will of Pardanashin—Independent advice— Opportunity for, necessary in case transferee stands in position of confidence.</strong></p><p>It is for the person, who seeks to hold a pardanashin, ignorant and illiterate woman to the terms of the deed, transferring the property to her disadvantage to prove affirmatively that not only the document was read over and explained to her before she put her thumb—impression to it, but that it was the result of her own free will, after she had thoroughly comprehended the terms of the document. If a person deriving benefit under the deed stands towards her in fiduciary character or in some relation of personal confidence, then the Court is to act with greater caution and in ordinary circumstances must presume confidence put and influence exerted. It is for him to bring evidence on the record to show that the lady executing the document was free from all undue influence, and when she executed it, she understood the terms of it quite intelligently and nothing was concealed from her. Generally it is prudent, although the rule is not rigid or inelastic that a woman of the description mentioned above before she disposes of her property to her disadvantage, is given an opportunity to seek independent advice given by a person, who has no interest in the party acting or in the property proposed to be disposed of. It, however, all depends upon the circumstances of the individual case, whether such an advice was necessary or not, and what kind of advice was needed. In cases where the transfer is gratuitous and in favor of a person, who stands towards a woman in fiduciary character or in some relation of personal confidence, the presumption will be still strong against the validity of the deed. [In the present case daughters gave up their rights in the inheritance from their father in favor of their brothers eight days after the death of their father. One of the daughters repudiated the deed of relinquishment within a few days of its execution]:</p><p><em>(Muhammad Ibrahim J.C. and Muhammad Shafi, <u>J</u>.)</em></p><p><em>Muhammad Isa Khan vs. Muhammad Hussain Khan: PLD 1954 Pesh. 39.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2302	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Parsi Marriage and Divorce Act, 1936</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  15 DLR (WP) 105</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Parsi Marriage and Divorce</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Parsi Marriage and Divorce Act</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;">(III of 1936)</p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>S.32 (g)</strong>. Husband filed a petition for divorce against the wife in High Court of West Pakistan, on ground of desertion by wife — Wife, however, already obtained an ex pane decree for judicial separation from Bombay High Court— decree for judicial separation, held, not judgment-in-rem.</p><p><em>Farokh Homi Irani vs. Nargish Farokh (1963) 15 DLR (WP) 105</em>.</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2303	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Parties to Suit—General</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  PLD 1956 Sind 101, PLD 1956 Lah. 479,  PLD 1954 Sind 273 ref,  PLD 2954 Lah 406,  PLD 1951 Sind 32,  PLD 1954 Lah. 406, PLD 1956 Kar. 391, PLD 1954 Lah. 406,  PLD 1954 Dacca 158, PLD 1955 Lah. 644, PLD 1953 Lah. 266, PLD 1950 B J 57</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Parties to Suit—General</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong>Parties to Suit—General</strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong> </strong></p><p><em>—Necessary parties— Proceedings on a petition for writ of quo warranto against the appointment, as Chief Minister of a Province, of a person who was under a disqualification imposed under S. 3 of the Public and Representative Offices (Disqualification) Act, 1949 but the period of whose disqualification was curtailed by an amending order of the Governor— General—Whether the Province or the Federation are necessary or proper parties to proceedings.</em></p><p> </p><p>In a petition for a writ of quo warranto, it was contended by the petitioner that the Governor— General had no power to amend this previous order of disqualification passed against the respondent under section 3 of the Public and Representative Offices (Disqualification) Act, 1949 so as to curtail the period of disqualification of the respondent, and thus to enable the Provincial Governor to appoint the respondent as the Chief Minister of the Province. The respondent put forward a preliminary objection that the Federation and the Province were necessary parties to the writ proceedings. Held, that while they were proper parties, and while, if they had applied for it, they would have been heard they were not necessary parties; that in the circumstances of the case, IL was not desirable, at the expense of an adjournment, to make either of them parties to the proceedings:</p><p><em>[(Constantine, C.J., Vellani and Muhammad Bakhsh, JJ.) Illahi Bakhsh vs. Muhammad Ayoob Khuhro: PLD 1956 Sind 101]</em></p><p> </p><p><em>—Necessary parties—Order of ejectment issued by Deputy Rehabilitation Commissioner under instructions of Central and Provincial Government— Contested by writ petition—Central or Provincial Government nor necessary party.</em></p><p>The mere fact that the Deputy Rehabilitation Commissioner passed order for ejectment of the petitioner at the instance of the Provincial or the Central Government does not render it incumbent upon the petitioner to implead the said Government as parties to the petition</p><p><em>[(Ortcheson and Muhammad Yaqub Ali, JJ) Khadim Mohy-ud-Din vs. D.R.C. Lyallpur: PLD 1956 Lah. 479]</em></p><p> </p><p>—Suit directed against authority under control of Federation of Pakistan—Federation of Pakistan only necessary party. PLD 1954 Sind 273 ref.:</p><p><em>[(Lan, J.) Noorul Hassain vs. Federation of Pakistan: PLD 1955 Sind 2001]</em></p><p> </p><p>—Necessary party means party in whose absence no effective decree can be granted in suit at all—Sec Civil Procedure Code, 0.1. R. 10: PLD 2954 Lah 406.</p><p> </p><p>—Person may be joined as proper party, when Court considers necessary—No common question of law or fact involved—Party need not be added—See Civil Procedure Code, O.I.R. 10: PLD 1951 Sind 32.</p><p> </p><p>—Plaintiffs who were tenants under Municipal Committee sued their servants for possession of shop, who alleged that they were not servants of plaintiff, but tenants under Municipal Committee— Municipal Committee not necessary party—See Civil Procedure Code, O.I.R. 10: <em>PLD 1954 Lah. 406.</em></p><p> </p><p>—“Proper” as distinguished from “necessary” party to suit—’Question involved in suit’—Whether questions between parties to Suit only—See Civil Procedure Code, 0.I.R. 10(2): <em>PLD 1956 Kar. 391.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p>—Proper party means party whose presence is necessary for final adjudication of all matters in dispute—See Civil Procedure Code, 0.I.R. 10: PLD 1954 Lah. 406.</p><p> </p><p>—Suil for specific performance— Subsequent transferee for value— Interested pety—Scc Civil Procedure Code, OJ, R. 10 : PLD 1954 Dacca 158.</p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"> </p><p><strong>Parties to Suit—Adding parties to suit</strong></p><p>—Suit for specific performance—Parties alien to contract may be joined as defendants for the purpose of a complete and effective, adjudication of title— Relief as to possession cannot be claimed against such alien parties—See Civil Procedure Code, 0.1. R. 3etc.: PLD 1955 Lah. 644.</p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Parties to suit—Substitution of Parties to Suit</strong></p><p>—Substitution of defendant—To be effected under O.I.R. 10 CPC and not under 0.VI, R. 17 C.P.C See Civil – See Civil Procedure Code, 0.I.R. 10 etc. PLD 1953 Lah. 266.</p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Parties to Suit—Transposition of Parties</strong></p><p>—No appeal in eye of law before Court—No transposition possible— Sec Civil Procedure Code, 0.I, R. 1O: PLD 1950 B J 57.</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2304	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Partition</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p align="center" style="text-align:center;"><b><u><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Partition</span></u></b></p><p align="center" style="text-align:center;"><b><u><span style='Cambria","serif";'><span style="text-decoration:none"><br/></span></span></u></b></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Partition—co-sharers</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>A person is not entitled to oust hisco-sharer from a plot of land in exclusive possession of the latter on the pleathat he has got title to every inch of the joint property. If he feels that hisco-sharer is in possession of some lands in excess of his share his remedy liesin a suit for partition.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>SefatullaSheik Vs Abjannessa Bibi (1953) 5 DLR 39.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The right ofa co-sharer to have a partition of his share is incidental to his right ofownership. </span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>A co-owner whose title to an undivided shareof joint property is admitted or is clear is entitled to partition as a matterof right. Difficulty in making a division of the subject matter or a resultingprejudice to some of the co-owners, is not a sufficient ground for refusing apartition and it has sometimes been maintained that partition may he claimed,even though it be impossible to divide the property without materiallyimpairing its value, or even totally destroying it.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The fact that the suing co-owners will not beable to get possession of their shares but will have to possess them throughtheir tenants as their tenancy is subsisting is no reason why they should bedenied their right to have a partition.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>JagneswarPal Vs Jgadish Ch. Pal.(1954) 6 DLR 379; (1951) 3 DLR 266 (278).</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The general rule is that a suit for partitionshould embrace the whole tract held by the co-tenancy and if it does not, anyparty interested may insist that the omitted land or lands be included in thesuit.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>MirShariatulla Vs. Abdur Rahman Bepari (1956) 8 DLR 645.</span></i></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—In allotment of shares, a co-sharer shouldget the portion on which he has raised a construction (1959) 11 DLR 530.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—In respect of a portion of the joint estatea suit for partition is maintainable when the portion is jointly held by theplaintiff and defendants even though it leaves out portion of the estate whichis held jointly by defendants and some others. <b>(1956) 8 DLR 645.</b></span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Whether suitcan be instituted leaving out some joint property</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>It cannot be said that in all circumstancesthere is an absolute prohibition in law from instituting a partition suit afterleaving Out some of the properties alleged to be joint properties.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>MuhammadLatif Vs. Muhammad Hafiz (1954) DLR (FC)III</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The general rule which governs a suit forpartition is that it should include the entire joint property of theco-sharers. This general rules can be relaxed and a partial partition allowed,where it is not proved that the parties will be prejudiced or inconvenienced bysuch partition.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>MoniruddinBiswas ys Sohrab Ali Mir (1953) 5 DLR 544.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>A partition suit between members of the samefamily does not preclude a subsequent partition between the same parties asalso against strangers in respect of other properties.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Nazir AhmedSerang Vs. Benoybhusan Saha. (1956) 8 DLR 159.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The Lower Appellate Court excluded certainplot of land from a partition suit on the finding that there is no community ofinterest inasmuch as all the parties have no right, title and interest in thatplot.</span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Held:</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> This was wrong. Partition in a suit is anequitable relief and it should be seen, while decreeing a partition suit, howmuch equity can be done to the parties without asking them to go to anothersuit.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>In this case it has been found by the Courtof appeal below that some of the parties have no rights and title in oneparticular plot but all the persons having interest have been impleaded in thesuit. This finding of the Court below will not exclude the plot from partition.The land will be partitioned among the co-sharers and may be allotted to one ormore of the co-sharers while taking into consideration their shares in otherproperties.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Md. MadguBhuiya Vs. Jabban Haq (1959) 11 DLR 355.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>In a suit for partition the defendantcontended that the suit was not maintainable for defect of parties and for notbringing all the lands of the tenancy into hotchpotch.</span></p><p><b><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Held</span></i></b><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> Tue Suitfor partition without bringing the rest of the land of the tenancy intohotchpotch and without impleading the other parties interested in die land isnot maintainable. 10 PLR (Dac.) 27.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Tenancycreated by a co-sharer, without partition.</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Unless a co-sharer is in exclusive possessionof some of the joint land either by amicable arrangement or on partition bymetes and bounds he is not entitled to induct permanent tenants or let it outpermanently to tenants to the detriment of the other co sharers and the tenancythus created is not valid and binding against the non-consenting co-sharers.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Harendra M.Majumdar vs. Sudhir Ch. Das. (1955) 7 DLR 519.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Purchaser ofspecific portion of land in joint possession is entitled to get possessionthereof till partition.</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The vendee of a co-sharer who owns anundivided land in common with another is clothed with the same rights as thevendor has in the property, no more and no less. If the vendor was in exclusivepossession of a certain portion of the joint land and transfers its possessionto his vendee, so long as there is no partition between the co-sharers, thevendee must be regarded as stepping into the shoes of his transferor ‘qua’ hisownership rights in the joint property, to the extent of the area purchased byhim; provided that the area in question does not exceed the share which thetransferor owns in the whole property. Alienation of specific plots transferredto the vendee would only entitle the latter to retain possession of them tillsuch time an actual partition by metes and bounds takes place between theco-sharers.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Md. MuzaffarKhan Vs. Md. Yusuf Khan. (1959) 11 DLR (SC) 78.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Tenantsinducted by co-sharer in joint land if can maintain a suit for partition</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The principle that if one co-sharer is inpossession of the joint land, the remedy of the other co sharer out ofpossession is to bring a suit for partition and specific possession of hisspecific share, is not applicable in case of tenants inducted by them in thejoint land and they are not entitled to maintain a suit for partition andrecovery of possession against the non—consenting co-sharer and co-sharers.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Harendra M.Mazumdar Vs. Sudhir Ch. Das. (1955) 7 DLR 519 (521—22)</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>It is well known that a co-sharer inpossession may introduce a tenant within his land, and he may realize rent fromhim separately, but that fact by itself does not prove an out and out partitionamongst the different coparceners. The defendants in order to succeed mustprove that there were circumstances which could not be reasonably explainedexcept on the hypothesis that there was a previous partition amongst theco-sharers.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Abdur Razzakvs Abdul Malek Chowdhury (1955) 7 DLR 242.</span></i></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The defendant claimed the land on the basisof a lease granted to them by a fractional co-sharer of the plaintiff. In apartition suit the land was allowed to the share of the plaintiff. The latterthereupon instituted a suit for recovery of khas possession.</span></p><p><b><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Held</span></i></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—The plaintiff is entitled to get a decree for khas possession, he being noparty to the lease it is not binding on him. As soon as by the partition decreethe land is allotted to the plaintiffs share, he is J entitled to it free fromthe tenancy and the defendant’s tenancy under the lease will shift to the shareof the land allotted to the co-sharer who granted the lease. </span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Rahmatullahvs Jambar (1955) 7 DLR 124.</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Co-sharertransferee</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>No inflexible rule can be laid down eitherthat a transferee of a portion of joint property from a co-sharer cannotmaintain a suit for partition in any case, or that he can maintain such a suitin every case.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>MoniruddinBiswas vs. Sohrab Ali Mir (1953) 5 DLR 544.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Where the plaintiff brought a suit forpartition omitting their landlords from whom they got the property as lessees,the suit is not maintainable in the absence of the lessor zamindars. Ibid.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>A suit for partition is incompetent if allthe cc— owners are not parties to the suit as no effective decree can be passedin the absence of every one of them.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>This rule applies also to an appeal, and ifan appeal arising out of suit for partition abates in part the whole appealabates. 7 PLR (Dac.) 619.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Transfer of land during the pendency ofPartition Suit is hit by <i>lis pendens</i>.(1968) 20 DLR 513.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Partitionsuit—whether shares declared by preliminary decree can be amended</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>There is nothing illegal in a preliminarydecree in a partition suit being amended and varied by the court passing thedecree consequent upon the death of one of the parties and the amendment of theshares have been affected even after the dismissal of an appeal from thepreliminary decree. A partition Suit in which only a preliminary decree hasbeen passed is still a pending suit and the rights of the parties have to beadjusted at the time of the final decree.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Md Latif Vs.Md. Hafiz. (1954) 6 DLR (FC) 111.</span></i></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Muhammedanheirs take defined shares but not exclusive portion till partition.</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>It is true that Muslim heirs take defined andascertained shares but that does not necessarily mean that they also take theseshares in separate portions in the properties inherited by them, The share isascertained but not the extent of the lands held by the heirs. For thispurpose, if an heir intends to carve out his definite ascertained share in theproperties, he has inevitably to file a partition suit and until the partitionis effected, he possesses his ascertained share jointly with his co-heirs.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Syed SujatAli vs Sm. Lachman Bibi. (1957) 9 DLR 581—8 PLR (Dac) 525.</span></i></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Co-sharer inexclusive possession of specific land—entitled to retain the same untilpartition.</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The fact that there was no partition by metesand bounds amongst the co-sharers do not justify that one co-sharer inexclusive possession of specific plot of land should be dispossessed by anotherco sharer. If any such co-sharer is dispossessed from his specific land he hasgot the right to recover possession of the land from which he has beendispossessed. If anybody is aggrieved by such exclusive possession of a portionof joint land let him go to the partition suit for his remedy but so long thatis not done the possession of a co-sharer of the specific land must berespected.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Ahmed Miajivs Hakub All Munshi (1960) 12 DLR 708.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>When by private arrangement amongst cosharers, one of them is in exclusive possession of a certain portion of theijmali land a purchaser of the right, title and interest of the latter isentitled to be placed in the same portion as his vendor.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>SefarullaSheik vs Abjannessa Bibi (1953) 5 DLR 39.</span></i></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Valuation ofjurisdiction in partition suit—Payment of Court Fees.</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Plaintiff claiming joint possession in Suitproperty and asking for a separate share of his—fixed court— fee is payable butvalue of plaintiff’s share shall determine the forum both of the suit andappeal — If the object of the suit is partition of the entire property, valueof the entire property will determine the forum of the suit and appeal.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>KhayratullaVs. Kamala Kanta Saha. (1960)12 DLR 329.</span></i></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Where plaintiff in joint possession claims ashare for himself, court’s jurisdiction will not be affected even if defendantgets a share of the value exceeding Court’s pecuniary jurisdiction—The forum ofappeal will be according to the value of the defendant’s share.   Ibid.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Partition suit—Where the plaintiff is out ofpossession—Court fee is to be payable on the plaintiffs share and jurisdictionof the court determinable on the value of the plaintiffs share.        Ibid.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Valuation, for jurisdiction, in partitionsuit—Where plaintiff is out of possession, valuation for the purpose ofjurisdiction is the same as that for the purpose of court fees.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Patak Ch.Halder Vs. Sademan Howlader (1957) 9 DLR 190.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Valuation in the partition suit forjurisdiction, where plaintiff is in joint possession — to be calculated at thevalue of the share claimed by the plaintiff.        Ibid.</span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>HinduLaw—Mitakshara School</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Partition of the family property by thefather— Sons born thereafter cannot reopen it.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Rai MohanChowdhury Vs Tejindra Lal Chodhury (1956) 8 DLR 577.</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>In a partition suit a defendant can ask forthe separation of his share too.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>A suit for partition remains pending till thepassing of the final decree. 1953 PLR (Lah.) 545</span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Partition,instrument of—Unstamped</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>‘Unstamped memoranda of a partition whichrequire to be stamped as constituting an instrument of partition cannot beadmitted in evidence even for any purpose.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>AminullahBhuiyan &amp; ors. Vs. Abdul Hafiz &amp; ors. (1981) 33 DLR  (AD) 282.</span></i></p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span> </div></div>
2305	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Partition Act, 1983</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1954) 6 DLR 379, 1 PLR (Dac) 844, (1959) 11 DLR 355, 7 PLR (Dac) 945, (1960) 12 DLR 649, (1957) 9 DLR 119, 13 DLR 347, (1968) 20 DLR 489, (1974) 26 DLR 96, (1982) 34 DLR 245, (1984) 36 DLR 351, 8 PLR (Dac.) 778, 1 PLR (Dac.) 844</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Partition </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Partition Act (IV OF 1983)</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p><strong>S.2. Persons owing interests, which are not coordinate in degree can claim partition and get relief.</strong></p><p>Persons in joint possession have a right to partition although their rights may not be identical; Section 2 of the Partition Act provides that if it appears to the court that by reason of the nature of the property or of any other special circumstances a division of the property cannot conveniently be made and that a sale of the property and distribution of the proceeds would be more beneficial for all the shareholders, the court may direct sale of the property and a distribution of the assets.</p><p>Financial condition of either of the parties cannot be a guide for application of the provisions of section 2 of the Act.</p><p><em>Santa Kumari De Vs. Nanda Kumar De (1951) 3 DLR 266; (1954) 6 DLR 379.</em></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>S.4. Relief may be granted in the execution proceeding.</strong></p><p>Relief under section 4 of the Partition Act may be granted in the execution proceeding in a partition suit. Its provision shows that the time for granting relief is co-extensive with the partition proceeding which commences with institution of the Suit and terminates with the delivery of possession. PLR (Dac.) 844.</p><p> </p><p>There is no reason to limit the operation of the section up to the stage of the final decree nor is there anything to limit the word “Court” to the Thai court and the appellate court only and not to include the executing court. Ibid.</p><p> </p><p><strong>Executing Court not to amend the final decree—but to give direction.</strong></p><p>When the executing court grants relief under section 4 of the Partition Act, the said court is not to amend the final decree but to make an order directing conveyance by the party concerned within a specified time failing which the court will execute the conveyance at the cost of the other party in whose favor the conveyance is to be executed. Such order is deemed to be a decree under section 8 of the Partition Act. 1 PLR (Dac) 844.</p><p> </p><p>This section is equally applicable to a suit brought by a co-sharer and not only when a suit under the section is brought by a 3<sup>rd</sup> party purchaser.</p><p>Section 4 of the Partition Act will apply not only when a suit is brought by a stranger — purchaser for partition of a dwelling house but also in a case instituted by any other co-sharer, because in a suit for partition all the parties are in the capacity of plaintiffs.</p><p>When a partition suit is instituted every co sharer, will be entitled to have a share in the joint properties and will be in a position to proceed with the suit.</p><p>The criterion to decide whether section 4 of the Act will apply or not will be whether a stranger-purchaser is going to have a share in the dwelling house belonging to an undivided family.</p><p><em>Md. Madgu Bhuiya vs Jabban Haq (1959) 11 DLR 355.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Residence, whether necessary.</strong></p><p>In order to get the benefit of section 4 of the Partition Act, it is not necessary that a person must live in the family dwelling—house. It is not the residence but the ownership of the dwelling house that entitles a person to apply under section 4 of the Act. <em>7 PLR (Dac) 945.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Plaintiff entitled to purchase share of undivided family property from a stranger transferee or ask for partition.</strong></p><p>The question is whether a plaintiff, who is not a transferee in respect of a share of a dwelling house belonging to an undivided family, but a member of the family and a share—holder of the dwelling house, can claim to purchase the share of a stranger-transferee?</p><p><strong><em>Held</em></strong>— The right of pre—emption in relation to a dwelling house as envisaged and authorized in section 4 of the Partition Act is exercisable by a member of an undivided family not only when a stranger— transferee figures as a plaintiff, but also as a defendant in a partition suit, and claims a saham out of the homestead.</p><p>The object of the section 4 of the Partition Act is to prevent intrusion of strangers in the dwelling— house of an undivided family. This object would be frustrated if a stranger—purchaser forces himself into the dwelling house of an undivided family, drives the other co—owners to file a suit as plaintiffs, and then figuring as a defendant is allowed to defeat the claim for pre-emption under sec. 4 of the Act on a narrow and literal interpretation of the section. In a suit for partition, the parties to the suit arc in the position of the counter—claimants, and it can very well be predicated of a defendant in a suit for partition that he is suing for partition.</p><p>The language of section 4 does not militate against the view that the object of the Legislature being to prevent intrusion by strangers to the dwelling—house of an undivided family, the terms of section 4 should be liberally construed.</p><p><em>Bhaba Kanta Joddar Vs. Satish Ch. Mandal, (1960) 12 DLR 649.</em></p><p> </p><p>A stranger-purchaser of a dwelling-house of an undivided family is not entitled to get joint possession or other common or part enjoyment of the house. His only remedy is to file a suit for partition and for specific possession on partition of his share, subject to the right of co-sharer under section 4 of the Partition Act.</p><p><em>Md. Habibulla Patwari Vs. Pranballav Bhakta (1957) 9 DLR 119.</em></p><p> </p><p>Where plaintiff is a stranger to the joint Hindu family—he is not entitled to a share on partition in the homestead of the family.</p><p><em>Radha Chandra Sardar vs Harihar Mondal (1961) 13 DLR 347.</em></p><p> </p><p>The applicability of the section depends on certain factors. The prerequisites to the applicability of section 4 are:-</p><p style="margin-left: .5in;">(1) The property must be a dwelling house.</p><p style="margin-left: .5in;">(2) It must belong to an undivided family.</p><p style="margin-left: .5in;">(3) There must be transfer of a share of the dwelling house.</p><p style="margin-left: .5in;">(4) The transferee must be a person who is not a member of the undivided family.</p><p style="margin-left: .5in;">(5) There must be a suit for partition.</p><p style="margin-left: .5in;">(6) One or more members of the undivided family must undertake to purchase the share of the transferee</p><p> </p><p>The above fundamental requirements of law must be satisfied before the benefit of section 4 can be claimed by a member of the undivided family.</p><p>Section 4 was enacted to afford protection to the members of an undivided family against a stranger purchaser. Its simple object was to prevent intrusion into the dwelling house of an undivided family by strangers on the basis of purchase of some share in such dwelling house.</p><p><em>Md. Habibullah Vs. Mvi. Saleh Chowdhury, (1968) 20 DLR 489.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Dwelling house, buying up share by share-holder—</strong></p><p>Elements necessary for attracting section 4 of Partition Act are (i) the house belongs to an undivided family; (ii) the share thereof has been transferred to one who is not a member of such undivided family and (iii) the transferee should sue for partition.</p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Partition suit—</strong></p><p>In a Suit for partition the plaintiff and the defendant stand on the same footing with regard to a party’s capability to ‘sue’ and to be ‘sued’.</p><p>Dwelling house, buying tip the share of the transferee—For buying up the shares of the transferee the transferee must be found to have sued at the relevant time when actually the partition suit under section 4 of the Partition Act is filed.</p><p>In a partition Suit a particular plaintiff or a defendant might have prayed for having their shares partitioned but unfortunately for some reason or other they might have given up that claim and in that case it cannot be said while considering a petition under section 4 of the Partition Act that the petitioner can be allowed to buy up the shares of those parties who subsequently gave up their claim. The transferee must be found to have sued at the relevant time when actually the partition Suit under section 4 of the Partition Acts is filed for buying up the shares of the transferee.</p><p><em>Kefatulla Sikdar Vs. Korban Sk. (1974) 26 DLR 96.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>Female member of undivided family upon marriage goes to the husband’s house— No longer to be treated as a member of the undivided family.</strong></p><p>A female member of an undivided family who marries and goes to live in her husband’s house prima fade gives up her intention of continuing to reside in her old house and so she is prima facie no longer a member of the family and as such she is not entitled to the benefit of section 4 of the Partition Act.</p><p><em>Abdul Gani Vs. Asifadullah (1982) 34 DLR 245.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>“Undivided family” means undivided qua the dwelling house—When there was no partition of the dwelling house.</strong></p><p>“An undivided family” must be taken to mean, “Undivided qua the dwelling house in question and to be a family which owns the house but has not divided it.”</p><p><em>Azizur Rahman Vs. Jugal Kishori Sarkar (1984) 36 DLR 351.</em></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>When claim u/s. 4 arises </strong></p><p>—When a stranger transferee sues for partition then only the claim under section 4 of the Partition Act can be laid. Ibid.</p><p>—Section 4 will apply also in a case instituted by a co-sharer. Ibid.</p><p>Under section 4 only the area actually covered by the dwelling house can be claimed by the co sharer and not any area beyond that. Ibid</p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>S. 4 (I) The conditions to be fulfilled for application of the section 4(I).</strong></p><p>The house concerned should be in actual use though not necessarily in constant occupation. Grant of a tenancy (not a permanent and irrevocable lease) will not have the effect of making a house owned by members of an undivided family cease to be a dwelling—house.</p><p><em>Md. Tozammal Hossain vs. Purni Agarwalini (1958) 10 DLR 318—8 PLR (Dac.) 778</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Where co-sharer has permanently left the country—whether he can invoke the provisions of sub-section.</strong></p><p>The principle that the creation of a tenancy by co-sharer owner does not terminate the possibility of his returning to its occupation and, therefore the provisions of section 4(I) of the Partition Act are available to him as a co-sharer has no application where the co-sharer owner has left the country, where the house is situated for good.</p><p><em>Priya Sarkar Sen vs. Abdul Wahed Sheik (1960) 12 DLR 584.</em></p><p><strong>S. 8</strong>. Orders under section 4 arc deemed to be a decree under section 8. (See under section 4, above). 1 PLR (Dac.) 844.</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2306	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Partition Suit</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1960) 13 DLR 115, (1961) 13 DLR (SC) 191, (1961) 13 DLR 765, (1967)19 DLR 344,  (1969) 21 DLR 97, (1969) 21 DLR 423, (1981) 33 DLR (AD) 347, (1984) 36 DLR 290</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Partition </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Partition Suit</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u> </u></strong></p><p><strong>Partition—suit for, by mortgagee—Suit for partition by a usufructuary mortgagee of an undivided share—maintainable.</strong></p><p>In the present case the question for consideration is whether it is necessary to have a partition to give effect to the transfer i.e. the mortgage in favor of the plaintiff.</p><p>The mortgage in the present case is a usufructuary one and so the plaintiff is entitled to possession of the mortgaged property. Partition is, therefore, necessary for giving possession to the plaintiff— mortgagee.</p><p>Suit for partition is maintainable at the instance of the usufructuary mortgagee whether he is in actual possession or out of possession of the mortgaged land, provided the mortgagor is a party to the Suit and the suit is necessary for giving effect to the mortgage.</p><p>In case the mortgagee be not in actual possession of the mortgaged land it would be necessary to pray not only for partition but also for khas possession of the share allotted to him on ejectmcnt of other co-sharers from that portion.</p><p><em>Md. Eshaque vs. Afzal Ahmed (1960) 13 DLR 115.</em></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Where defendant also asks for partition of his share—procedure to follow—Effect on the jurisdiction of the Court when defendant joins in asking a share.</strong></p><p>If a defendant wants to get his share by partition the ordinary rule should be that he files a suit for it. He may however be allowed to make such claim even in a written statement provided he pays court fee on this claim.</p><p>In such a case, truly speaking, the written statement is only a plaint, and proceedings in the two suits, that is one filed by the plaintiff and the other by the defendant, arc deemed to be consolidated and the answer to the question as to what is henceforth the jurisdictional value of the suit would depend upon whether the Court regard the two suits as one or regard it an ordinary case of consolidation. If it is a simple consolidation of two suits, i.e., there is no effect on jurisdictional value. If the view is taken that the defendant who has prayed for a partition of his share should also be regarded as plaintiff in the suit then the jurisdictional value would be the total of the values of the shares of the plaintiff and of those defendants who claim to have their shares separated.</p><p><em>Ajiruddin Mondal vs. Rahman Fakir (1961) 13 DLR (SC) 191.</em></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Plaintiff out of possession—Claim amounts to asking for two reliefs.</strong></p><p>When the plaintiff is out of possession of joint property the grant to him of separate possession of his partitioned share amounts really to two reliefs. (1) Joint possession of his share, and (2) the transformation of that joint possession into separate possession of his partitioned share, for a plaintiff out of possession is not entitled to partition unless he first gels joint possession. Ibid</p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Partition suits and suit for mesne profits, drawing up of the final decree.</strong></p><p>In partition suits and in suits for mesne profits, the drawing up of the final decree may depend upon the filing of the necessary stamp paper or court fees.</p><p><em>Barada Prasanna vs. Kobbad Mia (1961) 13 DLR 765.</em></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>A surplus of two decimals of land with nobody to claim it—No other co-sharer being in existence, the suit for partition maintainable.</strong></p><p>The trial court has discovered that a residium of 2 decimals of land would ensue on a computation of he figures that have been given by the parties to the suit. True, but it does not follow that, of necessity, there must be another co-sharer in existence with regard to the aforesaid 2 decimals of land which appears to be a surplus on actual measurement of land as claimed by the parties.</p><p>In this view of the matter there is no substance in the argument that the prayer for partition is incompetent without impleading a co-sharer whose existence has not been proved and who may not exist at all.</p><p><em>Bazlur Rahman vs. Mahmudur Rahman Bhuiyan (1967)19 DLR 344.</em></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Partition suit remained pending till the passing of the final decree.</strong></p><p>The judgment does not clearly lay down the shares of the respective parties and also about the allotment of saham. We do not consider that there is any bar in the learned Subordinate Judge’s doing so, for a partition suit remains pending till the passing of the final decree.</p><p><em>Muzaffar Vs. Kabiruddin, (1969) 21 DLR 97.</em></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Partition suit—where plaintiff (co-sharer) out of possession of his share of property— Remedy lies in a partition suit.</strong></p><p>Plaintiff having right and title in respect of his share to the property in suit but being out of possession, his remedy for separate possession lies in a partition suit.</p><p><em>Haji Sorkum Ali Vs. Huson Ali (1969) 21 DLR 423.</em></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Declaration of title in a partition suit when not necessary.</strong></p><p>The main question is whether the Suit IS maintainable without declaration of title of the plaintiffs. On the death of Sachindra his title passed on to the plaintiffs, his minor sons, and his widow, defendant No. I, but the plaintiffs for some reason or other was thrown out of possession, according to the defendant No.2 since their father’s death. But their dispossession will not disentitle them to recover possession on payment of ad—valorem court—fee. The suit is not barred by limitation as the suit has been filed within one year of attainment of majority by plaintiff no.1. He is entitled to file the suit within three years from attainment of his majority as laid down in section 6 of the Limitation Act. During the period of their minority plaintiffs’ title was not extinguished and as such there is no necessity for getting a declaration of their title. The view taken by j the High Court Division that the suit is not maintainable without declaration of title is clearly erroneous.</p><p><em>Sanjib Kumar Bose &amp; another, Vs. Syed Shamsuddin Ahmed. (1981) 33 DLR (AD) 347.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Partition suit—</strong> General rule that all joint properties be included is a rule of equity and can be relaxed when necessary on this ground of equity and convenience.</p><p><em>Md. Shahidul Alam Khan Vs. Md. Gulzar Alam (1984) 36 DLR 290.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2307	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Partnership Act, 1932 [Section 1- 40]</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1949) 1 DLR (PC) 5, 110—PLR 1964(2) W.P. 235. (Bashir-ud-Din, J.), PLD 1966 Supreme Court 328. (Hamoodur Rahman, J), PLR 1962(2) W.P. 929 (DB). (Kharal, J), PLR 1962 Dacca 1419 (FB). (Chowdhury, J,), PLD 1961 (W.P.) Karachi 265 (DB) (Wahiduddin, J),  PL</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Partnership </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Partnership Act</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;">(IX OF 1932)</p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"> </p><p><strong>S. 4.  Partnership business—Accounts in the bank.</strong></p><p>Mere fact that the bank account of a business was in the name of proprietor and his manager will not show that they were partners.</p><p><em>Hubert James Vs. Gulam Hussain Paksuma (1949) 1 DLR (PC) 5.</em></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Cause of action arising after death of partner—Suit by firm not competent.</strong></p><p>When the suit was instituted one of the partners in the firm was dead and the cause of action had also arisen after his death. It was held that the suit was i incompetent at the time of its institution and no amendment of plaint could be permitted after limitation for the suit had expired.</p><p><em>Shujaul-Mulk vs. Firm Abdul Ghafoor, PLD 1964 Pesh. 110—PLR 1964(2) W.P. 235. (Bashir-ud-Din, J.)</em></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Creation of partnership—Oral agreement— Valid.</strong></p><p>The Partnership Act does not prescribe any special mode for the creation of a partnership which can validly come into being even upon an oral agreement between the partners.</p><p><em>Usman vs. Haji Omer Haji Ayub, PLD 1966 Supreme Court 328. (Hamoodur Rahman, J).</em></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Ss. 4, 6—Partnership—How may be determined—Facts and circumstances must be looked into.</strong></p><p>The question whether there is a relation of partnership in any particular case will depend on the facts and circumstances brought out in each case or in the words of section 6 “regard shall be had to the real relation between the parties as shown by all relevant facts taken together.”</p><p><em>Essa E.H. Jaffar vs. Nishat Ltd., PLD 1962 (W.P.) Karachi 603 =PLR 1962(2) W.P. 929 (DB). (Kharal, J).</em></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>—S. 5— Relation of partnership—How arises.</strong></p><p>The relation of partnership under the Partnership Act arises from contract and not from status.</p><p><em>Noor Hossain Vs. Commr. Income-Tax, PLD 1964 Dacca 373=PLR 1962 Dacca 1419 (FB). (Chowdhury, J,).</em></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>S.6, Expl. I—Joint lease of agricultural land—Joint management and sharing of profits—Not enough to prove partnership.</strong></p><p>The land in dispute was taken on lease jointly by two persons. It was contended that they were partners on that score.</p><p>Held: The respondent only alleged that the land in dispute was obtained by the parties jointly with a view to share profits. That by itself cannot make this adventure as of partnership and will not make the relationship of the parties as that of partners. According to section 6 of the Partnership Act in determining whether a group of persons is or is not a firm, or whether a person is or is not a partner in a firm, regard shall be had to the real relation between the parties; as shown by all persons. Holding a joint or common interest in that property does not of itself make persons partners.
