Thus, in the absence of any allegation of the respondent that the lease was obtained by them as partners or that the land in dispute was to be cultivated in order to carry on a partnership business, and further in the absence of any case of the appellant that the lease was obtained in partnership and the parties were carrying on any partnership business, it is difficult to appreciate how the question of partnership can arise in the present case. It, however, appears that if the co—owners of the land or the co—lessees of the land are shown not to have any interest in the land other than of receiving their share of its income that by itsself would not make them partners.</p><p><em>Mobarak Ali Shah vs. Muhammad Sadiq, PLD 1961 (W.P.) Karachi 265 (DB) (Wahiduddin, J)</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>S. 8—One transaction—If partnership can be for one transaction only.</strong></p><p>Under S. 8 a partnership can be for one transaction or one adventure only.</p><p><em>Muhammad Zakria vs. Mazahar Ali, PLD 1961 (W. P) Karachi 213 (DB) (Wahiduddin, J).</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Ss. 11, 44—Agreement between parties—Should be subject to Partnership Act—Court’ power to dissolve partnership cannot be taken away by agreement between partners.</strong></p><p>Section 11 of the Partnership Act, which provides for the determination of rights and duties of partners, by agreement between them, has been made subject to the provisions of Partnership Act, meaning thereby that no such agreement can override the provisions of the Partnership Act, but would be subordinate to it. No limitation, however, is placed on the power conferred by section 32 of the Act, on a partner to retire from the partnership, by agreement with the other partners, but this does not mean that such an agreement between them can override any other provisions of the Partnership Act, specially those of section 44, which permit a Court to dissolve a firm under certain conditions. Sections 32 and 44 of the Act being both independent provisions of law, one cannot override the other and hence, the argument that an agreement entered into between the partners permitting one of them to retire, would take away the power of the Court to dissolve such a partnership under section 44 of the Act, has no force.</p><p><em>Muhammad Yaseen Vs. Mahammad Yasin, PLD 1961 (W.P.) Lahore 468. (Masud, J.) </em>(Rel A I R 1917 P.C. 116).</p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>S. 14—Goodwill—Place of business is always part of goodwill.</strong></p><p>The place of business of a firm is not invariably a part of its goodwill.</p><p><em>Peshoton vs. Peerozshaw, PLD 1962 (W.P.) Karachi 293=PLR 1962 (I) WP. 880. (Qadeeruddin, J).</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>S. 14—Rent paid in form of services—Interest in property—Forms part of assets of firm.</strong></p><p>If a lease is created by agreement of the parties in which rent is paid in the form of service rendered to the owners of the property, it is interest in the property and would form a part o the assets of the firm in terms of section 14 of the Partnership Act.</p><p><em>Peshoton vs. Peerozshaw, PLD 1962 (W.P.) Karachi 293=PLR 1962 (I) WP. 880. (Qadeeruddin, J).</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Scope—Does not override provisions of Registration Act.</strong></p><p>The provisions of Section 14 of the Partnership Act which describes the property of the firm, and section 46 of the same Act which deals with the right of partners to have business wound up after dissolution, do not override the mandatory provision of the Indian Registration Act.</p><p><em>Zainab Bai vs. Ibrahimji, PLD 1962 (W.P.) Karachi 209 =PLR 1962 (1) W.P. 530. (Faruqui, J.).</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>S 17(a): </strong>Partnership firm may be reconstituted when one of the partners dies, resigns, or ceases to be a partner and the other partners may continue the business.</p><p><em>The Eastern Agencies Vs. Alhaj Mafizuddin (1968) 20 DLR 1056.</em></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>S. 18</strong>: It is true, a partner may, subject to the provisions of the Partnership Act, bind the firm itself. But in this case a specific provision has been made to the effect that while applying for registration under section 26—A of the Act, the application shall be signed by all the partners. Section 18 of the Partnership Act cannot override the provision of another Central Act, namely, 26A of the Income Tax Act and compel the Income Tax Authorities to accept the application filed by some of the partner. The Partnership Act is a general law which will go era the business transaction of the firm but cannot over—ride a specific provision made in section 26A of the Income Tax Act. In fact this specific provision shall override the general provisions made in the Partnership Act.</p><p><em>M/S Essential Industries Dacca Vs. Commissioner of Income Tax (1968) 20 DLR 1204.</em></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Ss. 18, 19, 22—Partner signing agreement as “of E &amp; Co”—Deemed to have signed on behalf of partnership.</strong></p><p>When a partner R. of the E &amp; Co. signed a contract as “of R of E and Co.” It was held that in the circumstances of the case he would be held to have signed the contract on behalf of the Company.</p><p><em>Hassanally Shah Vs.  Engineering &amp; Co. PLD 1966 Kar. 52 (DB). (Inamullah, J).</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>S. 19(2)(b): </strong>Partnership entered into by two firms—Deed of partnership signed by one partner of one firm on his own behalf alone, and by one partner of the other firm on behalf of his firm— bigger partnership not formed.</p><p><em>S.A. Rahim &amp; Ors. Vs. Commr. I Tax Punjab (1959) 11 DLR (SC) 289.</em></p><p><strong>Secs. 19(2)(f)—Power of transfer of immovable properties.</strong></p><p>It is clear from section 19(2)(f) of the Act that in the absence of any usage or custom of the trade to the contrary, the implied authority does not include the power to transfer immoveable properties belonging to the firm.</p><p>In the absence of an express authority two of the partners of the firm had no authority to transfer the immoveable properties of the firm even though the deed of sale was executed on behalf of the firm. 2 PLR (Dac.) 187.</p><p> </p><p><strong>S. 20—Partner—Public may presume every partner has authority to act on behalf of other partners—Liability of other partners for act of a partner.</strong></p><p>The public have a right to assume that every partner has authority from his co-partners to bind the whole firm in contracts made according to the ordinary usages of the trade. In a trading concern a partner has implied authority to accept and draw bills on behalf of the firm. Even if the authority to do so has been cancelled and such cancellation has not been brought to the notice or knowledge of a discounting bank, the bank is entitled to recover as against the other partners also.</p><p><em>Suleman Ibrahim vs. Eastern Rice Syndicate, PLD 1966 (W.P.) Karachi 289. (Ghulamally, J.).</em></p><p> </p><p>—A firm can only be made liable for what is done by one of it’s members. on the supposition that the action in question was authorized by the other members. Now, as by law they arc held prima facie to authorize all acts done in carrying on the business. of the firm in the usual way, they cannot escape liability for any act of this character unless they can show that the apparent authority to do it did not exist, and was known not to exist. But when it is sought to make the firm liable for some act not prima fade authorized by it. an actual authority by it must be shown; and if this cannot be done, no case is made out against the firm, however, ignorant the person seeking to charge it may have been of what was authorized and what was not. In the case now supposed the firm did not mislead him; and if he was misled by the representations of the partner with whom he dealt, his remedy is against that partner; just as when an agent untruly represents his authority, a person dealing with him acquires no right against the principal but must look to the agent for indemnity.</p><p><em>Aziz-ur-Rahman vs. Bahawalnagar Corp: Commn. Shop Ltd., PLD 1962 Baghdadul—Jadid 20=PLR 1962 (2) W.P. 359 (DB). (Bashiruddin, J).</em></p><p> </p><p>Opening of account in the name of individual partners, will bind the partnership firm.</p><p><em>Sachindra Kumar Saha vs. Eastern Banking Corporation Ltd. (1967) 19 DLR 200.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>S. 25—Firm liable—Suit may be brought against firm or partners—Ail partners need not be impleaded.</strong></p><p>If the firm is liable, then it is left to the plaintiff to make his choice as to whether he wants to sue all the partners of the firm or some of them. Under Order XXX, rule 1, Civil Procedure Code, a plaintiff is not debarred from making his choice in the above mentioned matter. The rule is a permissive one and does not make it incumbent on a plaintiff to sue a firm in the name of the firm. The liability of the partners of a firm being joint and several, any one of the partners could be sued with reference to the liability of the firm.</p><p><em>Nazar Mohd. Vs. Shafiq Ahmad, PLD 1963 (W.P.) Lahore 23 N.A. Mahmood, J.)</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>S. 30—Minor—Cannot create partnership—May be admitted to benefits of partnership.</strong></p><p>A minor cannot create a partnership but it cannot be said that by being merely admitted to the benefits of a partnership he also becomes a partner. There is no reason why the inclusion of the minors should render the constitution of the firm itself invalid when there were at least two adult partners, besides the minors, who could lawfully have entered into the partnership. Under section 26—A of the Income—Tax Act two conditions have only to be satisfied, firstly, that the firm has been constituted under an instrument of partnership, and, secondly, that the instrument has specified the shares of the partners. If these conditions are satisfied, the firm is entitled to registration.</p><p><em>Commr. of I-T. vs. Amin Match Works, PLD 1964 Supreme Court 337=(1964) 16 DLR (S.C. 183. (Hamoodur Rahman, J).</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>—Minor and partnership</strong></p><p>A minor cannot be admitted into partnership, but he can be admitted to the benefits of partnership under section 30 of the Partnership Act with the consent of all partners for the time being.</p><p><em>Maya Ray vs. Mrs. Dorothy Watts. (1954) 6 DLR 285.</em></p><p> </p><p>The minor becomes a partner unless within six months of his attaining majority or of his obtaining knowledge that he had been admitted to the benefits, whichever date is later, he elects by public notice not to become a partner of the firm.</p><p>The consequence of the attainment of majority of a partner in a partnership firm is that the contract so far as it seeks to make him a partner, and as such, make him personally liable for the act of the firm, is not effective. But the partnership agreement as between the adult is valid, the minor would be deemed to have been admitted to the benefits of the partnership. Ibid.</p><p>A contract entered into by a minor is void. But the doctrine of the minor’s incapacity is a doctrine for his protection by preventing others from injuring him by taking advantage of his incompetence.   Ibid.</p><p>Partnership is an agreement and agreement with a minor is void. No doubt under sec. 30 of the Partnership Act a minor can be admitted to the benefits of partnership, but in order that section 30 may apply there should be a partnership already in existence and cases where a minor became a partner from the very inception of partnership are beyond the scope of sec. 30. <em>1955 PLR (Lah) 588.</em></p><p> </p><p>—Minors acquire interest in partnership business by right of inheritance—To such a case section 30 not applicable.</p><p><em>Commissioner of Income Tax, Vs. Msi. Safiya Bai (1979) 31 DLR (AD) 41.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>S. 30(1)—Minor—When may be admitted to benefits of partnership—Status of such minor.</strong></p><p>For the applicability of S. 30 (1), two things are required, namely: (1) the existence of a valid partnership on the benefits of which a minor may be admitted, and (ii) the mutual consent of the partners to admit a minor to the benefits of that partnership.</p><p>The minors admitted to benefits of partnership are only beneficiaries under that section and not partners. Although a partner, for the purposes of Income Tax Act, includes a minor who has been admitted to the benefits of partnership, a partner within the meanings of the Partnership Act does not include a minor.</p><p><em>Amin Match Works vs. Commissioner of Income Tax, PLD 1964 Dacca 295 (DB). (M.R. Khan, J).</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Secs. 30(1) and 11: </strong>A minor may be included in partnership and when included it means he has been admitted to the benefits of partnership and he cannot be made liable personally, his liability is limited to the extent o his share in the partnership—Technical defect that the minor has been described as a partner if the document instead of showing him as ‘admitted to the benefits of partnership is no ground to refuse registration of a firm under section 26—A of the Income Tax Act.</p><p><em>Messrs Ittehad Textile Mills Multan Vs. Commissioner of Income Tax, (1969) 21 DLR (WP) 325.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>S. 37. Outgoing partners’ right in the partnership—asset of the partnership—Principles which govern the assessment of the outgoing (or deceased) partner in the assets of the partnership.</strong></p><p>The outgoing partner has either to claim a share in the profits made since he ceased to be a partner in so far as that may be attributable to the use of his1 share of the property of the firm or to claim interest at the rate of 6% per annum.</p><p>The principle accepted is that the deceased or the outgoing partner has rights over all the assets of the partnership and that this right is in the nature of an unascertained interest in every single item of asset thereof. He cannot be regarded merely as a person entitled to a particular sum of cash ascertained upon the striking of balance. If the continuing partners choose to carry on the business they obviously utilize the assets of the partnership and are thus placed in a fiduciary position with regard to the share of the outgoing partner in those assets. This makes them liable to account for whatever profits are attributable to such user.</p><p><em>Usman vs. Omar Haji (1966) 18 DLR (SC) 322.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Existing partners entitled to profits attributable to their personal skill or assets supplied by them alone</strong>— or it may be that the profits have been earned by reason of the fact that the remaining partners themselves provided further assets and further capital by means of which the business became a profitable one. Under this system of accounting, if insisted upon by the outgoing partner under section 37 of the Partnership Act, it will be t open for the remaining partners to claim to be recompensed for the skill and labor employed by them in the conduct of the business after dissolution and they will also be entitled to prove what portion, if any, of the profits was obtained not by reason of the use of the partnership assets but in some other manner. Ibid.</p><p>—Outgoing partner’s option under the section regarding his share—Courts cannot substitute its own option in place of that of the outgoing partner. Ibid.</p><p> </p><p><strong>S. 39 (dissolution of a firm).</strong></p><p>Retirement of a partner from a partnership firm and dissolution of the firm are quite distinct.</p><p>Retirement of a partner from a firm and dissolution of the firm are quite distinct and a clear distinction exists between the two concepts, inasmuch as the consequences flowing from each are entirely different.</p><p><em>Liu Ying Ping Vs. Leon Fang Ai (1984) 36 DLR (AD) 273.</em></p><p> </p><p>—Immovable property of partner held in a partner farm—transfer of such property by a partner does not require registration u/s. 17(1) of the Registration Act being treated as a moveable property.   Ibid</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2308	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Partnership Act, 1932 [Section 41- 69]</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  7 PLR (Dac) 23, 20 DLR 41,  7 PLR (Dac.) 23, 12 DLR (SC) 259,  8 DLR 381, 12 DLR (SC) 259, 7 PLR (Dac.) 23, 7 DLR 615, 12 DLR (SC) 259, 17 DLR 677, 12 DLR (SC) 259, 19 DLR 69, </p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Partnership </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u> </u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Partnership Act</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;">(IX OF 1932)<span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p><p> </p><p><strong>S. 42.When a firm is dissolved: </strong></p><p>Where a disputed partnership was to carry out one or more adventures or undertakings and in the absence of a contract to the contrary, the firm is dissolved, by the completion thereof under section 42 of the Partnership Act, where it is not made out that hr partnership was to continue even after the completion of the adventure or under staking. <em>7 PLR (Dac) 23.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>S. 42. Prosecution of the suit, when partnership dissolves.</strong></p><p>Partnership (consisting of 2 persons) is dissolved due to retirement of one of the partner during the pendency of the suit—Remaining partner competent to proceed with the Suit and upon decree passed therein competent to execute the decree in the name of the partnership.</p><p><em>Menon Trading Co. Vs. Hajee Gaffar Hajee Habib Janoo (1968) 20 DLR 41.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Sec 43 and 44: </strong>The prayer in the plaint for pronouncing a firm as dissolved cannot be construed as a prayer for dissolution by the court. <em>7 PLR (Dac.) 23</em></p><p>—A partnership account should cover all the transactions of the partnership. A commission for examination of accounts should not be issued unless the court is satisfied that an examination and adjustment is necessary.</p><p><em>Md. Mustafa Chowdhury Vs Sudhangshu Bimal Biswas (1956) 8 DLR 381.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Sec 43 and 69: Dissolution by notice of partnership at will—Effect of non-registration of a firm.</strong></p><p>An oral agreement was arrived at between the appellant and respondent that they would carry on jointly the business of military contracts on the basis of equal share in profits and losses, and the business was carried on till the end of March, 1946, when all war contracts ceased.</p><p>A suit thereafter was brought for a declaration of dissolution of partnership and rendering of accounts. The existence of partnership was denied and the liability for rendering accounts too. Maintainability of the suit was also questioned.</p><p><strong><em>Held</em></strong>— (1) Since the partnership was confined to a particular class of business venture and it term mated automatically with the termination of the venture neither section 43 nor section 69 of the Act would be a heard to the maintainability of the suit for accounts of a dissolved firm.</p><p>(2) No notice was necessary under section 43 of the Act to sustain a claim for accounts of a partnership in certain ejmali contracts which on completion of the business terminated in March, 1946.</p><p><em>Sudhangshu Bimal Biswas Vs. Md. Mustafa Chowdhury; (1960) 12 DLR (SC) 259.</em></p><p> </p><p>It is now well established that the mere fact that after a particular date no further business was done will not amount to dissolution of the partnership.</p><p><em>Md. Mustafa Chowdhury Vs. Sudhangshu Bimat Biswas (1956) 8 DLR 381.</em></p><p> </p><p>A partnership entered into after the 1st October, 1932, the date on which the Partnership Act IX of 1932 came into force, can only is dissolved in either ways mentioned in the Partnership Act.</p><p>When in a case no notice in writing was given by the plaintiff of his intention to dissolve the partnership prior to the institution of the suit, nor did the plaintiff claim dissolution by the Court, his suit for a declaration that the unregistered partnership stood dissolved and for accounts thereof is not maintainable. Furthermore as this suit is neither a suit for dissolution of the firm nor a Suit for accounts of a dissolved firm, it is also barred under section 69 of the Act. Ibid (388 rt.h. col.)</p><p>(This decision is overruled by the Supreme Court.</p><p><em>Sudhangshu Bimal Biswas Vs. Md. Mustafa Chuwdhury (1960) 12 DLR (SC) 259.)</em></p><p> </p><p>There is no restriction for a member of a registered firm or the firm itself for bringing a Suit again1 another partner or the firm itself either for accounts or for dissolution of the firm or for both. <em>7 PLR (Dac.) 23.</em></p><p> </p><p>Once suit filed for dissolution of an unregistered firm it will attract the operation of Order 20, Rule 15 of the C.P. Code and Court can grant a decree for accounts even if not prayed for specifically—Power of Court under Or. 20 r. 15 of C.P.C. not subject to provisions of sec. 69 of the Partnership Act—The firm is dissolved under sec. 42 of the Act after completion of one or more adventures or undertaking when there is no contract to the contrary. <em>7 PLR (Dac.) 23.</em></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>—Firm not registered</strong></p><p>Firm not registered at time of institution of suit—plaint must be rejected—Subsequent registration of the firm will not validate proceedings invalid in their inception. <em>1952 PLR (Lah) 263.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>—Whether a partner can sue in his individual capacity.</strong></p><p>One partner may sue alone on a written c made with himself if it does not appear from ti contract itself that he was acting as an agent of the firm and a partner ought to sue only on a contrac4 entered into with himself, if such contract is in made with him as a principal, and not on behalf I himself and others. If one partner acting for the firm has represented himself to be acting on his own account only, and has ostensibly entered into a contract on his own account, he alone ought to sue on it.</p><p><em>Gopal Ch. Chattopaddhyay Vs. Brojonathdon Poddar. (1955) 7 DLR 615</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>—Notice under section 43 when can held not necessary.</strong></p><p>An oral agreement was arrived at between the appellant and respondent the, they would carry on jointly the business of military contracts on the basis of equal share in profits a losses and the business was carried on till the end March, 1946, when all war contracts ceased.</p><p>A suit was brought for a declaration of disso lion of partnership and rendering of accounts. The defendant denied existence of partnership and also I, liability for accounts and further contended that ti suit was not maintainable in law.</p><p><strong>Held</strong>— Where a partnership was confined particular class of ventures which ant came to an end with the termination of those ventures no notice under section 43 was necessary.</p><p>Even if ii. be held that the partnership, if proved  was one at will the exchange of notices and the counter—claim made by the plaintiff as a simple creditor must be taken to amount to a notice to terminate the partnership as well as to a dissolution by consent.</p><p><em>Sudhanjshu Bimal Biswas Vs. Md. Most Chowdhury, (1960) 12 DLR (SC) 259.</em></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>S.44 — Agreement between parties that they would not have recourse to litigation—Court has power to dissolve partnership.</strong></p><p>Even if the partners had agreed that any of them would be at liberty to retire, by giving notice of this fact and would not have recourse to litigation for having the partnership dissolved, the power of the Court to order dissolution did not remain unaffected, nor was the right of the partners to claim dissolution taken away by such an agreement.</p><p><em>Muhammad Yaseen Vs. Muhammad yasin PLD 1961 (W.P.) Lohore 468. (Masud, L)</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>—Grounds for dissolution—What may Be.</strong></p><p>The order of dissolution was based on three grounds. Firstly that the Managing Director was guilty of misconduct in so far as he had been utilizing the assets of the partnership for his personal needs, secondly, that although the partnership was carried on for more than two years not a pie in the shape of profits, was paid to the financing partner,</p><p>and thirdly, that the relations between the parties having become strained, on account of criminal litigation, it was just and equitable to dissolve the firm. Ibid</p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>—Partner guilty of misconduct was not entitled to sue for dissolution of partnership</strong></p><p>A partner who is himself guilty of misconduct was not entitled to sue for dissolution of partnership. Ibid</p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>—Ss. 46, 47 &amp; 48. After the dissolution a partner may sue or be sued in firm’s name provided the cause of action arose before its dissolution.</strong></p><p>Merely because the firm was dissolved during the pendency of the suit will not render the suit untenable.</p><p><em>M/S Memon Trading Co. Vs. M/S. Hajee Gaffar (1965) 17 DLR 677.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Ss. 63, 69—Change of name and membership of firm—Suit filed for cause of action arising prior to change—Intimation of change given to Registrar after filing of suit— Suit competent.</strong></p><p>There was a change in the name and membership of the firm and a suit was brought by it on a cause of action which arose prior to the change. It was argued that as the intimation of the change had not been sent to the Registrar regarding the change at the time of the filing of the suit; the suit did not lie.</p><p><strong><em>Held:</em></strong> Section 63 of the Partnership Act under which an intimation with regard to the change in the members of the firm and of the name of the firm has to be given to Registrar does not prescribe any time limit for sending such intimation. The mere fact that intimation about this change was given to the Registrar subsequently does not alter the situation. The firm running under the name and style of Messrs Jumani Brothers, therefore, was fully competent to file a suit against the applicant and by filing such a suit there has been absolutely no contravention of the provision contained in section 69 of the Partnership Act.</p><p><em>Muhammad Zaman Khan vs. Jumani Bros., PLD 1961 (W.P) Karachi 19. (DB) (Khamisani, J).</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>—S 69. Applicablity of provision of section 69 when the suit is one for accounts of dissolved firm.</strong></p><p>Where on an interpretation of the plaint it is evident that the suit was for the accounts of a dissolved firm, the provisions of section 69 would not be a bar for the maintainability of the suit.</p><p><em>Sudhanjshu Birnal Biswas Vs. Md. Mustafa Chowdhury. (1960) 12 DLR (SC) 259</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>S. 69— Change in members and name of firm—Does not debar firm from filing suit on cause of action which accrued prior to the change.</strong></p><p>Where some new partners were introduced in a firm with a change in the name of the firm, and the new firm brought a suit under the new name.</p><p><strong><em>Held</em></strong>: There is in law no restriction in regard to some of the members of the firm leaving the firm and some new members being taken in their place.</p><p>There is also no restriction for the changing of the name of the firm. Merely because the name of the firm has been changed or some of the members of the firm have left and some new members have been taken in it does not necessarily mean that the firm has been dissolved and that a new firm has been set up. The firm Messrs Jumani Brothers &amp; Co. which has ultimately come into being as Messrs Jumani Brothers is not a new firm but is the same firm continuing under a different name. Therefore the suit was maintainable.</p><p><em>Muhammad Zaman Khan Vs. Jumnani Brothers, PLD 1961 (W.P.) Karachi 19 (DB). (Khamisani, J).</em></p><p> </p><p>—Loan made to person to earn profits on his business—Does not constitute partnership with him. Where two persons advanced a loan to another without interest on the hope of making profit in his business of paddy.</p><p><strong>Held:</strong> That was not sufficient to constitute them his partners.</p><p><em>Muhammad Z.akria vs. Mazahar Ali, PLD 1961 (WP) Karachi 213 (DB) Wahiduddin, J).</em></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>—Partnership agreement not registered—Suit for accounts or realization of assets on dissolution is not barred—Suits by or against firm not permitted</strong>.</p><p>Non-registration of the firm under section 69 of the Partnership Act does not affect the validity of the partnership or prevent any of the partners from suing for the dissolution of the firm or for accounts or the realization of the property of a dissolved firm. This section only bars a Suit for enforcing a right arising out of a contract against either the firm or any past or present member of it or against any third party.</p><p><em>Usman vs. Haji Omar Haji Ayub, PLD 1966 Supreme Court 328. (Hamoodur Rahman, J).</em></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>S. 69— Suit by partner in individual capacity— Not for benefit of the firm— Suit not barred under the Act</strong>.</p><p>Section 69 of the Partnership Act. 1932 applies to those cases only where the plain shows that the dispute in respect of which the suit is brought was for the benefit of the partnership and the plaintiff has either brought the suit for the benefit of the partnership or has based his claim in respect of a transaction which was entered into between the partners and the defendant. Where a suit, on a claim arising out of a contract, was brought by one person alone and there was no allegation in the plaint that the benefits of the contract in dispute also accrued to some other persons, it was held that the suit was not barred under section 69 of the Partnership Act, 1932.</p><p><em>Jaffar Khan vs. Muhammad Achar, PLC) 196 (W.P) Karachi 335 (DB). (Wahiduddin, I).</em></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>S. 69: Partnership defacto.</strong></p><p>Partnership—Not necessarily involved in mere promise of share of profits in lieu of work. 1955 PLR (Lah.) 588.</p><p>Partnership—in fact but, legally defective, and failing to produce legal effects of partnership agreement— May give rise to equitable rights. Ibid.</p><p> </p><p>—Suit against a 3<sup>rd</sup> party will not lie unless the partnership is registered.</p><p><em>Eastern Union insurance Co. Ltd. vs.  Yusuf &amp; Co. (1967) 19 DLR 69.</em></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>S. 69(1)(2): Suit by a member of dissolved firm. </strong>Then a suit for recovery of damages is not one by the firm but by one of its members of the dissolved firm—such a suit at the instance of such a member is not hit by sub—sections (1) and (2) of section 69 of the Partnership Act.</p><p>Where the deed dissolving the partnership authorizes one of the members of the partnership firm to institute a suit such a member is entitled to institute such a suit and the provisions of sub—section (1) and (2) of section 69 do not stand as a bar.</p><p><em>M. Ismail &amp; Sons Vs. Trans Occeanic Steamship (1965) 17 DLR 269.</em></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Scope—All rights assigned by partners of dissolved firm to one partner— Suit by latter not hit by S. 69(1) (2).</strong></p><p>Where one of the partners of the dissolved firm was at the time of dissolution atoned to realize their assets and meet the liabilities of the dissolved firm, and he brought a suit for realizing the assets of the firm. It was held that as it is not a suit by the firm but by one of the members of the dissolved firm at the instance of the plaintiff, it cannot be held to be hit by sub-sections (I) and (2) of section 69 of the Partnership Act.</p><p><em>M. Ismail &amp; Sons vs. Trans Oceanic Steamship Co. Ltd., PLD 1966 Dacca 296(DB). (Hasan, J).</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>S. 69(1)(2)(3): Partnership firm </strong></p><p>—A suit originally filed for declaration of rights and for accounts—By a subsequent prayer and additional ground namely for dissolution of the firm was sought to be included in the suit—Question arose whether the amendment sought would alter the nature of the suit so as to substitute one cause of action for another cause in the suit and whether such an amendment may be allowed under Or. 6, r.17 CPC.</p><p><em>Ans</em>. An amendment of such nature in the plaint may be allowed under the provisions of law without affecting the nature of the Suit.</p><p><em>Radha Krishna Jogani Vs. Dwarka Das Agarawalla (1984)36 DLR (AD) 253</em></p><p> </p><p>—The present suit prima facie barred under sub-section(1) of s.69, but having regard to sub-section(3) it cannot be said to be actually barred. Ibid</p><p>—A Suit in respect of a partnership firm instituted originally for declaration of the share and for accounts-By-amendment it also prayed in addition for dissolution of the firm—Such an amendment permissible. Ibid.</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2309	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Passport Act, 1920</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  22 DLR (WP) 57</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Passport </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Passport Act</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;">(XXXIV of 1920)</p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"> </p><p>Read with Passport Rules, 1955 Passport does not clothe its bearer with any vested right to leave native country at pleasure.</p><p><em>Syed Abul A‘ala Maududi Vs. The State Bank of Pakistan, (1970) 22 DLR (WP) 57</em></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>S. 3—Issue of passport</strong>—Object of—No citizen has a right to issue of passport.</p><p>A passport is not a document under which a citizen is authorized to leave that country but it is a document issued by a sovereign State requesting the other sovereign State or its functionary to give certain facilities to one of its citizens. The rights to issue passport to a citizen arc recognized in a sovereign State under the well—established rule of International Law and the issuing of passport is a part of the State Department’s Foreign Affairs function, which is not justifiable. In other words, Pakistani citizen has no legal right, much less Constitutional right, to be issued a passport.</p><p><em>Manzoor Khan vs. Government of Pakistan, PLD 1966 (W.P) Peshawar 29 (D.B.) (Faizullah, J.)</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2310	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Patents &amp; Designs Act, 1911</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  36 DLR 59, </p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Patents &amp; Designs </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Patents &amp; Designs Act (II of 1911)</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u> </u></strong></p><p><strong>S. 43(6): </strong>Right as to design operates from the date of its registration.</p><p><em>Md. Abdul Latif Vs. Md. Harunur Rashid (1984) 36 DLR 59</em>.</p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Secs—47 and 52: </strong>Registration of the design ensures the right of the design. So long as the registration certificate (regarding a design) exists the plaintiff gets protection under sections 47 and 52 of the Patent and Designs Act to guard against piracy of his registered design. Ibid.</p><p> </p><p><strong>S. 47 (1)—Registered design—</strong>Copyright is granted in favor of owner—Length of time of existence of copyright or doubts as to its validity not sufficient reason for not protecting copyright.</p><p>Registration of a design creates copyright which is protected by section 53(1) of the Act “during the existence of copyright”. In the presence of these statutory provisions it is difficult to see how the length of time in which registration may exist, or mere doubts, whether substantial or otherwise, as to its validity which may be entertained can be given weight for not protecting copyright in a registered design, irrespective of whether the protection that is needed is temporary or otherwise. Section 53 (1) is categorical when it says that “(luring the existence of copyright in any design it shell not be lawful for any person” other than the registered proprietor to use it for the purpose of selling his goods.</p><p><em>Silver Cotton Textile Mills Ltd. Vs. Bawany Violin Textile Mills Ltd., PLD 1963 (W.P) Karachi 79=PLR 1963 (1) W.P. 71. (Qadeeruddin, J.).</em></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Ss. 47(I) and 83 (I): </strong>Copyright over the registered design extends for 5 years when no imitation is permissible.</p><p><em>Md. Abdul Latif Vs. Md. Harunur Rashid (1984) 36 DLR 59.</em></p><p><strong>S. 51(6): </strong>If a registration in regard to a particular design is obtained by fraud the remedy is to move the Controller of the Patents and Designs or the High Court Division for cancellation of registration of design. Ibid.</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2311	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Payment of Wages Act, 1936</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p align="center" style="text-align:center;"><b><u><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Payment of Wages Act (IV of 1936)</span></u></b></p><p align="center" style="text-align:center;"><b><u><span style='Cambria","serif";'><br/></span></u></b></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Purpose</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>To compel employers to make prompt and fullpayment of wages to certain class of workers.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>DivisionalSuperintendent vs. Md. Sharif (l963) 15 DLR (SC) 261.</span></i></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 1(5)—Applicableto an industrial establishment: </span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Provision ofthe section applicable to an industrial establishment within the meaning ofsec. 2(9) of the E. B. Shops and Establishment Act, 1952, even though nonotification was published as required under section 1(5) of the Payment ofWages Act.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Md AzizurRahman Vs. Md. Babar Ali (1956) 8 DLR 721.</span></i></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 2(ii)(f):</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The definition of “wages” inS.2(vi) of the Payment of Wages Act made it perfectly clear that the authoritymust decide as to what was the remuneration which would, if the terms of thecontract of employment express or implied, were fulfilled, be payable, whetherconditionally upon the regular attendance, good work or conduct or otherbehavior of the person employed, or otherwise, to a person employed in respectof his employment or of work done in such employment. To say that the authorityhas absolutely no jurisdiction to entertain an application under that Act, ifthe wages stated by the petitioner are denied by the employer, would defeatthat Act itself and make it completely ineffective.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Under sub—section (3) of section 15, it isnot payment of the delayed wages but the payment of compensation which isaffected by a bona fide error or bona fide dispute as to the amount payable tothe emp4oyed person. <i>PLR (1960)2 (WP)251.</i></span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Under section 8(2) of the East Bengal Shopsand establishment Act 1952, the provisions of Payment of Wages Act areattracted even though no notification was published as required under section1(5) of the later Act.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Md AzizurRahman Vs. Md. Babar Ali (1956) 8 DLR 721.</span></i></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 2(vi): </span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Employee ready and willing to render servicebut employer not giving employee opportunity to render szxh service — Entitledto wages for period of suspension.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Divl. Supdtvs. Md. Sharif (1963) 15 DLR (SC) 261.</span></i></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 15: </span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The word “direction” in section 15 includes refusalto make direction. Authority appointed under the section is not a court but apersona designate.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Golam Ahmedvs. Md. Ata Karim (1957) 9 DLR 382 = PLR (Dac.) 195</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Claims mean entire sum overdue as wages. <i>1952 PLR (Lah.) 657</i></span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Secs 15</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> <b>and7(2)(h): </b>Claims of wages for the period of extraordinary leave disallowedby the competent authority cannot be granted.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Bacha MeahVs. Province of E.P. (1975) 27 DLR 563.</span></i></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S.15(2)—Authority’s satisfaction with the reasons for the delay in filing theapplication before it is sufficient.</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>According to the last proviso to sub—section(2) of section 15 of the Payment of Wages Act, if the “authority” is satisfiedthat there was sufficient cause for the petitioners for not making theapplication within six months from the date on which the payment of wages wasdue application will not be barred by time.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>RaiIwaymen’sStore vs M. Sultan Ahmed Chodhury (1957) 9 DLR 286.</span></i></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 15(2).Proviso 1,2: </span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Limitation for application forpayment of wages for illegal removal from service—Time taken in getting removaldeclared illegal by Civil Court and securing order for reinstatement—sufficient reason for condonation of delay.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Div Supdt VsMd. Sharf (1963) 15 DLR (SC) 261.</span></i></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 15(3): Seeunder section 2(f) above. </span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>LR (1960)2(WP) 215.</span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 15 (3)(a): </span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The sub-section contemplates abona fide dispute and not a voluntary dispute created by the employer or theemployee. </span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Md. AzizurRahaman Vs. Md. Babar Ali (1956) 8 DLR 721.</span></i></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Secs. 15(2)and 16(2): </span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Non compliance with theprovisions of subsection (2) of section 16 of the payment of Wages Act is notfatal to the maintainability of an application for recovery of wages undersection 15 (2) of the Act</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Railwaymenisstore Vs. M. Sultan Ahamed Chowdhury (1957) 9 DLR 286 </span></i></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Sec 15 and17: </span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The authority appointed undersection 15 of the Act is a Court subordinate to the High Cowl within themeaning of section 115 C. P. Code. An appeal lay to the District Judge undersection 17 (1) (b) of the Act against an order whereby the employee’s claim hadbeen rejected in tow. <i>PLR (1960)I (WP)495.</i></span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 17 (1): </span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The expression “District Court” as mentionedin section 17 (I) of the Payment of Wages Act is not a persona designata butmeans the principal civil Court of original jurisdiction in the district. Ibid.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Section 17, clause (a) provides that anappeal may be filed “by the employer or other person responsible for thepayment of wages under section 3” which expression can only mean that an appealis to be filed either by the employer or, in cases where some other person isresponsible for the payment of wages, by that other person. 1954 PLR (Lah.)356.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 18: Authority under the Act is not to bedeemed a civil court</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>If it was the intention of the Legislaturethat the authority referred to in section 18 of the Payment of Wages Act willbe the same as an inferior civil Court of ordinary jurisdiction, there was nonecessity of providing in section 18 that the authority shall have all thepowers of a civil court for all purposes of section 195 and of Chapter XXXV of’the Code of Criminal Procedure. These provisions only go to show that theauthorities functioning under the Act are not in reality civil courts properlyso called, but are only so by fictitious supposition. <i>(1957) 9 DLR 383 =8 PLR (Dac) 195.</i></span></p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span> </div></div>
2312	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Police Act, 1861</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  31 DLR 66</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Police </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u> </u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Police Act (V of 1861)</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u> </u></strong></p><p><strong>S. 13—District Magistrate competent to give direction u/s. 13 of the Police Act.</strong></p><p>Under section 13 of the Police Act though it is for the Inspector General, or any Assistant Inspector General or for the District Superintendent of Police to depute any additional number of police officers to keep the peace at any place, yet the District Magistrate is competent to give general direction to them in this respect.</p><p><em>Ali Akbar Pandit &amp; others.. Petitioners Vs. Jadu Gopal Shah Bhowmik &amp; others Opp. Party. (1979) 31 DLR 66.</em></p><p>An order passed u/s.13 of the Police Act is not judicial order and therefore not subject to revision by, the High Court under section 435 Cr.P.Code.   Ibid</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2313	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Police Officers (Special Provisions) Ordinance (84 of 1976)</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  34 DLR (AD) 173</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Police Officers </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p><strong>  <br/></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Police Officers (Special Provisions) Ordinance (84 of 1976)</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p><strong>Appellate authority under P.O. (S.P) Order</strong></p><p>Even the appellate authority that is the Government cannot be said to be exercising any part of IL judicial power of the State. Such appellate authority does not come within the ambit of sub—article (5) of <strong>Article 102</strong> and is not a tribunal within the meaning of <strong>Art. 102(5) of the constitution.</strong></p><p><em>Bangladesh Vs. Dhirendra Nath Sarker and others (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 173.</em></p><p> </p><p>—Authorities mentioned in Police Officers (S.P)’ Ordinance are not a tribunal — Police Officers of sated rank — Invoking of writ jurisdiction.</p><p><em>Bangladesh Vs. Dhirendra Nath Sarkar and others (1982) 34 (AD) 173.</em></p><p> </p><p>—The Authorities specified in the second and third columns of the Schedule to the Police Officers (S.P) Ordinance, 1976 cannot be treated as “tribunals” exercising judicial or even quasi—judicial power. Ibid.</p><p> </p><p>—Authorities mentioned in the Police Officers1 (S.P) Ordinance do not possess any power to act judicially but are mere administrative or executive bodies.  Ibid.</p><p> </p><p>— “Authority” mentioned in the Police Officers Ordinance is a tribunal. Its decision is immune from challenge under Article 102 of the Constitution. Ibid.</p><p> </p><p>—Police Officers (Special Provisions) 0rdinance, 1976—Restriction as regards invoking Fundamental rights. Ibid.</p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>“Tribunal” - </strong>The word ‘tribunal’ has been used in the Police Officers Ordinance more in the nature of an administrative tribunal than in the nature of a Court. Ibid.</p><p> </p></div></div>

2315	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Political Parties Act, 1962</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>   18 DLR (WP) 65</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Political Parties</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Political Parties Act (III of 1962)</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u> </u></strong></p><p><strong>S. 8(2): ‘Political party’—meaning of</strong></p><p>The respondent in the present case was originally a Muslim Leaguer but during the last General Election joined the Combined Opposition Parties and with its support returned to the Provincial Legislature. After election he again joined the Muslim League Party in the Assembly and the question arose m the present case which was brought to unseat him from the Legislature was whether in view of <strong>section</strong> <strong>8(2)</strong> of the Political Parties Act he was not disqualified from being a member of the Assembly on the ground that he left Combined Opposition Parties at whose instance he was returned to Provincial Assembly and joined another Party in the Legislature .d thereby incurred the penalty imposed by subsection (2) of section 8 of the Act.</p><p>Held: Since the Combined Opposition Parties be said to be a political party the respondent does not come within the mischief of section <strong>8(2)</strong> Act.</p><p><em>Manzur Hussain Vs. Raja Muhamad Abdullah (1966) 18 DLR (WP) 65.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>

2317	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Possession and Ownership</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  3 DLR 484, 5 DLR 305,  5 DLR 344, 3 DLR 484, 11 DLR 470,  6 DLR 253, 7 DLR 94, 7 DLR 82, 7 DLR 163, 7 DLR 425, 8 DLR 82, 5 DLR 39.</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Possession and Ownership</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Possession and Ownership</u></strong></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p>It is well settled that possession cannot become adverse to the owner so long as he is not entitled to claim immediate possession.</p><p><em>Abdul Hakim Sik.dar Vs. Tokejaddy (1951) 3 DLR 484.</em></p><p>Possession is one of the ‘methods by which property can be acquired. If a person takes possession of a property which belongs to another, he does not become the owner, but his possession is good against all except the true owner, and if he is dispossessed by a stranger, he is entitled to recover possession as a possessory owner.</p><p><em>Julfikar Joardar Vs. Abdul Karim Bari (1953) 5 DLR 305.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Auction-purchaser must apply for delivery of possession within 3 years— possession if amicably.</strong></p><p>The auction-purchaser must apply for delivery of possession within 3 years, from the date of confirmation of sale. If he comes after that, the court will not help him and restore possession to him. There is nothing in law which suggest that the auction— purchaser could not acquire title if possession be not taken through court. If after confirmation of sale he gets possession amicably or otherwise he need not apply for delivery of possession through Court.</p><p><em>Rahijuddin Sarker Vs. Monser Ali Shaikh (1953) 5 DLR 344.</em></p><p> </p><p>—If title is transferred during the submergence, the transferor must be deemed to be in possession from the date of the transfer. It makes no difference whether the transfer is by a private treaty or by a court sale. Ibid.</p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Where a raiyat is entitled to retain possession as against real owner when he was let into possession by a de facto landlord—bonafide must be proved.</strong></p><p>The principle that an agricultural raiyat who was let into possession of the land by and holds it under a defacto proprietor bona fide, is entitled to retain posses ion as a raiyat although the de facto proprietor is subsequently proved to be not a real owner, is an encroachment upon the ordinary rule of law that the granter is not competent to confer upon the grantee a better title than what he himself possesses and as such must be cautiously applied and must not be extended.</p><p><em>Abdul Hakim Sikdar Vs. Tokejaddy (1951) 3 DLR 484.</em></p><p> </p><p>—To make the principle applicable there must, therefore, be a bonafide belief of the lessor and the lessee that the former had sole interest in the land to create the interest and the latter also believed that he obtained a valid right available against the sole real owner. Ibid.</p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>When a trespasser is dispossessed by vis major the constructive possession is deemed to be with the rightful owner.</strong></p><p>The doctrine of constructive possession is no available to a trespasser when he is dispossessed by vis major because such dispossession has the same effect d voluntary abandonment of possession by him.</p><p>Where it appeared that the land in suit remained under water during the rainy season and the submergence of the land did not interfere with rising of the usual crops, it could not be said that there was break in pos session. The submergence contemplated by law must 1 such as to render the land derelict, that is, incapable of use for any purpose, and not a seasonal submergence during which the possession of the then possessor not interrupted or discontinued<em>. I PLR Dac. 395.</em></p><p>Criminal Court’s finding regarding possession not conclusive. <em>S.N. Gupta &amp; Co. Vs. Sudananda Ghose. (1959) 11 DLR 470</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>Possession in fact and possession in law</strong></p><p>If two persons are in possession of a piece of land, one having title and the other not, then the one who has title is in possession in the eye of law and then other is a mere intruder. Possession in fact is not all ways possession in law; nor is it necessary that possession, in order to be possession in law, must be possession in fact.</p><p><em>Sadeq Ali Shaik Vs. Fayazuddin Ahmed. (1954) 6 DLR 253</em>.</p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Possession under a mistaken or invalid title</strong></p><p>Possession under a mistaken or invalid title is as effective as that of a trespasser, and, if sufficient in length of time and continuity, gives the holder a good title.</p><p><em>Sadak Ali Vs. Suruj Ali (1955) 7 DLR 94.</em></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Fresh delivery of possession</strong></p><p>So long as the previous proceeding stands the decree holder is not entitled to get a fresh delivery of possession in a subsequent execution case if he was dispossessed by the judgment—debtors after the previous delivery of possession. His remedy is to move the executive court for vacating the order or to move the superior tribunal against that order. It cannot be challenged in a subsequent proceeding started by a separate execution case.</p><p><em>Md. Mojibur Rahmen Vs. Jamimi Mosahar (1955) 7 DLR 82.</em></p><p> </p><p>In the absence of any evidence that the submergence of the land during the rainy season was such as to make ii incapable of possession of the nature to which the land is susceptible, it cannot be held that inundation of the land in the rainy season is an interruption with possession.</p><p><em>Soramani Nath Vs. Kamar Au (1955)7 DLR 163.</em></p><p> </p><p>In Bengal every land goes under water during the rainy season. But that cannot be interpreted as an interruption with the possession of the actual occupier of the land. Ibid.</p><p> </p><p>Symbolical possession—Decree-holder being entitled to khash possession can get symbolical possession where circumstances permit</p><p><em>Satish Ch. Pal Vs. Asgar Ali (1955) 7 DLR 425.</em></p><p> </p><p>Symbolical possession of land—effective as against tenant judgment debtor.</p><p><em>Almaz Khaiun Vs. Ezhar Mia (1956) 8 DLR 82.</em></p><p> </p><p>A person is not entitled to oust his co-sharer from a plot of land in exclusive possession of the latter on the plea that he has got title to every inch of the joint property. If he feels that his co-sharer is in possession of some lands in excess of his share his remedy lies in a suit for partition.</p><p><em>Safatulla Sheik Vs. Abjanennessa Bibi (1953) 5 DLR 39.</em></p><p> </p><p>Mere possession immediately before the suit when counter-balanced by previous possession within lmitation of the other party will not be a sufficient ground for claiming possession. <em>(1954) PLR (Lah.) 371.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2318	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Post Office Act, 1898</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  7 DLR 587</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Post Office Act, 1898</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Post Office Act (VI of 1898)</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p><strong>S. 3(c): </strong>Under section 3(c), the Post Office Act, the delivery of a postal article at the house or office of the addressee, or to the addressee or his servant or agent or other person Considered to be authorized to receive the article according to the usual manner of delivering postal articles to the addressee, shall be deemed to be delivered to the addressee, So when the Income Tax Department chooses to send a notice by registered post, they can rely on the presumption of service at the proper time unless the presumption is rebutted by positive evidence.</p><p><em>R.P. Shah Vs. Commr. I. Tax, E-B, (1955) 7 DLR 587.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2319	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Pourashava Election Rules, 1977</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  32 DLR (AD) 186, 34 DLR (AD) 146</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Pourashava Election </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Pourashava Election Rules, 1977</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><br/><u></u></p><p><strong>Election (of Chairman) to Pourashava.</strong></p><p>—Election Tribunal when deciding an election petition counted the ballot papers—On writ petition before the High Court Division, the High Court Division, in the interest of fair play and justice, again recounted and counted the ballot papers — Recounting though not normally done by the Election Tribunal yet it is unobjectionable when done in the interest of justice — The High Court Division only completed the process started by the Election Tribunal.</p><p><em>Afzal Khan...Appellans. Vs. Election Tribunal and Munsif, 3rd Court, Comilla and another Respondents. (1980) 32 DLR (AD) 186.</em></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Rules 37, 38 &amp; 39</strong>: Election held must be declared to be vitiated for reasons of unusual delay in depositing the election materials with the Returning Officer and also because the election materials were sent to the R.O. without escort as provided in rule 39(4).</p><p><em>Md. Enayet All Vs. Munsif of First court, Khulna (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 146.</em></p><p> </p><p>In an election case the decision of the Election Tribunal is final. Its decision should not be disturbed, unless it suffers from material illegality in the exercise of jurisdiction or the procedure as laid down under the rules. Ibid.</p><p>Strict compliance of the Rules, 37, 38 and 39 is a must for ensuring fair election.   Ibid</p><p>Infraction of election rules cannot be inferred for something done after the poll is over which can be said to have materially affected the result of the election.   Ibid.</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2320	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Practice and Procedure - Part I</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p></p><p align="center" style="text-align:center;"><b><u><span style='Cambria","serif";'><br/></span></u></b></p><p align="center" style="text-align:center;"><b><u><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Practiceand Procedure</span></u></b></p><p align="center" style="text-align:center;"><b><u><span style='Cambria","serif";'><span style="text-decoration:none"><br/></span></span></u></b></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Abatement ofsuit when Government withdraws- </span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>P.O. 69 or1972 does not provide any specific mode regarding abatement under C.P. Code ifthe Government Pleader files a pertition that the Government withdraws from thesuit and not party to it—that is enough that the suit has abated as far as theGovernment is concerned. (C.P. Code Or. 27. rr. 2, 5, 8 (b)</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>M.S. IafarVs. Sub-Judge 3rd Court (1981) 33 DLR (AD) 47</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>.</span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Absence ofofficial signature</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—in thegazette is at best an irregularity and does not render the notification invalidif the original contains the signature.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>In the present case the area in questionwhich was formerly a rural area has been converted into an urban area bynotification published in official Gazette. The notification has however beenattacked on the ground that it does not contain any signature of any Governmentofficer to give the publication an official authorize. </span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The question is: Will this absence ofsignature in the Gazette make it illegal?</span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Held</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>: Since from the records we are satisfiedthat this notification was signed by the Joint Secretary to the Govt. of EastPakistan, we do not think that this notification as published in the DaccaGazette is without any authority.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>At the most, it may be said to be anirregularity, but this mere irregularity will not affect the validity of thisnotification.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>M/S Amin Jute Mills Ltd. Vs. The ChittagongMunicipality, (1968) 20 DLR 1040.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Addressingthe Chief Justice or a Judge of the High Court directly on a point of law by asubordinate court— not proper.</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>If on the ground of urgency the attention ofHigh Court is sought to be drawn directly, the Registrar of the High Courtshould be addressed by the subordinate court and it is not the practice towrite a personal letter addressed to the Chief Justice or any other Judge ofthe High Court.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Normally such matters should be brought tothe notice of the High Court by way of a proper application moved through theLegal Remembrancer.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>HarmuzMondal Vs. State (1961) 13 DLR 405.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Adjournmentfor argument</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>There is no warrant for the proposition thaton the conclusion of the evidence the case must be adjourned for arguments.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>M. IbrahimVs. Crown. (1955)7 DLR (FC) 65(67 l.h.col.)</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Administrationof justice.</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Court’s function is to administer law and notto look into the propriety of the legislation—no deviation from its strictapplication by the court—stricter vigilance necessary in cases wheremisapplication of law apprehended. (1956) 8 DLR 526.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Administrativedecision</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> said to have been arrived at togive a fishery right to a particular party unless expressed by a written ordercannot create any right to that party in whose favor the decision is said tohave been made and therefore creates no legal right vested in that party.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The petitioner claims that the Board ofRevenue could not cancel the settlement made in its favor for the year 1375B.S. and this cancellation and order of settlement of the fishery for the year1375 B.S. with Abu Bakkar Siddique are without any legal authority.</span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Held</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>: The correspondence between the DeputyCommissioner, Rajshahi and the Board of Revenue is internal correspondencewhich does not create any actionable claim in the petitioner Co—operativeSociety. Had it been the case that the settlement for the year 1375 B. S., hadbeen made with it and if it had been put into possession of the fishery thenpossibly the petitioner could have said that the lease could not be cancelledwithout giving it a prior hearing.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>NawabganjThana Fishermen Co-operative Society Ltd. Vs. Member, Board of Revenue, Govt.of East Pakistan, (1968) 20 DLR 992.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Advantage,taking of—the lack of any provision in law—nothing wrong.</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>To take advantage of the lack of anyprovision in a law for some particular case does not necessarily amount todefeating the provisions of the said law.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Dula Mia Vs. Haji Md. Ebrahim (1956) 8 DLR616=8 PLR (Dac.) 326.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Adverseopinion given by one’s own witness if binding on the party.</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>During cross—examination the plaintiffs’father said that a widow in a Jam family must have the permission of herhusband or of the eldest male member of the family to make a valid adoption.</span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Held</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>:— Such answer is not an admission binding onthe plaintiff and it was no more than an opinion of a witness not speciallyqualified to give one.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>MajnthaiDulal Chand Vs. Sugarchan Bhikam Chand (1951)3 DLR (PC) 251.</span></i></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Advocate, ifaggrieved, to petition—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> Advocate’sfeeling aggrieved by remarks in the judgment. Where an Advocate feels aggrievedon Certain remarks made in the judgment of the High Court Division and praysfor their expunction, the procedure ought to be that the Advocate against whomremarks have been made shall be the petitioner. </span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Md. GolamRabbani and another Vs. Honorable Judges of the High Court (1979) 31 DLR (AD)87.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Amendment—Correctionsare amendments.</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Corrections arc amendments, but the two termsarc not synonymous and arc not co—extensive. All corrections though areamendments but all amendments are not corrections though some amendmentsaffecting are impositions of taxes or affecting the rights and liabilities ofsubjects cannot have retrospective effect unless expressly or by necessaryimplication it is made so.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>StandardVacuum Oil Co. Vs. Trustees for the Port of Chittagong (1961) 13 DLR 795.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Appraisementof facts—serious error in</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>— Where thisis not established, the Privy Council will not interfere.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Chief JosephWobo Vs. Attorney-General (1957) 9 DLR (PC) 616.</span></i></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Approbationand reprobation—Not permissible</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>A party through his lawyer obtaining an orderin its favor cannot in a subsequent proceeding between the same parties go backupon its former stand— Principles of <i>resjudicata</i> applicable.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>A petitioner is not entitled to takedifferent pleas at different times so as to file more than one petition on thesame facts. The general principle of <i>resjudicata </i>applies to writ petitions also.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>TamizuddinMunshi Vs. Election Tribunal (1966) 18 DLR 410.</span></i></p><p><b><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></b></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Auction saleof the proceeding lands—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>A court orpublic servant or any person who holds auction of any property has the powerand jurisdiction to lay down the conditions of auction. A court of law may onlysee that the conditions are not unconionab1e, illegal or unreasonable.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Abdul HamidVs. The State (1981) 33 DLR 399.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Award—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>An award is altogether different from arecommendation.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Manager Vs.Abdus Sattar (1979)31 DLR 58.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Awarding</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> <b>ofcosts—</b>Awarding cost is no doubt a matter of discretion of the Court, butsuch discretion must be exercised judiciously.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>HabibullahKhan Vs. Shah Azharuddin Ahmed. (1983) 35 DLR (AD)...72.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Benami saleand ex-parte decree </span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Plaintiffs claim to the property based onbenami purchase and an ex-parte decree—Ex-parte decree obtained on the basis ofbenami purchase—Court is entitled to go into the question of validity of decreesuo mow and come to its conclusion as to the validity of such ex-parte decree,even though the defendant raised no objection.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>ImanuddinRarhi Vs. Lilabati Das (1980) 32 DLR 75</span></i></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Bench has nopower to grant leave to Asstt. Attorney-General</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Bench has no power to grant leave of absencefrom office duties to a Government officer like the Assistant Attorney—General.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>MoazzemHossain Vs. State. (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 290.</span></i></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Cases onmerits—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Court should give the partiesopportunity to present their cases on merits.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Haji KarimdadVs. Insaf Meah and others (1981) 33 DLR 435.</span></i></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Changedcircumstances</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—During the pendency of thesuit—Court to take notice of it and mould the decree accordingly.<i> (1956) 8 DLR 713.</i></span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—It is not only competent to a Court ofappeal to take notice of such events (viz. enactment of a new statute duringthe pendency of the appeal) but it is its duty to do so.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>FaizurRahman Vs. Jogendra Mohon Das (1951) 3 DLR 115 (120A).</span></i></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Choice ofoption—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>When two options are available toauthority concerned, it can choose for either of the two. When two options areavailable to the authority, it can lawfully opt for and exercise power undereither of them. It would be lawful for the authority concerned to exercisepowers under any of the two laws available to them.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>M.A. RashidVs. Secretary (1979) 31 DLR 339.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Compulsoryretirement—Notice to be served.</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Notice to be served on a person whenallegation is that he was responsible for ordering compulsory retirement of theperson retired.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>HabibullahKhan Vs. Shah Azharuddin Ahmed, (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 72.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Contract whencan be enforced by one not a party to the contract.</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>A stranger to a contract reserving a benefitfor him could not sue thereon unless it was clear from the terms of thecontract that a trust had been created for such stranger.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Lal Miah Vs.Abdul Gani (1953) 5 DLR 338(344).</span></i></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Contradictionin the statement of a witness—Is a task of appreciation for the trial andappeal court.</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Contradiction in the statement of witness,either with his own statement or with the statement of another witness, a taskof appreciation of the evidence, and, therefore. it is within the jurisdictionof the trial court and the Court of appeal on fact, to deal with the question.No doubt, there is certain rule of prudence governing the case of contradictingstatement.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>MoyezuddinVs. The Staie(1 979) 31 DLR (AD) 37</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Costs—Liabilityto pay</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Liability to pay costs to the party in whosefavour writ petition is decided can be determined by starting a separateproceeding against a person not served with notice of the writ petition beforeits hearing concluded and judgment delivered.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>HabibullahKhan Vs. S.A. Ahmed (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 72.</span></i></p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span> </div></div>
2321	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Practice and Procedure - Part II</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p></p><p align="center" style="text-align:center;"><b><u><span style='Cambria","serif";'><br/></span></u></b></p><p align="center" style="text-align:center;"><b><u><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Practiceand Procedure</span></u></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Court togive opportunity to parties to present cases on merits</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Court should give the Parties opportunitypresent their cases on merits.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>HajiKarimdad Vs. Insaf Meah &amp; ors.(1981 33 DLR 435.</span></i></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Court notbound to take notice of events subsequent to the institution of a suit, thoughit has the discretions.</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>A Court is not bound to take notice of eventsubsequent to the institution of the suit though has discretion to do so. Itcan adjudicate up rights of parties as they existed at the date of institutionof the suit leaving the question arising out of subsequent events to be decidedin fresh proceedings.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Md. JamilAsghar Vs. Improvement Trust Rawalpindi (1965) 17 DLR (SC) 520.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Court—Firstappellate—not bound by finding.</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The first Appellate Court is no bound by thefindings of fact; but it has not the same opportunity of appreciating theevidence as the trial Court has. There is always a balance in favor of thejudgment of the trial Court and the appellant cannot succeed unless he can showthat the trial Co in spite of the privileged position committed an error. <i>57 CWN (5 DR) 57.</i></span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Court’sorder passed behind the bad of the parties</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>and not communicated to them—renders that order and subsequent order on thebasis thereof void and illegal.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Md. RamzanVs. Faziul lluq (1963) 15 DLR 99.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Court’sright to prefer judgments when they are inconsistent—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>If two decisions are inconsistent, the Courtcan choose which it is to follow.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Wahed AliMia Vs.
