Haji Abdul Wahed (1954) 6 DLR 206 (209 Lh. col).</span></i></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Courts ofjustice are courts of equity—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Courts ofjustice arc also courts of equity in this country and if a deed ofrelinquishment is executed for consideration of which the executant has taken abenefit, there is no reason why in appropriate cases such an agreement shouldnot be equitably enforced in the absence of any statutory prohibition.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>QuamiridinVs. Mt. Aisha Ban (1956) 8 DLR (WP) 86.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Court’simportant orders have to be shown and signed by the lawyer concerned—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> Copies of the application to the court to beserved on the party or his pleader. (High Court Civil Rules Order, Rule 466(2).</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Copy of the application to the court forappointment of a pleader commissioner (after passing of the preliminary decreein a partition suit) was not supplied to the lawyer of the other party, (norhis signature to the order of court appointing a commissioner obtained). Theacceptance of such report in passing the final decree and making it a part ofit was not done carefully.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>JaharunnessaVs. Safed Ali Bepary and ors. (1984) 36 DLR 253.</span></i></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>CourtsWarning not heeded—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Warningsgiven by the Court against affidavits containing untrue statements—not heeded:Responsibility of the government lawyers, further caution— Mutualresponsibility of the government officers id the government lawyers.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Neerala TeaState Ltd. Vs. Bangladesh Tea Board (1982) 34 DLR 161</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Creditor’sright to realise money—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Failure ofthe creditor to realise the debt as a public demand in a summary procedure doesnot extinguish the debt— Can recover the debt in a civil court as an ordinarydebt.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Siddik AhmedKhan Vs. Gura Mia Khan (1956) 8 DLR 417.</span></i></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>(Custom inPunjab)—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Custom that devolution ofproperty has a preference over the personal law of the parties, is limited tothe ancestral property only and not to non—ancestral property and in case oflatter, the governing la” is the personal law.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>It was contended that even if the evidence isaccepted that the family was governed by custom then the custom established bythe document, viz. Wajibul An in the present case applies only to ancestralproperties and not to non—ancestral properties, because it is not so specifiedin the Wajibul Arz.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Mst. QaiserKhaioon Vs. Mr. Abdul Khaliq (1973) 25 DLR (SC) 104.</span></i></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Decree onpersonal covenant—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Where nospecific prayer was made i the plaint for a decree on the basis of personalcovenant in the mortgage bond the court nevertheless, would be justified inpassing a money decree on the general prayer for further reliefs, if there wereenough materials on records for such a personal decree.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Kadam RasulVs. Union Bank of India (1953)5 DLR 290—295.</span></i></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Defect inform of a quit—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Defect inform of a suit is immaterial—Substance to be looked to.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Ramani Bh.Chowdhury Vs. Mahendra Kr. Saha. (1954)6 DLR 156.</span></i></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Delay indisposing of matters involving legal rights, deprecated.</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The High Court has been pleased to deprecatethe unusual delay in disposing of the application submitted for registration oftrademarks and made pointed reference that a similar deprecatory remark wasmade before 10 years by the High. Court in regard to the unusual delay by theTrade marks authority in disposing of trademarks applications without producingany visible effect to correction. </span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>B.S. <i>IndustriesVs. Dy. Registrar, (1968) 20 DLR 787.</i></span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Delay inrectification of Clerical Mistake in the Judgment, when can be condoned:</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>It appears that on 30.3.1964 the trial Courtaccepting the Pleader Commissioner’s report passed the following order:</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Petitioner is directed to deposit Rs.12201—within one month from this date. </span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>In fact, the proper words should be not “thepetitioner” but the Opposite party and the amount is not Rs. 1220/- but Rs.1160/-. For correction, of these mistakes an application was moved on 16.9.68but it is objected to that it is too late to have this mistake rectified.</span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Held:</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> Delay alone is not sufficient to disentitlea party from securing rectification of a clerical or arithmetical mistake in anorder or a decree provided the delay is not intentional and based on mala fidemotives or because of such delay the property itself has passed into the handsof a bona fide third party.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Ramjan Vs.Abdul Gani Mistry, (1970) 22 DLR 61.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Delegationof the Govt. Function—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Art. 143:Delegation of the Government function—can be given by the Central Government tothe Provincial Government and the Provincial Government in turn may delegate itto its officers.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Mir Abdul Baqi Baluch Vs. Govt. of Pakistan,(1968) 20 DLR (SC) 249.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Depositiontaken on commission—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Depositiontaken on commission in mofussil not formally tendered in Court—Admissible inevidence.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Abid AliShaikh Vs— Sadek Ali Biswas (1957) 9 DLR 128.</span></i></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>DeputyAttorney General not to appear in private Criminal Cases—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Deputy Attorney General cannot appear onbehalf of a private party, in a criminal case, when he is already appearing forthe State in the same case—Neither can he ask the court to accept an affidavitsworn by a private party.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Md. MustafaAnwar Vs. The State. (1983) 35 DLR 165.</span></i><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></b></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Depredationwas let loose on the garden—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>During theliberation struggle in 1971 and thereafter the tea garden was subjected to allkinds of depredations causing heavy loss to the petitioners and they could notdo any work for nearly two years.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Neeraka TeaState Vs. Bangladesh Tea Board (1982) 34 DLR 161.</span></i></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Devolutionof interest—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>If the Government of EastPakistan is going to be substituted by the Government of Bangladesh, a law mustbe enacted to that effect for such devolution of interest.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Messrs. M.S. Jafar Vs. Subordinate Judge, 3rd Court, (1981)33 DLR (AD) 47.</span></i></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Device todefeat the Government</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Device to defraud the Government deprecated.A transaction in aid of an illegal device to defraud the, Government cannot betaken as a valid ground in a proceeding before a court of law.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Nurjahan BegumVs. Mahmudur Rahman Mid— lick. (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 61.</span></i></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Discriminatorylegislation—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Discriminatorylegislation—guiding principle for determining whether in fact the impugned Actis reasonable and rational relation between the object of the legislation andthe classification made must exist. <i>(1956)8 DLR 457.</i></span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Disregard oflawful order condemned—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Order de-requisitioningthe house passed by the competent authority defied and disregarded by theDirector and the Estate Officer of the Accommodation Board, Govt. ofBangladesh—Disregard of lawful order by responsible government officialcondemned.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Hazi Md.Illiyas Vs. Government of the Peoples Republic of Bangladesh, (1979)31 DLR 69.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Documents toprove question of law without formal proof—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Whenboth the parties without going to the trouble and expense of legal proof putforward documents bearing on the law prevailing in a certain locality and thesedocuments were received and referred to by the trial judge. Held— The HighCourt in these circumstances was entitled to have regard to them.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>MagnibalGutal Chand Vs. Suganchan Bhilkhan Chan. (1951) 3 DLR (PC) 251</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Document,when insufficiently stamped—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Where thereis a pre-existing debt or liability and a bill or note is passed in respectthereof, the plaintiff can fall back on the original consideration if thedocument is not admitted in evidence as not being duly stamped.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Benoy Bh.Saha Vs. Abdul Samad, (1954) 6 DLR 50.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>During thependency of a case the court can go back on its own finding. </span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>So long as the Court is in the seizing of acase it may go back upon its own finding.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Moksed AliVs. Katu Khan (1961) 13 DLR 571.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Employees ofNationalized Industries</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> are neitherGovernment servants nor persons in the service of the Republic.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Manager Vs.Abdus Sattar (1979) 31 DLR 58.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Evidence,inadmissible evidence does not become admissible from omission to object.</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>An erroneous omission to object to evidencewhich is irrelevant and consequently inadmissible under any circumstance doesnot make it admissible. </span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Prov. ofBengal Vs. Jamila Khatun (1952) 4 DLR 222 (231).</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Ex-parteadverse finding—</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The adverse finding against the appellant inthe judgment cannot be sustained because those were in the absence of theappellant. In the absence of those adverse finding there could not be anyoccasion far less, raising the question of payment of costs to the respondent.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>HabibullahKhan Vs. S.A. Ahmed (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 72.</span></i></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Exercise ofpower by the Government subject to the law of the country.</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Court has called upon the Corporation to showcause why a certain order should not be made in such a case. The Corporationhas the bounden duty, apart from the question of its powers and duties underthe said Presidential Order, to state before the Court why it has not compliedwith the Government order and the Court is bound to decide upon the legalityand enforceability of the Government order after giving a hearing to therespondent Corporation.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Chairman,Bangladesh Steel Mills vs. Masood Reza (1974) 30 DLR (SC) 169.</span></i></p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span> </div></div>
2322	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Practice and Procedure - Part III</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p></p><p align="center" style="text-align:center;"><b><u><span style='Cambria","serif";'><br/></span></u></b></p><p align="center" style="text-align:center;"><b><u><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Practiceand Procedure</span></u></b></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>FinanceMinistry to deal with financial matters</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Since no other rule could be found in theRules of Business as empowering the Ministry of Law to exercise the functionsrelating to financial matters which are reserved under the Rules of Business tothe Ministry of Finance, in the absence of such a rule the Ministry of Law cannotinitiate the proceeding in question in the Prize Court.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>BangladeshVs. Hon’ble Judge. (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 212.</span></i></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Governmentaction not supported by any paper on record.</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>No inspection of the garden, no measuring ofthe area under tea plantation by the Government to vouch its allegation thatthe petitioner failed to carry out its obligation in terms of thelease—deed—Nor is there any scrap of papers on record in support of what italleged.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Neerala TeaState Vs. Bangladesh Tea Board (1982) 34 DLR 161.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Government’s affidavit sworn by its officerwho, as he affirmed, was made on the basis of official records to the effectthat the petitioner invested no money on the construction of roads, dwellinghouses and staff quarters are all statement without any</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>basis whatever.            Ibid.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Government’scase—Petitioners ailed to bring 30% of the land under tea plantation within thescheduled period.</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The Government’s simple case is that thepetitioners failed to bring 30% of the land under tea plantation within thescheduled period as per terms and conditions of the lease—deed and as theyabandoned the tea garden without proper management, the tea garden as per orderof the Ministry of Land Administration and Land Reforms, had been taken underthe possession of the Government.     Ibid.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>GovernmentDepartment officers dereliction of duty.</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Deliberate dereliction of duty by theGovernment Officers, leading to usurpation of citizen’s property in the guiseand in the name of law—severely condemned.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>ChandiKaibarta Das Vs. Bangladesh. (1982) 34 DLR 227.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>GovernmentDepartment, Secretary has a duty to place relevant facts.</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Duty cast upon the Secretary of GovernmentDepartment to place relevant facts to enable the competent authority to decidewhich of the two alternatives should be adopted in a particular case and factson record should show this.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>SalehuddinKhan Vs. Bangladesh (1982) 34 DLR 120.</span></i></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Government—device to defeat the Government</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>A transaction in aid of an illegal device todefraud the Government cannot be taken as valid ground in a proceeding before acourt of law.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Nurjahan Begum Vs. Mahmudur Rahman (1982) 34DLR (AD) 61.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Government’shigh handed and arbitrary act and Neerala Tea Garden</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Nationalization Order and subsequently theorder of resumption of the Neerala Tea Estate by the Government at the instanceof the Prime Minister Sk. Mujibur Rahman held totally without the sanction oflaw and vindictive.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Breach of condition by the Government aboutextension of time which has been allowed in case of every other tea gardenexcepting the petitioner garden— Regardless of lease terms and illegally theGovernment swooped down upon the garden—Worse of all the Government which wasall eager to expand tea cultivation made no arrangement, after its seizure, tosafeguard the existing plants of the petitioner garden.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Neerala TeaEstate Vs. Bangladesh Tea Board (1982) 34 DLR 161.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The Tea Board (a statutory body) in view ofthe then disturbed conditions informed the petitioner by a letter to go aheadwith the tea cultivation. Other lessees of other tea gardens were in the same predicament — Government while leaving other gardens untouched resumed thepetitioner’s garden—a position in clear contradiction with the Tea Boardinstructions I to ahead with further cultivation.      Ibid.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>GovernmentLawyer’s responsibility</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Although in making the statements the primaryresponsibility was of the deponent who is a responsible Government officer, theGovernment lawyer w certified the affidavits as having been prepared by him cannotdisown his responsibility in the matter either.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Neerala TeaEstate Ltd. Vs. Bangladesh Tea Board (1982) 34 DLR 161.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Governmentlawyers not to appear in private case against government.</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Government lawyers should not appear for valeparty in a case in which Government is a party.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>It is not desirable practice for thegovernment .lawyers to appear for private individuals in a ca where thegovernment is also a party. More so cause in a criminal case, the interest of aprivate ty and the State may not always be the same.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Md. Mustafa Anwar Vs. State (1983) 35 DLR 165</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'><b>Government resolution not a law</b>.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>A resolution of the Government, issued froqMinistry of Natural Resources, Scientific &amp; Tec logical Research is not alaw and as such the Co though engaged in the discharge of some functions havingpublic character is not a local authority. A resolution of the Government isnot a law since it is not made or issued in exercise of any law—making power ofthe President.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Bangladesh Council of Scientific &amp;Industrial Research Ordinance (V of 1978) will not come into existenceautomatically on the Promulgation of the Ordinance. The Council shall have tobe established by the Government by a separate notification in the gazette.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>A.Z. RafiqueAhmed Vs. Bangladesh Council of Scientific. (1979) 31 DLR 222</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Governmentservant—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Reinstatement of a Governmentservant during the pendency of appeal before court is not a ground dismissingthe appeal.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>BangladeshVs. Md. Misfor Ali (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 304</span></i></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Governmentservant—if to be retained in public interest</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Authority concerned given power whether aparticular government servant is to be retained in service in public interest.       Ibid.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Governmentvis-a-vis the statutory Corporation</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The latter disobeys the Governments orderreleasing the property to the owner—Government’s last minute’s effort in favorof the corporation.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The present case offered a hard choice to theCourt inasmuch as the Government’s order was at the first instance notimplemented by a Statutory Corporation which was bound to implement it andsecondly, the Government itself did not come forward in support of the ordermade by itself. Between the date on which the order was made and the date offiling the writ petition there was a sufficient gap. Nothing was done by theGovernment in rescinding the same during this period.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Even the Government did not file an appeal intime which was only filed after notice was served by the Court upon theAttorney—General during the hearing of the leave petition.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>There is no precedence, as was admitted bythe learned Attorney—General, of opposition by a Statutory Corporation to aGovernment order particularly when it is passed by the Secretary to theMinistry.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Chairman,Bangladesh Steel Mills Vs. Masood Reza (1978) 30 DLR (SC) 173.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Governingbody—Suspension of</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Of an organization suspended—Chairman of theGoverning Body alone independently of other members of the Governing Body isnot competent to move against the order of suspension.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>M.R. KhanVs. Bangladesh (1975) 27 DLR 602.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Chairman alone not competent to move andseek relief against the order of suspension. Ibid.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>High CourtDivision to which District Court is subordinate</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—if finds that owing to certain circumstancesthe Munsif Court is unable to execute the order of the District Judge, is tocome up and help the Munsif Court to execute the order of the Higher court.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Alhaj Md.Ruhul Amin Vs. Dhaka Municipal Corporation. (1984) 36 DLR</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> 1.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>High Court’spower and obligation in finally disposing of a suit on materials available—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The Courts have no interest in multiplyingproceedings, and if the dispute between the parties can be brought to finalitymore swiftly by the appeal being dealt with in the High Court, assuming what isobvious, that this can be done without prejudice to its disposal on the merits,that would be of advantage to all concerned.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Ajiruddinvs. Rahman Fakir (1961) 13 DLR (SC) 191.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>High Courtsof Pakistan—decisions thereof, should be preferred.</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>It has been observed in many cases by thisCourt that the Subordinate Courts and the members of Bars in the MofussilCourts prefer to cite Indian decisions and make no attempt in find out if thereis any decision of any of the High Courts of our country. It is commonknowledge that when a decision of any of the High Courts in Pakistan isavailable on any particular point, the Subordinate Court in Pakistan shall notrely on any decision of any foreign Court. Furthermore, the decision of theHigh Court is binding on all Courts subordinate to it lying within itsjurisdiction.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>M/S Eastern Federal Union Ins. Co. Ltd.vs.  Yusuf &amp; Co. (1967) 19 DLR 69.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Hypothecatingone’s share</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—of money in the assets of a firmis lawful.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Federationof Pak. Vs Pioneer Bank (1958)10 DLR 361.</span></i></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>IndianRepublic decision not binding on Pakistan Courts.</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The decisions of Indian Republic are notbinding on the courts in Pakistan but that should not prevent the latter fromreferring to the legal principles enunciated by the former. <i>(1951)3 DLR 50.</i></span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Individualsright in court — When he is absent.</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Accepted rule of judicial procedure whiledetermining individual right.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>It is an accepted rule of judicial procedurein this country that the Court shall entertain and decide a civil actionrelating to the determination of an individual right only, if the person whohas initiated the action or his representative is present in Court to prosecutesuch action. The Court will not generally hear or decide an action in theabsence of such a person.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Parties to an action must present himself orhis lawyer before the Court in default whereof the case may be dismissed.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—It is the duty of the party concerned to bepresent in Court to prosecute the action and the Court may in his absence verywell presume that he is not willing to prosecute the matter and may in such acircumstance dismiss the same.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>JoytirghanandaVs. Dy. Commr. (1976) 28 DLR (SC) 159.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>InferiorTribunal’s order—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>When theinferior tribunal’s order has been merged in that of the superior court’sorder; the power which is exercisable by the inferior court to amend its ownorders ceases to exist after there has been merger of the inferior court’sorder in that of the superior court’s order.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Pak. RiverSteamers Vs. Commr. Of Income Tax (1978) 30 DLR (SC) 260.</span></i></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> Cases in which the order of the inferiorcourt is not merged in that of the superior court.        Ibid.</span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>— </span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>It may happen that a certain part of theorder may not be a subject matter for the consideration of the superiortribunal or the superior tribunal may dispose of the proceeding before it ongrounds other than the merits of the inferior tribunal Vs order. In such a casethe order of the inferior tribunal or part thereof, as the case may be, may notmerge in the order of the superior tribunal and may preserve its distinctidentity.     Ibid.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Illegalseizure by the Government—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The initialperiod of years under the lease ended on July 31, 1973. The Government by itsunilateral and illegal action dispossessed the petitioners in June 1975.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Neeerala TeaState Vs. Bangladesh Tea Board (1982) 34 DLR 161.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Infructuousdecree—No Court to pass an infructuous decree</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>No Court should pass an infructuous decree.If it comes to the notice of the Court that for the absence of a party who wasnecessary party in the suit, the decree which may be passed may run intojeopardy, the Court may not pass such a decree.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Abu SaberAziz Mohammad V.s. Government of Bangladesh (1979) 31 DLR (AD) 218.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Interveningevents</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Court may take notice of eventshappening after the institution of a suit only when it is necessary to shortenlitigation and doing justice to a case. </span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>It is well-settled that a change of law hasto bc taken notice of until the final disposal of a case either by the trialCourt or by a Court of appeal. It has been emphasized that in the casesreferred, a departure from the well—established principle is to be resorted toonly in exceptional circumstances with a view to shorten litigation and onlywhen such a course would be in the interest of justice.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Province ofEast Pakistan Vs. Nakuldas Mirdha (1968) 20 DLR 769</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>. </span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Invalidmember’s participation in pressed Board’s Proceedings</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Election being invalid participation inBoards proceedings by such invalid member during the period of invalidity doesnot render them illegal.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S.M. WallAhmed Chowdhury Vs. Maufazul Haq Chowdhwy (1956)8 DLR 429. </span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Irregularitiesor even nullities—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>in respectof procedure committed by courts acting under special ordinances andregulations may be condoned. </span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Nana KweiGyarku Vs. Joseph Sam Brew (1968) 10 DLR (PC) 232</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>. </span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Issuance ofsuo motu rule—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Issuance of suo motu rule afterdisposal of the writ petition is wrong and lacks sanction of any authority.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>HabibullaKhan Vs. S.A. Ahmad (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 72.</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Issue ofpublic importance—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Where issuesof far reaching public importance, it is essential to their properdetermination that the pleading should state with particularity the claims madeby the one side and the other and that the court should be fully seized of allthe facts relevant thereto. </span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>AttorneyGeneral Vs. G.P. Baley (1951) 3  DLR481(PC). </span></i></p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span> </div></div>
2323	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Practice and Procedure - Part IV</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  14 DLR 279, 10 DLR 9 (PC), 35 DLR 331, 15 DLR 1, 16 DLR (SC) 654, 34 DLR 161, 5 DLR 521 (PC), 8 DLR 417, 18 DLR (SC) 62, 21 DLR (SC) 382, 8 DLR 429, 7 DLR 406 , 8 DLR 327, 34 DLR 161, 26 DLR (SC) 68, 31 DLR 88, 33 DLR 288, 6 DLR 598 (PC) 603, 34 DLR 227,</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Practice and Procedure</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u> </u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Practice and Procedure</u></strong></p><p> </p><p><strong>Judge’s previous decision.</strong></p><p>Judge’s previous decision on specific law point ought to be accepted as binding on him.</p><p> </p><p><strong>Judgment—Presumptions that on which judgment is silent were not pressed—Cannot always be made. </strong></p><p>There can be no presumption that the Court will always be correct in its decision on points of law or that it will raise and decide the necessary issues every case. It is not always necessary to file an affidavit in support of the ground that all the points which were pressed in the lower appellate Court were not considered.</p><p>Asan Uddin Vs. Abed Ali (1962) 14 DLR 279.</p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Judicial functions – union of, with executive functions.</strong></p><p>Union of judicial functions with executives, administrative and arbitral functions in the same court unconstitutional and ultra vires. A body whose primary or only object is administrative, executive or arbitral cannot be converted into a court merely by being called a court—Essential difference between judicial power and arbitral power— whether a tribunal is a court depends upon the substance— Incidents of a court.</p><p><em>Attorney General Vs. The Queen (1958) 10 DLR 9 (PC)</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>Jurisdiction and exercise of jurisdiction —Distinction</strong></p><p>Distinction between jurisdiction and exercise of jurisdiction – Civil Courts not to correct errors of judgments of Revenue Officers far less the Executive officers.</p><p><em>Golam Hossain Vs. Abdul Manna (1983)35 DLR 331.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>Laches defeats claim for relief</strong></p><p>In refusing the petitioner’s petition for relief under Art. 98 the court in this circumstances of this case, made the following observations:—</p><p>On the one hand, we are faced with facts which leave no room for any doubt that the respondents not only acted illegally but also in a most high— handed manner, on the other hand, we are also faced with the proposition that, if we allow the petitioner the relief prayed for, we would be encouraging petitioner to come to this considerable lapse of time. The relief which this Court can give under Art. 98 must be given having regard to considerations of laches and delay on similar principles upon which prerogative writs were issued</p><p><em>Akhtaruddin Khan Vs. Pov. of East Pakistan (1963) 15 DLR 1.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Law requiring application of mind—A mere counter-signing the order complained of not proper fulfillment of the law’s requirement.</strong></p><p>It was contended that by mere counter—signing the order passed by the Settlement Commissioner, the Chief Settlement Commissioner did not act in accordance with law.</p><p>Held: The Chief Settlement Commissioner had not exercised the jurisdiction vested m him in accordance with law and there was no proper disposal of the revision petition filed before him.</p><p><em>Ghulam Mohiuddin vs. Chief Settlement Commissioner, Lahore (1964) 16 DLR (SC) 654.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Law flagrantly set at naught by the government</strong></p><p>The Petitioner’s inalienable right to enjoy the protection of the Jaw and to be treated in accordance with law, and only in accordance with law as guaranted under Article 31 of the Constitution has been clearly infringed.</p><p><em>Neerala Tea Estate Ltd. Vs. Bangladesh Tea Board. (1982) 34 DLR 161.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>Legislation where offending the constitution.</strong></p><p>There may be circumstances in which legislation though framed so as not to offend directly against a constitutional limitation of the power of the legislature may indirectly achieve the same result and that in such circumstances the legislation would be ultra vires.</p><p><em>Govindan Silappa Vs. Punche Banda. (1953) 5 DLR 521 (PC).</em></p><p>—It must be shown affirmatively by the party challenging a statute which is upon its face intra vires that it was enacted as part of a plan to effect indirectly something which the legislature had no power to achieve directly. Ibid.</p><p> </p><p><strong>Legislation—principle of</strong></p><p>The principle that a legislature cannot do indirectly what it cannot do directly has always been recognized by the Privy Council and a legislature must of course be assumed to intend the necessary effect of its statutes. But the maxim omnia pracsumuntur rite esse acta is at least as applicable to the Act of a legislature as to any other acts and the court will not be astute to attribute to any legislature motives or purposes or objects which are beyond its power.</p><p><em>Govindan Silappa Vs. Punchi Banda (1953) 5 DLR 521 (PC)</em></p><p><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p><strong>Legislature to determine the composition of its nationals.</strong></p><p>It is a perfectly natural and legitimate function of the legislature of a country to determine the com— position of its nationals. Standards of literacy, of property, of birth or of residence are standards which a legislature may think it right to adopt in legislation on citizenship and it is clear that such standard though they operate to exclude the illiterate, poor an the immigrant to greater degree than they may ex., elude other people do not create disabilities in a community by its literacy, its poverty or its migratory character but by its race or its religion. <em>(1953) 5 DLR 521 (PC).</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Legislature illegally adding to its members—</strong>The general rule is that if a legislature illegally adds to its members and the persons so added take part in discussion and voting the laws passed by ii are void.</p><p><em>Federation of Pakistan Vs. A. Ahmed Hossain Sah (1955) 7 DLR (FC) 279 (281 r-h.col).</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Liability arising out of debt—</strong>Liability arising out of debt and the manner of payment of debt under D.S. Board’s direction by in statements are different. If the manner of payment can’ not be given effect to the liability Continues to exist.</p><p><em>Siddik Ahmed Khan Vs. Gura Mia Khan (1956) 8 DLR 417.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Letter put in the process of transmission by posting it cannot be held to beyond recall if the post office is instructed to withhold it or a quicker means of transport is used before the letter reached the addressee</strong>.</p><p>It was suggested that once the letter of resignation had been put in transmission so as to go beyond recall of the writer, it could not have been withdrawn.</p><p><strong>held:</strong> If such a letter is sent by post, the possibility is still open that, before it is delivered to the addressee, it may be withheld at the instance of the sender, by the Postal Authority, or the latter being satisfied that the sender did not want it to be delivered at its destination. The Post Office acts in such a case as an agent of the sender and not of the addressee. Again, if the letter is sent through a messenger and overtakes him by a quicker means of transport, so as to prevent him reaching his destination, the resignation, would not take effect.</p><p><em>Fazlul Quader Chowdhury Vs. Shah Nawaz (1966) 18 DLR (SC) 62</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Matter not raised in the original Court—</strong>should not ordinarily be allowed to be raised in appeal.</p><p><em>Allahdino Vs. Fakir Mohammad, (1969) 21 DLR (SC) 382.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>Members wrongly elected or nominated —acts done by,</strong></p><p>Acts done by wrongly elected or nominated members do not become invalid, before the member’s election or nomination is declared invalid, nor the Board’s proceedings are affected.</p><p><em>S.M. Wali Ahmed Chowdhury Vs. Mahfuzul Haq Chowdhury (1956) 8 DLR 429.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Made of determining the nature of claim sought to be assigned</strong></p><p>The true test for determining the nature of a claim sought to be assigned should be to see that the claim when it does accrue partakes of the character of a debt beneficial interest in moveable property not in the possession, either actual or constructive, of the claimant which can be recovered by an action.</p><p><em>Kazi Abdul Ali Vs. Nurul Amin (1955) 7 DLR 406 (411 r-h. col)</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Municipal law prevails over international law</strong>— and the courts are bound to administer law as it stands. <em>Jagadish Ch. Mazumdar Vs. Commr. of Agriculture. (1956) 8 DLR 327.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>Nationalization order was passed unlawfully—</strong>Petitioner 2 politically victimized from a motive of personal vendetta—Obligations of a constitutional government functioning under a full—fledged Constitution was thrown to the winds, the Prime Minister passed an order of nationalisation when under law of the land such an order could not be passed much less to take over the Garden.</p><p><em>Neerala Tea Estate Vs. Bangladesh Tea Board (1982) 34 DLR 161.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>Nationalisation Order was without legal basis—</strong>Order of Nationalisation passed by the Prime Minister totally without any legal basis—Order for resuming the Garden is clear breach of lease condition and opposed to the law of nature.   Ibid.</p><p> </p><p><strong>Natural justice</strong></p><p>An application or substitution of the heirs of a deceased opposite party was made before the trial court (in this particular case) on 9.8.58 when it was contended on behalf of other opposite parties that death actually took place much earlier and therefore the case had abated for non—substitution of the heirs of the said deceased opposite party. On a direction by the Appellate Court to Trial Court (which dismissed the applicant’s cast,) for giving opportunity to the applicant to get the abatement set aside, the applicant made an application on 26.8.61 for treating the application made on 9.8.58 as one under Order 22, r. 9, C.P.Code for setting aside the abatement consequent on the death of the opposite party No.1. The Court granted the prayer and set aside the abatement of the case but on appeal, the High Court held that the application filed on 9.8.58 could not be treated as one made under Order 22, r. 9, of the Code. On appeal by special leave to the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, it has been held: It is true that there was no prayer for setting aside abatement in the application filed on 9.8.58 and there could not be any such prayer in the said petition since the death of opposite party No. I was shown as within time. But in the application filed on 26.8.61 the appellant stated:</p><p>“Before the date of 9.8.58, this petitioner was not aware of the death. Therefore, this petitioner is entitled to get extension under section 5 of the Limitation Act.”</p><p>And thereafter made the following prayer: “The application filed on 9.8.58 by this petitioner for the substitution of the heirs may be treated as an application under Order 22, r. 9 C.P.C.</p><p>Technically it can be said that the petition filed on 9.8.58 cannot be treated as an application for setting aside abatement since there was no such prayer in the said petition. But when the applicant for setting aside abatement filed a petition on 26.8.61 stating that he had no knowledge of the death earlier and is entitled to get extension under section 5 of the Limitation Act and the learned Munsif, for ends of justice, treated the petition as a proper one for disposal of the issue and disposed it accordingly.</p><p>The technicality of form, if adhered to, as the High Court took to be so, and then there would be no proper dispensation of justice in the facts and circumstances of the case. The substance of the prayer should be looked into taking an overall view of the facts and circumstances of the case, ignoring the mere technicality of form of the petition, and it is not desired that the technicality of form should prevail causing impediment of dispensation of justice.</p><p><em>Abdul Hamid Kazi Vs. Abdul Jabbar (1974) 26 DLR (SC) 68.</em></p><p>—When an order has taken effect and in pursuance of that order certain right has been created in favor of any person that order cannot be withdrawn or rescinded to the detriment of that person.</p><p>When a right has accrued to a person by virtue of an order that order cannot be rescinded by the person who made it. Again, when it is not incumbent upon the Government to punish a 3overnment servant merely because he has been convicted by a court a fresh order of punishment after the petitioner will be reinstated is wholly un-warrantal.</p><p><em>A.H.M. Abdul Hai Vs. Bangladesh (1979) 31 DLR 88.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Next friend—appointment of in the appellate stage.</strong></p><p>Order for Appointment of next friend of a deity can be made in the Appellate stage.</p><p><em>Lalai Mia &amp; ors. Vs. Sree Subhankar Bhowmik Shubha (1981) 33 DLR 288.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>New trial when should not be asked—</strong>Their Lordships of the Privy Council cannot concede to the application made by counsel on behalf of the defendant that the case should be remitted for a new trial to enable him to prove the existence of an agreement in writing which was essential to his case and which he failed to do during hearing which had with numerous adjournments covered a period from March, 1947 to February, 1949.</p><p><em>Emmanuele Grech Vs. Antonio Grech (1954) 6 DLR 598 (PC) 603.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>Notice of requisition issued without any lawful authority—</strong>Impugned notices of requisition in these cases were issued without any lawful authority and of no legal effect.</p><p>The main respondents could not say whether there was any public purpose of public interest in the matter or any form of propriety, as they appeared to be hell—bent in getting the lands for a Society which was not even registered. In their anxiety they even forgot the law that the authority requisitioning or acquiring any property, under the compulsive power of the act, must indicate definitely what part of the land is required by them.</p><p><em>Chandi Kaibarta Das Vs. Bangladesh. (1982) 34 DLR 227.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>Notice for particular relief not available to plaintiff—</strong>Particular relief asked for in the notice not being available to the plaintiff, the court can substitute appropriate relief, without the necessity of a fresh notice under section 80 C.P.C.</p><p><em>Federation of Pak. Vs. Mrs. A.V. Isaacs. (1957) 9 DLR (SC) 16.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>No Court can pass a decree in favor of a defendant which is not sought—</strong>The contention was that the plaintiffs have come to Court for relief but not the defendants but the lower Court passed orders in favour of the defendants though not claimed. The portion of the order objected to, runs thus: The defendant Government and the lessees under the Government arc quite entitled to enter into the Suit properties by removing there from all the plaintiffs of the suits aforesaid’ and the same has been made part of the decree i.e, a decree has been passed in favour of the defendants.</p><p><strong>Held</strong>: No Court can pass a decree in favour of a defendant which is not sought for by him legally.</p><p><em>Jadu Nath vs. Province of East Bengal (1961) 13 DLR 496.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>No existing law authorizing taking over the possession of the petitioner’s Tea garden</strong></p><p>Neither in the affidavit—in—opposition nor in course of submission the learned Assistant Attorney General appearing for the respondent No.2 could point out any provision of law authorizing the Government take possession of the Tea garden in the manner it has been done.</p><p><em>Neerala Tea State Vs. Bangladesh Tea Board (1982) 34 DLR 161</em>.</p><p><strong>No notice served on the Petitioner—</strong>No notice as required by law was served on the petitioner and the Government action further violates rule of natural law—Government action wholly illegal without jurisdiction—government re-entering the garden is without any lawful basis. Ibid.</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2324	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Practice and Procedure - Part V</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  35 DLR (AD) 72, 31 DLR 58, 34 DLR 225, 18 DLR (SC) 267, 34 DLR (AD) 212, 17 DLR (SC) 126, 19 DLR 33, 16 DLR (SC) 298, 33 DLR 16,  33 DLR 17,  35 DLR (AD) 174, 12 DLR 638, 13 DLR 338,  8 DLR (FC) 15,  8 DLR (WP) 86, 7 DLR 6, 34 DLR (AD) 222],  35 DLR (AD)</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Practice and Procedure </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u> </u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Practice and Procedure</u></strong></p><p> </p><p><strong>Objectionable observation quashing of — </strong>In view of the facts and circumstances the findings imputing malafide on the appellant cannot be sustained. Therefore, the objectionable findings and observations made in the judgment of the High Court Division are quashed.</p><p><em>Habibullah Khan Vs. S.A. Ahmed (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 72.</em></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Pay Commission’s recommendation</strong>—must be notified in official gazette to create a legal right.</p><p><em>Manager Vs. Abdus Sattar (1979) 31 DLR 58.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>Plaintiff to prove his case to get a decree—</strong>Plaintiff to prove his case to enable him to get a decree—Absence of the defendant no ground to award decree in plaintiffs favour.</p><p><em>Kiron Chandra Das Vs. Sirajul Hoque Patwari (1982) 34 DLR 225.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>Point not taken in High Court— cannot be raised in Supreme Court.</strong></p><p>A point not taken in the High Court which is involving a question of fact cannot be permitted to be raised in the Supreme Court.</p><p><em>S.M. Ismail &amp; Co. vs. Chief Cotton Inspector (1966) 18 DLR (SC) 267.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>Prize Court—Proceedings in</strong>.</p><p>Since no other rule could be found in the Rules of Business as empowering the Ministry of Law to exercise the functions relating to financial matters which are reserved under the Rules of Business to the Ministry of Finance, in the absence of such a rule the Ministry of Law cannot initiate the proceeding in question in the Prize Court.</p><p><em>Bangladesh Vs. Prize Court, (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 212.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>Prize Court fund: Constitutional provision—</strong>Constitutional provision regarding Consolidated Fund or Public Accounts of the Republic—Prize Courts Fund.</p><p>The Constitution provides that all public moneys which will form, part either of the Consolidated fund or the Public Account of the Republic is payable into such Fund or Account or can be withdrawn from it under an Act of Parliament or Rules made by the President.</p><p><em>Bangladesh Vs. Hon’ble Judge, (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 212.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Procedure—Defect of—</strong> Question of prejudice—Party prejudiced must raise question—Not to be raised suo motu by Court—May be waived by party concerned.</p><p>A question of defect of procedure is always a question of prejudice. When there is no point made of any defect of procedure by the party there is any prejudice to the party…….There is no ground for raising this question suo motu by the Supreme Court.</p><p>An objection as to procedure has force only if prejudice be caused unless there be some strict statutory provision which vitiates proceedings in case of non-compliance.</p><p>With respect to such defects in procedure the settled rule is that they can always be waived and had there been any defect in procedure it would surely have been waived by the fact that no objection was ever taken at any stage.</p><p><em>Zafarullah Khan Vs. Custodian of E. Property (1965) 17 DLR (SC) 126.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Procedural law, amendment of will have retrospective effect.</strong></p><p>Since the provisions of the Code of Civil Procedure is nothing but a procedure, an amending section will have retrospective operation.</p><p><em>Abdul Gafur Sardar vs. Wazedali Talukdar (1967) 19 DLR 33.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Proceedings of one kind treated as those of another kind.</strong></p><p>Ordinary Courts have no objection to treat proceeding of one kind as proceedings of another kind, if dint becomes necessary for doing justice between the parties.</p><p>Court did not allow him to contest the service of notice as the point had not been taken either before the Custodian or in the concise statement.</p><p><em>Ata Ullah vs. Custodian of Evacutive Property (1964) 16 DLR (SC) 298.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Publication necessary before notification comes into force </strong></p><p>It is well settled principle that publication of some reasonable sort is essential before a notification or Act comes into force.</p><p><em>Mohammad Faizullah &amp; others. Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh (1981) 33 DLR 16.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Publication of some reasonable sort—</strong>It is well settled principle that publication of some reasonable sort is essential before a Notification or Act comes into force.</p><p><em>Mohammad Faizllah Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh (1981) 33 DLR 17.</em></p><p><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p><strong>Question of law when dependent upon prior determination of fact.</strong></p><p>Principle that a question of law can for the first time be raised even before the High Court Appellate Division has no application if the determination of a question of law is dependent upon prior determination of a question of fact.</p><p><em>Hafizuddin Ahmed Vs. Mahbubul Huq (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 174.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Railway administration</strong>—Power of the General Manager re: the recommendation of Selection Board.</p><p>The General Manager is not bound to accept the recommendation of a Selection Board nor is he incompetent to revoke an earlier order whereby he accepted the recommendation of the Selection Board but cancelled it later on.</p><p><em>Md. Seraj Mia Vs. D.G. Railways. (1960) 12 DLR 638.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>Registration of document of sale after payment of consideration and taking of actual possession</strong>.</p><p>Generally after payment of the full consideration and execution of the kabala (where it is stated that the land has been given in possession of the transferee) the transferee takes possession of the land and he never waits for getting back the registered kabala from the registration office.</p><p><em>Satya Ranjan halder vs. Surendra Nath (1961) 13 DLR 338.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Re-hearing and re-considering—</strong> difference between—Federal (Supreme) Court can change its opinion. The distinction between an application for the rehearing of a decided case and reconsidering in a subsequent case a question of law previously decided must be borne in mind. The Federal Court on who rest the ultimate responsibility of interpreting the law of the land is like Privy Council, entitled to change its opinion and take a different view from the one it has hitherto held.</p><p><em>Mirza Akbar Ali Vs. Mirza Iftekhar Ali (1956) 8 DLR (FC) 15.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Re-opening of a matter—</strong>The Privy Council consistently refused to re-open a matter, on an application for re-hearing, except where the law had been applied on a mistaken assumption of or by inadvertence the Order—in—Council did not give effect to the intention of the Board as expressed in the judgment. Ibid.</p><p> </p><p><strong>Relinquishment of expectancy</strong></p><p>Relinquishment of expectancy—by a Muslim heir, for consideration received of his right not to claim his right nor to claim his share of inheritance when it opens in future does not operate as a complete transfer, but in equity in can be enforced as an agreement to sell when it comes into the possession of the heir—Application of this principle depends upon the facts and circumstances of each case.</p><p><em>Quamiridin Vs. Mst. Aisha Bi (1956) 8 DLR (WP) 86.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Revenue Court’s order holding plaintiff to be tenant can be challenged in civil court</strong></p><p>A person who’s Suit to contest his liability ejectment has failed and who has been held by the Revenue court to be a tenant can set up in defense his title to the land in a subsequent suit in a civil court for his dispossession. <em>(1955) 7 DLR (FC) 90.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Reversioner refusing to sue—next competent person.</strong></p><p>If the nearest reversioner without sufficient cause refuses to institute proceedings, or he has precluded himself by his own act or conduct from suing or has colluded with the person who had the prior right to bring suit, or concerned in the act alleged to be wrongful, the next respective reversioner would be entitled to sue.</p><p><em>Hajee Yar Ali Khan Chowdhury Vs. Mobarak Ali Chowdhury (1955) 7 DLR 6.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Review of ML. Court’s judgment—Ateration of review forum does not affect parties</strong></p><p>Review of M.L. Court’s Judgments—Previous review Authority is changed for another review authority. A Review of Judgment passed by M.L. Court offers no right of hearing or the persons personal appearance; as such it is not a substantive right which could not be altered by amendment whereby a former review authority is changed by appointment of another review authority—in the absence of any right of personal, appearance etc. the persons concerned is not prejudiced by mere alteration of review forum.</p><p><em>Khandker Moshtaque Ahmed, Vs. Govt.of Bangladesh, (1981) 33 DLR 348. [Reversed by 34 DLR (AD) 222]</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Review of judgment referred in Reg 4</strong>.</p><p>In the matter of review of Judgment referred to in Reg. 4, the Government has to exercise its mined judicially and that should be apparent on the face of record which is lacking hem Appellate Division held it otherwise.   Ibid.</p><p> </p><p><strong>Revisional jurisdiction—exercise of.</strong></p><p>Orders passed in exercise of revisional jurisdiction should be clear and precise.</p><p><em>Abdul Jalil Munshi Vs. Abu Bakr Siddique (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 42 (44).</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Revival of suit when not proper.</strong></p><p>Where a suit was struck out and was re-listed after a lapse of nine years and having regard to the length of the delay and in consequence of setting aside the sale of Land as against a bonafide purchaser for value who had been in occupation of the land during the whole period and had apparently altered the buildings thereon—such a suit ought not to have been re-listed.</p><p><em>John Obojo Agbeygbe Vs. Festus Makene Ikomi (1953) 5 DLR 219 (PC).</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>Rules of procedure—compliance with—imperative.</strong></p><p>Enactments regulating procedure in courts are imperative and not merely directory. If, for instance, an appeal from a decision is given with provisions requiring the fulfillment of certain conditions such as giving notice of appeal and entering into recognizance, or transmitting documents within a certain time, a strict compliance would be imperative and noncompliance would be fatal to the appeal.</p><p><em>Muhd. Hakim Mia Vs. Mafizuddin Dhupi, (1959) 11 DLR 438.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>Rules and forms under an Act—</strong>Rules and forms under the authority of the Act can be referred to for the purpose of the interpretation of the Act.</p><p><em>Aryyasrhan Insurance Co. Vs. Nurul Islam Chowdhury (1958) 10 DLR 510.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Rules of evidence in Muhammedan Law—</strong>The Muhammedan Law relating to rules of evidence is no longer in force, having been superseded by the provisions of the Indian Evidence Act.</p><p><em>Khirodin Nessa Vs. Sekander Biswas (1952) 4 DLR 626.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Same person cannot both be plaintiff and defendant in the same suit.</strong></p><p>A man cannot sue himself. If he is present in one capacity in the suit, his entire involvement in the subject—matter of the suit falls for determination. He need not enlist in the opposite camp for a complete adjudication of his conflicting interests.</p><p><em>Madan Chand Gouthy Vs. Mohammad Nurul Huda. (1979) 31 DLR 372.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>Sovereign authority—suing of</strong></p><p>One independent sovereign power is not the agent of another independent sovereign power as far as municipal courts are concerned unless specifically such a state of agency is, for a particular purpose, assumed and the court is given jurisdiction.</p><p><em>Bengal Store Vs. Dominion of Pak. (1954) 6 DLR 594.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Stamps when not cancelled—</strong>Stamps not cancelled before filing is no ground to reject the instrument.</p><p><em>Anath Bandhu Guha Vs. Sudhangsu Sekar Dey (1979) 31 DLR (AD) 312.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>Standing Rules and Orders</strong>—of Shop Employees of the Bats Shoe Co. Ltd. Clauses 21(8) (XII) and 21(A).</p><p>The plaintiff was found guilty of misconduct under clause 21(B)(XI1) of the Standing Rules and Orders for absenting himself beyond seven days after the expiry of period of leave granted to him. But inspite of the said finding the plaintiff has been dismissed under clause 21(A) though it has been stated in the order that in order to give the benefit of provident fund the order has been passed under clause 21(A).</p><p>No doubt the relationship between the parties is that of master and servant. But in view of the Standing Orders and Rules governing the services of the shop employees, the rules must be strictly followed in terminating the services of an employee. The Service Rules have been framed by the company to be binding both on the employer and the employee.</p><p><em>Abdul Majid Vs. Bata Shoe Co. (1978) 30 DLR 262.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Statute creating liability or right—</strong>Where statute creates a liability or a right and at the same time prescribes a special or particular method or machinery for enforcing it, then that method or machinery alone must be followed and none others.</p><p><em>Almas Khatun Vs. Ezhar Mia, (1956) 8 DLR 82.</em></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Stay of the operation of an order for moving the High Court.</strong></p><p>Granted on condition that petitioner must deposit in court Th. 8000/— which shall be returned to him in the event of his success and in case of failure the Opp. party shall get the same.</p><p><strong>Held</strong>: Order passed on such condition is illegal.</p><p><em>Modern Talkies Vs. Chowrangee Cinema (1976) 28 DLR 416.</em></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Stranger purchasing the interest of a cotenant—</strong>Where the interest of a co-tenant is purchased by a third person, such person becomes a tenant in common with the other co-tenants and the possession of such a co-tenant cannot, in the absence of clear proof to the contrary, be adverse to such purchaser.</p><p><em>Syed Abul Fazal Vs. Nirod Bala Deb Roy (1956) 8 DLR 181.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Subordinate Court’s Order in ignorance of any order of superior Court— not ipso facto null and void—</strong>If any step is taken by any subordinate Court haying ordinary normal jurisdiction In ignorance of any order of a superior Court, the subsequent orders passed by j.he subordinate Court are not ipso facto null and void. But they will stand unless they are either recalled or are set aside.</p><p><em>Rani Harshamukhi Vs. Maharaja Shashi Kanta, (1955) 7 DLR 473 (495 r.h. col.)</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Subordinate legislation when struck down—</strong>Subordinate legislation struck down in conflict with an Act of Parliament.</p><p>A subordinate legislation can be struck down as being invalid if it conflicts with an Act of Parliament under which it is made. It may also be declared unconstitutional if it is seen to violate any provisions of the Constitution.</p><p><em>Kundeswari Ausudhalaya Vs. Bangladesh (1976) 28 DLR 63.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>Superior Court’s Order—inferior Court’s duty in respect thereof—</strong>Although an ex parte order of slay is a valid order, it does not ipsofacto nullify all the proceedings of the Court of the first instance passed subsequently. If the Court comes to know of the orders of the superior Court, it should always act on the orders of the superior Court and the question is not a question of communication only but is one of knowledge of the Court and ibis knowledge may be direct or indirect.</p><p><em>Rani Harshamukhi Vs. Maharaja Shashi Kanta (1955) 7 DLR 495.</em></p><p>—As soon as a subordinate Court is satisfied of the existence of such an order of a superior Court, it must act on it. Ibid.</p><p> </p><p><strong>Superior Court’s power to sit in judgment on a matter which is also before a subordinate Court for trial—</strong>Decision on a particular question by the High Court while disposing of a case when the same question between the same parties was also pending adjudication before a subordinate Court, not a valid ground for the High Court to refuse to decide that question.</p><p><em>Dr. A.N.M Mahmood Vs. Syndicate, University of Dacca (1966) 18 DLR 357.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Surety’s liability enforceable when judgment—debtor fails to pay.</strong></p><p>Suret’s liability to pay money he undertook to pay is enforceable only when Judgment—debtor failed to pay the same or it was found not realisable from him.</p><p><em>Yusuf Ali Mondal &amp; ors. Vs. Soleman Ali Biswas (1981) 33 DLR 286.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>Suspicion cannot take the place of proof—</strong>A strong amount of suspicion which attaches to the plaintiff’s case does not amount to proof.</p><p><em>Misri Lal Nayak Vs. Mst. Surji (1957) 9 DLR 375 (PC).</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2325	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Practice and Procedure - Part VI</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  27 DLR 603, 25 DLR 99, 8 DLR (FC) 15, 31 DLR 372, 10 DLR (PC), 8 DLR (PC) 19, 32 DLR 292, 35 DLR 65, 30 DLR 231, 8 DLR (WP) 66, 13 DLR (SC) 47</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Practice and Procedure </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Practice and Procedure</u></strong></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>Temporary suspension order—</strong>Does not require a prior show cause notice.</p><p>No judicial decision is available in support of proposition that an interim administrative order for temporary suspension of any person in any office, required any prior show cause notice, particularly when such order is followed by a quasi—judicial proceeding where the aggrieved person is enabled to defend oneself before any final penal action is taken.</p><p><em>MR. Khan Vs. Bangladesh (1975) 27 DLR 603.</em></p><p> </p><p>—Time allowed by Court to do an act by a certain date—whole of that date available for performance of that act.</p><p>When time is allowed by the Court upto a certain date for performance of an act the whole of that date will be available to the person to whom the time is allowed for compliance with the order. (Chowdhury, C.J.)</p><p><em>Md. Ramjan Vs. Faziul lluq (2963) 25 DLR 99.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Transfer of a case—Friendship with a judge.</strong></p><p>Friendship with a judge is not a factor to disqualify a judge to hear a case.</p><p><em>Mirza Akbar Ali Vs. Mrza Jftekhar Ali, (1956) 8 DLR (FC) 15.</em></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Transposition takes place</strong>—between two different persons and not between the same people.</p><p><em>Madan Chand Gouthy Vs. Mohammad Nurul Huda, (1979) 31 DLR 372.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>Trial Court’s decisions—</strong>Trials court’s decision on fact—advantages which it enjoys—when cannot be disturbed and when can be disturbed. <em>(1957) 9 DLR 682.</em></p><p> </p><p>—It can only be on the rarest occasions, and in circumstances where the appellate court is convinced by the plainest considerations, that it would be justified in finding that the trial judge had formed a wrong opinion. But when the court is so convinced, it is entitled and indeed bound to give effect to its conviction.</p><p>An appellate court is not justified in reversing the trial Judge on what is in truth his perception of the facts not his evaluation of them.</p><p><em>K.M. Parira Vs. H.G. Martin Dias, (1958) 10 DLR (PC).</em></p><p> </p><p>—However excellent a judge’s note of evidence may be, the cases must be rare where, no transcript being available, the appellate court in a case involving the veracity of a witness can properly disturb the finding of fact of the trial judge who made the note.</p><p><em>Md. Akbar Abdul Sattar Vs. W.L. Bogtstra (1956)8 DLR (PC) 19.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>Trial Court’s order when irregular and illegal—</strong>Trial courts order irregular or illegal if it passes an order in contravention of the appellate court’s stay order.</p><p><em>Zillur Rahman Sarkar Vs. Abu Bakkar Siddique  @ Siddique Ali Pk. (1980) 32 DLR 292.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Trial Court’s reasoning and findings—when agreed to by 1st appellate Court.</strong></p><p>When the 1st. appellate court agrees with the reasoning and findings of the Trial Court it need not re—slate effect of evidence or repeat reasons of the Trial Court.</p><p><em>Abdus Salam Vs. Md. Ustar (1983) 35 DLR 65.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Verification of antecedents—</strong></p><p>Of an intending employee is not a punitive measure and question of giving opportunity to show cause does not arise.</p><p>There is no doubt that the service of a temporary employee can be terminated according to the terms and conditions of the contract. In the instant case, the Government could have terminated the case without showing any cause.</p><p><em>Md. Abdur Rashid vs. Govt. of Bangladesh (1978) 30 DLR 231.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>Voting paper— casting of</strong></p><p>Voting paper taken out from one booth and cast into box in another booth, invalid.</p><p><em>Md. Mohsin Siddiqui vs. Chief Judg Karachi. (1956) 8 DLR (WP) 66.</em></p><p><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p><strong>What an appellate or revisional authority is competent to do.</strong></p><p>The revisional authority not empowered to pass an order which the original Court could not have passed.</p><p>The conception of an appellate or revisional authority is that it examines the original order for determining whether it ought to have been passed in accordance with the law and even though in some exceptional case an order may be passed by the revisional authority in view of some facts which had occurred after the original order was passed, it is not empowered to pass an order on any ground on the basis of which the original Court could not have proceeded.</p><p><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">M.M. Ispahani Ltd. vs. Md. Sultan (1961) 13 DLR (SC) 47.<span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></span></em></p></div></div>
2326	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Pre-emption</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>   3 DLR 224, 9DLR 476</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Pre-emption</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Pre-emption</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p><strong>Pre-emptor gets the land by arrangement.</strong></p><p>If a pre-emptor succeeds in having the property transferred to himself from the purchaser by private arrangements instead of bringing a suit, it would not be right to say that he has not exercised his right of pre-emption.</p><p><em>Mehr Baksh Vs. Mala Dad (1951) 3 DLR 224.</em></p><p>In the absence of a proof that physical possession of a property was taken by the vendee on the date of the execution of the deed, the period of one year under Article 10 of the Limitation Act, within which the pre—emptor is entitled to exercise his right of pre—emption must be taken to have commenced from the date on which the deed in favour of the purchaser was registered.   <em> Ibid.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Pre-emption—covenant for</strong></p><p>A covenant for pre-emption or a covenant giving an option of repurchase, if entered into after the coming into force of the Transfer of Property Act, does not create any interest in the land itself and the covenant is merely a personal covenant, binding the parties to the contract, and such covenants can only be enforced by a Suit for specific performances under section 27 of the Specific Relief Act. Such covenant could be enforced against a transferee only if such transfer was gratuitous transfer with notice.</p><p><em>Nagendra Chandra Vs. Parameswar Roy, (1957) 9DLR 476.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>Partial pre-emption</strong>—Co-sharers pre-empting of land and claiming rest in their own right—Suit incompetent. <em>1957(1) PLR WP (311.)</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2327	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Premises Rent Control Act, 1953</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  11 DLR 253, 7 DLR 266, 13 DLR (SC) 13, 11 DLR (SC) 193, 13 DLR 245, 8 DLR 272, 12 DLR 781, 12 DLR 720, 12 DLR 404, 9 DLR 302, 7 DLR 314, 8 DLR 448, 8 DLR 448, 9 DLR 597,  12 DLR 528,  6 DLR 206,20 DLR 429,  1 DLR (SC) 13, 13 DLR 869, 20 DLR 429, 10 DLR 2</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Premises Rent Control </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p align="justify"> </p><p align="justify"> </p><p align="justify" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Premises Rent Control Act</u></strong></p><p align="justify" style="text-align: center;"><strong>(XVI Of 1953)</strong></p><p align="justify" style="text-align: center;"><strong> </strong></p><p align="justify">The East Bengal Premises Rent Control Act, as appears from Notification No. 8935 L.R., date 26th June, 1954, was not made applicable to the mouzas of the district of Noakhali before 26th June, 1954, and in that notification mouza Shonapur Bazar within Police Station Ramganj has not been included as a place to which the Act was made applicable.</p><p align="justify"><em>Ramani M. Mazumdar Vs. Jasodha Kumar Nath Bepari, (1959) 11 DLR 253.</em></p><p align="justify"> </p><p align="justify"><strong>S. 2(1): Fixing of basic rent</strong></p><p align="justify">In order to find out what is the basic rent of a premises within the meaning of section 2(i) of the East Bengal Premises Rent Control Ordinance, 1951, the Rent Controller will have to find, first, what was the rent paid in respect of the premises in question in 1941, if it had been tenanted. If such rent cannot be ascertained, then he has to determine approximately the rent, at which in reasonable probability the premises were let out in December, 1941. In trying to arrive at a reasonably payable rent he should ascertain rent of similar premises in that locality in 1941.</p><p align="justify">The Municipal assessment by itself cannot be taken as a correct index for fixing basic rent. If no other better data is available, then perhaps the Rent Controller can take it into consideration in ascertaining the reasonable rent in 1941.</p><p align="justify"><strong>Onus on tenant—</strong>When the tenant applies for fixation of standard rent and thereby evades payment of contractual rent, the onus of establishing standard rent should be on him.</p><p align="justify"><em>Aminul Islam Vs. Hiru Mia (1955) 7 DLR 266.</em></p><p align="justify"> </p><p align="justify"><strong>S. 10(2)(c)(ii): Requirement for the use of brother would not satisfy the condition of the section— </strong>Requirement of the premises by the landlord for the use of his brother would not satisfy the condition of section 1 0(2)(c)(ii) of the Act, in the absence of anything to show that the premises were held by him for the benefit of his brother.</p><p align="justify"><em>Abdullah Baloch vs. Adam Ali (1961) 13 DLR (SC) 13.</em></p><p align="justify"> </p><p align="justify"><strong>S. 14(3), cl.(h).</strong></p><p align="justify">The necessary condition for interference by the Controller under clause (h) of section 14(3) of the Act in a case like the present is that, in his opinion, the rent at present fixed for any premises is not just and fair. In such a case, he may fix a standard rent at such amount as, having regard to the provisions of the Act and the circumstances of the case, he deems just. Bearing in mind the proviso to the definition of “standard rent”, the result might be that in a case of the present kind the “standard rent” is any rent which the Controller might think to be just in his uncontrolled discretion. Such a conclusion would, however, run contrary to the nature of the Act, which provides with great particularity, in regard to a large number of specific cases the manner in which the “standard rent” shall be ascertained.</p><p align="justify"><em>Md. Taher Ali Vs.
