Hari Pada Roy Chowdhury, (1959) 11 DLR (SC) 193.</em></p><p align="justify">In view of the fact that the District Judge in appeal has found that the agreement between the landlord and the tenant fixing the rent of the Premises at Rs. 414—to be just and fair, the power of the Controller under clause (h) of section 14(3) was not attracted, and for that reason alone his order inducing the rent from Rs. 414—to 250/- was bad in law. Ibid.</p><p align="justify"> </p><p align="justify"><strong>S. 15 — </strong>Standard rent fixed between the landlord and the previous tenant will have no operative force in a case where another tenant by a fresh contract with the landlord occupies the premises.</p><p align="justify"><em>Ahmed Hossain Vs. Sherbanoo. (1961) 13 DLR 245.</em></p><p align="justify"><em> </em></p><p align="justify"><strong>S. 15(1) — Standard rent fixed payable from the month next after the date of application: </strong>The ordinarily rule as laid down seems to be that the standard rent when fixed should be payable from the month next after the date of application unless reasons to be recorded by the controller he decides that such rent should operate from any earlier or later date. Ibid.</p><p align="justify"> </p><p align="justify"><strong>S. 17 — Deposit of rent in the Controller’s office by the tenant under the Act: </strong>Transmission of money to the landlord or hold it till doubt as to person entitled to receive, resolved—Landlord’s acceptance without prejudice- Rent Controller is a mere ‘conduit pipe’.</p><p align="justify">The tenant is entitled to deposit rent under section 21 in Rent Controller’s office by simply making allegations that the landlord refuses to rent by the postal money order or that there is lx fide doubt or dispute as to who is entitled to receive rent referred to in section 17 and the Rent Controller is bound to accept it and remit the amount by money order to landlord in case of deposit under sub-section (1) of section 21 and in a case of deposit it under sub-section (2) of section 21 hold it until the removal of doubt or settlement of dispute.</p><p align="justify"><em>Md. Akhtar Vs. Md. Abdus Siddique (1956) 8 DLR 272.</em></p><p align="justify"> </p><p align="justify">—This the Rent Controller has to do under the above provisions of the statute irrespective of and without determining whether the said allegations are true or false and even if the landlord accepts any such remittance sent by the Rent Controller under sub-section (4) of section 21 or withdraws ii under sec 22, this will be without any prejudice. Ibid.</p><p align="justify"> </p><p align="justify"><strong>S. 17(1)—Where relationship of land-lord and tenant is denied—Duty of the Rent Controller: </strong>In cases where the relationship is altogether denied and in spite of that Rent Controller lakes the deposit, the landlord will be remediless to go to the ordinary Civil Court for ejectment until he is compelled to apply for permission to sue before t House Rent Controller and that is decided in his favour. The acceptance of the deposit by the Rent Controller will at least mean that he has assumed jurisdiction of the matter.</p><p align="justify">When a deposit case is heard and decided on the ground that the parties do not stand in the relationship of landlord and tenant at all, the House Rent Controller has .to come to some decision on the same. In such a situation, the House Rent Controller is not a mere conduit pipe for deposit or his office a mere counter for the acceptance of deposit.</p><p align="justify"><em>Haji Yunus Bepari Vs. Abdul Majid Khan (1960) 12 DLR 781.</em></p><p align="justify"><em> </em></p><p align="justify"><strong>S.17— ‘As long as’- What the words connote: </strong>The words “as long as” in section 17(1) indicate that the point of time at which it has to be decided whether the tenant has paid the rents allowable under 314. the Act to the full extent or not is the point of time at which the order or decree for eviction is to be made and this must inevitably be much later than the permission for the filing of the suit granted by the Rent controller.</p><p align="justify"><em>Ananda Sundari Karmakar Vs. Dr. Mozamnel Huq (1960) 12 DLR 720.</em></p><p align="justify"> </p><p align="justify"><strong>S. 17(1) provision (e) — For use and occupation of landlord’s constituted attorney— whether the proviso is applicable</strong>: The words of the Act in section 17(I)(e) that the premises are required by the landlord either for his own occupation or for the occupation of any person for whose benefit the premises are held do not include the constituted attorney of the landlord, for, the occupation or the use of the constituted attorney is neither for the own occupation of the landlord nor for the occupation of any person for whose benefit the premises c held.</p><p align="justify"><em>Md. Israil Biswas Vs. Amrita Lal Chowdhury (1960) 12 DLR 404.</em></p><p align="justify"><em> </em></p><p align="justify"><strong>—</strong>Grounds stated in the application for permission is sue for ejectment before the Rent controller as also before the Civil Court in a suit filed for ejectment-Because an additional ground was added in the suit this will not make the suit defective.</p><p align="justify"><em>A.K.M. Faziul Kader Chowdhury Vs. Haji Abdul  Matin Sowdagar (1957) 9 DLR 302.</em></p><p align="justify"> </p><p align="justify"><strong>S.17 (e) — Bona fide requirement</strong>: Where the landlord wants the house for his own use and occupation, it will never be considered sufficient that he should “desire” to have the premises back or even that he should “require” them, but it has been further insisted that the requirement must be “bona fide requirement” for the purposes recognized by the Act. As regards the “bona fide requirement” for rebuilding, the landlord has to satisfy the Court that he honestly desires to build and rebuild.</p><p align="justify">Partial eviction of tenant is not tenable before a Court though it may be effected by the parties by mutual consent.</p><p align="justify"><em>Jagadish Sarkar Vs. Abdul Aziz (1955)7 DLR 314.</em></p><p align="justify"><strong> </strong></p><p align="justify"><strong>Own occupation includes occupation of family members as daughters—</strong>By the use of the word ‘required’ in section 17(e) of the East Bengal Premises Rent Control Act, the Legislature clearly intended to indicate that there must be a genuine present need which must not merely be a desire for the premises, but at the same time it does not go to the .extent of saying that the word ‘required’ connotes that there must be an absolute necessity.</p><p align="justify"><em>Mulla Mahbub Ali Vs. Janab Ali, (1956) 8 DLR 448.</em></p><p align="justify"><em> </em></p><p align="justify"><strong>—</strong>The landlord’s case was that he would retire soon from service when he would have to take up his residence at Pabna and that he required the premises for keeping his marriageable daughters there under the guardianship of their uncle in Pabna.</p><p align="justify"><strong>Held:</strong> So far as the need for the housing of the marriageable daughters is concerned, even the element of ‘must have’ is present there and the fact that the landlord possesses a house in a village not very. far from the town of Pabna does not affect the question of his need for a house in the place where the daughters are already staying under the guardianship of their uncle. The only question is as to whether the needs of the daughters comes sufficiently within the meaning of ‘own occupation’ for the purposes of this Act. It would be putting too narrow a construction on the words ‘own occupation’ to say that the words were limited to the personal occupation of the landlord himself and of none others. The words ‘own occupation’ must embrace the occupation of the landlord himself personally as also of such members of his family as are dependent on him.</p><p align="justify"><em>Mulla Mahbub Ali Vs. Janab Ali, (1956) 8 DLR 448.</em></p><p align="justify"><em> </em></p><p align="justify"><strong>Sec. 17 clauses (1) and (6) — </strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">The landlord brought a suit against the tenant, who has been found to be habitual defaulter in payment of rent and who had not deposited the admitted rent, for recovery of arrears of rent and he also filed an application before the Rent Controller for permission to sue the tenant for ejectment. About three months after the filing of the rent suit and the case for permission for ejectment, the tenant applied to the Rent Controller for fixing of standard rent.</span></p><p align="justify"><strong>Held:</strong> The application for fixation of standard rent does not lie where it is made malafide.</p><p align="justify"><em>Syed Akhtar Alam Vs. Md. Zafirul Huq, (1957) 9 DLR 597.</em></p><p align="justify"><strong> </strong></p><p align="justify"><strong>S. 17(1) — Material time in default of payment of rent is the date</strong> <strong>of decree: </strong>The material time to consider whether there has been default in the payment of rent is the date on which the decree in the suit comes to be passed by the Court. The words ‘so long as’ occurring in sub-section I of section 17 of the Act indicate a continuity of payment and the opening words of that sub-paragraph indicate the terminus of that continuity.</p><p align="justify"><em>Mulla Mahbub Ali Vs. Janab Ali, (1956) 8 DLR 448.</em></p><p align="justify"> </p><p align="justify"><strong>—Arrear rents for period before transfer paid to the transferee -if can be treated payment of rent falling due after the transfer.</strong></p><p align="justify">The landlord acquired the premises in occupation of the tenant in January 1955. The tenant paid to the landlord arrears of rent due prior to his acquisition in January, 1955 and subsequently when the landlord brought an ejectment suit against the tenant for default in paying rent subsequent to January 1955, the tenant claimed that the arrears rent paid to the landlord for the period which was prior to his acquisition in January, 1955 should be adjusted to the rent fallen due after January, 1955. If the tenant i given an adjustment for arrears of rent paid to the landlord in respect. of the rents due prior to the landlord’s acquisition of the property there would be no default at all.</p><p align="justify">Held: The tenant is not entitled to claim such an adjustment. If he feels that the assignment of the arrears of rent has been invalidly made and the arrears of rent wrongfully realized he may sue to recover them from the landlord but that does not entitle him as a matter of right to claim an adjustment in respect of the default accruing subsequent to the transfer of the property.</p><p align="justify"><em>Abdul Hafiz Abdul Nabi Vs. M. Doud Ali, (1960) 12 DLR 528.</em></p><p align="justify"> </p><p align="justify"><strong>S. 17(1) Proviso (b) — </strong>Where there has been a sub-letting of the premises by the ten without any permission or consent in writing o the landlord, he provisions of proviso (1,) of section 17(I) of the Act would apply.</p><p align="justify"><em>Wahed Ali Mia Vs. Haji Abdul Wahed (1954) 6 DLR 206.</em></p><p align="justify"> </p><p align="justify"><strong>S. 17(1)</strong> <strong>—</strong> Protection afforded to the tenants subject to his fulfilling the laid down conditions Sub-letting the premises by the tenant is a breach of such condition.</p><p align="justify"><em>Babu Saradindu Bhusan Nandi vs. Gopal Chandra Roy (1968) 20 DLR 429.</em></p><p align="justify"> </p><p align="justify"><strong>S. 17(i)(e) — ‘Certificate’ of controller must satisfy all formal requirement of law: </strong>Landlord’s plea that he required the premises bonafide for personal use negatived by Rent Controller but he granted certificate on the ground thaw landlord required the premises for re-construction purpose and in so saying the Rent Controller not use the words “reasonably and in good faith Certificate invalid in law.</p><p align="justify"><em>Abdullah Baloch vs. Adam Ali (1961) 1 DLR (SC) 13.</em></p><p align="justify"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p align="justify"><strong>S.17 (e) — Bonafide requirement for personal use may arise subsequently</strong>: A landlord or a owner of a house may hay family members or other dependents who might grow in number and might also require more accommodation from time to time.</p><p align="justify">It is true that the owner concerned must have a bonafide necessity for using and occupying the entire house but while determining the question as to bonafide necessity, the desirability of allowing the landlord for having better accommodation should not be ignored or overlooked.</p><p align="justify"><em>Fazlur Rahaman Vs. Nyeema Khatun (1961) 13 DLR 869.</em></p><p align="justify"><strong> </strong></p><p align="justify"><strong>S. 17(3) Provision of sub-section 3: </strong>Sub-section (3) of section 17 of the Act is a mere elaboration of proviso (b) to sub section (I). It is not an independent sub-clause (3) but must be read along with sub-section (1), proviso (b) which began with the words “in the absence of any contract to the contrary”. Therefore the words “in the absence of any contract to the contrary” must also be read with sub-section (3).</p><p align="justify">Where there is no contract to the contrary, subsection (3), will come into play so far as sub-letting with regard to premises used by the tenant for commercial purposes are concerned. But if there is contract to the contrary it will govern all cases of sub-letting whether the premises are being used for residential purposes or for commercial purposes or for industrial purposes.</p><p align="justify"><em>Babu Saradindu Bhusan Nandi Vs. Gopal Ch. Roy, (1968) 20 DLR 429.</em></p><p align="justify"><em> </em></p><p align="justify"><strong>S. 18 — Bona fide requirement— Civil Court to decide the question over again: </strong>Rent Controller’s decision about the bona fide requirements is not final. Civil Court can go into that question again.</p><p align="justify"><em>Satish Ch. Pal Vs. Mst. Mazidan Begum (1956) 1O DLR 271.</em></p><p align="justify"> </p><p align="justify"><strong>—</strong>Question whether the landlord requires the premises bona fide is to be determined afresh by Civil Court after the decision of the same question by the Controller.</p><p align="justify"><em>Hamidun Nissa Bibi Vs. Faizur Rahman (1958) 10 DLR 275.</em></p><p align="justify"><em> </em></p><p align="justify"><strong>—</strong>Life of the East Bengal Rent Control Act (XVI of 1953) expired on 31.12.60—Ordinance XXV of 1961 was promulgated in July 1961 which re-enacted the provisions of the Act XVI of 1953. In between January 1961 to July 1961 the East Bengal Rent Control Act did not exist.</p><p align="justify">In this particular case, an application was made w the 22nd of May, 1960 for permission to sue the defendant in eviction on the ground of plaintiff’s bonafide use and occupation of the premises. Such premise was granted by the Controller on the 5th of June, 1961 that is to say, on a date when the E.B. Rent Control Act did not exist nor the Ordinance XXV of 1961 came into being.</p><p align="justify">The suit was, however, filed, on the 30th of September, 1961. Therefore, at the time when the suit was filed, under the law, the permission of an appropriate Rent Controller again became necessary.</p><p align="justify"><strong>Held:</strong> The application for such permission would come within the purview of the Ordinance because it commenced proceedings which even after the period of vacuum, was kept alive by section 38 of the ordinance. It is true that the permission itself was given at a time when there was a legislative vacuum, but the permission obtained by plaintiff is one which comes within the express terms of the subsequent legislation namely Ordinance XXV of 1961.</p><p align="justify">Further no permission of the Rent Controller is necessary under the Ordinance of 1963 at the present moment. Therefore, plaintiff is new competent to maintain the suit without permission of the Rent Controller.</p><p align="justify"><em>Iftakharuddin Vs. Sekander Jahan Begum (1965) 17 DLR 347.</em></p><p align="justify"><em> </em></p><p align="justify"><strong>Sec 18 and 19 —</strong> Permission to institute a suit for ejectment not obtained before the filing of the suit for ejectment in Civil Court but obtained after the institution of the suit.</p><p align="justify">A suit for ejecting a tenant filed without previously obtaining the permission of the House Rent Controller is maintainable though the section speaks of “no suit or proceeding by a landlord against a tenant shall be entertained or proceeded with by any Court”. It does not say that no suit shall be filed without the permission of the House Rent Controller. Therefore, filing of the suit is not barred. What is barred is the entertainment of suit by the Court which means that the suit “shall not be considered by the Court” unless a permission from the House Rent Controller has been produced by the landlord.</p><p align="justify">Where the landlord has after remand obtained an order from the House Rent Controller permitting him to institute a suit that is sufficient for the entertainment of the suit by the Court.</p><p align="justify"><em>Dwarika N. Das Vs. Md. Abdulla (1960) 12 DLR 423.</em></p><p align="justify"><em> </em></p><p align="justify"><strong>S.19</strong> <strong>—</strong> As regards the question of default in payment of rent—the civil court before passing a decree has to be satisfied over again inspite of the decision of the Rent Controller.</p><p align="justify">Notwithstanding the decision of the Rent Controller the question whether the tenant concerned has paid rent due to the full extent allowable by the Act within the time fixed has to be re-investigated into by the civil court when the Suit comes up for hearing there.</p><p align="justify">There is no difference in principle between the provisions contained in section 18 and those in section 19 of the East Bengal Premises Rent Control Act, 1953.</p><p align="justify"><em>Ananda Sundari Karmakar Vs. Dr. Mozarnmel Huq (1960) 12 DLR 720.</em></p><p align="justify"> </p><p align="justify"><strong>—</strong> Several causes of actions were all combined in a suit for eviction in which one of the causes of action, namely, non-payment of rent required Rent Controller’s permission-Suit for eviction not maintainable without Rent Controller’s permission.</p><p align="justify"><em>United Suppliers &amp; Co. vs. Tarapada Sarkar (1961) 13 DLR 127.</em></p><p align="justify"><em> </em></p><p align="justify"><strong>Sec 19(2) and rule 6A — Matters which should weigh before giving permission to sue the tenant for ejectment— Ejectment sought on the ground of default— Determination of standard rent: </strong>Rent Controller should be a little more vigilant in safe-guarding the interest of the tenant when the permission applied for on behalf of the landlord to sue the tenant in ejectment is made only on the ground of default. The Rent Controller seems to have been given powers even to determine the standard rent of the premises when he is satisfied that reasonable grounds exist for non-compliance with the provisions of the Act and then to allow the tenant an opportunity to pay or deposit the arrear rent before an order is made rejecting the application for permission.</p><p align="justify">On a construction of rule 6A read with section 19(2) of the Act it would appear that in a case where there is a likelihood of dispute on the score of absence of any standard rent that dispute should be resolved by fixation of the standard rent and by allowing tenant to pay up according to the standard rent all arrears up to the date of the order. In the event of the tenant defaulting in such circumstances the permission to sue in ejectment on the ground of default could be granted in favour of the landlord.</p><p align="justify">Where there has been a case for fixation of standard rent which resulted ultimately in favour of the tenant, it means that there was some dispute or misgivings between the parties as to what should have been a just and fair rent technically called standard rent.</p><p align="justify"><em>Ahmed Hussain vs. Sherbanoo. (1961) 13 DLR 245.</em></p><p align="justify"> </p><p align="justify"><strong>S. 19 (2) — Requirements of the section which must be compiled with before passing an order—if the tenant has paid to the landlord or deposited rents before the order for eviction is made—application to be rejected: </strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">In a proceeding for eviction for non-compliance with the provisions of the Act as to the payment of rent, section 19(2) of the Act provides that the Controller, after giving the tenant in possession of the premises an opportunity of showing cause, must consider all the circumstances of the case and be satisfied that there has been no such compliance with the provision of the Act as to payment or deposit of rent due by such tenant in respect of such premises and that no reasonable grounds exist for such noncompliance. In the latter event, if the tenant has paid to the landlord in the manner in which the deposit is to be made under the Act, rents allowable there under before the order kr eviction is made, then the Controller should make an order rejecting the application.</span></p><p align="justify"><em>Md. Israil Biswas Vs. Amrita lal Chowdhury (1960) 12 DLR 404.</em></p><p align="justify"> </p><p align="justify">—Under the provisions of sub-section (2) of sec. 19 of the Act, if the Controller is satisfied that there has been no non-compliance with the provisions of the Act as to the payment or deposit of rent or that reasonable grounds exist for such non compliance and if the tenant has paid to the landlord I or has deposited in the manner provided by the Act all arrears of the rent then he shall refuse such permission. The section further goes on to say that if the Controller in not so satisfied or if the tenant has not so paid or deposited the rent as allowed in this Act the Controller shall make the order applied for. It is thus clear from the above provisions that the Rent Controller, as also the Appellate Court, are perfectly competent to go into this question and have in fact to be satisfied about this question before they could make any order one way or the other.</p><p align="justify"><em>Mulla Mahbub Ali Vs. Janab Ali (1956) 8 DLR 448.</em></p><p align="justify"> </p><p align="justify"><strong>—</strong>Under the provisions of sec. 19(2) the Controller will give an opportunity to the tenant of showing cause and, thereafter if he considers and if he is satisfied on consideration of all the relevant facts and circumstances that there has been no such non-compliance with the provisions of the Act or that reasonable grounds exist for such noncompliance even then he will reject the application of the landlord after recording the reasons, provided the arrears are paid as laid down in the Act.</p><p align="justify"><em>Syed Akhter Alam Vs. Zafirul Huq. (1957) 9 DLR 597.</em></p><p align="justify"> </p><p align="justify"><strong>Secs. 19(2) and 21(1)</strong> <strong>— </strong>Unless arrear of rent is either paid to the landlord or deposited in the manner provided for under sub-section (I) of section 21 of the Act, the Rent Controller has no other alternative but to pass the order permitting the landlord to sue the tenant for ejectment under section 19(2) of the Act.</p><p align="justify"><em>Mukunda Lal Pakrashi Vs. Traders Syndicate (1957) 9 DLR 260.</em></p><p align="justify"> </p><p align="justify"><strong>S.21</strong> <strong>— </strong>Payment of rent to the E.B. Evacuee Management Committee after the property was purchased, not valid.</p><p align="justify"><em>Md. Anwar Vs. Hosne Ara Begum (1962) 14 DLR 586.</em></p><p align="justify"><strong> </strong></p><p align="justify"><strong>Sec 21 &amp; 22 — Deposit of rent: </strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Deposits of rent in the Rent Controller are Office by the tenant under the Act - Transmission of money the landlord or hold it till doubts as to person entitle to receive, resolved. Landlord’s acceptance with prejudice-Rent Controller is a mere ‘conduit pipe’.</span></p><p align="justify"><em>Md. Akhtar Vs. Md. Abdus Siddique (1956) 8 DLR 272.</em></p><p align="justify"> </p><p align="justify"><strong>S.22</strong> <strong>— </strong>Acceptance of money order does not operate as a waiver of quit notice.</p><p align="justify"><em>Moulana Vs. Makhan Lal Saha. (1965) 17 DLR 306.</em></p><p align="justify"> </p><p align="justify">—Provision of the section would prevail over those of the Transfer of Property Act. Ibid.</p><p align="justify"><strong> </strong></p><p align="justify"><strong>S.23</strong> <strong>— </strong>Benefits conferred require that provisions of the Act must be strictly complied with when a party invokes the privileges conferred —Tenant not entitled to make repairs and recover cost unless the condition of the section fulfilled.</p><p align="justify"><em>Sushil Kumar Roy Vs. Rameswar Lal Agarwala (1962) 14 DLR 352.</em></p><p align="justify"> </p><p align="justify"><strong>— </strong>Provisions for realization of repair costs under the section are merely an alternative method. The suit premises were in a bad condition. There upon the Municipality took up the matter and directed the defendant by a notice to re-construct the Suit house according to a plan approved by the Municipality and other necessary things so as to avoid interference with free flow of water with refuses. The landlord- defendant, on getting these notices approached the tenant-plaintiffs and asked them to take up the matter with the Municipality and execute all necessary works of the repairs.</p><p align="justify">The plaintiffs accordingly undertook the repairs as in case of default the structure would be demolished and they would lose their business which they were carrying on in the suit premises.</p><p align="justify">The defendant not having paid the costs of repairs incurred by the plaintiffs the latter sued him for recovery of the costs.</p><p align="justify">Section 23 of the East Bengal Premises Rent Control Act is to be read subject to the provisions of the Act. This section provides a machinery within the Act for realizing the dues of repairs carried out by the tenant from the landlord but it is not the exclusive method. It must be regarded as an alternative method in addition to other methods permissible by law. Moreover the section refers to any repairs. It was not a question of mere repairs but it was a question of support of the suit premises as required to be altered by the Municipality.</p><p align="justify"><em>Kazi Md. Ishaque Vs. Surendra Chandra Bose (1968) 20 DLR 707. </em></p><p align="justify"><em> </em></p><p align="justify"><strong>Sec 23 and 25 — </strong>Where any electric supply in any premises has been discontinued by the landlord the proper section under which the application is to be filed is section 25 of the East Bengal Premises Rent Control Act which corresponds to section 20 of the Rent Ordinance, and not section 23 of the Act. Section 25 of the Act also does not provide for any penalty in case of disobedience to carry out the order of the Rent Controller based under section 23(I) of the Act or section 20(1) of the Ordinance. An aggrieved party can go in appeal against an order under section 23(1) of the Act in a proceeding under section 23(2) of the Act. <em>7 PLR (Dac.) 1163.</em></p><p align="justify"> </p><p align="justify"><strong>Sec 25 — Limitation: </strong>Any complaint by a party under section 25 of the Act must be brought within 6 months from the date of the commission of the act in respect of which the complaint is brought. <em>7 PLR (Dac) 1163.</em></p><p align="justify"><em> </em></p><p align="justify"><strong>Sec 29 — District Judge: </strong>The expression connotes Court of District Judge and does not refer to him as a persona designata.</p><p align="justify"><em>Azizul Huq.Vs. Hanif (1955) 7 DLR 287.</em></p><p align="justify"><em> </em></p><p align="justify"><strong>Sec 29 — District Judge, not a persona designata, but is the Court of the District Judge: </strong>The words ‘District Judge’ in section 29 of the Premises Rent Control Act mean the Court of the District Judge and, therefore, the District Judge or the Subordinate Judge, to whom the District Judge may transfer an appeal becomes seized of the appeal as ordinary Courts of the country under the Code of Civil Procedure; the said courts must also be governed by the ordinary rules of Procedure applicable to such Courts.</p><p align="justify"><em>Sasanka Bimal Dey Vs. Mst. Halima Bai (1957) 9 DLR 213.</em></p><p align="justify"><em> </em></p><p align="justify"><strong>Sec 29 (1)(5) — </strong>An order of the Rent Controller rejecting an application for review is not appealable. Any order passed in an appeal against such order is a nullity.</p><p align="justify"><em>M/S Yad Mahbub and Co. Vs. Dedar Bux (1964) 16 DLR 585.</em></p><p align="justify"> </p><p align="justify"><strong>Sec 29(3) and 29(4) — </strong>There is a distinction between “deciding an appeal” and “disposing an appeal”. the word “decide” connotes the determination of the questions in issue; but “dispose” is wider and may include the power to dismiss for default’ The power to “hear and dispose’ contained in section 29 of the Act is intended to be used at a stage before the appeal is admitted and the records of the called for. <em>(1957) 9 DLR 213.</em></p><p align="justify"> </p><p align="justify"><strong>—The section as amended by section 10A of the Act—If remand order by appellate authority is without jurisdiction: </strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Where there is an appeal against the decision the House-rent Controller to the District Judge the Appellate Court allowed the same and sent the case on remand for ascertaining the basic rent first and then for fixing a standard rent, it was that the remand order was clearly illegal and jurisdiction by virtue of the provisions of 10A of the East Bengal Premises Rent Control which is an amendment of section 29, sub- (4) of the Act by the Government notification No. 14162, dated the 22nd October, 1954. No consent or waiver on the part of any party will make the order within jurisdiction.</span></p><p align="justify">The decision of the House Rent Controller remand and the decision of the Appellate there from are clearly without jurisdiction. <em>8 PLR (Dac.) 1209.</em></p><p align="justify"><strong> </strong></p><p align="justify"><strong>S.29 (5)</strong> <strong>— </strong>Provisions of Order 47. Rule 7 C. Code are attracted by section 29(5) and therefore and appeal would lie from an order rejecting application for review.</p><p align="justify">The provisions of the Civil Procedure Code down in Order 47, arc attracted to sub-section (5) section 29 of the East Bengal Premises Rent Control Act as far as they are applicable. Since Order 47 of the Code bars an appeal from an rejecting an application for review, there can consequently be no appeal under section 29 of the Bengal Premises Rent Control Act, 1953, from an order rejecting an application for review under sub-section (5) of the said section.</p><p align="justify">From the specific words used in sub-section (I) and (5) of section 29, read with the relevant rules made under the Act it is clear that the provisions of the Order 47 rule 7 of the C.P.C., are attracted by sub-section (5) of section 29, of the said Act.</p><p align="justify"><em>Kazi Altaf Hossain Vs. Mst. Matia Begun (1960) 12 DLR 118.</em></p><p align="justify"> </p><p align="justify"><strong>Sec. 29(5) — </strong>Violation of the provisions of the Section 29(5) is no ground to uphold an order obtained by practicing fraud on Court.</p><p align="justify">Provisions of the C.P.Code are applicable to proceedings before the Controller, District Judge and others appointed under section 29(2) of the Act.</p><p align="justify"><em>Md. Idris Khan Vs. Haji Erfanuddin. (1957) 9 DLR 601.</em></p><p align="justify"> </p><p align="justify"><strong>Sec 29(6) — ‘Final’- This word does not take away the revisional jurisdiction of the High Court and means only not appealable.</strong></p><p align="justify">The world “final” occurring in section 29(6) of the Act means that the order of the Rent Controller subject to the result of an appeal to the District Judge is final. It does not, however, take away the jurisdiction of the High Court to interfere with the District Judge’s order under section 115. C.P.Code.</p><p align="justify"><em>Azizul Huq. Vs. Hanif (1955) 7 DLR 287.</em></p><p align="justify"> </p><p align="justify"><strong>Sec. 29 (6) — Not open to revision by the High Court: </strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Order of the District Judge under sec. 29 (6) of the Act, 1953, is final and not open to revision by the High Court under section 115 of the C.P. Code. <em>(1954) 6 DLR 206.</em></span></p><p align="justify"> </p><p align="justify"><strong>Sec 34 and 37 — Inspection by Rent-Controller—Procedure to follow: </strong>When the Rent Controller himself holds the inspection, under rule 5, he shall follow the procedure laid down in the Code of Civil Procedure for the regular trial of suits. The Rent Controller shall not however base his finding solely on the result of his local inspection without giving an opportunity to the parties to let in counter evidence or to explain what is recorded in the inspection report. He should not put his own views or impressions after inspection of a place. He can only make notes of inspection which should be confined to facts.</p><p align="justify">The report of a subordinate officer holding an inspection will be treated as report of a Commissioner for local investigation, and under Order 26 rule 2(2) C.P.C., this will be evidence in the case and the parties with permission of the Court will be entitled to examine the officer concerned.</p><p align="justify"><em>Aminul Islam Vs. Hira Miah. (1955) 7 DLR 266.</em></p><p align="justify"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p align="justify">S.38 - [See under section 18 in the case of Iftakharuddin vs. Sakander Jahan Begum (1955) 17 DLR 347 above]<span id="pastemarkerend"></span></p></div></div>
2328	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Premises Rent Control Ordinance, 1963 &amp; Premises Rent Control Rules, 1964</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>   22 DLR (SC) 134, 31 DLR (AD) 155, 25 DLR 324, 22 DLR 737, 20 DLR 513, 36 DLR (AD) 94, 35 DLR 388, 27 DLR 643, 22 DLR 811, 28 DLR 444, 29 DLR 170, 21 DLR 104, 29 DLR 170, 29 DLR 314, 28 DLR 444, 29 DLR 13, 33 DLR (AD) 55, 26 DLR 221, 31 DLR (AD) 155, 25 </p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Premises Rent Control </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Premises Rent Control Ordinance</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;">(XX of 1963)</p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"> </p><p><strong>S. 2(5): </strong>Explanation. The word ‘premises’ includes not only a building or hut but also grounds, among other things</p><p><em>Abdul Mutaleb Vs. Musammat Rezia Begum (1970) 22 DLR (SC) 134.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>S. 10(a)(b)</strong> Advance payment of rent for a premises hit by S. 10(b) of the Act—Agreement for advance payment of rent hit by S. 23 of the Contact Act.</p><p>Clause (a) of section 10 of the Premises Rent Control Ordinance prohibits the acceptance of any sum of money over and above the rent payable by a tenant. This clause has also made illegal even any claim or invitation of an offer for the payment of such some of money in the form of premium, salami or fine either when a tenancy is being created or renewed, or during its continuance. Under Clause (b) no one is allowed to claim or receive a payment of more than one month’s rent in advance.</p><p>Agreement for lease was void under section 23 of the Contract Act as its object was not lawful and that it having not been registered was unenforceable and also inadmissible in evidence.</p><p>The agreement to pay Tk. 19,200/- by way of advance rent was undoubtedly a part of the consideration of the transaction as defined in section 2(d) of the Contract Act. This contravenes the positive statutory mandate as provided in section 10(b) of the Premises Rent Control Ordinance.</p><p>In view of the unenforceability of the agreement the position is that the appellant is a monthly tenant who is liable to ejectment if he makes default in payment of rent as provided in section 18(5) of the premises Rent Control Ordinance.</p><p><em>Shamsuddin Ahmed Vs. Mohd. Hassan. (1979) 31 DLR (AD) 155.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>S 15(1):</strong> Fixation of standard rent - Rent Controller has to fix standard rent of premises- He shall not hold roving enquiry for the purpose.</p><p><em>Abu Ahmed Vs. Mobarak Ali Chowdhury (1973) 25 DLR 324.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>S. 15(1)</strong>: Rent Controller’s competency in alteration of rent previously fixed by him.</p><p>The Rent Controller has been expressly authorized by section 15 (I) of the Ordinance to fix the standard rent of any premises at the amount per annum which is equivalent to fifteen per cent of the market value of the premises to be assessed in such a manner as may be prescribed.</p><p>In the present case the Rent Controller has exactly done so by altering the monthly rent fixed under the previous enactment from Rs. 35/- to Rs. 125/- and therefore, fixing of the rent in the manner is permissible under the law.</p><p>The word ‘modification’ or ‘alteration’ has been used in the proviso in its usual and ordinary sense and it will be wrong to interpret these words prescribing different meaning thereto.</p><p><em>Abdul Maleq Vs. Alhaj A. K. Md. Hussain (1970) 22 DLR 737.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>Sec 17 —</strong> The transfer of land during the pendency of partition suit so long as a tenant pays to the full extent allowable by the East Pakistan Rent Control Ordinance, but the person in occupation must be tenant. A tenancy created during the pendency of a suit relating to a right to that property is not a tenancy in the eye of law.</p><p><em>Wazed Ali Vs. Sudhir Chandra Das (1968) 20 DLR 513.</em></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>S. 17: Transfer of land during the tenancy of partition suit is hit by the doctrine of lis pendens.</strong></p><p>The Transfer of Property Act will not be applicable so long as a tenant pays rent to the full extent allowable by the East Pakistan Rent Control Ordinance, but the person in occupation must be a tenant. A tenancy created during the pendency of a suit relating to a right to that property is not a tenancy in the eye of law. Ibid.</p><p> </p><p><strong>S.18.</strong> Bonafide requirement—Requirement of room for commercial purposes in an area meant for use as residential purposes. The finding that the shop room is bonafide required by the landlord is based on proper consideration of materials on record as well as on correct interpretation of section 18.</p><p><em>Md. Monzoor Adam Vs. Noor Mohaminad. (1984) 36 DLR (AD) 94.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>S.18(1) — </strong>Eviction of Tenant from the suit premises when sought on the ground of rebuilding--Landlord to prove his such requirement as being bonafide which must contain an element of need.</p><p><em>Abdur Rashid Bhuiyan Vs. Mosammat Rahima Khatun (1983) 35 DLR 388.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>S. 18 (1)(e) — ‘Bonafide require’ explained: </strong>The expression “bonafide require” means a feeling of genuine need and not colorable pretext. The use of the term ‘require’ indicates something more than a mere wish or fancy and it involves an element of need, that is to say, it does not connote a mere subjective phenomenon, but has also an objective Import. The use of the qualifying word ‘bonafide’ along with the word ‘require’ tries to limit the scope of the subjective aspect of the landlord’s feeling of need for his house, although the word ‘bonafide’, the equivalent of which is ‘honestly’ is essentially a subjective concept. The Legislature seems to convey by using the words ‘bonafide require’ a kind of genuine feeling of need and not a colorable pretext.</p><p>The expression, therefore, connotes an honest feeling of need for the house and in ultimate analysis it is a question of fact which is to be determined on the basis of the facts and circumstances</p><p><em>Mst. Shamsher Nessa Vs. Mohsenuddin 1 (1975) 27 DLR 643.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>S. 18 (1)(e)</strong>: Bonafide requirement” as contemplated in section 18(I)(e) of the Ordinance means not merely an assertion as to the requirement of the house by the plaintiffs but something more. He has also to prove by evidence that he needs the house for the use of the same.</p><p><em>Abdul Rouf Vs. Mir Muhibur Rahman Chowdhury. (1970) 22 DLR 811.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Bonafide requirement: </strong>According to law, bonafide requirement also included building or re-building but unfortunately the court below rejected the prayer on the presumption that since the plaintiff had other houses, there was no bonafide requirement. The Learned Judge did not at all consider the petitioner’s case and the exhibits filed by the plaintiff in support of his case.</p><p><em>Dr. Md. Arfan Au vs. Bazlur Rahman (1976) 28 DLR 444.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>S. 18(1) —</strong> So long a tenant pays rent to the full extent he has right to. possess the premises subject to conditions set forth in proviso (a) to (c) of S. 18(I).</p><p><em>Jahur Mia Vs. Sri Ram Prasad (1977) 29 DLR 170.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>S. 18(1) and (4)</strong> : The landlord can evict the tenant if he requires the premises for own use and occupation—Tenant’s right to get back the premises when accrues.</p><p><strong>Sec. 18(4):</strong> Gives an opportunity to the tenant to re-enter the premises or obtain damages if the landlord fails to fulfil the purpose for which eviction was sought.</p><p><em>Haji Habihuilah Vs. Abdul Hamid, (1969) 21 DLR 104.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>S. 18 (1) (5).</strong> Tenant’s obligation- to pay rent fallen due to the full extent—Deposit of rent in court should follow refusal to accept rent duly offered by the tenant. The deposit of rent shall have to be accompanied by an application u/s. 19 (5).</p><p><em>Jahir Mia Vs. Sree Ram Prasad (1977) 29 DLR 170.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>When a tenant becomes a defaulter with liability to eviction—</strong>Tenant is entitled to protection under subsection (1) of section 18 so long as he paid rent to the full extent and performed the conditions of the tenancy. Sub-section (5) of section 18 lays down that the tenant shall not be entitled to the benefit of section 18 (1) unless he paid rent due by him in respect of the premises to the full extent within time fixed either by contract or allowed under the law. It was therefore abundantly clear that under the law any default in payment of rent or failure to deposit the rent with the Rent Controller in accordance with law would render the tenant a defaulter.</p><p><em>Begum Fazilatunessa Vs. Nowshad Au (1977) 29 DLR 314.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>No protection against eviction once the tenant is found a defaulter—</strong>Prayer for eviction cannot be refused on the ground that he was not a habitual or willful defaulter. The law makes no distinction whether a defaulter was habitual or willful otherwise. Ibid.</p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Secs.18(1), 18(5) —</strong>To get the benefit of section 18(5) the tenant must clear his rent dues in terms of the contract or within the 15th day of the month next following.</p><p><em>Dr. Md. Arfn Ali Vs. Bazlur Rahman (1976) 28 DLR 444</em>.</p><p> </p><p><strong>S. 18 (5) Tenant to take care that he does not become a defaulter: </strong>There is no duty cast upon the landlord to pursue the tenant in demanding the rent which falls. It is rather the duty of the tenant to pay rent to the landlord in time with a view to saving him from being a defaulter the consequence of which is his eviction from the premises in his occupation.</p><p><em>Abul Layes Vs. Mst. Anwara Khatun (1977) (SC) 29 DLR 13.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>S.18 (1) (5</strong>): Rent must be paid in terms of contract if any or within 15th day of the next h—In case of refusal to accept rent by landlord the tenant is to remit it by money order. If that too is refused deposit of rent shall be with the Rent Controller—These provisions followed duly secures protection against ejectment—Circumstances which are not within the control of the tenant need consideration.</p><p><em>Profulla Kumar Chakraborty Vs. Anil Proshad Chowdhury (1981)33 DLR (AD) 55.</em></p><p><strong>—Payment of rent in lump (for several months) does not help the tenant from the mischief of default.</strong></p><p>A tenant by making payment of rent in lump of rent in terms of section 18(1) and 18(5) of the Premises Rent Control Ordinance, 1963 is not protected unless there is a contract to the contrary or such payment is covered by waiver and acquiescence on the part of the landlord. Ibid.</p><p> </p><p><strong>S. 18(5) — </strong>Tenant defendants are not entitled to the benefit of the House Rent Control Ordinance unless they pay the rent due in respect of such premises to the full extent within the time fixed in the contract or within 15 days of the month next following which the rent is payable.</p><p><em>Joynal Abedin Vs. Nazira Banu (1974) 26 DLR 221.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>—Deposit of house-rent u/s. 18(5) of the Ordinance must be strictly within the time permitted by the statute or by contract</strong>.</p><p>Failure to deposit the amount of rent on the alleged ground that the necessary permission of the House Rent Controller has not been accorded for such deposit will not protect the tenant from being a defaulter within the meaning of sub-section (5) of section 18 of the Ordinance.   Ibid.</p><p>The learned Counsel submitted that untill the entire amount of Tk. 19,200/- taken by the respondents at the time of creating the tenancy was adjusted, the appellant could not be said to have defaulted in paying rent within the meaning of the aforesaid section. It cannot be denied that there is considerable force in this argument. As long as the respondents had the unadjusted amount in their hands, they could have adjusted it towards the payment of rent for the months of October, November and December.</p><p><em>Shamsuddin Ahmed Vs. Mohd. Hossain (1979) 31 DLR (AD) 155.</em></p><p> </p><p>—Benefit of the sub-section can be claimed only where the tenant pays rent due to the full extent in the due time and not otherwise.</p><p><em>Sk. Md. Emaduddin Vs. Jasimuddin Mistry, (1973) 25 DLR 404.</em></p><p> </p><p>—The explanation to sub-section (5) of section 18 clearly indicates that there is no refusal unless the landlord has refused to accept any rent remitted within the period mentioned in sub-section (5). Ibid.</p><p> </p><p>—Defaulter-tenant cannot seek the protection under the sub-section. Protection against eviction available only when in due time the tenant pays the rent in full. A defaulter cannot claim protection against eviction. Ibid</p><p> </p><p><strong>Ss. 18(5) and 19</strong>: Tenant not entitled to get protection from eviction unless he pays rent to the landlord within the stipulated time as provided in section 18(5) and 19 of the Act—Once default is made that cannot be cured by subsequent deposit of rent with the Rent Controller.</p><p>The tenant is bound to pay rent to the landlord or to deposit the same in the treasury within the stipulated time under sections 18(5) and 19 of the Ordinance (i.e.) by the 15th day of the month next following that for which the rent is payable or deposit such rent in case of refusal by the landlord to accept the rent, within a fortnight of the date on which the rent so remitted is returned to the tenant by the defendant through postal authority.</p><p>But in the present case the defendant deposited rent for the months of February to September, 1958, with the permission of the Rent Controller on the 6th October, 1958.</p><p><strong>Held:</strong> Once a defaulter always a defaulter. If once a default is established it cannot be cured by subsequent deposit of the rent with the Rent Controller. A tenant not having paid the rent to the landlord in terms of section 18 (5) or not having deposited the same with the Rent Controller according to the provisions of section 19, is not entitled to claim a protection from eviction.</p><p><em>M/S East Bengal Paper Traders Association Ltd. Vs. Md. Waziullah (1969) 21 DLR 572.</em></p><p> </p><p>—Tenant’s liability to pay rent—If landlord improperly refuses to accept the rent, the steps which tenant must rake for protection against eviction.</p><p>To sum up, the tenant must pay rent in terms of the contract, and in the absence of the contract within fifteenth day next following month on which the rent falls due, and if the landlord refuses to accept the rent tendered by the tenant the tenant must remit the rent within the aforesaid fifteenth day of the following month by money order. If the rent remitted by money order is refused, the tenant can deposit the rent with the Rent Controller within a fortnight from the date of the receipt of the undelivered rent sent through the postal authority, and when these conditions as prescribed in the Ordinance are fulfilled by the tenant, he gets the protection, otherwise the protection from ejectment on ground of default in the payment of rent granted by the Ordinance is clearly taken away by the express language of sub-section (5) of section 18.</p><p><em>Ramjan Ali Mistry Vs. Md. Headayatulla (1979) 31 DLR (AD) 183.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>—Forfeiture of protection when there is default to pay rent: </strong>The Ordinance makes no distinction between default for one month and default for more than one month or a habitual defaulter. If the default has taken place, the protection from ejectment is withdrawn. Ibid.</p><p> </p><p><strong>Sections 18 &amp; 19:</strong> Compliance with statutory conditions regarding deposit of rent, mandatory: When the conditions under sections 18 and 19 are fulfilled the tenant is entitled to protection and that the law makes no distinction between default for one month or default for more than one month or a habitual defaulter. When the conditions of section 19 are not fulfilled the tenant is not entitled to deposit rent in time and such a deposit is not a valid deposit.</p><p><em>Indra Kumar Paul Vs. Mvi. Sirejuddin Ahmed, (1979) 31 DLR 389.</em></p><p> </p><p>—Tenant’s liability to ejectment for default in payment of rent and protection against ejectment-Explained.</p><p>In case of default in payment of rent, a tenant is protected, notwithstanding the provisions of Transfer of Property Act or the Contract Act from ejectment as long as he pays rent to the full extent allowed by the East Pakistan Premises Rent Control Ordinance and he performs the conditions of the tenancy.</p><p><em>Ramjan Ali Mistry Vs. Md. Hedayetullah. (1979) 31 DLR (AD) 183.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p>—Deposit of rent by the tenant with the Rent controller on refusal to accept the same by the landlord. Ibid.</p><p> </p><p>—Deposit with the Rent-Controller for 3 months once and again after a few months deposit for two months more—Not a deposit according to law to save ejectment</p><p><em>Prafulla K. Chakrabarty Vs. Anil Prasad (1981) 33 DLR (AD) 56.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p>—The section says that when the landlord has refused to accept rent in terms of section 18 remitted by the tenant by postal money order, the tenant may deposit the rent with the Rent Controller within a fortnight of the receipt of the undelivered rent sent through the postal authorities.</p><p><em>Ramjan Ali Mistry Vs. Md. Hedayetullah. (1979) 31 DLR (AD) 183.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>S. 19 </strong>— Deposit of rent accompanied by an application must be made u/s. 19 (1)(a) within the time fixed—Mere application filed within time without deposit not in accordance with law.</p><p><em>H.B. Khan Vs. Amanuddin Khan. (1981) 33 DLR 242.</em></p><p>—Extension of time by the Controller for deposit of rent not legal.   Ibid.</p><p>—-Onus on the tenant to prove the circumstances entitling him to deposit rent with House Rent Controller.</p><p><em>Abul Layes Vs. Mt. Anwara (1977) 29 DLR (SC) 13.</em></p><p>—Conditions in sec. 19 when not satisfied the tenant not entitled to deposit rent in Court. Any such deposit not a valid tender.   Ibid.</p><p> </p><p><strong>S. 19(1)(5)(6).</strong> Deposit of rent shall be accompanied by an application stating the circumstances under which the deposit is being made. If the court finds circumstances stated do not fulfill the requirement of law, he shall refuse to accept the deposit.</p><p><em>Jahur Mia Vs. Sri Ram Prasad (1977) 29 DLR</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>S. 19 (2).</strong> Provisions of sub-section (2) of s. 19 have no relevance when the premises has been transferred to the clear knowledge of the tenant occupying the premises.</p><p>The deposit of rent in court in the name of the ex-landlord, after the transfer of the premises to the new landlord, offers no protection against ejectment for non-payment of rent.</p><p><em>Basiruddin Ahmed &amp; ors. Vs. Dhirendra Mohan Das (1984) 36 DLR</em> <em>(AD) 191</em>.</p><p> </p><p><strong>—S. 21. </strong>Circumstances when a tenant can deduct from the amount payable by him to the landlord in regard to certain expenses and charges incurred by him on account of making necessary repairs and other matters—Procedure which the tenant must follow in such cases.</p><p>A notice has to be served on the landlord in the prescribed manner—If the landlord neglects to make such repairs the tenant may submit to the Controller an estimate of such cost—Controller after affording the landlord an opportunity of being heard, may permit the tenant to make the repairs— Controller shall determine the cost of the repair, and thereupon the tenant may deduct the amount so determined.</p><p><em>Murguba Khatun Vs. Shahifur Reza (1978) 30 DLR 179.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>S. 21 [S. 23 of E.B. Premises Rent Control Act (16/1953)</strong></p><p>Provisions for realization of repair costs under the section is merely an alternative method.</p><p>The suit premises was in a bad condition; thereupon the Municipality took up the matter and directed the defendant by a notice to reconstruct the suit house according to a plan approved by the Municipality and other necessary things so as to avoid interference with free flow of water with refuses.</p><p>The landlord-defendant, on getting these notices approached the tenant-plaintiffs and asked them to take up the matter with the Municipality and execute all necessary works of repairs.</p><p>The plaintiffs accordingly undertook the repairs as in case of default the structure would be demolished and they would lose their business which they were carrying on in the suit premises.</p><p>The defendant not having paid the costs of repairs incurred by the plaintiffs the latter sued him for recovery of the costs.</p><p><strong>Held:</strong> Section 23 of the E.B. Premises Rent Control Act is to be read subject to the provisions of other Acts. This section provides machinery within the Act for realizing the dues of repairs carried out by the tenant from the landlord but it is not the exclusive method. It must be regarded as an alternative method in addition to other methods permissible by law. Moreover the section refers to any repairs. It was not a question of mere repairs but it was a question of support of the suit premises as required to be altered by the Municipality</p><p><em>Kazi Md. Ishaque Vs. Girindra Chandra Bose, (1968) 20 DLR 707.</em></p><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Premises Rent Control Rules, 1964.</u></strong></p><p><strong>R. 7</strong>: No duty is cast on the Court to collect materials beyond that which are produced before the Court.</p><p><em>M/S Purabi Pictures Ltd. Vs. The National Medical</em> <em>Institute, (1971) 23 DLR 8.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2329	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Prescription</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  7 DLR 577,  8 DLR 640</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Prescription</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong>Prescription</strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">(See also under Easement and ‘Right of way’)</span></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p><strong>Prescriptive right of way</strong>—A prescriptive right of way cannot be acquired by mere enjoyment for the statutory period. The enjoyment must be as of right, i.e. not attributable to permission implied or express.</p><p><em>Abdul Hafiz Vs. Mafizuddin, (1955) 7 DLR 577.</em></p><p> </p><p>—The mere fact that one person walks over the land of another does not raise any presumption that he has a right to do so. Numerous people pass over the lands of their neighbors, friends and relations with their tacit permission. Such user though continuous and long is seldom understood as being assertion of any right. Ibid.</p><p>—In a suit for prescriptive right of way the plaintiff must show that user was such as was sufficient to put servient owner on notice that the enjoyment was not attributable to his tacit permission or favour. Ibid.</p><p> </p><p><strong>Prescriptive right—acquisition of—limited interest by. </strong></p><p>A limited interest of a lessee may be acquired by prescriptive right.</p><p><em>Hajari Sardar Vs. Mozam Molla. (1956) 8 DLR 640.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2330	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Presidency Town Insolvency Act, 1909</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>   17 DLR (SC) 147</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Presidency Town Insolvency</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Presidency Town Insolvency Act</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;">(III OF 1909)</p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"> </p><p><strong>S. 11--</strong>By virtue of Article 5 of the High Court (Bengal) Order, 1947 in regard to the territories now known as East Pakistan, the High Court of Dacca is vested with the same jurisdiction, original and appellate, which was before the partition exercisable by the High Court at Calcutta.</p><p>At the time of partition, there was in the Calcutta High Court, no insolvency jurisdiction, of an original character, in respect of any area now f. - within the Province of East Pakistan. Consequently by the effect of the High Courts (Bengal) Order, 1947, no original insolvency jurisdiction under the Act of 1909 became vested in the High Court of East Pakistan at Dacca.</p><p>But whereas provision has been made with regard to the Capital of Federation by specifying the limits of its ordinary original civil jurisdiction the High Court of East Pakistan at Dacca does not possess any ordinary original civil jurisdiction for the simple reason that no limits within which such jurisdiction may be exercised have ever been prescribed by competent legislative authority in respect of that High Court.</p><p> </p><p>That being the case where an application is made by creditors for the declaration as insolvent of a person resident in the town of Dacca, the consequences are that by virtue of the amendment made in the Provincial Insolvency Act, die District Judge of Dacca has no jurisdiction in the case, and equally by virtue of the fact that no limits have been fixed for the ordinary original civil jurisdiction of the High Court of East Pakistan, that High Court also has no original jurisdiction to deal with the application.</p><p><em>Abdus Sattar Vs. Arang Limited (1965) 17 DLR (SC) 147.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2331	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">President’s Order 36 of 1962</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  20 DLR 883</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  President’s Order</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p><em> </em></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>President’s Order 36 of 1962</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p><strong>Settlement of Disputes (First Elections) (Second Amendment) Order.</strong></p><p>If during the course of the trial of an election petition any one of the members of the Tribunal is for any reason unable to attend any sitting of the Tribunal, the trial shall continue before the other two members of the Tribunal.</p><p><em>Mahbubul Huq Vs. Chief Election Commissioner of Pakistan (1968)20 DLR 883.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2332	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Presidents Order No. 13 of 1962</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  16 DLR 657, 16 DLR 593, 20 DLR 883, 20 DLR 883</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Presidents Order </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Presidents Order No. 13 of 1962</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p><strong>Art. 11 (as amended by article 2 of President’s Order No. 1 of 1963)</strong></p><p>No substantial change introduced by the amendment as to period of limitation for petition containing allegation of corrupt or illegal practice in relation to the election expenses.</p><p><em>Golam Sarwar Mulla vs. Chairman &amp; Member, Election Tribunal (1964) 16 DLR 657.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Art. 54</strong>. An election petition in which an allegation of corrupt or illegal practice in relation to election expenses is made, has to be filed within 14 days from the date of receipt of the return of election expenses under Article 54 of the President’s Order No. 13 of 1962.</p><p>593.</p><p><em>Jamalus Sattar Vs. Badrul Huq (1964) 16 DLR 593.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Art. 9-14: When an election petition shall be dismissed.</strong></p><p>For petition contained in Article 9 to 14 under Chapter III of President’s Order No. 13 of 1962 the election petition shall be dismissed by the Election Commission as contemplated by Article 15 of the said Order. It has been further provided by way of amendment of Article 21(3) of President’s Order No. 13 of 1962 by Order No. 1 of 1963 that an election petition shall be dismissed by the Tribunal if any provision of Article 9 to 14 has not been complied with, notwithstanding that it has not been dismissed by the Commission under Article 15.</p><p><em>Mahbubul Huq Vs. Chief Election Commissioner of Pakistan, (1968) 20 DLR 883.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Art. 11</strong>: Amendment of the election petition must be made within prescribed Lime—Whether new facts can be introduced by amendments.</p><p>Any amendment sought to be made to the election petition has to be made within the period prescribed for filing of an election petition in clause (1X2) and (3) of Article 11 of President’s Order No. 13 of 1962 (as amended).</p><p> </p><p>The point at issue is whether by way of amendment the respondent No. 3 could bring in new facts about which he made no mention in his original election petition. When that is not done it cannot be said that the petition becomes non- maintainable in terms of Article 21 of President’s Order No. 13 of 1962 as amended by president’s order No. I of 1963. If there had been any attempt to introduce any such particulars by way of amendment to the original election petition of which no idea could be gathered from the contents of the original election petition, then certainly the petition would be hit by Article 21 of President’s Order 13 of 1962, as amended.</p><p><em>Mahbubul Huq Vs. Chief Election Commissioner of Pakistan, (1968)20 DLR 883.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>Art. 12—All particulars of corrupt or illegal practice to be set forth: </strong>Under the provisions under Chapter III of President’s Order No. 13 of 1962, there is no provision made for the Tribunal to declare an election void on the ground of an illegal or corrupt practice adopted by the successful candidate of which no mention has been made in terms of Article 12 of the Order in the election petition. Ibid.</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2333	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">President’s Order No. 14 of 1962</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  15 DLR 167, </p><p><b>Subject:</b>  President’s Order</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>President’s Order No. 14 of 1962</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p><strong>Art. 25. Presiding Officer must wait for full 5 hours allotted for casting of votes and any other work done provided under Article 35 within these 5 hours, illegal.</strong></p><p>Article 25 of the President’s Order No. 14 of 1962 provides that the total period allotted on any one day for polling shall not be less than five hours without any break.</p><p>In the present case in the voting centre 5 hours’ time was fixed as commencing from 9 a.m. and ending at 2 p.m. But as all the voters cast their votes by 12-15 p.m. in this centre, the Presiding Officer immediately after 12.15 p.m. unsealed the ballot-boxes and started counting votes.</p><p>The point of contention raised was whether the Presiding Officer acted rightly in doing what he had done after 12.15 p.m. without waiting till 2 p.m. before he unsealed the ballot-boxes and started counting.</p><p><strong>Held:</strong> Even though all the voters had cast their votes by 12.15 p.m., yet the Presiding Officer was not within his rights to take up the other works provided under Article 35 of the president’s Order No.4 of 1962 before 2 p.m.</p><p>The statutory limit of the five hours cannot be said to be a subject-matter of reduction at the option of the Presiding Officer.</p><p><em>Jasimuddin Ahmed Vs. Matiur Rahman Chowdhury (1963) 15 DLR 167.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>—Art. 35</strong>. [See under Article 25 of Presidents Order No. 14 of 1962 in case of <em>Jasimuddin Ahmed vs. M. R. Chowdhury in 15 DLR 167 above].</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2334	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">President’s Order No. 34 of 1962</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  18 DLR (SC) 69</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  President’s Order </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>President’s Order No. 34 of 1962</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p>The Order being of the nature altering the Constitution—Court’s right to interpret the Consti0n cannot be taken away by the Order—Order ultra vires.</p><p> </p><p>The aspect of the franchise and of the form of Government are fundamental features of a Constitution and to alter them, in order to placate or secure the support of a few persons, would be equivalent not to bringing the given Constitution into force, to bringing into effect an altered or different constitution.</p><p><em>FazIul Quader Chowdhury Vs. Muhammad Abdul Haque, (1966) 18 DLR (SC) 69.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2335	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">President’s Order No. 4 of 1962</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>   17 DLR (SC) 21</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  President’s Order </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u> </u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>President’s Order No. 4 of 1962</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p><strong>Art. 76. Application of the not limited only to the holding 1st election to the National and provincial Assemblies.</strong></p><p>The contention was that Article 76 of the President’s Order No.4 of 1962 which enacted that the wife of a person in the service of Pakistan is qualified from being elected as a member of the Assembly was limited to the holding of the first election and secondly that the President acted beyond his constitutional powers by prescribing a further disqualification in the said Article 76 in addition to those already specified in Article 103 of the Constitution.</p><p>Held: Reading Article 230 of the Constitution with the preamble of Order 4 of 1962 which sets Out in clear terms that it is necessary to provide for the conduct of the elections to the National d Provincial Assemblies and for matters ancillary thereto or connected therewith one cannot escape conclusion that the above Order No. 4 was not confined to the very first election.</p><p><em>Begum Shamsunnehar Vs. Speaker, East Pak. Assembly (1965) 17 DLR (SC) 21.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2336	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">President’s Order No.1 of 1963</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  16 DLR 657</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  President’s Order </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p><em> </em></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>President’s Order No.1 of 1963</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p>Art. 2. The wording of the Article makes out a case of retrospective operation of the changed law and therefore the period of limitation shall have to be counted accordingly.</p><p><em>Golam Sarwar Vs. Chairman and Members of Election Tribunal, E.P., (1964) 16 DLR 657.</em></p><p><strong>Art. 5.</strong> The discrimination made in the article between cases which remained pending on the date of change of the law is neither arbitrary nor unreasonable. Ibid.</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2337	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">President’s Order No.35 of 1962</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  8 DLR 1 (Special Bench)</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  President’s Order </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>President’s Order No.35 of 1962</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p>The Election Tribunal was constituted under President’s Order No. 35 of 1962, which expired on the 21st of November, 1964. The result is that the Tribunal itself had ceased to function as a legally constituted authority on and from the 21st of November, 1964. Order 35 of 1962 cannot be described as an “existing law”; under Article 225(7) having come into force after the 8th June, 1962, that is, after the Constitution itself has come into force.</p><p>Therefore, the finding arrived at by Election Tribunal and the order made by it against the petitioner in this case are of no legal effect as it was passed by an authority which had no legal existence on and from the 21st November, 1964.</p><p><em>K.A. Kader Vs. Election Tribunal, East Pak (1966) 8 DLR 1 (Special Bench).</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2338	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">President’s Order Nos. 4 and 13 of 1962</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>   18 DLR 16</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  President’s Order </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>President’s Order Nos. 4 and 13 of 1962</u></strong><u></u></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></p><p><strong>These Orders fall within the category of “existing law” is Article 225(7) of the Constitution.</strong></p><p>As President’s Orders Nos. 4 and 13 fairly and squarely fall within the definition of “existing laws” defined in Article 225(7) they were continued in force, (that is to say, they continued in force even after 21.11.64 when the Electoral College was constituted.)</p><p>In the absence of any other provision continuing the laws made under clause (8) of Article 229, they would have come to an end on and from the 21st of November, 1964, the date when the Electoral College was declared to have been constituted. As, however, Article 225 contains such a provision the argument that these provisions are meant to govern only laws other than those which were operative on the authority of Article 229, cannot be accepted. President’s Orders Nos. 4 and 13 of 1962 are still in force and will cease to be operative only when a notification under section 117 of the National and Provincial Assemblies (Election) Act (IV of 1963) is issued. (Sattar. J.)</p><p><em>K.A. Kader Vs. Election Tribunal, East Pak. (1966) 18 DLR 16.</em></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>—Ceased to have effect from 2 1. 11.64.</strong></p><p>Salahuddin Ahmed, J. (disagreeing with Sattar, J.)</p><p>President’s Orders Nos. 4 and 13 of 1962 are temporary Acts and are subject to the consequences of such Acts. Article 229 ceased to have effect on the constitution of the Electoral College as provided in Article 158 of the Constitution on the 21st November, 1964, and with this according to the accepted principle of interpretation came to an end the said Orders. The source, namely, Article 229 having ceased to exist, these orders which followed from that source, too, must die a natural death.</p><p>The expression “subject to this Constitution” in Art. 225 must necessarily mean subject to Article 229 of the Constitution as well. Article 229, by its own decree ceased to have effect on the constitution of the Electoral College of Pakistan and with this, the said orders, too, ceased to exist as if they never existed.</p><p>Article 225 having made the continuance of ‘existing law subject to the Constitution” must mean that the Article saves only such existing laws as are not hit by other provisions of the Constitution. Thus interpreted the Article does not save the said orders.   Ibid.</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2339	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Press and Publication Ordinance, 1960</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  I7 DLR 498</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Press and Publication </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Press and Publication Ordinance</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;">(XV of 1960)</p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"> </p><p><strong>S. 23, Clauses (e), (i) and (j) of sub-section (1).</strong></p><p>“Tend to incite anyone to interfere with the administration of law or the maintenance of law and order”. The impugned article in the present case does not come within the mischief of the clauses of the section. Officials and students of particular place cannot be described as forming section of citizens of Pakistan</p><p> </p><p>—Criticism of official action of a particular cannot be said to generate feelings of hatred or enmity—Right of criticisms of the Government’s acts—its scope and the limit.</p><p>The impugned article to be read as a whole— Court must keep in view while construing the article to what extent it is likely to affect the public which read it.</p><p><em>Tofazzal Hossain Vs. Province of East Pak.(1965) I7 DLR 498.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>—S. 23. —‘Attempt’, ‘contempt’ and ‘Hatred’—defined.</strong></p><p>‘Contempt’ in the active sense may be defined as the act of viewing another as mean, vile or worthless and hatred is a “sustained feeling of bitter aversion or dislike generally combined with a desire to injure, destroy or get rid of its object”.</p><p>The term “disaffection” means and include disloyalty and all feelings of enmity and hatred. Ibid.</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2340	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Principal and agent</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  8 DLR (P.C.) 28, 8 DLR 68, 8 DLR 121 (122)</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Principal and agent</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Principal and agent</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p>The proposition contended for is that the agent authorized to part with the firms money on loan to A, B. or C had no authority to receive repayment on their behalf. Their Lordships cannot accept this. In their opinion the authority to invest on loan necessarily implies in the circumstances of this case authority to receive repayment.</p><p><em>Firm of T.A.R.C.T. Vs. Firm of S.V.K.R. (1956) 8 DLR (P.C.) 28.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p>Principal can sue for recovery of moneys on promissory note executed in favour of his agent without any formal assignment by the agent in favour of the principal.</p><p><em>Jogendra M. Deb Vs. Raisaheb Nirmal Chakladar, (1956)8 DLR 68.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p>Liability to account for legal relationship of agent and principal and trustee and <em>cestuique</em> trust. Responsibility to account not only for the amounts which have been actually received but also for that which with due diligence could be received does not rest on a co-sharer with no responsibility to undertake it.</p><p><em>Jogna Chandra Nandi Majumdar- Vs. Rasik Lal Nandi Majumdar (1956)8 DLR 121 (122).</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2341	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Private International Law</h2>
