<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  21 DLR (WP) 129, 20 DLR (WP) 207</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Private International</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Private International Law</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p><strong>Choice of proper law—Law of land with whose legal system particular contract had closest and most substantial connection—Proper law applicable— Maxim: lex loci solutionis</strong>.</p><p>A contract was made at Karachi and according to its terms, the goods were to be delivered on board a vessel named F.O.B. Mombasa and the buyer had admittedly agreed to pay the freight of the goods at Kenya. Ultimately, the breach of the contract also took place at Kenya in view of the defendant’s cable to the plaintiff repudiating their obligation.</p><p>— <strong>Held</strong>: A substantial part of the contract (i.e. so far as its performance was concerned) was to be governed by the Law of Kenya with which it had the closest connection. Consequently, the conclusions of both the Foreign Courts, as to the choice of proper law applicable to the contract, appear to be proper, as they were founded on a correct view of Private International Law.</p><p><em>Hashem Issaq Vs. Karachi Gas Company. (1969) 21 DLR (WP) 129.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p>Private International Law is that part of law which comes into play when the issue before the court effects some fact, even or transaction that is so closely connected with a foreign system of law as to necessitate recourse to that system.</p><p><em>A.M. Qureshi Vs. Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, (1968) 20 DLR (WP) 207.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2342	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Procedure</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p align="center" style="text-align:center;"><b><u><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Procedure</span></u></b></p><p align="center" style="text-align:center;"><b><u><span style='Cambria","serif";'><span style="text-decoration:none"><br/></span></span></u></b></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Procedure oflaw—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Where astatute creates a liability or a right and at the same time prescribes aspecial or particular method or machinery for enforcing it, then that method ormachinery alone must be followed and none or. </span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Almaz KhatunVs. Ezhar Mia (1956) 8 DLR 82.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Procedure—lawof, takes effect prospectively in pending suits: </span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Change inthe law of procedure affects pending suits prospectively unless the legislatureindicates otherwise, either expressly or impliedly.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Monmotho N.Poddar Vs. Tripura State Bank (1959) 11 DLR 204.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Procedure,compliance with the rules of imperative: </span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;Cambria","serif";'>Enactments regulating procedurein courts are imperative and not merely directory. If for instance, an appealfrom a decision be given with provisions requiring the fulfilment of certainconditions, such as giving notice of appeal and entering into recognisances, ortransmitting documents within a certain time, a strict compliance would beimperative and non-compliance would be fatal to the appeal.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Md. HakimMia Vs. Mafizuddin Dhupi, (1959) 11 DLR 438.</span></i></p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span> </div></div>
2343	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Proclamation by Government of Bangladesh at Mujibnagar on 10.4.71</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  35 DLR 82, 31 DLR (AD) 165, 31 DLR (AD) 165</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Proclamation by Government of Bangladesh at Mujibnagar</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Proclamation by Government of Bangladesh at Mujibnagar on 10.4.71.</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p><strong>Laws in force in former E.P. before 25.3.71 would continue to operate subject to changes</strong></p><p>It is seen that on 10th April, 1971 the Government of Bangladesh at Mujib Nagar issued Proclamation of Independence. In pursuance of the Proclamation of Independence and Laws Continuance Enforcement Order all laws that were in force in erstwhile East Pakistan before 25th March, 1971 should continue to be in force with such consequential changes as might be necessary on account of the creation of the State of Bangladesh.</p><p><em>Md. Yahya Vs. Government of Bangladesh (1983) 35 DLR 82.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Proclamation of Independence and Martial Law Regulation—</strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">On the 16th March, 1971 Bangladesh proclaimed independence and a proclamation was issued to that effect on 10th day of April, 1971 from Mujib Nagar.</span></p><p><em>Mullick Brothers, Appellant. Vs. Income Tax officer and another—Respondents. (1979) 31 DLR (AD) 165.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p>The Proclamation having been issued on the 18th April, 1971 and having come into existence on the 26th March, 1971 and the President of the Republic being responsible for discharging all the executive and legislative powers and only those laws which were not inconsistent with the Proclamation of Independence having been continued in force, the irresistible conclusion is that the Regulation made by the authority against whose authority the Proclamation of Independence is directed could not legally legislate for Bangladesh if such legislation was inconsistent with the Proclamation of Independence.</p><p><em>Mullick Brothers Vs. Income Tax Officer (1979) 31 DLR (AD) 165.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Martial Law as distinguished from law passed under the will of the people: </strong></p><p>The Martial Law Regulations promulgated by the Martial Law Regime lack the trappings of law. It is issued by one person who arrogates to himself all the State powers on the basis of force of arms and commands obedience to him by the force emanating from the military power.</p><p>Law, as it is understood in jurisprudence, draws its authority from the will of the people of a country and absence of the expression of that will or rather silencing that will of the people through the strength of military force cannot be substituted for the jural concept of law. Martial Law comes into existence under certain conditions and it rules the country by Regulation and Orders and such Regulation and Orders if are desired to be continued are saved and preserved by a protective clause by constitution framed by a Parliament.</p><p><em>Mullick Brothers vs. Income Tax Office (1979) 31 DLR (AD) 165.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Martial is anti-thesis of constitutional law—</strong>On return to constitutional government, regulation as referred to in the definition clause of the] General Clauses Act is a regulation made under constitutional instrument by a person or authority empowered on that behalf in Bangladesh. - Law is an anti-thesis of any Constitutional authority.</p><p><em>Mullick Brothers, Appellant. Vs. Income Tax officer and another—Respondents. (1979) 31 DLR (AD) 165.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>Tax assessed under Martial law Relation not legally enforceable—</strong>Tax assessed under the Regulation was not imposed under any law in force in Bangladesh immediately before the commencement of the constitution. As has already been noted it was not  under any Act, Ordinance, Order, Rule, Regulate Bye-law, Notification or other legal Instrument The amendment of Regu1atioa” in the General Clauses Act shall be deemed to have came into feet on the 26th day of March 1971. Article 83 the Constitution provides as follows: “No Tax shall be levied or collected except1 or under he authority of an Act of Parliament”. Article 83 authorizes levies or collection on under the authority of an Act of Parliament. Merely use of procedural mechanism for collection of a tax provided in the Income Tax Act, does not make the levy or collection under the authority of Act of Parliament.</p><p>Regulation being a Martial Law Regulation has not been saved by any legal Instrument of People’s Republic o Bangladesh.</p><p><em>Mullick Brothers Vs. Income Tax Officer (1979) 31 DIR (AD) 165.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2344	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Proclamation of Independence</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  30 DLR (SC) 23, 31 DLR 50</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Proclamation of Independence</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Proclamation of Independence</u></strong></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Proclamation of Independence from Mujib Nagar on 10.4.71.</strong></p><p>The Proclamation of Independence made from Mujibnagar on 10th April, 1971, a declaration of the then East Pakistan into a sovereign Independent State. It recited that the Pakistan Government had started an unjust war which led to the making of such declaration of independence.</p><p><em>Jamal Jute Baling Vs. M. Sarkies (1978) 30 DLR (SC) 23.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>People’s Republic of Bangladesh set up on 26.3.71 after proclaiming independence.</strong></p><p>The State of People’ Republic of Bangladesh was established after proclaiming Independence on the 26th March, 1971. The Constitution of the People’s Republic of Bangladesh was enacted by the Constituent Assembly on the 4th November, 1972.</p><p><em>Md. Khalilur Rahaman Vs. State (1979) 31 DLR 50</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2345	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Proclamations</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  32 DLR (AD) 110, 30 DLR (SC) 209, 32 DLR (AD) 110,  31 DLR 50, 33 DLR (HCD) 348, DLR (AD) 358,  35 DLR 108, 33 DLR (AD) 154, 35 DLR (AD) 1,  32 DLR (AD) 110,  32 DLR (AD) 110, 21 DLR (SC) 291</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Proclamations</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p> </p><p><strong><u>Proclamation of the 15th August, 1975</u></strong></p><p>Proclamation of 15th Aug. 1975 provided that—Proclamations, Martial Law Regulations and Orders shall have precedence over the Constitution.</p><p>Constitution cannot be said to be still in force as the supreme law of the country, untrammeled by the proclamation and martial Law Regulation.</p><p>The Constitution though not abrogated, was reduced to a position subordinate to the proclamation, inasmuch as, the unamended and unsuspended constitutional provisions were kept in force and allowed to continue subject to the proclamation and Martial Law Regulations or Order and other orders and the Constitution was amended from time to time by issuing Proclamations. It is difficult to accept the arguments in support of the view that the Constitution as such is still in force as the supreme law of the country, untrammeled by the proclamation and Martial Law Regulation.</p><p>So long the Constitution is in force as the supreme law of the country, any act done or proceeding en by a person purporting to function in connects with the affairs of the Republic or of a local authority may be made the subject-matter of review by the High Court in exercise of its writ jurisdiction. The moment the country is put under Martial Law, the above noted constitutional provision along with civil laws of the country loses its superior position.</p><p><em>State, People’s Republic of Bangladesh Vs. Haji Joynal Abedin (1980) 32 DLR (AD) 110.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Martial Law courts being creatures either of the proclamation or Martial Law regulation, have the authority to try any offence made triable by such Courts.</strong></p><p>All proceedings before a Martial Law Court have been made immune from being challenged before a Court including the Supreme Court.</p><p>By the amendment of Regulation No. 4, while keeping the order, judgment, sentence or proceedings of a Martial Law Court immune from interference from any Court, including the High Court and the Supreme Court, a new provision was inserted as clause (8). It puts a bar to the effect that no Court, including the High Court and the Supreme Court, shall call for the records of the proceedings of any Martial Law Court for any purpose whatsoever. From the above noted provisions it appears that the proceedings before a Martial Law Court has Li protected from being challenged before any Court including the High Court and the Supreme Court.</p><p><em>Stale, People’s Republic of Bangladesh Vs. Haji Joynal Abedin (1980)32 DLR (AD) 110.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p>The first Proclamation dated 20.8.75 suspended Article 48 (relating to election of the president) and Article 55(relating to the Cabinet) and modified Article 148 and Form I of the 3rd. Schedule (relating to Presidents oath of office); except these the Constitution of Bangladesh as it stood then was kept intact.</p><p><em>Stale, People’s Republic of Bangladesh Vs. Haji Joynal Abedin (1980)32 DLR (AD) 110.</em></p><p> </p><p>The Constitution and the Martial Law Regulations and Orders (and other orders) were under this proclamation intended to co-exist neither claiming to be superior to the other.</p><p>Clause(g) of Proclamation of 20.8.75 is the Ouster clause and seeks to oust the jurisdiction of all courts including the Supreme Court to call in question or declare illegal or void this Proclamation or any Martial Law Regulation or Order (or other orders) made by the President in pursuance thereof.</p><p><em>Stale, People’s Republic of Bangladesh Vs. Haji Joynal Abedin (1980)32 DLR (AD) 110.</em></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Proclamation of the 20th August, 1975 clauses (d)(e) and (g)— </strong></p><p>Supremacy of the Constitution is not unqualified. It stands so far it is not unaffected by the proclamation.</p><p>No court including the Supreme Court has any power to call in question the Proclamation, or any Regulation or Order (issued under the authority of Proclamation).</p><p><em>Halima Khatum Vs. Bangladesh (1978) 30 DLR (SC) 209.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>—And with regard to such matters the ouster of the courts is total.</strong></p><p>Courts are concerned with the administration of law as it stands, whether that law is considered as a just or unjust law, with which matter the courts have no concern.</p><p><em>Halima Khatum Vs. Bangladesh (1978) 30 DLR (SC) 209.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Second Proclamation of 8th Nov. 1975—Its salient features</strong></p><p>Proclamation of the 8th November, 1975-(here- in after called the Second Proclamation) which is made by the President of the Republic would show that the President realized the necessity of retaining legislative authority and for this purpose the President assumed the powers of the Chief Martial Law Administrator the Salient features of which arc (i) Martial Law Regulation and Orders shall be made by the Chief Martial Law Administrator and (ii) the Martial Law Regulations and Orders enforced before the proclamation shall be deemed to have been made by the Chief Martial Law Administrator and they could be amended and repealed only by the Chief Martial law Administrator, (iii) The Parliament stood dissolved by this Proclamation and dissolution dated back to the 6th November, 1975 and general election for the Parliament was to be held before the end of February 1977. (iv) The person holding office such as Vice-President, Speaker, Deputy Speaker, Ministers, Ministers of State, Deputy Ministers and Whips at the time of the Proclamation were deemed to have ceased to hold office from the 6th November, 1975, (v) An Ordinance promulgated by the President shall be of unlimited duration, (vi) The provisions of Article 48 of Constitution relating to the election of the president shall remain suspended, (vii) Part VI A of the Constitution stood omitted (viii) this Proclamation could be amended by Order by the Chief Martial Law Administrator.</p><p><em>State, Bangladesh Vs. Haji Joynal Abedin (1980) 32 DLR (AD) 110.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Three Proclamations in Bangladesh</strong></p><p>First Proclamation on 20.8.75 by Khandker Mostaque the President, Second Proclamation on 8.11.75 and Third Proclamation on 29.11.76 by Mr. Justice AM Sayem the President.</p><p><em>Md. Khalilur Raman Vs. The State (1979) 31 DLR 50</em>.</p><p><strong>Effect of 3 Proclamation-</strong>Constitution continued to operate except certain parts along with the ML Regulations for the purpose of administration.</p><p><em>Md. Khalilur Rahman Vs. The State (1979) 31 DLR 50</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Proclamation of 20th August 1975, Arts. (D), (E) and (G).</strong></p><p>Proclamation— Martial Law Regulations, Orders are protected from challenge by any court by (d), (e) and (g) of the Proclamation of 20.8.7 these are immune from challenge by any court subject to the condition that if the actions of the authorities from challenge by any courts, s:’, - the condition that if the actions of the authorities a without jurisdiction and malafide, immunity can’ longer be claimed.</p><p><em>Khandker Moshtaque Ahmed Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh (1981) 33 DLR (HCD) 348</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Proclamation of the 6th April, 1979.</strong></p><p>Both the last Proclamation of Martial Law Act I of 1979 saving Martial Law was issued on same day, i.e. on 6th April, 1979. The specific period ascribed in the last Martial Law Proclamation - saving all Martial Law Proclamations, F - Orders, acts and actions however extended period from date and time of the withdrawal of Martial Law on 6th April up to 9th April, 1979.</p><p><em>Rezaul Karim Bhuiyan Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh (1981) DLR (AD) 358</em>.</p><p> </p><p><strong>Proclamation dated 7.4.79. Clause (f).</strong></p><p>Sessions Judge’s order for retrial of the ca which had been disposed of after the commencing day (7.4.79) is without jurisdiction since he had jurisdiction in respect of case tried and disposed of fore the commencing day.</p><p><em>Sabdar Rahman Khan The State (1983) 35 DLR 108</em>.</p><p> </p><p><strong>Proclamation: MLR</strong></p><p>No court shall call in question or declare as gal the Proclamation or any MLR or Order made by the Chief ML Administrator.</p><p><em>Kh. Ehteshamuddin Ahmed @ Iqbal Vs. Bangladesh &amp; Ors. (1981) 33 DLR (AD) 154.</em></p><p>With the lifting of ML and revocation of the Proclamations Ouster of jurisdiction of superior Courts remains operative.</p><p><em>Kh. Ehteshamuddin Ahmed @ Iqbal Vs. Bangladesh &amp; Ors. (1981) 33 DLR (AD) 154.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Proclamation of Martial Law on 24.3.82.Clause (4). Sub-Clauses (1) &amp; (2)</strong></p><p>Powers and jurisdiction exercisable by the High Court Div. and Appellate Div. of the Supreme Court of Bangladesh.</p><p><em>Bangladesh Vs. Md. Salimullah (1983)35 DLR (AD) 1</em>.</p><p>With the suspension of the Constitution by the Proclamation, the HC Div. writ jurisdiction is i.e. So appeals against HC Div’s judgment in writer to the Appellate Division also abate.</p><p><em>Bangladesh vs. Md. Salimullah (1983)35 DLR (AD) 1.</em></p><p>New law coming into effect after judgment is rendered Effect-Law operates prospectively unless it is otherwise provided in the law.</p><p>Bangladesh vs. Md. Sallimullah (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 1.</p><p> </p><p><strong>Proclamation of 24th March (1982)</strong></p><p><strong>Clause (g)—</strong>Special leave application pending in App. Div. abates under clause (g) of the Proclamation and this does not affect the HC Div. Judgment.</p><p><em>Bangladesh Vs. Md. Salimullah (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 1.</em></p><p><strong>—</strong>With the abatement of the special leave application in the AD, the effect is HC Div: judgment stands and does not abate.</p><p><em>Bangladesh Vs. Md. Salimullah (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 1.</em></p><p><strong>—</strong>When an appeal by certificate or by special leave becoms pending before the AD of the Supreme Court, judgment, under appeal along with the writ application also becomes sub-judice.</p><p>Writ application against judgment of the HC Div. in connection with appeal before the Appellate Div.—Effect is HC Div s judgment is subjudice.</p><p><em>Bangladesh Vs. Md. Salimullah (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 1.</em></p><p><strong>—</strong>Consequences which follow when the appeal before the App. Division is either dismissed or allowed:-</p><p>If the appeal is dismissed, the relevant judgment of the High Court Division retains its finality and consequently the writ application concerned is also finally disposed of. But if the appeal is allowed, then the judgment of the High Court Division is either set aside or modified, and accordingly, the writ application also stands finally disposed of.</p><p><em>Bangladesh Vs. Md. Salimullah (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 1.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>—</strong>Proclamation of Martial Law (dated 24.3.82) Para 1(1) of the Schedule, dispensation of Govt. land- when done by CMLA that cannot be questioned by the Court.</p><p>Memos. of 29th June and 8th July, 1982 effectively transfer the Government markets to the Dhaka Municipal Corporation.</p><p><em>Dhaka</em> <em>Municipal Corporation vs. Alhaj Md. Ruhul Amin (1983) 35 DLR 482</em>.</p><p> </p><p><strong>Proclamation (Amendment) Order, 1977, (P0 I of 1977)</strong></p><p>Validated all orders etc. passed by the President or CMLA. Therefore vires of clause(2) of Regulation 3 of MLRI of 1975 nor any order passed under clause (b) transferring a case to a Special Martial Law Court can be questioned.</p><p><em>State, People’s Republic of Bangladesh Vs. Haji Joynal Abedin (1980) 32 DLR (AD) 110.</em></p><p> </p><p>By the Proclamation (Amendment) Order, 1977 (Proclamation) Order No. I of 1977) all orders made, acts and things done, and actions and proceedings taken, or purported to have been made, done or taken by the President or the Chief Martial Law Administration by any other person or authority, were validated. In view of the provisions of law the irresistible conclusion is that neither vires of clause (2) of Regulation No. 3 of Martial Law Regulation No. 1 of 1975 nor any order passed within the language of clause (b) transferring a case to a Special Martial Law Court can be challenged in any Court of law.</p><p>Per KM Sobhan, J (contra)—The administrative activities of the country are to be guided both by the Constitutional Legislations as well as Martial Law Regulations and Orders. In the event, however, of a conflict between the two, under clause (d), Martial Law Regulations and Orders are to have precedence.</p><p>Martial Law Courts are amenable to the writ jurisdiction of the High Court which jurisdiction can be ousted when (i) M.L. Courts are properly constituted: (ii) accused are subject to M.L. Courts; (iii) and the offences are triable by M.L. Courts only.</p><p><em>State, Bangladesh vs. Haji Joynal Abedin (1980) 32 DLR (AD) 110.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>(Protection of Evacuee Property) Ordinance (XVIII of 1948)</strong></p><p>Pakistan (Economic Rehabilitation) Ordinance (XIX of 1948) Read with Supplementary Instrument of Accession, 1949.</p><p>Clause 4 of the Instrument of Accession.</p><p>Evacuee Laws—Evacuee laws enacted by Pakistan validly extends to the former State of Khairpur.</p><p><strong>Held:</strong> Clause 4 of the Supplementary Instrument was intended to confer on the Federal Legislature of Pakistan power to enact evacuee laws in relation to Khairpur State. The Pakistan Ordinance XVIII of 1948 and Pakistan Ordinance XIX of i943 and the various Ordinances and Acts which amended or replaced them from time to time were valid.</p><p><em>Fatoomal Vs. Reh. Commissioner (1969) 21 DLR (SC) 291.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>

Disturbed Persons Reh. Ord.)</strong></p><p><strong>Art. 5:</strong> Section 1(4) of the Ordinance providJ that the E.P. Disturbed Persons (Reh) Ordinance will remain in force upto the 31st March, 1969. Martial Law abrogated the 1962 Constitution and sequent1y by Art. 5 of the Proclamation nu1gatcd on 25th March, 1969, preserved all laws in force immediately before the making of the promulgation—Promulgation under Art. 5 will keep alive the Ordinance upto the date of its expiry as incorporated in the Ordinance but not beyond that.</p><p><em>Mrs. Hasina Rahman Vs. Babu Nripendra Kumar Roy Chowdhury (1969) 21 DLR 442.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>—Art. 5:</strong> An Ordinance which was in force immediately before the abrogation of the Constitution shall continue to be in force by reason of Article 5(a) of the Proclamation and such Ordinance will not be subject to requirement laid down.</p><p><em>Mrs. Hasina Rahman Vs. Babu Nripendra Kumar Roy Chowdhury (1969) 21 DLR 614.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>—Art. 5:</strong> Ordinance which was in force be in force the proclamation will continue to be in force in view of article 5 of the Proclamation. But Article 5 cannot keep an Ordinance alive beyond the date of expiry dcclarcdby the Ordinance.</p><p><em>Mrs. Hasina Rahman Vs. Babu Nripendra Kumar Roy Chowdhury (1969) 21 DLR 614.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p>—Proclamation of the Martial Law under Article 5 can keep alive the Ordinance upto the date of its expiry, if any, incorporated in the Ordinance but not beyond that.</p><p><em>Mrs. Hasina Rahman Vs. 2348	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Provincial Insolvency Act, 1920</h2>

Economic Aid Corporation (1959) 11 DLR 459.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>S. 17:</strong> <strong>Proviso:</strong> Proviso to section 17 the Insolvency Act gives the secured creditor authority to realise or otherwise deal with the security independent of the winding up proceeding.</p><p><em>Uttara Bank. vs.  M/S Rahman Biscuit Factory Ltd. (1980) 32 DLR 45.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>S.51</strong>. The position of an attaching creditor under the Company’s Act is similar to that a Provincial Insolvency Act.</p><p><em>Chandpur Mills Ltd Vs. Economic Aid Corporation (1959) 11 DLR 459.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>Provisional Constitution Order 1969: </strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Article 5(c): After promulgation of the Provisional Committee. Constitution Order, High Court has no power to call in question any finding, judgment or order of a Military Court—Constitution abrogated, keeping a part alive—provision of Martial Law Regulation or Orders prevails over the Constitution.</span></p><p><em>Miss Khadja Bibi Vs. The State, (1969) 21 DIR 618.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2349	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Public conduct (Public statutory Corporation) (scrutiny) Ordinance, 1959</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  14 DLR 430</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Public conduct (Public statutory Corporation) (scrutiny) </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Public conduct (Public statutory Corporation) (scrutiny) Ordinance</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;">(XLI OF 1959)</p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"> </p><p><strong><em>Clause 2(a).</em></strong><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> An appropriate authority could lawfully pass an order of suspension, etc. against a person for misconduct amongst other grounds un2(a) of Ordinance XLI of 1959 by which will be disqualified.</span></em></p><p>It was contended that ‘misconduct’ as used in the order of the Governor finds no mention in the categories of the grounds enumerated in rule 2 of the Public Service (Scrutiny) Rules, 1959 under which an employee of a statutory body could have been screened by the Governor and therefore, it was contended, in so far as the order passed by the Governor of the Slate Bank of Pakistan purporting to remove the petitioner on the ground of misconduct, it was bad and ultra vires the powers of the Governor.</p><p><strong><em>Held:</em></strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> The petitioner cannot now impeach before the High Court as he could not have done before the Commissioner, the respondent No. 1, the validity of the order passed by the Governor of the State Bank.</span></p><p><strong><em>Held further:</em></strong> The Public Conduct (Public Statutory Corporation) (Screening) Ordinance, (XLI of 1959) was in force when the order against the petitioner was passed by the Governor and clause 2(a) of this Ordinance authorized the removal of a person, amongst other ground, for ‘misconduct’ also.</p><p>‘Misconduct’ as a separate and distinct ground for the action taken against the petitioner by the Governor of the State Bank is a ground “other than that of inefficiency” within the meaning of clause 5(1)(a) of the Elective Bodies (Disqualification) Order, 1959.</p><p><em>A.K. Jamaluddin Ahmad vs. D.K. Power (1962) 14 DLR 430.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2350	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Public Conduct (Scrutiny) Ordinance, 1959</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  21 DLR 492, 23 DLR 131, 15 DLR (SC) 110, 13 DLR 616, 14 DLR (SC) 1, 32 DLR 214, 13 DLR 131,14 DLR (SC) 1,  15 DLR (SC) 110</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Public Conduct (Scrutiny) </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p><em> </em></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Public Conduct (Scrutiny) Ordinance</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;">(III of 1959)</p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"> </p><p><strong>S. 3: </strong>Head Quarter Screening Committees constituted by the Provincial Government are competent to screen the Head Quarter Staff and the District Screening Committees competent to screen the staff of the District.</p><p>The Provincial Government constituted two sets of Screening Committees, one for screening the Head Quarter Staff and the other for screening the staff working in the District.</p><p>The appellant’s contention was that the respondent a staff of the Revenue Department being posted at an interior place of the district of Dacca, the Dacca District Screening Committee was not competent to screen the conduct of the respondent.</p><p><strong>Held</strong>: The intention for constituting two sets of Screening Committees was that those who were posted in the Head Quarter to the department were to be screened by the Head Quarter Screening Committees and the other staff of the department posted at various places in different districts were be screened by the District Screening Committees concerned. So, the respondent who was posted at Keraniganj within the district of Dacca at the material time, for the purpose of screening, came ‘under the jurisdiction of the Dacca District Screening Committee.</p><p><strong><em>Province of East Pakistan Vs. A.K.M.Rezaul Karim (1969) 21 DLR 492.</em></strong></p><p> </p><p><strong>S. 4—</strong>The word “finding” does not necessarily i an adverse finding—Appointing authority is empowered to refer a case to Advisory Committee.</p><p><strong><em>Md. Taiyab Ali Vs. Province of East Pakistan (1961) 23 DLR 131.</em></strong></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>—</strong>The Department Head (in this case DPI) was directly subordinate to the Chief Executive (i.e. the Provincial Government represented by the Secretary of the department). A Committee under the Public Conduct (Scrutiny) Ordinance recommended the compulsory retirement of the respondent for misconduct in respect of whom the D.P.I. was the appointing authority and under the provisions of the above mentioned Ordinance was authorized to pass the final order on the recommendation of the, Committee.</p><p>In the present case the D.P.I. found himself unable to agree with the Committee recommending the compulsory retirement of the respondent and wrote to the chief executive for direction. The latter directed compulsory retirement of the respondent and the D.P.I in compliance with that direction rendered his compulsory retirement.</p><p>The respondent moved the High Court and contended that the impugned order was not a lawful order as it was not the order of the appointing authority the D.P.I who was under law authorized to act finally in his own discretion (and his inclination was just the other way) but it was the chief executive’s order which the D.P.1 faithfully carried out. The High Court upheld this contention and set aside the impugned order.</p><p><strong>Held</strong>: The question in this case is not merely as to the exercise of discretion, but whether, in the direct line of subordination, such as obtain between the chief executive and the Head of a Department, it is necessary, to maintain a power in the Departmental Head independent of, and if necessary mop- position to, the power of the Chief Executive.</p><p>The DPI made his order as befits a subordinate authority, as to the exercise of discretion vested in him, in an executive matter. It is not dishonesty fop a subordinate to submit his judgment to that of an executive superior.</p><p>The judicial power of the Crown in the prerogative can never be employed so as to create conflict between senior and subordinate in a direct line of executive authority.</p><p>There can be no excess or abuse of authority in the exercise of, on the executive side, by superiors over subordinates.</p><p><strong><em>Province of East Pakistan vs. Amir Hossain (1963) 15 DLR (SC) 110.</em></strong></p><p> </p><p><strong>—Governor has the power to revoke his earlier order</strong></p><p>On the basis of the recommendation of the Screening Committee the Governor on 28.6.59 passed an order of compulsory retirement of respondent, under section 4 of the Public Conduct (Scrutiny) Ordinance and accordingly a notification was issued notifying the fact of retirement.</p><p>The recommendation of the Screening Committee was not accepted by the Advisory Committee who found the respondent fit and competent. On the basis of the report of the Advisory Committee the Governor on 29 .6.59 revoked the former order and a notification was also issued to that effect.</p><p>It was contended that the order of the Governor passed on 29.6.59 revoking his earlier order 28.6.59 is illegal.</p><p>Held: The Governor has the power to rescind an order which he had been empowered to make under the Laws (Continuance in Force) order and Public Conduct (Scrutiny) Ordinance.</p><p>Advisory Committee is something superior to the Screening Committee and is a revisional authority.</p><p><strong><em>Sabir Ahmed vs. Province of East Pakistan (1961) 13 DLR 616.</em></strong></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>—Rules framed have the force of the provisions of the Ordinance itself.</strong></p><p>The phrase “shall pass orders thereon according to law” in section 4 of the Public Conduct (Scrutiny) Ordinance comprehends as well the Rules framed under the Ordinance.</p><p>The Rules stand on the same footing as the substantive provisions of the Ordinance and consequently the infraction of the Rules would have the effect of taking an order passed out of the purview of the Ordinance itself.</p><p>Rules 6 and 7 require the appointing authority to consider any appeal, filed within 15 days, by any person concerned against the recommendation of the Screening Committee. Where therefore the appointing authority without allowing 15 days time to prefer appeal against the recommendation of the Screening Committee passed orders immediately on receipt of the recommendations:</p><p><strong>Held:</strong> An essential part of the procedure designed to ensure a fair hearing to the person concerned not being complied with, the impugned order could not be said to be immune from challenge, in view of the bar raised by section 10 of the Ordinance.</p><p><strong><em>Sardar Muhd. Zaman Khan Vs. M.B. Nishat (1962) 14 DLR (SC) 1.</em></strong></p><p><em> </em></p><p>—On a charge of misconduct to which Public Conduct (Scrutiny) Ordinance applies enquiry by… the Screening Committee into the conduct of the officer concerned is mandatory.</p><p><strong><em>Govt. of Bangladesh. Vs. Dr. M. Nasiruddin. (1980) 32 DLR 214.</em></strong></p><p> </p><p>—Even when an enquiry into the conduct of a public servant is not a statutory requirement if nevertheless an enquiring is held it must follow the statutory provision in the conduct of such enquiry; otherwise the order passed will be without jurisdiction. Ibid.</p><p> </p><p>—Adverse remarks in the confidential report are an opinion of the Reporting Officer and cannot be treated as an evidence of misconduct—What is required are specific and definite acts of the public servant concerned. Ibid.</p><p> </p><p><strong>S 7.</strong> Advisory Committee not bound to follow the procedure of Screening Committee to issue notice to the person concerned.</p><p><strong><em>Taiyab Ali Vs. Province of East Pakistan (1961) 13 DLR 131.</em></strong></p><p> </p><p>—An allegation of malafides against particular member of Screening Committee is not enough unless it is also shown that he had influenced the other members of the Committee.   Ibid.</p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>S. 10.</strong> Court’s jurisdiction barred to call into question proceeding of a Screening Committee when it acts within its jurisdiction but not when it acts malafides. Ibid.</p><p> </p><p>—Rules framed under section 8 of the Ordinance, III of. 1959, are operative under the Public Conduct (Public Statutory Corporations) (Scrutiny) Ordinance, 1959.</p><p><strong><em>Sardar Muhd. Zaman Khan Vs. M.B. Nishat (1962) 14 DLR (SC) 1.</em></strong></p><p>—See under section 4 in the case of Province of East Pakistan vs. Amir Hossain, in 15 DLR (SC) 110 above.</p><p>—[See under section 4 in the case of <em>Sardar Muhd. Zaman Khan vs. M.B. Nishat, in 14 DLR (SC)</em> I above].</p><p>—Under Article 6(5) of the Laws (Continuance in Force) Order, 1958, an order rearing a public servant for a “cause mentioned in clause (3)” which includes “misconduct” shall not be called in question in any Court. But to attract this bar, misconduct must be found.</p><p>Under section 10 of the Public Conduct (Scrutiny) Ordinance, 1959, an order or finding by i appointing authority or a Screening Committee shall not be called in question in any Court. But for the same reasons, the finding in the present e is no finding for which protection against judicial examination can be claimed, and the order which proceeded thereon is liable to interference.</p><p><strong><em>Province of East Pakistan Vs. M. Amir Hossain (1963)15 DLR (SC) 110.</em></strong></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2351	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">  Public Conduct Scrutiny Rules, 1959</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  14 DLR (SC) 13, 13 DLR 175, 21 DLR (SC) 16, 20 DLR 394, 14 DLR (SC) 1</p><p><b>Subject:</b>   Public Conduct Scrutiny </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Public Conduct Scrutiny Rules, 1959</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p><strong>Rule 2. Misconduct—Canvassing for cancellation of transfer order -‘unbecoming of officer’s office’</strong></p><p><em>Province of East Pakistan Vs. Muhd. Sajjad Ali Muzumdar (1962) 14 DLR (SC) 13.</em></p><p>—The notification by which the respondent was reduced in rank said that he was guilty of inefficiency and misconduct. There being no charge of inefficiency against the respondent reference of inefficiency in the notifications was otiosc. The mere presence of the charge of inefficiency does not, however, indicate that Government failed altogether to apply its mind to the case.</p><p><strong>Rule 2</strong> under which action against the respondent was taken did not contain the word ‘misconduct’ but contained the words ‘guilty of conduct contrary to good order or unbecoming his office.’</p><p>It was contended that the word ‘misconduct’ which has not been defined in the Ordinance or Rules normally should be interpreted by the Court narrowly in the sense of an infringement of a binding rule of conduct applicable to Government servants.</p><p>The expression “misconduct” in the notification has been used in the wide sense of improper conduct. Ibid.</p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>R. 2(a)(b)(c). Reputations of being corrupt different from misconduct and inefficiency from both.</strong></p><p>Under rule 2 of the Public Conduct (Scrutiny). Rules the offence of general and persistent reputation of being corrupt is an offence which is distinct and different from that mentioned in sub-clause (b), namely, misconduct or conduct unbecoming his office and lastly, inefficiency is a separate offence by itself. Again under clause (b) of this rule a difference has been made between the offences with which Government Servants on the one hand and persons holding the other offices specified in clause (1) of Article 6of the Laws (Continuance in Force) Order on the other hand, may be charged.</p><p><em>Muhd. Sajjad Ali Vs. Province of East Pak. (1961) 13 DLR 175.</em></p><p>—Proceeding before the Screening Committees and Appointing Authority are not judicial proceeding. Ibid.</p><p>—Government servants in screening proceedings are not to be condemned unheard—substance of charge should be provided. Ibid.</p><p> </p><p><strong>—Disregard of provisions of law by the Committee is a misuse of power</strong></p><p>In the category of actions considered to be ‘malafide,’ actions described as “misuse of powers” even “abuse of powers” or as acts done in “colorable exercise of powers” are also included.</p><p>A total disregard of the provision prescribed by the statute or rules amounts to a misuse of powers and brings it within the ambit of an act which in fact it is not taken though it purports to have been taken under the statute.   Ibid.</p><p> </p><p><strong>—Appointing authority’s power of Punishment not dependant on the committee’s recommendation.</strong></p><p>Discretion of the appointing authority as regards the punishment to be imposed is not in any way fettered by the recommendation offered by the Screening Committee. Ibid</p><p> </p><p><strong>R. 2(c):</strong> A Government official retired compulsorily from service by the Governor under sub-clause (b) of clause 5 of Article 6 is valid in law after the introduction of sub-clauses (a) and (b) of clause (5) vided the order of retirement is passed before the July of 1959. The Laws (Continuance in Force) Ordinance 1958 is a super constitutional law and has a riding effect over all other laws.</p><p><em>Govt. of East Pakistan Vs. Mr. Murzuqullah (1969) 21 DLR (SC) 16.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Rule 2(2):</strong> Compulsory retirement order the ground of unsatisfactory service’ or upon recommendation of the Screening made on 24.4.59 not legal and operative inasmuch any basis for such recommendation for retiring a 1 son on the ground of inefficiency was no available on 24.4.52, that ground have been with effect from 28.2.59 from the statute con namely, Public Conduct (Scrutiny) Rules 1959. being basis of the order in the present case it be said that it was passed by the Governor under dc 7(5) of the laws (Continuance in Force) Order.</p><p><em>Naziruddin Ahmed Vs. Prov. of East Pakistan (1968)20 DLR 394.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>Rr. 6 and 7. Rules framed have to force of the provisions of the Ordinance itself.</strong></p><p>The phrase “shall pass orders thereon according to law” in section 4 of the Public Conduct (Scrutiny) Ordinance comprehends as well the Rules framed undo the Ordinance.</p><p>The Rules stand on the same footing as the substantive provisions of the Ordinance and consequently the infraction of the Rules would have the effect of taking an order passed out of the purview of the Ordinance itself.</p><p>Rules 6 and 7 require the appointing authority to consider any appeal, filed within 15 days, by any person concerned against the recommendation of the Screening Committee. Where therefore the appointing authority without allowing 15 days time to prefer appeal against the recommendation of the Screening Committee passed orders immediately on receipt of recommendations.</p><p><strong>Held:</strong> An essential part of the procedure designed to ensure a fair heating to the person conned not being complied with, the impugned order could not be said to be immune from challenge, in view of the bar raised by section 10 of the Ordinance.</p><p><em>Sardar Muhd. Zaman Khan vs. M B. Nishat (1962) 14 DLR (SC) 1.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2352	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Public Demands Recovery  Act, 1913 [Section 11 - 57 + Schedules + Rules]]</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p align="center" style="text-align:center;"><b><u><span style='Cambria","serif";'><br/></span></u></b></p><p align="center" style="text-align:center;"><b><u><span style='Cambria","serif";'>PublicDemands Recovery Act</span></u></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> <br/></span></p><p align="center" style="text-align:center;"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>(III of1913)</span></p><p align="center" style="text-align:center;"><span style='Cambria","serif";'><br/><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 12</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>. <i>[See under section 9 in the case ofChittagong Engineering &amp; Electric Supply Company Vs. Certificate Officer,in 17 DLR 404 above].</i></span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 13</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>. [See undersection 9 in the case of <i>ChittagongEngineering &amp; Electric Supply Co. vs. Certificate Officer, in 17 DLR 404above].</i></span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 13—Issueof a warrant—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Issue of a distress warrant in advance against acertificate-debtor is permissible only in relation to movable property underthe proviso to section 13 of the Act which provides for attachment of the wholeor any part of any movable property belonging to the certificate-debtor.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>KumudiniWelfare Trust Vs. Pakistan (1950) 12 DLR (SC) 17.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 20:</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> Acertificate-purchaser can claim the right, title and interest only of thecertificate-debtor at the time of the sale and not of any other person.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Golam HafesMiah vs. Khadem Ali Miah (1971) 23 DLR 99.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—S. 20.</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> Defendantwithout title was in possession of the land sold in auction—Plaintiffs purchaseof the land in certificate sale—Effect.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The question before the High Court was whattitle was acquired by the plaintiff in the certificate sale. And having foundthat the defendant was on the land without any title, the High. Court was inerror in going to the question of title acquired by the plaintiff u/s 20 of thePDR Act, because defendant’s claim of title through the certificate- debtor hadfailed. But the defendant being in possession, the question to be determinedis, whether plaintiff, has a better title to recover possession from him.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Golam HafizVs. Khadem Ali (1977)29 DLR (SC) 312.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 20(1).</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> What apurchaser gets when a property sold in execution of a certificate.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Sub-section (1) says, that when a property issold in execution of a certificate, there shall vest in the purchaser merelythe right, title and interest of the certificate debtor at the time of thesale, even though the property itself be specified.      Ibid.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—S. 20(1)and (3)</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'><b>— </b>Purchase u/s. 20(1) has the effectof a money decree and u/s. 20(3) it has the effect of rent-decree.              Ibid.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 20(3) —</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Certificate-Salewhen held in default of payment of rent—consequence of such sale.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>A certificate sale held in default of paymentof rent, and on the compliance with the requirement of the principles ofrepresentation of the land-lord and the tenant, the tenure or holding passeswith the certificate sale. It has the effect of a rent decree. If the doctrineof representation is not fulfilled, it will have the effect of money decree.            Ibid.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S.22—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Suit forsetting aside of a sale where Collector is a necessary party, withoutimpleading him is not maintainable.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>In the present case the impugned order waspassed by the Certificate Officer of Chandpur and the certificate- holder beingthe Collector, the Government required to be implcadcd in the Suit. No order ofany authority can be impugned in a Court of law unless the authority concernedthat passed the impugned order or the relevant authority above him under theGovernment is impleaded in the proceeding. In that view of the matter thepresent suit suffers from material defect of parties.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Sekandar Miavs. Manjuma Khaun (1977) 29  DLR 48.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—S.22:Conditions needed to sustain an application under section 22.</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>In an application under section 22 of the PDRAct it is not necessary for the applicant to prove there was any defect in thecertificate proceedings that he needs is to make the application days of thesale and to deposit the amount in section 22. The application should also beany one of the persons mentioned in section 22.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Azizul Huqvs. Hussain Ali Bepari. (1969) DLR (BR) 1.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—S. 22:</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> A trespassfor a considerable constituted an interest sufficient to confer a takeadvantage of the provisions of section 22 of Act.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>TalebuddinAhmed Vs. Shafiqur Rahman, 21 DLR (BR) 3.</span></i></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—S. 22:</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> Bargadar isa representative of certificate-debtor and therefore payment of dues by aBargadar is valid.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Abdul MalekDhali Vs. Motahar Hossain (1969) 21 DLR (BR) 21.</span></i></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Ss. 22 &amp;23: Sale — of can be set under the Rules.</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>A certificate sale held under the provisionsPublic Demands Recovery Act can be set aside under secs. 22 and 23 of the Act,and not under provisions of any rule framed under the Act. Board of Revenue hadno jurisdiction to set aside certificate sale under Rule 50(3) of the BengalDemands Recovery Rules.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Mansur Ali-Vs- Member, Board of Revenue E. Pakistan (1959) 11 DLR 412.</span></i></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 23</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>. Bonafideauction purchaser even not a party to the proceedings is without when the saleheld is void.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>It was argued that the interest acquired by afide auction-purchaser who was not a party to proceedings, cannot be affected,and reliance has placed in this behalf upon the cases of Zai Khan vs. HanifunNissa Bibi and another.</span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Held:</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> The casesreferred to were cases in the Court concerned had jurisdiction to hold the andtherefore the sales were good and valid at the the sales were held but theposition is otherwise where the Court lacks jurisdiction to proceed with theexecution which renders the sale void ab initio.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>ChittagongEngineering &amp; Electric co. Vs. Certificate Officer (1965)17 DIR 404.</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Deposit under the section when filing anapplication for setting aside the sale can be made by a person on behalf ofcertificate-debtors who were, at the Lime of deposit, Indian nationals, and noquestion of the contravention of section 5 of the Foreign Exchange RegulationAct arises.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Md. AkbarVs. Brojendra (1965) 17 DLR 421.</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—[See undersection 9 in the case of Chittagong Enginering and Electric Supply Co. Vs.Certificate Officer, in 17 DLR 404 above].</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—S. 23:</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> Delay infiling a petition under season 23 is presumed to be condoned if thecertificate  admits the petition forhearing.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Hakim AliVs. Belayet Hossain, (1969) 21 DLR (BR) 9.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—S. 23:</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> Co-sharerentitled to be served with prescribed notices regarding certificate processesfail which sale void—Collector’s duty to produce real evidence in support ofauction sale held under e ceritificate procedure.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Abul HossainVs. Nirmal Chandra Pal. (1969) 21 DIR (BR) 11</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—S.23.</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> <b>Trust property sold without the -e being aparty.</b></span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>A trust property was sold under thecertificate proceeding under the P.D.R. Act without the trustee shown as acertificate-debtor.</span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Held</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> —The trustproperty cannot be affected by the certificate sale.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>HalimunnessaVs. Hemendra K. Roy Chowdhury (1960) 13 DLR 448.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Acertificate under the P.D.R. Act has the extraordinary effect of a decreeagainst the persons named in it as debtors and has the effect of bindingproperty when sold in execution of But, if anyone is not named in thecertificate, there is no foundation for the sale of his property.        Ibid.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Where the certificate-officer had noauthority or jurisdiction under the B.P.D. Act to sell the share of a trustestate, the civil court is to entertain the suit and grant relief to theaggrieved party under the general law and this jurisdiction is not ousted by section36 or 37 of the Act.      Ibid</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—S.23</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>. <b>Omission of names in the certificate form—if a material omission.</b></span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>It was contended that there arc certainirregularities in the certificate form as printed in the Appendix to the PublicDemands Recovery Act, namely, names to whom the money is due and by whom duehave been left blank and, therefore, all proceedings taken on the same arcillegal.</span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Held:</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> Theomission to mention these names and the figures in a portion of the form cannotbe taken to be a material omission which could go to the length of invalidatingthe certificates. The ideas underlying the filling up of the form is that thedebtor should have information of the specific sum claimed from him and theparticulars thereof in the certificate.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>KumudiniWelfare Trust -Vs- Pakistan. (1959) 11 DLR 57.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Secs. 29&amp; 30—Arrest of certificate-debtor—S. 496, Cr.P.Code, if applicable</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The provisions of sec. 496, Cr.P.Code, arenot - attracted in the case of certificate debtor who is arrested under sec. 29of the Public Demands Recovery Act for realisation of the certificate amountand who can be released by the orders of the Collector under sec. 30 of theAct.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>KafiluddinAhmed Vs. Crown (1956) 8 DLR 184.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Certificateofficer—jurisdiction of—</span></b><span style='line-height:115%;Cambria","serif";'>In view of the provisions of sec. 30 of the Act, read with Rule48, a Certificate Officer has no jurisdiction to put up a property to salebefore the expiry of 30 days from the date of the service of sale notice.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Tarangini Devivs. Govinda Mollik (1957) 9 DLR 57.</span></i></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 36:</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> Provisionsof section 36 is only applicable to persons who arc parties to the proceedingor who have lost possession due to the sale—Persons who are neither affected bythe sale nor have lost possession due to the sale need not challenge the sale.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Golam HafezMia Vs. Khadem Ali Mia. (1971) 23 DLR 99</span></i></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 36.</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> Sale notheld on the date as proclaimed in the sale proclamation—Is a materialirregularity to be set aside on proof of substantial injury.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>A question arises as to what would be theeffect of a finding to the effect that the sale having taken place on a datewhen the properties were not proclaimed to be sold — Whether the sale would bea nullity or whether such deviation from the legal provision would amount to amaterial irregularity only, that is, the sale would be liable to be set asideon proof of the fact that the party challenging the sale has been adverselyaffected.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>On this point there is preponderance ofdecision in favour of the proposition that the sale is not a nullity but isvitiated by material irregularity and is liable to be set aside on proof ofsubstantial injury suffered by the judgment-debtors.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Akmal KhanVs. Amaresh Chandra (1966) 18 DLR 502.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—S. 36.Import of section 36 explained—Effect of non-service u/s 7.</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The true import of section 36 is that thesale in a certificate proceeding for non service of notice under section 7 isvalid against the whole world for all times and as against the certificate-debtor after a period of one year from the date of delivery of property to thepurchaser, if no proceeding for setting aside the sale has been started in themeanwhile.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The position is two-fold; such sale is validas against the whole world, except the certificate- debtor it is voidable for alimited period, and valid for all times against the certificate- debtor afterthe prescribed period. The purchaser may claim a valid title against thecertificate- debtor as well after the lapse of the period under section 36.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Golam HafezVs. Khadem (1977) 29 DLR (SC) 313.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Certificate-debtor cannot challenge a certificatesale by way of defense in a suit by the certificate-purchaser to establish histitle.       Ibid.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Secs. 36&amp; 37</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—<b>Fraudulent Sale limitation for a suit.</b></span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Where a sale has been brought about by ii offraud, proviso (a) to sec. 36 of the Public Demands Recovery Act will not beattracted and plaintiff will be competent to take advantage of sec 18 of theLimitation Act in computing the time for bringing his suit.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Tarangini DeviVs Govinda Mollik (1957) 9 DLR 57.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Where a sale is found to be a nullity, no copeof a suit being hit either by pros sec. 36 or by sec. 37, and it will begoverned by general law and not by Public Demands Recovery Act.       Ibid.</span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S.37. Thesection — if a bar to a suit in the Civil Court.</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The section is not a bar to a suit in a CivilCourt where the proceedings under the Act are unauthorized and fraudulent.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Md.Mazaharul Huq Choudhry vs Nagendra Dey (1957) 9 DLR 456.</span></i></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—S. 37.Courts functions while disposing of a case u/s 7.</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>In order to decide whether the suit ismaintainable under section 37 of the Act the ultimate - in respect of the suitis not the decisive factor. In the case as made out by the plaintiff in his placewhich is the primary material upon which such decision has to be made.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The appellate Court in dealing with a casefit, under section 37 of the Public Demands Recovery Act on the allegation thatthe sale of the property not take place on the date mentioned in the saleproclamation and the property was sold for a grossly  equate price has to apply its mind to thesequestion Finding in these questions would become import for a decision as towhether the sale was a fraudulent one, because, if it is found that it wastainted fraud, then the entire sale was vitiated and must treated as nullity.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Akmal Khan VsAmaresh Chandra (1966) 18 DLR 502</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Civil Courts have jurisdiction to cancelcertificate when they are not ‘duly filed’.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>There can be no foundation for issuance ofthe certificate under the Public Demands Recovery Act the realisation of thecost of repairs (in this case under the Embankment Act) inasmuch as thecertificate having been made for an amount not legally determined and due, thecertificate cannot be said to bye been “duly filed” within the meaning of sec.37 d, as such, the proceedings taken on the basis of that certificate werewithout jurisdiction And therein, section 37 cannot operate as a bar to theCivil Court’s jurisdiction to cancel the certificate.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Province ofEast Bengal Vs. Maharaja Kirit Bikram (1962) 14 DLR 215.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Section 37 considered in the light of theentire scheme of the Act seems to suggest that in matters the present one thehierarchy of authorities under the Public Demands Recovery Act are alonecompetent to deal with them.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Having regarded to the facts andcircumstances of this case it is not an appropriate case wherein we should useour discretion in favour of the petitioner exercise of the extraordinaryjurisdiction of this Court. Such forbearance on our part, will advance the seof equity and justice rather than retard it.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Abdul HadiKhan vs. Member, Board of Revenue (1967) 19 DLR 898.</span></i></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—[See undersection 9 in the case of Chittagong Enginering and Electric Supply Co. Ltd. in17 DLR r.4 above.]</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Certificate officer to decide questionrelating to setting aside of an auction sale held in execution of a certificateand not by any suit.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Sekander MiaVs. Manjuma Khatun (1977) 29 DLR 47.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Civil Court may entertain a suit when fraudis alleged—Limited jurisdiction of the Civil Court action under section 42 ofthe Specific Relief Act.         Ibid</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Sec 41 </span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>— <b>Deity </b>— <b>liability of </b>— A deity under the Hindu Law has the capacity toproperty and capacity to enter into contract and capacity to sue and be suedbut in every case it must act through a shebait.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Upendra N.Biswas -Vs. Haripada Saha Kundu (1956) 8 DLR 374.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Certificate Officer - Authority in respectof a representative idol.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>When the shebait was dead on the date offiling of the certificate, the idol, even if he was named in the certificate,could not take any action in the matter. Under scc.4 1 of the Public DemandsRecovery Act when the Certificate Officer is satisfied that the certificate-debtor is a minor or of unsound mind, he shall, in any proceeding under thisAct, permit him to be represented by a suitable person but, in the case of anidol, the Certificate Officer has no authority to direct that the idol shouldbe represented by a suitable person.             Ibid</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—On account of the death of the shebait, theestate of the idol went unrepresented and for that reason the whole proceedingwas a nullity. The fact that the succeeding shebaits and other shebaits weremade parties at a subsequent stage could not save the situation.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 43:</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> When acertificate-debtor dies after a certificate case started, notice under section43 must be served prior to the date of actual sale; otherwise thecertificate-debtor could legitimately claim that they have received nointimation of the date of sale.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>JitendraNath Das Vs. Income Tax Officer (1969) 21 DLR (BR) 12.</span></i></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 53.</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> There beingnon-service of notice of sale and of sale proclamation, sale of immovableproperty held is not valid and revisional authority u/s 53 can so declare it.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>A.Y. AhmedAli Vs. Dr. Jamshed Ali &amp; ors. (1981) 33 DLR 295.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—S. 53.</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> Revisionalauthority acting under the section 53 can suo motu (in this case at theinstance of a 3rd person who was not a party in the execution proceeding of thecertificate) set aside a sale held by the Certificate Officer—(No time-limitapplicable, there being no provisions for tune-limit for acting under section53).</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>HassainuddinVs. Additional Collector (1962)14 DLR 753.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 57.Certificate Officer</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>A Certificate Officer is not a civil Courtfor all purposes excepting for the purpose stated in the section. Injunctionorder passed against the Certificate Officer is not illegal.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Federationof Pak. -Vs- Kumudinni Welfare Trust (1954) 6 DLR 177.</span></i></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Schedule II</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Rule 22, The Certificate Officer wrote aletter to the executing Court requesting the executing Court to credit acertain amount of money in favour of the certificate officer for satisfactionof certain income-tax dues. The question was whether this letter could betreated as a notice under rule 22 of Schedule II of the Public Demands RecoveryAct and whether executing Court had jurisdiction to decide the question ofpriority between the decree-holder and the Income- Tax Department.</span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Held</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>: Therequest made by the Certificate Officer should be treated as notice under rule23.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The executing Court has jurisdiction todecide the question of priority between the decree- holders and the Income -taxDepartment. In such cases the executing court after deciding priority would becompetent to issue payment orders.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Pakistan vs.Badarunnessa (1961) 13 DLR 375.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>R. 62:</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> ScheduleII—Encumbrances—Certificate sale does not automatically annul the encumbrances.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Azizur RahmanVs. Hedayet Ahmed Chowdhury, (1972) 24 DLR 11.</span></i></p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span> </div></div>
2353	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Public Demands Recovery  Act, 1913 [Section 1 - 10]</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  14 DLR 213, 21 DLR (BR) 12, 21 DLR (BR) 15, 29 DLR (SC) 234, 1 DLR 18, 8 DLR 374,  9 DLR 236, 9 DLR 57, 8 DLR 129, 12 DLR (SC) 17, 23 DLR 9, 17 DLR 405,  29 DLR (SC) 233, 29 DLR (SC) 234, 27 DLR 442 and 443, 29 DLR (SC) 312, 21 DLR (BR) 5, 21 DLR (BR) 15</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Public Demands Recovery  </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p><em> </em></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Public Demands Recovery Act</u></strong> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;">(III of 1913)</p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"> </p><p><strong>S. 3(6): Trespassers of the Government d or fishery cannot be proceeded against under Article 7</strong></p><p>Demand under Article 7 of Schedule I of the Public Demands Recovery Act must be payable to the Collector by a person holding any interest in the land.</p><p>Possessory right may be a right in certain circumstances but a trespasser’s possession is not such a right as contemplated under Article 7 of Schedule I of the Act.</p><p>So the demand which can be made by the Collector must be in pursuance to a contract enforceable in aid therefore the Governments right to realise compensation for use and occupation against a trespassers does not come under Article 7 of Schedule I of the Act nor it is public demand as defined in subsection (6) of section 3 of the Act..</p><p><em>Province of East Pakistan Vs. Mahim Chandra (1962) 14 DLR 213.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>S. 4:</strong> <strong>Certificate against dead person void and also the sale there under—</strong>A certificate was issued in the name of one Jagadish Chandra Ganguly by the Certificate Officer of Mymensingh and was transferred to the Certificate Officer of Dacca for execution. The Certificate debtor was in fact one Jagadish Chandra Banarjee. It is admitted that Jagadish Chandra Banarjee died in 1946 and the certificate was filed in 1956. After receipt of the peon’s report the Certificate Officer of Dacca substituted the heirs of Jagadish Chandra Binarjee and the sale was held.</p><p><strong>Held:</strong> The certificate issued is void having been issued against a dead person. The Certificate Officer of Dacca could only return the certificate to the Certificate Officer of Mymensingh for necessary correction. As this has not been done in the present case not only sale but also the certificate proceedings pursuant to which the sale is made is absolutely void.</p><p><em>Yar Ahmad Vs. Province of East Pakistan, (1968) 20 DLR 1103.</em></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>—Ss. 4 and 5:</strong> Duty of the certificate officer is to satisfy himself that a particular demand was recoverable and in a long drawn and complicated case, the certificate officer should not shift the onus (as to the clearance of the certificate dues) entirely upon the certificate debtor.</p><p><em>Jitendra Nath Das Vs. Income Tax Officer, (1969) 21 DLR (BR) 12.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>—S. 4:</strong> A certificate against a dead person is void ab- initio and a fresh certificate must issue against the legal representatives of the deceased.</p><p><em>Abdul Jahl Shaikh Vs. Md. Ameer Ali (1969) 21 DLR (BR) 15.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>—S. 4.</strong> “That they were jointly recoverable and its recover by suit is not barred by Law’. Omission of these words does not affect validity of a certificate.</p><p><em>Shafiqur Rahman Vs. Certificate Officer (1977) 29 DLR (SC) 234.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>—S. 4. Party to Certificate Proceeding.</strong></p><p>The plaintiff purchased the share of the defendants in a holding in a money sale and the landlord’s. fees and notice were duly sent to the landlord before the confirmation of the sale on 29.9.34.</p><p>Thereafter, in a certificate sale under the Public Demands Recovery Act against the recorded tenants only in which the plaintiff was not impleaded as a party, the holding was put to sale and purchased by one M and 2 others on 8.4.35.</p><p>Thereafter, in a suit by the plaintiff, he gave up his title in the land to the defendants by a compromise decree. The holding was again sold in execution of a rent decree and was purchased by the plaintiff, the defendants not being made parties to the rent suit or the execution proceeding. An application by the defendants for setting aside the sale under sec. 174 of the Bengal Tenancy Act was dismissed on the ground that they had no interest and, therefore, no locus standi. The plaintiff then attempted to take possession of the land but was resisted by the defendants. Hence the present suit for declaration of title and possession.</p><p><strong>Held</strong>: The plaintiff not being made a party in the Certificate sale or suit sale, his title in the land remains intact and went to the benefit of the defendants under he compromise decree. Even if it be conceded that the plaintiff had no title at the time of the compromise decree, still, after subsequent acquisition of title under the rent sale, he would be estopped by the principle of ‘estoppel by the conduct” from taking such a plea and re-asserting his title to the land he previously gave to the defendants under the compromise decree.</p><p><strong>Also held</strong>: The applications under sec. 174 of the Bengal Tenancy Act was neither a suit nor a continuation of a suit, and did not operate as res judicata against the defendants and in favour of the plaintiff. The appeal was dismissed.</p><p><em>Upendra Ch. Acharya Vs. Prazap Ch. Sutradhar. (1949) 1 DLR 18.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>—Secs. 4,6-9: </strong>Procedure to follow to recover debts under Act— The effect of service of notice upon the caw-debtor —Steps which a certificate- debtor take when he denies liability.</p><p><em>Upendra N. Biswas Vs. Haripada Saha Kundu (1956) 8 DLR 374.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>S. 7: Service of notice—effect of—</strong>The service of notice under sec. 7 of the Demands Recovery Act upon a certificate-debtor the effect of attachment of the immovable proc in respect of which the certificate is filed within meaning of sec. 17 of the Bengal Land Sales Act, 1859, and any sale of such property under the Bengal Land Revenue Sales Act is void ab initio and in toto.</p><p><em>Province of East Bengal Vs. Subodh Ch. Gupta (1957) 9 DLR 236.</em></p><p> </p><p>Before a sale is held, a notice of the date for setting terms of the sale proclamation is to be given to the certificate-debtor in Form as required by Rule 46.</p><p><em>Tarangini Debi Vs. Govinda Mallik (1957) 9 DLR 57.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>—S. 7. </strong>Certificate issued for recovery of public demand. The form of certificate— Non-filling columns in the certificate form will not vitiate sale if the failure to fill up the blanks cannot treated as material defects.</p><p><em>Harendra K. Kanungo Vs. Manindra Ch. Sen (1956) 8 DLR 129.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>—S. 7. </strong>Action under section 7 of the Public Demand Recovery Act can only be taken against a certificate debtor and not one who is not already a certificate debtor.</p><p><em>Kumudini Welfare Trust Vs. Pakistan (1960) 12 DLR (SC) 17.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>—S. 7: </strong>Non-service of notice under of the act does not render the sale void—such a sale is voidable.</p><p><em>Golam Hafez Mia Vs.
