Khadem Ali Mia (1971) 23 DLR 9.</em></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>—Sale void when it is held for several certificate debts consolidated together:</strong></p><p>Where a sale is held under the Public Demands Recovery Act not in respect of one particular certified-debt but in respect of several certificate debts all consolidated together, such a sale is not a sale in accordance with the Public Demands Recovery Act and as such is void.</p><p>Chittagong Engineering &amp; Electric Supply <em>Co. vs. Certificate Officer (1965) 17 DLR 405.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>S. 7. Provisions of section 7 explained: </strong>Service of notice and copy of certificate served on certificate debtor.</p><p>Section 7 says that when a certificate has been filed the Certificate Officer shall serve upon the certificate-debtor in the prescribed manner a. notice in the prescribed form. After service of the notice, when a period of 30 days has elapsed, and no objection has been taken in terms of the Act, the Certificate Officer under section 14 shall proceed with the attachment id sale, or sale without previous attachment of any property or attachment of the decree, or arrest and detention of the certificate-debtor as the case may require.</p><p>The prescribed manner is to be found in rules 2 to 9 contained in Schedule H of the Act. A reading of the rules shows that there must be an attempt to serve the notice directly on the certificate-debtor in. But there is also the alternative provisions for service, by way of substituted service, if the attempt personal service fails that is contained in Rules 6 (a) (b)</p><p><em>Golam Hafez Mia Vs. Khadem Ali Mia (1971) 23 DLR 9.</em></p><p> </p><p>—Decision in the case of Md. Muslim Ali Molla held to be wrong.</p><p>The decision in Mohammad Muslem Ali Molla’s (PLR 1957 Dac. 6) which says that rule 6(b) cannot be resorted to for service under section 7 of the Act is not correct. For substituted service of notice under section 7 of the Act, both the alternative clauses (a) and (b) of rule 6 can be resorted to, according to the facts of exact case. Ibid.</p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>—Consequences following from service of notice under section 7.</strong></p><p>On the service of notice under section 7 the consequences following from it are first: any private transfer of any immovable property in the district where certificate is filed is void, and secondly, the certificate dues become a charge upon the immovable property of certificate-debtor throughout the country. Ibid.</p><p>—Sections 7-10. Any variation from the prescribed form would not be fatal in a certificate issued under the Bengal Public Demands Recovery Act for realisation of certificate dues.</p><p><em>Shafiqur Rahman Vs. Certificate Officer (1977) 29 DLR (SC) 233.</em></p><p>—If no certificate is filed having the force of a decree no valid sale can be held under the certificate. Ibid.</p><p> </p><p><strong>—Requirements to comply with the provisions embodied in sections 7, 8, 9, &amp;10.</strong></p><p>It is necessary to refer to the sections mentioned above namely, 7.8, 9 and 10. By section 7 when certain public demands were in arrears, the Collector of the district was to make under his hand a certificate (in the Form 2 given in the said Act) for the amount of such arrears remaining unpaid and was to cause the same to be filed in his office. By section 8 such certificate should, as regards the remedies for enforcing the same, have the force and effect of a decree of a civil court. Under section 10 such certificate having been filed in the office of the Collector, he has to issue to the Judgment- debtors a copy of such certificate and a notice in form No. 4 as given in the Act, and such certificate from the time it was served would bind all the immovable properties of the debtor if it has been attached under section 274 of the Code of Civil Procedure (Old). Such certificate u/s 19 of the Act is to be enforced in accordance with the provisions of the Civil Procedure Code as a demand for money.</p><p><em>Shafiqur Rahman Vs. Certificate Officer (1977) 29 DLR (SC) 234.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>—Ss. 7 and 36.</strong> Notice under section 7 is found as not a proper service on the certificate- debtor. What is the effect of this improper service of notice under section 7? Under section 36 it does not make the sale void but the defendant could have challenged it either in the certificate proceeding or by a suit. It appears that he did file a case to set aside the sale before the Revenue Authority but failed: But he did not pursue his remedy by a suit. Could he be allowed to challenge it collaterally in the present suit? On the plain language of section 36 of the Act he cannot.</p><p><em>Julfu Molla Vs. Noab Ali (1975)27 DLR 442 and 443.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p>—Suit to recover possession of or to set aside sale of, immovable property will lie where no notice as required by s. 7 has been served on certificate debtor.</p><p><em>Golam Hafez Vs. Khadem Ali (1977) 29 DLR (SC) 312.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p>—Validity of a certificate sale on the ground of non-service of notice cannot be challenged by way of defense and a sale held u/s. 7 is valid unless set aside as provided in S. 36—Substituted service under rule 6(b) cannot be treated as non-service.</p><p><em>Golam Hafez Vs. Khadem Ali (1977) 29 DLR (SC) 312.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>—S. 7 &amp; 23</strong>—Persons who can claim service of notice under sec. 7 and those who can file applications under section 23<em>. </em></p><p><em>Md. Yakub Vs. Abul Hossain Master (1969) 21 DLR (BR) 5.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>S. 8</strong>—Transfer by private sale of a property in respect of which notice has been served under section 7 is void against any claim enforceable under the certificate.</p><p><em>Abdul Jahl Shaikh Vs. Md. Ameer Ali (1969) 21 DLR (BR) 15.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>—Sees. 8 &amp; 13</strong>—Where an assessee transfers the property in respect of which dues are charged, proper course for the authority to adopt is to attach the property itself—The only Acton which could properly be taken by the Income-Tax authorities for recovery the income-tax dues was to take out attachment the properties in this particular case on the basis  they vested, in the àssessee R.P. and, thereupon, should have been open to the Trust to make an objection before the certificate-officer and thereby making it possible to obtain a resolution of the question, arising in this matter in accordance with I jurisdiction provided by the law.</p><p><em>Kumudini Welfare Trust Vs. Pakistan (1960) 12 DLR (SC) 17.</em></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>S. 9—Sale of property while the application filed under section 9 had not b heard and disposed of—Without jurisdiction.</strong></p><p>When an objection petition denying liability whole or in part, in respect of a certificate debt been filed by a certificate-debtor under section the Public Demands Recovery Act, any sale held a Certificate Officer while the objection petition under section 9 was still pending disposal shall, u the mandatory provisions of section 15 of the be void and without jurisdiction.</p><p><em>Chittagong Engineering &amp; Electric Supply Co. Vs. Certificate Officer (1965) 17 DLR 405.</em></p><p> </p><p>—Collector’s order under section 53 resulting j the sale being held while application under section was pending disposal—without jurisdiction.</p><p>An order of a Collector in exercise of his revisional power under section 53 of the Act leading the sale of the certificate-debtor’s property while certificate-debtor’s petition under section 9 was pending disposal is equally without jurisdiction.</p><p><em>Chittagong Engineering &amp; Electric Supply Co. Vs. Certificate Officer (1965) 17 DLR 405.</em></p><p> </p><p>—Certificate Officer to whom a certificate is possesses under section 37 all the powers of the certificate Officer under sections 4 and 6, but exercise of such powers is subject to the provisions of section 9.</p><p>The Certificate Officer to whom a certificate is sent under section 12(2) has under section 37 all the powers of the Certificate Officer who filed the certificate under sections 4 or 6 and may decide all questions arising between certificate-holder and certificate-debtor relating to the making, execution, satisfaction and discharge of the certificate. But the power so vested in him is exercisable subject to the statutory exception embodied in section 9(2). Ibid.</p><p> </p><p>—Mandatory provision in holding sale not observed—relief under writ jurisdiction, can be availed of.</p><p>Compliance with the provision of section 13 is mandatory and object to the proviso thereto a Certificate Officer has no jurisdiction to proceed with the execution of a certificate until and unless he has disposed of the objection, filed under section 9, Hence the certificate-debtor, under the circumstances, was within his right to invoke the writ jurisdiction of the High Court under Article 98 of the Constitution.</p><p>It is to be noted that a sale held without service f notice under section 7 also was by general consensus held to be a nullity till the Legislature expressly provided to the contrary under section 36.   Ibid.</p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>—Petition under the section not verified </strong>—Held: merely a formal defect which does not affect the sale. It was contended that the petitions purported to be under section 9 were not verified as required and could not, therefore, be regarded as valid petitions under the said section.</p><p><strong>Held:</strong> It is no doubt necessary to verify such petitions but an omission or failure to do so is a for defect, which does not affect the merits of the e. The most that the Certificate Officer could do to call upon the petitioner to remove the defect.   Ibid.</p><p> </p><p><strong>S. 9(1).</strong> An objection that certain sum of money is due to the certificate-debtor by the certificate holder and has therefore to be adjusted is valid under section 9.</p><p>In his objection under section 9 of the Act the certificate - debtor in relation to the certificate-debt due to the Government, prayed that certain amount due to him by the Government might be adjusted towards the claim of certificate-debt.</p><p><strong>Held:</strong> Since a certificate debtor has the rightto deny his liability in respect of a certificate-debt in part under section 9(I) a prayer for adjustment of the certificate-debtor’s dues payable by the Government, i.e. the certificate-debtor is legally tenable.   Ibid.</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2354	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Public Safety Ordinance, 1958</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (19 J7 DLR 76, (1967) 19 DLR (SC) 100</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Public Safety </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Public Safety Ordinance</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;">(LXXVII of 1958)</p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"> </p><p><strong>S.9.</strong> Restriction imposed by section 9, whether inconsistent with the guaranteed fundamental right of freedom by the constitution.</p><p><strong>Held:</strong> The power vested in the Government under section 9 of the Ordinance are indeed wide they are to be exercised only if it were satisfied to the necessity of using them for securing public safety or the maintenance of public order. There cannot be any presumption that there will be abuse in the exercise of the powers. A case of mala fide, exercise of power is always subject to judicial  interference. In determining the vires of the section, Court is to see only whether the restriction put it on freedom of speech were reasonably necessary I the interest of public order.</p><p>In answering that question, the Court cannot assume that the Provincial Government will exercise the discretion given to it by section 9 arbitrarily.</p><p><em>Tofazzal Hossain Vs. Govt. of E. Pak. (19 J7 DLR 76.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>S.31 (1) </strong>— <strong>Collective fine when can be imposed.</strong></p><p>The section visualizes a situation when court offences by reason of the frequency of their preparation and other attending circumstances may legitimately call for imposition of collective fine by of deterrent in order to check the further commission of such offences.</p><p>The section does not by reason of a single incident, confer power on the Government to impose collective fine in a particular locality. On the contrary the clear recital in the section furnishes a t giblc and rational basis for imposition of collect fine to check criminal courses of conduct by a community.</p><p><em>Province of East Pakistan Vs. Abu Farid Khan (1967) 19 DLR (SC) 100.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2355	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Public Servants Retirement Act, 1974 &amp; Rules of 1973, 1975</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1981) 33 DLR (AD) 201, (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 72,  (1981) 33 DLR 326, 30 DLR 40, (1979) 31 DLR 233,  (1981) 33 DLR 216, 1982) 34 DLR 21</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Public Servants Retirement </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Public Servants Retirement Act</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;">(XII of 1974)</p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"> </p><p><strong>Defects of the Act </strong>— No policy or principle for guidance of exercise of discretion by the Government has been laid down in the impugned Act. Nor has the Government laid down such principle for its guidance in the rules framed under the Act.</p><p><em>Dr.Nurul Islam, Vs. Bangladesh represented by the Secy. Ministry of health (1981) 33 DLR (AD) 201.</em></p><p> </p><p>Distinction between retiring a Government servant on Government’s subjective satisfaction in which case the Government is the sole authority to decide and the preventive detention of a citizen in which case the High Court is empowered to weigh Government’s decision to sec if the order of detention is lawful.</p><p>H<em>abibullah Khan, Vs. Shah Azharuddin Ahmed and ors. (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 72.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p>A person aggrieved by an order of retirement may plead it was not passed in public interest, in which case the Government should place materials before the court in justification of its action.</p><p><em>Habibullah Khan, Vs. Shah Azharuddin Ahmed and ors. (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 72.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Sec. 4 read with sec. 3</strong></p><p>An employee of a statutory corporation (being a public servant) cannot be retired before 57 years of his age even under a contract or terms of service with Employer. Such employee cannot be dismissed or removed without rules being framed therefore.</p><p>Golam <em>Morshed Vs. Bangladesh Textile Mills. (1981) 33 DLR 326.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Secs. 4 and 9(2)</strong></p><p>Section 4 of the Act is controlled by sec. 9(2)— Government is the sole judge of what is public interest.</p><p><em>Dr. Nurul Islam Vs. Bangladesh, represented by</em> <em>“Secretary, Ministry of health.(1981) 33 DLR AD 201.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>S.7</strong> Entitlement of leave preparatory to retired can not be denied to one who is compulsorily retired.</p><p><em>Abdur Rashid Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh 30 DLR 40.</em></p><p> </p><p>S<strong>s. 7 and 9(2</strong>)—The authority while passing order directed that the petitioner would not be entitled to leave preparatory to retirement. This direction not permissible in a case of compulsory retirement. The right that accrued under section 7 of the Act cannot be denied to a government servant who is compulsorily retired under section 9(2) of the Act.</p><p>This part of the impugned order, that is, “that he shall not be entitled to leave preparatory to retirement” is bad in law, and as such it cannot be sustained.</p><p><em>Abdur Rashid, Vs. The Govt. of the People’s Republic of Bangladesh (1979) 31 DLR 233.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>S. 9(2)—</strong>Privilege available to a government servant under section 9(2) of the Act—preparatory to retirement.</p><p><em>Mostafa Hyder Chowdhury Vs. Bangladesh (1981) 33 DLR</em><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> <em>216.</em></span></p><p> </p><p>Although the government has the power to cause compulsory retirement after completion of 25 years of service— There should be some nexus with the decision of the Govt.</p><p><em>Mostafa Hyder Chowdhury Vs. Bangladesh (1981)33 DLR 216.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>S. 9(2)—</strong>Empowering the Government to Retire a Government Servant on Completion of 25 years Service Suffers from Unconstitutionality.</p><p><em>Dr. Nurul Islam Vs. Bangladesh represented by the Secy, Ministry of health (1981) 33 DLR (AD) 201</em>.</p><p> </p><p><strong>Sub-sec (2)</strong> <strong>—</strong>Sub-Sec. (2) of Sec. 9 is Violative of articles 27 and 29 of the Constitution since it gives scope to Discrimination.</p><p><em>Dr. Nurul Islam Vs. Bangladesh represented by the Secy. Ministry of Health (1981) 33 DLR (AD) 201.</em></p><p> </p><p>—Authority to decide as to what is “public interest” is the Government alone- A court of law not to sit on Government’s judgment if its order is not malafide.</p><p>H<em>abibullah Khan Vs. Shah Azharuddin Ahmed (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 72.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Section 9(2)</strong> <strong>— </strong>Violates the Guarantee given under article 135 of the constitution and is thus ultravires.</p><p><em>Dr. Nurul Islam Vs. Bangladesh represented by the Secretary. Ministry of health (1981) 33 DLR</em> <em>(AD) 201.</em></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Public Servant</strong></p><p>—Order retiring a public servant by the Government must show that such order is necessary in public interest - Where there is none in the retirement order, it shall be struck down as being passed without legal authority.</p><p><em>Dr. Abu Ahmed Chowdhury Vs. Bangladesh (1982) 34 DLR 21.</em></p><p> </p><p>—Sub-section (2) of section 9 of Act XII of 1974 is <em>ultra vires</em> the Constitution being violation of Articles 27, 29 and 135 of the Constitution. The impugned notification is therefore an invalid provision of law causing premature retirement of the appellant from Government service and as such is illegal and Void.</p><p><strong>B.H. Chowdhury, J.</strong>—Section 9(2) is bad and ultra vires and the impugned notification is illegal and has been made without any lawful authority and therefore is of no legal effect.</p><p><em>Dr.Nurul Islam, Vs. Bangladesh represented by the Secretary, Ministry of Health. (1981) 33 DLR (AD) 201. </em></p><p> </p><p>—Absence of Principle of guideline in section 9(2) of Act XII 011974 as to how description is to be exercised—scope for arbitrary Act exists.</p><p>Since neither the impugned provisions of the Act nor the rules provide any principle or guideline for the exercise of discretion by the Government when it proposes to retire a Government servant form amongst a group of Government servants similarly situated and holding similar jobs, there invariably exists the scope for arbitrary exercise of such discretion.</p><p>Discretion of the relevant authority must be seen to have been exercised on some such principles as arc discernible in Fundamental Rule 56, Note 2 of the East Bengal Service Rule and Rule 3 of the Bangladesh Public Servants Retirement Rules, 1973. Where such basis has been provided the concerned authority before exercising its discretion, has to conform to the principles so provided therein.</p><p><em>Dr.Nurul Islam, Vs. Bangladesh represented by the Secretary, Ministry of health. (1981) 33 DLR (AD) 201.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>—Per Kemaluddin Hossain, CJ.</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">-(Agreed Munim, J. except to the extent indicated):</span></p><p>‘I do not propose to declare section 9(2) of Public Servants (Retirement) Act, 1974 (ACT XII 1974) ultravires the Constitution, as the finding the order under challenge is vitiated by malice in is sufficient to dispose of the appeal.</p><p>A Court will not declare a law unconstitutional if the case in which the question is raised can properly disposed of in some other way. I, therefore refrain from striking down the section as unconstitutional in adherence to the principles set out herein.</p><p><strong>Per F. Munim, J.</strong> (Delivering the leading judgment)<strong> — </strong>Sub-Section (2) of section 9 is unconstitutional and violative of articles 27 and 29 of the constitution and also suffers from malice in Law Notification issued void.</p><p><em>Dr.Nurul Islam, Vs. Bangladesh represented by the Secretary, Ministry of health. (1981) 33 DLR (AD) 201.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>—Section 9(2) not ultravires of the Constitution.</strong></p><p>The petitioner being in service of the Republic immediately before the commencement of the situation is entitled to continue in that service on same terms and conditions as were applicable to r immediately before such commencement. This section does not divest the Parliament or the prime Law-making body to regulate the condition of service, as in the instant case, fixing age of retirement. However, clause (b) sub-paragraph(2) of paragraph 10 makes it clear that the protection as mentioned in sub-paragraph (1) shall not prevent making of any law varying or revoking the cc lions of service (including remuneration, leave, pension rights and rights relating to disciplinary matters) of person employed at any time before commencement of this Constitution or of persons continuing in the service of the Republic under the p visions of paragraph 10. In view of the above note provisions in the Constitution, we are of the c ion that section 9(2) of Act XII of 1974 is not ultravires of the Constitution.</p><p><em>Abdur Rashid, Vs. The Govt. of the People’s Republic of Bangladesh. (1979) 31 DLR 233.</em></p><p> </p><p>—Section 9(2) is not violative of Art. 135 of The Bangladesh constitution, 1972.</p><p>Section 9(2) is not violative of Article 135 for die simple reason that protection under article 135 is strictly limited to dismissal, removal or reduction in rank, whereas premature retirement on completion of 25 years’ service with full pensioner benefits, does, under no circumstances, amount to dismissal or removal.</p><p><em>Dr. Nurul Islam, Vs. Bangladesh (1981) 33 DLR (AD) 201.</em></p><p> </p><p>—Order of Retirement illegal.</p><p><strong>Per Shahabuddin, J.</strong> -Government’s power section 9(2) of the Bangladesh Public Servants Retirement) Act was exercised for a collateral pure, that is to say, the impugned order of retirement t the appellant was made to Circumvent the High Cart. Division’s order allowing the Writ Petition No. 571 of 1979.</p><p><em>Dr. Nurul Islam, Vs. Bangladesh represented by the Ministry of Health. (1981) 33 DLR (AD) 201.</em></p><p>—Decision on the question of section 9(2)being ultra vires of articles 27 and 29 of the Constitution called for.   Ibid.</p><p>—Retiring a public servant before superannuation be on the ground of “public interest’ S.9(2) of 4aX11 of 1974 does not say so. Ibid.</p><p>—Retiring a public servant on his completion of service amounts to punishment. Such termination is “removal” under Art. 135. Ibid.</p><p>—Government servants retiring with full pension 25 years of service—cannot be said to have been punished and it does not impute any stigma. Retirement order after 25 years service may be made for various reasons—Procedure and penalty under article 135 of the Constitution different from those u/s 9(2) of (Public Servants Retirement Act (XII of 1974) - Section 9(2) not violative of art. 135. Ibid.</p><p> </p><p><strong>S.9(2) : after the amendment </strong>—</p><p><strong>Shahabuddin Ahmed, J.—</strong> Government empowered u/s 9(2)(as it stands after the amendment) to retire government servant after 25 years of service in public interest without assigning any reason, and holding that Civil Appeal No. 70, 1981 be allowed and judgment of the High Court Division be set aside.</p><p><em>Habibullah Khan. Vs. Shah Azharuddin Ahmed and ors. (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 72.</em></p><p> </p><p>—Completion of 25 years service when takes place, the Government, if it so thinks order his retire with eligible benefits. Ibid.</p><p>—Retirement after 25 years service is not dismissal or removal or compulsory retirement. Ibid.</p><p>—No malafide motive to be attributed when Government takes any step lawfully.   Ibid.</p><p>—When retiring a servant after 25 years’ service Government under provision of law not required giving any notice and it shall be assumed that the step was taken in public interest. Ibid.</p><p><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p><strong><em>—S. 9(2) </em></strong>— <strong><em>after amendment in 1981 by Ordinance VI of 1981. </em></strong></p><p>In S.(2) of Act XII of 1974 the words “public Interest”. interest’ were not there. By amendment introduced by Ordinance Vl/1981 the expression “public interest’ was added and given retrospective effect. Ibid.</p><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>PUBLIC SERVANT’S RETIREMENT RULES OF 1973</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p>Enacted that Retirement of the public servant could be ordered where it is necessary for the interest of public service or in public interest thereby offering a basis for a retirement order.</p><p><em>Dr. Nurul Islam, Vs. Bangladesh (1981) 33 DLR (AD) 201.</em></p><p>—Such a basis if could be found in Act XII of 1974 as was in the rules of 1973 that would have enabled the authority to show the basis of its action.   Ibid.</p><p><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Public Servants Retirement Rules, 1975</u></strong></p><p><strong>No Guideline Provided. </strong></p><p>No principle or guideline for the exercise of discretion by the Government in the matter of retiring a Government servant on the completion of 25 years of service is provided in the Public Servants (Retirement) Rules, 1975.</p><p><em>Dr. Nurul Islam, Vs. Bangladesh represented by the Secretary, Ministry of Health. (1981) 33 DLR (AD) 201.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2356	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Railways Act, 1890</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p align="center" style="text-align:center"><b><u><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Railways Act</span></u></b></p><p align="center" style="text-align:center"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>(IX of 189O)</span></p><p align="center" style="text-align:center"><span style='Cambria","serif";'><br/></span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Secs. 55 and56</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Railway’sresponsibility as a warehouseman in respect of goods entrusted to Its care.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Responsibilityof the Railway as a carrier may come to an end within a reasonable time afterthe consignments have reached the destination, but its responsibility as awarehouseman continues until terminated in accordance with the provisions ofsections 55 and 56 of the Railways Act.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Mr.Kalimuddin Ahmed, Vs. Ibid</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Responsibilityof Railway for loss, destruction or deterioration is to consignor only and notto insurer of goods-No privity of contract between Railway and insurer— Letterof subrogation obtained by insurer from consignor confers no locus standi oninsurer to sue. <i>(1957) (1) PLR (LAH) 273.</i></span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Railways inIndia are not common carriers and their liability in a case not affected bycontract is the liability of a bailee under the Contract Act, that is to say, aduty to take as much care of the goods entrusted for carriage as a man ofordinary prudence would be expected to take of his own goods. <i>54 CWN (DR 2) 35.</i></span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>In a case towhich the provisos to clause (b) of sub-section (2) of section 72. Pakistan (1964) 16 DLR 114.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—S.80</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>. Roy (1951) 3 DLR 139.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—When thissection will apply.</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Section80 of the Railways Act will apply only when the different Railway systems runthough the same state.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Damages -claim for</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Lossoccurred over E.B. Railway while the goods were booked in Calcutta with E.I.Railway - Suit against E.B.Railway for loss does lie as there was no contractwith the latter for safe delivery, nor a privity of contract between the twoRailways.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Satya Ch. (Contra) — </span></b><span style='line-height:115%;Cambria","serif";'>The sovereign activity of the Crown stands absolutely on adifferent footing from the commercial function undertaken by the Crown and theState Railway is an organization standing on the same footing as any otherorganization of carriers. In respect of the commercial activities of the Crown nospecial privilege can be claimed so far as the suits for damages are concerned.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Itis not a question of one Sovereign State being the agent of another SovereignState. So there is a privity of contract between the consignor and theRailway of destination.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Independentlyof contract, in the case the E.B.
