(Expressing a contrary view)— The President’s Order 21 of 1962 in terms applies only to Judges who have retired or resigned their office but not to those who have been removed re from.</p><p>There is no warrant in the language employed in Order 21 of 1962 for extending its benefit to removed Judges in respect of relief from any undertaking or other constitutional disqualification to practice binding on them as a condition of service.</p><p>As to the necessity of enacting a statute like the Legal Practice Disqualification Ordinance 1962, the Chief Justice observed as follows:</p><p>‘It became common practice for ox-Judges to be I practicing in their own High Court, making submission where previously they made only pronounce. and if their submissions were subjected to constant criticism by their opponents at the bar, as well as from the Bench, this would necessarily pro. duce in the public mind a feeling that the position which these persons enjoyed and were under the law allowed, during their period on the Bench, was scarcely deserved by personal merit. Such a feeling, once it commenced, would tend to grow and eventually to develop into a large doubt in the public mind as to the efficacy of the entire system.</p><p><em>Government of Pakistan vs. Akhlaque Hussain (1965) 17 DLR (SC) 545.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2367	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Revenue Sales Act, 1859</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1964) 16 DLR 580, (1972) 24 DLR 24</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Revenue Sales </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Revenue Sales Act (XI of 1859)</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u> </u></strong></p><p><strong>Ss. 29, 37. Sale of an estate for arrears of revenue does not annul under tenures automatically but renders them voidable at the option of the purchaser.</strong></p><p>Purchaser can exercise his option of annulment by institution of suit, service of notice upon the under-tenure holders, by collecting rent from tenants or by any other overt act indicating a clear intention to annul and the intention must be made known to the under-tenure holders.</p><p>Santa Gopal Roy Choudhary vs. Md. Mohashwaruddin, (1964) 16 DLR 580.</p><p>—The under- tenure holder or his successor in interest may succeed on ground of adverse possession even inspite of annulment. Ibid.</p><p> </p><p><strong>S. 37 (4th exception): </strong>Dwelling house—For availing protection under 4th exception of section 37 of the Revenue Sales Act a dwelling house should be of permanent character but that does not mean that it must be a building or a structure of permanent build—Dwelling house includes cowshed.</p><p><em>Rahman Ali Vs. Upendra Lal Sarkar (1972) 24 DLR 24.</em></p><p>—Tanks and panborj, i.e., betel leaves plantation arc ‘protected interest’ within the meaning of 4th exception of section 37 of the Revenue Sales Act.   Ibid.</p><p><strong>—S. 37</strong>. Encumbrances, annulment of—No formal notice by the purchaser is required under the Revenue Sales Act to annual encumbrances. Ibid.</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2368	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Review</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1964) 16 DLR (SC) 655,  (1964) 16 DLR (SC) 712</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Review</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u><span style="line-height: 115%;">Review</span></u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><br/><u></u><u></u></p><p><strong>Review of a decision</strong>—</p><p>Any order passed on such review is without jurisdiction—when an appeal or revision against the decision itself was pending before a superior authority, and the law prohibits reviewing when an appeal or revision is pending. Question of knowledge or lack of knowledge about pendency of appeal or revision irrelevant, the bar to review being complete.</p><p><em>Ghulam Mohiud-Din Vs. C.S. Commr. Lahore, (1964) 16 DLR (SC) 655.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Review of an order passed in revision by an authority to which the power of revision was delegated— if permissible under law.</strong></p><p>Majority view (per S.A. Rahman and Hamoodur Rahman, 3.3.) was that such authority has no power review its own order. The power of review in this context cannot be regarded as ancillary to the revisional power conferred on the delegate. A power of review is a creature of the statute and it cannot be id that a delegate exercising revisional powers under sub-section (2) of section 20 of the Act has inherent power to review orders passed in his capacity as a delegate.</p><p><em>Mst. Zainab Khatoon Vs. Mian Ghulam Shabbir (1964) 16 DLR (SC) 712.</em></p><p> </p><p>Kaikaus, J. (differing from the majority view) expressed the opinion that such power of review by the sub-ordinate officer does exist.</p><p>His Lordship further held that there is an inherent power of review, that is, whoever has the authority to review it, without there being any specific provision.</p><p>The power to review an order goes with the power to pass the order whether one calls it an ancillary power or a power that accompanies or is inherent in the power to pass an order. Ibid.</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2369	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Rules of Business of Govt. of Bangladesh</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1981) 33 DLR 171, (1982) 34 DLR 120</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Rules of Business of Govt. of Bangladesh</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Rules of Business of Govt. of Bangladesh</u></strong></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Rule 4 clauses, I, II, III, IV and VII, The contents of these clauses of r. 4.</strong></p><p>Clause I of rule 4 of the Rules of Business says that no important policy decision shall be taken except with the approval of the President. Clause II of rule 4 says that no policy decision taken by the President shall be varied without the approval of the President. Clause ill of rule 4 says it shall be duty of the Minister to aid and advise the President in the formulation of policy. Clause IV of rule 4 says that a Minister shall remain responsible to the President for policy matters concerning the Ministry. Clause VII of rule 4 says that the Secretary shall be the official head of the Ministry and shall be responsible for its administration and discipline and for proper conduct of business assigned to it.</p><p><em>Shah Azharuddin Ahmed Vs. Government of Bangladesh (1981) 33 DLR 171.</em></p><p>—The President’s role is formulation of policy and making policy decisions— the Ministers act in advising the President in this presidential role. Ibid.</p><p> </p><p><strong>Rule 4, Clauses</strong> <strong>IV and VIII</strong></p><p>Ministers have no legal authority to visit any Government office to ensure attendance of the Government employees and to enforce disciplinary action, such as removing an employee from service— This will amount to undue interference without jurisdiction and abuse of authority. (Constitution of Bangladesh: Art 58(1) read with rule 4, clause IV &amp; VIII of Rules of Business of the Govt.)</p><p>The Minister remaining responsible for policy matters concerning the Ministry under Clause IV of rule 4 of the Rules of Business has no constitutional or legal authority to visit any office of the Government for specific enforcement of proper attendance of its employees and to initiate disciplinary action specifically against any particular Government servant by a specific direction in that regard; that will proper. amount to undue interference with the executive administration of the Government in excess of jurisdiction and abuse of authority.</p><p><em>Shah Azharuddin Ahmed, Vs. Government of Bangladesh (1981) 33 DLR 171.</em></p><p>—Minister paying surprise visit to the office which he has no lawful authority to do followed by an order retiring an officer from service having acted illegally and without lawful authority is liable to pay cost of the proceedings in Writ Petition to the panic officer whose retirement has been found illegal. Ibid.</p><p> </p><p><strong>Rules of Business—Sch. III item: 73- Where officer draws salary of Tk. 2100 and above.</strong></p><p>The petitioner is at officer of the Government drawing a salary in the scale of Tk. 2100-26(X). It was, therefore, necessary to place his case before the president as required under item 73 of Schedule-Ill of Rules of Business.</p><p><em>Salahuddin Khan Vs. Bangladesh (1982) 34 DLR 120.</em></p><p>—Delegation of power should be made in specific ms—Order of suspension cannot be maintained (Rules of Business. Sch. III; item 73.)</p><p>Whenever there is a question of delegation of r by one authority to another, it must be done specific and categorical terms and not impliedly a permissible to read it by necessary implication. particularly when the rights of others are involved. Ibid.</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2370	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Rules of the High Court of Judicature (VoI. I)</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 72</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Rules of the High Court</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Rules of the High Court of Judicature (VoI. I)</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p><strong>Chap. A r. 9 (Appendix IV).</strong></p><p>Rule 9 of Chapter A in Appendix IV to the Rules of the High Court of Judicature Vol. I pros that if at the hearing of the application the t is of opinion that any person who ought to been served with notice of the application has been so served, the Court may order that notice also be served on such person and adjourn the hearing upon such terms as the Court may consider.</p><p><em>Habibullah Khan Vs. Shah Azharuddin Ahmed and ors. (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 72.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Rule 9—</strong>Rule 9 clearly provides that if in the opinion of the Court the appellant ought to have been served with notice of the writ petition, and since no notice was served upon him, only course open to the Court was to adjourn the hearing and issue direction for service of the writ petition upon appellant. Ibid.</p><p>(Appendix IV) r. 15, Chap. A Procedure to be followed in awarding costs by initiating a proceeding suo motu after the disposal of the original petition. Ibid.</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2371	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Sale</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p align="center" style="text-align:center"><b><u><span style='line-height:115%;Cambria","serif";'>Sale</span></u></b></p><p align="center" style="text-align:center"><b><u><span style='line-height:115%;Cambria","serif";'><span style="text-decoration:none"><br/></span></span></u></b></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Sale-voidand voidable.</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Distinctionbetween a void sale and an illegal or irregular sale is that a void sale is anullity held absolutely without any jurisdiction or in contravention of apublic policy in which a person is sought to be affected by sale may proceed onthe basis that it had no existence and his right in the property standsunaffected.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Ifa sale takes place under the order of the court and does not observe theformalities provided for in the statute which give protection to an individual,who may waive them, the sale is an illegal or irregular one and it is voidableand not void.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Santosh Lal SahaVs. Dakhina Ranjan Chowdhury (1953) 5 DLR 81.</span></i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—The extreme contention that a sale in contravention of a statutory provision isa nullity or void is supported by neither principle nor authority.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Sale-purchase—</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Inthe field of compulsory acquisition of land such words as ‘sale’ and ‘purchase’are frequently used in connection with transaction by which the transfer ofownership in land takes place in the absence of mutual assent.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Ratu TaitoNalukuya Vs. Director of Lands. (1959) 11 DLR 81 (PC).</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Thediscovery of defect in title does not per se make a contract of sale void. <i>1953 PLR (Lah.) 689.</i></span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Contractof sale cannot be rescinded after execution of sale deed on the ground of adefect in the title unless a warranty was incorporated in the deed.          Ibid.</span></p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span> </div></div>
2372	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Sale of Goods Act, 1930</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p align="center" style="text-align:center"><b><u><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Sale ofGoods Act</span></u></b></p><p align="center" style="text-align:center"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>(III of1930)</span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 2(14).Specific goods.</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>“Specificgoods” according to the definition given in sub-section (14) of Section 2 ofthe Act, means “goods identified and agreed upon at the time a contract forsale is made”.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Ahmed AbdulGani Vs. Rahmania Trading (1958) 10 DLR 348=8 PLR (Dac.) 576.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 13.Buyer’s option.</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Buyer’soption either to waive the condition in a contract the breach of which entitleshim to treat the contract as repudiated or he may treat such a breach as breachof warranty and stick to the bargain with a right to claim damages.        Ibid.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Thesection does not contemplate the case of a seller failing to tender delivery ofgoods.      Ibid.</span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 13(1)(2):</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Buyer’soption of treating a breach of a condition in a contract as a breach ofwarranty. Ibid.</span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Sec.13(1)(2): </span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Bothsub-section (1) and the first part of sub-sec. (2) of section 13 are based onthe same principle which gives the buyer the option of treating a breach of acondition in a contract to be fulfilled by the seller as a breach of warranty.In the one case he exercises his option by express words and in the other lawpresumes exercise of the option from his conduct.       Ibid.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Fraud etc.,on a contract of sale</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Therewas no provision in the Sale of Goods Act bearing on the effect of fraud,misrepresentation, coercion and undue influence on a contract of sale.Therefore, the relevant provisions of the Contract</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Acton these questions continued to be applicable to contracts of sale despite theprovisions of section 13, Sale of Goods Act. That section also did not containany reference to cases of fraud, etc., and apparently contemplated such casesas involved a breach of condition, without fraud, misrepresentation and thelike- affecting the formation of the contract itself in its inception. If thusinterpreted, there was no difficulty in holding that section 19, Contract Act,could stand with section 13 of the Sale of Goods Act. The result was that incases of fraud and misrepresentation etc., vitiating the contract unless therewas a waiver on the part of the party affected, the right of reels ion was notlost.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Accordingly,the remedy of rescission of the contract was open to the respondent in thepresent case on the condition that <i>restitutionin integrum</i> took place in a just manner. <i>PLR. (1960) (WP) 524.</i></span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Sees. 32,33, 36(2)—Sellers were bound to make delivery within a reasonable time.</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Exceptthe term “f.o.r” and it’s necessary implication, there were no terms expressedin contract  fixing either the time fordelivery or the time for payment. It necessarily follows from the statutoryprovisions contained in sections 32, 35, 36(2) of the Act that the sellers werehound to make delivery within a reasonable time, subject to the feasibility ofobtaining wagons and the buyer was to make payment concurrently with thosedeliveries.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Tarani Ch.Gupta Chowdhury Vs. Jagannath Rice Mills (1951) 3 DLR 23.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 18.Effect of contract for sale on goods—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> For enforcement of such contract goods—imust be specific and in a deliverable state.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Inorder to pass title from the seller to the buyer goods must he specific and ina deliverable state. If these two conditions are not fulfilled then the titleto the goods does not pass by the contract.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Titleto the goods will pass from the seller to the buyer (irrespective of the timeof payment of price or the time of delivery) when there is unconditionalcontract for sale of goods, which are identified and agreed upon at the time ofthe contract and are in deliverable state.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Pak.Mercantile Corps. Vs. Madan Mohan Oil Mills (1966) 18 DLR 487.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Contract ofthe sale of moveable property</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Presumptionis that the purchaser has become the owner when the contract is made.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Ifproperty in the goods continued to vest in the owner, there could be noquestion of the hire-purchaser having a right to any part of the sale proceeds.Moreover, the goods in question being moves property, the ordinary presumptionwould be that she property in the apparatus passed to the allegedhire-purchaser when the contract was made, it being immaterial whether the timeof payment of the price was postponed beyond the date of the contract.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Section20 of the Sale of Goods Act embodies a principle which may be extended to covera case where there are terms in the contract which purport retain ownership inthe vendor until the fulfillment of a certain condition relating to the price,alongside with other conditions from which an equally clear conclusion may bedrawn that ownership in the odds became vested in the vendee upon the making ofthe contract.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Shewram DasVs. Arobinda Poddar (1961) 13 DIR (SC) 141.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 20</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>. Sale ofgoods affected not by free agreement between the parties, but under the ordersof the Government—Date of such sale is not the date when rods were deliveredbut the date when Government order were received and invoices delivered forgoods sold. </span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Sale-taxbecomes payable when invoices arc delivered and since the Pakistan GeneralSales-tax Act which imposes the liability to sale-tax came into force on 1448,no sales tax becomes due in respect of sales of goods for which invoices, inthe manner referred above, were delivered before 1.4.48.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Goodslegally passed to the defendant from the date of delivery of invoices thoughgoods were not actually delivered then.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>M/S Hanif vs. Mohini Mills (1964) 16 DLR 135.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>“Forre-submission as per instructions” explained—</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Afterreceipt of invoices by the defendant the latter sent back the same to theplaintiff with respect “for re-submission as per instructions” and it wasthereupon contended that the date of re-submission should be the date on whichthe invoices should be treated as being sent to the defendant.</span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Held:</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> Theexpression used in the letter “for resubmission as per instructions” does notconstitute a refusal, rather it means that the defendant accepted the goods hutthe invoices should have been submitted as per instructions given by thedefendant.         Ibid.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 20:</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> Goods inthe present case, the subject- matter of the suit, had been purchased and notmerely agreed to be purchased by the defendant. The mere fact that theplaintiff complained about procrastination of wcighment by the defendant doesnot change the nature of the transaction. In the present case the goodsremained with the seller after they were approved and sold and thereforenecessity was felt of satisfying the buyers that they had not been tamperedwith when they had remained in possession with the seller.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Messrs. AragLtd. V.s. Messrs. Muhammad Ismail, (1968) 20 DLR (WP) 242.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 34. Effectof part delivery of goods—</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Whena part delivery of the goods is made in progress of delivery of the whole, thefirst delivery will have the effect of passing the property in such goods asthe delivery of whole, hut the delivery of a part of the goods with anintention of severing it from the whole, does not operate as delivery of theremainder or in other words, does not pass any title in the remainder to thebuyer. The word “whole” in this section means the goods identified in terms ofsection 20 of the Act.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Hatu MallikVs. State (1966) 18 DLR 437.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 37(I).</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> Delivery oflesser quantity of goods—Buyer can either accept it or he can reject it-If heaccepts, he will have to pay for it at the contract rate. </span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Ahmed AbdulGani Vs. Rahmania Trading (1958) 10 DLR 348.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Itfollows that when the part which was not tendered previously is tenderedafterwards it cannot be referred back to any subsisting contract between thebuyer and the seller.      Ibid.</span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Secs. 37(1)and 38 (1)—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>When a part of the goods contracted to be sold is offered andaccepted by the buyer, he is not bound to accept the remaining part whenoffered later on.       Ibid.</span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 39:Provisions of the section explained—</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Section39 of the Sale of Goods Act merely contemplates that prima facie the sellerdischarges his duties as soon as he delivers the goods to a carrier for thepurpose of transmission to the buyer or he delivers the goods to a wharfingerfor safe custody. In such cases under section 39 of the Sale 01 Goods Act thebuyer may decline to treat the delivery to a common carrier or wharfinger as adelivery to the buyer himself. Section 39 of the Sale of Goods Act will assumeimportance if a dispute is raised with regard to passing of title from theseller to the buyer or if any risk is involved after the delivery of the goodsby the seller to a common carrier or wharfinger. In the present case no suchdispute has been raised by either party.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>RalliBrothers Vs. Abul Lais, (1973) 35 DLR 99.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Ss. 46 (1)(c) and 56 :</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> So far as the right of unpaid seller is concerned it is thequantum of damages for non-acceptance of goods property in which already passedto buyer—Measure of damages is the difference between the contract price antithe market price as prevailed on the date when non- acceptance took place.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Messrs AragLtd Vs. Messrs Muhammad Ismail (1968) 20 DLR (WP) 242.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 60“Anticipatory breach”—</span></b></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Section60 of the Sale of Goods Act avoids the difficulties wrapped up in the phrase“an anticipatory breach.”</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Tarain Ch. GuptaChowdhury Vs. Jagannalh Rice Mills (1951) 3 DLR 23.</span></i></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 61(2).Awarding of interest to a seller—No interest payable on damage for breach ofcontract.</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Sub-section(2) of section 61 of the Sale of Goods Act empowers the Court to award interestto seller for the price of his goods at such rate as it thinks fit. Under thissection a party, however, cannot claim interest on damages for breach of acontract.</span></p><p><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>A. Z. Co.Vs. S. Maula Bakhsh (1965) 17 DLR (SC) 405.</span></i></p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span> </div></div>
2373	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Sales Tax Act (III of 1951)</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1958) 10 DLR 46, (1967) 19 DLR 93, (1964) 16 DLR 514, (1966) 18 DLR 331, (1965) 17 DLR (SC) 157, (1958) 10 DLR 46, (1978) 30 DLR 226, (1967)19 DLR 592, (1969) 21 DLR (SC) 468, (1970) 22 DLR 798, (1965) 17 DLR (SC) 157,  (1978)30 DLR 226, (1966) 18 DLR 3</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Sales Tax </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><u>Sales Tax</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><u> </u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ship-owners not liable when tax paid for goods which were never imported.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Elerman and Busnell Steamship Vs. Shahidi Trading Corporation (1958) 10 DLR 46. </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><u>Sales Tax Act (III of 1951)</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><u> </u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">S. 2(11). ‘Manufacture’</span></strong>—Marking cloth after going through the process of dyeing, calendaring and marking—This constitutes “manufacturer of goods” and assessable to lax.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Messrs Muhammad &amp; Ahmed Co. Vs. Commissioner of Income Tax (1967) 19 DLR 93.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Period of limitation in regard to both the years 1954-55 and 1955-56 would be extended by 3 months.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The petitioner (a private limited company) in its returns for the year 1955-1956 filled under the Sales Tax Act, 1951 showed taxable sales at the amount a - Rs. 48182/-. The Sales Tax Officer acting under sec Lion 28 of the Act, by his order dated 31.5.60, fix the taxable sale at the amount of Rs. 232190/-.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The question that arose was: whether on account of the definition of the “year” in Finance Ordinance (XXV of 1960), four years mentioned in section 34 of the Income Tax Act would mean four years of 12 months each or three years of 12 months each and the year 1958-59 of 15 months.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In the present case, four years mentioned in section 28 of the Sales Tax Act began from the 1st of April, 1956, and before the period had run out the amendment to section 2(20) of the Act came into effect on the 31st of March, 1959.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Held</span></strong> : In this view of the matter the contention that since there is nothing in the Finance Ordinance to indicate that the amended provision would have retrospective effect the amendment cannot be pressed into service in the instant case, cannot be accepted.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The clear indication by introducing the two provisos to sections 2(2) and section 28 of the Sales x Act is that the period of limitation in regard to ii the years 1954-55 and 1955-56 would be extendeb by three months.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Hossain Brothers (Pak) Ltd Vs. Sales Tax Officer (1964) 16 DLR 514.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">S. 2 (12)—</span></strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sale tax is payable for batching oil which is a part of manufactured jute goods.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Commissioner of Income Tax vs. Amin Jute Mills Ltd. (1966) 18 DLR 331.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">S. 2(12) read with S. 27(1)—</span></strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">‘Partly manufactured goods’ explained—Paper cartons used while selling electric bulbs are not partly manufactured goods within the meaning of section 2(12) of the Sales Tax Act and hence the under section 27(I) of the Act cannot be claimed.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Bangladesh<em> Lamps Ltd. Vs. Commr. S. Tax  27 DLR 473.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">S. 3.Tax on manufactured or produced goods—</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">So far as the manufactured or produced goods are concerned the sales tax becomes payable only when goods are delivered to the purchaser or when the property in the goods passes to the purchaser.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Noorani Cotton Corporation Vs. Sales Tax Officer (1965) 17 DLR (SC) 157.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Secs. 3 &amp; 37—Payment of sales-tax when not payable.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Payment of sales-tax when the same was not payable under the law relating to sales tax could not be said to be a disbursement so as to be recoverable in terms of the contract between the parties. The goods not having been imported at all, no sales tax was payable on the same and an improper payment cannot constitute disbursement so as to entitle the plaintiff to recover the same.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Ellerman and Busnull Steamship vs. Shahidi Trading Corporation (1958) 10 DLR 46.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The fact that the carriers did not object to the payment of the import duty does not take away any right which the carriers may have under the law to object to the payment of sales-tax.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">For satisfaction of the Sales-Tax Officer as to excess payment of sales tax in respect of goods short landed in order that ret und of such excess may be allowed to the consignee, production of short landing certificate is not indispensably necessary. Such satisfaction can he obtained by any other evidence. Ibid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">S. 3(a).</span></strong> [See under section 2(11) in case of Messrs Muhammad &amp; Ahmed Co. vs. <em>Commissioner of Income Tax in, (1967) 19 DLR 93 above.</em>]</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">S. 3(1)(b)</span></strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> Fire extinguishing plant is used to put out fire. Safety devices are parts of the machinery of manufacturing plant.-Such plants comes under exemption clause.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Machineries used for industrial process in the modern times seem to have built-in safety devices. It is not disputed that this fire extinguishing plant is a modern device for extinguishing fire by the jute manufacturers.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Commissioner of Sales Tax, Vs. Amin Jute Mills Lid. (1978) 30 DLR 226.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">S. 3(5).</span></strong> Provisions of Sea Customs Act regarding clearance, shipping, removal of goods and securing payment of tax have been incorporated in the Sales Tax Act, but provisions as regards assessment or re-assessment of tax has not been so incorporated.Customs Officers not competent to make assessment or reassessment for rectification under section 3(5).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Usmania Glass Sheet Factory Ltd. s. Assistant collector of Customs (1967)19 DLR 592.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Customs Officers’ power exercisable in regard to matters mentioned in section 3(5) in Sales Tax Act—Customs Officers have no power for reassessment of tax by way of rectification of mistake under section 3(5) of the Sales Tax Act.   Ibid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Section 3(5) provides that the tax shall be paid on importation or exportation as the case may be “as provided hereunder”.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The point of Lime as to when the tax is realizable is of great importance and ordinarily should not be departed from except under circumstances of fraud, collusion or mistake. ibid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">S. 3(5) : </span></strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Laws which were in operation before independence in Tribal Areas did not lapse with the Independence Act of 1947 but continued even after that.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The Custom Authorities seized a truck-load of smuggled goods in the tribal area and proceeded against the accused for violating the provisions of section 5(1) of the Land Customs Act, Section 167 (8) (36) and (81) of the Sea Customs Act and section 3(s) of the Sales Tax Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">On a writ petition, the High Court of West Pakistan held the seizure illegal and in an appeal before the Supreme Court (by the State) question arose whether the aforesaid laws which were in operation in tribal areas before independence were still in operation after the coming into force of the Indian Independence Act of 1947.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Held :</span></strong> The laws of a state or territory do nor disappear by a change in its sovereignty. Law governing or regulating the relations, the rights and obligations of the residents of a acceding territory do not lapse by a mere change in the sovereignty but continues to remain operative until changed by a competent authority.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Moreover, sections 8 and 9 of the Indian Independence Act, 1947 extended the power of the Governor-General to tribal areas and in exercise of that power the Governor-General issued Order Nos. 5 and 6 of 1949 to provide for the accession of tribal areas to the territories of Pakistan arid the governance thereof.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Under the Constitution of 1956, by sub-article (2) of Article I the tribal areas which in 1955 were incorporated in the territories of the Province of West Pakistan also became territories of Pakistan but the nomenclature was altered and they were to be known as ‘special area’.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Superintendent, Land Customs Vs. Zewar Khan (1969) 21 DLR (SC) 468.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">S. 3(6)(d) :</span></strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> Goods manufactured for manufacturing some other articles though itself may be finished goods—Not liable to taxation.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Latif Bawani Jute Mitts Ltd. Vs. The Sales Tax Officer (1970) 22 DLR 798.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—S. 3(6)(d).</span></strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> <strong>Sale of ‘partly manufactured goods’ to a manufacturer is not liable to tax.</strong></span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Under section 3(6)(d) the Sales Tax Officer may determine the value for the tax in a case where the goods are kept for use by the manufacturer and such a transaction is to be regarded as a sale.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Noorani Cotton Corp. Vs. Sales Tax Officer (1965) 17 DLR (SC) 157.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">S. 4. Sale of ‘partly manufactured goods’ to a manufacturer is not liable to tax.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">What is the device adopted for ensuring that sales-tax is paid only at one stage in spite of what is contained in the charging section making all manufactured goods when they go to the purchaser liable to the payment of tax?</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The device adopted as will appear from section 4, is that the sale of “partly manufactured goods” to a manufacturer is not liable to the charge of tax.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The provision in section 4 is that the sale of. goods by a licensed manufacturer to another licensed manufacturer of partly manufactured goods is not liable to the incidence of tax.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Provisions contained in section 4 arc a sufficient guarantee that the tax will be paid only with respect to the last stage of manufacture of goods.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In a case where a manufactured article into which partly manufactured goods arc to be incorporated is for some reason not liable to the payment of sales tax, in such a case no sales tax will need be paid at all.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Noorani Cotton Corporation vs. Sales Tax Officer (1965) 17 DLR (SC) 157.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—Sec. 4</span></strong>. refers to articles which arc to be manufactured after importing of part of goods. Exemption against liability to pay u/s. 3(I)(b) is sought on the basis of Notification of 5-12-62. Clause (I) of this notification shows that exemption is granted for machinery of all sorts operated by power of any description as is used in industrial process. It is the admitted position that Hydrant Sprinkler Plant is operated by power and it is erected in every part of a jute mill and is controlled centrally as modem safety device for extinguishing fire.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">commissioner Sales Tax Vs. Amin Jute Mills (1978)30 DLR 226.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">S 4(a). Tax when not payable in respect of partly manufactured goods</span></strong>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Section 4 (a) of the Sales Tax lays down that the tax will not be payable if the goods are sold by one licensed manufacturer to another licensed manufacturer provided the goods are “partly manufactured goods”.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Commissioner of Income Tax vs. Amin Jute Mills Ltd. (1966) 18 DLR 331</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Secs. 4(b) and 17</span></strong>. Exemption from pay- merit of sales-tax as provided under section 4(b) of the S.T. Act— When can be claimed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Held</span></strong>: Import of raw materials for using in the manufacture of washing soap must be by a licensed manufacturer, Section 4(b) speaks about goods imported by a licensed manufacturer. Similarly section 17(I) speaks about purchases of partly manufactured goods by a licensed manufacturer.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Exemptions as contemplated in section 4(b) and the remedy as provided in section 27(I) are not available to the assessed because he was not a “licensed manufacturer” when partly manufactured goods were imported.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Messer. Haji Noor Ali Sowdagar Vs. Commissioner of Sales Tax (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 339.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">S. 5(1):</span></strong> Sales Tax Act, 1951 visualized therein an Income-tax Officer under the Income-lax Act, 1922 to be a Sales Tax Officer for the purpose of the Act. By a subsequent amendment of the Income-Lax Act, 1922. Examining Officer was also included in the definition of the Income-tax Officer as given in the Income-tax Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Haji Nazimuddin Ltd. Amanullah Vs. The Corm. of Sales Tax, Dacca Zone (1970) 22 DLR 527.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—An Income-lax Officer and others named in section 5(1) is entitled to exercise the powers of a Sales Tax Officer. By an amendment effected in 1963 in the Income-tax Act, an Examining Officer was also made an Income-tax Officer. Ibid</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—</span></strong> <strong>S. 7, Edible oil, what edible oil is exempt</strong> <strong>from sale tax.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Such edible oils are exempt from payment of sales-tax as are not included within “vegetable products” in entry 23 of the Notification No. 9 of the Government under section 7 of the Sales Tax Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Noorani Cotton Corp. Vs. Sales Tax Officer (1965) 17 DLR (SC) 157</span></em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Products of iron foundries—Which are the items in respect of which sales tax was assessed by the Sales Tax Officer were:</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">C.I. (Cast Iron) Pans; Rice Huller Shells; Hand pumps, Hand pump Plungers, Rain Water Pipes; Hamon Dastan; Jalkhati Structural works.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The reason given by the Sales Tax Authority was that the above items cannon be termed a product of iron foundries and steam and hammer works.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Held:</span></strong> C.I. Pans, Rain water Pipes; Haman Dastan; Jalkhati arc certainly foundry products, as after the process of casting is done nothing else remains to be done for the completion of the manufacture of these articles.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Mansur Engineering Works Ltd. vs. Commissioner of Income Tax (1967) 19 DLR 494.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—S. 7:</span></strong> Exemption of tax payment under section 7 under the order of the Government is discretionary with the Government—subsequently such exemption can, in the judgment of the Government, be withdrawn.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Baby Biscuit Co. vs. Sales Tax Officer (1976) 28 DLR 463.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—S. 7:</span></strong> Exemption granted under section 7 of the Act applied to the gunny bags exported by the petitioners and this exemption covered also “other jute manufactures” including hessian or sacking cloth that went into the making of the gunny bags.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Latif Bawany Jute Mills Ltd. Vs. The Sales Tax Officer (1970)22 DLR 798.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Ss. 7 &amp; 8(2): The provision of these two sections do not amount to delegated legislation to the executive— Conditional legislation permissible under certain circumstances.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It was contended that the power given under sections 7 and 8(2) of the Sales Tax Act to the Executive Government amounts to conferment of delegated legislation to the Executive as the Executive Government is given the right to exempt any good or class of goods or any person or class of persons from Lax and as such it amounts virtually to handing over all the power of imposing the sales tax to the executive Government and therefore these sections arc ultra vires.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It was further contended that the power given under these sections permit discrimination between goods and goods, persons and persons and classes of persons.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Held:</span></strong> The Act envisages that in the matter of imposition of sales Lax there cannot be a right rule as to the rates of tax in regard to certain classes of goods and the exemption to be granted to goods which come within the purview of the Act: If the relevant provisions are considered, it will be evident that the legislature felt that, in regard to the above two matters, decision will be dependent upon the trade conditions prevailing in the country at a given time. It is because of this that wide powers in regard to the rates of tax exemption have been given to the Central Government. In this view of the matter, ii. Cannot be said that the provisions under attack amount to delegated legislation and arc therefore ultra vires.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Where it is not possible for the Legislature to anticipate the circumstance under which exemption can be granted (in regard to payment of sales tax) discretion had to be left to the Executive Government to take decisions according to the exigencies of trade, and in the absence of any clear proof that the discretion has been abused it is not possible to accept the contention that the impugned provisions are ultra vires as delegated legislation or violative of the 15th Fundamental Right guaranteed by the Constitution.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Tiger Wire Products Ltd. vs. Sales Tax Officer (1965) 17 DLR 237.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">S. 8(2):</span></strong> For determining total turnover of any manufacturer, turnover of exempted goods cannot be added to turnover of unexempted goods for the purpose of Notification No. 10 issued under section 8(2) of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Commissioner of Income Tax, E.Pak. Vs. M/s. Ayurvedic Pharmacy Ltd., (1970) 22 DLR (SC) 179.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Ss. 10 and 28</span></strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> Assessment year 1957-58. — The order of assessment dated June, 1961, two years having elapsed from the assessment year, section applicable is section 28 and not section 10.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Relevant assessment year is 1957-58, and a notice was issued on the Assessee on 1.5.61 and thereafter the assessment order made on 26.6.61 under section 10 of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The question which was referred under section 17(1) of the Sales Tax Act was in the following terms</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">“Whether in the circumstances of the case issue of a notice under section 28 of the Sales Tax Act, 1951 was necessary for initiation of the proceedings for assessment year 1957-58 after the expiry of that year?”</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The question as framed, however, is whether the issue of a notice was necessary for initiation of proceedings for assessment for the year 1957-58, after the expiry of that year. It has been seen that the assassinate has been admittedly made under section 10(4) and that assessment can be made in this case only under section 28 of the Sales Tax Act and that a notice should have been issued, proceedings conducted, and an enquiry held, as contemplated in section 28 as distinguished from section 10 of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Absence of enquiry is prejudicial to the interest of an Assessee.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Messrs. Ata Hussain Khan Ltd. vs. Commissioner of Income Tax, (1968) 20 DLR 567.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Goods in the present case not liable to sales tax—</strong>The expression “hammer work” is of wide connotation. It is not the name of any specific manufactured commodity. It must, therefore, mean products of a manufacturing process where the use of the hammer is a dominant factor.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The water tanks in question were made with C.I. iron sheets by a manual process of hammering and as such the said tanks are exempt from sales tax as it comes within the description as given in the Notification 9, dated 27th June, 1951.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Commissioner of Income-tax Vs. M/S Ameer Bux Metal Industries, (1968) 20 DLR 592.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 12: </strong>Recovery of sales tax or penalty from individual partner of unregistered firm without service of demand notice on him not legal.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Aswab Ali Vs. Commissioner of Income-Tax (1965) 17 DLR</em><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> <em>90.</em></span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 12A: </strong>Section 12A is <em>ultra vires</em> of 1962 Constitution inasmuch it imposes tax on tax which the central Legislature had the authority to enact.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sree Gobinda Oil Mills Vs. T.R. Officer (1977) 29 DLR 341.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 14 </strong>: Notwithstanding provisions of appeal and in the Sea Customs Act and Sales Tax Act, in case where it is found that relief contemplated by deference such appeal not equally effective, efficacious and inexpensive, the affected party can come for relief under Art. 98.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">M/S</span></em> <em>Usmania Glass Sheet Factory Ltd. Vs. Assistant Collector of Customs (1967) 19 DLR 592.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 28, 29:</strong> Section 29 does not refer to the cc of escaped assessment for which the appropriate section is section 28.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Specific provision has been made for issuance of notice for escaped assessment under the provisions of section 28 of the Sales Tax Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Commr. Of I. T. Ctg. Vs. Consolidated Tea (1978) 30 DLR 226.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 29: </strong>Section 29 is applicable to a person who is not a licensed manufacturer.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Commissioner of Sale Tax Vs. Amir Jute Mills. (1978) 30 DLR 226.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 30A </strong>: Expression “mistake apparent on the face of the record” explained.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The expression “Mistake apparent on the face of the record” has been accepted to mean a patent error or an error which is self-evident on the face of the record and does not require argument or evidence or a long drawn process to establish it.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Ganesh Oil Mills Vs. Commissioner of Income Tax 56 (1979) 31 DLR (AD) 56.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 30(1) </strong>: Section 30(1) permits rectification of mistake apparent on the face of the record within 4 years from the dale of the order—Mistake discovered beyond 4 years, section 30(1) not applicable. Ibid.</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2374	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Sea Customs Act, 1878</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>   (1958) 10 DLR (SC) 122, (1965) 17 DLR 146, (1974) 26 DLR 224, (1958) 10 DLR 258, (1968) 20 DLR 1136, (1962) 14 DLR 565, (1959) 11 DLR (SC) 384, (1967) 19 DLR 592, (1959) 11 DLR (SC) 384,  (1907) 19 DLR (SC) 157, (1967) 19 DLR 592,  (1968) 20 DLR 549, (1</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Sea Customs</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u> </u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Sea Customs Act (VIII of 1878)</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p><strong>S. 19 : </strong>‘Across any customs frontier’ —Apply to goods taken from West Pakistan to East Pakistan by air.</p><p><em>Fakir Mohd. Panjabi Vs. Faderation of Pak. (1958) 10 DLR (SC) 122.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>S. 19 : </strong>“Across any customs frontier”—</p><p>Indian film when taken from East Pakistan to West Pakistan, whether is taken out of Pakistan across any customs frontier.</p><p>Having regard to the (decision of the Supreme Court precisely on this question in the case of Fakir Muhammad Punjabi Vs. Federation of Pakistan (1958) 10 DLR(SC) 122 it must be held that under section 19 of the Sea Customs Act any one by taking anything from East Pakistan to West Pakistan by air takes it out of Pakistan across any customs frontier as defined by the Central Government.</p><p><em>M/s. Salimar Pictures Vs. Assessing Officer (1965) 17 DLR 146.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Ss. 19, 167 (8) :</strong> Unless prohibition or restriction in regard to importation of any particular goods is notified under sec. 19 of the Sea Customs Act importation of such goods cannot be held illegal merely by virtue of a prohibition contained in a circular issued by a Government Department.</p><p><em>Nabil Hossain V. Collector of Customs (1974) 26 DLR 224.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>S. 20:</strong> Liability to pay import duty under the provisions of the Sea Customs Act depends upon the inward entry, i.e., on the goods entering the port and the rates of duty shall be those that arc in force on the date of landing.</p><p>The word ‘final’ in ‘final inward entry’ in paragraph 6 of the General Manual connotes that such entry should be for fulfilling the purpose for which the ship came to the port, that is, for (discharge of the cargo. (In the present case, the final entry of the ship was effected on 19-849 and not on 29-7-49 and therefore, import duty on cotton yarn having been lifted on 17-8-49, the plaintiff’s goods are not liable to assessment of import duty).</p><p><em>Federation of Pak Vs. Dawood Corporation (1958) 10 DLR 258.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>S. 23A (2)(b)</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> : Failure to apply for repayment of customs-duties within the period specified by the customs authority in terms of section 23(A)(2)(b) operates as a forfeiture of the right to claim the repayment.</span></p><p>After the Customs Authority has issued a clearance order, there is nothing further to be done by the Customs Authority. 11 after that the petitioner does not remove the goods from the warehouse of the jetty which belongs i.e. the Port Authorities and chooses to pay demurrage or makes some other arrangement with the Port Authorities for stocking the consignment in the Port’s warehouse the Customs Authorities cannot be held liable.</p><p>The expression “within three months from the clearance of the materials”, occurring in clause(iv) of the impugned S.R.O. relates to the physical clearance of the goods from the customs warehouse. The clause, relates to the date on which the customs duty was paid and the clearance order was given by the Customs Authorities. The three months period mentioned in clause (iv) of the impugned S.R.O. means within three months from the date the customs duty was paid and clearance order was given by the Customs Authority for the consignment.</p><p><em>E. P. Lamps Ltd. Vs. Pakistan represented by the Secretary, Ministry of Finance. (1968) 20 DLR 1136</em>.</p><p> </p><p><strong>S. 30</strong> : Net price ascertained in this country cannot be the basis of the conviction on a charge of filing untrue statement-The price prevailing in the country of origin shall have to be established for such a conviction.</p><p>The order of parties under sections 167 (913) and 167 (8) was sought to be justified on the basis of materials obtained after enquiry under section 30 of the Sea Customs Act. It has been said that enquiries revealed that identical goods were sold by the said supplier at the rate of 1.51 dollars per pound and therefore the statement of the petitioner in the declaration that he purchased the disputed consignment at the rate of 51 cents per pound was fraudulent and therefore attracted the provisions of section 167(9B) and 167(8).</p><p><strong>Held:</strong> The petitioner did not get any opportunity to controvert the materials on which reliance was placed for holding that he was guilty of untrue statement in regard to the value of the imported goods; in other words, he was denied a fair hearing.</p><p>The normal price ascertained on the basis of the prevailing price in this country at the relevant time, though sufficient for assessing the amount of customs duties, cannot furnish proof sufficient to bring home a charge of untrue statement under section 30 so as to justify conviction under section 167(9B)or prove that the invoice had been deliberately undervalued so as to bring the petitioner within the mischief of section 167(8) of the Sea Customs Act. Such charge cannot be established otherwise than by furnishing proof of the correct or prevailing commercial price in the country of origin at the time of import.</p><p><em>OKM Bawaney Vs. Assist. Collector of Customs (1962) 14 DLR 565.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>S. 30: </strong>Mis-statement of price in his invoice by an importer can only be established by showing the actual price in the country of origin and not otherwise—Charge for untrue statement cannot be established of the basis of ‘normal price’ under section 30.</p><p><em>M/s. Eastern Rice Syndicate Vs. Central Board of Revenue (1959) 11 DLR (SC) 384.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>S. 39 </strong>: customs officers under section 39 cannot realise rehabilitation tax.</p><p><em>Usmania Glass Sheet Factory Vs. Asstt. Collector of Customs (1967) 19 DLR 592.</em></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong> —S. 39 </strong>: <strong>Untrue—what the word really means.</strong> The word ‘untrue’ in section 39 of the Sea Customs Act carries the sense of falsity to the knowledge of the person concerned. Thus, upon a point of mere valuation, if a declaration is made by such a person which on enquiry the customs authorities find to be too low, that will not be by itself sufficient to prove that the declaration was false to the knowledge of the maker, but it would be necessary also to establish that at the time when he made the declaration he was in possession of facts from which the necessary inference would be that the value declared by him was too low and that the value which be ought to declare was the same as that subsequently ascertained  by the customs authorities.</p><p><em>M/s. Eastern Rice Syndicate Vs. Central Board of Revenue (1959) 11 DLR (SC) 384.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>— Recording a finding about guilty knowledge, not mandatory.</strong></p><p><strong>S. A. Rahman, J</strong>. (Cornelius, C.J. agreeing) The High Court, in the present case seems to have thought that unless the Customs Collector had recorded an express finding that the person concerned bed guilty knowledge of the false declarations made i the relevant documents, no penal action could be taken against them.</p><p>The Collector need not have stated in so many words that the false statements were made in the relevant documents, consciously and deliberately by the respondents. It is sufficient if the Collector recorded findings of fact, from which such an inference necessarily followed.</p><p><em>Pakistan Vs. Hardcastle Waud (Pak.) Ltd. (1907) 19 DLR (SC) 157.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>S. 39: Customs Officers under section 39 cannot realise rehabilitation tax—</strong></p><p>The Rehabilitation Rules, 1964 provides that rehabilitation tax shall be assessed and collected by the officers empowered to assess and collect sales tax. Rule 4 provides that the provision of Sales Tax Act, and the Sales Tax Rules will apply to the assessment and collection of rehabilitation tax in the same way as is applicable in the case of sales tax. Therefore if in the absence of a notification under section (5)(2) of the Sale Tax Act a Customs Officer could not resort to the proceedings for rectification of mistaken or escaped assessment for the levy of sales tax under section 39 of the Sea Customs Act, he could not do the same for the realization of the rehabilitation tax as well.</p><p><em>M/s. Usmania Glass Sheet Factory Ltd. Vs. Asst. Collector of Customs (1967) 19 DLR 592.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>S. 39(2) :</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> Declaring a consign of imported goods a defaulter with attendant penal consequences without giving him an opportunity of being heard offends against the principle of natural justice—Conditions which need be fulfilled under section 39(2).</span></p><p>In order to proceed under section 39(2) of the Sea Customs Act the following four essential conditions must be fulfilled:</p><p>(i) A person delivers declaration or other document to an officer of Customs in connection with any matter of customs;</p><p>(ii) Such document, etc., is untrue in any material particulars;</p><p>(iii) By reason of such document or by reason of collusion, the full amount of customs or charge payable is not paid; and</p><p>The demand of the said duty or charge payable must be made within three years from the relevant date.</p><p>The contention on behalf of the Customs Authority that they were not obliged under the Sea Customs Act to afford such opportunity to the petitioner is untenable.</p><p><em>Md. Sona Mea Vs. Collector of Customs, (1968) 20 DLR 549.</em></p><p><em> </em></p><p><strong>S. 39(3): </strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Customs Officers power exercisable in regard to matters mentioned in section 3(5) in Act—Customs officers have no power for reassessment of tax by way of rectification of mistakes under section 3(5) of the Sales Tax Act.</span></p><p><em>Usmania Glass Sheet Factory Vs. Assit. Collector of Customs (1967) 19 DLR 592.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>—Ss. 39 &amp; 40 </strong>Customs Authorities realised extra duty from the importer not within months as required by section 39(2) but long after months was over—Importer applied for refund also not within 3 months as required by section 40 but after that period—Importers suit held barred by law.</p><p>Extra duty paid in this case was really assessable and the importer paying it even without any demand from customs authorities, cannot get refund of</p><p><em>M/s Mia Brothers Vs. Pakistan (1967)19 DLR 1</em>.</p><p> </p><p>—Customs authority demanded payment of furthe duty on imported paper from the importer—Section 39 authorized such demand where due to in advertence, error or misconstruction full customs duty was not originally charged—Such demand has to be made within 3 months’ time from the date of original assessment—Demand in the present case was made (and also paid by the importer) long after the expiry of 3 months. Extra-duty paid was actally payable under the Customs law, but the importer (plaintiff) took the plea that the demand for payment not having been made within 3 months’ time limit the extra amount paid was refundable.</p><p><strong>Held:</strong> Plaintiff’s suit is barred by section 40, since it requires that such claim must be made within 3 months from the date of payment and since the plaintiff’s claim is not made within 3 months, it is barred.</p><p><em>M/s. Mia Brothers Vs. Pakistan (1967) 19 DLR 1.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>S. 64(c)(d) </strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">: Any steps by a Ships agent in a suit for damages against the’ Ship’s owner not only binds the agent but also the owner of the ship under clauses (c) and (d) of section 64 of the Sea Customs Act.</span></p><p><em>Seafarers Inc. Vs. Province of East Pakistan</em> <em>(1968) 20 DLR (SC) 225.</em></p><p> </p><p><strong>S. 64(d) </strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">: Liability for damage on short delivery of goods—ship’s agent, liable—Voyage charter, when charter is a voyage charter. </span></p><p>The voyage charter differs from a time charter primarily in that it is a contract to carry specified goods on a defined voyage, the remuneration of the ship-owner being freight.</p><p><em>Mackinnon Mackenzie &amp; Co.Vs. M/S Abdul Rahman, Abdul Gani (1956) 8 DLR 349.</em></p><p>—If the charter is a voyage charter ownership of ship remains with the owner thereof and full possession, control and responsibilities of carrier lies with him and not with charterer. Ibid.</p><p>—In a voyage charter the ownership of the vessel remains with the owner of the ship and all responsibilities as a carrier lies with him. When the agent of the ship’s owner signs a declaration under section 64(d) of the Sea Customs Act and there is a short delivery and loss of goods to the consignor the liability for the loss is that of the owner of the ship and as such of his agent.   Ibid</p><p>—The liability under a declaration made under section 64(d) of the Sea Customs Act does not arise from the fact of declaration itself but from the fact the declarant is the ship’s agent. Ibid</p><p> </p><p><strong>Agent’s liability to be sued for damages limited</strong></p><p>It was argued that the second portion of 64(d) of Sea Customs Act casts a statutory duty upon the agent to meet the liability and as such the suit is maintainable against at least the agent of the Shipping Company.</p><p><strong>Held: </strong>Before the agent can be made liable for any claim the owner must establish the claim, that is to say, there must be adjudication on the claim, where the claim is not admitted. Here obviously the claim is not admitted. And for the purpose of adjudication the owner of the goods must obtain a decree from a Court in England. Let the owner do so then the question of maintainability of the suit would be considered as against the agent.</p><p><em>British India Steam Navigation Vs. M.A. Wadud (1968) 20 DLR 367.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2375	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Sea Customs Act, 1878</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1962) 14 DLR 297, (1964) 16 DLR (WP) 165, (1978) 30 DLR 219, (1959) 11 DLR (SC) 384, (1959)11 DLR (SC) 59,  (1967) 19 DLR (SC) 472, (1969) 21 DLR (SC) 408, (1979) 31 DLR (AD) 60, (1967) 19 DLR (SC) 157, (1978) 30 DLR (SC) 226, (1979) 31 DLR 306, (1962) </p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Sea Customs </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><u>Sea Customs Act (VIII of 1878) </u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 167 :</strong> Whenever a duty is cast upon any Tribunal to exercise judicial or quasi-judicial function, it becomes incumbent upon such Tribunal or body to t in accordance with well recognized principles of natural justice which also postulates that, if a penalty imposed upon a person or his rights are invaded upon. he should be given a fair hearing. It becomes incumbent upon such Tribunal or body to confer a proper opportunity to such a person in order to enable him to meet the case against him.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Osman Abdul Karim Bawaney Vs. Collector of Customs (1962) 14 DLR 297.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Power of confiscation under the Act vests in the Custom Authorities and not in a Magistrate -Magistrate’s power is derived from section 523, Cr.P.Code.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Assistant Director of Customs Vs. Muhd. Afzal Khan (1964) 16 DLR (WP) 165.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—S. 167</strong> of S.C. Act allows confiscation while 5.523 of the Cr. P. Code empower return of goods to the rightful owner.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Jogesh Chandra Vs. Bangladesh (1978) 30 DLR 219.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 167 (8):</strong> Customs authorities’ enormous power of imposing penalties deserves careful and fair exercise of the same.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>M/s. Eastern Rice Syndicate Vs.. Central Board of Revenue (1959) 11 DLR (SC) 384.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Possession simpliciter not an offence.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Item (8) of section 167 was aimed at the suppression of illegal import or export or attempts to commit such an offence or to evade payment of the duty leviable on the goods in question. The words “such goods shall be liable to confiscation” in the penalties column could only refer to goods which had been the subject of an offence of that character by an importer or exporter or his abetter or agent. The mere finding of goods that may have been initially brought into the country against a prohibition or restriction without paying the necessary duty, in the hands of an innocent transferee, was within the mischief of section 167(8).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Federation of Pakistan Vs. Sardar Ali (1959)11 DLR (SC) 59</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Ss.167(8) &amp; 167(9B).</strong> [See under section 30 in the case. of AKM Bawaney Vs. Assistant Collector of Customs, in 14 DLR 565 above.]</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—S. 167(8)(81).</strong> Gold in Pakistan existed from ancient times—A conclusion by the Assayer that gold seized being of higher fineness must be held to be smuggled is wrong.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Messers S. A. Haroon Vs. Collector of Customs, Karachi (1967) 19 DLR (SC) 472.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Allegation that gold had been imported is not sufficient—Party is entitled to rebut the report of the Assayer. Ibid</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—S.167(8)(36) and (81)</strong> : Laws which were in operation before independence in Tribal Areas did not lapse with the Independence Act of 1947 but continued even after that.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The laws of a State or territory do not disappear by a change in its sovereignty.
