Laws governing or regulating the relations, the rights and obligations of the residents of a ceding or acceding territory do not lapse by a mere change in the sovereignty but continue to remain operative until changed by a competent authority.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Under the Constitution of 1956, by sub-article (2) of Article I the tribal areas which in 1955 were incorporated in the territories of Pakistan but the nomenclature was altered and they were to be known as ‘special areas’.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The tribal areas, therefore, became part of the territories of Pakistan. The Sea Customs Act, the Land Customs Act and section 5 of the Tariff Act, which had been made applicable to the tribal areas therefore, continued to apply in those areas and never lapsed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Tribal areas were never a part of British-India nevertheless the Crown had acquired jurisdiction therein by grants, usages, sufferances, etc., in the same manner as if the Crown had acquired that jurisdiction by the cession or conquest of territory.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Superintendent Vs. Zewar Khan, (1969) 21 DLR (SC) 408.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.167(8)(b)—</strong>In violation of the permit giving the license-holder authority to import various items of goods of different description for setting up a cold storage and Ice plant mentioning the amount as against each item to be imported when the importer imported two items for Rs.2 19,000/- whereas under the license- permit the amount allocated for import of these item was Rs.6000/- the license holder was guilty under section 167(8)(b) and the confiscation of these items valid in law.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Collector of Customs Vs. Shamsur Rahman (1979) 31 DLR (AD) 60.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.167 (37-B).</strong> The language of section 167(37 B) suggests that this is a case of absolute statutory liability —unlike the provision of section 39 which requires that the statement should be untrue with knowledge.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Pakistan Vs. Hardcastle Waud (Pak.) Ltd. (1967) 19 DLR (SC) 157. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Item 37-B of the section does not create an offence of absolute liability—Mens rea essential. (H. Rahman, J. disagreeing.) Ibid</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.167 (9B)—</strong>Such goods in section 167(9B) mean goods which are liable to be confiscated u/s. 39 of the Act when they have arrived at the port.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Collector of Customs Vs. Shafiullah (1978) 30 DLR (SC) 226.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 167(17)</strong>—Nothing in the section to support the view that goods found on board a vessel must be measured on the ship itself.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In first part of the section the words “found on board” means goods actually and physically existing on board the vessel. This part refers to the cases where the goods shown in the import manifest are lost or are none existing. But so far as the second part is concerned, the section does not refer to any place of measurement and there is nothing in the section to indicate that measurement must Sc taken on board only and nowhere else.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The proper time and place of actual measurement according to common sense should be place where the oil is finally discharged.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Hegge &amp; Co. Vs. Assistant Collector of Customs (1979) 31 DLR 306.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—No duty cast on the customs authority to serve notice on the consignee or shipping agent before measurement of the goods. Ibid</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.167 (81): Presumption as to payment of custom duty—When foreign goods are sold in open market.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The ordinary method of import of goods from outside into Pakistan is that they come through the customs barrier and the duty payable is in fact paid. The presumption, therefore, with respect to any goods which may be sold in the open market, in the absence of an indication to the contrary, would be that the duty has been paid on them.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Pakistan Vs. Kazi Zinuddin (1962) 14 DLR (SC) 244.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Possession of banned goods is an offence—Date of import not relevant</strong>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Collector taking action under section 167(81), even though not a judicial tribunal, and not bound by rules of evidence and not authorized to administer oath to witnesses, yet should not act arbitrarily, the proceedings in such cases being of judicial or quasi- judicial character.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Collector of Customs, Karachi Vs. Haji Usman, Haji Gani (1959) 11 DLR (SC) 200 (217-218)</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The phrase ‘for the time being’, occurring in item (81), mean that at the time of the seizure of the articles in question, the relevant notification was in force.   Ibid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—There is no duty cast on the prosecution to prove not merely that the goods seized were covered by a notification restricting or prohibiting import but also that the particular goods had actually been imported. Ibid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Liability arising out of debt.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The date of acquisition of goods is relevant to the question of culpability under the amended section 167. The words of items (81) arc unambiguous and expressly make goods of the relevant kind liable to confiscation and their possession an offence from the date of the amendment. No question of giving retrospective effect to such a provision arises. From the date of promulgation of the Ordinance, anyone, who retained possession of such goods, however or whenever they might have been acquired could do so at his peril.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Federation of Pak. Vs. Sardar Ali (1959) 11 DLR (SC) 59 (62-63)</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss.167 (S1) &amp; 177-A: No offence committed</strong> <strong>when Government gives permission.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If goods are allowed to be brought into Pakistan without payment of duty on account of instructions issued by the Government it is hardly possible to allege that the Government has been defrauded of the duty payable on the goods by the person who brought the goods into Pakistan.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Pakistan Vs. Kazi Ziauddin (1962) 14 DLR (SC) 245.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Plea that there was an alternative remedy by way of appeal not having been raised in High Court, cannot be entertained in the Supreme Court— Constitution of Pakistan, 1956, Art. 170.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Conviction under section 167(81) liable to be set aside by issue of certiorari.   Ibid</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.177-A. Onus on the defense that the duty had been paid.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Item (81) to section 167 and section 177-An are be read together to avoid an absurd result. Prosecutions duty under section 167, item (81) is to show  the goods are chargeable with duty which has not been paid or their importation is prohibited. Under section 177-A, the onus is on the defense to prove that the duty on the goods seized had been paid or they had been imported before the imposition or restriction.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Collector of Customs, Karachi Vs. Haji Usman, Haji Gani (1959) 11 DLR (SC) 200. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Under section 177-A, if any question arises in respect of goods covered by section 167(8) as to whether duty has been paid or secured in respect of them or whether they had been lawfully imported, the burden of proof would lie upon the person in whose possession the goods were found or from whose premises they were recovered or who claimed their ownership.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Federation of Pak. Vs. Sardar Ali (1959) 11 DLR (SC) 59.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—In view of the new section 177-A placing a definite onus on the possessor of the relevant goods, covered by item (81) of section 167, a person proceeded against is entitled to an opportunity of not only being heard hut of adducing evidence, if necessary, to discharge that onus. Ibid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The section lays down a procedural rule and it is, well-settled that any change in procedure would affect pending actions or proceedings. Ibid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—S.177-A. Presumption rose under section 177-A. Presumption raised under section 177-A is only with respect to the goods and no presumption as to the person who committed the act.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The presumption raised by virtue of section 177- A is only as to an act having been committed, and there is no presumption as to the person who committed the act. Even if the first part of section 177-A were applicable, yet the person from whose possession the goods were seized could not have been found guilty on the basis of that presumption alone. For there will be no presumption that it was he who committed an act to defraud the Government. So far as the second part of section 177- A is concerned, this too raises a presumption only as to the commission of the act to evade a prohibition or restriction and not with respect to the person who committed the act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Further the presumption under section 117-A even if it is raised with respect to a particular person is not sufficient for holding that person guilty inasmuch as an act may be committed in violation of a prohibition or restriction and yet it may not be committed “knowingly and with intent to evade” the prohibition or restriction and unless this element of “knowingly and with intent to evade” is found to exist no offence can be said to have been committed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Presumption under section 177-A which arises as to an act would not be sufficient proof of guilt as against the person in possession. And that being so the proper procedure for application of section 177-A would be that the officer who seizes the goods states the grounds of his belief in order that the reasonableness of the belief may be tested.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Pakistan Vs. Kazi Ziauddin (1962)14 DLR (SC) 244.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Customs Collector while conducting enquiry is to act in conformity with natural justice.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In conducting an enquiry under the Sea Customs Act, the Collector does not act as a Court, but he undoubtedly exercises a judicial or quasi-judicial function in this respect. He is not bound to conform to the provisions of the Evidence Act. But in exercising a judicial or quasi-judicial function, he decides in a judicial spirit and manner in conformity to well recognized principles of natural justice.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Osman Abdul Karim Bawaney Vs. Collector of Customs (1962) 14 DLR 296.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Customs authority bound to disclose the identity of the informant who supplied the information.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Customs authorities may be bound not to disclose the identity of the informant upon whose information certain investigations are started; but if in a judicial or quasi judicial proceeding they have received any information as evidence and have relied upon such evidence, they cannot conceal the identity of the deponent and thereby deprive the petitioner of the opportunity of challenging his veracity. Ibid</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>[See under section 167 in the case of Osman Abdul Karim Bawaney Vs. Collector of Customs, in 14 DLR 296 above.]</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>[See under section 167(81) in case of Pakistan Vs. Kazi Ziauddin, in 14 DLR (S.C) 244 above]</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 178</strong>: The appellant’s shop was raided by the Custom Officials and certain imported goods were seized there from. The appellant moved the High Court in its writ jurisdiction and the two Judges of the High Court took two different views.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Due to difference of opinion between the learned Judges the matter was referred to a 3rd Judge who expressed his agreement with the judgment of Faruqui, J.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Thereupon on an appeal preferred before the Supreme Court it was contended that the conditions imposed for return of goods to the appellant was illegal and unauthorized in law.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Held: </span></strong>There is no escape from the position that the High Court can give only such direction for which provisions are made in law. If the High Court was of the view that the goods seized were smuggled in contravention of the Sea Customs Act then no order for their restoration should ever have been passed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In the present case, it having been found that the goods were illegally seized there is no warrant in law for the conditions imposed by the High Court on the restoration of the goods seized by the Custom Authorities from the appellant.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mohammad Yousuf Vs. The Collector of Sea Customs, Karachi, (1969) 21 DLR (SC) 118.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 187</strong>. <em>[See under section 167 in the case of Assistant Director of Customs Vs. Muhd. Afzal Khan, in 16 DLR (WP) 165 above.]</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 188</strong>—Appeal implies right of audience and an appeal cannot be disposed of on perusing the departmental report.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Federation of Pak. Vs. Sardar Ali (1959) 11 DLR (SC) 59</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 189</strong>—Not applicable to a person who disclaims ownership of goods for which duty or penalty was levied.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Akbar Adil Vs. Republic of Pak. (1958) 10 DLR (WP) 49</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 188</strong>—Remedy has been provided under section 188 of the Customs Act and as such it creates an implied bar to a proceeding under the Code of Civil Procedure before the civil court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Jogesh Chandra Vs. Bangladesh (1978) 30 DLR 219.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Limitation</strong> : For filing an appeal against the order of the Collector of Customs—Time of 3 months runs from the date on which the person affected by the order comes to know of it and not from the date on which it passed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If the proposition is sought to be established that the period of limitation would run from the date on which the order was passed or is claimed to have been passed, it must be proved that the person who will be affected by such order had actual or constructive notice that the order was going to be passed on a particular date or that the order has been passed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>New Cycle Mart Vs. Collector of Customs (1974) 26 DLR 104.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Concerned party’s case should receive a due consideration at the hand of the Collector</strong>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">When deciding upon somebody’s rights in a quasi-judicial proceeding like the one before the Collector of Customs: the officer must independently arrive at the conclusion upon a consideration of the materials, both of fact and law, placed before him and he must give an opportunity to the party concerned to see or inspect any document upon which he may be fond of placing his reliance. Ibid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.198.</strong> Notice served on the clearing agent cannot bind the importer of the goods —proceeding leading to imposition of fine in such a case not sustainable in law.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The notice under section 198 in this case to show cause why higher assessment of custom duties should not be levied and a penalty imposed was served not on the petitioner i.e. the owner who imported the goods, but upon his Clearing Agent who  as such on his behalf.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held:</strong> The petitioner was not personally served with any notice and therefore it cannot be held that the notice served on the Clearing Agent can bind the petitioner.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>AKM Bawaney Vs. Assistant Collector of Customs (1962) 14 DLR 565.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—General jurisdiction of the Civil Courts cannot be ousted by the conferment of special jurisdiction on Custom Authorities.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Although the special jurisdiction of the Customs Authorities to deal with the question of assessment of sales tax cannot be doubted and the machinery provided for the purpose by the Sea Customs Act is elaborate and is expressed so as to achieve finality, yet that finality is only to be understood within the limits of the statute, and those special provisions cannot by implication have the effect of excluding the general jurisdiction of the Civil Courts.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>M/S Habib Industries Ltd. Vs. Pakistan (1962) 14 DLR (SC) 60.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Limitation imposed by the section—</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">The provision in section 198 of the Sea Customs Act dealing with Civil Courts jurisdiction in matters decided under the Act merely subjects a proceeding commenced under the section against a person for something done in pursuance of the Act to the requirement of month’s notice in writing and of three month’s limitation from the accrual of the cause of such notice. Ibid</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 198</strong>—Provisions of S. 198 are intended to afford protection to the Customs officers from any vexations or frivolous proceeding.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Hegge &amp; Co. Vs. Assistant Collector of Customs (1979) 31 DLR 306.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 203B</strong>—The question for Court’s consideration is whether the provision of “reward” as contained in rule 7 of the Resolution of the Ministry of Finance dated 18.8.58, confers a right which can be enforced by a writ petition.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Govt. of Bangladesh Vs. Md. Arshad Ali (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 348.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Read with rule 7 of the Resolution of Ministry of Finance.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Rules framed under section 203B of the Sea Customs Act are office instructions for regulating grant of reward to Customs employees and other persons who are instrumental in detecting evasions of the provision of the statute. Ibid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The word “token” in rule 7 sufficiently shows that rewards cannot be claimed as of right.   Ibid.</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2376	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Service</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p align="center" style="text-align:center"><b><u><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Service</span></u></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><u><span style='Cambria","serif";'><span style="text-decoration:none"><br/></span></span></u></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Inspector ofExplosive appointed as the Dy. Chief Inspector of Explosives and havingthereafter made over charge of Inspector of Explosives, becomes the Dy. ChiefInspector of Explosives—No scope to argue that he acted as Dy. Chief Inspectorin addition to his post as Inspector of Explosives.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>M.A. Rashid,Vs. Government of Bangladesh &amp; ors. (1981) 33 DLR 366.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Service—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Officiatingfor any length of time does not confer on a person any substantive right.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Shamsul AlamVs. Superintendent of Police, Bangladesh Railway (1981)33 DLR (AD) 100.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Service—Orderof retirement when illegal</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Due topersonal animus which an officer- One Mr. Anisuzzaman Chowdhury, (who happensto be the brother-in-law of the Minister) bore against Mr. Shah Azharuddin (thepetitioner in the writ petition,) the latter under the orders of the Ministerwas illegally retired. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>ShahAzharuddin Ahmed. Vs. Government of Bangladesh &amp; ors. (1981) 33 DLR 171</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Service—Orderterminating the service of an employee, when held as being passed withoutjurisdiction.</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Therespondent was a Security Officer in the Tabani Beverage Co. Ltd. which underP.O. No. 16 of 1972, was placed under the appellant in Freedom Fighters WelfareTrust, set up under P.O. No. 94 of 1972. The respondent was employed by theappellant as the Public Relations Officer. The respondent was transferred fromthe Tabani Beverage Co. Ltd to Model Electrical Engineering Corporation,another abandoned concern, under the management of the appellant, as SalesOfficer.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Theappellant in relation to the respondent was exercising power as given to it byP.O. 16, which does not authorize the appellant to transfer an employee of suchabandoned concern appointed before it became abandoned to another concernplaced under the management of Bangladesh Freedom Fighters Welfare Trust, andas such the order of transfer was an unlawful order. The order of terminationwas passed for defying the order of transfer, which is patently withoutjurisdiction. The order of termination being beyond the powers of theappellant, a statutory body, is amenable to be impugned in the WritJurisdiction of the High Court Division.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>BangladeshFreedom Fighters Welfare Trust Vs. Burhanuddin Chowdhury (1981) 33 DLR (AD)321.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Service—Promotion to the next higher grade</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Petitioner,the senior most candidate not being a graduate, while the other candidates weresuch graduates, his claim for promotion turned down and this caused nothingillegal.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>A.H.M.Aminur Rahman. Vs. Chairman, BADC, Dhaka. (1981) 33 DLR 373.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Service—Removal(or dismissal) from service—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Punishment as indicated in the notice isremoval (not dismissal) from service—Actually punishment inflicted on thedelinquent servant is ‘dismissal’—Punishment by ‘dismissal’ in such a caseillegal</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>GiasuddinAhmed Chowdhury Vs. People’s Republic of Bangladesh (1981) 33 DLR 329.</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—An illegalorder of dismissal from service can be rectified by the High Court Division inexercising its power of review.        Ibid</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Service—Re-instatementin—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>if the orderis held invalid he would be entitled to reinstatement hut not to any arrears ofsalary.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Saleh Ahmed JoarderVs. People’s Republic of Bangladesh. (1984) 36 DLR (AD) 26.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Service-resignationfrom service when takes effect.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Resignationletter from service becomes effective, that is irrevocable with effect from thedate of resignation. But if before the date when resignation takes effect theconcerned officer withdraws his resignation it amounts that his resignation iswithdrawn and there is, in fact, no resignation.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S.M. GolamMustafa Sarker Vs. Chairman, Bangladesh Jute Mills. (1981) 33 DLR 430.</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Service—Retirement&amp; Pension.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—In case ofhis re-instatement, the appellant will retire as Circle Officer and will getpension on the basis of pay last drawn.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Saleh AhmedJoarder Vs. People’s Republic of Bangladesh. (1984) 36 DLR (AD) 26.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Service—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Security of service of an<b> </b></span><span style='Cambria","serif";'>employee of statutory Corporation, set upunder P.O. 27 of 1972. Dismissal for breach of internal discipline, in theabsence of Rules, illegal. Termination simpliciter of employee’s servicepermissible (Court directed that petitioner-employee’s service be terminated byCorporation instead of his being dismissed.)</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>An employeeof the Corporation set up by Presidential Order 27 of 1972 is an employee underthe State.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Md. Hazrat AliVs. Chairman Bangladesh Chemical Industry Corporation. (1981) 33 DLR 306.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Service—Temporary</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>FundamentalRule 9(22) defines ‘temporary service’ as a post which carries a definite rateof pay sanctioned for a limited time. Temporary posts arc often outside aregular cadre and are usually sanctioned from year to year. A temporary serviceis created to meet the requirement of sudden rush of business. A person may beappointed temporarily in a vacancy caused by the absence from duty of anotherperson having lien therein. In that case, a subordinate officer may also bepointed to officiate in the higher post: whether it is “officiation” in ahigher a post or it is a temporary appointed, it continues till the person onleave resumes duties or the vacancy is filled on permanent basis. Sometemporary services’ have been interpreted in a judicial pronouncements as“purely temporary  distinguished from atemporary service which is indefinite in duration and the length of servicerendered by a person therein is reasonably long so as to confer upon it theStatus of quasi-permanent’ or ‘non- temporary’ service.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Saleh AhmedJoarder Vs. People’s Republic of Bangladesh (1984) 36 DLR (AD) 26.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Service—Non-Temporary</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Appellant’sservice is non-temporary or quasi- permanent.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Theuninterrupted service rendered by the appellant for over 5 years could beeasily treated as one non-temporary or quasi-permanent attracting theconstitutional protection under Article 135. This case falling within the fourcorners of the case of Ismail Hossain, I find no reason whatever to take adifferent view.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Saleh AhmedJoarder Vs. People’s Republic Waqf Bangladesh. (1984)36 DLR(AD). 26.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Service—Terminationof Service</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Theappellant (in C.A. 169/79) was an officer of B.M.O.G. Corporation (calledCorporation). Later he was posted in the Titas Gas Co. Ltd. (called Enterprise)as the Administrative Officer of the Enterprise.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>His servicewas however terminated by the General Manager of the Enterprise on 24.5.79which he challenged as illegal by invoking the writ jurisdiction of the HighCourt.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>It may bestated that originally the appellant was an auditor of the Titas Gas Co.(Enterprise). In October 1965 he ceased to be an employee of this Company.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>AfterBangladesh came into being he was freshly appointed as the AdministrativeManager in the Enterprise which was placed under the Corporation under thenationalization measures of P.O. 27/72.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Theappellant’s claim is that though he has been placed by the Corporation as anemployee of the Enterprise; in licit he remains an officer of the Corporation,that is, he enjoys the status of an employee of a statutory body. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>High CourtDivision gave him no relief and thereupon he moved the Appellate Division.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Held:</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> Titas GasTransmission and Distribution Co. lost its autonomous character after it wasplaced under the Mineral Oil and Gas Corporation after it is declared as anabandoned property.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>After thechanges brought about by P.O. 16 of 1972 and P.O 27 of 1972, ills clear thatthe Titas Gas Transmission and Distribution Co. Ltd. lost its corporatecharacter.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>MusharrafHossain Chowdhury Vs. General Manager, Titas Gas Transmission. (1981) 33 DLR(AD) 186.</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Titas GasCo. is entirely controlled by the Bangladesh Mineral Oil and Gas Corporation.   Ibid</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—As TitasGas Transmission and Distribution Co. lost its autonomous character, with theCorporation gaining control over it the appellant is in the service of theCorporation and master and servant rule cannot apply to him and can thereforeinvoke jurisdiction of article 102 of the Constitution.          Ibid</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Service—Terminationof service in terms of</span></b><span style='line-height:115%;Cambria","serif";'> <b>law or contract</b></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Whentermination order casts stigma on the servants it amounts to removalnecessitating enquiry and show-cause notice.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>JaminiRanjan Jala Das Vs. Board of Trustees, (1981) 33 DLR 300.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Service—Violationof Principle of Natural Justice</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Theappellant challenged an order of the Bangladesh Biman Corporation whereby someemployees junior to him were given two years ante-dated seniority.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Governmentof Bangladesh prepared a comprehensive formula for giving special facilities tothe Freedom Fighters and in pursuance thereof a Memorandum was issued.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>In theinstant case the Bangladesh Biman in pursuance of the said Memorandum prepareda revised seniority list dated 9.6.78. The appellant contended that thisrevised seniority list has affected him adversely, and this was one inviolation of the principles of natural justice and without any legal authority.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Held:</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> TheAppellate Division in the case reported in 31 DLR(AD) 305 came to theconclusion that the employees of the Bangladesh Biman arc employees of astatutory corporation and their appointments have been madcand sanctified bynecessary enactments.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Thereforethe Bangladesh Biman Corporation Employees Service Regulations, 1979 wereframed on 20.12.79.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Noregulation has been framed empowering the preparation of revised seniority listin terms of the 4 Memorandum. Therefore, any revised list, if prepared forgiving two years ante-dated seniority, would be without any backing of lawfulauthority. Mere circular by an executive fiat would not be enough and thereforethe grievance of the appellant that his seniority has been affected without lawfulauthority must be accepted.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Abdul QuddusVs. Secretary, Cabinet Secretariat. (1981) 33 DLR (AD) 50.</span></i></p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span> </div></div>
2377	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Service Rules, Part 1</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1968) 20 DLR 306</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Service Rules </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Service Rules, Part 1</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rule S(50).—</strong>The plaintiff intentionally absented from duty from 15.11.54 unto the date of the order of his suspension on 18.3.58. It is for the plaintiff’s appointing authority to determine how the said period will be regulated or treated in this case. Therefore the question of his getting salary or allowance of the said period cannot be decided here.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Province of East Pakistan Vs. G.M. Chowdhury (1968) 20 DLR 306.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rule 71—Suspension period Subsistence allowance.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Rule is that during the period of suspension a Government servant is entitled to subsistence grant and not pay or leave salary.   Ibid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Suspension period—subsistence allowance-</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">As to the plaintiff’s entitlement to subsistence grant for the period of suspension, it is for his appointing authority to grant the same if according to the applicable rule, namely, rule 71. It is not either necessary or desirable to make a declaration with regard to the plaintiff’s entitlement to subsistence grant for the period of suspension. Ibid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—R. 75(c)</strong>—Retiring a Government servant under optional clause—Not a disciplinary action. An order retiring a Govt. servant from service under the approval power of the Govt. under rule 75(e) does not involve any disciplinary action, the same being a condition of service. Ibid</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2378	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Service Tenant (Protection) Act, 1952</h2>

Code and the decree must be treated as</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sri Sri Lakshrni Narayan Vs. Sri Suraih Lal Chakraborti. 2379	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Shops and Establishments Act, 1952 &amp; Shops and Establishments Rules, 1970</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1975) 27 DLR 244, (1956) 8 DLR 721, (1983) 35 DLR 151, 9 PLR (Dac.) 202, (1968) 20 DLR 520, (1959) 11 DLR (SC) 108, (1983) 35 DLR 151</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Shops and Establishments </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Shops and Establishments Act (1 of 1952)</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Secs. 1(3), 1(4), 2(1) and 2(k)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Industrial establishments excluded from the definition of factory—Provisions of the Shops and Establishments Act not applicable to a factory.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Nurul Islam Vs. Chairman, 2nd Labour Court (1975) 27 DLR 244.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 2(9).</strong> Provisions of the section applicable to an industrial establishment within the meaning of section 2(9) of the E.B. Shops and Establishments Act, even though no notification was published as required under section 1(5) of the Payment of Wages Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Azizur Rahman Vs. Md. Babar Ali (1956) 8 DLR 721.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 2 (c)—</strong>The Sonali Bank of Bangladesh is a public statutory body and not being a Government Department to act for and on behalf of the Government. After nationalization of the Sonali Bank, it operates as a bank to which the provisions of the Shops and Establishments Act, 1965 about wages, leave, hour and work, etc are applicable.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>The State.. Petitioner. Vs. Abdul Awal, Respondent (1983) 35 DLR 151.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Sonali Bank is a bank within the meaning of commercial establishment.   Ibid</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 8(2)—</strong>Under this sub-section, the provisions of Payment of Wages Act are attracted even though no notification was published as required under section 1(5) of the latter Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Azizur Rahman Vs. Md. Babar Ali (1956) 8 DLR 721.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A person employed in industrial establishment is entitled to the benefit of the Provisions of the Payment of Wages Act, 1936. <em>9 PLR (Dac.) 202.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 9—Leave of absence of an employee for 14 days with full pay.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It was argued that a piece-rated worker is not entitled to the benefit of leave. But this argument is not valid, because nowhere in the Act, a distinction has been made between a salaried employees and a piece- rated employee.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The East Bengal Shops and Establishments Act is mainly for the benefit of the employee and , if possible, ii should be given the widest construction so that the employee’s case may not be jeopardized.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>A. Sakur Vs. Chairman, (1968) 20 DLR 520.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 11—Words “discharge” and “dismissed” explained.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The words “discharged” and “dismissed” found in section 11 of 1952 must be construed to mean “a discharge’ or “a dismissal” at the instance of the employer. By way of reference, we may quote the definition of the word “discharge” as given in section 2(f) of the East Pakistan Employment of Labour (Standing Orders) Act of 1965 (East Pakistan Act No. VIII of 1965) which means the termination of services of worker by the employer for reasons of physical or mental incapacity or continued ill-health of the worker or such other similar reasons not amounting to misconduct. Ibid</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If the employer discharges an employee even on grounds of physical incapacity, that too, would amount to a “discharge” which will entitle the employees to the benefits contemplated by section 11 of East Bengal Act, I of 1952.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Tribunals (as the Labour) Court are to act in accordance with judicial principles.   Ibid</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 11</strong><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">— Does not empower the employers to dismiss employees.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Section 11 of the Act is intended to provide benefits and relief’s to employees even in cases of dismissal. It cannot be construed as a source of power for employers to exercise their right of dismissal of their employees.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>River Steam Navigation Co. Vs. A.B.S. Chowdhury (1959) 11 DLR (SC) 108.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Shops and Establishments Rules, 1970</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rules 10, 12-14—</strong>Failure to produce Registers and particulars as required by the rules on the instant demand by a visiting Inspector does not attract any penal provision. —Proper course would be to demand their production by service of notice. —It is on failure thereof that action can be taken.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>State Vs. Abdul Awal (1983) 35 DLR 151.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2380	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Small Cause Courts Act, 1887 [Section 01-23]</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1980) 32 DLR (AD) 212, (1967) 19 DLR 30, (1962) 14 DLR (SC) 60, (1970) 22 DLR 505,(1973) 25 DLR 211,  (1973) 25 DLR 142, (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 310, (1954) 6 DLR 277, (1954) 6 DLR 588, (1973) 25 DLR 142, (1970) 22 DLR 444, (1959) 11 DLR 402, (1979) 22 DLR 7</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Small Cause Courts </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Small Cause Courts Act (IX of 1887)</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Suit before a Small Cause Court ends in a decree —Appeal against a decree is a creature of statute—No appeal Lies against small cause court’s decree.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sayeb Ali.. Appellant. Vs. Sree Gopal Chandra Das and others.. Respondents (1980) 32 DLR (AD) 212.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 15—Transfer</strong>—Upon transfer of Small Cause Courts suit from the Court which was invested with Small Cause Courts power to another Court under section 24, C.P. Code which lacked power to try a suit as a Small Cause Courts suit the decree passed by the transferee Court is Small Cause Courts decree and as such no appeal will lie against such a decree.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Jamiruddin Ahmed Vs. Md. Nurul Islam (1967) 19 DLR 30.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Court’s jurisdiction depends upon the subject-matter of the suit.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It was contended that the suit was not competent to be tried in a Small Cause Court because it was in fact a suit asking for a declaration.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Held:</span></strong> Jurisdiction of a Court in a suit tried under the Small Cause Courts Act depends upon the subject-matter of the suit and not upon the correctness of the plaintiffs’ contention as respect the subject-matter.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Habib industries Vs. Pakistan (1962) 14 DLR (SC) 60.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sec. 15(2) and Second Schedule:</span></strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> Suit for ejectment of tenant is cognizable and triable by a Court of Small Causes—Articles 4 and 11 of the Second Schedule do not bar such trial by such Court.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Habibur Rahman Vs. Md. Manwar. (1970) 22 DLR 505.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">S. 15(2) and Second Sch. Art. (4): </span></strong>A suit for ejectment of tenant is excluded from article (4) of the Second Schedule and as such triable by a Small Cause Court even though ii involves the determination of a question of title.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Article (4) of the Second Schedule of the Provincial Small Cause Courts Act shows that a suit for ejectment of a tenant has been excluded from the am- bit of the said article (4) unless of course any other court or officer has been given exclusive jurisdiction in the matter. Thus a suit for ejectment of a tenant which is not exclusively triable by a particular court or officer is not contained within the ambit of article 4) of the Second Schedule. In view of the provisions of sub-section (2) of section 15 of the Provincial Small Cause Courts Act, 1887, such Suits arc cognizable and triable by a Court of Small Causes.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Even in a case where the principal point is one relating to the question of determination of title, the same can be considered and decided by a Court of Small Causes provided the suit is otherwise triable by such a Court and does not fall outside the ambit of its jurisdiction in views of the subject- matter being included within the list of articles mentioned in the Second Schedule of the Small Cause Courts Act. It is true that decision on the question of title in a suit for damages is not binding on the parties.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Dr. Habibur Rahman Vs. Md. Maniur, (1973) 25 DLR 211.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—In finding out whether a suit is triable by a court of small causes or not, it is necessary to examine the subject-matter of the litigation itself.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The frame of the suit itself is necessary to be taken into consideration before deciding whether the suit is of the nature triable by the Small Cause Court or not.   Ibid</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—S.</strong> <strong>15(2)—</strong>Defect in respect of pecuniary jurisdiction not raised and judgment delivered—No prejudice caused.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Gopal Krishna Das and another..Petitioner. Vs. Abdul Kader Mia..Opp.-Party. (1983) 35 DLR</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sees. 15 &amp; 16— Small Cause Courts—Determination of jurisdiction</strong>—In determining whether a Suit is triable by a Court of Small Causes or not the Frame of the suit itself is necessary to be taken into consideration— Objections raised in the written statement alone cannot determine the nature of the suit—Nature of the suit can be best ascertained by examining the subject-mailer before the court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Habibur Rahman Vs. Md. Mansur, (1970) 22 DLR 505.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 15 and 16</strong>—Trial of small cause by a Court not invested with Small Cause Courts power, not without jurisdiction when objection to such trial not taken at the initial stage.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It will be observed that while in relation to suits specified in the Second Schedule of the Provincial Small Cause Courts Act, sub-section (1) of section 15 provides that a Small Cause Court “shall not take cognizance”, section 16 provides that save as specifically provided by this Act or by any other enactment a Suit cognizable by a Small Cause Court “shall not be tried” by any other Court which may have jurisdiction within the local limits of the jurisdiction of the Court of Small Causes by which the Suit is triable.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The contention that section 16 of the Provincial Small Cause Courts Act impliedly bars taking of cognizance of small cause suits by ordinary courts, cannot be accepted in the face of the clear terms of the section which relate only to trial.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Trial of a small cause suit, through mistake, by a Court having no small cause court powers, without any objection from the parties, would not he a nullity; and that the decree resulting there from cannot be challenged on the ground of absence of jurisdiction.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Santosh Lal Gope Vs. Ahmed Ali (1973) 25 DLR 142.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Competency of Small Cause Courts to decide question of title</strong>—A Court of Small Causes is competent to consider and decide in a suit the question of title if the suit is otherwise triable by it —But such decision regarding title is neither final nor binding on parties to the Suit.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Even in a case where the principal point is, one relating to the question of determination of title, the same can be considered and decided by a Court of Small Causes provided the suit is otherwise triable by it and does not fall outside the ambit of its jurisdiction in view of the subject-matter being included within the list of articles mentioned in the second schedule of the Small Cause Courts Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Habibur Rahman Vs. Md. Mansur (1970) 22 DLR 505.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 15, 23</strong>—The Court of Small Causes is entitled to consider question of title incidentally but not when the question of title becomes an issue on law.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdul Khalek Mia.. Appellant, Vs. Maya Debi &amp; ors.. Respondents (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 310.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 16— Small Cause Court suit</strong>— Munsif invested with Small Cause Court powers tried the Suit of Small Cause Court nature in an ordinary way—Trial may be irregular but not void.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The same Judicial Officer is invested with both the powers of an ordinary Civil Court and those of the judge of Small Cause Courts for the same locality. The suit being of a certain value it has to be filed before the judge either in his ordinary file or in his Small Cause Court file and he keeps it in one file instead of the other and adopts a procedure other than that prescribed for a Small Cause Court suit, that by itself will not alter the character of the suit, for the mode of trial does not change the character of the suit.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Shamsuddin Pradhan Vs. Jasoda Kanta Sen &amp; ors. (1954) 6 DLR 277.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Although the judge was invested with the powers of the Judge of the Small Cause Court, he did not adopt the summary procedure of a judge of the Small Cause Court and instead followed the procedure prescribed by the Code of Civil Procedure, recorded evidence at length and also wrote out a considered judgment. As the judge had the powers of a judge of the Small Cause, he must have tried the suit as a judge of the Small Cause Court, even if the procedure adopted by him is not one of Small Cause Court. Ibid</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 16</strong>— Utmost that can be said that according to the letters of the provisions f law the judge acted with irregularity but it cannot be said that such irregularity is a material irregularity or it is of such a nature as has caused failure of justice.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Shamsuddin Pradhan Vs. Jasoda Kanta Sen &amp; ors. (1954) 6 DLR 277.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Small Cause Court suit tried as an advisory suit—effect.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">- Section 16 of the Provincial Small Cause Courts Act provides that a Suit cognizable by a Court of Small Causes shall not be tried by any other Court having jurisdiction within the local limits of the jurisdiction of the Court of Small Causes by which the suit is triable. The section does not extinguish the jurisdiction but only prevents the exercise of it, if the suit is recognizable by a Small Cause Court. If a Court by error tries a Suit which is of a nature cognizable by a Small Cause Court exercising jurisdiction within the same limits, then the proceedings of the Court are not entirely without jurisdiction and therefore, arc not a nullity. Such a case is not a case of want of jurisdiction. It is a case of exercise of jurisdiction in violation of the prohibition imposed by sec. 16 of the Provincial Small Cause Courts Act. The executing Court is not competent to treat the decree as a nullity nor is it open to the defendant to impeach it, he having raised no objection to the trial.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mofizuddin Mia vs. Muslim Khandakar (1954) 6 DLR 588.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—S. 16—</strong>On a true construction of section 9 read with Order 46, rule 7, C.P. Code it is clear that trial of a small cause by a Court not invested with small cause court’s power is not a nullity when no objection to such trial was taken initially.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Even apart from rule 7 of Order 46 of the Code of Civil Procedure on a true construction of section 9 of the Code and section 16 of the Provincial Small Cause Courts Act, the only conclusion that can be reached is that violation of the provisions of section 16, through mistake and in the absence of an objection by any parties to the suit, cannot render the trial of a small Cause suit by a Court not invested with Small Cause Court powers a nullity.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sansosh Lal Gape Vs. Ahmed Ali, (1973) 25 DLR 142.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Suit within exclusive jurisdiction of S.S.C. Judge erroneously tried by a court other than the S.S.C. Judge—effect of such trial.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The trial of a case by a court other than the S.S.C. Judge cannot be a case for want of jurisdiction in spite of the violation of the provision imposed by section 16 of the Small Cause Courts Act since the Legislature intended to cure such defect by taking recourse to the provision of Order 46, rule 7(2) of the C.P. Code. So, unless it is found that substantial justice has not been meted out by the court who tries the suit, the decree cannot be set aside simply on the ground that the case was tried by a Court other than the Small Cause Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Neyaz Ahmed Khan Vs. Anwari Khatoon (1970) 22 DLR 444.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 17(1)—Furnishing security.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A party applied to have an ex-parte Small Cause Court’s decree set aside, furnished security under sec. 17(1) of the Small Cause Courts Act at the time of presenting his application with the permission of the Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Held:—This was a sufficient compliance with sec. 17(1) of the Act and his application cannot be dismissed for not depositing the decretal amount.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Nadirum Mal Vs. Lakshman Ch. Dhali. (1959) 11 DLR 402.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—If an application for an order to set aside an ex parte decree is Filed on the last date of limitation without deposit of security and the security was furnished after the expiry of limitation, the application is barred and if in such a case an order is made restoring the suit under Or. 9 r. 13 of the Code of Civil Procedure the same is bad in law. <em>54 CWN (DR2) 67</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—S. 17(1):—</span></strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Plaintiffs suit was dismissed cx parte—awarding the cost to the defendant— Although, a decree for such an award has been drawn up but such a decree cannot be taken as one within the meaning of a “decree passed ex-parte” as contemplated in the proviso to section 17(11) of the Act.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Raicharan Das Vs. Sontosh Kumar Dos, (1979) 22 DLR 790.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—An order of dismissal for default not being a decree within the meaning of section 2(2)(b) of the C.P. Code, an application for setting aside the dismissal order passed ex-parte was not barred under section 17(1) of the Act.   Ibid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Requirement of the proviso to the subsection is mandatory and must be complied with.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Nitya Gopal Saha Vs. Binod Behari Saha (1977) 29 DLR 259.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Deposit of the decretal amount may not be necessary but security for performance of the decree is mandatory.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In a suit for ejectment of the defendant although a deposit of the decretal amount may not be necessary, but a security for the performance of the decree or compliance with the judgment appears to be the mandate of the proviso to section 17(l) of the Act. Ibid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 17(1): Proviso</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Applicant required to make deposit of the amount due under the decree or give security for performance of the decree at the time of presenting his application—But nevertheless if the other party fails to raise any objection as to non fulfillment of the conditions stipulated in the proviso hut sits over his right and the applicant’s application has been allowed by court he is equally guilty of omission like that of the applicant and having regard to the fact that if the applicant’s application under the proviso to section 17(1) is allowed, the other party is not going to be prejudiced in any way and hence the order granting the application under the proviso does not require to he interfered with.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>A.K. Murshed Ahmed...Appellant Vs. Md. Meher Ali and ors…Respondents (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 178.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Whether the application for setting aside the ex-parte decree passed by the Small Cause Court filed within time but the security bond furnished beyond the period of limitation, it will be deemed as due compliance of the proviso to sub-section(1) of section 17 of the Provincial Small Cause Courts Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ans—Yes, such an application for setting aside the ex-parte decree must be treated to have been validly presented.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Binode Behari Saha. Vs. Nitya Gopal Shaha. (1981) 33 DLR (AD) 130</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 23— Question of title cannot be gone into except incidentally.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In a Small Cause Court suit, the Court has got no business to go into the question of title except incidentally for the purpose of deciding the question raised in the suit which is absolutely necessary for decision of the case.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Ahmed Shah Khan Vs. Abdul Barkat (1958) 11 DLR 427.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Section 23 of the Provincial Small Cause Courts Act negatives the proposition that section 16 of the said Act was intended altogether to deprive the ordinary Civil Courts of the jurisdiction conferred on them by section 9 of the Code over a particular type of suits of civil nature, viz, small cause Suits.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Santosh Lal Gape Vs. Ahmed Ali, (1973) 25 DLR 142.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Suit for eviction of tenant—in a suit for eviction of tenant the S.S.C. Judge can go into the question of title incidentally only when such step was absolutely necessary to decide the points at issue.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mohammad Salim Vs. Mohammad Siddique Jamal (1970) 22 DLR 841.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Small Cause Court Judge, in case of question of title to the property involved, may return the plaint or it may not do so, and try the case touching the question of title incidentally but not finally deciding the question of title.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">This power is, however, discretionary, and it clearly indicates that a Small Cause Court has the power to decide an incidental question of title in a suit which is essentially of small cause nature, in case it chooses not to return the plaint. Its decision on the question of title wills not, of course, be final arid, therefore, will not be res judicata in a suit brought before a Civil Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The provision of section 23 of the Small Cause Courts Act does not lay down that an issue as to title renders a S.C.C. suit non-maintainable as such but enacts that the authority of a S.C.C. judge to hear such a suit is discretionary.<em> Merajuddin Vs. Md. Anwarul Islam (1974) 26 DLR 314.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Unless the plaintiff, framed the suit for a declaration of title with other necessary consequential relief’s, the mere enquiry into the question of title, will not, by itself, convert the suit into a suit for title depending on proof or disproof of title to immovable property.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Musud Ali Vs. Saulatunnessa (1977) 29 DLR 292</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 23(I)—</strong>Scope of sections 23(1) and 28A(1) on the question of determining whether a Court of Small Cause should try the suit or it should go to the ordinary Civil Court, explained—Court having the lowest jurisdiction should be approached.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The new section 28A in the Small Cause Courts Act in 1962 and the original section 23 together have set up two different forums of concurrent jurisdiction for determining whether h Court of Small Causes should try a suit filed before it or it should go before an ordinary Civil Court for trial. Aid of section 23(1) and of section 28A(1) cannot be invoked simultaneously, the proper course would be to require the party concerned to move the trial Court in the first instance.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Once a decision has been made by the District Court under section 28A(1), that is binding upon the Small Cause Court and it is no longer open to the latter to exercise the power vested in it under section 23(1).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Even where the Small Cause Court has declined to return a plaint under section 23(1), the District Court will be competent to consider the question afresh on its own, under section 28A(1).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Where, however, a Small Cause Court decides that the suit involves questions of title, which cannot be determined by it finally and returns the plaint accordingly under section 23(1), no scope, is left for the application of section 28A(1).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Shudhir Chandra Vs. Md. Alabaksh (1966) 18 DLR 208.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2381	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Soldiers Litigation Act, 1925</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  8 PLR (Dac) 1163</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Soldiers Litigation </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Soldiers Litigation Act</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;">(IV of 1925)</p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 10</strong>—A Collector is not a Court within the meaning of the section 10 of this Act.<em> 8 PLR (Dac) 1163.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2382	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">  Special Marriage Act, 1872</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1966) 18 DLR 509</p><p><b>Subject:</b>    Special Marriage </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Special Marriage Act</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;">(III of 1872)</p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 2—</strong>Renunciation of religion is necessary for a marriage under the Act—Marriage invalid if religion is not renounced by the parties to the marriage.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The provisions of the Act itself make any false declaration punishable. If the petitioner has not in fact renounced his religion he has made a false declaration.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In the present case she has categorically stated that she is a Christian, and she never renounced her faith and, therefore, she in fact has given a false declaration in the declaration form exhibit 2. Unless one is not a Christian or not a Muslim, as far as this case is concerned, one cannot contract a marriage under this Act.
