Therefore, on the evidence of respondent herself and on the admission of the petitioner neither of them were competent to contract a marriage under the Special Marriage Act and as such the whole proceedings before the Marriage Registrar, was void.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The marriage purported td have been performed on the 27th February 1964 between the petitioner Mustafizur Rahman Khan and the respondent No. 1 Rina Ghosh is null and void because, firstly, the petitioner was a Muslim before the marriage and is continuing to be a Muslim after the marriage and the declaration made by him on the 22nd February, 1964 was a false declaration and respondent No. 1 Rina Ghosh, as clearly testified by herself, was at the time of the alleged marriage and till this date a Christian of the Roman Catholic sect and she also made a false declaration on 22nd February, 1964, and as such no marriage under the Special Marriage Act (III of 1872) was possible to be contracted between the parties and secondly, because the essential formalities laid down in section 11 of the Special Marriage Act were not performed .</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Mustafizur Rahman Vs. Rina Khan (1966) 18 DLR 509</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 11</strong>—Formalities not having been observed, marriage is void.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The provisions of section 11 are mandatory provisions and this formality was not in fact performed. On this ground also the marriage is void.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Mustafizur Rahman Vs. Rina Khan (1966) 18 DLR 509</em>.</p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2383	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Specific Relief Act, 1877 [Section 1-11]</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1969) 21 DLR 354, (1969) 21 DLR 715, (1969) 21 DLR 929, (1969) 21 DLR (WP) 209, (1969 )21 DLR (WP) 293,  (1970) 22 DLR 310, (1955) 7 DLR 335, (1964) 16 DLR (WP) 164, (1977) 29 DLR 347, (1964) 16 DLR 599, (1966) 18 DLR 691, (1965) 17 DLR 187, (1962) 14 D</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Specific Relief</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u> </u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Specific Relief Act</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;">(I of 1877)</p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;">  </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 9</strong>—Object—If the plaintiff can prove his previous possession, he may recover possession from the defendant who dispossessed him without reference to any question of title. Even where the person ousting claims a superior title, the person dispossessed is entitled to be restored to possession if he can prove his previous possession and brings an action within six months from the date when the dispossession occurred.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The object is to prevent persons taking the law into their own hands, however good their title may be. <em>Sona Mia Vs. Prokash AIR 1940 Cal. 464; Rudrappa Vs. Narsing Rao (1905)29 Born 213 ; Baira Vs. Lakshni Ins. Co. AIR 1957 All 709; Sasish Vs. Madan, 58 Cal 29.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Points for determination in a suit under S. 9—</strong>The effect of this section, therefore, is that if a summary Suit is brought within six months, the plaintiff therein who was dispossessed otherwise than in due course of law, will be entitled to be reinstated even if the defendant, who dispossessed him, be the true owner, or a person claiming under him.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Ganga Din Vs. Bakul AIR (1950) All 407.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—What the plaintiff must prove in a suit under s.9</strong>.—In a suit under s. 9 the plaintiff is to prove—</p><p style="margin-top: 0in; margin-right: 0in; margin-left: 1.0in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">(i) that he was in possession;</p><p style="margin-top: 0in; margin-right: 0in; margin-left: 1.0in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">(ii)   that he has been dispossessed, i.e., deprived of actual physical possession of land.</p><p style="margin-top: 0in; margin-right: 0in; margin-left: 1.0in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">(iii) that the dispossession took place without his consent;</p><p style="margin-top: 0in; margin-right: 0in; margin-left: 1.0in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">(iv) that it was done otherwise than in due course of law;</p><p style="margin-top: 0in; margin-right: 0in; margin-left: 1.0in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">(v)   that the dispossession took place within six months before institution of the suit under s.9.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sona Mia Vs. Prokash AIR 1940 (Cal) 464.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Possession</strong>—What the plaintiff has to prove is ‘possession’ and not mere isolated acts of trespass over the property; he must prove that he exercised acts which amounted to acts of dominion; and that the act of dominion was exclusive. If the plaintiff’s occupation has been peaceful and uninterrupted and has extended over a sufficient length of Line, the inference may properly be drawn that the plaintiff was in possession.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Rajkrishna Vs. Muktaram 12 C.L.J. 605.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Provision of the section applicable only to persons who dispossessed the plaintiff—Others not involved in the act of dispossession if added after six months’ time as parties will not affect the validity of the suit.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The suit having been brought within 6 months from the date of dispossession by the defendants dispossessing him it was maintainable under section 9 of the Act. The added defendants being not the persons who dispossessed the plaintiff, their addition after 6 months does not affect the validity of the suit and section 22 of the Limitation Act has no application to a case like this.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mantaj Khan Vs. Ali Ahmed Khan, (1969) 21 DLR 354.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Co-heirs arc not necessary parties in a section 9 case if no relief is claimed against them— Bargadars’ possession is landlord’s possession as such they are not necessary parties in section 9 case.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Dispossession of the Bargadar is a dispossession of the landlord himself and as such the suit could clearly be brought by the plaintiff himself and without impleading the Bargadar.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sadan</em> <em>Kamar Vs. Atabuddin Sarkar (1969) 21 DLR 715.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Section 9 not concerned alone with actual physical possession—Persons claiming possession through tenants or bargadars competent to bring action under this section.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Karamat Fakir Vs. Safiruddin Sk. (1969) 21 DLR 929</em><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The plaintiff being dispossessed by the defendant from the suit land instituted suit under section 9 of the Specific Relief Act for recovery of possession but the defendant subsequently instituted a title suit in respect of the same land praying for stay of the previously instituted Suit under section 10 C.P.C.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Subsequent suit and not the previously instituted suit could be stayed under section 10 C.P.C.— Court can, however, stay the previously instituted Suit under section 151 C.P.C., if circumstances demand to stay the suit for the ends of justice.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mst. Arifa Begum Vs. Khaleque Muhammad Nakvi, (1969) 21 DLR (WP) 209.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Section 9 is concerned with physical possession but not with title.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Before a person can come under section 9, he has to show that he had actual physical possession of the immovable property from which he was dispossessed without his consent by the defendant within 6 months prior to the intuition of the suit.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The rule is now well-established that where allegations in a plaint arc those of ownership, no decree can be passed under section 9 of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdul Jameel Vs. Haroon, (1969 )21 DLR (WP) 293.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Possessor’s possession is good against all but the real owner.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">C having purchased the property from a person in possession is entitled to recover possession from those who dispossessed him without any semblance of right, title and interest in the property. Possession on the basis of purchase is good against all except the true owner. His title cannot be questioned by a stranger nor his possession disturbed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdul Salam Vs. Abdul Soban, (1970) 22 DLR 310.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—In due course of law.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The words “in due course of law” in section 9 do not mean that the party against whom a suit for recovery of possession is filed must, in due course of law, be in possession as a result of the proceedings between the same parties.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdur Rahman, Vs. Mofizuddin Bhuiya (1955) 7 DLR</em> <em>335.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—In order to bar a suit under section 9 it is not necessary that the possession in “due course of Law” must be possession as a result of the proceedings between the parties.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdur</em> <em>Rahman Vs. Mofizuddin Bhuiya (1955) 7 DLR 335</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—No appeal or review lies from an order or decree under the section.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Section 9 of the Specific Relief Act, 1877, provides a quick remedy for the recovery of possession, where a person is dispossessed of immoveable property. In other words, the object of the section is clearly to discourage forcible dispossession. The last part of the section expressly prohibits an appeal from or review of any order or decree passed in any suit under this section. A party adversely affected in a suit under the section has an alternative remedy by way of a regular suit for establishing title and it covering possession or by way of revision to High Court under section 115 of the Civil Procedure Code, but any order passed in appeal, against the express provisions of law, as contained in the last part of section 9, Specific Relief Act, must be held to be without jurisdiction and a nullity in the eye of law.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Nawabzada Muhammad Umar Khan Vs. Muhammad Asif (1964) 16 DLR (WP) 164.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—On the date of dispossession the defendant dispossessed the plaintiff otherwise than in due course of law. The subsequent acquisition of title, if any, by way of lease from Enemy Property Authority did not validate the illegal dispossession by the defendants.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Pramatha Nath Das Vs. Shamsur Rahman (1977) 29 DLR 347.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—In a Suit under section 9 of the Specific Relief Act, the Court will not adjudicate upon the title of the parties.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Dr. Kudrat Ali Vs. Munsur Ali (1964) 16 DLR 599.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Possessor’s possession is good against all but the real owner.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A person who first succeeded in taking possession of a thing which belonged to none, becomes the owner of t. If he takes possession of a property which belongs to another he does not become the owner but his possession is good against all except the true owner. If he is dispossessed by a stranger he is entitled to recovery of possession as of possessory owner. If a possessory owner is wrongfully deprived of the thing by a person other than the true owner, he can recover it.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The expediency of this doctrine of possessory ownership is based on sound reason. Were it not for such a rule, force and fraud would be left to determine all disputes as to possession between persons of whom neither could show an unimpeachable title to the thing as the true owner of it.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Where a trespasser has got no semblance of title, the observation of the Privy Council in the case of J.P. Wise has got no application.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The plaintiff company were let into peaceful possession of the disputed land and the plaintiff company. was found to be in possession till it was dispossessed by the defendant who had no title to the property.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The plaintiff is entitled to get a decree for recovery of khas possession after evicting the defendant from the disputed land on the basis of the possessory title even if they had not acquired any valid title.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Aminul Islam Vs. M/S. Kilburn &amp; Co. Ltd. Paikstan (1966) 18 DLR 691.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Suit for possession—Title cannot be pleaded in bar of a suit or this nature.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Any discussion in respect of title to a holding is beyond the scope of a suit for recovery of possession inasmuch as to do so would be to Trespass into the field of a suit for declaration of title.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Debendra Mohan Das Vs. Mohd. Afazuddin (1965) 17 DLR 187.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">S. 11—</span></strong>When the plaintiff in effect asks for delivery of a specific moveable property in terms of section 11—Proper relief for delivery of the property can be granted to him under Or. 7, r. 7 C.P. Code.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>S. Sibtain Fazli Vs. Star Film Distributors (1962) 14 DLR 308.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">S. 12—</span></strong>Onus of proof is on the transferee who purchases while there is a subsisting contract between the vendor and the plaintiff to prove his bona fide purchase—Quantum of such proof is light—mere denial is held to be sufficient<em>. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Dula Mia Vs Haji Md. Ibrahim, (1956) 8 DLR 616=8 PLR (Dac) 326.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Subsisting contract for sale—</strong>When a vendor executes a deed of sale but it remains unregistered and the vendee sues for specific performance of the original contract the question that is to be considered is whether there is a subsisting contract for sale or not. If the contract be subsisting the vendee has a statutory right subject to the provisions of the Specific Relief Act to have the contract performed. The suit cannot be defeated merely because the deed which was executed had not been registered.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It will have to be decided on the facts of each case whether there is still a subsisting contract and the suit cannot be barred by the mere fact that the document already executed remains unregistered. <em>1953 PLR (Lah) 210.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>An equitable relief only—</strong>Specific performance of contract is an equitable relief, and though it may be lawful to grant it, the Court may yet refuse to do so.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In the circumstances of the case, the plaintiff is not entitled to a decree of specific performance of contract. It will be more in accord with principles of equity to release the parties from the contract subject to the equitable relief to the plaintiff.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Banka Ch. Das Vs. Abdul Wahed Bhuiya (1955) 7 DLR 556.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Presumption under the section—</strong>Presumption under the section is that breach of contract for sale of immovable property cannot be adequately compensated by money payment.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">This presumption is rebuttable and onus lies on the person who seeks to avoid it—Alternative method of performance by payment of money— stipulation must clearly provide for such alternative.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Dula Mia Vs. Haji Md. Ibrahim (1956) 8 DLR 616=8 PLR (Dac) 326.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Onus of proof is on the transferee who purchases while there is a subsisting contract between the vendor and the plaintiff to prove bona fide purchase—quantum of such proof is light—mere denial is held to be sufficient.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Dula Mia Vs. Haji Md. Ibrahim (1956) 8 DLR 616=8 PLR (Dac) 326.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Specific performance of contract re-execution and registration of document.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Where the suit is brought within three years of the contract, the court is competent to award a decree for specific performance f the contract directing the legal representatives of the original vendor to execute a kabala in accordance with the terms of the original kabala and have the same registered,</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Hafez Ahmed Vs. Obedur Rahman (1955) 7 DLR 263.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A contract relating to sale of immovable properties cannot be said to have been specifically performed till the kabala embodying the terms of the contract is presented for registration either by the executants or his legal representative.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Hafez Ahmed Vs. Obedur Rahman (1955) 7 DLR 263.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Onus of proof when contract is subsisting contract.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In a suit for specific performance of a contract against a transferee who took subsequent to the contract sued upon, the burden of proving good faith and lack of notice is upon the defendant.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sekandar Ali Vs. Anwar Ali (1959) 11 DLR 177.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Suit for specific performance of contract wilt not be decreed, where it will defeat the provision of existing law, is opposed to public interest and adversely affects the Government financially—Relief by way of specific performance of contract is an equitable relief and will not be granted where it will be unconscionable to allow it.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mir Hasmat Ali Vs. Birenda Kumar Gosh (1964) 16 DLR 239.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Contract in favour of several persons jointly—One of them can bring a suit for enforcement of contract on payment of the entire amount due</strong>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Certain property was sold by several persons who secured a condition of repurchase within a certain stipulated Lime on payment of a fixed sum. Only one of the vendors applied, in terms of the agreement of repurchase, for reconveyance of the property but was met with the defense that in order to succeed in the Suit for repurchase, all the vendors must be parties to the suit.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held:</strong> The Suit must be decreed for reconveyance. Though the reconveyance will be executed in favour of plaintiff No. 1 it will ensure to the benefit of all other co-contractors subject to the payment of their share of the money to the plaintiff and it is no concern of the vendee how they arrange this among themselves.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Niranjan Das Vs. Charu Bala Das (1963)15 DLR 611</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Mortgage—piecemeal redemption not allowable—</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">In a contract of mortgage one out of several mortgagors cannot enforce his right of redemption against the mortgagee in respect only of his share of property on payment of proportionate mortgage money unless the mortgagee agrees to it. If he is to redeem the mortgage he is to redeem the whole of the mortgage on payment of the entire mortgage money. Similarly, here the right created by the agreement for reconveyance is joint and several and any one of them can enforce it in respect of the whole and cannot enforce it in respect of his share only. </span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Niranjan Das Vs.</em> <em>Charu Bala Das (1963) 15 DLR 611.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Suit under Specific Relief Act would lie for registration of a document when registration has been refused under section 77 of the Registration Act<em>. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Hazi Goyzuddin Vs. Mahammed Serajul Haq Mia (1962) 14 DLR 148.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Specific performance of contract—Court can grant relief treating the prayer as one for relief sought in a suit for specific performance of contract, when the required court-fee has been paid, even though the prayer in a particular case was made in the form of a mandatory injunction.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Court’s discretion to grant or refuse relief in a suit for specific performance of contract is similar to a suit for injunction and as such it exercises a similar discretion in granting or refusing relief in respect of a Suit for injunction.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Any equitable ground of refusal of relief which would have been open to the defendant for resisting a suit for specific performance would also be open to him in a suit for injunction.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>S. Sibtain Fazli Vs. M/S. Star Film Distributors (1964) 16 DLR (SC) 200.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—After the completion of contract and the land having vested in the purchaser who obtained a decree for specific performance of the contract, Government acquired a portion of the land sold—Vendee becomes the owner of the land sold and compensation money assessed will be received by the vendee—No frustration of contract.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The suit for specific performance of a contract for sale of land was decreed on 3.11.51. An appeal to High Court against the decree was dismissed on 6.2.58.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The contract was entered into on 30.9.47 and sonic consideration passed to the vendor by way of earnest money and the vendee was put in possession of the land under contract.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">On 13.12.58 a portion of the land was compulsorily acquired by the Government and compensation for the acquired land was assessed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In May 1959, the decree-holder (in the suit for specific performance of the contract) applied for amendment of the decree for the purpose of getting a kabala in respect of the compensation money awarded by the Government and the Court accordingly directed that the defendant shall execute the kabala in respect of the award money as fixed by the government on account of compensation. An appeal was preferred against this order to the High Court which was rejected. Special leave was granted by the Supreme Court to consider whether a decree for specific performance of a contract for sale of land could be modified as has been done in the case.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It was argued that the contract had become frustrated in respect of the land which had been compulsorily acquired by the Government and could not be enforced to that extent.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">When there is a contract by A to sell land to B at a certain price, B becomes the owner subject to his obligation to perform his part of the contract by paying the purchase money; but subject to that the land is the land of B, the purchaser. The whole of the compensation money under the compulsory purchase order in the present case will have to go to the purchaser. There being no frustration of the contract, and it being clear that at least after the making of the decree, the land vested in the purchaser-Company which had already gone into possession, the right to the compensation money for the land lost by reason of the acquisition by Government clearly vested in the purchaser-Company, and it was in all respect just and proper that the decree to be executed should make it clear that the purchaser should have exclusive claim to this compensation money.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Joydeb Agarwala Vs. Baitulmal Karkhana Ltd. (1964) 16 DLR (SC) 706.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Creation of equitable estate enforceable in law under Specific Relief Act.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">An important principle which has been certified in Specific Relief Act is the creation of an equitable estate by the making of contract for sale of immovables. The ascertainment and enforcement of .such equitable estates forms the main burden of the Specific Relief Act. A decree for specific performance, made for the purpose of such enforcement, cannot but have the effect of confirming the equitable estate in question.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Joydeb Agarwala Vs. Baitulmal Karkhana Ltd (1964)16 DLR (SC) 706.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Petition of compromise which formed part of the decree of suit No. 189 of 1957 shows that the defendant No. 1 had contracted to sell the land in the said title suit No. 189 of 1957, to the other defendants of that suit, if the latter would pay him Rs. 100/- as price per bigha.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The defendant on agreeing to sell the lands as per compromise-decree the plaintiff filed the present suit for specific performance of contract.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Question arose whether a separate suit would lie on the defendant’s failure to honour the contract or the plaintiff could seek the relief u/s 47 of the C.P.Code.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held: </strong>The term embodied in the solenama has created a contractual obligation and as such an independent suit instead of taking recourse to the provision of section 47 of the Code of Civil Procedure is not maintainable. The contractual obligation created on the basis of the solenama appears to have constituted a question of adjustment within the meaning of section 47 of the Code of Civil Procedure. So the suit of the plaintiff is not maintainable being hit by the provision of section 47 of the Code of Civil Procedure.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Syed Ali Mridha Vs. Hamida Khatun (1974) 26 DLR 279.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sec. 12—Explanation</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Breach of Contract—Compensation</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The principle relating to specific relief’s are contained in the Specific Relief Act, 1877. The explanation to section 12 of the Specific Relief Act raises a presumption that the breach of a contract to transfer movable-property can be adequately relieved by compensation unless and until the contrary is proved.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Bazlur Rahman</em> <em>Bhuiyan Vs. Bangladesh Shipping Corporation (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 42.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2384	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Specific Relief Act, 1877 [Section 12 - 24]</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1964)16 DLR (SC) 706,  (1964) 16 DLR (SC) 609, (1980) 32 DLR 118, (1965) 17 DLR 613, (1974) 26 DLR 347, (1980) 32 DLR 118, (1968) 20 DLR 1027, 8 PLR (Dac) 326, (1969) 21 PLD (Karachi), 304, (1961) 13 DLR 458, (1955)7 DLR 642, (1976) 28 DLR 239, (1976) 2</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Specific Relief </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u> </u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Specific Relief Act</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;">(I of 1877)</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 14—The Act contemplates in certain cases payment of money in compensation.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The Specific Relief ACL contemplates the possibility in certain circumstances, one of which is that the unperformed part of a contract in fact admits of compensation in money”, that a decree may be made awarding compensation in money for the deficiency while granting specific performance as to the rest. In equity jurisdiction, it has often been said that equity may treat land as money or money as land for the purpose of doing justice in the case.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Joydeb Agarwala Vs. Baitulmal Karkhana (1964)16 DLR (SC) 706.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 15—Applicability of the section</strong>—is confined to a case where the vendor purports to sell the whole property making no reference to any co sharer, when in fact a co-sharer exists.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">On a proper reading of section 15 of the Specific Relief Act it becomes plain that this section would have application if the vendor had expressly purported to sell the whole property to the plaintiff, making no reference to any co-sharer. But where (as in the present case) the agreement expressly says that the vendor undertakes to get the property duly and legally conveyed in favour of the vendee by his co-sharer the provisions of sec. 15 of the Specific Relief Act have no application.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">This circumstance makes it clear that the vendor (as in the present case) was not entering into an agreement by which he was obliging himself to convey the whole property to the plaintiff and consequently the provisions of sec Lion 15 cannot be called in aid (to the present case).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Anwara Chowdhury Vs. M. Majid (1964) 16 DLR (SC) 609.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Applicability of the section when a part of a contract can be performed and a part cannot be performed.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Section 15 is applicable only where the defendant made a representation that the whole of the property belonged to him, which eventually turned out not to be correct. The section has no application where the defendant contracted on his behalf and on behalf of a minor and it is found that the contract is unenforceable against the minor. The object of enactment of section 15 is to provide for abatement of compensation when the title of the persons agreeing to sell or lease is defective.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The section applies only when “a party to the contract is unable to perform the whole of his part of it.” A defendant who holds himself out as the owner of the entire property and whose claim turns out not to be correct is the party to the contract who is unable to perform the whole of his part of it, because it was his duty to convey the whole property to the plaintiff. Section 15 applies to him. But when a defendant contracts on his behalf and on behalf of a minor and it is found that the contract is unenforceable against the minor then that defendant is not a party to the contract who is unable to perform the whole of his part of it.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Archana Prasad Nandi, Vs. Miss Chilia Randolph (1980) 32 DLR 118.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.17—Specific performance cannot be enforced in regard to a part only</strong>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is the essence of specific performance that a part only of an agreement ought not to be performed except under special circumstances mentioned in section Ss.14, 15 and 16 of the Specific Relief Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In this case the entire land transferred by the document of 1914 is in existence but claim has been made for a part of the land transferred and, as such, such a suit is barred under section 17 of the Specific Relief Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Tazal Haque Vs. Md. Affan (1965) 17 DLR 613.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—When shares are definite, even though part of the contract is sought to be enforced, if does not offend section 17.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Plaintiffs case that late M.R. entered into a contract with the plaintiff to transfer his property to the plaintiff and in pursuance of the contract the plaintiff made some advances. Before the actual transfer of the property M.R. died leaving behind the plaintiff and the defendant in the case as his heirs and legal representatives and the share which the plaintiff got was 1/4th of the property and remaining 3/4th fell to the share of the defendant. After Mr.’s death plaintiffs filed the present suit against the defendant to transfer the 4th share of the property on the basis of the contract with M.R. Question arose whether the plaintiffs claim in the case amounts to enforcing a part of contract within the meaning of section 17 of the Specific Relief Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held :</strong> In this case after the death of M.R. 1/ 4th share of the property has devolved on the plaintiff and the defendant has inherited the specific 3/4th share of M.R. and it cannot therefore be said thai defendant’s share is either undefined or indivisible.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The share of defendant is well defined and capable of being specifically enforced and if the contract is enforced against the defendant there will be performance of the whole contract and no part will remain unperformed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In granting specific performance against the defendant the obligations under the whole contract arc satisfied and so it cannot be held that in allowing the suit there will be violation of the provisions of section 17 of the Specific Relief Act which prohibits enforcement of a part of contract and, therefore, it cannot be said that it will amount to allowing specific performance of part of the contract.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Nur Nessa Khatun Vs. Saleha Rahman (1974) 26 DLR 347.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—When specific performance of contract cannot be granted</strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">. The general rule of equity is that the Court will not compel specific performance of a contract unless it can enforce the whole contract. This rule is embodied in section 17 of the Specific Relief Act. Under section 17 a contract cannot be specifically enforced in part except under situations provided for under sections 14, 15 &amp; 16 of the said Act. </span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A<em>rchana Prasad Nandi Vs. Miss Chilia Randolph (1980) 32 DLR 118.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 17 and 23</strong>—Contract for reconveyance of property, parties to the contract on each side more than one—One of the several promises may obtain specific performance of contract on payment of the entire consideration money and by impleading the other promises as co-defendants.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The questions which were before the Full Bench for decision were: ‘Whether any one or some of the joint promises under a contract of reconveyance can obtain specific performance of the contract in its entirety;</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Whether specific performance of a part of a contract of reconveyance can be obtained in any case by anyone or some of the joint promises or by all of them jointly;</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Whether the case of Niranian Das Vs. Charu Bala Das reported in 16 DLR 611 has been correctly decided.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held:</strong> Both under the general law of contract and the Specific Relief Act, one or some of the joint premises may obtain specific performance of a contract of reconveyance in its entirety on payment of the whole of the stipulated price, provided the other promises are impleaded in the suit as co-defendants.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A suit for specific performance of a contract of sale or reconveyance at the instance of one or some of the joint premises appears to be maintainable under the provisions of section 23 of the Specific Relief Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">According to clause (a) of section 23 specific performance of contract may be obtained by any party thereto. The expression “any party thereto” in clause (a) does not mean any one of the parties to the contract.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The plain meaning of clause (b) of section 23 appears to be that the representative-in-interest of any one of the several joint promises may claim specific performance of a contract. If that be so, there is no reason why any of the several joint promises should not be entitled to obtain specific performance of a contract under clause (a) of section 23.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Part performance of contract enforceable in relation to cases under sections 15, 16 and 17 of the Specific Relief Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In view of the rigid provision of section 17 of the Specific Relief Act, specific performance of a part of contract can be obtained only in a case covered by any of the sections 14, 15 and 16 of the Specific Relief Act and not otherwise.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">All co-promises under a contract ought to be joined as plaintiffs in a suit where performance of the contract is claimed. Section 45 of the Contract Act appears to be the basis of this rule.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">K<em>abil Mridha Vs. Amena Khatoon (1968) 20 DLR 1027.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 18</strong>—Section 18 of the Specific Relief Act recognizes as enforceable in law the right of a person contracting to purchase or to lake in lease property from person who at the Lime of the contract does not own it but who subsequently acquires it.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Ghulam Mohd. Shah Vs. Fateh Mohd. Shah. (1955) 7 DLR (FC) 70 (77) 1-h.col).</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 20—Where a thing is agreed upon to be done though there is penalty annexed yet the very thing must be done</strong>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Where in a stipulation in a contract for sale of immovable property a penalty is attached to secure the performance of that very thing the person concerned will not be relieved from the specific performance of the thing stipulated to be done.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In cases where there arc penal clauses such clause do not debar the party who has not defaulted from enforcing specific performance as they are not in the nature of alternative stipulations.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Dula Mia Vs. Haji Md. Ibrahim (1956) 8 DLR 616=8 PLR (Dac) 326.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—One of the clauses in the agreement under review ran as follows :-</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">‘If the vendor and the said panel of trustees fail to execute and register the lease in the manner on the (late and at the place aforesaid for any reason whatsoever, the Promises hereby agreed to be demised unto the lessee shall remain charged and shall be available for realisation of the amount paid together with all costs and damages.’</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held :</strong> There is nothing in this clause to indicate that the plaintiff had agreed to abandon his right to specific performance.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Dula Mia Vs. Haji Md. Ibrahim (1956)8 DLR )l(=8 PLR (Dac) 326.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 21(a)(b</strong>)—Government servant—Dismissal from service of a Government servant or an employee of a statutory body—Civil Courts have jurisdiction to go into question whether services validly terminated or not—Suit for declaration that termination of service void, wrongful and inoperative—Cannot be termed as one for enforcing a contract for personal service and dismissed on that score.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mst. Manni Vs. Karachi Cantonment Board. (1969) 21 PLD (Karachi), 304.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 21(b)—A contract of personal service with a private firm—Suit for reinstatement on dismissal does not lie— Suit for damage is the proper course.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A private firm must have a free choice in the matter of appointment and discharge of its employees. A court cannot foist upon an unwilling private firm an employee whom it has thought fit to get rid of, and to that end, rightly or wrongly whom it has discharged, or whom, for one reason or the other, the firm is unwilling to accept. Should an employee, however, feel aggrieved and consider that he has been wrongfully and illegally discharged, all that he can seek from a Court is damage and not his reinstatement, which the Court is not competent at all to order.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Although an employee may establish that he has been wrongly dismissed, still he is not entitled to the remedy of an injunction or of specific performance inasmuch as a contract involving his personal service cannot be specifically enforced in view of section 21(b) of the Specific <em>Relief Act. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Azizar Rahman Vs. Burmah Oil Co. (1961) 13 DLR 458.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.22—Decree for specific performance is discretionary</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Section 22 of the Act provides that the jurisdiction to decree for specific performance is discretionary, but the discretion of the Court is not arbitrary but must be guided by judicial principles and capable of correction by a court of appeal.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Jamaruddin Mandal Vs. Mahiruddin Mandal (1955)7 DLR 642.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Specific performance of a contract may also be refused when its enforcement will involve the Mutawalli in litigation about his authority to transfer.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Administrator of Waqfs Vs. Mst. Sahera Begum (1976) 28 DLR 239.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Discretionary jurisdiction in granting a decree for specific performance should not be arbitrary</strong>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Section 22 of the Specific Relief Act does no doubt provide that the jurisdiction of the Court to pass a decree for specific performance of a contract is discretionary but this discretionary power is not arbitrary.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Administrator of Waqfs Vs. Mst. Sahera Begum (1976) 28 DLR 238.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Specific performance of a contract may be refused where its enforcement will adversely affect third parties or lead to breach of contract or compel the defendant to do an act not lawful.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Administrator of Waqfs Vs. Mst. Sahera Begun (1976)28 DLR 238.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Future eventuality envisaged in the deed of contract may be a ground for repudiation of contract.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Administrator of Waqfs Vs. Mst. Sahera Begun (1976)28 DLR 238.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Relief by grant of specific performance of contract discretionary—4llustrations under section 22 illustrative and not exhaustive.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The illustrations given in section 22 of the Specific Relief Act are not exhaustive but illustrative the said section clearly shows that the Court has discretion to refuse specific performance even it might be lawful.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">To grant specific performance of contract is absolutely within the discretion of the Court and no rigid rule  can be laid down when and where this discretion can be exercised by the Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The sentence before sub-section (1) is not “The following are the cases’ but the sentence is “The following are cases” which shows that it is illustrative cases have not been definitely mentioned we do not find any substance in the contention that the said cases are the only cases where the court is to exercise discretion not to pass decree for specific performance.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Nowab Meah Chowdhury Vs. Ezazuddin Ahmed, (1961) 13 DLR 554.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Contracts more than one covered by same instrument—Each separately enforceable—</strong>When there is more than one contract although 4 by the same instrument, each contract may be separately and independently enforced.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sahebuddin Mondal vs. Md. Aminuddin Mondal (1961) 16 DLR 105.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Time when the essence of contract—</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">The stipulation of the agreement is as follows— “If after establishment of our good title you do not within the stipulated period pay the balance of consideration money and get the kabala executed by us, then only the earnest money paid today will be forfeited and the bainapatra will be null and void.’</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">As the time specified in the agreement for sale was subject to more than one condition, it cannot be said that the parties thereto intended the time mentioned therein to be the essence of the contract.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">E<em>skandar Ali Vs. Musammat Alhamara Begum (1967) 9 DLR 43.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—If time is not made the essence of contract, subsequently it cannot be made so, barring Certain circumstances.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">E<em>skandar Ali Vs. Musammat Alhamara Begum (1967) 9 DLR 43.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.23—</strong>A settlement of land on receipt of a selami and also for consideration of reconveyance of demised land is a completed contract.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In the absence of any term prohibiting the transfer of the right or exercise of the right, to any other person, by the person in whose favour document was executed, the contract is not a personal contract. If there be consideration for the contract, it is a completed contract, and as such, it is assignable under the Specific Relief Act. <em>8 PLR (Dac) 1088.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Pre-emption right available—Specific performance relief will not be granted</strong>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Where specific performance is sought to be enforced against a subsequent purchaser who has got a right of pre-emption the court should, in the exercise of its discretion under section 23, Specific Relief Act, refuse to decree specific performance.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Nowab Meah Chowdhury Vs. Ezazuddin Ahmed (1961) 13 DLR 554.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Section 23 of the Specific Releif Act clearly provides that the specific performance can be enforced by either parties to the contract or their legal representatives. The only bar that has been contemplated in section 23 is that if the contract is of such a personal nature which could not otherwise be enforced then it should not be specifically enforced. There is no other bar provided in the said section 23 of the Specific Relief Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Nur Nesa Khatun Vs. Saleha Rahman (1974) 26 DLR 347.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 23(b)—Contracts, benefit of— assignable, subject to contrary intention which may be either implied or expressed— Personal contracts are not assignable.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">As a general rule, the benefits of a contract arc assignable subject to any contrary intention exhibited in the contract or the document itself.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A contrary intention may either be express or arise by necessary implication. One illustration of the cases in which such a contrary intention is implied is to be found in what arc commonly known as personal contracts or contracts depending upon the learning, skill, solvency or any personal qualification of the assignor or the party to the contract or from whom the benefits of the contract arc claimed under the particular agreement.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Lakshman Mandol Vs. Moslemuddin Sardar (1958)10 DLR 165.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Judgment-debtor in a money decree entering into a contract with a third party whereby the latter undertakes to pay the decretal dues of the judgment- debtor to the decree-holder. In executing the decree, the decree-holder cannot proceed against the third party as he is not the legal representative of the judgment-debtor.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sajedul Huq Vs. Sultan Hassan (1959) 11 DLR 293.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Benefit arising out of a contract of repurchase is assignable—</strong>The right that accrues to a vendor of immovable property on the basis of an agreement to retransfer by the vendee at the time of sale is assignable.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Ratish Chandra Mridha Vs. Hara Krishna Goldar (1963) 15 DLR 634.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">[See under section 21(b) in case of <em>Azizur Rahman Vs. Burmah Oil Co. in 13 DLR 458 above.]</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Right arising Out of a contract, when transferable.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A contractual right without limitation is assignable, transferable and heritable and thus, enforceable under section 23(b) of the Specific Relief Act, by the transferor or his representative-in-interest.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Aftabuddin Meah Vs. Kudrat Ali Miah (1982) 34 DLR 51.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 23 and 27</strong>—Suit must be against the sole contractor or entire body of contractors.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Reading sections 23 and 27 together, it seems that while a contract may be specifically enforced by any of one of the parties to a contract under clause (a) of section 23, a contract may be enforced against the sole contractor or the entire body of contractors and not against any one of them.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The case reported in 15 DLR 611, so far as it decided that only a part of contract of reconveyance cannot be specifically enforced, is not entirely a correct statement of the law.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Kabil Mridha V. Amena Khatoon (1968) 20 DLR. </em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2385	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Specific Relief Act, 1877 [Section 25 - 40]</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1983) 35 DLR 110, (1984) 36 DLR 114,  (1956) 8 DLR 616, (1954) 6 DLR 383, (1957) 9 DLR 476, (1955) 7 DLR 157, (1970) 22 DLR 146, (1969) 21 DLR (WP) 333, (1984) 36 DLR 337, (1984) 36 DLR 337, (1967) 19 DLR (WP) 63, (1965) 17 DLR 119, (1965) 17 DLR 119, (</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Specific Relief </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u> </u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Specific Relief Act</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;">(I of 1877)</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 25</strong>—Contract of sale cannot be enforced in favour of a vendor when he knew that he had no title to the land to be sold—A third party can in such a case be added as a party when he claims the land to be in his possession.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Bajrang Lal Agarwala Vs. Aksed Ali Shaikh. (1983) 35 DLR 110.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 27</strong>—Specific performance of the contract can be enforced against either party to the contract, or against any other who claims title under the original party.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>I.C.I. (Bangladesh) Ltd. Vs. M/s. G.K. Brothers. (1984) 36 DLR 114.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Onus of proof—quantum of onus</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Where in a suit for specific performance against a person who claims title from the vendor under a registered deed, executed after the contract sued upon, the said person claims to be a bona tide purchaser for value without notice of the previous contract, the onus lies upon him to prove that he had no notice of the earlier contract so as to bring himself within the exception provided by clause (b) of section 27 of the Act. With regard to the question as to what should be the quantum of proof that a person claiming to have purchased the property in good faith without notice should offer, it seems that since the onus is to disprove notice, the burden is a light one and may even be shifted by a mere denial of the factum of the notice on oath.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Dula Mia Vs. Haji Md. Ibrahim (1956) 8 DLR 616.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 27(b)— Sale in violation of contract—Document not registered.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Contract for sale of land valued over Rs. 100.00. Sale in violation of contract. Suit for specific performance of contract after the date of sale but before registration with notice to the vendees— Registration being compulsory, suit decreed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Apatarjama Vs. Abdul Karim (1954) 6 DLR 383.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The original contract with defendants 1-5 for the sale of land for Rs.200.O.O. to the plaintiff was on 3rd November, 1936 when some money was paid to the defendants as earnest money and the stipulation was that the balance would be paid in a few days when the transaction would be completed and the document would be registered. In violation of the contract the defendants 1-5 sold the land to defendants 6-8 for Rs. 300.00, on 13th November, 1936, the kabala was registered on 2nd March, 1937.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Plaintiff thereupon instituted a suit for specific performance of the contract on 14th December, 1936 and the summons of that suit were served on the defendants on the 15th January, 1937.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held:</strong> Section 27(b) of the Specific Relief Act merely enacts an equitable rule which allows a later legal title to prevail over an earlier equitable title in the case of bona fide purchaser for value without notice; but if the title is not completed there can be no room for application of that rule; and in completing and perfecting title to immovable property worth Rs. 100.00 and upwards registration is required.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Consequently at the date of service of summonses, that is, 15th January, 1937, the title of the defendants’ appellants was not complete and so they were not transferees within the meaning of section 27(b) of the Specific Relief Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Apatarjama Vs. Abdul Karim. (1954) 6 DLR 383.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A covenant for pre-emption or a covenant giving an option of re-purchase, if entered into after the coming into force of the Transfer of Property Act, does not create any interest in the land itself and the Covenant is merely a personal covenant, binding the parties to the contract, and such covenants can only be enforced by a suit for specific performance under section 27 of Specific Relief Act. Such covenant could be enforced against a transferee only if such a transfer was a gratuitous transfer with notice.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Nagendra Ch. Vs. Parameswar Roy (1957) 9 DLR 476.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Specific performance under section 27 of the Act can be claimed against a party to the contract as well as any other person claiming under him except a transferee for value paid in good faith and without notice of the original contract. A subsequent transferee with notice is in the same position as his vendor, the fact that he is in possession does not affect character of the suit.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdul Kader Bhuiya Vs. Kishori Lal Das (1955) 7 DLR 157.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Possession is notice of title</strong>—There is abundant authority for the proposition that possession is tantamount to notice of title of the party in possession under one title and may at the same time possess a document entitling him to have another interest transferred. The person who purchased the property shall be deemed to have notice of all his rights. <em>1953 PLR (Lah.) 210.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Requirements for subsequent transferee for availing exceptions under section 27(b) are his payment of money, his good faith and absence of notice of original contract.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Mamtazul Karim Vs. Abul Hossain, (1970) 22 DLR 146.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Doctrine of lis pendens</strong>—In a case of specific performance of contract conveyance in favour of the subsequent transferee, executed before but registered after the institution of the suit hit by the doctrine of lis pendens<em>. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Mamtazul Karim Vs. Abul Hossain, (1970) 22 DLR 146.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Bonafide transfer for value without notice—</strong>The plea of the subsequent transferee that he had no notice of the previous sale agreement— Onus lies on him to prove absence of such notice— Mere denial in the written statement that he had no notice of the previous sale not sufficient to discharge onus.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Malik Md. Ishaque Vs. Mirza Almas Ali Beg, (1969) 21 DLR (WP) 333.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Once it is established that the contract was an executory contract and not an executed contract there is hardly any doubt that it would be attracted by section 27(b) of the Specific Relief Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Hafez Ahmed Vs. Obedur Rahman</em> <em>(1955)</em> <em>7DLR 263(265 rt.h.col.).</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 31</strong>—In such matters circumstantial evidence as to subsequent dealing will be relevant.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Shahabuddin Vs. Saijuddin, (1984) 36 DLR 337.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—In such situation a declaratory suit instead of a suit for rectification of document will be admissible even much after a suit for rectification is barred by limitation.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Shahabuddin Vs. Saijuddin. (1984) 36 DLR 337.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Mutual mistake as to description calls for rectification by filing a suit within prescribed period of limitation<em>. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Shahabuddin Vs. Saijuddin. (1984) 36 DLR 337.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—When the terms of a contract are embodied in a document no secondary evidence admissible except under special circumstances.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Shahabuddin Vs. Saijuddin. (1984) 36 DLR 337.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 39—Suit can also be filed by a person against whom instrument is void or void able.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The use of the words “any person” in section 39 of the Specific Relief Act in contradistinction with the words ‘voidable at the option of the party whose consent was so caused” in section 19-A of the Contract Act give a wide scope to section 39 of the Specific Relief Act, and the relief can, therefore, be properly claimed not only by the party to the instrument but any person against whom the instrument is void or voidable.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Muhammad Bashir Vs. Mst. Walayat Begum (1967) 19 DLR (WP) 63.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Plaintiff prayed for declaration that: (1) the documents relating to the properly in Suit were void ab initio and that the defendant acquired no interest in them and (2) that the documents were brought about by forgeries for which no consideration passed. Held—Prayers are purely for declaration only for which a fixed court-fee under Article 17(iii) of the Court-Fees Act payable.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If suit be framed as one for declaration that certain document is void, should it be treated as one coming under section 42 or section 39 of the Specific Relief Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">(Hasan, J)—The first prayer for a declaration that the documents arc void ab initio comes under section 39 of the Specific Relief Act and the second prayer that the defendants have acquired no interest in the premises by virtue of the said documents comes under section 42 of the Specific Relief Act. They are prayer for declaration only and nothing more.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The prayer (b) is nothing but the ground in support of prayer (a). As such the plaintiff is liable to pay fixed court-fee under Article 17(iii), Schedule II of Court-fees Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Court is not bound to give relief for cancellation of a document in every case under section 39 of the Specific Relief Act by canceling the document, whether there is a prayer for cancellation or not.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The language of section 39 does not make it obligatory on the Court to order the instrument to be delivered up or cancelled even if not so prayed for. A relief may be granted when it is prayed for and not otherwise.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Where illegality of the document appears on the face of it, its cancellation may not be necessary. Where a person not a party to the instrument, apprehending injury thereby sues to have it adjudged void or voidable, he is not in a position to pray for cancellation. In such cases plaintiff cannot be compelled to pray for advisories court-fee for it. Where illegality or nullity of the document is non-apparent, the danger of its use in defense is always there and in such cases cancellation and delivering up of the document is necessary and the Court may give such relief. But the relief shall have to be prayed for and unless prayed for, it cannot be granted nor can the plaintiff be forced to pray for it and pay advalorem court fee for it. A suiter has absolute authority to frame his suit as he likes; he may suffer or gain for so doing.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Daibakilal Basak Vs. Iqbal Ahmed Quarishi (1965) 17 DLR 119.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—(Sattar, J.)—</span></strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">The suit as framed is a purely declaratory one in which the document need not be cancelled. Plaintiff is to pay fixed court-fees for declarations separately in respect of several documents.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A document to which the plaintiff is not a party need not be cancelled and mere declaration that it is void is sufficient. Only a document which has vested efface a valid claim, needs to be challenged. A forged document does not come under this category.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If, however, the plaintiff asks for cancellation of a forged document, though such cancellation is not needed, he must pay for it.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If on consideration of the plaint as a whole, the Court finds that there are both prayers for declaration and cancellation is to be ordered having regard to the case made out in the plaint, fixed court-fee under Article 17(iii) Schedule If of the Court-fees Act is not sufficient.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Simply because section 39 of the Specific Relief Act contemplates that relief of cancellation can be granted by the Court, even when the plaintiff has not asked for it, it cannot be said that the plaintiff need not pay for ii. The plaintiff must pay for the relief if it is granted by the Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is not necessary to cancel a document in every case. It depends upon the facts of a case. Relief of cancellation under section 39 need not be specifically asked for in view of the language of the section. It may be granted by the Court. If such a relief has to be given, the plaintiff must pay for it and payment of fixed court-fee for mere declaration is not sufficient.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Daibakilal Basak Vs. Iqbal Ahmed Quarishi (1965) 17 DLR 119</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">(Sayem, J.)—</span></strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">The contention that in a suit under section 39 of the Specific Relief Act, plaintiff need not specifically pray for cancellation and that the section casts a duty on the Court to grant the relief cannot stand.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is only the relief specified in the second paragraph of the section 39 which provides that if the instrument has been registered under the Registration Act, the Court shall, in its discretion, adjudge it void or voidable and order it to be delivered up and cancelled, send a copy of its decree to the registration of- lice for noting the fact of cancellation, and that need not be prayed for. The discretion mentioned in the section cannot relate to adjudgment alone but also to the relief of cancellation. A discretion conferred on the Court cannot be exercised in favour of a party even though the party chooses not to ask for its exercise. It cannot be said that once an instrument is &amp; judged void the discretion of the Court for cancellation is to follow, just as the relief set out in the second paragraph is to follow an order of cancellation.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Daibakilal Basak Vs.
