The right that the plaintiffs wants to assert in support of their claim must be a legal right and the injury that they allege must be legal injury.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The mere prospect or an apprehension of injury would not entitle the plaintiffs to an order of injunction.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Mizanur Rahman Vs Serajuddin Bepari and ors (1981) 33 DLR 212.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—It is now well settled that, apart from the provision of Order 39 a Civil court has power to issue a temporary injunction in the exercise of its inherent jurisdiction.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdul Jalil Munshi Vs. Abu Bakr. Siddique, (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 42.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Court’s power to issue mandatory injunction for demolition of a structure—</strong> If, in a case where an application for temporary injunction is pending, any party to the case in order to defeat the order of the Court which might be passed on such an application erected a wall with undue haste, the Court had inherent jurisdiction to issue a mandatory injunction ordering demolition of-such a wall.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdul Jalil Munshi Vs. Abu Bakr. Siddique, (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 42.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Mandatory injunction on an interlocutory application may be granted to restore status quo.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdul Jalil Munshi Vs. Abu Bakr. Siddique, (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 42.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The state of things existed just at the date of institution of the filed Suit to prevent defendant from doing an act—Defendant to defeat the very purpose for which the suit has been instituted does an act before the interlocutory order reaches him—Court in such case may issue an order in mandatory form to demolish the thing done by defendant.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdul Jalil Munshi Vs. Abu Bakr. Siddique, (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 42.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—First, the plaintiff has to establish a prima fade case. Secondly, it was to be shown that the plaintiff will suffer irreparable loss if the injunction prayed for is not granted and thirdly, the balance of convenience lies in favour of the plaintiff and in favour of granting the temporary injunction prayed for.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mt. Aymun Nessa Vs. Md. Obaidul Haque, (1983)35 DLR 25.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Where relief which the plaintiff claims can be compensated by money on his success, temporary injunction may not be issued.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Jupiter</em> <em>Glass Industries Ltd. Vs. Titas Gas Transmission (1983) 35 DLR 293.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Mandatory injunction as an order of restraint—to prevent continuance of a mischief.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdul Jalil Munshi Vs. Abu Bakr Siddique (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 42.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—When an injunction order may be discharged on hearing the parties.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">There is no doubt that in an exceptional circumstance, as for example in the case of an urgency or where the order of injunction is, on the face of it, without jurisdiction, an application under Order 39, rule 4 of the Code may be made for an ex parte order made under rule 3 of the order but such an application can be disposed of only on hearing the parties on merit, which is likely to be almost similar to the hearing of the parties in pursuance of a notice under rule 3.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdul Jalil Munshi Vs. Abu Bakr Siddique (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 42.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 54</strong>—Grant of perpetual injunction to prevent breach of obligation.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Provisions of section 54 of the Specific Relief Act authorize grant of perpetual injunction to prevent the breach of an obligation existing in favour of the applicant, whether expressly or by implication. The Court may grant perpetual injunction also under the said provisions when the defendant invades or threatens to invade the plaintiffs right to or enjoyment of a property.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>M/s. June Ferguson Vs. Ameenur Rasheed Chowdhury, (1973) 25 DLR 1.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Circumstances when perpetual relief is granted. Perpetual injunction is granted as provided under section 54.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It lays down that an injunction may be granted to prevent the breach of an obligation in favour of the applicant, whether expressly or by implication, provided there exists no measure for ascertaining the actual damage or likely to be caused, by threat of the defendants and where such invasion or threat is such that pecuniary compensation would not afford adequate relief.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>M/S. Hossain Ahmed Vs. HD Hossain, (1980)32 DLR (AD) 223.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—So far as permanent injunctions are concerned it will appear from section 54 of the Specific Relief Act that they are issued only to prevent breach of an obligation existing in favour of the plaintiff. <em>1954 PLR (Lab) 175.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2388	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Specific Relief Act, 1877 [Section 55 - 57]</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>   1955 PLR (Lah.) 242, (1968) 20 DLR 501, (1955) 7 DLR 606, (1970) 22 DLR (SC) 41, (1980) 32 DLR (AD) 223, (1973)25 DLR 69, (1976) 28 DLR 415, (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 42</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Specific Relief</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u> </u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Specific Relief Act</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;">(I of 1877)</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 55</strong>—Section 55 of the Act enables the issue of an injunction “to prevent the breach of an obligation” and to compel performance of acts which are necessary to prevent such breach. <em>1955 PLR (Lah.) 242.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The wall in question was built from days before the filing of the Suit. It is right and proper that the order of its demolition, if at all, by way of mandatory injunction should ordinarily be passed on the conclusion of the stilt.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdul Barik Vs.  Serajul Islam (1968) 20 DLR 501.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Mandatory injunction—The Court can grant u/s. 151 apart from provisions of Order 39.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Court’s power to issue temporary injunction of mandatory nature—</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The view that as the matter of temporary injunction has been dealt with by the Code of Civil Procedure under Order 39, there is no scope for the Court to exercise its inherent jurisdiction cannot be accepted as sound.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Order 39 does not exhaustively deal with the granting of temporary injunction and so apart from the provisions of Order 39 the Court can grant temporary injunction in the exercise of its inherent jurisdiction.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The tenant had filed an application for temporary injunction restraining the landlord from proceeding with the new construction on the suit premises. The landlord contested that application. Just before delivery of the Judgment in the injunction matter the landlord with indecent haste constructed a wall in order to defeat the order of the Court by doing the act which the temporary injunction intended to restrain.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held</strong>: In a case of this description the Court would if necessary proceed not only to grant a temporary injunction restraining further erection of the building, but also to direct that the building already erected be taken down.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">An injunction restraining a person from causing an injury may from the very circumstances of the case be of mandatory nature.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is no answer to such injunction that in effect the defendant is compelled to perform certain acts which ordinarily would be subject of a mandatory injunction. And if for some reason the Court finds it necessary to issue a temporary mandatory injunction it cannot be said that such an injunction is beyond its inherent power.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">On an interlocutory application the Court has inherent jurisdiction to order demolition of a wall which was erected in defiance of the authority of the Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>The National Bank of India Ltd. Vs. Yakub Mia of Yakub Stores (1955) 7 DLR 606.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 56(b)—</strong>Section 56(b) of the Specific Relief Act recognizes the power to stay judicial proceedings by injunction though it restricts the power so far as permanent injunction is concerned to courts subordinate to the court issuing the injunction. <em>(1955) PLR (Lah) 242.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">S. 56(d)—</span></strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">section 56(d) of the Act does not lay down that an injunction cannot be granted to interfere with the public duties of any department of Provincial Government, but one could hardly imagine a tortuous act of an officer of Government to be a “public duty”. <em>(1955) PLR (Lah) 242.</em></span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Even if section 56 does not limit court’s inherent power to grant temporary injunction against Government department, Court must not do so unless compelling reasons demand that course.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Shahzada Muhammad Umar Beg Vs. Sultan Mahmood Khan (1970) 22 DLR (SC) 41.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 56(d)(f</strong>)—Injunction cannot be granted when it will interfere with the carrying on of public duties.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Section 56, clauses (d) and (f) provide that no injunction can be granted to interfere with the public duties of any Department of the Government or for that matter to prevent the breach of a contract the performance of which would not be specifically enforced.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Contract, when can be validly revoked—The respondent’s tenders were not accepted. In others words, proposal made by them for supplying the labour and transport was not accepted. Therefore, no jural relationship was crcated.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>M/s. Hossain Ahmed Vs. M/s. HD Hossain &amp; Brothers (1980) 32 DLR (AD) 223.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Tender offering lowest quotation does not acquire a legal right that of being accepted in preference to others on the ground of its being the lowest quotation.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>M/s. Hossain Ahmed Vs. M/s. HD Hossain &amp; Brothers (1980) 32 DLR (AD) 223.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 56(i)—Provisions explained</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">— Provisions of section 6 are referable only to perpetual injunction as laid down under section 54.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Mere availability of equally efficacious relief would not go against the case of irreparable injury while deciding the question of granting temporary injunction.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The contention that section 85(I)(c) and (2) of the East Bengal Non-Agricultural Tenancy Act, 1949 and section 56(d) and (i) of Specific Relief Act will stand as bar to granting temporary injunction is not sustainable.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sk. Nur Mohammad Vs. The Province of East Pakistan, (1973)25 DLR 69.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.57—Implied negative covenant when cannot be imputed. </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">When the positive part of the agreement cannot be enforced by an injunction, the same object cannot be achieved by imputing an implied negative covenant in the agreement and enforce it under the provision of section 57 of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Modern Talkies Vs. Chowrangee Cinema Hall (1976) 28 DLR 415.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Chapter II</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Specific performance of contract in respect of movable property—principles to be followed.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In a suit for specific performance of a contract of movable property which can only be instituted under section 58 of the Sale of Goods Act the Court is to be guided by the principles laid down in Chapter II of the Specific Relief Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mr. Bazlur Rahman Bhuiyan Vs. Bangladesh</em> <em>Shipping Corporation (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 42.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2389	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Stamp Act, 1899</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1951)3 DLR 134,  (1969) 21 DLR 119, (1960) 12 DLR 466, (1976) 28 DLR 314, (1966) 18 DLR 588, (1954) 6 DLR 50,  (1953)5 DLR (WP) 134, (1955) 7DLR (WP) 102, (1966) 18 DLR 588, (1976) 28 DLR 314, (1979) 31 DLR (AD)-312, (1968) 20 DLR 196, (1976) 28 DLR 314</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Stamp </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Stamp Act (II of 1899)</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.1(2)—</strong>An. advocate enrolled in Calcutta High court before the 15th August, 1947, seeking enrolment in East Bengal High Court, is not liable to pay stamp duty under Stamp Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Ref No.1 of 1951 under Arc. 30, Stamp Act Bar Association, Dhaka high Court Vs. Chairman, Bar Council, Dhaka (1951)3 DLR 134.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 2(5)(b)—</strong>The document referred to above comes within the definition of bond as laid down in section 2(5)(b) of the Stamp Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A. promissory note written on a hundi paper and attested but not made payable to the bearer or to cider is a bond falling within the purview of s. 2(5) (b)of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In the instant case, the document is attested by witnesses and although there is an obligation to pay a sum of money, it is not payable to bearer or to order, Thus the document is a bond within the meaning of section 2(5)(b) of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Md. <em>Azizur Rahman Vs. Mustafizur Rahman, (1969) 21 DLR 119.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.2(10)—</strong>If a vendor can convey a property without an instrument of sale-deed, he can do it and an escape payment of stamp duty.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Enayet Hossain Chowdhury Vs. Member, Board of Revenue (1960) 12 DLR 466.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A deed weather was a deed of sale or mere contract of sale—Opinion of the Special Bench differed; the majority view, on the contents of the documents, held ii was a deed of sale and imposition of penalty by the Collector was justified, while Chowdhury, 3. held the view that the deed was a mere contract of sale and not a deed of sale.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Enayet Hossain Chowdhury Vs. Member, Board of Revenue. (1960) 12 DLR 466.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">(The Supreme Court subsequently upheld the view of Chowdhury, J.)</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 2(11)—”</strong>Duly stamped”—Explained S. 11 (c): Transfer of company’s share by endorsement.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The words ‘duly stamped’ in s. 2(11) of the Stamp Act mean that the instrument bears an adhesive or impressed stamp of not less than the proper amount and that such stamp has been affixed or used in accordance with the law for the time being in force. The law for the time being in force contemplates under section 11(e) that transfers by endorsement of shares in any company may be stamped with adhesive stamps.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sudhangshu Shekhar Vs. Anath Bandhu (1976) 28 DLR 314.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 2(14) and 3</strong>— An award by an arbitrator is like a decree of the Court—Such an award is not an instrument within the meaning of section 3 of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Province of East Pak. Vs. Najibur Rahman (1966) 18 DLR 588.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.2(22)—</strong>In order to determine whether an instrument is a promissory note it must be seen whether substantially ‘it only contains a promise to pay a defined sum of money and nothing more.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Benoy Bhusan Saha Vs. Md. Abdus Samad (1954) 6 DLR 50.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.3</strong>—Where a deed clearly purports to be an agreement to sell and purchase at a future date, the purchase was to be completed and a deed executed. Whether a deed was subsequently executed or not is irrelevant. If a deed purports to be an agreement of sale and law recognizes a distinction between such an agreement and an actual sale, the document should be stamped an agreement and not as a conveyance.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Geofrey Mrnners &amp; Co. Bombay Vs. Geofrey Maimers &amp; Co. Pakistan (1953)5 DLR (WP) 134.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Section 3 of the Stamp Act makes only “instruments” liable to duty and not “transactions.”</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Geofrey Manners &amp; Co. Bombay Vs. Geofrey Manners &amp; Co. Pakistan (1953)5 DLR (WP) 134.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—An affidavit sworn in relation to the grant of succession certificate and filed in Court does n&amp; require to be stamped as it was for “immediate” use within the meaning of exemption (b) in Art. 4 of Schedule I of the Stamp Act of 1899. The word “immediate” refers to purpose and not to time.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Begum Zebeda Khatun (1955) 7DLR (WP) 102.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Proviso: Proviso does not exclude an award made</strong> <strong>in favour of the Government.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The word “execute” in the proviso to section 3 of the Stamp Act is used when documents of transfer are drawn up inter-parties. An award is not executed nor can a decree be said to be executed by the Court. An award is made and signed by the Arbitrator just as a decree is made and signed by the Court. Therefore, the proviso to section 3 of the Act dock not except the award made in favour of the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Province of East Pak. Vs. Najibur Rahman (1966) 18 DLR 588.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Unless due stamp has been paid on it, an award cannot be taken into consideration by Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Province of East Pak. Vs. Najibur Rahman (1966) 18 DLR 588.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 3 and 2(14)—</strong> An award by an arbitrator is like a decree of the Court—Such an award is not an instrument within the meaning of section 3 of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Province of East Pak. Vs. Najibur Rahman (1966) 18 DLR 588</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.10—</strong> Instrument with an un-cancelled stamp admitted in evidence—This does not render it invalid but is to be impounded.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sudhangshu Shekhar Vs. Anath Bandhu (1976) 28 DLR 314</em><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Stamps not cancelled before filing is no ground to reject the instrument.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Anath Bandhu Guha Vs. Sudhansu Sekhar Dey (1979) 31 DLR (AD)-312</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 11(e) &amp; 12—</strong>Transfer-scripts though duly stamped but the stamps were not cancelled. Transfer- scripts cannot be treated invalid for that reason and the stamps can be cancelled at any moment under Courts’ order.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sirajuddin A Kader Vs. Chittaranjan Cotton Mills Ltd. (1968) 20 DLR 196.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 11(e)—</strong> Transfer of company’s share by endorsement.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The words ‘duly stamped’ in s. 2 (11) of the Stamp Act mean that the instrument bears an adhesive or impressed stamp of not less than the proper amount and that such stamp has been affixed or used in accordance with the law for the Lime being in force. The law for the time being in force contemplates under section 11(e) that transfers by endorsement of shares in any company may be stamped with adhesive stamps.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sudhangshu Shekhar Vs. Anath Bandhu (1976) 28 DLR 314.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.12</strong>—Cancellation of a stamp is a question of fact. Object of cancellation is to prevent its use over again.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Cancellation of the adhesive stamps should be in a manner that it cannot be used again. The adhesive stamps affixed in the impugned deed have writing on it ‘cancelled’ on each of the stamps. It is contended that it does not fulfill the requirement as indicated in section 13(3) of the Stamp Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The question arises as to whether the effective cancellation of the stamps contemplated in section 12 of the Stamp Act is a question of fact. The object of effectively canceling stamps is to make it unfit for further use in the ordinary course of business. The effectiveness of cancellation has to be determined by reference to the question whether if it be removed from the document it could be used again. This question must obviously be considered with reference to facts of each particular case.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The words “so that it cannot be used again’ occurring in sub-clause (l)(a) of section 12 of the Stamp Act means merely such cancellation as will prevent the stamp being lawfully or conscientiously used again.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Now that the document has been produced before the authority as an evidence of transfer and if the authority finds that the stamps do not show that these were used before and act upon it, the party gets the desired object. But if thereafter the stamp is stolen and used by any other person then it would only bring that person within the mischief of sub-clause (3) of section 12 the Stamp Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">J<em>abed Ali Vs. Dr. Sultan Ahmed (1975) 27 DLR (SC) 78</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Mode of cancellation of a stamp is a question of fact.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The mode of cancellation is a question of fact and since this has been decided by the Courts below, we find no substance in the contention of the learned Counsel.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">J<em>abed Ali Vs. Dr. Sultan Ahmed (1975) 27 DLR (SC) 78</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Fixed adhesive stamps, not cancelled</strong>—<strong>effect.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Section 12 of the Stamp Act provides that whoever affixed any adhesive stamp shall cancel the same so that it cannot be used again; any instrument bearing an adhesive stamp which has not been cancelled, shall be decided to be unstamped.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sudhangshu Shekhar Vs. Anath Bandhu (1976) 28 DLR 314.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.13</strong>—Cancellation of a stamp is a question of fact. Object of cancellation is to prevent its use over again.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Cancellation of the adhesive stamps should be in a manner that it cannot be used again. The adhesive stamps affixed in the impugned deed have a writing on it ‘cancelled’ on each of the stamp. It is contended that it does not fulfill the requirement as indicated in section 13(3) of the Stamp Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">J<em>abed Ali Vs. Dr. Sultan Ahmed (1975) 27 DLR (SC) 78</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.17, Art 40(b)</strong>—Agreement to sell property—Earnest money to be treated as charge on property in case of non-performance of contract— Agreement does not become mortgage deed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Where there is an agreement to sell the property in dispute on certain terms and conditions. In the document itself it is stated that as long as the contract is not performed, the amount advanced as earnest-money will be treated as charge on the property agreed to be sold. Even if this stipulation had not been made in the document, any amount paid in advance Cowards the agreement of sale is a charge under section 55, sub-section 6(b) of the Transfer of Property Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">By incorporating such a term, an agreement of sale cannot be considered to be an instrument whereby, for the purposes of securing money advanced or to be advanced by way of loan or an existing or future debt, or the performance of an engagement, one person transfers, or creates, to, or in favour of another a right over or in respect of specified property. The document did not require to be stamped as a mortgage deed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Moosa</em> <em>Vs. Mohd. Yakoob, PLD 1966 (WP) Karachi 376 (DB).</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.18—</strong>Foreign document not stamped according to section 18 is a document not “duly stamped” and may be admitted in evidence on payment of stamp and penalty in terms of section 35.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Punjab National Bank Vs. M/s. Dewan &amp; Co. (1955) 7 DLR (WP) 65.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.18(2)—</strong>Foreign document should be presented 10 Collector within 3 months of receipt in Pakistan for being stamped—Document presented afterwards should be impounded.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Punjab National Bank Vs. M/s. Dewan &amp; Co. (1955) 7 DLR (WP) 65.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 25 &amp; 49-—Acknowledgement by a fresh writing on the original document of debt (which document has been duly stamped) does not require to be stamped.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The contention raised was since the letter (under consideration) amounts to an agreement for payment of the debt it was a fresh contract and therefore it is required to be stamped under section 49 of the Stamp Act and as in this case it was not stamped it was not admissible in evidence under Section 25 of the Stamp Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held:</strong> So far as the original debt is concerned it was executed on duly stamped promissory note. Therefore the stamp duty required to be paid for the original debt has been paid. No fresh transaction was created by what has been written in the said letter. The letter is merely a promise to pay original debt.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is only in the case of a fresh transaction that further stamp duly is called for.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Tripura Modern Bank Ltd Vs. Elahi Baksha (196) 18 DLR 498.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 27, 64</strong>—Award—Omission to mention amount with regard to which award was given— Award not stamped—Liable to penalty under s. 64.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Where in an award given by a Superintending Engineer, the finding was that nothing was due to the contractor from Government, but the written award did not set out the amount of the claim to which the award was related.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held:</strong> that the omission was a contravention of s.27 of the Stamp Act (II of 1899) and was liable to a penalty under s.64 of the Act if the intention was to defraud the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The question whether any proceeding should be taken against the arbitrator was left for consideration to the Collector who was the authority to initiate proceedings under s.70.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Pakistan Contractors Co. Vs. Pakistan PLD 1958 (WP) Kar. 648.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 29—Section 29</strong> will only be applicable to a case where the document is not produced before the court. When the document is produced before the Court and tendered in evidence the stamp duty is to be recovered under s.44. <em>1937 (Mad) 763 :174 (IC) 20.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 30</strong>—When a creditor receives money exceeding Rs.20 or any movable property of the like value in satisfaction of debt it is obligatory on him to give a duly stamped receipt. Where immovable property valued more than Rs. 20 is delivered in satisfaction of debt no receipt need be given. <em>1932 Nag. 172 :140 (IC) 397.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss.31, 32</strong>—Limitation for applying to Collector for adjudication as to proper stamp duty—No period prescribed—Procedure applicable where document is brought to collector within or after one month of its execution.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It cannot be said that ss. 31 and 32 contained in Chapter 111 Form 1 integrated procedure for adjudication as to stamps and that the limit referred to in provision (a) to s.32 governs applications made under s.31. Section 31 provides no time limit for an application to the Collector for adjudication as to the proper stamp duty payable in respect of an instrument. There is nothing in the section to prevent a person from resorting to the Collector for adjudication as to proper stamp duty even after the expiry of one month from the date of its execution. If the instrument is brought to the Collector within one month of its execution, the applicant would be entitled to have the Collector’s certificate endorsed on the instrument on payment of the deficit duty. if any, but without having to pay any penalty. But if he seeks the Collector’s adjudication beyond the time specified in s.32, the Collector has, under s.33, to impound the instrument and proceed under s.40 to decide whether the instrument is duly stamped and to require the payment of the additional duty chargeable in respect of the instrument together with the prescribed penalty in case he is of opinion that it is not duly stamped. On payment of such duty and penalty a certificate that the proper duty and penalty have been paid has to be endorsed under s.42 on the instrument which becomes thereupon admissible in evidence and may be acted upon as if it had been duly stamped.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sethuraman Vs. Rama Nathan AIR 1946 (Mad) 437.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.32—</strong>The decision of the Collector is final if he has granted a certificate on the document. It is not open to the Civil Court to question the endorsement. 2942 (Mad) 381 :202 (IC) 77.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Ss.33, 38(2)—</span></strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Improperly stamped document produced before Civil Judge—Procedure to be adopted—Civil Judge has no jurisdiction to impose a penalty.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Under section 33, Stamp Act, 1899, a Civil Judge had authority to impound the document if he was of the opinion (as he was) that it was not sufficiently stamped. He could admit the document in evidence if eleven times the stamp duty was paid. If the document was not admitted in evidence, then section 38(2) was applicable and the document was to be sent to the Collector. Under section 38(2) he could only send the document to the Collector and he had no power to impose a penalty.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Ghulam Farid Vs. Board of Revenue, W. Pakistan PLD 1960 (WP) (Lah) 211—PLR 1960(2) WP 581 (OB)</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.34—</strong>A company shall not register a transfer unless the instrument of transfer is duly stamped.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sudhangshu Shekhar Vs. Anath Bandhu (1976) 28 DLR 314.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 35—</strong> <em>[Sec under Art. 5 in case of Kutubuddin Ahmed Vs. Al Firidwan Iiddin in 14 DLR 129 below]</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 35 and Art. 45</strong>—In the instant case the final decree was passed on 30.11.54 but the decree was drawn and signed on 22.5.65. The decree could not be drawn and signed earlier as the required stamp- paper was not put in. A decree in a partition suit is an instrument of partition which is chargeable with stamp duty under Article 45 of the Stamp Act. 1899, and unless it is duly stamped the decree is not a4missible in evidence as provided in section 35 of the Stamp Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>AminullahBhuiyan Vs. Abdul Hafiz (1981)33 DLR (AD) 282.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.35</strong>—Foreign document not stamped according to section 18 is a document not “duly stamped” and may be admitted in evidence on payment of stamp and penalty in terms of section 35.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Punjab National Bank Vs. M/s. Dewan &amp; Co. (1955) 7 DLR (WP) 65.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Penalty—Court’s power to impose</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The petitioner, a defendant in a civil suit, produced a document purporting to be a receipt. The Civil Judge trying the suit being of the opinion that it was a conveyance directed him to pay the deficiency in stamp and penalty equal to ten times the deficiency. He sent a robkar for recovery of the amount to the Collector who acting on the robkar proceeded to recover the amount.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held</strong>: The Civil Judge had no power to impose the penalty. Under s.35 of the Stamp Act he could allow the document to be admitted in evidence on payment of the stamp duty and ten times thereof as penalty but it was optioned for the party producing the document not to pay or to pay in order to get the document admitted in evidence. If eleven times the stamp duty was not paid, the only function left with the Court was to send the document to the Collector who was then bound under section 40 to determine whether the instrument was properly stamped and if he found that it was not so stamped to pass an order requiring payment of the duty and the penalty. <em>PLR (1960)2 WP 581.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Partition, instrument of—unstamped</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">“Unstamped memoranda of a partition which require to be stamped as constituting an instrument of partition cannot be admitted in evidence even for any purpose.”</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Aminullah Bhuiyan Vs. Abdul Hafiz (1981)33 DLR (AD) 282.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 35, 36—Instruments which have not been</strong> <strong>duly stamped but was admitted in evidence can be acted on under section 36.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Section 35 of the Stamp Act prohibits a Court from admitting in evidence any instrument which in its view is not duly stamped. This section also prohibits the Court from acting on such document. If the Court, however, wrongly admits such a document, the Appellate Court is prevented by section 36 of the Stamp Act from calling in question the admission in evidence of such an instrument, thought it may have been wrongly admitted.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A failure to comply with the Stamp Act may entail penalty. But the whole proceeding should not be vitiated and thrown away for want of stamp.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Amin Jute Balinyy Co. Vs. Aminpur Union Cooperative (1960) 12 DLR 590.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Instruments not duly stamped admissible in evidence—</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It was contended in the Appellate Court on behalf of the defendant appellant that the hand-note, which was chargeable with a stamp duty of 4 annas, was stamped with a stamp duty of 2 annas only and hence was not admissible in evidence in view of the provisions of section 35 of the Stamp Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held</strong>: Section 36 of the Stamp Act makes it reasonably clear that the instrument having once been admitted in evidence is not to be called in question at any stage of the same suit.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Under section 36, it matters little, whether it was wrongly admitted or rightly admitted or admitted without objection or after hearing or without hearing such objection.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">There is no warrant for introducing the limitation that the words “admitted in evidence” as qualifying the plain language of section 36 of the Stamp Act. The words “admitted in evidence” cannot mean admitted in evidence as a result of the judicial determination of the question whether it can be admitted in evidence or not for want of stamp.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdul Hashem Vs. Serajul Haque (1961)13 DLR 16.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S .35(a)—Penalty, amount of.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Penalty payable is ten times of the duty in accordance with the provisions of clause (a) of the proviso to section 35 of the Stamp Act The Court has no discretion in the matter.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Azizur Rahman Vs. Mustafizur Rahman, (1969) 21 DLR 119.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.36—Document admitted in evidence, if can be rejected.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The provision of section 36 of the Stamp Act is mandatory which provides that except for reason laid down in section 61 of the Act once a document is admitted in evidence it is not permissible for the Court to reject its evidence on the ground that it has not been duly stamped.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Benoy Bhusan Saha Vs. Md. Abdul Samad (1954) 6 DLR 50. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>“Admitted in evidence”—means—</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The expression “admitted in evidence” in section 36 means the act of letting the document in as part of the evidence a result of judicial determination of the question whether it can be admitted in evidence.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Benoy Bhusan Saha Vs. Md. Abdul Samad (1954) 6 DLR 50.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Document admitted cannot be questioned afterwards on the ground of stamp.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Punjab National Bank Vs. M/s. Dewan &amp; Co. (1955) 7DLR (WPC) 65.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Ss. 38(2), 33—</span></strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">improperly stamped document produced before Civil Judge—Procedure to be adopted—Civil Judge has no jurisdiction to impose a penalty.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Under Section 33, Stamp Act, 1899, a Civil Judge had authority to impound the document if he was of the opinion (as he was) that it was not sufficiently stamped. He could admit the document in evidence if eleven times the stamp duty was paid. If the document was not admitted in evidence, then section 38(2) was applicable and the document was to be sent to the Collector. Under section 38(2) he could only send the document to the Collector and he had no power to impose a penalty.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Ghulam Farid Vs. Board of Revenue, W. Pakistan PLD 1960 (WP) (Lah) 211—PLR 1960(2) WI 581 (DB).</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 40—Civil Judge imposing penalty—Collector refusing to follow section 40. Revision petition to the Board of Revenue whether to be made through Commissioner.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The petitioner, a defendant in a civil suit, produced a document purporting to be a receipt. The Civil Judge trying the suit being of the opinion that it was conveyance directed him to pay the deficiency in stamp and penalty equal to Len times the deficiency. He sent a robkar for recovery of the amount to the Collector who, acting on the robkar, proceeded to recover the amount. The petitioner applied to the Collector for withdrawal of the proceedings contending that the Civil Judge had no power to impose the penalty, that the Collector should follow the procedure under section 40, Stamp Act and that under section 29, it was not the petitioner but the executants of the document who was liable for stamp duty. The Collector rejected the application. The petitioner applied to the Board of Revenue, the Chief Controlling Revenue Authority under section 56. The Board of Revenue rejected the application on the ground that according to the Government instruction contained in paragraph 43 of the Stamp Manual the application should come through the Divisional Commissioner with his comments. The petitioner applied to the Court for interference in writ jurisdiction.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held:</strong> The Civil Judge had no power to impose the penalty. Under s. 35, tie could allow the document to be admitted in evidence on payment of the stamp duty and ten times thereof as penalty but it was optional for the party producing the document not to pay or to pay in order to get the document admitted in evidence If eleven times the tamp duty was not paid, the only function left with the Court was to send the document to the Collector who was then bound under section 40 to determine whether the instrument was properly stamped and if he found that it was not so stamped to pass an order requiring payment of the duty and the penalty.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held further</strong> (a) that it was not open to the Chief Controlling Revenue Authority to give directions as to the manner in which petitions for revision were to be presented to it;</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">(b) that the law had given no authority to the Commissioner to influence the views of the Chief Controlling Revenue Authority and this could not be provided for by administrative instructions of the Government contained in paragraph 43 of the Stamp Manual.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">(c) That the Chief Controlling Revenue Authority could not refuse to exercise its jurisdiction under section 56 though, after considering a case, it could pass such orders as it thought fit. <em>2 PLR (1960) (WP)581.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 49 &amp; 25—Acknowledgement by a fresh writing on the original document of debt (which document has been duly stamped) does not require to be stamped.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The contention raised was since the letter (under consideration) amounts to an agreement for payment of the debt it was afresh contract and therefore it is required to be stamped under section 49 of the Stamp Act and as in this case it was riot stamped it was not admissible in evidence under section 25 the Stamp Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Held: So far as the original debt is concerned it was executed on duly stamped promissory note. Therefore the stamp duty required to be paid for the original debt has been paid. No fresh transaction was created by what has been written in, the said letter. The letter is merely a promise to pay the original debt. It is only in the case of a fresh transaction that further stamp duty is called for<em>. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Tripura Modern Bank Lid. Vs. Elahi Baksha (1966) 18 DLR 498.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Ss. 57,59—</span></strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">An opinion expressed by a Bench of the High Court under section 9 of the Stamp Act on a reference under section 57 of the Act was in nature advisory and could not he subject-matter of an appeal to the Supreme Court. <em>PLR (1960) 2 WP 467.</em></span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 61</strong>—<strong>Document admitted in evidence, if can by rejected.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The provision of section 36 of the Stamp Act is mandatory which provides that except for reason laid down in section 61 of the Act once a document is admitted in evidence it is not permissible to Court to reject its evidence on the ground that it has not been duly stamped.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Benoy Bhusan Saha Vs. Md. Abdul Samad (1954) 6 DLR 50.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 61(2)—</strong>Document not bearing the required stamp—Directed to be impounded under section 61 (2) and ordered to pay penalty at 10 times the amount of stamp duty.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Al-Hajj Kutubuddin Vs. AJ Hridwan Uddin (1962) 14 DLR 129.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 64, 27</strong>—.-Award-—Admission to mention amount with regard to which award was given— Award not stamped—Liable to penalty under s.64.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Where in an award given by a Superintendirig Engineer, the finding was that nothing was due to the contractor from Government, but the written award did not set out the amount of the claim to which the award was related.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held:</strong> that die omission was a contravention of s.27 of the Stamp Act (II of 1899) and was liable to a penalty under s.64 of the Act if the intention was to defraud the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The question whether any proceeding should be taken against the arbitrator was left for consideration by the Collector who was the authority to initiate proceedings under s.70.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Pakistan Contractors Co. Vs. Pakistan PLD 1958 (WP) Kar. 648.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Articles</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Art.4—</strong>An affidavit sworn in relation to the grant of succession certificate and filed in Court does not require to be stamped as it was for ‘immediate use within the meaning of exemption (b) in Article 4 of Schedule I of the Stamp Act. The word “immediate” refers to purpose and not to time<em>. Begum Zubeda Khatun (1955) 7 DLR (WP) 102.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Art.5—</strong>Stamp duty on lease which operates as a lease in praesenti and not a mere agreement to lease.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Stamp duty on lease, including an under-lease or sub-lease and any agreement to let or sub-let is payable under Article 35 of Schedule IA to the Stamp Act as in force in East Pakistan. But an agreement to let or sub-let which does not operate as a lease in praesenti falls under Article 5 for the purpose of stamp duty.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Al-Haji Kutubuddin Vs. AJ Hridwan Uddin (1962)14 DLR 129.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Art.23—</strong>The stamp duty required to be paid on the deed of gift is the same as on a conveyance which is provided or by item 23 of the Schedule I of the Stamp Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Nabadwip Ch. Karmakar Vs. Madhu Sudan Kurmakar (1955) 7 DLR 235.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Art.30</strong>—The expression “Any High Court” occurring in Article 30 of Schedule I to the Stamp Act will mean any High Court in British India, if the reference is to the point of time before the 15th August, 1947, and to a High Court in Pakistan if the reference is toy time after the appointed day.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The word “entry” so far as Pakistan is concerned will relate to all entries present or future, on and from the 15th August 1947. The expression ‘previously been enrolled in High Court’ includes and extends to enrolment made in a High Court in British India before the 15th August 1947.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The previous enrolment (i.e. enrolment before the appointed day) in any of the High Courts in British India would entitle an Advocate, who seeks subsequent entry on the roll of the High Court of East Bengal, to exemption from payment of stamp duty under Article 30 of the Stamp Act; but an Advocate enrolled in any Indian High Court after the appointed day is not so exempted. Refer. No.1 of 1951 under Article 30, Stamp Act. <em>(1951) 3 DLR 133.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Art. 35</strong>—Stamp duty on lease which operates as a lease in praesenti and not a mere agreement to lease.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Stamp duty on lease, including an under-lease or sub-lease and any agreement to let or sub-let, is payable under Article 35 of Schedule IA to the Stamp Act as in force in East Pakistan. But an agreement to let or sub-let which does not operate as a lease in praesenti falls under Article 5 for the purpose of stamp duty.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Al-Hajj Kutubuddin Vs. AJ Haridwan Uddin (1962)14 DLR 129.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Art.40(b)—</strong>Respondent mortgaged his properties, as a security for obtaining loan to the Bangladesh Shilpa Rin Sangstha—But so far as the Bank of CC International is concerned it is a first security for which stamp-duty under clause (b) of the Act is chargeable.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Chairman National Board of Revenue Vs. GMG Corpn. (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 263.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Respondent executed a promissory note for the purpose of hypothecation to the Bank of CCI, but the present document is a first Document as a Mortgage deed to the Bank and as such it is an original mortgage transaction.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Chairman National Board of Revenue Vs. GMG Corpn. (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 263.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The instrument in question shows clearly that the mortgage was intended by the respondent in favour of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International, notwithstanding their earlier hypothecation and pledge of goods by execution of promissory note etc in favour of the same bank. If that is the position, as it appears to be so, Article 40 is attracted.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Where the mortgagor gives to the mortgagee a power of attorney to collect rent of a lease of the property mortgaged or part thereof it is deemed to give possession within the meaning of the article. That means in such case it will come under clause (a) and not (b).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Chairman, National Board of Revenue Vs. GMG Corpn. (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 263.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Present mortgage-deed is not a collateral security and does not relate to any previous mortgage in favour of Bank of CCI—If it had been in favour of Shilpa Rin Sangstha, it would be collateral security.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Chairman, National Board of Revenue Vs. GMG Corpn. (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 263.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Agreement to sell property—Earnest money to be treated as charge on property in case of non- performance of contract—Agreement does not become mortgage deed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Where there is an agreement to sell the property in dispute on certain terms and conditions. In the document itself it is stated that as long as the contract is not performed, the amount advanced as earnest-money will be treated as charge on the property agreed to be sold. Even if this stipulation had not been made in the document, any amount paid in advance towards the agreement of sale is a charge under section 55, sub-section 6(b) of the Transfer of Property Act. By incorporating such a term, an agreement of sale cannot be considered to be an instrument whereby, for the purposes of securing money advanced or to be advanced by way of loan or an existing or future debt, or the performance of an engagement, one person transfers, or creates, to or in favour of another a right over or in respect of specified property. The document did not require to be stamped as a mortgage deed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Moosa Vs. Mohd. Yakoob, PLD 1966 (WP) Karachi 376 (DB).</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Art. 40 (c)</strong>—Mortgage-deed is a security in addition to the securities already furnished, in favour of the same lender and in respect of the same loan.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Chairman, National Board of Revenue, Bangladesh Vs. M/s. GMG Corporation Ltd. (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 262.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Mortgage-deed in question is a collateral/ auxiliary security in relation to the demand promissory note and the hypothecation deed which are the primary and principal security w repayment of the same loan and as such this mortgagc-deed is chargeable under clause (C) of Article 40.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Chairman, National Board of Revenue, Bangladesh Vs. M/s. GMG Corporation Ltd. (1983)35 DLR (AD) 262.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Clause(c) applies to mortgage-deed when it is a collateral or additional security, which means a Security in addition to a security already furnished.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Chairman, National Board of Revenue, Bangladesh Vs. M/s. GMG Corporation Ltd. (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 262.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Security already furnished by executing a demand promissory note and a hypothecation deed in respect of movables—Mortgage-deed in respect of immovable is nothing but a collateral or anxiliary security and therefore is covered by clause(c) of Art. 40.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Chairman, National Board of Revenue, Bangladeshdesh Vs. M/s. GMG Corporation Ltd. (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 262.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Mortgage in this case falls in the category of collateral security and not that of primary security.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Chairman, National Board of Revenue, Bangladesh Vs. M/s. GMG Corporation Ltd. (1983) 35 DLR (AD), 262.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Art.45</strong>—The stamp duty required to be paid on a deed of partition under item 45 of Schedule I to the Stamp Act is the same as that item 15 for the amount of the value of the separated shares of the property and in the note it is clear that if there were two or more shares of equal value and not smaller than any of the other shares, then one of them would be property on which stamp duty will have to be paid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Nabadwip Ch. Karmakar Vs. Modhu Sudan Karmakar (1955) 7 DLR 235</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—In the instant case the final decree was passed on 30.11.54 but the decree was drawn and signed on 22.5.65. The decree could not be drawn and signed earlier as the required stamp paper was not put in. A decree in a partition Suit 1S an instrument of partition which is chargeable with stamp duty under Article 45 of the Stamp Act, 1898, and unless it is duly stamped the decree is not admissible if evidence as provided in section 35 of the Stamp Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Aminullah Bhuiyan Vs Abdul Hajiz (1981) 33 DLR (AD) 282.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Art. 45</strong>—Duty payable under Article 45.— Under Article 45 the duty payable on instrument of [ partition is for the amount of the value of the separate share or shares which have been separated off  from the longer share. <em>150 IC 119; 1934 (Mad) 204.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Compromise decree—Allotting of specific parcels is a final order—Engrossment of stamp paper—</strong>A compromise decree in a partition suit allotting specific parcels to the parties is a final order for effecting partition. The decree does not merely declare the rights of the several parties but also allots the properties according to the respective shares of each party. It is not therefore a preliminary decree but a final decree. The only that remains to be done is to engross it on a stamped paper under Article 45. The decree so engrossed on the stamp will bear the date of the decree. There is no time-limit prescribed for the engrossment of a partition decree on stamp of requisite value. The effect of engrossment of the decree on stamped paper would be that it will be rendered legally effective which it is not until so engrossed. <em>AIR 1945 (Pat) 482:24 Pat, 427.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Art. 48</strong>—The expression “general powers of attorney” used in Order Ill, rule 2(a), Code of Civil Procedure as amended by Appellate Side Rules of Chief Court of Sind should be interpreted as an ordinary expression of English Language and the idea of our transaction or more contained in Article 48 of the Stamp Act should not be superimposed on it. <em>PLR (1960) 1 (WP) 504.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A general agent may be one that has authority to act in all matters of a particular nature. The several acts which he may be expected to do for achieving the object may constitute one transaction, but the power that is conferred on him may be general in so- far as that contemplated transaction is concerned. Such a power-of-attorney is special for the Stamp Act and general for making the contemplated transaction. <em>PLR (1960) 1 (WP) 504</em>.<span id="pastemarkerend"></span></p></div></div>
2390	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1951 [Section 2]</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1954) 6 DLR 531 (536), (1957) 9 DLR 174, (1956) 8 DLR 457, (1959) 11 DLR 145, (1963) 15 DLR 5, (1968) 20 DLR 18, (1983) 35 DLR 331, (1983) 35 DLR MD) 230, (1968) 2O DLR 627, (1959) ii DLR 145, (1968) 20 DLR 627, (1961) 13 DLR 873, (1965) I7 DLR 329, (19</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  State Acquisition and Tenancy </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u> </u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1951</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Scheme of the Act</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The whole scheme of the East Bengal State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950 is to effect the transference of intermediate interests in the land to public ownership of the State, and it is, therefore covered at least by sub-section (3) of section 299 of the Government of India Act which authorizes ‘transference to public ownership’ of any land or immovable property.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">There is no preamble to the Act itself and there is no express mention of a public purpose but the whole intention is clear that the interest in the intermediate owners were to be acquired and to vest in the state for the purpose of ameliorating the condition of the actual cultivators of the soil.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Radhika Mohan Munshi Vs. Shama Kishore Manshi (1954) 6 DLR 531 (536).</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Interests of usufructuary mortgage</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The interests of usufructuary mortgage cannot be acquired under this Act. The mere fact that a mortgagee is in possession of the mortgaged property by realizing rent there from will not bring him within the four corners of this Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Nawab Sir KGM Faroqui Vs. Province E. Bengal. (1957) 9 DLR 174.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—In the case of the present impugned Act. (I.e., E.B. State Acquisition and Tenancy Act) the Government of East Pakistan acquired en bloc all rent- receiving interests and khas lands all over the province simultaneously; so far as acquisition is concerned, there is, therefore, no discrimination whatsoever.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Jibendra K. Acharya Vs. Prov. of E. Pakistan (1956) 8 DLR 457.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The impugned Act cannot be challenged on the ground that the Act has not made any provision for payment of the adequate compensation or that the acquisition is not for a public purpose as required by Article 15 of the Constitution or on account of any defect existing until the 29th of February, 1956, when the Validation Act was passed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Jibendra K. Acharya Vs. Prov. of E. Pak. (1 956)8 DLR 457</em><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 2(10) ,(11), (16)—</strong>Right of fishery—Right of fishery in a navigable river—Not a profit arising out of land—Cannot be acquired under the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Tozammel Hossain Vs. Prov. of 13. Pak. (1959) 11 DLR 145.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Right of fishery in a navigable river—Not an encumbrance. Ibid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A several fishery is an incorporeal right and cannot be acquired under the Act. Ibid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 2(10),(16)—</strong>Inland fishery falls within the definition of gestate” &amp; “land” and as such can be acquired. Ibid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 2(1 2)—Hat—Distinctive feature of hat—</strong>The distinctive feature of a hat or bazaar, as opposed to a number of shops established in a particular place, is that it is a place for assembling persons daily or on particular days in a week for purposes of buying or selling articles of general house-hold use. The setting up of a few shops, as found in this particular case, cannot be described as establishing a hat or bazaar.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Kari Azharuddin</em> <em>Ahmed Vs. Province of East Pakistan (1963) 15 DLR 5.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Hat—If necessaries of life are not sold on a land either daily or on particular days of the week the land cannot be said to be a hat.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If agricultural or horticultural produce used as food or drink, or any other necessaries of life arc sold in a hat and bazaar, either daily or on particular days in the week the aforesaid factum would constitute a hat or bazaar within the meaning of the said section 2(12) of the Act. The important thing to be remembered is that Golpalas (thatching straw) to be sold either daily or on a particular day or days in a week. If there is no evidence on record that there is any regularity in the sale of such Golpatas on the suit-land, therefore, the suit land cannot be described as a hat or bazaar within meaning of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The crucial point is whether there is any regularity in holding the hat with reference to particular days in the week. Irregular use as a hat is not within the purview of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If prior to the point of time when the Act came into force, the suit-land was used as a hat, but if subsequently, it has not been used as such, then the suit-land would not come within the mischief of the East Bengal State Acquisition and Tenancy Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The entry in the R S Khatian is in favour of defendant No. I and presumption is that the Suit land is a hat within the meaning of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Hashem Ali Hawlader Vs. Province of E. Pak. (1968) 20 DLR 18.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Hat—What is meant by hat—</strong>On analysis of the definition the following arc found to be the ingredients of a hat :</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">1. It means a place.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">2.
