The place is such where persons assemble daily or on particular clays in a week.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">3. The purposes of such assembly arc primarily buying or selling agricultural or horticultural produce and other commodities.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">4. It includes all shops of such articles or manufactured articles within such place.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Golam Hossain Khan Vs. Abdul Mannaf Khan (1983) 35 DLR 331.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A hat may shift from one place to another bearing the same name and with the assembly of same set of persons—In such a case in fact and in law it is a new hat distinct and separate.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Golam Hossain Khan Vs. Abdul Mannaf Khan (1983)35 DLR 331.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.2(13) and 2(17)—Definition of holding and non-agricultural land</strong>—The word ‘holding’ has been defined in Section 2(13) of the SA &amp; T Act According to the definition ‘holding’ means a parcel or parcels of land or an undivided share thereof held by a raiyat or an under-raiyat and forming the subject of a separate tenancy.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The expression ‘non-agricultural -tenant’ has been defined in section 2(17) and means a tenant who holds land for purposes not connected with agriculture or horticulture, but does not include a person holding together with any building standing thereon and necessary adjuncts thereto under a lease other than a lease in perpetuity.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>SM Basiruddin, Vs. Zahirul Islam Chowdhury &amp; others (1983) 35 DLR MD) 230.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 2(15)—</strong>Khas land”: Land with buildings on and let out is ‘khas land’ is retainable as khas land.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In this case there is ample evidence to show that the land in question had the structures on it and the plaintiff was realizing rent and lease was not a lease in perpetuity.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sudhir Chandra Das Vs. Hatem Bepari (1968) 2O DLR 627.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 2(16)</strong>—Land—Right of fishery in a navigable river is not profit arising out of land and cannot therefore be acquired under the Act. <em>Md. Tozammel Hossain (1959) ii DLR 145.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—On the question as to who was the owner of the premises the decision of the Settlement Officer cannot be final and binding on Civil Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sudhir Chandra Das Vs. Hatem Bepari. (1968) 20 DLR 627.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Right to collect rent is a benefit arising out of land, and can therefore be acquired.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The right to collect rents or profits from a hat comes within the meaning of the phrase “benefit to arise out of land” in sub-section (16) of section 2 of the East Bengal State Acquisition and Tenancy Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">And therefore such right is capable of being acquired under the East Bengal State Acquisition and Tenancy Act as land within the meaning of section 2 (16) of the said Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Abdul Asia Vs. Province of East Pakistan (1961) 13 DLR 873.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 2(17)—</strong>If a proprietor or a tenure-holder has a raiyat or an under-raiyat under him, then the said proprietor or a tenure-holder becomes a rent-receiver and with regard to non-agricultural at land which has been leased out otherwise than in perpetuity the holder of the land does not become rent-receiver.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdul Hafez Vs. Ashraf Ali Chowdhury (1965) I7 DLR 329.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—In this country a lease in perpetuity can be created by an express grant to that effect or by a necessary presumption raised by the terms of a grant and by an unambiguous and long possession.  Ibid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—30 years lease of non-agricultural land is not a lease in perpetuity. As such lessee’s interest cannot be acquired under sec. 3 of the Act. Ibid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A monthly tenant under Non-Agricultural Tenancy Act is a non-agricultural tenant.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>AFM Kutubudowla (1959)11 DLR 401 (SC).</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 2(20)—</strong>Mutawalli not a rent receiver. By operation of law a Mutwalli has been treated as a rent-receiver and the Legislature has not made provision for the Mutwalli nor gave a definition of Mutawalli. So he cannot be classified within the provision of the definition of rent-receiver in its general term. Keeping in view the intention of the wakf this portion of the property should be distributed amongst the legal heirs and representatives of the wakf.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Shamsuzzoha Nurul Amin Chowdhury Vs. Province of East Pakistan, (1970) 22 DLR 377.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 2(23)—Rent-receiver—defined—</strong> According to clause (23) of section 2, ‘rent-receiver’ means a ‘proprietor and according to clause (20) of section 2, proprietor’ means “a person owning whether in trust or for his own benefit, an estate or a part of an estate.” The word ‘trust’ in clause (20) of section 2 of the impugned Act is not limited in its meaning as the word “trust” in the Indian Trusts Act. A mutwalli holds wakf property either in trust or for his own benefit and he must be taken as a proprietor who has a rent-receiving interest. Ibid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Mutwalli or Shebait holding property for the benefit of a religious or charitable institution is a rent-receiver within the meaning of section 2, clause (23). Ibid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Proprietor within the meaning of rent receiver’ includes Mutwalli.   Ibid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The Mirashdar in Sylhet is a rent-receiver. <em>A. Noor Vs. Province of East Pakistan (1966) 18 DLR 666.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Usufructuary mortgagee’s interests is an encumbrance and cannot be acquired, The mere fact that a mortgagee is in possession of the mortgaged property by realizing rent there from will not bring him within the four corners of the <em>Act.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>KGM Farooqui Vs. Province of East Bengal (1957) 9 DLR 174.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The holder of malikana is a rent-receiver and his interest is acquirable. <em>(1966) 18 DLR 184.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Ejaradar is a tenure-holder within the meaning of the expression ‘tenure-holder’ used in the Acquisition Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>KGM Farooqui Vs. Province of East Bengal (1957) 9 DLR 174.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Who is and who is not rent receiver</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—Clause (23) of section 2 does not leave any scope for doubt that a proprietor or a tenure holder and a raiyat, an under raiyat or a non-agricultural tenant whose land has been let out is a “rent-receiver” but a person is not a rent-receive” in respect of such of his lands as has been let out together with any building standing thereon and necessary adjuncts thereto, otherwise than in perpetuity. </span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Surutannessa Bibi Vs. Debendranath Barman (1966) 18 DLR 490.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—“Otherwise than in perpetuity”</strong> <strong>explained.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The whole of the earlier portion of the section is not governed by the words “otherwise than in perpetuity.” They only govern the words “a person in respect of such of his land, as has been let out together with any building standing thereon and necessary adjuncts thereto.”   Ibid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—“Lease of land with building and necessary adjuncts thereto”—Let out other wise than in perpetuity explained.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If the lease of land let out together with any building standing thereon and necessary adjuncts thereto is a permanent lease, the lessor does not come within the exception and, as such, he becomes a “rent receiver.” The last portion of clause (23) which refers to the exception to “rent-receiver” makes it abundantly clear that a non-agricultural land, or, in other words, land let out together with any building standing thereon and necessary adjuncts thereto comes within the exception subject to the condition that such land is not let out in perpetuity<em>. </em> Ibid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Interest of a temporary lessor, is acquirable</strong>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The interest of a temporary lessor or in other words, the interest of a lessor who has granted a temporary lease, is acquirable under the Act with only one exception, namely, a temporary lease in respect of non-agricultural land which is not acquirable. Ibid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Acquisition of rent receiving interest became effective from the midnight of 30th Chaitra, 1362.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The acquisition of the rent receiving interest became effective on the midnight of 30th Chaitra while the lease was terminable from the first of Baisak which, commenced from the following morning i.e. sunrise. Ibid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">S. 2(27)—</span></strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">A Pourasava can establish and maintain a new market under sections 84 and 85 of the Pourasava Ordinance 1977, with the permission of the Government as contemplated under Ordinance No. XIX of 1959 as amended by Act. No.XII of l967. </span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Srimangal Pourashava Vs. Bangladesh (1980) 32 DLR 156 (157).</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—“A person” is sec. 2(27) includes a local authority like Pourashava which is therefore a tenant within the meaning of s. 2(27).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Language used in s. 2(27) is “a tenant” meaning “a person”. There is no statutory provision whereby a local authority like a Municipality or Pourashava has been specifically omitted from being a person like a tenant under the Government. Ibid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Acquisition of any municipal market is only possible under Chapter V showing final publication of compensation assessment-roll u/s44. Where this is not done taking over any municipality hat under a Pourashava u/s. 20(2)(a) is unauthorized and illegal. Ibid.<span id="pastemarkerend"></span></p></div></div>
2391	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1951 [Section 21 - 50]</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1962) 14 DLR 791, (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 230, (1965) 17 DLR 308, (1960) 12 DLR 266, (1958) 10 DLR 527, (1957)9 DLR (SC) 21, (1954) 6 DLR 531, (1961) 13 DLR 610, (1959) 11 DLR 128,  (1962) 14 DLR 791, (1965) 17 DLR 277,  (1970) 22 DLR 775, (1970) 22 DLR 191,</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  State Acquisition and Tenancy </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u> </u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1951</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 24(1)—</strong>Publication of notification under section 3 does not eliminate different classes of tenancies till publication of compensation assessment- rolls. (Sec under section 3, in the case of <em>Arfan Ali Sheikh Vs. Iad Ali Talukdar (1962) 14 DLR 791.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sees. 24(1) and 46A</strong>—These two sections read together would show that under-raiyati holding would continue to exist at the time of preparation of record-of-rights occurring subsequent to notification under section 3.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>S.M. Basiruddin Vs. Zahurul Islam Chowdhury (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 230</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 28</strong>—Transference of service-tenure, not authorized.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Section 28 only provides that if the holder of the chakran had so desired the could get himself recorded as a raiyat upon assessment of rent in the manner indicated by section 28 of the Act. The section does not authorize the transference of the service-tenure.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Narayan Chandra Kunda Vs. Ganesh Chandra Edbar (1965) 17 DLR 308</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Provision of the section analyzed.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Section 20 contemplates the sequel to the acquisition of all rent receiving interests. The section covers the holders of all categories of land, not only the rent-receiver, hut cultivating raiyat, cultivating under-raiyat and non-agricultural tenant. The section also defines the quality and quantity of the land each of them can hold.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Bangladesh Vs. Shamsuzzoha Nurul Amin Chowdhury (1976) 28 DLR (SC) 195.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 30—Court’s jurisdiction is barred only in respect of the matters mentioned in the section.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Notwithstanding sec. 30 of the East Bengal State Acquisition and Tenancy Act barring their jurisdiction in respect of certain matters specified therein, the Civil Courts still retain jurisdiction to declare title or possession of tenants; and the Revenue-officer, when preparing records of rights or compensation assessment-rolls under the said Act, cannot ignore the final orders or decrees of a Civil Court making such declarations. Under section 56 no party is even entitled to raise any issue in a proceeding under section 19 of the Act which is substantially in issue in a suit, appeal or other proceeding between the same parties in Civil Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Safiuddin Kazi Vs Moslem Ali Howladar (1960) 12 DLR 266.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Plaintiff’s suit for a declaration that he is entitled to a certain tenancy right in respect of a particular land is a suit purely for the declaration of his title to the land, the suit not being for a declaration of any question relating to his status as a tenant, is not barred by the provisions of section 30 of the E.B. Slate Acquisition and Tenancy Act. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss.30(2) &amp; 54</strong>—The jurisdiction bar created by section 30(2) is not related to question of title and possession to any land.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Abdul Mannan Vs. Mafizuddin Bepari (1958) 10 DLR 527.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">S.37—</span></strong>Classification made under section 37 is justified and not open to attack on the ground that it violates Article 15(2) of the Constitution.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Jibendra K Acharya Vs. Prov. of E Pak. (1957)9 DLR (SC) 21.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—In view of the addition of subsection 4(A) to section 299, (by the Amendment Act, 1951), Government of India Act, 1935, provisions as regards compensation provided in section 37 of the East Bengal State Acquisition and Tenancy Act are intra vires of the <em>Provincial Legislature. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Radhika Mohan Munshi Vs. Shama Kishore Munshi (1954) 6 DLR 531.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.37(3)—</strong>Rights secured to religious or charitable institutions under the Constitution—How far affected by the provisions of section 37(3) of the East Bengal State Acquisition and Tenancy Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The wakf-ai-aulads arc directly hit by this provision as well as other religious or charitable institutions if their manager has not been applying the income of the properly to the objects to which it was intcnded by the dedicator to be applied.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Jibendra K Acharya Vs. Prov. of East Pak. (1957) 9 DLR (SC)</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 39</strong>—The lands ceased to be tenanted lands with the passing of the decree for khas possession. Therefore, compensation for those lands can be assessed only under section 39 treating them as khas lands.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Tayabulla Sowdagar Vs. Shiddique Ahmed (1961) 13 DLR 610</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 40</strong>—Petitioner when did not even submit a return, Where complaint was made by ex-proprietors of illegal acquisition of hats and jalkars by Government and taking possession of all connected papers and not producing them before authorities for determining correct compensation: Held—Where the petitioner did not even submit a return when called upon to do so, nor asked for the inspection of the papers in the possession of Government or for copies thereof the petitioner is not entitled to any relief in the absence of any evidence either oral or documentary. The burden of proving the claim to enhanced compensation lies entirely on him. <em>9 PLR (Dac) 766.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 40(1)—</strong>A civil suit will lay challenging the legality of acquisition and a revision to the High Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Right of the parties to challenge the legality or otherwise of any acquisition of land by Government in a regular civil suit has not been taken away. When a compensation is claimed by one party as against another party under proviso (I) of sub-section (1) of section 40 of the Act, he can file an objection before the Revenue Authority and he can also prefer an appeal against his order to the superior Revenue Authority and then to the Special Judge and can come to High Court also by way of reference.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Brojendra K Roy Chowdhury Vs. Prov. of E Pak. (1959) 11 DLR 128.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Secs.40(1) &amp; 42</strong>—Under the proviso to sub-section (1) of section 40 of the Act no person who does not claim any title to any compensation entered in the draft compensation-roll can raise the objection under sub-section (1) of section 40 of the Act and under section 42, after the objections have been disposed of. Under Section 40(1) the assessment-roll will be published finally and once the assessment-roll is published finally such publication shall be conclusive evidence that the compensation assessment-roll has been duly made under Chapter V of the Act, and every entry in the compensation roll, except as otherwise provided in the Act, shall be final and conclusive evidence of the matter referred to in the entry and the nature of interest of the rent receiver.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Brojendra K Roy Chowdhury Vs. Prov. of E Pak. (1959)11 DLR 128.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 42</strong>—Publication of notification under section 3 of the Act does not eliminate different classes of tenancies till publication of compensation assessment-rolls.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is clear that the different classes of tenancies including under-raiyati tenancy do not cease to exist with publication of Notification of acquisition under section 3 of the East Bengal State Acquisition and Tenancy Act. The entire chain of interest of rent- receivers will be eliminated only after the publication of the compensation assessment-roll under section 42 of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Arfan Ali Sheikh Vs. Ead Ali Talukdar (1962) 14 DLR 791.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 43</strong>—Lands not included in compensation assessment-roll—Not vested in the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A close reading of the provisions made in sections 42, 43 and 44 of the Act point to inevitable conclusions, firstly, that every interest which is liable to be acquired under the Act has to be paid for and secondly, that except in the cases of acquisition under Chapter II of the Act the interests which are acquirable vest in the Provincial Government only if assessment of compensation in regard to the same has been made and published as provided in the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It having been found that the lands in question have not been included in the compensation assess merit roll it cannot be contended that the said lands hay: vested in the Government merely because they are acquirable and because there has been notification in respect of that area under section 43(2) of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Shah Mohd. Elias Shah Vs. Province of East Pakistan (1965) 17 DLR 277.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—All rent-receiver wakfs stood acquired under chapter V, if all formalities for such acquisition are observed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Jalil Ahmed vs. Province of East Pakistan (1967) 19 DLR 106.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Chapters II and V—Provisions of—These two not ex-facie discriminatory. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 42 and 43</strong>—play a very important part in the matter of determining the rate of the complete cessation of the right of rent-receiver—be they the holder of secular lands or endowed lands. When the compensation assessment-roll is finally published under section 42 and the certificate thereto is given under section 43(2) all chain of interest of the rent- receiver is eliminated.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Arfan Ali Sheikh Vs. Iad Ali Talukdar (1962) 14 DLR 791.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 43 and 44</strong>—Sections 42, 43 and 44 of the Act point to conclusions, firstly, that every interest which is liable to be acquired under the Act has to be paid for; and, secondly, that except in the cases of acquisition under Chapter II of the Act the interests which are acquirable vest in the Provincial Government only if assessment of compensation in regard to the same has been made and published as provided in the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If the lands in question have not been included in the compensation assessment roll it cannot be contended that the said lands have vested in the Government merely because that they are acquirable and because there has been a notification in respect of that area under section 43(2) of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Shah Md. Elias Shah Vs. Province of E Pak. (1965) 17 DLR 277.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Acquisition and vesting under section 44 relates to vesting of title from one who has title— Meaning of the word “vested” and “free from all encumbrances” cannot be extended to mean that the title will vest in the Government from one who has no land in excess of the permissible limit.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Province of East Pakistan Vs. Shajahan Gazi and others (1970) 22 DLR 775.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—<strong>Publication of Compensation Assessment - Roll—Tenant’s non-retainable land vests in the Government on publication of such notification.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In view of the provisions of sections 43 and 44 of the Act. a tenant’s non-retainable land like Bazar vests in the Government on the publication of a notification in the official Gazette under sub-section (2) of section 43. The notification referred to hereinbefore is a notification under sub-section (2) of section 43. This notification relates to a number of villages including Jarulia in which the disputed Bazar situates. Sub-section (2) of section 43 of the Act provides that notification under that sub-section shall be conclusive proof of its publication and its date thereof. Since the notification relates to a number of villages including the whole of the village Jarulia and as the disputed Bazar lies within that village, it should be taken that the compensation assessment- roll published in this case is also relatable to the disputed Jarulia Bazar. Thus the disputed Jarulia Bazar vested in the Provincial Government during the pendency of this appeal.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Province of East Pakistan Vs. Haji Abul Hussain (1970) 22 DLR 191.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 43(2) and 45</strong>—The provision embodied in section 45 has been made, not for the purpose of vesting any right in the Provincial Govt. but for the purpose of protecting the tenants from being misled into payments to somebody other than the Provincial Govt. who become entitled to rent on and from the first day of the next agricultural year on the publication of a notification under section 43(2). It is, therefore, a case of statutory transference of possession to the provincial Govt. and statutory creation of the relationship of landlord and tenant between the Provincial Govt. and the tenant of the ex-rent receivers as well as the rent-receivers themselves in respect of their retainable khas lands<em>. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Jalil Ahmed Vs. Province of East Pakistan (1967) 19 DLR 106.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 43(2), 44, 45 and 20</strong>—Although the property shall be deemed to have been acquired and vested absolutely in the Govt. as laid down in s. 45 on the promulgation of the notifications under see- Lion 43(2) the actual physical possession or the enjoyment is postponed till the proprietors have, in fact, been given the rights under Chapter 4 and a final proclamation under section 45 is made with regard to the particular area in which the property is situated.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Jalil Ahmed Vs. Province of East Pakistan (1967) 19 DLR 106.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 43(2)—</strong>Rent suit by Mutwalli after completion of proceeding under s. 43(2) does not lie.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Jalil Ahmed Vs. Province of East Pakistan (1967) 19 DLR 106.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—No real vesting in the Govt. of the rent- receiving interest, etc. under section 43(2). Ibid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Religious institutions having rent-receiving interests not affected by section 43(2) when Fundamental Rights No. 10 of the Constitution of 1962 was introduced.   Ibid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 44</strong>—After section 44 came into force rights of certain tenants under tenure holder disappeared and the tenants become raiyats directly under the <em>Provincial Government. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Ledu Mridha Vs. Chan Mridha (1968) 20 DLR 158.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Acquisition of rent-receiving-interest. Rent- receivers, till they are paid for, must be said to have their right, title and interest subsisting.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Rahman Ali Vs. Upendra Lal Surkar (1972) 24 DLR 37.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 44 and Chap.V</strong>—Tenant’s non-retainable khas lands—Classification of such lands is determined after the preparation of record-of-rights which gives the description of such land (whether land or fishery, etc.)—thereafter consequences under section 44 ensue—Government must inform the tenant to the satisfaction of the Court that these steps have been completed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A tenant can be dispossessed of his non- retainable khas land only when the steps enumerated in various sections in Chapter V have been taken.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">So far as a tenant is concerned the classification of his khas lands is determined after the preparation of record-of-rights and possession thereof is to be taken after completing the steps detailed in Chapter V of the Act. Preparation of the record-of-rights involves decision as to whether land is agricultural land, or a fishery or a hat or bazar and then the consequences set out in various clauses under section 44 would ensue. He is, therefore, entitled to claim to be informed that those steps have been taken.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In a Court of law, when challenged that those steps have not been taken, the Provincial Government which seeks to take possession of those non- retainable khas lands would be called upon to prove that the requirements of law have been complied with.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Province of East Pakistan Vs. Nakuldas Mridha (1968) 20 DLR 769.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 44</strong>—Acquirable lands which are not retainable under section 20, do not vest in the Government on the publication of compensation assessment-roll without assessment of the compensation, that is, such lands must be included in the compensation assassins roll.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Shah Md. Elias Vs. Province of East Pakistan (1965) 17 DLR 277.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 44(2)—</strong>Korfa interest has ceased to exist from the date of acquisition of the rent-receiving interest under section 3. They (korfa tenants) having become raiyats the provisions of pre-emption by co-sharer tenant available to them.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">After the wholesale acquisition by the Government of rent-receiving interest in 1956 there will be one kind of raiyat only in the country under the Government and that being the position there could not be any question of korfa or any other kind of sub tenants.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The holders of korfa being upgraded to the status of raiyat, a co-sharer in respect of such interest has got the full right of pre-emption available to them under section 26 (F) of the BT Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Priya Bala Devi Vs. Fazar Ali (1966) 18 DLR 480.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 44(3) read with S. 20(2a)—</strong>The words “in excess” mean whatever is non-retainable—Hats and Bazars in view of the 1960 amendment are excluded from the retainable lands and are vested in the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The High Court held the view that the words in excess” in sub-section (3) of section 44 necessarily refer only to retainable lands and can have no application at all to lands which are not retainable tinder section 20(2a).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held: </strong>Whatever is non-retainable is in excess of that which is retainable. In view of the retrospective effect by Ordinance No. XII of 1960 in section 20 by the incorporation therein of sub-sec. (2a) which had the effect of excluding hats and bazars from the category of retainable lands from the very beginning, the hats and bazars in the khas possession of rent-receivers became vested in the Govt. from the date of the notification in 1956 under subsection (2) of section 3 of the Act. But so far as raiyats, agricultural tenants and other tenants were concerned, the vesting took place, after the preparation of the compensation assessment roll and its notification by virtue of sub-section 3 of Section 44.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Province of E. Pakistan Vs. Secretary, MAS  Madrasha (1964) 16 DLR (SC) 281.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 44(3)—</strong>The words “in excess” refer only to maximum retainable lands.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">They do not refer to lands which are outside such classes of lands which the tenants are entitled to retain possession of under Chapter IV of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The above conclusion is irresistible for the following reasons; (a) Because such a result follows from the plain meaning of the words “in excess” which have been used in relation to lands which “tenants are entitled to retain under Chapter IV.” (b) Because, in accordance with the well-established canons of interpretation, a provision of a statute, which takes away the rights of citizens, has to be construed strictly against the Government and liberally in favour of the Citizen; (c) Because in the Act itself the Legislature has used the words “other than” in subsection (1) of section 44, in contradistinction to the words “in excess” in sub-section (3) of that section of the Act; (d) Because when the Legislature wanted to divest and disposes the rent-receiver of all his khas lands, other than the lands which he could claim to retain possession of under Sec. 20, they have specifically said so in sub-section (3) of section 46E of the Act; (e) Because the legislature has refrained from making provisions similar to Section 46E(3) with regard to tenants, as distinguished from rent-receivers.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Secretary, Muktagacha Abbasia Senior Madrasha Vs. Province of East Pak (1963) 15 DLR 37.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 44(4)</strong>—<em>See under section 3, in the case of Priya Bala</em> <em>Devi Vs. Fazar Ali (1966) 18 DLR 480 above.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">No fresh notification for acquisition of hats and bazars necessary. No fresh notification for the acquisition of interests of tenants in hats and bazars was necessary, because, that was to follow as a consequence of the publication by operation of the provisions of the statute itself, and it is for this reason that in sub-section (3) of section 44 the language used is that they shall be deemed vest absolutely in the Provincial Government, that is to say, that as a legal consequence of the notification of the final publication of the compensation assessment-roll they shall be treated as if acquired and vested in the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Province of E Pakistan Vs. Secretary MAS Madrasha (1964) 16 DLR (SC) 281.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 48</strong>—The Revenue Circle Officer is an agent of the Provincial Govt. But he can not be a judge— His work cannot be regarded as a Court. The provision of appeal to the Special Judge under section 48 can not by itself give the RCO the status of a Court, nor can his decision be called a decree in the real sense. <em>(1963) PLR 13 Dhaka 1482.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 48(4)—</strong>District and Subordinate Judges who are appointed Special Judge arc amenable to the jurisdiction of the High Court under section 115, CP Code.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdul Munnan Vs. Mafizuddin Bepari (1958)10 DLR 527.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The Court of Special Judge (referred to in see- Lion 48(4) of the EB Slate Acquisition and Tenancy Act) is a Court Subordinate to the High Court in terms of section 115 CPC—Revisional application under s. 115 CPC against order passed by a Special Judge is, therefore, maintainable.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Inamul Huda Vs. Guru Prassad Muchi (1970) 22 DLR 837.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2392	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1951 [Section 3]</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 230, (1957) 9 DLR (SC) 21, (1959) 11 DLR (SC) 318, (1958) 10 DLR (SC) 80, (1957) 9 DLR (SC) 21 (38), (1965) 17DLR 329, (1962) 14 DLR 791, (1966) 18 DLR 480, (1962)14 DLR 420, (1981) 33 DLR (AD) 13, (1964) 16 DLR (SC) 281, (1977) 29 DLR</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  State Acquisition and Tenancy </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u> </u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1951</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.3</strong>—With the publication of notification u/s 3 all existing classifications of tenants did not disappear as existed under BT Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ruhul Islam, J. (FKMA Munim, CJ and Chowdhury ATM Masud, J. agreed with Ruhul Islam, J; Shahabuddin Ahmed, J., while agreeing with R Islam, J. in the ultimate results of appeal, gave his separate reasons (not exactly the same as those of R Islam, J.)</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is not correct to say that on the publication of the Notifications under section 3 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act existing classification and gradation of tenants as provided under the Bengal Tenancy Act disappeared and there was only one class of tenants with effect from April 15, 1956.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>SM Basiruddin Vs. Zahurul Islam Chowdhury and others (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 230.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—From the date of notification u/s. 3 all classes of tenants became liable to pay rent directly to the Government and became tenants under the Government alone but in all other respects they continued to be regulated by the BT Act till Part V of the Slate Acquisition and Tenancy Act came into operation. Ibid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The view that with the acquisition of rent-receiving interests all under-raiyats were upgraded to the status of raiyats is wrong. Ibid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—After acquisition of rent-receiving interests, all existing tenants became raiyats under the Government for the sole purpose of collecting rent from them, not that the different classifications of tenants disappeared with such acquisition. Ibid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—It is not correct that once raiyat interests vested in the Government by acquisition of superior interests, under-ralyat interests automatically upgraded to the position of raiyats for all purposes. Ibid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>The underlying principles of section 3—</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Discretion conferred by the Section may be called in question when his exercised arbitrarily and unjustly.—Mere conferment of the discretion, the exercise of which may lead to classification, is not unconstitutional. </span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Jibendra K. Acharya Vs Prov. of E. Pak. (1957) 9 DLR (SC) 21.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">What the Supreme Court decided while remanding the appeals to the High Court was to expound the law that wakfs in view of Article 18(b) of the Constitution were not acquirable by the Government and left it to the High Court to apply that law if the High Court found the properties, after investigation, to be wakfs—The function of the High Court not being ministerial but judicial.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Prov. of E. Pak Vs. Md. Mehdi Ali Khan (1959) 11 DLR (SC) 318.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—In Jibendra Kishore’s case, the Supreme Court declared the law that in view of Article 18(b) of the Constitution wakfs and wakfs al-al-aulad cannot be acquired by the Government under E.B. State Acquisition and Tenancy Act. The High Court on remand following the law as laid down by the Supreme Court correctly held that expropriatory notifications for acquisition of such wakfs are void. What the Provincial Government seeks in the guise of appeal against that High Court’s previous judgment is but a review of the Supreme Court’s judgment which is entirely incompetent. Ibid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The notifications issued by the Provincial Government under the authority of EB Act XXVIII of 1951 for the acquisition of the estates having been issued under a void law were themselves void, and although that law regained operation in that respect upon the snaking of the Proclamation on 10th October, 1958, the notifications themselves did not regain validity. Therefore, despite the abrogation of the late Constitution and the promulgation of the Order, the order made by the Nigh Court on remand, to the effect that the acquisitions by the Government were void, being based on the law declared by the Supreme Court in Jibendra Kishore’s case, was perfectly legal and valid. Ibid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Alter the abrogation of the Constitution and the proriulgation of the Order of the 10th October, 1958. ii k open to the Provincial Government, acting is under powers derived from the Act of 1950, read with the relevant provisions in the General Clauses Act, 1897, to withdraw the notifications in question and to issue fresh notifications in purported exercise of owners derived from the Act of 1950 of which the relevant provisions must now be treated as being in full force and operation.   Ibid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Forests and fisheries—</strong>Forests and fisheries not being specified in the notification of the 2nd April, 1956, it is open to any person to move the authority to release any proper- Lies which have been seized and to which the Act does not apply.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A Writ petition is not the proper mode of implementation of the law in respect of wakf property.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Ali Haider Khan Vs. of E. Pak (1958) 10 DLR (SC) 80.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Rights conferred to acquire rent-receiving interests are not. ex-facie discriminatory-If and when they arc so used, the party complaining has to prove it.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Jibendra K. Acharya Vs Prov. of E. Pak. (1957) 9 DLR (SC) 21 (38).</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>30 year’s lease of non-agricultural land not a lease in perpetuity. As such, lessee’s interest cannot be acquired under section 3 of the Act.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is patent that the lease was limited to a specific period of time, namely, thirty years, and was not, therefore, a lease held in perpetuity.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The position, therefore, is that the defendant still Continues 10 be lessee under plaintiff, whose title has not been extinguished by acquisition of all rent-receiving interests in the Province by the Government under Section 3 of the said East Bengal State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950.If a proprietor or a tenure holder has a raiyat or an under raiyat under him, then the said proprietor's- tenure-holder becomes a rent-receiver, and, with regard to non-agricultural land, which has been leased out otherwise than in perpetuity, the holder of the land does not become a rent-receiver.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A<em>bdul Hafez Vs. Ashraf Ali Choudhary (1965) 17DLR 329.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Publication of notification under section 3 of the Act does not eliminate different classes of tenancies till publication of compensation assessment-rolls.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Having regard to the provisions of section 24(1) of the East Bengal State Acquisition and Tenancy Act read with relevant rules namely, rules 18—48(3) and 61, it is clear that the different classes of tenancies including under-raiyati tenancies do not cease to exist with publication of notification of acquisition under section 3 of the East Bengal State Acquisition and Tenancy Act. The entire chain of interest of rent- receivers will be eliminated only after the publication of the compensation assessment-roll under section 42 of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Arfan Ali Sheikh Vs. Ead Ali Talukdar (1962) 14 DLR 791.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 3 and 44(4):—</strong>Korfa interest has ceased to exist from the date of acquisition of the rent receiving interest under section 3—They (korfa tenants) having become raiyats the provisions of preemption by co-sharer tenant available to them.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">After the wholesale acquisition by the Government of rent receiving interest in 1956 there will be one kind of raiyat only in the country under the Government and that being the position there could not be any question of korfa or any other kind of sub-tenants.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The holders of korfa being upgraded to the status of raiyat, co- sharers in respect of such interest has got the full right of pre-emption available to them under section 26(F) of the B T Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Priya Bala Devi Vs. Fazar Ali (1966) 18 DLR 480.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>— Scope and functions of section 3 in relation to section 44.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Section 3 embodies a provision for acquisitions of rent receiving interest and section 44 contemplates acquisitions of all acquirable interests including those of rent-receiver which have been left out after acquisition under section 3. There is nothing to indicate that the latter section is either a proviso or an exception to section 44.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Haji Altafuddin Kazi Vs. Province of E. Pak. (1962)14 DLR 420.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Failure to specify the interests acquired does not render the acquisition invalid.   Ibid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—With the publication of notification u/s 3 all rent-receiving interests including wakf and debuttor property stood acquired by and vested in the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>People’s Republic of Bangladesh Vs. Sri Sri Madan Gopal Jew Bigraha (1981) 33 DLR (AD) 13.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Rent-receiver’s interest stand acquired from time mentioned in notification—Tenants’ interest stand acquired from the date of notification of the final publication of compensation assessment-roll.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Reading the Act as a whole the intention appears to be, firstly, that all rent-receiving interest shall disappear, secondly, that so far as tenants are concerned, they will be entitled to retain possession only of certain categories of lands which are retainable, and thirdly, that even in respect of such retainable lands a maximum ceiling is fixed. So far as the rent-receivers arc concerned, their interests are to vest either from the date of the notification of acquisition or from the date mentioned in such a notification. But so far as tenants were concerned, their interests arc to stand acquired and vested in Government on the notification of the final publication of the compensation assessment-roll.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Province of East Pakistan Vs. Secy. Muktagacha Abbasia Senior Madrassa (1964) 16 DLR (SC) 281.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>No fresh notification for acquisition of hats and bazaars necessary—</strong>No fresh notification for the acquisition of interest of tenants in hats and bazaars was necessary, because that was to follow as a consequence of the publication by operation of the provisions of the statute itself, and it is for this reason that in subsection (3) of section 44 the language used is that they shall be deemed to vest absolutely in the Provincial Government, that is to say, that as a legal consequence of the notification of the final publication of the compensation assessment-roll they shall be treated as if acquired and vested in the Government. Ibid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—After the notification issued under section 3 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, the status of an under raiyat was upgraded to that of a tenant.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Hossain Vs. Amir Hossain (1977) 29 DLR 225.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Rent-receiving interests can be acquired even before the preparation of record of rights and publication of compensation assessment-rolls.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">An exception has been made with regard to rent- receiving interest and special provisions for acquisition of the interests of certain rent-receivers have been made in Chapter II of Part II of the Act. According to the provisions of this Chapter, rent- receiving interests can be acquired by publication of notification under section 3 of the Act even before the general provisions of the Act are given effect to, that is, before preparation of the record of rights and preparation and publication of the compensation assessment rolls<em>. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Anwara Begum Vs. Nur Jahan (1975) 27 DLR (SC) 109</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—After the Notification issued under section 3 of the Act, the status of the under-raiyat became upgraded to that of raiyat. Ibid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Malikana is rent-receiving interest and as such acquirable under the Act—</strong>Right to get malikana claimed by the petitioner vested in the Government on publication on 2nd April, 1956.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Section 3 is clear indicator of the fact that the intention of the legislature was that malikana interest also would be acquired.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Interest claimed by the petitioner, though acquirable, has not yet vested in the Provincial Government nor has been acquired by it. Therefore, the Provincial Government cannot refuse to continue payment of the malikana to the petitioner until his rights is acquired under Chapter V of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Khondkar Ali Afzal Vs. Province of East Pak. (1966) 18 DLR 184.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—No difference between different kinds of tenants in case of acquisition by Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">There is no distinction between a temporary tenant, a tenant for a term of years, and a tenant from year to year so far as acquisition of tenancy right by the Government is concerned.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Province of East Pakistan Vs. Abdul Jalil Molla, (1968) 20 DLR 1223.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Notified acquisition of khas lands under sec. 3(2) can be taken possession of only after observance of the requirement of law as laid down in (1956) 8 DLR page 457, Jibendra Kishore Acharya Vs. Prov. of E. Pak.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Prov. of E. Pakistan Vs. Nakuldas Mridha (1968) 20 DLR 769.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—All khas lands, till the retainable area is determined are held by the (former) rent-receivers as tenants under the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">As the acquisition of the khas lands of the rent receiver s, is subject to the provisions of subsections (2), (3), (4) and (5) of section 20, the rent- receivers whose interest have been acquired under sub-section 3 can retain all khas lands in excess of the retainable limit till the excess lands are determined and taken Out in the manner prescribed in subsections (2), (3), (4) and (5) of section 20, but those rent-receiver shall till then hold all their khas lands as tenants directly under the Provincial Government under clause (1) of sub-section (4) of section 3.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Al-Haj Kutubuddin Ahmed Vs. Al Haridwan Uddin (1962) 14 DLR 128.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Chapter V which deals with acquisition of all acquirable interests under the Act not only of rent-receivers but also of cultivating raiyats, cultivating under-raiyats and non-agricultural tenants. Under Chapter II acquisition precedes preparation of compensation assessment-rolls but under Chapter V acquisition follows preparation of compensation assessment-rolls.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Snahalata Chowdhury (1969) 21 DLR (SC) 440.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Rent-receiving interest and non-retainable khas lands of waifs vested in the Govt. from 14<sup>th</sup> April, 1956 notifications and not excepted by 9<sup>th</sup> May, 1959 notifications. <em>Jalil Ahmed (1967) 29 DLR 106.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Mutawallis and shebaits who were rent- receivers—the rent-receiving interests and non- retainable khas lands vested in the Provincial Govt. by the notification, dated 2nd April, 1956.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Excess khas lands in possession of Mutawallis vest in the Government in terms of s. 43(2) only when compensation assessment-roll in respect of such land has been prepared. Ibid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Notification of 2.4.56 acquiring the interest and next notifications of 9.5.59—Affect of these two sets of notifications—Law applied discriminatingly.   Ibid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Notifications of 9.5.59 are re-issuance of notifications of 2.4.56 and expressly excluded all the properties of religious institutions. Ibid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Notification of 2.4.56 did not bar the right to challenge acquisition by the Governrnent.   Ibid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Notifications of 2.4.56 did not acquire the waifs when the Constitution of 1956 was alive.   Ibid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—No physical possession by the notification of 2.4.56.   Ibid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—When actual physical possession of waifs not taken, they are intact after 10.1.64 when fundamental right regarding freedom of religious rights came into being<em>.</em>   Ibid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Rent-receiver—If a person claims to be not a rent-receiver he must state that<em>. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Haji Altafuddin Kazi Vs. Prov. of East Pakistan (1962) 14 DLR 420.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The interest of a lessor who has granted a  temporary lease is also acquirable with only one exception, namely a temporary lease in respect of nonagricultural land is not acquirable. 30 years’ lease of non-agricultural land not a lease in perpetuity. Such interest cannot be acquired under section 3.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Surutannessa Bibi Vs. Debendra Nath Barman (1966) 18 DLR 490.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Encumbrances on a tenure when annulled before the date of acquisition on 14.4.56—Khas lands under the tenure pass to the purchaser.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Adhu Miah Vs. Bazlur Rahman (1964) 16 DLR 669.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Govt. notification of 2.4.56 as well of 9.5.59 with regard to the acquisition of waif and debuttor esbtablish—Latter notification did not exempt waqfs from acquisition.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Jalil Ahmed Vs. Province of East Pakistan (1967)19 DLR 106.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Specification of interests acquired not necessary when “all interests” are acquired. <em>Tofazzal Hassan (1963) 15 DLR (SC) 139.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Failure to specify the interests acquired does not render the acquisition invalid. <em>Haji Altafuddin (1962)14 DLR 420.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Publication of notification u/s 3 of the Act does not eliminate different classes of tenancies till publication of compensation assessments-rolls.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Arfan Ali Vs. Ead Ali (1962) 14 DLR 792.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Acquisition of waif when fundamental right not in existence.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Religious institutions such as waqfs or debuttors, guaranteed under the Fundamental Rights arc not acquirable under the East Bengal State Acquisition Act, but when Fundamental Rights arc not in existence such acquisition will be valid in law and subsequent enactment of the Fundamental Right will not invalidate such acquisition.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Prov, of East Pak. Vs. Khawaja Habibullah Bahadur (1966) 18 DLR 727.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Steps to be taken for actual physical possession not taken by the Government—Notification does not amount to acquisition. <em>Jalil Ahmed (1967) 19 DLR 106.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—30 years’ lease of non-agricultural land not a lease in perpetuity. As such lessee’s interest cannot be acquired under section 3 of the Act. Where the lease was limited to a specific period of thirty years it can be said that it was a lease held m perpetuity. The position, therefore, is, that the defendant still continues to be lessee under plaintiff whose title has not been extinguished by acquisition of all rent-receiving interests under section 3 of the said East Bengal State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950. If a proprietor or a tenure holder has a raiyat or an under raiyat under him, then the said proprietor or tenure holder becomes rent-receiver, and with regard to non-agricultural land, which has been leased Out otherwise than in perpetuity, the holder of the land does not become a rent-receiver.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abul Hafez Vs. Ashraf Ali Chy. (1965) 17 DLR 329.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Encumbrances created by rent-receivers in respect of their khas lands—After acquisition of excess khas lands, the khas lands which are retained by the rent-receivers, do not vest in them free from encumbrances.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Nirode Chowdhury Vs. Ostar Mia. (1964) 16 DLR 202</em><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—“Free from all encumbrances” Right of way and easements are encumbrances and, as such , arc destroyed, with the acquisition of an estate to which they relate, by the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Kali Charan (1958) 10 DLR 523.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Tenant’s interests were auction sold to the plaintiff and encumbrances annulled and decree for khas possession was passed on 24.7.52. Execution proceeding for delivery of possession started on 24.7.53 which continued when on 1.5.54 Government acquired the rent-receiving interests. Tenants- judgment-debtor’s contention that with effect from 1.5.54 they became tenants under the Government is untenable—Plaintiffs became the owner of the tenants’ interests right from 24.7.53—Execution proceeding cannot affect plaintiff’s rights—Government acquired rent-receiving interest on 1.5.54 but that cannot affect the decrees which the plaintiff obtained for khas possession before acquisition by the Government. Plaintiff became tenant under the Government from 1.5.54 in respect of lands decreed in his favour.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Tayabullah Sowdagar Vs. Shiddique Ahmed (1961) 13 DLR 610</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—After acquisition of the rent-receivers’ rent receiving interest u/s 3 the relationship as landlord and tenant ceased and for arrear rent only money suit could be filed u/s 63C.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Babar Ali Prodhan Vs. Kinu Miah (1979) 31 DLR AD 323.</em><span id="pastemarkerend"></span></p></div></div>
2393	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1951 [Section 3(1)]</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1969) 21 DLR (SC) 440, (1958) 10 DLR 523, (1958) 10 DLR 523, (1963) 15 DLR 703, (1962) 14 DLR 792, (1966) 18 DLR 727, (1966) 18 DLR 727, (1957) 9 DLR (SC) 21,  (1957) 9 DLR 174, (1968)20 DLR 627, (1968) 20 DLR 699, (1981) 33 DLR (AD) 53, (1966) 18 DLR 7</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  State Acquisition and Tenancy </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u> </u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1951</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 3(1)—</strong>Acquisition of rent-receiving interest by publication of notification under section 3(1). On the publication of a notification under sub-section (1) of section 3 the rent-receiving interests of the rent-receiver stand acquired from the date mentioned in the notification and all his rent-receiving interests together with his interests in all lands in his khas possession vest absolutely in the Provincial Government free from all encumbrances and he becomes a tenant directly under the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Snahalata Chowdhury Vs. Ostar Mia (1969) 21 DLR (SC) 440</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Upon acquisition the estate vested in the Govt. free from encumbrances which includes all easements and customary rights and such rights arc destroyed by acquisition.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Kali Charan Das Vs. Tamiruddin (1958) 10 DLR 523.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Rights of way are easements and as such are encumbrances and destroyed with the acquisition of an estate.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Kali Charan Das Vs. Tamiruddin (1958) 10 DLR 523.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—On a notification published u/s. 3(1) the interests of the rent-receivers in estates, taluks and tenures specified in the notification including their interests in all the land in their khas possession and also including their interests in any building, etc. specified in sub-section (4) shall vest in the Provincial Govt.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Ibrahim Mondal Vs. Province of E. Pakistan (1963) 15 DLR 703.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Publication of notification under section 3 does not eliminate different classes of tenancies till publication of compensation assessment-role.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Arfan Mia Vs. Ead Ali (1962) 14 DLR 792.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Notification showing acquisition must be published before the date from which acquisition became effective, otherwise notification is ineffective.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In the Notification, it was stated that the Provincial Government was acquiring the estate in question with effect from the 1st July, 1955. It has been contended that even if the notification was not published on or about the 8th June 1955 or before the 1st July 1955 the notification would be effective on and from the date when it was published.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Held: In order that a notification under section 3 of the Act becomes effective, it is necessary that it should be published before the date mentioned in the notification on and from which the Provincial Government intends to acquire the estate in regard to which the notification is issued. 11 this is not done, the notification will be absolutely ineffective.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Province of East Pakistan Vs. Nawab Habibullah. (1966) 18 DLR 727.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Acquisition if otherwise valid will not be rendered invalid merely because compensation for acquisition not paid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Held: Payment of compensation not being a condition precedent for acquisition, its non payment before the Fundamental Rights come into operation - on the 10th January, 1964, cannot be said to have affected the position of the Provincial Government if the estates had otherwise vested in it<em>. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Province of East Pakistan Vs. Nawab Habibullah. (1966) 18 DLR 727.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—If the Government by a notification acquired the interests of all rent-receivers in a district, part of a district, or local area, by reference to areas wherein they had interest—It is valid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Jibendra K. Acharya Vs. Prov. of E. Pak. (1957) 9 DLR (SC</em><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">) <em>21.</em></span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section 3(1) and Form No. 1, column 2.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Omission in the notification, of the extent of share of the interest acquired, not fatal.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Nawab Sir KGM Faroqui Vs. Prov. of E Bengal (1957) 9 DLR 174.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Acquisition of property by notification on 24.4.1952 rendered the plaintiff (who was originally a zaminder) ‘non-rent-receiver”—Another notification dated 11.8.52 released from acquisition certain property of the plaintiff—Plaintiffs claim to the suit property is based on the notification of 11.5.52 is well founded, as on the date of the general acquisition notification issued on 2.4.56 acquiring rent receivers’ interest did not affect the plaintiffs property as he was on that date not a rent-receiver.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sudhir Chandra Das Vs. Hatem Bepari (1968)20 DLR 627.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Abolition of rent-receiving interest—-Relationship between landlord and tenant  from 14.4.56—Suits for rent for period after 14.4.5 arc not rent suits but money Suits.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It appears that the rent Suit was filed by the outgoing landlord in 1959 for arrears of rent prior to the acquisition by the State under the notifications of 2nd April, 1956. The Government allowed the Outgoing landlord to realise the arrears of rent due. The suits for realization of such rents cannot be called as rent suits. On or from 14th of April 1956, the relationship of landlord and tenant so far as the previous rent-receivers are concerned ceased to exist. The State had become the landlord throughout the province.
