Therefore, the ex-landlord could bring only a suit which could be called money suit for realization of their arrears of rent. Therefore, the Court had no jurisdiction to entertain the suit in the form of a rent suit.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdul Hamid Vs. Ali Baksha Mondal (1968) 20 DLR 699</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Read with Bangladesh (Legal Proceedings) (Third) Order (90 of 1972)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">After the promulgation of P0 90 of 1972 all orders including orders of injunction, etc. passed in appeals, applications, etc. shall cease to have any of- feet and no court shall entertain any fresh suit, appeal, application, etc. in which the legality of any such law of acquisition is challenged or called in question.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Promode Ranjan Shuha Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh (1981) 33 DLR (AD) 53.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Acquisition of wakf when fundamental right not in existence.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Religious institutions such as wakfs or debuttors, guaranteed under the Fundamental Rights are not be acquirable under the East Bengal State Acquisition Act, but when Fundamental Rights are not in existence such acquisition will be valid in law and subsequent enactment of the Fundamental Right will not invalidate such acquisition.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Province of East Pakistan Vs. Khawaja Hahihullah Bahadur (1966) 18 DLR 727.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Acquisition of debuttor property by notification of 1959, if valid.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Question arose was whether the Provincial Government acquired the debuttor property by notification No. 7463 LR dated 9.5.59.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held:</strong> If a valid debutter had been created in respect of the properties by a deed then those properties would not be affected by the notification of the 9th May, 1959.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Province of East Pakistan Vs. Kshiti Dhar Roy (1964) 16 DLR (SC) 457.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 3(1)(2)</strong>—Notifications of 2.4.56 did not acquire the wakf when the Constitution of 1956 was alive.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Jalil Ahmed Vs. Province of East Pak. (1967) 19 DLR 106.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Steps to be taken for actual physical possession not taken by the Government—Notification does not amount to acquisition. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—When actual physical possession of wakfs not taken they are in fact after 10.1.64 when Fundamental Right regarding freedom of religious rights come into being. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Dedication of property to religious trusts— Document to be read as a whole to find out the real purpose.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Where a document shows that the property has’ been substantially dedicated to religious or charitable purposes, it becomes a religious trust notwithstanding the use of the words lessor, lessee or rent in the document.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Kishti Dhar Roy Vs. Province of East Pak. (1962) 14 DLR 680.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Government notifications of 2.4.56 as well of 9.5.59 with regard to the acquisition of wakf and debuttor estates—Latter notifications did not exempt wakfs from acquisition.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Satter, J. (Ali, J. agreeing with him):— It is impossible to hold that the Government decided when they issued the notifications of the 9th May, 1959, to exempt all wakf and debuttor estates from acquisition. The intention appears to be not to seem to acquire any wakf or debuttor property which had not been till then acquired.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Jalil Ahmed Vs. Province of East Pakistan (1967) 19 DLR 106.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Protection afforded by Article 18 of the 1956 Constitution having disappeared with its abrogation, while appeals were pending before the Supreme Court, Governments acquisitions under section 3(1) (2) could not be challenged—This also implies that all wakfs stood acquired less than 1956 Constitution. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Rent-receiving interest and non-retainable khas lands of wakf vested in the Govt. from 14th April, 1956 notifications and not accepted by 9th May, 1959 notifications.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Under the notifications of the 2nd ApriL, 1956, the rent receiving interests and the non-retainable khas lands at least of the Wakfs and debuttors having rent-receiving interests vested in the Provincial Government on and from 14th ApriL, 1956.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The legal consequence under section 44, amongst others, is that all acquirable interests “other than the interests who have already been acquired under Chapter 1l’ vest in the Government. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Acquisition revives when Fundamental Rights are gone—Subsequent introduction of Fundamental Right not being retrospective does not help. Effect of Supreme Courts decision in Mehdi Ali Khan’s case.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If acquisition of such properties takes place under the Act at a time when no such Fundamental Right is in force the same cannot be challenged on the basis of Fundamental Rights having been brought in force subsequent to the acquisition. <em>   Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—So far as the rent-receivers arc concerned, their interests are to vest either from the date of the notification of acquisition or from the date mentioned in such a notification. But so far as tenants were concerned, their interests arc to stand acquired and vested in Government on the notification of the final publication of the compensation assessment-roll.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Province of East Pakistan Vs. Secretary, Muktogachu Abbassia Senior Madrassa (1964)16 DLR (SC) 21.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Khas lands of rent-receivers are possessed by them in their capacity as rent-receivers, but once the rent-receiving interests are acquired on the publication of notification under sub-section (1) of section 3, the khas lands also vest in the Government. This vesting is rather notional and is for the purpose of realization of rent from the outgoing rent-receivers. Whatever vests in the Government vests free from all encumbrances. A rent-receiver in spite of this vesting continues to retain possession of his khas lands. A change, no doubt, takes place in his status. He held, before the date mentioned in the notification, these lands in his right as rent-receiver but from that date he becomes a tenant under the Government. The lands remain with him and the vesting in the Government of these lands free from all encumbrances does not come to his aid in any way.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Snahalata Chowdhury (1969) 21 DLR (SC) 440.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Notification under sub-section (1) of s. 3 does not deprive rent-receiver of possession of his khas lands for which another notification under subsection (2) is necessary.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Tofazzal Hossain (1963)15 DLR (SC) 139.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Notifications of 2.4.56 acquiring the interest and next notifications of 9-5-59. Effect of these two sets of notifications—Law applied discriminatingly.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Abdullah. J.—(Disagreeing with the majority views)—So far as notifications under section 3(1) and 3(2) issued on 9th May, 1959 are concerned it will be seen that on the relevant date exceptions in the matter of acquisition have been made with regard to interests and rights which had already been acquired by and already vested in the Provincial Government under the provisions of the Act as also with regards to the interests and rights that were held under any wakf, debuttor or other religious trusts. If the exceptions as to the wakf, debuttor or other religious trusts  deemed to relate only to those estates which, because of some technicality or special circumstances, had not been deemed to have been included in the omnibus notifications of 2nd April, 1966, then obviously, the executives were applying the law discriminatingly. There was no reason for the exemption of certain particular wakfs from acquisition on 9th May, 1959.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In reissuing the notices on 9th May, 1959, the Government exempted those properties which had been held by the Supreme Court in Jibendra Kishore’s case to be protected from acquisition.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">For this reason the notifications of 9th May, 1959, were the rcissuancc of the notice of 2nd April, 1956, without the vitiating inclusion of properties held by the Supreme Court to be exempted from acquisition under the Act as it stood.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Jalil Ahmed Vs. Pronince of East Pakistan (1967) 19 DLR 106.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Notification of 2,4.56 did not bar the right to challenge acquisition by the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Notifications of 2nd April, 1959, did not extinguish the right of any petitioner to challenge the validity of the acquisition purported to be made by those notifications. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Governments acknowledgement by the notifications of 9.5.59 that they did not acquire the wakfs, etc. by the notifications of 2.4.56—In effect notifications of 9.5.’59 arc re-issuance of notification of 2.4.56 and expressly excluded all the proper- ties of religious institutions.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The (majority) decision in Mehdi Ali Khan Panni’s case was confined to the set of appeals before the Supreme Court—No declaration in the judgment that all acquisitions of 2.4.56 valid. <em>   Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Two alternative modes of acquisition under the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Government not having followed the prescribed procedure for taking possession of the properties concerned in the manner laid down in Chapters II and VA and in relevant rules, after service of their notifications under section 3, they were not acquired by them. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Encumbrances created by rent-receivers in respect of their khas lands — After Government acquisition of excess khas lands, the khas lands which are retained by the receivers, do not vest in them free from encumbrance created by them.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The question arose was whether in view of the visions in the East Bengal State Acquisition and tenancy Act, 1950, the rent-receivers’ khas lands, retained by them, will also vest in them free from all encumbrances:</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held:</strong> After the acquisition of the interest of the rent-receivers, khas lands which are retained by the rent-receivers do not vest in them free from all encumbrances but they are taken subject to the encumbrances created by them or by their default.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Nirode Ranjan Vs. Ustar Miah. (1964) 16 DLR 202.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Supreme Court in Jibendra Kishore’s case declared that acquisition by Notifications in April, 1956 of Wakf and Debuttor properties under section 3(l)(2) of EB State Acquisition and Tenancy Act being in derogation of the Fundamental Right, Article 18 of the 1956 Constitution were illegal and ultra vires. But with the abrogation of the 1956 Constitution and its replacement by the Laws (Continuance in Force) Order, 1958, Fundamental Rights under 1956 Constitution became dead and thereupon the acquisitions of Wakf and Debuftor properties which were made by Notifications in April 1956 revived and regained their life and it must, therefore, he held that properties held in Wakf and Debuttor vested in the Government by virtue of the Notifications issued wider section 3(1 )(2) in Chapter II, and those that were not so acquired by Notifications under section r 3(1X2) in April 1956, stood subsequently acquired d vested in the Government on the final publications of the compensation assessment rolls under secs. 43 and 44. (This conclusion has been arrived at on the basis of the majority’s decisions in Khan Panni’s and Dosso’s cases. Minority view expressed therein by the learned Chief Justice was that Writ petitions made under the 1956 Constitution challenging acquisitions on the basis of Fundamental Rights did not abate with the abrogation of 1956 Constitution.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Introduction of Fundamental Rights in the 1962 Constitution in 1964 being at a time when the Government’s acquisitions of Wakf and, Debutlor proper- tics under Chapter II and V had already taken place and therefore, the present Writ petitions on the basis of Fundamental Rights embodied in 1964 were of no avail and must be dismissed as non-maintainable.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Chowdhury Tanbir Ahmed Siddiky Vs. Prov. of East Pakistan (1968) 20 DLR (SC) 145.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 3(1)(4)—</strong>Failure to specify the interest acquired does not render the acquisition invalid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The specifications of the properties which are intended to be acquired mentioned in sub-sections (I) and 4) of section 3 of the Acquisition Act refer to rent-receivers and not to their interests. Sub-section 2(a) of section 3 of the Act provides that in a notification issued under this section, rent-receivers may be specified or described by name, or by reference to areas wherein they have interests, or in such other manner as the Provincial Government may determine. The notification dated the 2nd of April, 1956 was issued with reference to area. For the failure to mention the interest of the rent-receivers falling in the area, no illegality has been committed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Haji Altafuddin Kazi Vs Prov. of East Pakistan (1962) 14 DLR 420.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 3(1) &amp; (4)(a)—</strong>Khas lands which were parts of taluks and over which the neighboring people had pasturage rights—On acquisition of taluka interests the lands remaining in possession of the former rent-receivers were not free from the pasturage right which the people had over them.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Khas lands of rent-receivers are possessed by them in their capacity as rent-receivers, but once the rent-receiving interests are acquired on the publication of notification under sub-section (1) of section 3, the khàs lands also vest in the Government. This vesting is rather notional and is for the purpose of realization of rent from the outgoing rent-receivers.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Whatever vests in the Government vests free from all encumbrances. A rent-receiver in spite of this vesting continues to retain possession of his khas lands. A change, no doubt, takes place in his status. He held before the date mentioned in the notification, these lands in his right as rent-receiver but from that date he becomes a tenant under the Government. The lands remain with him and the vesting in the Government of these lands free from all encumbrances does not come to his aid in any way.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">On the publication of a notification under subsection (1) of section 3 the rent-receiving interests of the rent-receiver stand acquired from the date mentioned in the notification and all his rent-receiving interests together with his interests in all lands in his khas possession vest absolutely in the Provincial Government free from all encumbrances.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Snahalata Chowdhury Vs. Ostar Mia (1969) 21 DLR (SC) 440.</em><span id="pastemarkerend"></span></p></div></div>
2394	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1951 [Section 3(2) - 6A]</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1957) 9 DLR 569,  (1957) 9 DLR (SC) 21 (46-47), (1964) 16 DLR (SC) 125, (1963) 15 DLR 703, (1962) 14 DLR 228, (1963) 15 DLR (SC) 139, (1963) 15 DLR 703, (1968) 20 DLR 769, (1983)35 DLR 331, (1957) 9 DLR (SC) 21,  (1962) 14 DLR 420,  (1957) 9 DLR (SC) 21</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  State Acquisition and Tenancy </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u> </u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1951</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.3(2)—Hat when cannot be acquired—</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Hats when owned and possessed by persons who are not rent-receivers, cannot be acquired. </span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Mohar Ali vs. Prov. of E. Pak. (1957) 9 DLR 569.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—It cannot be held that the lands of which a rent-receiver cannot be dispossessed had to be specified in the notification.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Jibendra K. Acharya Vs Prov. of E. Pak. (1957) 9 DLR (SC) 21 (46-47).</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Fresh notification for acquisition of Kutcheryghar not necessary.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is not correct to say that if and when the Provincial Government decides to acquire the kutcheryghar it will be necessary for them to issue a fresh notification under section 3(2) of the Act. Action already taken, if supplemented by an order f the Provincial Government specifying the property in question as one which they have decided to acquire, will elliptically serve the purpose.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Secretary, Revenue Department Govt. of E Pak. Vs. Ibrahim Mondal. (1964) 16 DLR (SC) 125.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Kutcheryghar does not become acquired upon the issue of notification under section 3(2)—ft must be acquired upon an express decision to that effect.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The right of a rent-receiver to retain his kutcheryghar against a vesting notification under section 3 of the Act is not lost unless the kutcheryghar is expressly acquired by the Provincial Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Unless a decision to acquire a kutcheryghar is made by the Provincial Government, the rent- receiver to whom it appertains has a statutory right to retain it as a tenant under the Provincial Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Secretary, Revenue Department Govt. of E Pak. Vs. Ibrahim Mondal (1964) 16 DLR (SC) 125.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A kutchery would come within the category of retainable khas land, unless the Provincial Government has decided to acquire—The decision must be that of the Provincial Government—But the Provincial Government will have to acquire under a notification under section 3(2).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—After such a decision by the Provincial Government, the property iii question, if it is a kutchery, would not be acquired automatically upon decision; it would become acquired khas land inasmuch as it would be outside the category of khas land as defined in section 20(2)(a); but the Provincial Government will have to acquire under a notification under section 3(2) of the Act, which is the only manner prior to a final publication of the assessment-rolls by which such property can be acquired.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Ibrahim Mondal Vs. Province of E Pak. (1963) 15 DLR 703.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—All khas lands’ till the retainable area is determined are held by the (formal) rent-receivers as tenants under the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">As the acquisition of the khas lands of the rent- receivers is subject to the provisions of subsections (2),(3),(4) and (5) of section 20, the rent- receivers whose interests have been acquired under sub-section (1) of section 3 can retain all their khas lands in excess of the retainable limit till the excess lands are determined and taken out in the manner prescribed in sub-sections (2), (3), (4) and (5) of section 20, but those rent-receivers shall till then hold alt their khas lands as tenants directly under the Provincial Government under clause () of sub-section (4) of section 3.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Al-Haj Kutubaddin Ahmed Vs. AJ Haridwan Uddin (1962) 14 DLR 228.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Unless there is a notification under section 3 (2) on whole of the khas lands of a rent-receiver he remains in possession as a tenant under the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Tofazzal Hossain Vs. Province of East Pakistan (1963) 15 DLR (SC) 139.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Upon the publication of a notification under subsection (2) of section 3 all the lands in the khas possesion of the rent-receiver, excluding retainable lands under section 20(2)(a) and (b) shall vest in the said Government. Such khas lands which come within the meaning of section 20(2)(a) and (b) have not been acquired by the Provincial Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Ibrahim Vs. Province of East Pakistan (1963) 15 DLR 703.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Rent-receivers cannot retain Flat and Bazar after introduction of sub-section (2a) to sec. 20. Hat and Bazar of a rent-receiver will be affected by a notification issued under sub-section (2) of sec. 3 of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Province of East Pakistan Vs. Nakuldas Mirdha (1968) 20 DLR 769.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Notified acquisition of khas lands under sec. 3 (2) can be taken possession of only after observance of the requirement of law.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">As regards rent-receivers, there were notified acquisitions of non-retainable khas lands under subsection (2) of Section 3 of the Act and in pursuance of these notifications such land could be taken possession of only after observing the requirements of law as laid down by the Special Bench of this Court in the case of Jibendra Kishore Acharya Vs. Province of East Pakistan, (1956) 8 DLR 457<em>. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Province of East Pakistan Vs. Nakuldas Mirdha (1968) 20 DLR 769.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">By Government notification hats in khas possession of a landlord vested absolutely in the Government free from encumbrances.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Golam Hossain Khan Vs. Abdul Mannan Khan (1983)35 DLR 331.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Customary right of compulsorily holding the hat on Tuesdays and Fridays is also an encumbrance and is wiped out on the vesting of the hat in the Government free from encumbrances. Ibid</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 3(2a) </strong>lithe Government by a notification acquired the interests of all rent-receivers in a district, part of a district, or local area, by reference to areas wherein they had interest, it was not beyond the powers of the provincial Government given to it u/s 3 (1)3.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The notifications for the acquisitions of khas lands under section 3(2) are subject to the provisions of sub-clauses (a) and (b) of s. 20(2) and, therefore, it cannot be held that the lands of which a rent- receiver cannot be dispossessed had to be specified in the notification.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Jibendra Kishore Vs. Province of East Pakistan (1957) 9 DLR (SC) 21.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Failure to specify the interests acquired does not render the acquisition invalid. The specifications of the properties which are intended to be acquired mentioned in sub-sections (1) and (4) of section 3 of the Acquisition Act refer to rent-receivers and not to their interests. Sub-section (2a) of section 3 of the Act provides that in a notification issued under this section rent-receivers may be specified or described by name, or by reference to areas wherein they have interests, or in such other manner as the Provincial Government may determine. The notification dated the 2nd of April, 1956 was issued with reference to area. For the failure to mention the interest of the rent-receivers falling in the area, no illegality has been committed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Haji Aftabuddin Kazi Vs. Prov. of E Pak. (1962) 14 DLR 420.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—If the Government by a notification acquired the interest of all rent-receivers in a district, part of a district, or local area, by reference to areas wherein they had interest—It is valid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Jibendra Kishore Vs. Province of East Pakistan (1957) 9 DLR (SC) 21.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Omission in the notification of the extent of share of the interest acquired, not fatal.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Nawab Sir Faruqui Vs. Prov. of E Bengal (1957) 9 DLR 174.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 3(4)</strong>—Right of way and casements are encumbrances and, as such, arc destroyed, with the acquisition of an estate to which they relate, by the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Kali Charan Das. Vs. Tamiruddin (1958) 10 DLR 523.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 3(4)(a)—</strong>Persons who were holding over as tenants, after the expiry of the lease, became tenants directly under the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">With the acquisition of rent-receiving interests, all tenants holding lands under rent-receivers became tenants directly under the Government under section (3)(4)(c) of the East Bengal State Acquisition and Tenancy Act. Thus, the defendant who was a tenant holding over under the plaintiffs became a tenant directly under the Government on and from the 14th April, 1956, the date on which the rent-receiving interests were acquired by the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sm. Lalita Roy Vs. Rafiqueullah Khan (1966) 18 DLR 107.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.3(4) </strong>clauses (a) &amp; (1)—Under clause (I) a rent-receiver retains all lands which have not been acquired under sec. 3(2) as tenant under the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">By virtue of clause (a) sub-section (4) of section 4 of the Act on the publication of a notification by the Government the whole of the land in the khas possession of the rent-receiver vests in the government. By virtue of clause (I) of sub-section (4) of section 3, however, the rent-receivers are entitled to retain as tenants under the government such of their khas land as has not been acquired by a notification under sub-section (2) of section 3.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Tofazzal Hossain Vs. Prov. of East Pak. (1963) 15 DLR (SC) 39.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The cumulative effect of clauses (a) and (I) of sub-section (4) of section 3 on khas lands of rent- receivers is that on and from the date specified in a notification under sub-section (1) all khas land hitherto held by them in their capacity as rent-receivers, that is, as proprietors, tenure-holder, etc. shall with effect from the date, be held by them in a different capacity, namely, as tenants directly under the provincial Government on payment of the rent determined for the khas lands under section 5.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Al-haj Kutubuddin Ahmed Vs. Haridwan (1962) 14 DLR 128.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 3(4)(e)—</strong>After acquisition of rent-receiving interest there will be only one class of tenants, namely, the raiyats, under the Government. There being no under-raiyats, they shall be up-graded as raiyats.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Rafiqul Islam Vs. Kazi Taibur Rahman (1966) 18 DLR 475.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>—Also see Sm. Lalita Roy Vs. Rafiqullah Khan (1966) 18 DLR 197.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Clause(e) of section 3(4) of East Bengal State Acquisition and Tenancy Act secures the actual tenant in possession of his land as a tenant directly under the government and the omission of the words “other than sub-tenancies” by Ordinance No. Ill of 1956 has not the effect of nullifying clause (e).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Ali Haider Khan Vs. Prov. of E. Pak. (1958) 10 DLR (SC) 80.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In the absence of attachment under a decree for arrears of rents, the rent-receiver cannot be thought to possess any special interest in the land merely through accrual of arrears of rent in his favour. <em>Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 3(4)(e)(f)—</strong>Tenants’ interests were auction-sold to the plaintiff and encumbrances annulled and decree for khas possess ion was passed on 24.7.52—Execution proceeding for delivery of possession started on 24.7.53 which continued when on 1.5.54 Government acquired the rent-receiving interests—Tenants-judgment-debtors’ contention that with effect from 1.5.54 they became tenants under the Government is untenable—Plaintiff became the owner of the tenants’ interests right from 24.7.53. Execution proceeding cannot affect plaintiffs right— Government acquired rent-receiving interest but not the decrees which he obtained for khas possession before acquisition. Plaintiff became the tenant under the government from 1.5.54 in respect of lands decreed in his favour.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Tayabullah Sowdagar Vs. Shiddique Ahmed (1961)13 DLR 610.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Tenant under the Government—</strong>Effect of these clauses and of section 5.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">There is no procedure laid down in the Act as to how possession of acquirable interests is to be taken.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The effect of provisions embodied in clauses (c) and (I) of section 3 (4) as well as of section 5 of the Act is that on and from the date mentioned in a notification under sub-section (1) of section 3 the Provincial Government became entitled to collect rent from the tenants of the rent-receivers in question and on and from the date mentioned in a notification under sub-section (2) the rent-receiver becomes tenant under the Provincial Government in respect of the retainable khas lands.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Jalil Ahmed Vs. Province of East Pakistan (1967) 19 DLR 106.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 3(4)(ff) read with sec. 19(3)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">After final determination of rent u/s. 19(3) every tenant is liable to pay enhanced to (if any) under clause (ff) of s. 3(4a).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In this connection reference may be made to the provisions of clause (f) of sub-section (4) of section 3 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act which provides for the obligation of every owner of any land to pay rent to the Government at the enhanced rate, if any, after the final determination of the rent under sub-section (3) of section 19 of the State Acquisition &amp; Tenancy Act and in such case the tenant in question shall be liable to pay the balance with retrospective effect from the notified date, that is, the date of final publication of the record of rights under sub-section (3) of section 19 of the <em>State Acquisition and Tenancy Act. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Chandpur Tea Company Ltd. Vs. Joint Secretary &amp; ors. (1980) 32 DLR 130.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Balance dues finally determined and finally published tinder sec. 19(3), recoverable with retrospective effect.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Thus it will appear that once the rate of rent is finally determined and published in the final record- of-right under sub-section(3) of section 19 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, any balance dues there under can be recoverable with retrospective effect from the date of such final publication of the record-of-right under sub-section(3) of section 19 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act<em>. Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—For prospective realisation of rent at the final rate. limitation shall run from date of final publication of record-of-rights under sec. 19(3) which, in case of Sylhet district, and in view of section 3(4a) read with s. 142 shall be 5 years. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 3(15)—</strong>Land with buildings on and let out is ‘khas land’ and therefore retainable as khas land.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The act of the Government in excluding these premises along with the other premises by the Notification of 11th August, 1952 clearly shows that these were treated as retainable khas land of the plaintiff. “Khas land” has been defined in sub-section (15) of section 2 of the State Acquisition Act and reads as follows:</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">“(15) “Khas land” or “land in khas possession”, in relation to any person, includes any land let out together with any building standing thereon and necessary adjuncts thereto, otherwise than in perpetuity.”</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In this ease there is ample evidence to show that the land in question had the structures on it and the plaintiff was realizing rent and the lease was not a lease in perpetuity.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sudhir Chandra Das Vs. Hatem Bepari (1968) 20 DLR 627.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Revenue authority’s decision on question of title to land—Not binding on a Civil Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is true that there is a finding in favour of the defendant but then it remains a finding of a Settlement Officer and is subject to findings of a Civil Court. The point for determination before the Settlement Officer would be actually who is in possession. On the question as to who was the owner of the premises the decision of the Settlement Officer cannot be final and binding on a Civil Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sudhir Chandra Das Vs. Hatem Bepari (1968) 20 DLR 627.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.3A</strong>—Where complaint was made by ex.- proprietors of illegal acquisition of hats and jalkars by Government and taking possession of all connected papers and not producing them before authorities for determining correct compensation:</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held:</strong> Where the petitioner did not even submit a return when called upon to do so, nor asked for the inspection of the papers in possession of Government or for copies thereof the petitioner is not entitled to any relief in the absence of any evidence either oral or documentary. The burden of proving the claim to enhanced compensation lies entirely on him. <em>(1957) 9 PLR (Dac) 766.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—In s. 3A reference has been made as to acquisition of khas lands in addition to rent-receiving interest before preparation of record of rights. This also refers to notice to be served on the rent-receivers before acquisition u/s 3A directing the rent-receivers to submit returns and particulars as may be required by the <em>Revenue Officer.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Jadu Nath Roy Vs. Province of East Bengal (1961) 13 DLR 496.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">S. 6A—</span></strong>Property can be saved from acquisition by creation of charitable and religious endowment.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 6A</strong>(1) — read with notification No. 7463 LR dated 9-5-59 lays down that if the grantor had anticipated that his properties might be eventually acquired it was within his right to give such properties to charity and to religious purposes instead of allowing the same to be acquired by the Government in future.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Kishti Dhar Roy Vs. Prov. of E Pak. (1962) 14 DLR 680.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2395	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1951 [Section 51 - 70]</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1968) 20 DLR 471, (1959)11 DLR 128, (1970) 22 DLR 679, (1971) 23 DLR 60, (1958)10 DLR 527,  (1966) 18 DLR 52, (1970) 22 DLR 178, (1958) 10 DLR (SC) 80, (1979) 31 DLR (AD) 323, (1963) 15 DLR 744, (1956) 8 DLR 170,  (1959)11 DLR 151, (1954) 6 DLR. 531, (1</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  State Acquisition and Tenancy </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u> </u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1951</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 52</strong>—Special Judge having erred in not referring the case to the High Court has been directed by the High Court to refer the case to the High Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Yusuf  Ali Chowdhury Vs. Province of E Pak (1968) 20 DLR 471.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 52(1)—90 days’ time limit not mandatory—Reference to the High Court.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The provision that the reference has to be made within 90 days is not mandatory but is directory and a reference not made within 90 days is not for that reason a nullity.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Brojendra K Roy Chowdhury Vs. Prov. of Erak. (1959)11 DLR 128.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The provisions of law for reference to the High Court under the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act are almost the same as those under the Income Tax Act that is, the proceedings of assessment before the Income Tax Officers, those before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and thereafter the proceedings before the Income-Tax Appellate Tribunal and then a reference by the Tribunal to High Court under section 66 of the Income-Tax Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Brajendra K Roy Chowdhury Vs. Prov. of E Pak (1959) 11 DLR 128.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 52(2) &amp; 49</strong>—Special Judge should state a case to the High Court when a point of law such as suo moto correction of a compensation assassins-roll beyond time is involved.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Masuda Khatun Vs. Province of East Pakistan (1970) 22 DLR 679.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 53</strong>—A Special Judge within the meaning of section 53 of the Act is a Court subordinate to the High Court and accordingly the orders passed by such a Judge are revisable by the High Court under section 115 of the Civil Procedure Code<em>. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Pijush Kanti Chowdhury Vs. Abdur Rashid (1971) 23 DLR 60.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>The word ‘final” in section 53</strong>—The word ‘final’ as occurring in Section 53 of the East Bengal State Acquisition and Tenancy Act only means that the order is final as it relates to a right of appeal. Power given to the High Court under section 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure can be exercised in a case where an order is passed by a Court subordinate to the High Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Pijush Kanti Chowdhury Vs. Abdur Rashid (1971) 23 DLR 60.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—‘Final’, what it implies</strong>—High Court is not thereby ousted. <em>Abdul Mannan Vs. Mafizuddin Bepari (1958) 10 DLR 527</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Special Judge adjudged an order passed by the Assistant Settlement Officer u.s being wrong and directed the party to seek relief in a Civil Court— Valid. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 54—</strong>Jurisdiction bar created by section 30 (2) is not related to question of title and possession to any land—The bar of jurisdiction created by section 30(2) is not related to question of title and possession to any land which has been specially provided in section 54 of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdul Mannan Vs. Mafizuddin Bepari (1958)10 DLR 527.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 55</strong>—Under section 55 appeals are disposed of by the Special Judges as a Court—The provision of section 55 of the Act is conclusive on the point that these appeals are to be considered not by a persona designata, hut by a Court as contemplated under the Code of Civil Procedure.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Pijush Kanti Chowdhury Vs. Abdur Rashid (1971) 23 DLR 60.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 58(4)—After acquisition by the Government the proceeds of time wakf shall be paid to the Administrator of Wakfs</strong>—In accordance with the provisions of section 58(4) of East Bengal State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, the proceeds of the Wakf, whatever form they have now taken upon acquisition, must be made over to the Administrator of Wakfs, East Pakistan, (who has taken the place of the Commissioner of Wakfs.)</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Alhaj Agha Gholam Hossuin Sherazee Vs. Province of E Pak. (1966) 18 DLR 52.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.60</strong>—Disputes as to compensation assessment-roll itself cannot be referred to under section 6() of the Act—Provisions of section 60 apply only to disputes arising after final publication of the compensation assessment-roll and before payment of compensation.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Hafizur Rahman Chowdhury Vs. Gholam Nabi Chowdhury (1970) 22 DLR 178.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.60A</strong>—insertion of Section 60A has the effect of restoration of ordinary legal position between a rent-receiver and rent-payer.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In the absence of attachment under the decree (for arrears of rents), the rent-receiver cannot be thought to possess any special interest in the land merely through accrual of arrears of rent.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Ali Hyder Khan Vs. Province of East Pakistan (1958) 10 DLR (SC) 80.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section 63C read with s. 3</strong>—After acquisition of the rent-receivers rent-receiving interest u/s 3 the relationship as landlord and tenant ceased and for arrear rent only money suit could be filed u/s 63C.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Babar Ali Prodhan Vs. Kinu Mia and ors. (1979) 31 DLR (AD) 323.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">S. 68C and 68E—</span></strong>For computing limitation for execution of rent-decree obtained before 14.4.56, 24 or 48 months would have to be excluded, after promulgation of Ordinances XIV of 1957 and LII of 1959.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In order to determine whether the application for execution of a rent-decree obtained before 14.4.56 is barred by limitation or not, the period of 24 months or 48 months as provided in section 68C and 68E by the Ordinance XIV of 1957 and Ordinance LII of 1959 respectively would have to be excluded in computing the period of limitation.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sarat Chandra Roy Vs. Ananta Kumar Haldar (1963) 15 DLR 744.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>5.69—Decrees which cannot be executed and Court’s duty.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In view of the provisions of section 69 of the Act directing the Courts not to execute certain kinds of decrees, the amount of which under the Act is liable to be scaled down, the Courts are bound to stay their hands as soon as their attention is drawn to them. No estoppel can operate against the provisions of a statute. The failure of the judgment-debtor to raise the objection under section 69 of the Act in his petition of objection which he filed earlier cannot operate as a bar to the Court giving effect to these provisions when its attention is drawn subsequently.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Jinendra Ch. Mazumdar Vs. Dhirendra Ch. Saha Roy (1956) 8 DLR 170.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Court must stop executing a decree against a rent- receiver as soon as it is brought to its notice that the judgment-debtor is a rent-receiver, irrespective of the plea that the judgment-debtor by his own conduct is estopped from raising this plea before the Court inasmuch as so far as the Courts are concerned, there cannot be any estoppel against a statute.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Dhirendra N Datta Roy Vs. Sudhindra Chandra Chakraborty (1959)11 DLR 151.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Sale barred in public interest and that in the interest of some persons— Difference.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If a Statute is passed barring Certain property to be put to sale by execution in the interest of public policy and not merely to benefit a particular class or individual, any order for the sale would be void, and the executing Court should refrain from putting it into execution. If, on the other hand, the law is introduced simply for the benefit of a particular class or individuals, a sale would be voidable only, and it might be that in such circumstances the matter would be res judicata by reason of judgment of the Court which granted the decree.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Dhirendra N Datta Roy Vs. Sudhindra Chandra Chakraborty (1959) 11 DLR 151.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Orders passed are appealable</strong>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Orders passed under section 69 of the Act, either refusing or granting stay of execution proceeding, come under section 47, C.P.C., and are appealable.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Radhika Mohan Munshi Vs. Shama Kishore Munshi (1954) 6 DLR. 531.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Even before the properties arc acquired or compensation money is paid, as soon as the East Bengal State Acquisition and Tenancy Act came into force it was open to the Civil Court to stay the execution of the decree under sec Lion 69 of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Birendra Ch. Das Vs. Naresh Ch. Bhattacharyya (1955) 7 DLR 339.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The legislature has provided in section 69 of the Act that after the commencement of the Act no Court shall entertain any suit, etc. In suits instituted before the commencement of the Act the Court will look into the matter in a prospective sense, and decide whether it could still maintain the suit; the Court will, provided other requisites are fulfilled, stay its hand and stop the whole process, and suspend the progress of the suit, and may, after finding that it is not entertainable, return the plaint or keep it in the file during the interregnum period<em>. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Monmotho N Poddar V.s. Tripura State Bank (1959) 11 DLR 204.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Entertainment of the suit – A  question of procedure.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The question of entertainment of the Suit in certain contingencies is a question of procedure, and section 69 of the Act was enacted by the Legislature to regulate the procedure. It may be that the debtors might acquire some rights incidentally on account of the law enjoining to regulate that procedure but the main question is how and in what circumstances, the Court will entertain the suit and dispose of it. This is eventually a question of procedure, and in this view also the amendment to section 70 by the amending Act IV of 1956 must be taken in a prospective sense.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Monmotho N Poddar Vs. Tripura State Bank (1959) 11 DLR 204.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Orders staying or refusing to stay execution proceedings—Appeal lies.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">An order staying or refusing to stay execution proceedings under section 69 is an order which comes under section 47 of the Civil Procedure Code and as such appealable. <em>5 PLR(Dac.) 267.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Section 69(1) of the Act prohibits the entertainment of any suit or execution of any decree or order against any property of any rent-receiver for the recovery of any debt which is liable to be scaled down under section 70. Such prohibition is to last until all the interests of the rent-receiver which are liable to be acquired have been so acquired and compensation for the acquisition paid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Radhika M. Munshi Vs. Shama Kishore Munshi (1954) 6 DLR 531.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The section lays down three requisites; firstly, the section would have application in suits brought after the commencement of the Act (16.5.5 1), secondly, it would apply in the case of a rent-receiver; and for debts which were liable to be scaled down under sec. 70 of the Act; and, thirdly, no Civil Court would entertain a suit or execute a decree or order if it was brought to the notice of that Court that the debtor was a rent-receiver, and his debts were liable to be scaled down.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Monmotho N. Paddar Vs. Tripura State Bank (1959) 11 DLR 204.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Benefits of section 69 start with the commencement of the Act till rent-receiving interests are acquired and compensation paid—Liability to be acquired is the test—Section 69 encompasses not only the rent-receiving interests but also khas lands in possession—Unsecured debt or debt on pawn of movable property are included if the debt is liable to be scaled down.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mafazal Ahmed Vs. Haji Abdus Sattar (1964)16 DLR 92.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>‘Final Order’</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The order passed by the High Court under section 69 directing stay of the suit for recovery of debt insofar as it concerns the application of the bar of jurisdiction provided by section 69 of the Act of 1950 was a ‘final order’.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>United Industrial Bank Vs. Mohonbashi Saha. (1959) 11 DLR (SC) 369.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—‘No Civil Court shall entertain’ means that the Court should cease to keep the case on the file but must return the plaint.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">To keep the Suit Of the file of the Court and to pass orders slaying further proceedings in the suit will amount to entertaining or receiving the suit which is prohibited by section 69 of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Atul Ch. Saha Vs. Tripura Modern Bank (1957) 9 DLR 495</em><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">. </span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">(Compare 11 DLR 204 where a different view has been expressed, Ed.).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The East Bengal State Acquisition and Tenancy Act requires that in a case under section 69, read with section 70 of the Act, the relevant date, that is the date as to when the debt was incurred, has got to be determined and this can be determined even by an executing Court and the determination of this question is not possible unless the Court makes an enquiry as to the original debt upon which a decree can be said to have been based or passed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Jahiruddin Talukdar Vs. Shoarma Bibi (1960) 12 DLR 139.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Even before the properties arc acquired or compensation money is paid, as soon as the East Bengal State Acquisition and Tenancy Act came into force it was open to the Civil Court to stay the execution of the decree under section 69 of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Birendra Ch. Das Vs. Naresh Ch. Bhattacharyya. (1955) 7 DLR 339.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—It cannot be said that until the property is actually acquired and the debt is actually scaled down section 69 has no application. On the other hand, section 69 provides for slay of all further proceedings in respect of such debts of a rent-receiver as are incurred before the 7th April, 1948 and as are liable to he scaled down.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Birendra Ch. Das Vs. Naresh Ch. Bhotacharyya (1955) 7 DLR 339.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—There cannot be two final decrees in a suit. The decree of the appellate Court whether confirming, varying or reversing the decree of the trial Court, is the only final decree in the suit.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The decree of the appellate Court having been passed in the instant case on the 13th June, 1952, long after the 7th April 1948, it has been held that the bar of section 69 of the East Bengal State Acquisition and Tenancy Act was not applicable to the execution of that decree. <em>6 PLR(Dac.) 803.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sec. 69 (2)—</strong>An order striking out an execution case on the ground that the decree could not be executed in view of section 69 of the East Bengal State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, is not an illegal order. Sub-sec. (2) of sec. 69 gives the decree-holder protection against limitation.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Kazi Abdul Hamid Vs. Kashi Charan Roy. (1955) 7DLR 115.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 69, 79 and 20</strong>—Question as regards whether a rent-receiver has got lands in excess cannot be ascertained before the provisions of Chapters II and V are complied with.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In section 69 the Legislature never intended that the property of the debtor which is retainable was sought to be treated as not acquirable on account of the explanation added to section 70.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">From the explanation of section 20 it will be quite clear that the lands mentioned in those subsections of section 20 are not treated as not acquired or not acquirable.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">For the purpose of applicability of section 69, the Courts are not concerned with whether a piece or a plot of land has been acquired or not which may be a matter of great consideration for the application of section 70, but, whether it is acquirable or not. If it is acquirable under the Act, whether under Chapter II or under Chapter V, section 69 come into play and any Suit or execution of decree is to be stayed till such time as mentioned in that section.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mofazzal Ahmed Vs. Haji Abdus Sattar (1964) 16 DLR 92.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 69 &amp; 70</strong>—Costs awarded in a suit decreed after 7.4.48 cannot be stayed under section 69 of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Decree was passed before 7.4.48 but the appeal was filed after that date. Provision of section 69(1) of the Act attracted.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The decree for costs in the present case was passed by the High Court on 13th of March, 1953.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held:</strong> The execution of the decree for costs cannot be stayed as the same is not a debt as contemplated by section 70 and the party entitled to cost has the right to proceed with the execution case o far the decree for costs is concerned.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In the present case the decree was passed by the trial Court on 21.5.47 and if sub-section (1) of section 69 of the Act be applied to the appeal and ii. be held that the appeal being a continuation of the suit and the appeal being filed in the appellate Court after the 7th April. 1948, then in that case the appeal could not be maintainable, in view of the provision of section 69 of the Act. But this position cannot be accepted. The decree was passed against the judgment debtors and the judgment debtors were entitled to have their grievance redressed in a superior Court; that was not barred by the provision of sub-section (1) of section 69 of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>United Bank of India Vs. Mahabubur Rahman (1965) 17 DLR 177.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Benefits of section 69 start with the commencement of the Act till rent receiving interests arc acquired and compensation paid—Liability to be acquired is the test—Section 69 encompasses not only the rent-receiving interests but also khas lands in possession—Unsecured debt or debt on pawn if movable properly are included if the debt is liable to be scaled down.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mafazzal Ahmed Vs. Haji Abdus Sattar (1964)16 DLR 92.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A decision that the execution of decree is barred under section 69 of the E.B.S.A. and T. Act is not res-judicata for all time to come. The bar may be got over under changed circumstances<em>. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Habibur Rahman Vs. Sankar Bank Ltd. (1964)16 DLR 576.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Question of retainability or non-retainability of khas land by a rent-receiver cannot be determined unless the area is known and the option of retaining the land is exercised. Until these arc ascertained the Court is not in a position to conclude that a particular khas land of a rcnt-rcceivcr will not be retained by him and therefore stay of execution of a decree can be allowed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mofizuddin Mia Vs. Mangeswar Das Poddar (1963)15 DLR 446.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—No slay of execution when compensation assessment roll is finally published—Compensation assessment-roll (in the present case) not published when Executing Court granted stay but was published when the case was before the appellate Court—Appellate Court competent to take into consideration that fact that it has been in the meanwhile published.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Relief by way of stay of execution case is available to a debtor who is a rent-receiver so long as the Compensation Assessment Roll is not finally published in respect of his lands or rent-receiving interests. In the present case what happened was that notification showing publication of the Compensation Assessment-Roll could not be produced before the Executing Court as at that time it did not come into existence. Question, therefore, arose whether the High Court in appeal could look into it and their Lordships—</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held:</strong> In the interest of justice, the party concerned should be given an opportunity to prove the publication of the Compensation Assessment-Roll in respect of the properties of the debtor to show that the relief is no longer available to the debtor and we are accordingly of opinion that it should be remanded to the executing Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sankar Bank Ltd. Vs. Sultan Bhuiya (1968) 20 DLR 63.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—In view of the fact that mortgages secured wholly upon properties which are not liable to acquisition under the Slate Acquisition Act have been omitted from sub-section (I) of section 70 of the Act, the presumption is, unlike the three categories of properties referred to in clauses (a), (b) and (c) of section 70(1), they are not liable to be sealed down.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>United Industrial Bank Vs. Mohanbashi Saha (1959) 11 DLR (SC) 369.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The argument that all cases of debts other than the excepted debts are intended by the Legislature to be dealt with under sub-section (1) of section 70 despite the fact that the precise mode of scaling down has been prescribed in respect of only three specified categories of debts, is not one which can be  accepted inasmuch as the Court could not assume the function of the Legislature and lay down a formula applicable to cases of this nature Out of its own mind.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The purpose of the Legislature in relation to debts secured upon properties not liable to be acquired is that these debts are applicable to and are recoverable in full from the properties upon which they are secured.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The debt here in question is not one which is liable to be scaled down under that section, and consequently the bar of section 69 is not applicable to it.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>United Industrial Bank Vs. Mohanbashi Saha (1959) 11 DLR (SC) 369.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>“Debts incurred before 7-4-48</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">”— Where a bond was executed after 74.48 for debt incurred before 7.4.48 and in respect of which a decree was passed after 7.4.48—Cannot be said that the debt was incurred after 7.4.48.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The decree, insofar as it provides for the costs, cannot be said to be the debt in respect of which any relief can be asked for on the principle of section 69 read with section 70 of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Jahiruddin Talukder Vs. Shoarma Bibi (1960)12 DLR 139.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Order need not be ‘final order’.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The order passed by the High Court in its revisional jurisdiction with reference to an application under sections 69 and 70 must be regarded as an appeal from a ‘decree or order” as mentioned in clause (c) of section 109, Civil Procedure Code. Therefore, for purposes of the grant of the Certificate under section 109 the condition that the order should be” final order” is not obligatory.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>United Industrial Bank Vs. Mohanbashi Saha (1959) 11 DLR (SC) 369.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The argument that when a person who has properties in respect of which he is a rent-receiver and other properties in respect of which he is not, the decree in respect of a debt incurred before the 7th day of April, 1948, can be executed against him by attachment of properties in respect of which he is not a rent-receiver is opposed to the scheme of section 69 and is not tenable at all. There is sufficient indication in clause (b) of sub-section (1) of section 70 that section 69 is applicable to a rent-receiver who has properties other than those liable to be acquired under the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Kazi Abdul Hamid Vs. Kashi Ch Roy (1955) 7 DLR 115.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Bank (being a rent-receiver) can get a stay order of the execution of the decree by the depositor for money deposited in the Bank. A deposit in bank creates relation of debtor and a creditor or between the parties and so, when a depositor sues a bank on his deposit and gets a decree thereof, the decretal amount is a debt and, as such, it comes within the purview of sections 69 and 70 of the Estate Acquisition Act and, therefore, the judgment debtor—a rent-receiver, is entitled to an order staying the execution of the decree under sections 69 and 70 of the E.R.Statc Acquisition and Tenancy Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mahalaxmi Bank Vs. Md. Saheb Mia (1957) 9 DLR 133.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Order appealable—</strong>An order on an application under sections 69 and 70 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act comes under the section 47, C.P.C., and is appealable.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mahalaxmi Bank Vs. Md. Saheb Mia (1957) 9 DLR 133.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Debts, irrespective of whether obtained on the security of rent-receiving interest or on other proper- tics which arc not rent-receiving interest, are liable to be scaled down under section 70 and, therefore, Liable to be stayed under section 69. Clauses (a), (b) and (c) of section 70 are illustrative in nature and do not control or modify the substantive provisions of section 70(I) according to which all debts arc liable to be scaled down.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Ary asthan Insurance Co. Vs. Nurul Islam Chowdhury (1958) 10 DLR 510.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Law of procedure-Takes affect prospectively—Amendment of section 70.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Change in the law of procedure affects pending suits prospectively unless the Legislature indicates otherwise either expressly or impliedly,</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The amendment of section 70 in 1956, by which “loan advanced for financing tea industry” was expected from being scaled down and to which the effect, the provisions of section 69 will not be applicable, will operate prospectively.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Monmotha N Poddar Vs.
