Tripura State Bank (1959) 11 DLR 204.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Period during which proceeding shall not be entertained.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is evident from the wording of section 69 and section 70 that period during which proceedings of the specified kinds “shall not be entertained” is a period which commences with the acquisition of the rent-receiving interest of the debtor in question and ends with the payment to him of compensation.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>United Industrial Bank Vs. Mohanbashi Saha (1959) 11 DLR (SC) 369.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Bar to further proceedings applies to debts which are liable to be scaled down.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The date on which the Act came into operation is the dale after which section 69(1) prohibits the entertainment of any suit for execution of any decree or order against any property of any rent-receiver for the recovery of any debt which is liable to be scaled down under section 70. <em>5 PLR (Dac) 267.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">S. 69(I)—</span></strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sub-section (I) of section 69 expressly provides that in respect of debts which are liable to be scaled down, the Civil Court shall not entertain any Suit or execute any decree or order against the property of the rent-receiver.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The words “after the commencement of this Act” and “until” occurring in several places in subsection (1) of section 69 prescribed the maximum period during which the party concerned can have the benefit of this section and Status quo has to be maintained and the words “liable to be scaled down” under section 70 indicate the nature of debts in respect of which this benefit can be claimed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Birendra Ch. Das Vs. Naresh Ch. Bhattacharyya (1955) 7 DLR 339.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Mortgage debt incurred by a rent-receiver prior to 7th April, 1948—Decree for costs in mortgage suit passed after that date, if executable against the rent-receiver.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Under section 69(I) read with section 70(1) of the East Bengal State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, no decree for debt incurred by rent-receiver prior to the 7th April, 1948, can be executed by a Civil Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Where a mortgage debt was incurred by a rent- receiver prior to that date, but a decree for principal and interest as well as for costs was passed after that date:</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held:</strong> The decree for principal and interest comes within the terms of section 69(1) read with section 70(I) and cannot be executed, but the decree for costs is not one for debt within the meaning of section 70(1) and does not come within the meaning of section 69(1), and the execution thereof cannot be stayed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Before applying section 69, it is the duty of the Court to see that each and every item of debt was incurred prior to the said date irrespective of any objection taken by the party. <em>7 PLR (Dac.)106.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—If any amount has not been scaled down it will be open to the decree-holder to proceed against the judgment-debtor in respect of the debt which cannot bear has not been sealed down under section 70 and, so far as the law of limitation is concerned, even after the process of scaling is over the decree holder is protected by the provisions of sub-section (2) of section 69 to the effect that the period during which his suit or execution of decree or order is stayed will not be computed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Section 69 only speaks of the debt which is liable to be scaled down under section 70, but section 70, specifically gives the exception to debts which are liable to be scaled down and also the mode of scaling down of debts which are liable to be scaled down.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Birendra Ch. Das Vs. Naresh Ch. Bhattacharyya (1955) 7 DLR 339 (343-44).</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Section 69 (I) of the Act prohibits the entertainment of any suit or execution of any decree or order against any property of any rent-receiver for the recovery of any debt which is liable to be scaled down under section 70. Such prohibition is to last until all the interests of the rent-receiver which are liable to be acquired have been so acquired and the compensation for the acquisition paid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Radhika M. Munshi Vs. Shama Kishore Munshi (1954) 6 DLR 531.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Bar to further proceedings in a suit or execution for recovery of any debt, imposed by section 69 is confined to debts which arc liable to be scaled down under section 70. Section 70 is not expressed as an exhaustive statement of debts subject to such liability.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>United Industrial Bank Lid. Vs. Mohan Bashi Saha (1959) 11 DLR (SC) 369.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Where a mortgage is secured wholly upon property of a rent-receiver which is not liable to be acquired under the Act, a suit to enforce the mortgage is not barred by section 69 thereof but a Court may entertain and proceed with such a suit irrespective of anything contained in section 69.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Aryasthan Insurance Company Ltd. Vs. Nurul Islam Chowdhury PLD 1955 SC (Pak) 306—PLR 1959 (2) WP 1597.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A rent-receiver having debts can have the same scaled down.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Aryasthan Insurance Co. Vs. Nurid Islam Chowdhury (1958) 10 DLR 510.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Provisions of the sub-section read with the rules make it clear that annual income of all properties including those which are not liable to be acquired under the Act will have to be taken into consideration for the purpose and relief’s under section70. Ibid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>“Entertained</strong>”—The word “entertained” has been interpreted as meaning “admitted for consideration and disposal”.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Monmotha N. Poddar Vs. Tripura State Bank (1959) 11 DLR 204.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 69(1), 70(1)—</strong>Amount of cost decreed before 7.4.1948 is a debt and as such execution case is not maintainable.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The amount of costs, being decreed before the 7th of April, 1948 is a debt within the meaning of section 70(1) of the EB State Acquisition and Tenancy Act. The execution applications for realization of such dues are therefore barred under section 69(1) read with section 70(1) of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Khalilur Rahrnan Vs. Binoy Bhusan Saha (1962) 14 DLR 721.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.70</strong>—Provisions of the sub-section read with the rules make it clear that annual income of all properties including those which are not liable to be acquired under the Act will have to be taken into consideration for the purpose and relief’s under section 70.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Aryasthan Insurance Co. Ltd. Vs. Mvi. Narul Islam Chowdhury (1958) 10 DLR 510.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—“Entertained”—</strong>The word “entertained” has been interpreted as meaning “admitted for consideration and disposal”.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Manmatha Nath Poddar Vs. The Tripura State Bank (1959) 11 DLR 204.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Date of the decree—Court’s duty to ascertain the nature and date of the debt before it orders execution.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It was contended that inasmuch as the decree was passed on the 7th of August 1948, on the basis of a promissory note executed some day prior to the 1st of April, 1948, it must be taken that the debt was incurred on a date subsequent to the 1st April, 1948, and, therefore, on that ground the judgment- debtor is not entitled to get any relief prescribed by section 69 of the East Bengal State Acquisition and Tenancy Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held:</strong> The date of the decree with respect to a debt is not the date when the debt was incurred within the meaning of section 70. An executing Court is to examine the nature and date of the debt before it orders execution and the words “debts incurred” in section 70 make it clear that the executing Court is bound to determine whether the decree is a decree which relates to a debt incurred prior to the 7th of. April, 1948, or to a debt incurred on a date subsequent to the 7th April, 1948.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Dhirendra Nath Datta Roy Vs. Sadhendra Chandra Chokravorty (1959) 11 DLR 151.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A rent-receiver having debts can have the same scaled down.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Atyasthan Insurance Co. Vs. Md. Nurul Islam Chowdhury (1958) 10 DLR 510.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.70 read with section 20—<em>Explanation to section 70, what it provides.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Explanation to section 70 provides that land retained under Section 20 shall be deemed as not acquired under the Act for the purpose of section 70. What has been allowed to be retained by each person arc properties excepted from the operation of the East Bengal Stale Acquisition and Tenancy Act and, therefore, it can be said that these properties are not acquirable<em>. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mafazal Ahmed Vs. Haji Abdus Sattar (1964) 16 DLR 92.</em><span id="pastemarkerend"></span></p></div></div>
2396	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1951 [Section 71 - 95]</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1971) 23 DLR 60, (1981) 33 DLR 260, (1984) 36 DLR 163, (1978) 30 DLR (SC) 164, (1969) 21 DLR 429, (1962) 14 DLR 128, (1964) 16 DLR (SC) 667, 17(3) or 3 1(1), (1964) 16 DLR (SC) 667, (1979) 31 DLR (AD) 109,  (1978) 30 DLR (SC) 164,(1977) 29 DLR (SC) 14, </p><p><b>Subject:</b>  State Acquisition and Tenancy</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u> </u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1951</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.75</strong>—Solenama which does not show the creation of sub-tenancy or granting of sub-lease of lands but it records the recognition of the existence of such tenancy from a date of distant past—Such solenama cannot he hit by the provisions of sections 9 and 75 of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Pijush Kanti Chowdhury Vs. Abdur Rashid, (1971) 23</em> <em>DLR 60.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.75A</strong>—Sub-lease being prohibited land under sub-lease reverts back to the original owner.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdur Rashid Khan, Vs. Abdus Samad Mondal (1981) 33 DLR 260.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Sub-letting of any land in khas possession being prohibited and void u/s.75A, the lessee acquires no right by virtue of an illegal transfer and therefore the lessor shall be treated to have continued to remain owner in possession of the land.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Surendra Nath Vs. Saryandra Nath Halder (1984) 36 DLR 163.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.75A and the relevant provision of the Premises Rent Control Ordinance of 1963.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">There is no inconsistency between the provision of section 75A of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act and those of the Premises Rent Control Ordinance, 1963 which provides for letting out of premises on monthly basis.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Ambia Khatun Vs. Altaf Hossain (1978) 30 DLR (SC</em>) <em>164.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—S. 75A and notification issued under sec. 3, effect—Section 75A prevents creation of any rent receiving interests—With effect from 14.4.1956 all rent receiving interests and all non-retainable lands of the rent-receivers and of the non-rent receivers stood acquired after notification Ws. 3 which vest in the Govt. on publication of compensation assessment-roll under Chapter V of the Act. Ibid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—When not applicable—</strong>Letting Out of land along with building thereon on a temporary basis is outside the scope of sec. 75A—The land continues to be in the khas possession of the lessor and as such he is not a rent-receiver. Ibid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Kabuliyat (creating a tenancy) executed after coming into force of section 75A is hit by its provision.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Before the High Court question arose, whether the “Kabuliyat” executed after coming into force of section 75A of the Act was hit by its provision and, on the other hand, whether the Suit was barred by estoppel.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held:</strong> The “Kabuliyat” is null and void being hit by the provision of section 75A of the Act. Section 75A being a statute there can be no estoppel against a statute under certain Circumstances as in the present case where the “Kabuliyat” is shown to be tainted with illegality.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sree Sudhir Chandra Saha Vs Heirs of late Jan Mamud Sirker (1969) 21 DLR 429.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Contract for lease exclude before section 75A was enacted—Contract void and unenforceable.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The plaintiff’s contract of lease having been made prior to the coming into operation of section 75A was lawful at the time when it was made. But the object of that contract i.e., the demise of the Suit properties being now prohibited under section 75A—in this  Section has rendered the object of the plaintiff’s contract of lease unlawful and thereby made the contract itself void.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Further, the doctrine of frustration coming within the purview of the second paragraph of section 56 of the Contract Act comes into play with the result that the plaintiff’s contract of lease has become void and unenforceable also under the provision of section 56, paragraph second of the Contract Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Al-Haj Kutubuddin Ahmed Vs. Abu Jafar Hridwan Uddin Ahmed (1962) 14 DLR 128.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—An executory contract does not create a vested interest—Due to the operation of section 75A, section 56 of the Contract Act renders it unenforceable.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The question to be considered is whether it is necessary that right acquired by the plaintiff under his con tract of lease may properly be called a vested right.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The contract of lease in question is a mere executory contract not a deed affecting an actual demise. Therefore the right acquired by the plaintiff under the contract is only a contractual right to have a lease of the suit properties on fulfillment of the terms mentioned therein but is not a completed and accomplished right so as to be termed as vested right.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">When no vested right accrued to the plaintiff under the contract of lease that contract falls within the mischief of the aforesaid section 75A and is, therefore, hit by section 56 of the Contract Act. Ibid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Sub-lettings—not illegal</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Sub—letting connotes the creation of a subordinate tenancy or under raiyati, under which the sub— lessee would but for a special contract be liable to pay rent for that land to a person other than the Provincial Government. Section 75A was intended to prevent this eventuality.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">“Sub-letting” in this section should, therefore, be construed strictly and unless the transaction sought to be invalidated comes strictly within the ambit of sub-letting in this strict sense, it should not be brought within the mischief of this section.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Government of East Pak. Vs. Md. Hossain (1964) 16 DLR (SC) 667.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Purpose of the section—The intention of this section appears to be that since after the acquisition of the interest of rent-receivers, rent- receivers were themselves to retain certain classes of retainable khas land as tenants directly under the Government, they should not be allowed to create further sub-tenancies under them. <em>  Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Does not invalidate leases which were effected before the notification under section 17(3) or 3 1(1).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Section 75A, though it came into force on the 30th August, 1954, was made operative only fromthe date of the notification under section 17(3) or section 31) and, as such, it ‘baa no retrospective operation and did not invalidate leases created before such date. The provisions of sections 9 to 9D would still continue to govern such cases.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">All that happened after the publication of the notification under section 17(3) was that the authority prescribed under section 9 could no longer permit a transfer by lease.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The view that even in the case of a lease created after the issue of notification under section 17(3) which was effected on the 16th December. 1955, the provisions of section 9A to 9B should have been resorted for effecting a forfeiture of the leased land cannot be accepted as sound: This would render the provisions of sub—section (2) of section 75A wholly nugatory.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Government of East Pak. Vs. Md. Hossain (1964) 16 DLR (SC) 667.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—No conflict— </strong>There is no real conflict between the provisions of sec Lions 75A and 9 to 9D of the Act and the two can well stand together. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 75A and 81A</strong>—If the contract in substance is a contract for exchange of property which means a sale of the properties, obviously the provision of section 75A or for that matter section 81A of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act is not at all attracted.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Debaranjan Sen Vs. Md. Abdus Sabur &amp; Ors. (1979) 31 DLR (AD) 109.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Purposes sought to be achieved under these two sections—Letting out with building thereon otherwise than in perpetuity not barred.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Ambia Khatun Vs. Altaf Hossain (1978) 30 DLR (SC)</em> <em>164.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Letting out of the premises in regard to nonagricultural land on monthly basis not barred. <em>   Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Prohibition of sub-letting of any khas land in any area after publication of notification under sections 17(3) and 3 1(1<em>). </em><em>   Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Lease dated 8.8.1956 in respect of a premises followed by a deed of sale of rent receiving interest with regard to that premises is a complete sale of the premises in law—Sec. 75A not applicable.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abul Layes Vs. Mst. Anwara Khatun (1977) 29 DLR (SC) 14. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.</strong> <strong>75A(3)—</strong>Sub-section (3) of section 75A relates to sub-letting of land by a landlord, who has purchased the land in a rent execution case, to another person at a rent which is higher than the rent payable for the land by the out-going tenant—In such a case the Government cannot acquire the land on the ground that sub-letting is prohibited under subsections (I) &amp; (2) of section 75A.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">But when the landlord of a Kharija taluk put a sikmi taluk under the Kharija taluk to auction-sale for rent and purchases the same himself and thereafter annuls the darsikmi Laluk under shikmi iaiuk and plaintiff who owned the shikmi taluk took lease of a portion of land held in darsikmi taluk—to such a case provisions of sub-section (3) of s. 75A not applicable and the Government may treat the same as land of the land) order and when the area is in excess of the retainable limit Government may take possession of that land.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Golam Rahman Vs. Bangladesh (1983) 35 DLR 419.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 76</strong>—Lands held by Government under the provisions of s. 76 which the Government can settle at its discretion with any person even though no Rules have been framed regarding the disposal of land by Government—No suit shall lie disputing any such settlement of land by the Government and the failure to enquire by the Government regarding preference to be given to an applicant will not render the settlement null and void.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mokbul Ahmed Vs. Bazal Ahmed (1984)36 DLR 232.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 76(2)—</strong>Bar to jurisdiction of Civil Court— Settlement of khas lands—Suits filed by tenants challenging order of cancellation of their settlement by the Commissioner is not barred under section76 (2) of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdul Majid Vs. Province of East Pakistan (1971) 23 DLR 203.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">S. 79—</span></strong>Sections of Part V become operative in different areas or districts from the date of publication of Notifications and thereupon B.T. Act stood repealed to those areas or districts.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdul Mannan Vs. Kulada Ranjan Mowali (1979) 31 DLR (AD) 198.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—All holders of land within the area in respect of which the compensation assessment-roll had been published became tenants under the Government and if there had been any land gained by accession they became tenants liable to pay rent to the Government, in respect of the said land as well u/s 44.<em>   Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The retrospectively of the said provision cannot therefore be extended beyond the first day of the agricultural year next following the publication of the notification under section 43(2) of the Act, evidencing the final publication of the Compensation Assessment-Rolls. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 80</strong>—Chapter V of the Act came into force in Jessore District on 1.8.63.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Haratulla Sardar Vs. Md. Majid Baksh Daria (1967) 19 DLR 630.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 81</strong>—The expression “there shall be one class of holders of agricultural land”—Explained. Distinction within the class of raiyati holding would remain till publication of notification under section 80 repealing Bengal Tenancy Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">This expression in section 81 indicates that on and from the date of acquisition under section 3 of the Act all the lands would be held under the Government as raiyats and the distinction between classes of raiyals as distinguished from different classes of tenancies, such as tenure, raiyati-holding, etc. would go, but within the classes of raiyati-holdings the distinction of occupancy-holding, non-occupancy holding, settled-raiyat and raiyat at fixed rate would continue till the publication of the notification under section 80 bringing into operation the whole of Part V of the Act and repealing Bengal Tenancy Act as a whole.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Saheb Meah Vs. Habban Ali (1967) 19 DLR 714.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—After the Notification issued under section 3 of the Act, the status of the under-raiyat became upgraded to that of raiyat.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Anwara Begum Chowdhury Vs. Nurjahan Begum (1975) 27 DLR (AD) 109.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Section 81 provides that with effect from the date from which Part V comes into force in any area all holders of agricultural land under the Government be known as maliks.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>SM Basiruddin Vs. Zahurul Islam Chowdhury (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 230.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Existing classifications of tenants (as they stood under B.T. Act) shall continue to exist till Part V of the Act came into force and thereafter all holders of agricultural land shall be known as maliks—Till Part V came into being rights and liabilities of the holders of agricultural lands arc governed by the BT Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>SM Basiruddin Vs. Zahurul Islam Chowdhury (1983 )35 DLR (AD) 230.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 81(2)(3)—Nadabipatra not a deed of transfer—No pre-emption</strong>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A nadabipalra being merely a deed of disclaimer disclaiming any interest in the properties transferred by an earlier sale-deed is not itself a deed of transfer and, therefore, no right of pre-emotion can be claimed upon the registration of such a deed of nadabipatra.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Simply the fact that the document was registered and ad valorem stamp-fee was paid on the document—that by itself cannot turn a deed of disclaimer into a deed of transfer<em>.</em> <em>(1959) 11 DLR 539.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Section 24 not repealed by section 81 (2)(3) of the State Acquisition Act. It cannot be said that subsections (2) and (3) of section 81 of the E.B. State Acquisition and Tenancy Act have repealed section 24 of the Non-Agricultural Tenancy Act by implication. <em>(1968) 20 DLR 1197.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 81A</strong>—Rights and liabilities of nonagricultural tenants to be governed by the Nonagricultural Tenancy Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>SM</em> <em>Basiruddin Vs. Zahurut Islam Chowdhury (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 230.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Position of tenants of non-agricultural lands under sec. 81A falls under two categories referred to in sub-sections (1) and (2) of sec. 81A. Their positions as referred to in sub-sections (1) and (2) explained.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">According to the section 81A, such tenants have been divided into two categories, namely, (1) those who have become tenants under the Government because of the acquisition of the superior interest of their landlords by the Government under the Act and were governed by the provisions of the East Bengal Non-Agricultural Tenancy Act at the time of the acquisition of the superior rights over the said land, and (2) other non-agricultural tenants. The rights and liabilities of the tenants of the first category would be regulated by the East Bengal Nonagricultural Tenancy Act and those of the second category would be controlled by the terms of the lease and the provisions of the Transfer of Property</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Act except in the matters relating to determination, enhancement or reduction of rent or sub-letting, which would necessarily be governed by the provisions of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Ali Ekabbar Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh (1974) 26 DLR 394.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sec. 81A (and s.24 of Act XIII of 48)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Provisions regarding right of pre-emption made in Act 28 of 1951 and Act 13 of 1948 are quite different.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Under the provisions of sub-section (1) of section 81A of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, the rights and liabilities of a holder of nonagricultural Land, in so far as they were sought to be not affected by this sec. (that is s.81A) were to be governed by the provisions of the Non-Agricultural Tenancy Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The relative positions of the holders of nonagricultural land and agricultural land concerning the right of pre-emption under the two different Acts have not been disturbed by any express provision. Neither in sub-s.(2) of sec.81A nor in any other provision in Part V of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act is there any provision which has obliterated the distinction.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Abdur Rouf Vs. Ahmuda Khatun (1981) 33 DLR (AD) 323.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Retention of different classes of tenants in the record of rights prepared or revised under Chapter IV of this Act was intended for completing some consequential result.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>SM</em> <em>Basiruddin Vs. Zahurul Islam Chowdhury (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 230.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A raiyat creating under him an under raiyat—Vis-a-vis amongst themselves they are not co sharers and on government acquisition of rent- receiving interest, the under-raiyat becomes raiyat, but he does not become a co-sharer with the former raiyat—In such case preemption is not allowable u/ s.96 SAT Act on account of transfer of land as one is not a co-sharer of the other<em>. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>SM Basiruddin Vs. Zahurul Islam Chowdhury (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 230.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 82(8)</strong>—Raiyat and tenant to be known as malik and rent to be called land revenue—Change brought in by Chap. V.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Haladhar Dutta Vs. Abdul Rob Chowdhury (1984) 36 DLR 193.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.86</strong>—Tenant’s right in his diluviated land subsists for 20 years—In case where this period is over he can still save his right by payment of rent.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Right, title and interest of a tenant in his diluviated land subsists during the period of diluvion not exceeding 20 years and he is entitled to immediate possession of the same on reappearance of such land within 20 years of diluvion of the lands irrespective of the question whether any abatement of rent has been taken for the lands or not. Under the provisions of the East Bengal State Acquisition Act, the tenant will be entitled to possession of the land, subject to the limitation regarding total area that can be possessed under section 20 or 90 of the State Acquisition Act. But if the land reappears beyond 20 years after diluvion then he cannot claim right to the land as a matter of course. It is, however, conceivable that a tenant may contrive to have subsisting interesting such land irrespective of the extent of the period of submergence of the land if he has continued to pay the entire rents and the same has been accepted or realised.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdur Rahman Gazi Vs. QM Rahman (1969) 21 DLR 192.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Provisions of sub-sections (2) and (3) of section 86 of the Act cannot be given any retrospective effect beyond the date of coming into force of Part V of the Suite Acquisition and Tenancy Act in the area in which the diluviatcd land is situated. <em>Abdul Mannan Vs. Kulada</em> <em>Ranjan Mowali (1979) 31 DLR (AD) 195</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The suits, applications, appeals and other legal proceedings referred to in sub-section (5) of s. 86 must necessarily involve claims which come within the mischief of sub-sections (2) and (3) of section 86 and relate to lands which arc lost by diluvion after the commencement of the State Acquisition and Tenancy (Sixth Amendment) Order as well as lands which were lost by diluvion before the commencement of the Order but have re-appeared after coming into force of Part V of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdul Mannan Vs. Kulada Ranjan Mowali (1979)31 DLR (AD) 195.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Provision of sub-s.(3) of s.86 when not applicable in case of re-appearance of land in situ.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If the disputed lands re-appeared in situ more than 12 years before filing of the application by the petitioners and they have been in possession of the same since such re-appearance being recognized by the landlord the provisions of sub-section (3) of P0 135 of 1972 will not be applicable in respect of such lands.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Nurul Hasan Mia and others Vs. Kherode Sarker &amp; others (1980) 32 DLR 96.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 87</strong>—The provisions of the section which occur in Part V and which deal with incidents of a holding are no: retrospective in effect.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">With the acquisition of all rent-receiving interests under the State Acquisition Act on the 14th April, 1956, the plaintiffs in this case became raiyats under the Government but the incidents of their holding continued to be governed by the provisions of the Bengal Tenancy Act which Act in view of section 80 of the State Acquisition Act, stood repealed only with effect from the date of coming into operation of Part V of the latter Act, that is, with effect from 1.8.1963 on which date the said part was applied to the district of Chittagong.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Chapter XIII which includes section 87 of E.B. State Acquisition Act deals with incidents of holding of ralyats as defined in section 89(2). The Bengal Tenancy Act deals with the incidents of occupancy and other holdings. The provisions of these two Acts were not intended to be operative simultaneously. As the Bengal Tenancy Act was kept alive till before 1.8.1963, the clear implication is that Chapter XIII including section 87 were intended to be operative from the date of application of Part V of the State Acquisition Act by a notification under section 79 thereof and not from an earlier date. Thus, the said section 87 which is a substantive law is not retrospective in operation by implication.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Province of East Pakistan Vs. Imam Sharif (1966) 18 DLR 276.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Section 87(3) read with clause (e) and (f) of section 3(4)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Any suit or appeal, etc. which have been brought on the basis of tenant’s right recognized under clauses (e) and (1) of s.3(4) in respect of any accorded land is outside the provision of sub-section (3) of s.87 and therefore provisions of sub-section (3) of s.87 are not attracted to such a suit, etc.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Abdul Mannan Vs. Kulada Ranjan Mowalli (1979) 31 DLR (AD) 196.</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Such a suit is really on the basis of the statutory right conferred by clauses (c) and (1) of section 3(4) or items (2) and (4) of section 44 of the Act and is, therefore, outside the purview of sub-section (3) of section 87 of the Act and therefore no court shall pass an order that the suit has abated and shall not be proceeded with. <em>Ibid</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Having regard to the legal consequences following from section 3, no retrospective effect can be given to the provision of sub-section (2) of section 87 of the Act.   <em>Ibid</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The use of the word ‘malik’ in place of the word ‘raiyat’ or ‘tenant’ in s.87(2) makes it clear that the legislative authority was contemplating a situation in sub-sections (1) and (2) of section 87, which could arise only after the coming into force of Part V of the Act. The retrospectively of the provision of s.87 (2) cannot be pushed beyond the date of commencement of Part V of the Act in the area where the accretion has taken place. (1966) <em>Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Only such accretions as took place after Part V of the Act came into operation are affected by the provision of sub-section (2) of s.87. <em>Ibid</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—As regards accretions which took place after the notification under sections 3 and 43 and before the coming into force of Part V of the Act— provision of s.87 not applicable. <em>Ibid</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—On June 28, 1972 the riparian owner’s right of accretion was abrogated by President’s Order No.72 of 1972 which substituted, in place of section 87 of the Suite Acquisition and Tenancy Act, a new section 87.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The provision of sub-section (1) of section 87 that the land gained by accession shall not be considered as an increment makes it clear that the said provision is applicable only when all the rent-receiving interests were acquired by the Government u/s 3(4) with effect from the date specified in the notifications issued u/s 3(I), in which case all interests of rent-receivers in their estates, taluks, tenures, holdings or tenancies vested in the Government and further from that date all such tenants become tenants directly under the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The entire interests of the whole body of rent- receivers were acquired with effect from 14th April, 1956 and since then all accreted lands adjoining those of the tenants or rent-receivers become a part of their tenancies by virtue of the aforesaid provisions of the Act. <em>Ibid</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The immediate basis of the plaintiffs claim is their statutory right conferred by clauses (e) and (1) of s.3(4) and thereafter under items (2) and (4) of s.44. Their claim cannot be said to be reformation in situ and, as such, the present suit cannot be said to be a Suit for a “claim to the repossession of any land lost by diluvion.” <em>Ibid</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Reformation in situ</strong> : Where a land reappears on its old site which originally belonged to one person, he does not lose his ownership of it only because the reappeared land joins the land which belongs to another man and the latter cannot claim it as an accession to his land<em>. </em><em>Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Sees. 86 and 87 of Part V become operative in different areas or districts from the date of publication of Notifications and thereupon B.T. Act stood repealed to those areas or districts. <em>   </em><em>Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—S.87 read with s.79 will have effect only when Part V becomes operative. <em>  </em><em>Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The provisions of the section which occur in Part V and which deal with incidents of a holding arc not retrospective in effect.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">With the acquisition of all rent-receiving interests under the State Acquisition Act on the 14th April, 1956, the plaintiffs in this case became raiyats under the Government but the incidents of their holding continued to be governed by the provisions of the Bengal Tenancy Act which Act in view of section 80 of the State Acquisition Act, stood repealed only with effect from the date of coming into operation of Part V of the latter Act, that is, with effect from 1.8.1963 on which date the said part was applied to the district of Chittagong.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Chapter XIII which includes section 87 of EB State Acquisition Act deals with incidents of holding of raiyats as defined in section 89(2). The Bengal Tenancy Act deals with the incidents of occupancy and other holdings. The provisions of these two Acts were not intended to be operative simultaneously. As the Bengal Tenancy Act was kept alive till before 1.8.1963, the clear implication is that Chapter XIII including section 87 were intended to be operative from the date of application of Part V of the State Acquisition Act by a notification under section 79 thereof and not from an earlier date. Thus, the said section 87 which is a substantive law is not retrospective in operation by implication.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Province of East Pakistan Vs. Imam Sharif (1966) 18 DLR 276.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 87(I) and 82(2)—</strong>The word “raiyat” occurring in section 87(1) means the raiyat as defined in section 82(2). <em>Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 89</strong>—Non-service of notice of transfer on a co-sharer does not amount to fraud.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Osman Gani Vs. Safi Anwar Hussen (1967) 19 DLR 347.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 90—</strong>It is only when Chapter XIII of the Act comes into full play that there will be an automatic adjustment and if the provisions of that Chapter are by efflux of time fully worked out, a tenant or raiyat cannot possess any land, whatever might have been the previous classification of such land, beyond the limit of three hundred and seventy five standard bighas.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Secy, M.A.S. <em>Madrassa Vs. Province of East Pakistan (1963) 15 DLR 37.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 90 &amp; 96</strong>—Statement as to area of land referred to in s.90 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act must not be vague and evasive but clear in that the area in possession of the pre-emptor will exceed 100 bighas if the application is granted (which may necessitate framing of an issue on the question.)</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Shahidur Rahman Molla Vs. Abdul Halim Molla (1983) 35 DLR 79.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 90</strong>—Mere omission by the pre-emptors to make an assertion regarding the ceiling of land and in the absence of any averment to the contrary there cannot be any ground for dismissal of the preemptors case.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sultan Ahmed Vs. Md. Islam (1984) 36 DLR 81.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 90 and 96</strong>—The pre-emptors did not specifically allege that if the pre-emption application is allowed, the added land would exceed the permissible limit of land allowance under the law by the three pre-emptors to be held. In this connection a reference may be made to the decision in the case of Shahidur Rahman Molla and others Vs. Abdul Halim Molla and others 35 DLR 79.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sultan Ahmed Vs. Md. Islam (1984) 36 DLR 81.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 92</strong>—The onus is on the Government to prove that the last owner died intestate.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Geeta Rani Vs. Bangladesh (1984)36 DLR (AD) 225.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 95—A ralyat can only enter into a complete usufructuary mortgage as defined in s. 2(6) of the Act.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Section 95 of the Act provides that a raiyat could not enter into any form of usufructuary mortgage other than the complete usufructuary mortgage as defined in section 2(6) of the Act and every such complete usufructuary mortgage is subject to the limitation of section 90. The State Acquisition and Tenancy Act placed embargo that “notwithstanding anything contained in any law for the time being in force a raiyat shall not enter into any form of usufructuary mortgage other than complete usufructuary mortgage”. The Transfer of Property Act so far as mortgage of a raiyat-holding is concerned is thus displaced.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The amendment was made by President’s Order No.88 of 1972 and section 95A was inserted by the same President’s Order. Section 95A provides that in any transaction when the transferor receives from the transferee any consideration, and transferee acquires the right to possess and enjoy the usufruct of such holding, etc. for a specified period in lieu of such consideration, then such transfer shall be deemed to be a complete usufructuary mortgage for not exceeding 7 years and the provisions of section 95(4) and (5) will apply for restoration of possession.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Bangladesh Vs. Haji Abdul Gani Biswas and others (1980) 32 DLR (AD) 233</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The Supreme Court (Appellate-side) has, on the interpretation of section 95 and 95A of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, reversed the earlier decision of High Court Division on precisely the same point [see (1974) 26 DLR page 394]. Due to the importance of the point at issue the head-notes of that case is reproduced below. The head-notes run as follows:</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Transfer of a holding or part thereof by a raiyat by way of out and out sale with an agreement of to reconvey shall be deemed a complete usufructuary mortgage for maximum 7 years. So also when a transferor received consideration from the transferee who, on the basis thereof, possesses and enjoys the usufruct of the land—that shall be treated a complete usufructuary mortgage. To both transactions section 95(4)(5) shall apply. Provisions of the Transfer of Property Act shall not apply to such kinds of transactions.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Transactions subsisting when P0 88/72 was promulgated are hit by s. 95A save and except those which were not alive when P0 88172 was promulgated, being transactions past and closed. <em> Ibid.   </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A raiyat can only enter into a complete usufructuary mortgage as defined in s.2(6) of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act.<em> Ibid.   </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—S. 95 &amp; 95A</strong>—After an enjoyment of the usufruct for a maximum period of 7 years, u/s 95A the raiyat has the right to get back the property as provided in s.95. <em>   Ibid.   </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Since 1928 all sorts of mortgages— usufructuary mortgage, mortgage by conditional sale, anomalous mortgage—shall be deemed to be complete usufructuary mortgage defined in the B.T. Act. <em> Ibid.   </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Transaction entered into with raiyat, by way of mortgage, is not governed by the Transfer of Property Act but must be deemed a complete usufructuary mortgage as defined in the Bengal Tenancy Act. <em> Ibid.   </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—So far as the complete usufructuary mortgages. are concerned with its meaning as given by the law there is no question of vested interest. President’s Orders 88 of 1972, 136 of 1972 and 24 of 1973 are valid law. <em> Ibid.   </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 95</strong>—After expiry of 7 days (unless earlier redeemed on repayment) mortgagor will get back his property—Mortgagor’s right to redeem subsists for 60 years.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abu Bakkar Vs. Nazir Ahmed (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 237.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section 95</strong>—(after its amendment by PO 86/ 72) gives the mortgagor the right to get his property by application to a Magistrate—Amendment by P0 86/72 further says, an out-and-out sale with a condition of reconveyance will still be treated a complete usufructuary mortgage. <em> Ibid.   </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Once a mortgage always a mortgage—Bar of past and closed transaction not applicable. <em> Ibid.   </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 95(4)—</strong>Sub-section (4) of section 95 of the Act does not debar filing civil suit by mortgagor.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Jahir Ahmed Vs. Badsha Mia Sowdagor (1984) 36DLR 90.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—PO Nos. 88 and 136 of 1972 and P0 24 of 1973 arc valid laws—Transfer of a holding or part thereof by a raiyat by way of out and out sale with an agreement of recovery shall be deemed a complete usufructuary mortgage for maximum 7 years—So also when a transferor received consideration from the transferee, who on the basis thereof possesses and enjoys the usufruct of the land—shall be treated a complete usufructuary mortgage—to both transactions section 95(4)(5) shall apply—Provisions of the Transfer of Property Act shall not apply to such kinds of transaction.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Transactions subsisting when P0 88/1972 was promulgated are hit by s. 95A save and except those which were not alive when P0 88/1972 was promulgated being transactions past and closed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Bangladesh Vs. Haji Abdul Gani Biswas (1980) 32 DLR (AD) 233.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">President’s Order Nos. 88 and 136 of 1972 and No. 24 of 1973 are all valid legislation for effecting necessary amendments in the East Bengal Slate Acquisition and Tenancy Act and those laws cannot be attacked on the ground of ultra vires; (2) any transfer of a holding or part thereof by a raiyat either by way of out and out sale with an agreement to reconvey or where the transferor receives from the transferee any consideration and transferee acquires the right to possess and enjoy the usufruct, shall, notwithstanding anything contained in the document relating to the transfer, be deemed to be a complete usufructuary mortgage for a period of maximum 7 years and the provisions of section 95(4) and (5) of the SAT Act shall apply to such transfer; (3) and such transfers are not to be understood in the light of the Transfer of Property Act because those are to be understood in the light of the enactment in question; (4) those transactions which are subsisting on the date of promulgation of President’s Order No. 88 of 1972 are hit by section 95A including the transaction entered into by way of an out and out sale with an agreement to reconvey, made whether before or after the promulgation of President’s Order No.88 of 1972; and (5) as for the transactions which were not alive before the promulgation of President’s Order No.88 of 1972 they arc concluded by the transactions past and closed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Bangladesh Vs. Haji Abdul Gani Biswas (1980) 32 DLR (AD) 233.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 95A</strong>—Introduced by PO No. 24 of 1973 is discriminatory and as such unconstitutional.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Section 95A of E.B. Act XXVIII of 1951 affects only one class of persons, viz, agricultural tenants: the law providing for extinction of interest of such tenants acquired on the basis of a transaction of an out and out sale with agreement to reconvey, but without affecting other class of people must be considered discriminatory and violative of the fundamental right guaranteed under Article 27 of the Constitution when there appears to be no rational basis of this classification.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The law regulating the right of an agricultural tenant to mortgage his land may not be considered to be discriminatory inasmuch as indebted agricultural tenants who constitute poorer section of the people may be regarded as a class apart for which there appears to be a rational basis, having a just and reasonable relation to the object of the legislation. But the position of such a person with regard to the land which he has acquired on the basis of a deed of out and out sale with an agreement to reconvey, has no unique distinction providing a reasonable basis for classification for the purpose of expropriation.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Ali Ekabbar Farazi Vs. Government of Bangladesh (1974)26 DLR 394.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Insertion of the word ‘or’ in s. 95A by P0 24 of 1973 when interpreted in ordinary way is viola- Live of the fundamental right and as such unconstitutional.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Effect of the impugned legislation (i.e. s. 95A of EB Act XXVIII of 1951) in its literal interpretation is a virtual prohibition against this common form of transaction, so far as the agricultural tenants are concerned, and there having been no reasonable basis for such a differential provision, the said legislation may well be considered to be discriminatory. So, if the expression out and out sale with an agreement to reconvey is construed in its ordinary and natural meaning, in consequence of insertion of the word ‘or’ in section 95A by President’s Order No. 24 of 1973, then the said provision will be discriminatory and as such violative of the fundamental right as provided in Article 27 of the Constitution.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Ali Ekabbar Farazi</em> <em>Vs. Government of Bangladesh (1974) 26 DLR 394.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—If the word “transfer” in s.95A is to mean transfer by way of mortgage, then the agreement to reconvey must be inserted in the same deed as required by s. 58(c) Transfer of Property Act and in case there are two deeds each must be registered.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The word ‘transfer’ in section 95A has been used in the sense of a transfer by way of a mortgage, the necessary conclusion which follows from the said premises is that in order to bring a transaction of out and out sale with an agreement to reconvey within the purview of the said section, the agreement to reconvey shall have to be incorporated in the deed effecting the transfer, in view of the proviso to section 58(c) of the Transfer of Property Act. If the transaction consists of more deeds than one each of the deeds must necessarily be registered in accordance with the provision of sub-section (2) of section 95 of the Act. <em>   Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Section 95A if construed literally and read in the ordinary way will seriously .‘effect rights of a bonafide purchaser, a sequence which ‘-cannot be contemplated. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Right of repurchase sometimes conceded as a personal right given by the purchaser to the seller and not assignable or heritable. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—This right of repurchase may also be heritable and assignable—Such right operates within strict limits and must be strictly construed.<em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Since a literal construction of this section leads to absurd results courts are called upon to find Out a rational meaning which it bears<em>   Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Part V of the Act came into force first in Patuakhali on 5.8.74 and last in the district of Faridpur on 5.8.65. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Since transfers contemplated by s.95A apply to all transactions made before 2:8.72 as well as those after that date, such transactions must be mortgages. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Read with amendment introduced by P0 24 of 1973. Placing of the word ‘or’ in P0 24 of 1973 not natural—Insertion of words ‘or otherwise’ and not merely ‘or’ is more appropriate.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Ali Ekabbar Farazi Vs. Government of Bangladesh (1974) 26DLR 394.</em> Reversed by the decision in <em>Bangladesh Vs. Haji Abdul Gani Bishwas (1980) 32 DLR (AD) 233.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—PO Nos. 88 and 136 of 1972 and P.0.24 of 1973 are valid laws—Transfer of a holding or part thereof by a raiyat by way of out and out sale with an agreement to reconvey shall be deemed a complete usufructuary mortgage for maximum 7 years— So also when transferor received consideration from the transferee, who on the basis thereof possesses and enjoys the usufruct of the land—shall be treated a complete usufructuary mortgagee—to both transactions section 95(4)(5) shall apply—Provisions of the Transfer of Property Act shall not apply to such kinds of transaction.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Transactions subsisting when P0 88/72 was promulgated are hit by s. 95A save and except those which were not alive when P0 88(72 was promulgated being transactions past and closed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Bangladesh Vs. Haji Abdul Gani Biswas (1980) 32 DLR (AD) 233.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The present law regarding usufructuary mortgage was enacted to protect the helpless raiyat.<em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The legislature in section 95 provided that the raiyat shall not enter into any form of usufructuary mortgages other than the complete usufructuary mortgage. The legislature also prohibited a contract of Out and out sale with a clause of reconveyance and by a deeming clause had made such transaction as complete usufructuary mortgage. In other words, in Bangladesh a raiyat cannot enter into any other transaction of his raiyat holding except a complete usufructuary mortgage. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—After an enjoyment of the usufruct for a maximum period of 7 years u/s.95A the raiyat has the right to get back the property as provided in s. 95. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Since 1928 recourse was taken of the deeming provision by the legislature and all sorts of mortgages, usufructuary mortgages, mortgages by conditional sale, anomalous mortgages have been displaced by providing that all such mortgages by a raiyat “shall be deemed to be a complete usufructuary mortgage” for which a definition was given in the Bengal Tenancy Act. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Transaction entered into with raiyat, by way of mortgage is not governed by the Transfer of Property Act but must be deemed a complete usufructuary mortgage as defined in the Bengal Tenancy Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The High Court Division has fallen into error by construing the expression “transfer” in the context of the Transfer of Property Act. Since 1928 the Legislature wanted to take out the transaction of the raiyat from the purview of Transfer of Property Act for which specific definition was supplied, namely, “complete usufructuary mortgage” in the Bengal Tenancy Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">So far as the complete usufructuary mortgages are concerned with its meaning as given by the law there is no question of vested interest.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The High Court Division observed that the vested right of the property should not be extinguished “except in the manner as provided in the second part of Article 42(1) or 47(1)”. There is, however, no question of vested right because the complete usufructuary mortgage presupposes the restoration of land to the transferor either by redemption or by efflux of time whichever is earlier.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A transferee enjoyed the rights during these years before redemption or restoration and the transaction known in vernacular is “Khai Khalashi’ for which both the principal and interest are liquidated. Therefore, the question of vested right does not arise, nor can it be said that the raiyat gets it as a windfall because, after all, the property is his and he had to transfer it as complete usufructuary mortgage or “Khai Khalashi” in order to obtain loan. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p> </p></div></div>
2397	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1951 [Section 9 - 20]</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>   (1971) 23 DLR 60, (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 174, (1954) 6 DLR 326, (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 230, (1984) 36 DLR 193, (1969) 21 DLR 854, (1984) 36 DLR 193, (1962) 14 DLR 425, (1966) 18 DLR 666,  (1961) 13 DLR 538, (1962) 14 DLR 603, (1969) 21 DLR 854, (1967) 19 DLR 9,</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  State Acquisition and Tenancy </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u> </u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1951</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 9</strong>—Solenama which does not show the creation of sub-tenancy or granting of sub-lease of lands but it records the recognition of the existence of such tenancy from a date of distant past—Such solenama cannot be hit by the provisions of sections 9 and 75 of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Pijush Kanti Chowdhury Vs. Abdur Rashid (1971) 23 DLR 60.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 9(1)</strong> (After amendment by EP Ordinance 27 of 1961)—Transfer of land not exceeding 10 bighas, whether it is agricultural or non-agricultural land, valid, after the amendment of 1961 which is made retrospective.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Hafizuddin Ahmed Vs. Mahabubul Huq (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 174.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">1258</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 11 and 12</strong>—By section II nankar tenants have been given a right of occupancy with effect from 16th of May 1951, the date on which the Act came into force.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Latif Ali Vs. Manwar Ali (1954) 6 DLR 326.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.12—</strong>Section 3 of the East Bengal Service Tenant (Protection) Ordinance 1952, docs not embrace the proceedings under section 12 of the East Bengal State Acquisition and Tenancy Act. The proceedings affected by section 3 of the Ordinance arc applications for execution of a decree for ejectment or other proceedings relating thereto or suit for ejectment. An application by the landlord under section 12 of the East Bengal State Acquisition and Tenancy Act is neither an application for execution of a decree for cjcctmcnt nor is it a suit for ejectment.<em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The word ‘thereto’ in section 3 of the Ordinance refers either to “application” or “decree for ejectment” and not to “cjcctmcnt of a service tenant”. Section 3 of the Ordinance does not affect an application under section 12 of the East Bengal Slate Acquisition and Tenancy Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Though the East Bengal State Acquisition and Tenancy Act gave occupancy right to the nankar tenant, the right was conferred with effect from the date when the Act came into force. Section 3 of the Ordinance is designed to give protection from such suits and proceedings. It does not refer to a proceeding under section 12 of the Act. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 17</strong>—Retention of different classes of tenants in the record-of-right, prepared or revised under Chapter IV of this Act was intended for completing some consequential results.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>SM Basiruddin Vs. Zahurul Islam Chowdhury (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 230.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sees. 17 &amp; 19—Functions under these sections.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">There arc two provisions under the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act regarding preparation of the record-of-rights. Under section 19 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act in view of the notification of the Government under section 17 of the Act a drahi record-of-rights was prepared for the purpose of acquisition of the rent-receiving interest or under the same provisions the record-of-rights that ‘was pre</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">pared under Chapter X of the Bengal Tenancy Act would have been revised in respect of any district. part of a district or of any local area as the Government would deem fit and necessary. The particulars which were required to be incorporated under those draft record-of-rights have been mentioned in the rules framed for the purpose.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Haladhar Datta Vs. Abdul Rob Choudhury (1984) 36 DLR 193.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 19</strong>—The presumption of correctness as to C. S. Khatians under the Bengal Tenancy Act is not available with regard to the State Acquisition Khahan. There is no presumption of correctness in re- spect of State Acquisition Khatian like the one under section 103 B of the BT Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Halima Begum Vs. Syed Ahmed (1969) 21 DLR 854.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sees, 19&amp;144—</strong>ln the absence of final publication of record-of-right as provided in sections 19 and 144 there can not be any presumption as to  correctness.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Haladhar Datta Vs. Abdul Rob Choudhury (1984) 36 DLR 193.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Purpose for which record-of-rights arc prepared under Chapter IV as well as those prepared under Chapter XIV of the SAT Act. In the absence of any materials on record to the effect that the separation of original tenancy has been effected as provided in s. 117 (l)(c) a co-sharer’s right to pre-empt cannot be denied.<em>   Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 19(1)—</strong>A Revenue Officer acting under section 19(1) is not a Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Md. Kafiluddin Vs. State (1962) 14 DLR 425.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 19(2)—</strong>Special Judge adjudged the order passed by the Assistant Settlement Officer wrong and directed the party to seek relief in a Civil Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The Special Judge held that the Assistant Settlement Officer in disposing of an appeal under section 19(2) of the Act passed a wrong order and directed I the party affected by the order to seek relief in a competent Civil Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Held: This is a perfectly legal order.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdul Mannan Vs.
