Mafizuddin Bepari (1958) 10 DLR 527.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The Revenue Authority, namely the Additional Collector of Revenue has no power or jurisdiction to declare a kabala void.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>A Noor Vs. Prov. of East Pak. (1966) 18 DLR 666.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">S. 19(3):</span></strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">The decision of the Revenue Authority is not operative against a person who was not a party to the proceedings<em>. </em></span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mafizur Rahman Vs. Prov. of East Pak. (1961) 13 DLR 538.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Record of right when finally prepared shall be conclusive evidence that it has been prepared or revised under Chapter IV which deals with the subject of preparation of record of right. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The recording by a Revenue Authority while preparing the record of rights has nothing to do with the question of title. In a Suit for title, the entries as to possession can be investigated to see if they have got foundation. If they arc found to be correct, then the question of adverse possession is to be decided.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Hamid Ali Vs. Rahola Khatun (1962) 14 DLR 603.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The presumption of correctness as to C.S. Khatians under the Bengal Tenancy Act is not available with regard to the State Acquisition Khatian. There is no presumption of correctness in respect of State Acquisition Khatian like the one under section 103 of the BT Act<em>. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Halima Begum Vs. Syed Ahmed (1969) 21 DLR 854.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Unlike the provision of s. 103(5) B.T. Act, the finally published record-of-rights under section 19(3) is not conclusive evidence of the correctness of entries in the record of right, but only that it was duly prepared and revised.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Khairod Chandu Das Vs. Bhuti Ram Das (1967) 19 DLR 9.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 20</strong>—Hats and bazars of the rent-receivers vested in the Government from the date of notification of acquisition and those belonging to the tenants vested in the Government from the date of final publication of compensation assessment roll.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Shamsur Rahman Khan Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh (1983) 35 DLR 299</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Any bazaar which includes any land, building or hut therein cannot be retained by any rent-receiver or raiyat or tenant., </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Ananla Dev. Chakra Bigraha &amp; ors Vs. Bangladesh (1983) 35 DLR 301.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Maximum limit of retainable land shrinks to the size mentioned in section 20 when Chapter XIII comes into play.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">No arrangement exists by which a tenant would become automatically dispossessed of his non- retainable classes of lands.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is only when Chapter XIII of the Act comes into full play that there will be an automatic adjustment and if the provisions of that chapter are by efflux of time fully worked out, a tenant or raiyat cannot possess any land, whatever might have been the previous classification of such land, beyond the limit of three hundred and seventy five standard bighas.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Secy, Muktagacha Abbasia Senior Madrassa Vs. Prov. of E Pak. (1963) 15 DLR 37.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The scheme of Act, therefore, is that whatever is not retainable vests in the Government by operation of law and that too free from all encumbrances. The High Court was, therefore, not right in holding that the interest of tenants or raiyats in such hats and bazars had not vested in Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Province f East Pak. Vs. Secretary, Muktagacha Abbasia Senior Madrassa (1964) 16 DLR (SC) 281.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Wakf Estate—Distribution of khas lands of wakf estate among its beneficiaries not permissible.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">There is no authority under the EB State Acquisition and Tenancy Act for distribution of khas lands among the beneficiaries of a wakf estate. The wakf estate is itself a person and can retain possession of such quantity of khas lands as is permissible under the Act. The order of the Revenue Officer distributing khas lands of the wakf estate amongst the beneficiaries of the wakf estate was bad in law.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Khawaja Mayenuddin Vs. Province of East Pakistan (1969) 21 DLR 886.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Lands claimed to have been acquired by Government as excess khas lands of the ex-rent-receiver should be mentioned in the CA Rolls.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If all the lands stood acquired by Government being excess khas lands of e ex-rent-receiver, one should normally find them mentioned in the compensation assessment-rolls of the mouza with compensation assessed thereof.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If the lands had been recorded in the finally published khatians as the ex-rent-receiver’s khas lands, the plaintiffs were not obliged to make Government a party.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Hafiz Afsar Jama Khan Vs. Tarulata Dasi, (1969) 21 DLR (Board of Revenue) 7</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 20(2)</strong>—Retainable khas lands—Government’s taking away of lands in khas possession within the area of 375 bighas—Unlawful.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The petitioner complained that the Revenue authorities were trying to take away and settle with others the land in his khas possession which was in excess of 100 standard bighas even though under the Amended Law, 1961, the retainable area of khas lands has been increased from 100 to 375 standard bighas.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held:</strong> Any attempt to take away and settle lands in khas possession when the area of such lands is not in excess of 375 bighas, will be unauthorized in law.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sree Gour Nitai Saha Vs. Province of East Pakistan (1970) 22 DLR 143.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Proviso—Maximum limit of retainable land shrinks to the size, that is, 375 bighas mentioned in section 20 when Chapter XIII comes into play.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">No arrangement exists by which a tenant would become automatically dispossessed of his non- retainable classes of lands. <em>(1963) 15 DLR 37.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Government’s taking away of khas lands within the area of 375 bighas, unlawful. <em>(1970) 22 DLR 143.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Acquirable lands which are not retainable under section 20 do not vest in the Government on the publication of compensation assessment-roll without assessment of the compensation, that is, such lands must be included in the compensation assessment-roll<em>. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Shaha Md. Elias Shah Vs. Prov. of E. Pak. (1965) 17 DLR 277.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—From the words used in clause (ii) of s. 20 (2)(b), it is clear that hat and bazar are not included in the said Clause.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Yusuf Ali Chowdhury Vs. Prov. of E Pak. (1957) 9 DLR 674.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Explanation (b)—”Family’, what the words means—Mutwalli when cannot claim the entire property.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The explanation of ‘family’ as given under explanation (b) of section 20 of the Act cannot be applied in the case of the family of a wakcef, for disposal of the portions of the property which devolve on all the legal heirs and representatives of the wakeef. The position of a Mutwa Hi is as good as other legal heirs and representatives of the wakeef. In that view of the matter Mutwalli alone cannot reap the benefit of the property set apart as secular property<em>. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Shamsuzzoha Nurul Amin Chowdhury Vs. Province of East Pakistan (1970) 22 DLR 377.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 20(2a) proviso</strong>—Hat or Bazar—Mere proximity to Hat or Bazar—does not make a shop as a building in a Hat.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Serajul Haque Vs. Hurunnessa Chowdhury (1970) 22 DLR 715.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 20(2a) and 44(3)—</strong>Hats and bazars belonging to the rent-receiver vested in the Government with effect from the date of the Notification in 1956 and so far as raiyats, etc. arc concerned vesting took place after the final publication of the compensation assessments-roll and its final publication u/s 44(3).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">After the retrospective amendment made by Ordinance No. XII of 1960 in section 20 of the East Bengal State Acquisition and Tenancy Act by the incorporation therein of sub-section(2a) which had the effect of excluding Hats and Bazars from the category of retainable lands from the very beginning, the Hats and Bazars in the khas possession of a rent-receiver became vested in the Government from the date of the Notification in 1956 under sub-section (2) of section 3 of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">But so far as raiyats,, agricultural tenants and other tenants are concerned, the vesting took place after the preparation and final publication of the compensation assessment-roll and it’s Notification by virtue of sub-section (3) of section 44 of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Province of East Pakistan Vs. Md. Sahabuddin Qazi, (1973) 25 DLR 248.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 20(2a)—</strong> The term fishery means the business of catching fish and the right connected therewith. Due to the peculiar geographical phenomena prevailing in the riverine part of this Province, a considerable part of the Province remains submerged for several months of the year. During this time, fishes may be available and may also be caught in these submerged areas. It cannot be said that these areas vest in the Government as fisheries as long as they remain under water and revert to the owners thereof as soon as the water recedes.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A fishery is a right to catch fish in any water of a more or less permanent nature, where fish is capable of being reared and caught throughout the year as an occupation, business or industry. Casual availability of fish in such areas will not render them a fishery.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In other words, in order to constitute a closed fishery, the land concerned must contain so much water throughout the year as is sufficient for enabling rearing and catching of fish therein and, that too, in pursuit of fishing as a trade, business, occupation or industry. As a corollary, it follows that the purpose of the lease and the nature of the tenancy right recognized and treated by the lessee and the manner in which the land is being used or capable of being used are all important factors to be considered in determining whether a land does or does not constitute a fishery. If the purpose of lease is not one for fishing exclusively, or if the land grows or is capable of growing crops or if the owner of the land is being usually recognized and treated by the successive landlords including the Government as a raiyat then the inference would be that the land concerned is not a fishery.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Province of East Pakistan Vs. Tasiruddin Ahmed (1968) 20 DLR 435.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Hat is made non-retainable land by section (2a) of s. 20—Tenant’s right to retain some special kind of khas land (as for example hat) besides the maximum permissible limit of 375 bighas, not having been specifically taken away, it cannot be said that a tenant is deprived of his right to retain such land nor the same automatically vested in the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Secretary, Muktagacha Senior Madrassa Vs. Province of East Pakistan. (1963) 15 DLR 37.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 20(2)(a)—</strong>Fresh notification for acquisition of kutchery ghar not necessary. It is not correct to say that if and when the Provincial Government decides to acquire the katcharyghar it will be necessary for them to issue a fresh notification under section 3(2) of the Act Action already taken, if supplemented by an order of the Provincial Government specifying the property in question as ‘one which they have decided to acquire, will effectually serve the purpose.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Secretary, Revenue Department, Govt. of E Pak. (1964) 16 DLR (SC) 125.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Kutcheryghar does not become acquired upon is issue of notification under section 3(2). It must 1bc acquired upon an express decision to that effect.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Govt. of E Pak. Vs. Ibrahim Mondal (1964) 16 DLR (SC) 125</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Lands with buildings on and let out arc to be treated as retainable khas lands of the owner. <em>(1968)20 DLR 627.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Kutchery buildings and contiguous vacant land with a hat, if transferable.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Under s. 3 of EB Act V of 1952 no one can transfer kutchery building or any land contiguous toit or any vacant land situated within a hat or bazar without previous permission of Collector. Every Transfer in contravention of this shall be null and void. <em>1961 PLR 11 Dacca 1000 PLD 1964 (SC) 420.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A kutchery would come within the category of retainable khas land, unless the Provincial Government has decided to acquire. The Government will have to acquire under a notification under section 3 (2), which is the only manner prior to a final publication of the assessment-rolls by which such property can be acquired.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Ibrahim Mondal Vs. Prov. of £ Pakistan (1963) 15 DLR 703.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Acquisition of kutchery by the Govt. must be published otherwise it comes within the category of retainable khas lands.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mr. Gokul Chowdhury Roy Vs. Province of East Pakistan (1963) 15 DLR 62.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 20(2a)—Hats and bazars pass to the Government only U/s. 20(2a).</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Apart from the general provisions of section 20 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950 there is no other special statutory provisions authorizing the Government to acquire market already remaining under the ownership and possession of a local authority and a Pourashava.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Question is whether any land or building in a hat or bazar which inevitably includes a market as such can be retained by a local authority like a Pourashava.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Srimangal Pourashava Vs. Bangladesh (1980)32 DLR 156.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Tanks are retainable by the owner.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Tanks in which fish is reared are retainable in view of the provision of section 20(2a) of the Act. Although the plaintiffs have averred that people of the bazar and villagers use the water of the tanks yet, in our opinion, it does not make the tanks part of the bazar. By use of water of the tanks no right whatsoever has been created in favour of the users. The plaintiffs have succeeded in establishing a prima fade case that the tanks are retainable khas tanks of the plaintiffs.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sree Sree Ananta Deb Chakra Bigraha Vs. Bangladesh (1983) 35 DLR 301.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A hat where marketing of various articles take place and which has structures on it is not covered by clause (iii) of s. 20(2)(b).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>SM Nurul Huq Vs. Province of E Pak. (1973) 25 DLR 476.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—By virtue of s. 20(2a)(b) hats or bazars stand acquired—No fresh notification under s. 3(2) is necessary. <em>Tofazzal Hossain (1963)15 DLR (SC) 139.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Hat—If necessaries of life are not sold on a land either daily or on particular days of the week the land cannot be said to be a hat.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Hashem Ali Hawlader Vs. Province of East Pak. (1968)20 DLR 18.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The Provincial Government has no right to acquire under the provision of SAT Act, by virtue of their notification No. 4845 LR dated 2.4.56, the hats owned and possessed by persons who are not rent—receivers.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Mohar Ali Vs. Province of East Pakistan (195 7)9 DLR 569.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A hat where marketing of various articles take place and which has structures on it is not covered by clause (iii) of section 20(2)(b).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The hat under consideration is a hat within the meaning of clause (12) of section 2 and it sits regularly once in a week where people assemble for marketing their commodities and making purchases. Such a hat does not fall within the category of vacant none—agricultural land under section 20(2)(b)(iii) of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>SM Nurul Huq Vs. Prov. of East Pakistan (1973) 25 DLR 476.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Bazar with some structures on which are held once in the morning every day can be acquired but hats which remain vacant except being used for sale of cattle once a week fall within the definition of vacant non-agricultural land under sub-clause (iii), clause (b) of section 20(2) and, therefore, such hats cannot be acquired under section 3(2) of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Yousuf Ali Chowdhury Vs. Province of E Pak. (1959) 11 DLR (SC) 316.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The term fishery means the business of catching fish and the right connected therewith.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">n order to constitute a closed fishery, the land concerned must contain so much water throughout the year as is sufficient for enabling rearing and catching of fish therein and, that too, in pursuit of fishing as a trade, business, occupation or industry. <em>(1968)20 DLR 435.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Right of fishery. Right of fishery in a navigable river—Not a profit arising Out of land—Cannot be acquired under the Act.<em> (1959) 11 DLR 145.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A several fishery is an incorporeal right and cannot be acquired under the Act<em>. (1959) 11 DLR 145.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Forests and fisheries.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Forests and fisheries not being specified in the notification of the 2nd April, 1956, it is open to any person to move the authority to release any properties which have been seized and to which the Act does not apply.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Ali Haider Khan Vs. Prov. of E Pakistan (1958) 10 DLR (SC) 80.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Inland fishery falls within the definition of ‘estatc’ and ‘land’ and as such can be acquired.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Tozammel Hossain Vs. Prov. of East Pakistan (1959) 11 DLR 145.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Hat—Distinctive feature of hat. It is a place for assembling persons daily or on particular days in a week for purposes of buying or selling articles of general household use. The setting up of a few shops cannot be described as establishing a hat or bazar.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Kazi Bahauddin Ahmed Vs. Province of East Pakistan (1963) 15 DLR 5.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—In the present case a number of persons set up a few shops immediately adjacent or in close proximity to the old hat which had thus gradually extended itself.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Held: Unless there is independent evidence to show that a hat was set up as a result of all these persons acting in concert the extended portion in continuity of the old hat cannot be said to be a hat within the meaning of section 2 of the EP. Hats and Bazar (Establishment and Requisition) Ordinance<em>. Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—No fresh notification for acquisition of hats and bazars necessary.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">No fresh notification for the acquisition of interests of tenants in hats and bazars was necessary, because, that was to follow as a consequence of the publication by operation of the provisions of the statute itself, and it is for this reason that in subsection (3) of section 44 language used is that they shall be deemed to vest absolutely in the Provincial Government, that is to say, that as a legal consequence of the notification of the final publication of the compensation assessment-roll they shall be treated as if acquired and vested in the <em>Government. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Province of East Pakistan Vs. Secretary, Muktagacha Abbasia Senior Madrassa (1964) 16 DLR (SC) 281</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—In view of the retrospective effect by Ordinance No. XII of 1960 in section 20 by the incorporation therein of sub-section 2(a) which had the effect of excluding hats and bazars from the category of retainable lands from the very beginning, the hats and bazars in the khas possession of rent-receivers became vested in the Government from the date of the notification in 1956 under sub-section (2) of section 3 of the Act.<em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Time of vesting of hats and bazars.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Hats and bazars vested in the Government with effect from the date of the Notification in 1956 u/s 3(2) and so far as raiyats, etc. are concerned vesting took place after the final publication of the compensation assessment-roll and its final publication u/s. 44(3).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Province of East Pakistan Vs. Md. Sahabuddin Gazi (1973)25 DLR 248.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Hats and bazars pass to the Government after introduction of sub-section (2a) to s. 20.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Prov. of E Pak. Vs. Nakuldas (1968) 20 DLR 769.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 20(2)(b)(ii)—</strong>’Cultivable land’ does not include hat and bazar. The qualifying word cultivable’ indicates that land must be capable of cultivation without alteration or conversion. It cannot mean a conversion of land from one use to another. The word ‘cultivable’ clearly shows that the Legislature never intended to include hat and bazar within clause (ii) sec. 20(2) (b)</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">From the words used in clause (ii) of section 20(2)(b), it is clear that hat and bazar arc not included in the said clause.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Yusuf Ali Chowdhury Vs. Province of East Pakistan (1957) 9 DLR 674=8 PLR (Dac) 315.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 20(2) clause (b)(ill)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Bazars with some structures on, which are held once in the morning every day, can be acquired but hats which remain vacant except being used for sale of cattle for some Lime once a week fall within the definition of vacant non-agricultural hand under sub- clause (iii), clause (b) of sec. 20(2) and, therefore, such hats cannot be acquired cls. 3(2) of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Yusuf Ali Chowdhury Vs Province of East Pakistan (1959) 11 DLR (SC) 316.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A hat where marketing of various articles take place and which has structures on it is not covered by clause (iii) of s. 20(2) (b).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In the present case the hat does not sit only for the sale of a particular thing or commodity but it is a hat in which several commodities are marketed and there are also permanent shops and huts. On the other hand, there was no structure on the hat in the case of Yousuf Ali Chowdhury, 9 DLR 674. The said hat used to be held for some time once in a week only for sale of cattle and for the rest of the week the hat remained vacant. But this is not so with regard to the hat of the present case where there are permanent shops and other huts and it does not remain wholly vacant for the rest of the week. The hat under consideration is evidently distinguishable from the hat in the case of Yusuf Au Chowdhury. In this view of the matter, it cannot be said that it is not a hat in the proper sense of the term.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Therefore, this hat under consideration is a hat within the meaning of clause (12) of section 2 and it sits regularly once in a week where people assemble for marketing their commodities and making purchases. Such a hat does not fall within the category of vacant non-agricultural land under section 20(2) (b)(iii) of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">SM <em>Nurul Huq Vs. Province of East Pakistan (1973) 25 DLR 476.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 20, sub-sec (4B)—</strong>Land in excess of the permissible limit when cannot be retained.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The owners formed a Co-operative Society and filed a title suit being TS No 441 of 1966 for permanent injunction to restrain the Government from interfering with their excess land an allotting the same to any other person. Their main contention was that on co-operative basis they have undertaken to do large-scale farming. The Trial Court granted plaintiffs prayer for temporary injunction.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Basis of the plaintiffs prayer was that he was entitled to a certificate for retaining the excess land. Such certificate was, in fact, granted but was later on cancelled by the Board of Revenue. That matter was challenged and ended with the judgment of the Supreme Court of Pakistan.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The order of cancellation was challenged in Writ Petition No. 169 of 1964 but the Writ petition was dismissed and the order of cancellation of the certificate was maintained. An appeal against the said order of the High Court was dismissed by the Supreme Court which observed that the ex-rent receivers got no legal right to grant of a certificate under sub-section (4) of s. 20 After this decision of the Supreme Court no suit for permanent injunction against the Government is maintainable whether it is filed by the ex-rant-receivers directly or in the name of their co-operative society. While the certificate granted by the Revenue Authority, which is revisable, permit’s the retention of the quantity of land in excess of the permissible limit, such certificate does not confer any right upon the certificate-holder because sub-section (4B) says,” the land held under a certificate under sub-section(4) or 4A) by the prescribed Revenue Authority shall absolutely vest in the Government and the certificate-holder on an application submitted by him for granting a Lease on a long-tern basis in respect of such land” but he is to give up “claim of compensation” and such land may be Leased out to him under certain conditions.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The purpose of the law clearly is this that the certificate-holder becomes the lessee under the Government and he is to give up his claim of compensation which otherwise woukl has been admissible to him. Such being the right and privilege the question is whether the plaintiff can claim any injunction restraining the Government from interfering in the setting of such facts when admittedly no certificate is in existence. The opinion is that no right inheres in him so as to entitle him to an injunction.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In this case no case has been made Out for temporary injunction nor any certificate is in existence and, therefore, the question what is the distinction between the temporary injunction or status quo or whether there is any distinction at all becomes academic.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Debishahar Agricultural &amp; Fish Farming Cooperative Society Ltd. Vs. Narayan Chandra Swarnakar &amp; others (1983)35 DLR (AD) 98.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 20(3)—</strong>When actual area is known and the stage of exercising the option is over then the khas lands of rent-receiver become liable to be acquired. <em>1964 PLR 14 Dacca, 80.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—When the rent-receiver does not exercise his right of choice after notice served on him, the Revenue Officer can acquire the khas lands in excess of the limit imposed by law. If the procedure is not followed the acquisition will be illegal. <em>Haji Abdus Sattar (1964)16 DLR 92.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S20(5)—</strong>The State can acquire wakf properties like the other properties and only they have to qualify and restrict such acquisition in the manner provided in sub-section (5) of section 20.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Jibendra K. Acharya Vs. Prov. of E Pak. (1956) 8 DLR 457.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">(Regarding the observations of the Supreme Court regarding the question of acquisition of wakfs, etc., see <em>(1959) 11 DLR (SC) 318. </em>See also under Article 15 of the Constitution)</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Withdrawal of the notification in question and fresh notification in the purported exercise of power derived from the Act, of which the relevant provisions must now be treated as being in full force and operation.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Prov. of East Pak. Vs. Mahdi Ali Khan Panni (1959)11 DLR (SC) 318.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—In Jibendra Kishore’s case, the Supreme Court declared the law that in view of Article 18(b) of the Constitution wakfs and wakfs al-al-aulad cannot be acquired by the Government under E.B. State Acquisition Act. The High Court on remand following the law as laid down by the Supreme Court correctly held that expropriator notifications for acquisition of such wakfs are void. What the Provincial Government seeks in the guise of appeal against that High Court’s previous judgment is a review which is entirely incompetent. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Section 3 or section 37 does not offend against Article 5 or Article 18 of the Constitution of 1956, so far as wakfs and debuttor estates are concerned.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Jibendra Kishore Acharya Vs. Prov. of East Pak. (1957) 9 DLR (SC) 21.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The notification issued by the Provincial Government under the authority of EB Act XX VIII of 1951 for the acquisition of the estates having been issued under a void law were themselves void., and although that law regained option in that respect upon the making of the Proclamation on 10th October, 1958, the notifications themselves did not regain validity. Therefore, despite the fact of the abrogation of the late Constitution and the promulgation of the Laws (Continuance in Force) Order, the High Court on remand, held that the acquisitions by the Government of wakf and debutter were void, being based on the law declared by the Supreme Court in Jibendra Kishorc’s Case, was perfectly legal and valid.<em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—In view of Article 18(6) of the Constitution of 1956 properties of religious institutions cannot be acquired by Govt. under SAT Act. The High Court correctly held that expropriator notification for acquisition of such wakfs or debutter is void. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 20(5)—Clause (i)(c).</strong> What the Supreme Court decided (while remanding the appeals to the High Court) was to expound the law that wakfs in view of Article 18(b) of the Constitution of 1956 were not acquirable by the Government and left it to the High Court to apply that law if the High Court found the properties, after investigation, to be wakfs—The function of the High Court not being ministerial but judicial. <em>(1959) 11 DLR (SC) 318.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The properties of wakfs, wakf-af-al-aulad and debutter, which were religious institutions within the meaning of Article 18, Constitution of Pakistan (1956) cannot be acquired under the impugned Act viz. East Bengal State Acquisition and Tenancy Act. 1950. (As held earlier by the High Court).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Muhammad Mahdi Ali Khan Panni Vs. Province of E Pak. (1958)10 DLR 96.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Dedications of property to religious trusts— Document to be read as a whole to find out the real purpose.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Where a document shows that the property has been substantially dedicated to religious or charitable purpose, it becomes a religious trust notwithstanding the use of the words lessor, lessee or rent in the document.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Kishti Dhar Roy Vs. Province of East Pakistan (1962) 14 DLR 680.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Clause c(ii)—</strong>Charitable and religious institutions are protected. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>—</em>The debutter and wakf properties are not affected notification dated 9.5.59.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Province of East Pakistan Vs. Kishiti Dhar Roy 16 DLR (SC) 457.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Whether acquisition of debutter property by notification No. 7463, LR dated 9.5.59 valid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If a valid debutter has been created in respect of properties by a deed, then these properties would not affected by the said notification. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Non retainable lands.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">So much of land under wakf, debutter, wakf-al-al-aulad or any other trust as is exclusively dedicated and income of which is exclusively applied to religious or charitable purpose without reservation of pecuniary benefit for any individual. The State can acquire wakf properties like the other properties only they have to qualify and restrict such acquisition in the manner provided in s. 20(5).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Prov. of E. Pak. Vs. Khawaja Hahibullah Bahadur</em> (<em>1966)18 DLR 727.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">S. 20(5)—</span></strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Acquisition of wakf when fundamental right not in existence. Religious institutions such as wakfs or debutters, guaranteed under the Fundamental Rights are not acquirable under the East Bengal State Acquisition Act, but when Fundamental Rights are not in existence such acquisition will be valid in law and subsequent enactment of the Fundamental Right will not invalidate such acquisition. </span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Province of East Pakistan Vs. Khawaja Habibuliah Bahadur (1966)18 DLR 727.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Rent-receiving, interest and non-retainable khas lands of wakf vested in the Government from 14th April, 1956 notifications and not excepted by 9th May, 1959 notifications.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Under the notifications of the 2nd April, 1956, the rent-receiving interests and the non-retainable khas lands at least of the wakfs and debuttors having rent-receiving interests vested in the Provincial Government on and from 14th April, 1956.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The legal consequence under section 44, amongst others, is that all acquirable interest “other than the interests which have already been acquired under Chapter Il” vest in the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Jalil Ahmed Vs. Province of East Pakistan (1967) 19 DLR 106.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Government’s acknowledgement by the notifications of 9.5.59 that they did not acquire the wakfs etc. by the notification of 2.4.56. In effect notifications of 9.5.59 are re-issuance of notifications of 2.4.56 and expressly excluded all the properties of religious institutions.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The (majority) decision in Mahdi All Khan Panni’s case (11 DLR (SC) 318) was confined to the set of appeals before the Supreme Court. No declaration in the Judgment that all acquisitions of 2.4.56 valid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Jalil Ahmed Vs. Province of East Pakistan (1967) 19 DLR 106.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Notifications of 2.4.56 did not acquire the wakf when the Constitution of 1956 was alive. <em>   Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—In reissuing the notices on 9th May, 1959; the Government exempted those properties which had been held by the Supreme Court in Jibendra Kishore’s case 9 DLR (SC) 21 to be protected from acquisition.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">For this reason the notifications of 9th May, 1959, were the re-issuance of the notice of 2nd April, 1956, without the vitiating inclusion of properties held by the Supreme Court to be exempted from acquisition under the Act as it stood. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Notifications of 2nd April, 1959, did not extinguish the right of any petitioner to challenge the validity of the acquisition purported to be made by those notifications. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Steps to be taken for actual physical possession not taken by the Government—Notification does not amount to acquisition. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—When actual physical possession of wakfs not taken they are intact after 10.1.64 when Fundamental Right regarding freedom of religious rights come into being. <em>  Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—(Contra: minority view)—Government notifications of 2.4.56 as well of 9.5.59 with regard to the acquisition of wakf and debutter estates—Latter notifications did not exempt wakfs from acquisition. Sattar, J, (Ali, J. agreeing with him).—It is impossible to hold that the Government decided when they issued the notifications of the 9th May, 1959 to exempt all wakf and debuttor estates from acquisition. The intention appears to be not to acquire any wakf or debuttor property which had not been till then acquired.<em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Protection offered by Article 18 of the 1956 Constitution having disappeared with its abrogation, while appeals were pending before the Supreme Court, Government’s acquisitions under section 3(1) (2) could not be challenged. This also implies that all wakfs stood acquired under 1956 Constitution<em>.   Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Acquisition revives when Fundamental Rights ase gone—Subsequent introduction of Fundamental Right not being retrospective does not help. Effect of Supreme Court’s decision in Mehdi Au Khan’s case.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If acquisition of such properties takes place under the Act at a time when no such fundamental right is in force the same cannot be challenged on the basis of Fundamental Rights having been brought in force subsequent to the acquisition. <em>   Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Supreme Court in Jibendra Kishorc’s case declared that acquisitions by Notifications in April, 1956 of Wakf and Debutter properties under section 3(1)(2) of the Act were illegal and ultra vires. But with the abrogations of the 1956 Constitution and its replacement by the Laws (Continuance in Force) Order, 1958, Fundamental Rights under 1958 Constitution became dead and thereupon the acquisition of Wakf and Debutier properties which were made by Notifications in April, 1956 revived and regained their life and it must therefore he held that properties held in wakfs and debuttcr vested in the Government by virtue of the Notifications issued under section 3 (l)(2) in Chapter II, and those that were not so acquired by Notifications under section 3(1)(2) m April, 1956, stood subsequently acquired and vested in the Government on the final publications of the compensation assessment-rolls under ss. 43 and 44 (This conclusion has been arrived at on the basis of the majority’s decisions in Khan Panni’s and Dosso’s cases). Minority view expressed therein by the learned Chief Justice was that writ petitions made under the 1956 Constitution challenging acquisitions on the basis of Fundamental Right did not abate with the abrogation of 1956 Constitution.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Introduction of Fundamental Rights in the 1962 Constitution in 1964 being at a time when the Government’s acquisitions of Waki and Dcbutter properties under Chapters II and V had already taken place and therefore the present writ petitions on the basis of Fundamental Rights embodied in 1964 were of no avail and must be dismissed as non-maintainable.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Chowdhury Tanbir Ahmed Siddiky Vs. Prov. of E Pak. (1968) 20 DLR (SC) 144.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Wakf Estate—Distribution of khas lands of wakf estate among its beneficiaries not permissible.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">There is no authority under the E.B. State Act question and Tenancy Act for distribution of khas lands among the beneficiaries of a wakf estate. The wakf estate is itself a person and can retain possession of such quantity of khas lands as is permissible under the Act. The order of the Revenue Officer distributing khas lands of the wakf estate amongst the beneficiaries of the wakf estate was bad in law.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Khawaja Mayenuddin Vs. Province of East Pakistan (1969) 21 DLR 886.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Explanation (b): </strong>“Family’, what the word means—Mutawalli when cannot claim the entire property.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The explanation of ‘family’ as given under explanation (b) of Section 20(5) of the Act cannot be applied, in the case of the family of a waked, for disposal of the portions of the property which devolve on all the legal heirs and representatives of the wakeef. The position of a Mutawalli is as good as other legal heirs and representatives of the wakeef. In that view of the matter Mutawalli alone cannot reap the benefit of the property set apart as secular property.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Shamsuzzoha Nurul Amin Chowdhury Vs. Province of E Pak. (1970) 22 DLR 377.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 20(5)(a)(ii)—</strong>But where the property is dedicated partly for religious or charitable purpose and partly reserved for the pecuniary benefit of any individual, only such portion comes within s. 20 (5)(1)(c) as may be in accordance with the Rules on behalf of Govt. As to wakf and debuttor properties excluded by s. 20(5) acquisition of their khas lands must go and to this extent the notifications were invalid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Province of East Pakistan vs. Khawaja Habibullah Bahadur (1966) 18 DLR 727.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.20(5)</strong>—Wakif’s heirs alive represent the wakf estate.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The test is who can represent the wakf estate for the purpose of this section. Mutwalli though he represents the wakf estate for the purpose of s. 3, cannot so represent for the purpose of this section.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Bangladesh Vs. Shamsuzzoha (1976) 28 DLR (SC) 195.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The State can acquire wakf properties like the other properties and only they have to qualify and restrict such a acquisition in the manner provided in sub-section (5) of section 20. (1956) 8 DLR 457.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">[Regarding the observations of the Supreme Court regarding the question of acquisition of wakfs’, etc., <em>see 11 DLR (SC) 318</em>. See also under Article 15 of the Constitution].</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 20(5)(i)(c)—</strong>Clause (C) does not pose any complication.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">All wakfs which arc exclusively for religious or charitable purpose will be allowed to retain all retainable khas land<em>. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Bangladesh Vs. Shamsuzzoha (1976) 28 DLR (SC) 195.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 20(5)(ii</strong>)—Share which a Mutwalli can claim in wakf property, after it ceased to be so.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In combined wakf, part of the lands consisting of the wakf being dedicated to charitable purposes and part for the benefit of the wakeef’s heirs and descendants—The area for the benefit of the wakeef’s heirs and descendants shall be distributable amongst those heirs and descendants; the Mutwalli as such shall have no share in those lands.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Shamsuzzoha Nurul Amin Chowdhury. Vs. The Province of East Pakistan (1970) 22 DLR 376.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Lands dedicated partly for the benefit of any individual will be governed by sec. 20.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Bangladesh Vs. Shamsuzzoha (1976) 28 DLR (SC) 195.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—It is further to be remembered that the heirs of the wakif come to represent the wakf estate in their representative capacity and not in their personal capacity. The land so allotted will ensure to the benefit of the wakf estate. It will subsist as part of retainable khas lands of the wakf estate. Mutwalli will, in his managerial capacity, administer the lands as part and parcel of the wakf estate.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Heirs of the wakif in the aggregate will represent the wakf estate in their representative capacity. Government shall get area of land in excess of the retainable area—Money which is allotted as compensation for excess area shall be received by the Mutwalli who shall continue to be the manager of the wakf estate.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Bangladesh Vs. Shamsuzzoha (1976) 28 DLR (SC) 195.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Mutwalli cannot represent the wakf estate for purpose of section 20(5)(ii). <em>   Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Wakf is a permanent dedication in the path of god.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Provisions in the wakf for maintenance of wakif’s family is valid and the entire income may validly be expended for wakif’s descendants with ultimate benefit to charity. etc. <em>   Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—In a mixed wakf the charitable part will continue under the original wakf in all retainable khas lands—Non-charitable part will be subject to maximum area u/s. 20(2). The land in excess of the quantitative ceiling will stand acquired to the Governance but the wakf estate will get compensation for it. Money paid by way of compensation is a wakf to be invested on the principle of cypres. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Mutwalli cannot be the owner of wakf estate. He can represent wakf estate for the purpose of sec. 3 but not for the purpose of sec. 20(2)—It is the heirs of the wakf alone who really represent the wakf estate u/S. 20(2). <em> Ibid.</em><span id="pastemarkerend"></span></p></div></div>
2398	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1951 [Section 96] - Part I</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  10 PLR (Dac) 1018, (1965)17 DLR 327, (1961)13 DLR 819,  (1962) 14 DLR 204,  (1962) 14 DLR 847, (1967) 19 DLR 677, (1975) 27 DLR (SC) 114, (1959) 11 DLR 539,  (1960) 12 DLR 479,  (1974) 26 DLR (SC) 59,(1967)I9DLR 318, (1967) 19 DLR 510,   (1967)19 DLR 615</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  State Acquisition and Tenancy </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u> </u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1951</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 96—Raiyat defined—Right of pre-emption.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Where the petitioners were allowed to exercise their right of pre-emption in respect of certain nonagricultural lands sold away by their co-sharers to a third party, the first appellate Court disallowed it, on the ground that the land had been acquired by the Provincial Government and the mere deposit of money would not be enough to cover the requirement of section 96.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Held:</span></strong> As the land is not used for cultivation, the petitioners do not come within the definition of ‘raiyat’ within the meaning of section 96 of the East Bengal State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950. <em>10 PLR (Dac) 1018.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—In order to maintain a claim for pre-emption, the pre-emptor should have an interest in the holding as a co-sharer-tenant not only at the time of the tiling of the application for pre-emption but also throughout the proceedings.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Lakhi Kanta Patibar Vs. Sunil Kurnar Patibar (1965)17 DLR 327.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Former raiyat possessing some lands in his khas possession within a holding and letting out some portion in the same to an under raiyat—After acquisition of the rent-receiving interest by the Government the under-raiyat in respect of his share of lands under the original raiyat became himself a raiyat directly under the Government—This results in effecting two separate tenancies, each independent of the other—When therefore the original ratyat transfers (after the acquisition under the Act) some lands which were in his possession the original under raiyat who now became a raiyat directly under the Government cannot claim pre-emption on the ground of his being a co-sharer, as under law he cannot be treated as a co-sharer.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Huzzat Ali Vs. Imamuddin Bapari (1961)13 DLR 819.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Application for pre-emption shall have to be filed within four months of the date of knowledge. Provisions of section 96 are procedural laws.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The question is whether to an application by a non-notified co-sharer for pre-emption in respect of a transfer, which took place, before the section 96 of the East Bengal State Acquisition and Tenancy Act came into force but filed after the said date, the provisions of the said section will apply or it will be governed by section 26 of the Bengal Tenancy Act read with the general law of Limitation.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Huzzat Ali Vs. Imainuddin Bapari (1961) 13 DLR 819.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Pre-emption, right of contiguous landowners—Sub-section (2) has two parts—Co-sharer applying for pre-emption need not impicad contiguous land holders as parties, but a contiguous land owner applying for pre-emotion must implead other contiguous land holders as well.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Raji Wahad Ali Vs. Kadam (1962) 14 DLR 204.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Co-sharer becomes party to a pre-emption proceeding from the date of notice on him—Notice on him to represent minors will not in law make him a party as a co-sharer.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Right of the remaining co-sharer tenants to join within prescribed time—Application for rateable preemption under 96(4) not possible unless application under section 96(1) was first made.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Syed Abdul Karim Vs. Harendra Chandra Dhupi (1962) 14 DLR 847.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Pre-emption application having been filed in Court any re-conveyance of the property by the transferee to the transferor will not defeat the application for pre-emption.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abu Hossain Vs. Md. Masim Au (1967) 19 DLR 677.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The suit for pre-emption was framed as one under section 96 of the LB State Acquisition Act but subsequently it being found, having the nature of the land, that pre-emption could be claimed under section 24 of the LB Non-Agricultural Act a prayer for treating the claim as one under section 24 of the EB Non-Agricultural Act was made before the High Court Division which court rejected it on the ground that it was a new case altogether.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held:</strong> The prayer ought to have been granted as it is not correct to say that new case has been made—Such amendment could also be allowed if no mention of section 24 is made in the plaint.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Jadav Chandra Mali Vs. A Khaleque (1975) 27 DLR (SC) 114.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A nadabipatra being merely a deed of disclaimer disclaiming any interest in the properties transferred by an earlier sale deed is not itself deed of transfer and, therefore, no right of pre-emption can be claimed upon the registration of such a deed of nadabipatra.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Simply the fact that the document was registered and ad valorem stamp fee was paid on the document by itself cannot turn a deed of disclaimer into a deed of transfer<em>. (1959) 11 DLR 539.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Hiba and hiba-bil-iwaj—Love and affection combined with payment of money—Deed interpreted not as hiba-bil-iwaj and provisions of sec. 26F not applicable. <em>(1960) 12 DLR 479.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A non-notified co-sharer u/s. 88 can maintain pre-emption application.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Since the respondent pre-emptor is entitled to maintain the application for pre-emption under section 26F of the Bengal Tenancy Act, the respondent, a non-notified co-sharer seeking pre-emption under section 26F of the Bengal Tenancy Act is entitled to the application for pre-emption within three years from the date of the sale.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Addition of opposite parties made beyond the period of limitation cannot be a bar for denying the right of the respondent.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Begum Asia Rahman Vs. Abdul Bashir (1974) 26 DLR (SC) 59.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Right accrued u/s. 26F, BT Act is not destroyed (in respect of pre-emption) by virtue of s. 96 of the State Acquisition Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It appears on a comparison of provisions of sections 26F of the Bengal Tenancy Act and 96 of the State Acquisition Act that the legislature by repealing the Bengal Tenancy Act did not destroy the right accrued under the Bengal Tenancy Act. From the provisions of the State Acquisition Act it cannot be said that the right accrued under section 26F of the Bengal Tenancy Act was destroyed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Begum Asia Rahman Vs. Abdul Bashir (1974) 26 DLR (SC) 59.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Provision of section 96 is different from that of section 26F of BT Act.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Right of pre-emption accrued before the repeal of the Bengal Tenancy Act does not cease to be a right under the repealed Act by virtue of section 8 of the Bengal General Clauses Act, 1899. An applicant seeking to enforce his right of pre-emption accrued under section 26F of the old Act is entitled to the rule of three years limitation as was available to him before the repeal.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdul Malek Vs. Abdur Rahman (1967)I9DLR 318.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Proviso (As stood amended by EB State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, (4th Amendment) Ordinance, 1961, giving retrospective effect to its provision.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Even though the sale deed was not legally valid when it was executed as well as when suit in relation to the sale was filed, it would be treated as valid if during the pendency of the suit a new law [in the present case 4th Amendment Ordinance of 1961] permitting such transfer comes into existence, since the Court is bound to apply the current law to its decision.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Rais Ali Vs. Jobed Ali (1967) 19 DLR 510.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Petitioner acquired a right of pre-emption in respect of the land in suit under section 26F of B.T. Act but application for pre-emption was made when section 96 of the State Acquisition Act came into force—Petitioner is entitled to pre-empt the land under the provisions of section 26F, BT Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdul Basir Bhuiyan Vs. Begum Asia Rahman (1967)19 DLR 615.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Only co-sharer tenants who arc occupancy raiyats can seek pre-emption under section 26F. The right of pre-emption under section 96, on the other hand, is an incident of a holding of a “raiyat” who is entirely different from an occupancy raiyat under the Bengal Tenancy Act, and who is a malik according to section 82(8) of that Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdul Basir Bhuiyan Vs. Begum Asia Rahman (1967) 19 DLR 615</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—The procedure of the section 96 is not retrospective in operation.</strong> To give it a retrospective effect will give rise to many difficulties resulting in injustice to an applicant whose right to pre-empt accrued when section 26F of the BT Act was operative.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Hence any construction that the procedure prescribed in section 96 has retrospective effect in the case of enforcement of a right of pre-emption accrued under the repealed section 26F is textually inadmissible.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdul Basir Bhuiyan Vs. Begum Asia Rahman (1967) 19 DLR 615.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Several holdings transferred by one document—Co-sharer of one such holding entitled to apply for pre-emption with regard to that holding—A prayer may be made by one application in respect of two distinct holdings.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mosammat Asimon Nessa Vs. Md. Akbar Ali Sheikh (1967) 19 DLR 659.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Pre-emption proceeding will be. governed by the BT Act, even after the coming into operation of Act XXVIII of 1951, unless Part V, is put in operation by Notification.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The right of pre-emption vested (in the co sharer) under section 26F of the Bengal Tenancy Act if the sale in question had taken place prior to the coming into operation of Part V of the East Bengal State Acquisition and Tenancy Act<em>. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Haratulla Sardar Vs. Md. Majid Baksh Daria (1967) 19 DLR 630.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Transfer is affected by hiba-bil-ewaz—Price stated in the document not conclusive for pre-emption purpose.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Where a transfer is effected by hiba-bil-ewaz in spite of the value put in the transfer deed by the transferor of the ‘hiba bil ewaz’ and that for the purpose of registration of the deed, the transferee when faced with a pre-emption application by a co-sharer of the holding is not estopped from proving that the price of the land transferred is higher than what has been stated by the transferor of the deed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Azizul Bari Vs. Md. Ismail (1967)19 DLR 184.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">—Korfa interest has ceased to exist from the date of acquisition 0/the rent-receiving interest under section 3—They (korfa tenants) having become raiyats the provisions of pre-emption by co-sharer tenant available to them.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">After the wholesale acquisition by the Government of rent receiving interest in 1956 there will be one kind of raiyat only in the country under the Government and that being the position there could not be any question of korfa or any other kind of sub-tenants.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The holders of korfa being upgraded to the status of raiyat, a co-sharer in respect of such interest has got the full right of pre-emption available to them under section 26F of the BT Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Priya Bala Dew Vs. Fazar Ali  (1966) 18 DLR 480.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Section 96 and the procedure and limitation under it have no retrospective application.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Serajuddin Ahmed Vs. Haris Mia (1968) 20 DLR 312.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—If by one document lands of several holdings to which the applicant is a co-sharer tenant are sold—one application for pre-empting the lands of all the holding is maintainable if the applicants claim is not barred otherwise.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Hajee Majarullab Sowdagar Vs. Mvi. Narul Haque (1971)23 DLR 68.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Pre-emption—one application for preemption was filed with regard to three independent sales of several holdings to which the applicant was a co-sharer tenant.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held:</strong> The application is maintainable if it is not barred by limitation and not also barred otherwise.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Hajee Majarullah Sowdagar Vs. Mvi. Nurul Haque (1971) 23 DLR 68.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Pre-emption—persons to be impleaded as parties in an application for pre-emption.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The persons who are to be impleaded as panics in an application for pre-emption are as follows:</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">(i) In the case of an application by a co-sharer by inheritance all other co-sharers by inheritance are to be impleaded.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">(ii) In the case of an application by a co-sharer by purchase all other co-sharers by inheritance or by purchase are to be impleaded.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">(iii) In the case of an application by a holder of land contiguous to the land transferred, all co-sharer tenants, either by inheritance or by purchase, as well as other holders of land contiguous to the land transferred, must be impleaded.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Hajee Majarullah Sowdagar Vs. Mvi. Nurul Haque (1971) 23 DLR 68</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A claim for pre-emption under section 96 supported by the record-of-rights showing the applicant as the owner of the contiguous plot of land cannot succeed where the Court has given judgment in favour of the applicant on the basis of record-of- rights alone ignoring relevant documents produced by the opposite party which showed that the recording of the applicant’s name in the record-of-rights was not correct.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Kutu Chand Miah Vs. Rabindra Kumar Deb (1970)22 DLR 295.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—By consenting to a transfer made in pursuance of a compromise decree a person loses his right of pre-empting altogether.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In pursuance of a compromise decree passed in a suit for specific performance of contract, X transferred certain land to A and B (the co-sharer tenants by purchase in the disputed plot) by a registered deed Ext. 1. Thereupon, A filed an application for preempting B’s share of land in his favour.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held:</strong> By consenting to the transfer A has lost his right of pre-emption in respect of the suit land. A is, therefore, estopped not only against the vendor and Lhe4vcndec but also against a rival pre-emptor.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Ali Khandakar Vs.
