Haji Mokshed Ali Khan, (1970) 22 DLR 449.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Petitioner purchased the disputed property in a sale held in execution of a certificate. The opposite party claiming to be the co-sharer tenant of the holding by inheritance filed an application for preemption of the disputed property.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held:</strong> The opposite party is entitled to preempt the land under section 96 of the EB State Acquisition and Tenancy Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Amjad Hussain Talukdar Vs. Basirannessa Bibi (1970) 22 DLR 489</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Question relating to jurisdiction</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">— statutory right of pre-emption not liable to be defeated by question of jurisdiction.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The statutory right of pre-emption, if otherwise available to opposite party No. I  is not liable to be defeated by reason of an erroneous decision given by the Court on the question of jurisdiction. For it is an universally by recognized principle that the Court will not permit an injustice being done to any person by reason of an erroneous order made by it, and when the erroneous order is reversed, the Court will restore the parties to the position which they would have otherwise occupied but for the erroneous order.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abul Hossain Vs. Pulin Behari Sikdar (1920) 22 DLR 535.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Court’s pecuniary jurisdiction.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Determination of pecuniary jurisdiction— Amount of consideration money or the value of the transferred holding as stated in the deed of transfer determines the valuation of the application for preemption and its forum.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abul Hossain Vs. Pulin Behari Sikdar (1920) 22 DLR 535.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Pre-emption in respect of non-agricultural land is only possible under section 24 of the E. B. Non-Agricultural Tenancy Act—Provision of section 96 of the EBSAT Act not applicable to such case.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The question is whether an application for preemption under section 96 of the Act in respect of non-agricultural land is maintainable.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The petitioner as owner of a land contiguous to the land under pre-emption, filed the application under section 96 of the East Bengal State Acquisition and Tenancy Act. The land of which pre-emption is sought is a non-agricultural land.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held</strong>: Pre-emption in respect of nonagricultural land can be claimed only under the provisions of section 24 of the Non-Agricultural Tenancy Act and not under 96 of the State Acquisition Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Section 24 of the East Bengal Non-Agricultural Tenancy Act has made specific provisions for preemption of lands which are non-agricultural lands.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Forman Ali Howladar Vs. Helaluddin Pashari (1968) 20 DLR 1197.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Pre-emption under section 96 relates to raiyati holding.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">As all the co-sharer tenants of the raiyati holding concerned are required to be impleaded even in an application for pre-emption under section 96(1) by a contiguous owner, the clear inference is that the land liable to be pre-empted by the contiguous owner must be the land pertaining to a ralyati holding.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Forman Ali Howladar Vs. Helaluddin Pashari (1968) 20 DLR 1197.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Homestead within a municipality or nonagricultural land cannot be pre-empted under section 96 of the Act by a contiguous owner of the land— Purpose for which the land was leased out is the determining factor whether it is agricultural or nonagricultural land.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Character of land is determined by the purpose for which the lease is taken. Deed of settlement is - therefore a document of great importance for determination of the character of land. In the present case it was stated in the lease-document that the lessee shall be able to construct pucca structure, buildings and also utilize the same for gardening and such other purposes. The tenancy therefore, as originally created comes within the meaning of ‘homestead’ as defined in section 2(14) of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A homestead land cannot be a raiyati land (agricultural land) even if some part of it is used for “purpose connected with agriculture”.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Section 96 of the Act lies down that the right of pre-emption is available only in respect of agricultural land. There is specific provision for preemption. of non-agricultural land in the East Bengal Non-Agricultural Tenancy Act. Under that Act a contiguous owner cannot claim right of preemption. Section 96 of the Act is confined to agricultural land and therefore a right of pre-emption under this section cannot be claimed in respect of a homestead land within a Municipality. <em>[EB Nonagricultural Tenancy Act: (XXIII of 1949)].</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mst. Lutfun Nahar Vs. Syeeda Hashmat Ara Begum (1969) 21 DLR 633</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Pre-emption cannot be claimed under section 96 in respect of homestead land (Chandina) within a Municipality.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdul Khaleq Vs. Jadav Chandra Mali (1968) 20 DLR 562.  </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Transferor of the land is not a necessary party in a pre-emption case.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In a Suit for pre-emption the co-sharers are made parties in order to enable them to exercise their similar right if they so desire. The transferor of the property is no doubt a co-sharer of the properly transferred but he cannot like other co-sharers claim for pre-emption in respect of the property transferred by him. So for determination of the case the transferor may be a proper party but not a necessary party in the suit for pre-emption. Non inclusion of a transferor of a land sought to be pre-empted will not, therefore, liable the suit to be dismissed for defect of party.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Ruhul Amin Mestory Vs. Fazar Banu (1969)2 1 DLR 647</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—One of the several co-sharers is entitled to pre-empt to the extent of his own share in a preemption case.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Eleven co-sharers claimed pre-emption in respect of the land transferred. The trial Court granted the prayer for preemption but the lower appellate Court dismissed the whole pre-emption case. As against this order of dismissal of Out of eleven co-sharers moved the High Court in revision. High Court held the order of the Munsif but held that the petitioner before the High Court is entitled to preemption only to the extent of his own share and nothing more. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 96 and 89(4)—</strong>A notified co-sharer tenant may apply for pre-emption within four months from the date of service of the notice and a non- notified co-sharer tenant as well as tenants having lands contiguous to the land transferred for whom no provision has been made for service of notice of the transfer may apply for pre-emption within four months of the date of knowledge of the transfer— Question of knowledge of the transfer is immaterial in respect of a notified co-sharer tenant.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Syed Ali Vs. Abdul Khaleque (1969) 21 DLR 463</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sec. 96</strong>—Identifier of the executants of a document not supposed to know the contents thereof. </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Habibur Rahman Vs. A Waded (1969) 21 DLR 382.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Right of pre-emption is a statutory right— Joint deposit of consideration—Homestead when part of a holding—Improvement effected on that land.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Right of pre-emption under section 96 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act is a statutory right and is to be exercised within the scope of the statute itself. There is no embargo in the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act that the right of preemption shall stand forfeited if a disqualified person is joined with the pre-emptor in an application for pre-emption.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A joint deposit of consideration money does not frustrate a right of pre-emption.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The homestead being a part of the holding of a raiyat is not excluded from the operation of section 96 of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Improvement made by the pre-empted does not create a clog to the right of pre-emption and does not alter the nature of the transfer.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Asiruddin Sk. Vs. Serajuddin Talukder (1978) 30 DLR 75.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Sale of the land in dispute took place on 7.4.69.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">On 1.8.69 a co-sharer applied for pre-emption in respect of the land sold. The vendor thereupon produced a reconveyance deed executed on 26. 7. 79 selling the same land back to him on the basis of oral agreement which was however registered on 5.8.69.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held:</strong> The application for pre-emption must fail as the land had already been reconveyed to the original vendor.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Upendra Chandra Roy Vs. Janab Ali  (1977)29 DLR 229.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Partial pre-emption of a holding not permissible.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In section 2(13) of the Act the term holding has been defined to mean a parcel or parcels of land or an undivided share thereof, held by a raiyat or an under raiyat and forming the subject of a separate tenancy. It is undisputed that partial pre-emption of a holding or a share thereof which has been transferred is not permitted in law. The pre-emptor must pre-empt the entire land of the holding or portion thereof which has been transferred.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Aktamunnessa Vs. Habibullah (1976)28 DLR 400.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Three separate plots of land were transferred by a deed of sale. A tenant holding land contiguous to the land transferred applied u/s. 96 for two out of three plots averring that these two plots are contiguous to his land. The Court on evidence found that only one plot was contiguous to the applicant’s land and allowed pre-emption of that plot only.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The High Court upheld this decision over-ruling the contention that this will lead to partial preemption.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sreemati Monkhushi Das Vs. Abdus Sobhan (1977) 29  DLR 195.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Division of a holding u/s 88 UT Act leaving out some co-sharers—Their right not affected.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A division of a holding effected u\s 88 BT Act leaving out some of the co-sharers not a valid division—Pre-emption application by co-sharers who had been left out in s. 88, division cannot be defeated—No presumption against them that they produced no rent-receipt in respect of the holding.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdus Salam Vs. Md. Nurul Islam (1975) 27 DLR 37.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Sale of the land in dispute took place on 7.4.67. Right accrued under section 26F, BT Act not destroyed under section 96.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Begum Asia Rahman Vs. Abdul Bhuiyan (1974) 26 DLR (SC) 58.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Onus is on the person who seeks to repurchase the land sold to show that the area of lands in his possession does not exceed the maximum he is entitled to retain under sec. 90.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Nayeb Ali Vs. Akhtar Rahman (1977) 29 DLR 153.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Court’s judgment should record a finding when allowing an application for pre-emption that the applicant is co-sharer or a tenant holding contiguous land.<em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Court must also record a finding that the person who seeks pre-emption is entitled to so preempt on the basis of sec. 90. <em>   Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Between the dates of filing of the- application for pre-emption, and its final disposal the vendor filed a suit for specific performance of contract against the transferee on the ground that at the time of the transfer of the holding the transferee stipulated to reconvey the property to the vendor and on that agreement obtained an ex pane decree against the transferee.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held:</strong> This being the situation pre-emption application cannot be granted.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Yekub Khan Vs. Amjad Ali Khan (1977)29 DLR 164.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Seller is a necessary party in a pre-emption proceeding if after his transfer, he still remains a co-sharer in respect of the property sold by him.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A seller is not a necessary party in a preemption proceeding unless it can be shown that he has still some subsisting interest in the holding after the transfer in question was made. For instance, if it is found that the vendor has some interest left in the holding even after the transfer in question and thus he is still a co-sharer in the holding, in that case there cannot be any doubt that he is a necessary party in a pre-emption proceeding under section 96 of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Monohar Ali Vs. Abdul Majid (1974) 26 DLR 359. </em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2399	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1951 [Section 96] - Part II</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>   (1974) 26 DLR 93, (1977) 29 DLR 178, (1966) 18 DLR 480, (1979) 31 DLR 230, (1979) 31 DLR (AD) 118, (1980) 32 DLR (AD) 183, (1980) 32 DLR (AD) 231,  (1981) 33 DLR 254,  (1981) 33 DLR 168, (1981) 33 DLR 318, (1981) 33 DLR (AD) 269, (1981)33 DLR (AD) 269, </p><p><b>Subject:</b>  State Acquisition and Tenancy</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u> </u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1951</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Partial pre-emption—Elucidated</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The expression ‘partial pre-emption’ is to be understood with reference to the definition of holding read with the provisions of section 96 of the Act and not with reference to the number of properties transferred by a particular deed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If a particular holding comprises several plots, for example, belonging to two or more co-sharers, and if one of the co-sharers transfers his share in all the plots of the holding to a stranger-purchaser, the remaining co-sharer or co-sharers, in that case, shall have to apply for pre-emption with respect to all the plots; otherwise it will amount to partial preemption and such partial pre-emption cannot be allowed because a co-sharer cannot be allowed to pick and choose arbitrarily according to his own convenience in pre-empting the lands of the same holding.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Clause (c) of sub-section (10) of section 96 of the Act stands as a bar to the petitioner’s prayer for pre-emption with respect to the lands of schedule 4. But that cannot render the petitioner’s application as one for partial pre-emption in respect of the lands of the schedules which are quite distinct and separate holding.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Tamizuddin Ahmed Vs. Guljan Bibi (1974) 26 DLR 93.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Transfer before Part V becomes operative will be governed by the BT Act even though the application made after Part V came into force.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Habibar Rahman Vs. Satish Chandra (1977) 29 DLR 178.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Read with Ss. 3 and 44(4)—Korfa interest has ceased to exist from the date of acquisition of the rent-receiving interest under section 3 of Act XX VIII of 1951—They (korfa tenants) having become ralyats the provisions of pre-emption by a co-sharer tenant available to them.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Priya BaIa Devi Vs. Fazar Ali and others (1966) 18 DLR 480.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Application for pre-emption was filed in court after the kabala in respect of the land sought to be pre-empted was executed, but before it was duly registered in accordance with s.61 of the Registration Act. The question arose whether in view of the fact that the registration of the kabala took place alter the date of the filing of pre-emption application it can be maintained as a proper application under s. 96 of SA and T Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Held:</span></strong> Though in the present case pre-emption application was filed earlier than the registration of the kabala, yet in view of the fact that the document was duly registered under s.60 of the Registration Act, the application may be treated as maintainable because the defect of non-registration was cured when the application was pending in the Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Altab Mia Vs. Wahab Ali (1979) 31 DLR 230.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Pre-emption application was filed in Court 3 days before the deed of sale in question was registered—Defect gels cured as soon as the document was registered while the pre-emption application was pending before the Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdur Rahinan Vs. Makus Ali (1979) 31 DLR (AD) 118.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—There being no word of limitation as to the nature of transfer in section 96 of the Act any transfer, which is a transfer in the eye of law, subject to the restrictions laid down in the section, is pre-emptible.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Badsha Mia Bepari Vs. Abul Bashar (1980) 32 DLR (AD) 183.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Sale in pursuance of a decree for specific performance of contract is pre-emptible.<em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Sale in pursuance of a decree for specific performance of contract is pre-emptible—Provisions embodied in section 26F of BT Act and those in section 96, State Acquisition Act, similar in nature.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In this regard the decision of Chandra Kumar Maladas v. Abdul Motaleb 19 DLR (SC) 36 may be cited where an auction-sale was assumed without contest to be pre-emptible under section 26F of the Bengal Tenancy Act. The language of section 96 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act is substantially the same as that of section 26F of the Bengal Tenancy Act and so the cited decision gives ample authority for holding that a sale in pursuance of a decree for specific performance of contract is preemptible. <em>   Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—It is true that the earlier decisions are with regard to section 26F of the Bengal Tenancy Act but the material provisions of section 26F of the Bengal Tenancy Act and those of section 96 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act arc substantially the same. The interpretation given earlier does not militate with the language of section 96 of the Act and so is applicable to the section as well.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Belayet Hossain Vs. Md. Abu Taher (1980) 32 DLR (AD) 231</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Subject of pre-emption must be strictly construed as it operates as a clog on a citizen’s right to deal with his property in tile ways he likes.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Ahmed Hossain Vs. Basharat Ali (1980) 32 DLR (AD) 55.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Right of pre-emption accrues with effect from the date of the registration of the deed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Ashutosh Mali &amp; ors. Vs. Shemsunnahar &amp; ors. (1981) 33 DLR 254</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—An order passed in a pre-emption suit conclusively determines the rights of the parties and as such has the effect of a decree—So provisions under Order 23, r. 3 regarding a compromise arrived at between the parties concerned arc applicable in a case of pre-emption u/s 96 of the SAT Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The proceeding under section 96 of the East Bengal State Acquisition and “tenancy Act is in the nature of a suit. The right, title and interest of the transferee vest in the petitioner, if is successful, and as such the order passed in a pre-emption proceeding conclusively determines the rights of the parties with regard to the land in dispute and as such this is an original proceeding and the determination of the right of parties are conclusive, whether it is called a decree or an order and the effect is the same. Therefore the provisions of Order 23, rule 3 of the Civil Procedure Code would apply in a proceeding under section 96 of the East Bengal State Acquisition and Tenancy Act whether it is in the trial Court or in the appellate Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Serajul Mostafa Vs. Ali Ahmed Sikdar &amp; ors. (1981) 33 DLR 168.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A person seeking pre-emption u/s. 96(1), if fails to state in his application what is required of u/s. 90, his application must fail.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Md.</span></em> <em>Rais Ali Vs. Imam Hussain (1981) 33 DLR 318.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The manner of impleading of parties in a partition suit is governed by Order I, rule 10, CP Code while that of implcading of parties in a pre-emption case under SAT Act is governed by section 96(2) of this Act—When impleading of parties in a preemption proceeding not necessary.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Abdul Jalil Vs. Durjan Ali alias Siddique Hossain (1981) 33 DLR (AD) 269.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The distinctive features of Motilal’s case 28 DLR (1976) page 5, vis-à-vis the instant case, has been pointed Out in para 12.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The observation of the High Court Division relying on Motilal’s case shows that it was for the pre-cinptcc to lead evidence to the effect that the left out co-sharers still got interest in the land sought to be pre-empted.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The facts of the instant case are not attracted by the decision in Motilal’s case: on the contrary, these facts are attracted by the decision in the case of Abdus Samad Vs. Sohrab Ali (1981) 33 DLR (AD) 113 in which it has been held that non-joiner of parties who got right of pre-emption is fatal to the proceeding.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Abdul Jalil Vs. Durjan Ali alias Siddique Hossain (1981)33 DLR (AD) 269.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Prior to allowing a pre-emption application. Court not obliged to record a finding that the applicant is a cultivator and land in his possession does not exceed the prescribed limit if the application is allowed as required u/s.90.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Chandu Mia Mestry Vs. KM Wajih Ullah (1981) 33 DLR 134.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Omission to state that the petitioner is a bonafide cultivator, but the statement that he is in possession of the land through bargadar is enough. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—No appeal lies under the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act against an order dismissing an application under Order 9, rule 13 CPC for restoring a proceeding under section 96 of the said Act decreed ex-parte.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Haji Karimdad Vs. Insaf Meah (1981) 33 DLR 435.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—High Court entitled, on going through the record of the case, to come to a finding that the petitioner is a bonafide cultivator.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Chandu Mia Mestry Vs. AKM Wajih Ullah (1981) 33 DLR</em> <em>135.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Order made u/s 96 is an order within the meaning of it as given in s. 2(14) CP Code.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The definition of an order given in the Civil Procedure Code fully applies in the case of an order passed by a civil court in a proceeding under section 96 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdul Hamid. Vs. Abdul Jayar (1981) 33 DLR 341.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 96 read with S. 144 CPC</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">An order passed by a civil court in a proceeding u/s. 96 of SAT Act being not a decree in a suit, no application for restitution of property u/s. 144 CP Code will be allowed. <em>   Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 96</strong>—Right of pre-emption not dependent on the initiation of a proceeding by a co-sharer tenant or owner of the contiguous land.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdus Samad Vs. Md. Sohrab Ali (1981) 33 DLR (AD) 113. (28 DLR (AD) 5, overruled by this decision.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Pre-emption right accrues on transfer of the land—All the necessary parties to the pre-emption application must be impleadcd. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">—</span></em>Ingredients of s.24 of Act XXIII of 49 and those of sec.96 of Act. XXVIII of 1951 are different— Provisions of sec. 24 of Act XXIII of 1949 attracted in case of a land in a municipal area.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Abdur Rouf Vs. Ahmuda Khatun (1981) 33 DLR (AD) 323.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Partial pre-emption not allowed where a Co. sharer tenant claims pre-emption-—Contiguous landholder may pre-empt only that part which is contiguous to his land.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Haji Tajamal Ali Vs. Abdus Sattar (1982)34 DLR (AD) 217.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Several plots transferred—These several plots however make one compact block of land— Claimant can pre-empt entire block. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Policy behind allowing pre-emotion to Contiguous land-holder—Entire land constituting one compact block (though in khatian they are recorded as several plots of land) can be pre-empted on the basis of contiguity u/s. 96.<em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—When the pre-emption case was filed, the kabala was not registered—It was however registered when the case came up in appeal at the appellate stage. But as at that stage kabala was registered the defect about the document not being registered was cured—Case remanded to the Lower Court for disposal.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Lebu Miah Vs. Ganesh Chandra Nath (1982)34 DLR (AD) 220.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—When plots are several in numbers, but themselves constitute one compact block, the entire compact block is to be treated as contiguous to the land of the person claiming pre-emption.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Haji Tajamal Ali Vs. Abdus Sattar (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 217.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—If the registration of the sale-deed takes place when a revision arising out of the pre-emption case was pending in the High Court Division the application should not be rejected even though on the date where it was filed in the original court the application was premature, since during the pendency of the case before the High Court Division document was duly registered.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Jatindra Chandra Urang Vs. Md. Shamsuddin (1982)34 DLR 264.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A Hindu widow having only a life-interest has inalienable right to pre-empt any land to which she is a co-sharer—Reversioner right will not be affected as after widow’s death the land shall revert to him.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Rai Kishori Saha Vs. Basat Ali Sardar (1982) 34 DLR 181.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Pre-emption application maintainable if the kabala (though not registered when the pre-emption application was filed) is registered when the preemption proceeding is pending in court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Tofazzal Hossain Vs. Md. Yunus Au Biswas (1982) 34 DLR 402.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A decree in a partition suit does not result in splitting up the land which can be done u/s. 117 of the SAT Act (=s. 88 of the BT Act). Therefore right of pre-emption not extinguished by partition decree.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>SM Basiruddin Vs. Zahurul Islam Choudhury (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 230.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Question of benami transaction can not be decided in proceedings u/S. 96.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Respondent I claimed pre-emption of the transferred land sold under a kabala on the ground that respondent 2(the vendor) sold the land to A (a stranger) without serving notice upon him (i.e. respondent I) though he was a co-sharer in the holding by inheritance. A’s case was that there was really no transfer as it was he (i.e. A) who purchased the land from respondent 6 in October 1970 in the benami, respondent 2 of his nephew.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held</strong>: In a proceeding for pre-emption under section 96 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, the Court is not required to entertain the question whether the vendor was benamdar of the person seeking pre-emption<em>. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Ashwini Kumar Karmaker &amp; others Vs. Hari Mohan Shil &amp; others (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 334.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Father got the land (subject matter of preemption) from one of the original owners by purchase—Sons by devolution get the same on father’s death—Sons are co-sharers with the original owners by inheritance.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdul Haque Miah Vs. Abdul Rashid (1983)35 DLR (AD) 54.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Partition simpliciter does not split up the land.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Partition on the land amongst co-sharers on the basis of civil Court decree—does not bring about the division of the tenancy having the same jama.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>S. M. Basiruddin Vs. Zahurul Islam Chowdhury (1983)35 DLR (AD) 230.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The view taken by Rahman, J. in (1960) 12 DLR 849 that when a transfer is made on condition for reconveyance, the right of pre-emption is subject to this condition for reconveyance is found to be correct being in accord with section 40 of the Transfer of Property Act as well as with reason.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Shafi Khan Vs. Mannujan Hussain and others (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 225.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Pre-emption right—Decree in a collusive decree conveying the land back to the vendor—No automatic right of pre-emption. <em>   Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Period of ignorance as to the sale of a land sought to be pre-empted—Plea of such ignorance can not extend to 12 years when the pre-emptee had been cultivating the land within the sight of the preemptor for over a decade.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Anil Kumar Vs. Syed hafiz Moinuddin (1983) 35 DLR 39.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Objection as to non-joinder of a party not taken at the earliest stage—deemed to have been waived—Disclosure of some names not impleaded as party in application u/s. 96 will not render the application bad for defect of parties.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Shahidur Rahman Mollah Vs. Abdul Halim Molla (1983) 35 DLR 79.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—If the land sought to be pre-empted has already gone back to the original vendor, no right of pre-emption can be claimed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Ramesh Chandra Barman Vs. Naresh Chandra Barman (1983) 35.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Subsequent transferee takes the transfer subject to the right available against the original transfer whether the transfer was made before or after the application for pre-emption.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Hajera Bibi Vs. Noor Jahan Begum (1983)35 DLR 238.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Vendor transfers the land to N on 28.3.74. N retransfers the same to the vendor on 3 1.3.74. Co sharer of the vendor claims the land by pre-emption u/S. 24 of the Non-Agricultural Tenancy Act on 1.11.74 (i.e. after the land had gone back to the vendor) claiming that he acquired a right of pre-emption as soon as the original sale took place on 28.3.74 and further the subsequent sale to the vendor is fraudulent just to deprive the co-sharer of his right of pre-emption.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A co-sharer applicant for pre-emption may add a subsequent transferee from the original transferee who may be substituted for the original transferee and such subsequent transferee entitled only to the amount deposited in favour of the original transferee.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Hajera Bibi Vs. Noor Jahan Begum (1983) 35 DLR 238.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Error on the face of record—Failure of the appellate Court to give decision on limitation is an error of law apparent on the face of the record which calls for an interference<em>. </em><em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—When no notice is served on the co-sharer, onus of proving date of transfer does not lie on the co-sharer—If however evidence on the issue is led by both the parties the court may come to its conclusion on the basis of evidence led. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Different sahams which were allotted to different co-sharers appertain to one holding—In the revenue records of the Government it is also not shown that the holding has been splitted up—In case of transfer by one co-sharer of his share of the land—in such case a pre-emption case will lay.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdus Salam Vs. Md. Ustar and another (1983) 35 DLR65.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held</strong>: With the conveyance of the land by N to the vendor on 31.10.71, it must be held there was no transfer of land which could be a subject-matter of pre-emption.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Shafi Khan Vs. Mannujan Hussain and other (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 225.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Right of pre-emption. when cannot aid when can be defeated. The real question is whether by virtue of retransfer the vendor actual got back the land. If it is so pre-emption right not arise—If the transaction is a colorable on. a mere paper transaction, then there has been no real re-transfer and pre-emption right will prevail. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Right to pre-emption as a contiguous owner not having been raised in the original application u/ s. 96 can not be allowed to do so by subsequently amending the application to include a claim to that effect.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Al-haj Moulvi Idris Miah Vs. Sree Shushil Ranjan Dutta (1984) 36 DLR 206.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The question of benami cannot be gone into in a summary proceeding under section 96 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act. The facts of the case of 6 DLR 589 and 51 CWN 644 are altogether different from that of the instant case.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>S Joga Maya Debi Vs SDD Singh Hazari (1984) 36 DLR 272.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Claim for rateable pre-emption by the transferee can be made even in his written Statement which he files in traversing pre-emption application u/s. 96, SA &amp; T Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Reazul Karim Vs. Mst. Shirin Begurn (1984) 36 DLR 250.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Pre-emption: Question of benami nature not to be agitated in pre-emption proceeding</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">But if in fact no transfer of the land took place and the alleged vendor continuing to be in possession, such a question can be gone into.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Ashwini Kumar Karmaker Vs. Hafizur Rahman Munshi (1984) 36 DLR (AD) 1.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—S. 96 read with Or. 9, r 13, Civil Procedure Code.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">No appeal lies against an order dismissing an application made under Or. 9, r. 13 CP Code for restoring a proceeding under section 96, State Acquisition &amp; Tenancy Act, disposed of ex-parte.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The State Acquisition and Tenancy Act does not provide for any appeal from such an order i. e. an expane order passed in an application u/s. 96 of the Slate Acquisition &amp; Tenancy Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Belayet Hossain Vs. Md. Abu Taher (1980) 32 DLR (AD) 231.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The State Acquisition and Tenancy Act does not provide for any appeal from such an order i. e. an ex-parte order passed in an application u/s. 96 of the Stale Acquisition &amp; Tenancy Act.   <em>   Ibid.</em><span id="pastemarkerend"></span></p></div></div>
2400	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1951 [Section 96(1)]</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1967) 19 DLR 655, (1977) 29 DLR 178, (1969) 21 DLR 599, (1972) 24 DLR 186, (1973) 25 DLR 397, (1962) 14 DLR 204, (1979) 31 DLR (AD) 88, (1968) 20 DLR 1197, 10 PLD (Dac) 1018, (1969) 21 DLR 633, 27 DLR (AD) 114, (1971) 23 DLR 68, (1967) 19 DLR 659, (1974</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  State Acquisition and Tenancy</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u> </u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1951</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 96(I)—Time for application by co-sharer</strong>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Sub-section (1) of section 96 of the Act requires an application for pre-emption to be made by a co sharer within four months from the date of knowledge of the sale when no such notice was issued.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Nekjan Bibi Vs. Sarojan Bibi (1967) 19 DLR 655.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Right of pre-emption when accrues.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Right of pre-emption does not accrue on the date of knowledge but on and from the date of the transfer. The period of 4 months referred to in section 96(1) of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act is the limitation prescribed for exercising the right by a tenant holding land contiguous to the land transferred from the date of the knowledge of such transfer.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Habibur Rahman Vs. Satish Ch. (1977) 29 DLR 178.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Petitioner seeking pre-emption is to prove the date of his knowledge of transfer that his petition is within time. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Right of pre-emption accrues not on the date of execution of the deed but on the date of its registration.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A sale-deed in respect of a portion of a holding in favour of A was executed on 20.2.59 but it was registered on 2.8.65.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Another sale-deed in respect of another portion of the same holding was executed in favour of B on 10.3.61 and registered on 28.3.61. In a contest over the claim of pre-emption between A and B, question arose who is the earlier purchaser of a portion of holding so as to entitle him to maintain an application for pre-emption under section 96 of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held</strong>: Right of pre-emption accrues not on the date of execution but on the date of registration of the document and hence in the present case B acquired the right of pre-emption of the land sold to A inasmuch as B’s document was registered in 1965 though the execution of A’s deed as in 1959 and that of B’s deed was in 1961.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdur Rahman Vs. Baser Ali (1969) 21 DLR 599.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Pre-emption—Holding consists of several plots—One co-sharer transfers his share in all plots—Other co-sharer must apply for pre-emption in respect of all plots.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If a particular holding comprises several plots, belonging to two-or more co-sharers, and if one of the co-sharers transfers his share in all the plots of the holding to a stranger purchaser, the remaining co-sharers in that case, shall have to apply for preemption with respect to all the plots otherwise it will amount to partial pre-emption.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Janab Ali Sardar Vs. The Controlling Authority (1972) 24 DLR 186.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—In several districts (see the body of the judgment) by virtue of government notification section 96 becomes operative with effect from 1.8.63—All transfers before this date, in respect of pre-emption rights in these districts, will be governed by section 26F, Bengal Tenancy Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Tamoshi Bewa Vs. Janu Shah (1973) 25 DLR 397.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Application for rateable pre-emption u/s. 96(4) not possible unless application u/s. 96(1) was first made.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Haji Wahab Ali Vs. Kadam Ali (1962) 14 DLR 204.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 96(1)—Preemption coming under first part and that coming under 2nd part of s. 96(1)-Requirement that has to be met in each case of pre-emption.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In a case of pre-emption coming under the first part the pre-emptor is required to establish his locus standi by showing that he is a co-sharer tenant of the holding. In such a case rule of partial preemption has been applied. In a case of pre-emption coming under the second part of sub-section (1) of section 96 the tenant is not required to meet the same test. In case of tenant’s right of pre-emption falling under the second part, the pre-emptor is required to establish that he has land contiguous to the land transferred. The expression holding land contiguous to the land transferred cannot be suetched to support the view that even in such a case the preemptor is required to include in the application for pre-emption also the lands to which he does not hold contiguous land and implead all the tenants holding contiguous lands to non-contiguous lands.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Akhtarun Nessa Vs. Habibullah (1979) 31 DLR (AD) 88.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Preemption falling under 2nd part of sub-section (1), Test—Contiguity of the land sought to be pre-empted.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A pre-emptor coming under the second part of sub-section (I) of section 96 cannot maintain his application for pre-emption for the land transferred to which he has no contiguity. According to subsection (5) (b), in such an application only those tenants holding lands contiguous to the land sought to be pre-empted are to be impleaded; and tenants holding lands contiguous to other lands transferred under the kabala but not subject to pre-emption, are not required to be impleaded. Sub-section (5) (b) removes any doubt that there might be.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Akhtarun Nessa Vs. Habibullah (l979) 31 DLR (AD) 88.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Non-agricultural land and pre-emption.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Pre-emption in respect of non-agricultural land is only possible under section 24 of the E.B. Non-Agricultural Tenancy Act. Provision of section 96 of the EBSAT Act not applicable to such case.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Forman Ali Howlader Vs. Helaluddin Pashari (1968) 20 DLR 1197.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The petitioners were allowed to exercise their right of pre-emption in respect of certain nonagricultural lands sold away by their co-sharers to a third party but the first appellate Court disallowed it, on the ground that the land had been acquired by the Provincial Government and the mere deposit of money would not be enough to cover the requirement of section 96.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held</strong>: As the land is not used for cultivation, the petitioners do not come within the definition of ‘raiyat’ within the meaning of section 96 of the EBSAT Act, 1950. <em>10 PLD (Dac) 1018.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Homestead within a municipality or nonagricultural land cannot be pre-empted under section 96 of the Act by a contiguous owner of the land— Purpose for which the land was leased out is the determining factor whether it is agricultural or nonagricultural land.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The tenancy in the present case as created comes within the meaning of “homestead” as defined in section 2(14) of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A homestead land cannot be a raiyati land (agricultural land), even if some part of it is used for purpose connected with agriculture.”</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Contiguous owner cannot claim right of pre-emption. Section 96 of the Act is confirmed 10 agricultural land and therefore a right of pre-emption under this section cannot be claimed in respect of homestead land within a Municipality.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mst. Lutfun Nahar Vs. Syeeda Hashmat Are Begum (1969) 21 DLR 633.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Pre-emption cannot be claimed under section 96 in respect of homestead land (Chandina) within a Municipality. <em>Abdul Khaleq Vs. Jadav Chandra Mali (1968) 20 DLR 562. (Reversed by 27 DLR (AD) 114.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Several holdings—If by one document lands of several holdings to which the applicant is a co sharer-tenant are sold—one application for preempting the lands of all the holdings is maintainable if the applicant’s claim is not barred otherwise<em>.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Hajee Majardullah Sowdagar Vs. Nurul Hague (1971) 23 DLR 68.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—One application for pre-emption was filed with regard to three independent sales of several holdings to which the applicant was a co-sharer tenant.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held: </strong>The application is maintainable if it is not barred by limitation and not also barred otherwise. <em>Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—Partial pre-emption</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The right of pre-emption is given to the co sharer under section 26F of the Bengal Tenancy Act with reference to ‘the holding,” that is to say, that the right accrues holding-wise. It must necessarily follow that even if there has been a sale of several holdings by one transaction and by a single document, a co-sharer has a right under the aforesaid section, in respect of a particular holding covered by the same document and of which he is to be a co-sharer. It would be a misnomer to describe it as a partial transaction.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The right conferred upon a co-sharer under the provisions of section 26F of the Bengal Tenancy Act is a distinct holding. A prayer may be made in one application relating to two distinct holdings. Conversely, two distinct applications may be made in two different periods.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mosammat Asimon Nessa Vs. Md. Akbar Ali Sheikh (1967) 19 DLR 659.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The expression ‘partial pre-emption’ is to be understood with reference to the definition of ‘holding’ read with the provisions of section 96 of the Act and not with reference to the number of properties transferred by a particular deed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If a particular holding comprises several plots, for example, belonging to two or more co-sharers, and if one of the co-sharers transfers his share in all the plots of the holding to a stranger-purchaser, the remaining co-sharer or co-sharers, in that case, shall have to apply for pre-emption with respect to all the plots; otherwise, it will amount to partial preemption and such partial pre-emption cannot be allowed because a co-sharer cannot be allowed to pick and choose arbitrarily.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Tamizuddin Vs. Guljan Bibi (1974) 26 DLR 95.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Contiguous land owner applied for pre-empting one piece adjacent to it.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Three separate plots of land were transferred by a deed of sale. A tenant holding land contiguous to the land transferred applied u/s 96 for two out of three plots averring that these two plots are contiguous to his land. The court on evidence found that only one plot was contiguous to the applicant’s land and allowed pre-emption of the plot only. The High Court upheld this decision over-ruling the contention that this will lead to partial pre-emption.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sreemati Monkhushi Vs. Abdus Sobhan (1977) 29 DLR 195.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Pre-emption of a part or share of holding when its price is mentioned separately in the kabala— allowable.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Diam Hossain Vs. Haran Das (1961) 13 DLR 283.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Application for pre-emption shall have to be filed within four months of the date of knowledge. Provisions of section 96 are procedural laws.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Application by a non-notified co-sharer for prescription in respect of a transfer, which took place before section 96 of the Act came into force but filed after the said date.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held:</strong> The right of pre-emption of the co sharers has been re-enacted in s. 96 of the Act and a person having no notice of the transfer has to apply within 4 months from the date of his knowledge. This is a procedural law and this being so the provisions of s.96 will apply to the case of a co-sharer not served with notice and if he does not come to the court within four months of the date of knowledge his application will be dismissed<em>. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Hazzat Ali Vs. Imamuddin Bapari (1961)13 DLR 819.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Expiry of the time limit dates from the time of knowledge. Impleading one as a party when time is expired does not extend the time limit.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Syed Abdul Karim Vs. Harendra Chandra Dhupi (1962) 14 DLR 847.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—If a party does not apply for pre-emption within the prescribed period he loses his right to preemption. A case of pre-emption does not abate if such a person is not impleaded.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If the right of parties seeking pre-emption u/s 96(1) becomes unenforceable by the date of presentation of the application for pre-emption on account of the lapse of the period of limitation the suit for preemption does not abate if they are not made parties to the suit.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Benodoni Das Vs. Matilal Sikder (1969) 21 DLR 262. (Reversed by 28 DLR (AD) 5 which was overruled by 33 DLR (AD) 113).</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—When the original pre-emption fails on the ground of limitation the co-applicant’s fails for pre-emption (according to their share) under section 96(4) though made in rime, not sustainable.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If the first application for pre-emption by a co. sharer tenant is made after the expiration of the periods of limitation it will not be a vali4 application within the meaning of opening words of subsection(4).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A co-applicant is entitled to pre-emption only when the first co-sharer petitioner has applied with the periods of limitation u/s 96(1).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Although the two co-applicants in the r’ case applied within the two months of the date if the service of notice of the application u/s 96(4) they are not entitled to the benefit of proportionate pre-emption.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Bijan Bala Chowdhury Vs. Maniruddia Biswas (1972) 24 DLR 170.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>General</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">By consenting to a transfer made in pursuance of a compromise decree a person loses his right 01 pre-emption altogether.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In pursuance of a compromise decree passed 11, suit for specific performance of contract, X transferred certain land to A and B (the co-sharer tena by purchase in the disputed plot) by a resisted deed Ext.  Thereupon, A filed an application for preempting B’s share of land in his favour.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held</strong>: By consenting to the transfer the purchaser of the land has lost his right of pre-emption in respect of the suit land. A is, therefore, estopped not only against the vendor and the vendee but also against a rival pre-emptor.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Ali Khandakar Vs. Haji Morshed Ali Khan (1970) 22 DLR 449.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The statutory right of pre-emption if otherwise available to opposite party No. 1, is not liable to be defeated by reason of an erroneous decision given by the Court on the question of jurisdiction. For, it is an universal recognized principle that the Court will not permit an injustice being done to any person by reason of an erroneous order made by it, and when the erroneous order is reversed, the Court will restore the parties to the position which they would have otherwise occupied but for the erroneous order.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abul Hussain Howladar Vs.</em> <em>Pulin Behari Sikdar (1970) 22 DLR 535.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Right accrued under section 26F B.T. Act not destroyed by section 96.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Begum Asia Rahman Vs. Abdul Basir Bhuiyan (1974) 26 DLR (SC) 58.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>General—Court’s pecuniary jurisdiction.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Amount of consideration money or the value of the transferred holding as stated in the deed of transfer determines the valuation of the application for pre-emption and its forum.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abul Hussain Howladar Vs.</em> <em>Pulin Behari Sikdar (1970) 22 DLR 535.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Land sold in execution of a certificate—Co-Sharer is entitled to preemption.</strong> Petitioner purchased the disputed property in sale held in executiOfl of a certificate. The opposite party claiming to be the co-sharer tenant of the holding by inheritance filed an application for pre-emption of the disputed property.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held</strong>: The opposite party is entitled to preempt the land under section 96 of the EB State Acquisition and Tenancy Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Amjad Talukder Vs. Basirunflessa Bibi (1970)22 DLR 489.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Change of law pendente lite Court to give effect to it.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Even though the sale-deed was not legally valid when it was executed as well as when suit in relation to the sale was filed, it would be treated as valid if during, the pendency of the suit a new law (in the present case EBSAT 4th Amendment Ordinance of 1961 permitting such transfer) comes into existence, since the Court is bound to apply the current law to its decision.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Rais Ali Vs. Jabed Ali (1967) 19 DLR 510.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Title Suit, when the pre-emptor not a party to it.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A decree in a title suit can not affect the right of a pre-emptor when the suit was brought without impleading the pre-emptor. Pre-emptor is entitled to get the transferred right of the vendor.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Meher Abjan Vs. Jalal Ahmed Howlader (1961)13 DLR 642.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A Nadabi-PatIa being merely a deed of disclaimer disclaiming any interest in the properties transferred by an earlier sale-deed is not itself a deed of transfer and, therefore, no right of pre-emption can be claimed upon the registration of such a deed of Nadàbi Patra. Simply the fact that the document was registered and ad-valorem stamp fee was paid on the document by itself can not turn a deed of disclaimer into deed of transfer.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Muhammad Arabullah Vs. Durgaprasad Tribedi (1959)11 DLR 539.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Division of a holding u/s 88 BT Act leaving out some co sharers—Their right not affected.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A division of a holding effected u/S. 88 BT Act leaving out some of the co-sharers not a valid division. Pre-emtion application by co-sharers who had been left out in s. 88, division cannot be defeated—No presumption against them that they produced no rent-receipt in respect of the holding.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdus Salam Vs. Md. Nurul Islam (1975) 27 DLR 27.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Sale of the land in dispute took place on 7.4.67.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">On 1.8.69 a co-sharer applied for pre-emption in respect of the land sold. The vendor thereupon produced a reconveyance deed executed on 26.7.69 selling the same land back to him on the basis of oral agreement which was however registered on 5.8.69.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held:</strong> The application for prc-emption must fail as the land had already been reconveyed to the original vendor.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Upendra Chandra Vs. Janab Ali (1977) 29DLR 229</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Right of pre-emption—Joint deposit of consideration money Homestead when part of holding— Improvement effected on that land.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The right of pre-emption shall not be forfeited if a disqualified person is joined in a pre-emption application for pre-emption.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A joint deposit of consideration money does not frustrate a right of pre-emption.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Homestead being a part of the holding of a raiyat is not excluded from the operation of section 96 of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Aseruddin Sk. Vs. Serajuddin (1978) 30 DLR 75.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Extent of contiguity of land is the only test for determining order of priority—Right in respect of contiguous plots as envisaged u/s. 96(5)(b).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">“Extent of contiguity of land” is the only test for determining the order of priority as among tenants claiming pre-emption on the ground of holding land, contiguous to the land transferred. If land transferred consists of one plot, all the tenants having land contiguous to the land under pre-emption are to be impleaded. Their right is to be determined in the manner as provided in sub-section (5)(b). In a case where land transferred consists of more than one plot, a tenant or tenants having land contiguous to the plot or plots may apply for pre-emption but in such a case, a tenant having land contiguous only to one of the plots, cannot claim pre-emption of other lands.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In an application by a tenant claiming preemption on the ground of contiguity of land, such tenant may apply to the court for the holding or portion or share to be transferred to himself or themselves.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Akhtarun Nessa Vs. Habibullah (1979) 31 DLR (AD) 89.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Deposit of consideration money if does not accompany the application for pre-emption but made later on—if the deposit is within 4 months from the date of registration of the deed or 4 months from the knowledge of transfer, is a sufficient compliance with law and is a valid deposit under the law.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Mafizuddin Sarder Vs. Md. Abdul Jabbar (1982) 34 DLR 272.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A Hindu widow having life-interest in the property is entitled to pre-emption u/s. 96(1) of the SAT Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Notwithstanding the fact that a Hindu widow has life interest in the property in question during her life-time, she remains a full owner thereof with complete right of acquisition and dispensation subject to law. Such a widow can be safely said Lo be a co-sharer of any holding or of any property as contemplated u/s. 96 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Rai Krishna Shaha</em> <em>Vs. Md. Matleb Ali Pramanik (1982) 34 DLR 178.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Proviso: </strong>Prior to allowing a pre-emption application, Court not obliged to record a finding that the applicant is a cultivator and land in his possession does not exceed the prescribed limit if the application is allowed as required u/s 90.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Chandu Mia Mestry Vs. AKM Wajih Ullah &amp; ors.
