(1981) 33 DLR 134.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Proviso: </strong>Omission to state that the petitioner is a bonafide cultivator, but the statement that he is in possession of the land through bargadar is enough. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 96(1) Read with S. 90</strong>—A person seeking pre-emption u/s 96(1), if fails to state in his application what is required of u/S 90, his application must fail.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In the instant case, the pre-emptor opposite party no. I did not make any averment on section 90 of the State Acquisition Act at all. He has, therefore, failed to show that he is a person to whom the transfer may be made under section 90. Since he has failed to meet one of the basic requirements of section 96(1) his application for pre-emption is not maintainable.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Rais Ali Vs. Imam Hussain and Ors (1981) 33 DLR 318.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—From judgment of the Munsif, in a pre-emption case, appeal will lie to the District Judge.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Md. Eshaq Vs. Ruhul Amin (1982) 34 DLR 342.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">—</span></em>Co-sharer by inheritance shall have the highest priority followed by a co-sharer by purchase and thereafter a contiguous owner. Co-sharer comes first in priority over a contiguous owner.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Dhirendra Narayan Das Vs. Gouranga Mohon Das (1982) 34 DLR 177.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Co-sharer by inheritance has the highest priority to claim of pre-emption in any holding.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Rafiqul Alam Vs. Rahimuddin Sarkar (1982) 34 DLR 180.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 96(1)(2)—Sub-sections (1) and (2) explained.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">From a plain reading of sub-section (I) of section 96 of the Act, it appears that it consists of two parts : the first part giving right of pre-emption to one or more co-sharer tenants and the second part giving right of pre-emption to a tenant or tenants holding land contiguous to the land transferred.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Sub-section (2) also consists of two parts. The first part deals with an application for pre-emption by a co-sharer tenant or tenants. The second part deals with an application for pre-emption by a tenant or tenants holding land contiguous to the land transferred. In the former case all other co-sharer tenants of the holding and the transferees are to be impleaded and in the latter case all the co-sharer tenants and all the tenants holding lands contiguous to the land transferred and the transferee to be made parties.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Akhtarun Nessa Vs. Habibullah (1979) 31 DLR (AD) 88.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Pre-emption right accrues on transfer of the land—All the necessary parties to the pre-emption application must be impleaded.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The right of pre-emption as provided under subsection (1) of section 96 is a statutory right. The cause of action for pre-emption of any transfer accrues to the co-sharer tenants and contiguous land owners. The right of the applicant or applicants claiming to be co-sharer tenants or owner of contiguous land, is not absolute but subject to the right of other co-sharers and other holders of land contiguous to the land transferred as the case may be for proper adjudication. To give full effect to the statutory provision, all the necessary parties must be impleaded, because relief cannot be given in the absence of such party.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdus Samad Vs. Md. Sohrab Ali (1981) 33 DLR (AD) 113.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Pre-emption under section 96 relates to raiyati holding.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">As all the co-sharer tenants of the raiyati holding concerned arc required to be impleaded in an application for pre-emption under section 96(I) by a contiguous owner, inference is that the land liable to be pre-empted by the contiguous owner must be the land pertaining to a raiyati holding.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Forman Ali Howladar Vs. Helaluddin Pashari (1968) 20 DLR 1197.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Owner of contiguous land whom to be impleaded—Sub-section (2) has two parts—Co-sharer applying for pre-emption need not implead contiguous land holders as parties, but a contiguous land owner applying for pre-emption must implead other contiguous land holders as well.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Raji Wahab Ali Vs. Kadam Ali (1962) 14 DLR 204.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Necessary parties</strong>—not impleaded. Suit for pre-emption abates, if necessary parties are not substituted.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">After the filing of the application for preemption and lapse of statutory period of limitation to pay for rateable pre-emption the co-sharer tenants and other parties concerned become un-necessary parties and as such Rule cannot be affected for not substituting their heirs.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Binodini Dasi Vs. Mail Lal Sikdar (1969) 21 DLR 262. [Reversed by 28 DLR (AD) 5].</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—One contiguous holder should not necessarily be contiguous holder in respect of all lands transferred—All contiguous holders of land should be impleaded as parties.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Syed Abdul Karim Vs. Harendra Chandra Dhupi (1962) 14 DLR 847.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Parties impleaded after the limitation period—</strong>Application for pre-emption cannot be said to be not maintainable because necessary parties were impleaded by subsequent amendment after the expiry of the period of limitation, when the application for pre-emption itself was made in time.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Nekjan Bibi Vs. Sarojan Bibi (1967) 19 DLR 655.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 96(1)(2)(3)—Limitation of four months in sub-section (1)—Parties subsequently added—Effect.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Limitation of 4 months in sub-section (1) lays down the time within which pre-emption application must be made—Mere addition of parties without claiming any relief against them under sub-section (2) does not attract rule of sub-section (1) but if relief is claimed—question of limitation would be involved.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Nekjan Bibi Vs. Sarojan Bibi (1967) 19 DLR 655.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sec. 96(1) and 3(b)—</strong>Tahurul Karim made an application for pre-emption u/s. 96 on the ground of his holding land contiguous to the land transferred—while this application was pending in court, Abdul Hashim, a co-sharer of the land, filed an independent application u/S. 96(1) within 4 months of the date of transfer. Hashim’s application not covered by s. 96(3)(b).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">“Since Abdul Hashim has an earlier and independent knowledge of the transfer,” he need not apply under sub-section (4); his application u/s. 96(1) competent.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Tahurul Karim Vs. Abdul Hashem (1978) 30 DLR 8.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 96(1)(4)—</strong>Right of pre-emption can be exercised under sub-section (I) as well as under subsection (4) of s. 96 which thus provide a twofold period of limitation.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Section 96(1) provides for a period of limitation of 4 months from the date of service of notice under section 89 or within 4 months from the knowledge of the transfer in respect of a person who claims to be a co-sharer; for a person claiming pre-emption as a tenant holding land contiguous to the land transferred, the period of limitation is 4 months from the date of the knowledge of such transfer.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Tahurul Karim Vs. Abdul Hashem (1978) 30 DLR 8.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Sub-section (4) of section 96 provides that the remaining co-sharers including transferee may join in a pending application.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The two-fold remedy refers to the two different sources of the knowledge of the transfer and the consequently two different periods of limitation, otherwise the expression “whichever is earlier” becomes superfluous.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is, therefore evident that this is an enabling provision and does not operate as a bar to an independent proceeding under section 96(1) of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Tahurul Karim Vs. Abdul Hashem (1978) 30 DLR 8.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—When the original pre-emption application for pre-emption under section 96(1) fails on the ground of limitation the co-applicants’ prayer for pre-emption (according to their share) under section 96(4) though made in time, not sustainable.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The words, “when the application has been made under sub-section (1)” of section 96. If the first application for pre-emption by a co-sharer tenant is made after the expiration of the periods of limitation as stipulated in sub-section (1), it will not be a valid application within the meaning of the opening words of sub-section (4).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Therefore, it necessarily follows that a Co. applicant is entitled to pre-emption according to his share only when the first co—share petitioner has applied within the periods of limitation as prescribed in sub-section (1) of section 96.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Since in the present case the petitioner’s application for pre-emption was filed beyond the period  limitation as prescribed in sub-section (I) of section 96 it was not an application within the meaning of sub-section (4) of section 96; so, although the two co-applicants in the present case applied within the two months of the date of the service of notice of the application, they are not entitled to the benefit of proportionate pre-emption.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Bijan Bala Chowdhury Vs. Maniruddin Biswas (1972) 24 DLR 170.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The expression partial pe-emption is 10 be understood with reference to the definition of ‘holding ‘read with the provisions of section 96 of the Act and not with reference to the number of properties transferred by a particular deed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If a particular holding comprises several plots. for example, belonging to two or more co-sharers, and if one of the co-sharers transfers his share in all the plots of the holding to a stranger-purchaser, the remaining co-sharer or co-sharers in that case, shall have to apply for pre-emption with respect to all the plots; otherwise, it will amount to partial preemption and such partial pre-emption cannot be allowed because a co-sharer cannot be allowed to pick and choose arbitrarily.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Tamizuddin Vs. Guljan Bibi (1974) 26 DLR 95.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Contiguous land owner applied for pre-empting one piece adjacent to it. Three separate plots of land were transferred by a deed of sale. A tenant holding land contiguous to the land transferred applied u/s. 96 for two out of three plots averring that these two plots are contiguous to his land. The court on evidence found that only one plot was contiguous L the applicant’s land and allowed pre-emption of the plot only. The High Court upheld this decision over-ruling the contention that this will lead to partial pre-emption.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sreemati Monkhushi Vs. Abdus Sobhan (1977) 29 DLR 195</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Pre-emption of a part or share of holding when its price is mentioned separately in the kabala— allowable.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Diam Hossain Vs. Haran Das (1961) 13 DLR 283.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 96(1)(5)(b)—</strong>No contiguity with the land transferred, no pre-emptive right—Parties to be impleaded in cases arising out of contiguity.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Akhtarun Nessa Vs. Habibullah (1979) 31 DLR (AD) 90.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—If the land forms a share of a holding the preemptor is required to apply for the share only. Determination of the claim of the pre-emptor in such a case would be only on the basis of the contiguity of land and not on the basis of holding or portion or share thereof. <em>   Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Pre-emption may not be refused on the analogy of non-joinder of all co-sharers in a partition suit<em>. </em><em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Objection as to omission of necessary party if not taken will be treated as being waived by the party. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—‘Contiguous’, means ‘touching’. If the Government is the owner of the contiguous land, contiguity in respect of land touching the Government’s land is broken.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Ahmed Hossain Vs. Basharat Ali (1980) 32 DLR (AD) 55.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2401	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1951 [Section 96(2) - 96(13)]]</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1979) 31 DLR (AD) 88, (1981) 33 DLR (AD) 269, (1981) 33 (AD) 114, (1962) 14 DLR 204, 33 DLR (AD) 270, 33 DLR (AD) 113, (1982) 34 DLR 342, (1962) 14 DLR 847, (1967) 19 DLR 655, (1976) 28 DLR (SC) 6, (1969) 21 DLR 262, (1978) 20 DLR 8, (1962) 14 DLR 204, </p><p><b>Subject:</b>  State Acquisition and Tenancy </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u> </u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1951</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 96(2)—Parties to be impleaded in the application.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">This sub-section in plain language provides that when an application for pre-emption under subsection(I) is made by one or more co-sharer tenants, all other co-sharer tenants of the holding shall be made parties but when the application is filed by a tenant claiming to be the owner of contiguous land to the land transferred, all co-sharer tenants plus all the tenants holding lands contiguous to the land sought to be pre-empted are to be made parties.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Akhtarun Nessa Vs. Habibullah (1979) 31 DLR (AD) 88.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—When lands consisting of several plots are transferred—Right of tenant or tenants holding land contiguous to the hind of particular plot or plots.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If lands consisting of several plots are transferred by a kabala, tenant or tenants holding land contiguous to the land of particular plot or plots are entitled to pre-empt only the land or land to which they have contiguous lands. In such a case the preemptor or pre-emptor are required to implead all the co-sharer tenants’ o1 the holding and all the tenants holding lands contiguous to the land transferred and the transferee.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Pre-emptor having been found to be a tenant holding land contiguous to only two plots out of three plots transferred, was entitled to pre-emptor only the land to which he holds land contiguous thereto.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Akhtarun Nessa Vs. Habibullah (1979) 31 DLR (AD) 88.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The matter of impleading of parties in a partition suit is governed by Order I, rule 10 C P Coue while that of impleading of parties in a pre-emption case under SAT Act is governed by section 96(2) of this Act.—When impleading of parties in a preemption proceeding not necessary.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Abdul Jalil Vs. Durjan Ali (1981) 33 DLR (AD) 269.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A co-sharer in the holding cannot be allowed to purchase the entire land without impleading the other co-sharers and thereby depriving them from getting their share.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdus Samad Vs. Sohrab Ali (1981) 33 (AD) 114.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Presence of all the persons mentioned in subsection (2) is a matter of absolute necessity. Their presence is necessary, so that the Court can adjudicate the claim of pre-emption more effectively and completely.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdus Samad Vs. Sohrab Ali (1981) 33 (AD) 114.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Sub-section (2) has two parts,-Co-sharer applying for pre-emption need not implead contiguous land-holders as parties, but a contiguous land owner applying for pre-emption must implead other contiguous land holders as well.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Haji Wahab Ali Vs. Kadam Ali (1962) 14 DLR 204.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The distinctive features of Motilals case, 28 DLR (1976) Page 5, vis-à-vis the instant case has been pointed out in para 12.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The observation of the High Court Division relying on Motilal’s case shows that it was for the pre-emptee to lead evidence to the effect that the left- out co-sharers still got interest in the land sought to be pre-empted.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The facts of the instant case are not attracted by the decision in Motilal’s case; on the contrary, these facts are attracted by the decision in the case of Abdus Samad Vs. Sohrab Au (1981) 33 DLR (AD) 113 in which it has been held that non-joinder of parties who got right of pre-emption is fatal to the proceeding.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Abdul Jalil Vs. Durjan Ali (1981) 33 DLR (AD) 270.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Regarding non-joinder of necessary parties in the pre-emption application, the provision of Or. I, r, 9 will be applicable as is contemplated in s. 141. CP Code.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdus Samad Vs. Md. Sohrab Ali (1981) 33 DLR (AD) 113.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Impleading of persons who are necessary parties to a pre-emption application is mandatory under sub-section (2) of s. 96, which is not controlled by Or. I, r. 9., CPC.<em> Ibid</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Plea of non-joining of necessary parties should be taken before the trial. If the party selecting pre-emption fails to implead such a party whose existence is disclosed, right of pre-emption is lost. Plea of non-joinder of necessary parties can even be taken in appellate stage. <em> Ibid</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—In a pre-emption application who are to be impleaded as parties.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The different provisions of section 96 clearly point out that a duty has been cast on the preemptor, if he is a co-sharer tenant, to make all the remaining co-sharers tenants; and if he is a tenant holding land contiguous to the land transferred, all the remaining tenants holding lands contiguous to the land transferred and the transferee, arc parties to the application. Object of sub-section (2) is to have all the co-sharer tenants or all the tenants holding lands contiguous to the land transferred, before the Court for proper and complete adjudication in accordance with law.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdus Samad Vs. Md. Sohrab Ali (1981) 33 DLR (AD) 113.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—From judgment of the Munsif, in a pre-emption case, appeal will lie to the District Judge.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mohammad Eshaque Vs. Ruhul Arnin (1982) 34 DLR 342.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—One contiguous holder should not necessarily be contiguous holder in respect of all lands transferred—All contiguous holders of land should be impleaded as parties.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Syed Abdul Karim .Vs. Harendra Chandra Dhupi (1962) 14 DLR 847.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Parties impleaded after the limitation period. </strong>Application for pre-emption cannot be said to be not maintainable because necessary parties were inpleaded by subsequent amendment after the expiry of the period of limitation, when the application for pre-emption itself was made in time.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Nekjan Bibi Vs. Sarojan Bibi (1967) 19 DLR 655.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—As regard impleading of parties in a suit for partition as well as in an application for pre-emption u/s. 96 both are not governed by the same principles of law—In partition Suit all co-sharers are necessary parties, failure to implead any one of such co-sharers will render the suit in fructuous and apart from the question of leaving out a necessary party a court will not pass a decree in a suit (as in a partition suit) which will be rendered infructuous—General principle that objection as to impleading of parties at the proper time is also applicable in partition Suit.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Matilal Sikdar Vs. Benodini (1976) 28 DLR (SC) 6.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Provision regarding making the co-sharers or the contiguous owners of the land parties in a proceeding u/s. 96 has been made to avoid multiplicity of proceedings and a bar has been placed regarding time within which such co-sharers or contiguous owners must join seeking pre-emption, failing which that right lapses. <em> Ibid</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Right conferred upon co-sharer tenants or the owners of the contiguous lands offering them an opportunity as available thereby under S. 96 and as such they can very well waive such right. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Only those of the co-sharer tenants and the holders of contiguous lands, whose right of preemption has not been barred under sub-section (I) of section 96 were necessary parties within the meaning of sub-section (2) of the said section. <em>   Ibid</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—If a party does not apply for pre-emption within the prescribed period of time he loses his right to pre-emption under the section. A case of pre-emption does not abate if such a person is not impleaded.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Benodini Dasi Vs. Matilal Sikdar (1969) 21 DLR 262. [Reversed by 28 DLR (AD) 5]</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Impleading of all the co-sharer tenants and tenants holding land contiguous to the land transferred in the pre-emption case mandatory. </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Under the law of pre-emption a person is allowed to take away the properties of another person although the latter acquired the said properties under a valid and legal transaction, all the provisions of the said law would be construed very strictly. On a proper and careful analysis it is clear that the provisions as laid down in sub-section (2) of section 96 that all the co-sharer tenants of the holding and all the tenants holding land contiguous to the land transferred shall be made parties are mandatory and not directory irrespective of the provision made in proviso to sub-section (I) of section 96. If we read this provision of sub-section (2) together with that made in sub-sections (4),(5)(b), (6)(b) and (7) of section 96 it appears that the intention of the Legislature to make it mandatory in this regard is very clear.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Suit for pre-emption not abates if unnecessary parties are not substituted.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">After the filing of the application for preemption and lapse of statutory period of limitation to pray for rateable pre-emption the co-sharer tenants and other parties concerned become unnecessary parties and as such rule cannot be affected for not substituting the heirs<em>. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Binodini Dasi Vs. Matilal Sikdar (1969) 21 DLR 262. [Reversed by 28 DLR (AD) 5]</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 96(3)—</strong>Made an application for preemption u/s 96 on the ground of his holding land contiguous to the land transferred. While this application was pending in court A, a co-sharer of the land, filed an independent application u/s 96(1) within 4 months of the date of transfer. A’s application not covered by s. 96(3) (b).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Tahurul Karim Vs. Abdul Hashim (1978) 20 DLR 8.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 96(3)(b)—</strong>Co-sharer becomes party to a pre-emption proceeding from the date of notice on him. Notice on him to represent minors will not in law make him a party as a co-sharer.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Haji Wahab Ali Vs. Kadam Ali (1962) 14 DLR 204.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 96(3)—</strong>Pre-emptor failing to deposit the money in due time does so at his risk, if the appellate Court does not grant extension.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The pre-emptor takes the risk of getting his Suit dismissed for failure to make the deposit, within the time fixed by the trial Court, if the appellate Court, on an appeal from the decree, does not extend the time for payment.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In the present case for the pre-emptor’s default in making payment of the correct amount within the time fixed by the appellate decree, his suit stood dismissed and there was no question of extension of time involved, either by the original Court or by the appellate Court thereafter, the appeal or revision for the appellate decree having already been dismissed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Shah Wali Vs. Ghulam (1967) 19 DLR (SC) 143.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Entire consideration money together with the required compensation must be in deposit when preemption application is filed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Akhtarun Nessa Vs. Habibullah (1979) 31 DLR (AD) 88.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 96(4)—</strong>Right of the remaining co-sharer tenants to join within prescribed time—Application for rateable pre-emption u/s 96(4) not possible unless application under section 96(I) was first made.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Haji Wahab Ali Vs. Kadam Ali (1962) 14 DLR 204.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Right of pre-emption can be exercised under sub-section (I) as well as under sub-section (4) of s.96 which thus provide a two-fold period of limitation.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Sub-section (4) of s.96 provides that the remaining co-sharer including transferee may join in a pending application.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Tahurul Karim Vs. Abdul  Hashim (1978) 30 DLR 75.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Since A has an earlier and independent knowledge of the transfer, he need not apply under subsection(4); his application u/s. 96(1) competent. <em> Ibid</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Application for rateable pre-emption u/s 96(4) not possible unless application u/s 96(1) was first made<em>. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Haji Wahab Ali Vs. Kadam Ali (1962) 14 DLR 204.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Expiry of the time limit dates from the Lime of knowledge of the transfer—impleading one as a party when time is expired does not extend the time- limit.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Syed Abdul Karim Vs. Harendra Ch. Dhupi. (1962) 14 DLR 847</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Co-sharer after service of notice on him may either join in the original case for pre-emption or may bring a separate independent case within time limit—Objection as to non-joinder or mis-joinder of parties must be taken at the earliest opportunity, failing which the objection will not be entertained.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Jamiyat Ali Vs. Mrs. Chemon Ara Begum (1968) 20 DLR 480.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Objection as to non-impleading a party in a proceeding u/s. 96 for the first time in the High Court cannot be entertained as question of facts has to be investigated if such objection is to be given effect to.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">From sub-section (4) of section 96, it is clear that the said provision was obviously made for the purpose of providing the facility of pre-emption to the persons interested, who have not lost their right of pre-emption under sub-section (I) of the said section.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Motilal Sikdar Vs. Benodini (1976) 28 DLR (SC) 6.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Transferee contiguous-landholder is included in the category of tenants holding land contiguous to the land transferred and he can maintain an application under section 96(4) of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Taferuddin Pramanik Vs. Tahmina Khatun (1978) 30 DLR 417.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—If the application u/s. 96(1) is dismissed as non-maintainable, it does not follow that preemption claim of others who joined after being served with notice under section 96(I)(b) should fall through.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Santibala Suiradhar Vs. Upendra Mohan (1977) 29 DLR 183.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Claim for rateable pre-emption by the transferee can be made even in his written statement which he files in traversing pre-emption application u/s. 96 S.A.&amp; T Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Reazul Karim Vs. Mst. Shirin Begum (1984) 36 DLR 250.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 96(4)—2nd Part.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">parties entitled to re-empts the land sold if fail to excise their right to pre-empt the land within the vcn time the right of pre-emption is lost.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdus Samad Vs. Md. Sohrab Ali (1981)33 DLR (AD) 113.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 96(5)(a)—</strong>Clause (a) of sub-section (5) shows that law recognizes 3 classes of pre-emptor:</p><p style="margin-top: 0in; margin-right: 0in; margin-left: 1.0in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">(i) a co-sharer tenant whose interest has accrued by inheritance;</p><p style="margin-top: 0in; margin-right: 0in; margin-left: 1.0in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">(ii)   a co-sharer tenant whose interest has accrued by purchases; and</p><p style="margin-top: 0in; margin-right: 0in; margin-left: 1.0in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">(iii) a tenant or tenants holding land contiguous to the land transferred.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The statute gives priority to the co-sharer tenant whose interest has accrued by inheritance. The first class excludes both second and third class, and the second class, excluding the third. Clause (a) provides necessary guidance for determining order of priority among the tenants claiming pre-emption on the ground of having lands transferred.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Akhtarun Nessa Vs. Habibullah (1979) 31 DLR (AD) 88.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 96(5)(b)—</strong>Pre-emption under 2nd part of s. 96(I)—Contiguity of land—According to subsection (5)(b) in an application for pre-emption only those tenants holding lands contiguous to the land sought to be pre-empted are to be impleaded; and tenants holding lands contiguous to other lands transferred under the kabala but not subject of preemption arc not required to be empleaded. Subsection (5)(b) removes any doubt that there might be<em>.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Akhtarun Nessa Vs. Habibullah (1979) 31 DLR (AD) 88.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Extent of contiguity of land—Test for determining order of priority—Right regarding contiguous plots u/s 96(5)(b).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">“Extent of contiguity of land” is the only test for determining the order of priority as amongst tenants claiming pre-emption on the ground of holding land, contiguous to the land transferred. If land transferred consists of one plot, all the tenants having land contiguous to the land under pre-emption are to be impleaded. Their right is to be determined in the manner as provided in sub-section (5)(b). In a case where land transferred consists of more than one plot, a tenant or tenants having land contiguous to the plot or plots may apply for pre-emption but in such a case, a tenant having land contiguous only to one of the plots, cannot claim pre-emption of other lands. <em> Ibid</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 96(5)—</strong>Pre-emption not to be refused for non-joinder of  co-sharers.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A case of pre-emption under section 96 may not be defeated on the analogy of non-joinder of all co sharers in a suit for partition. This right of preemption is not absolute but subject to the right of other co-sharers and holders of land contiguous to the land transferred, as the case may be. Requirement of the statute of impleading those in whose favour right of pre-emption accrued, is for the sole purpose of enabling the Court to adjudicate the claim of all the parties as provided under sub-section (5) of section 96 in one proceeding and avoiding multiplicity of proceedings. So, for the sake of full and complete adjudication of the rights and granting relief, there should not be absence of any necessary party.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Objection as to omission of a necessary party, if not taken at the earlier opportunity, will be treated as waived. <em> Ibid</em><strong>.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 96(5), Clause(a)—</strong>Co-sharer by inheritance shall have the highest priority followed by a co-sharer by purchase and thereafter a contiguous owner.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Co-sharer comes first in priority over a contiguous owner.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Dhirendra Narayan Das Vs. Gouranga Mohon Das (1982) 34 DLR 177.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Co-sharer by inheritance has the highest priority to claim pre-emption in any holding.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Rafiqul Alam Vs. Rahimuddin Sarkar. (1982) 34 DLR 180.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 96(5)(b)—</strong>The words ‘contiguous’ and ‘contiguity in clause (b) of sub-s. (5) to he interpreted to mean touching or adjacent and not meaning neighboring.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Ahmed Hossain Vs. Basharat Ali (1980) 32 DLR (AD) 54.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Clause (b) provides guidance regarding order of priority when more than one tenant holding contiguous land applies for pre-emption. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Priority of the applicants is to be determined having regard to (1) the total quantity of land in possession of each of the tenants; (ii) whether the contiguous laid of the tenant is homestead land or any other class of land; (iii) extent of contiguity; (iv) to what extent k is necessary for the applicant to have possession of the contiguous land; and (v) the right of easement, if any, of the applicants<em>. Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Clause (b) of sub-section (5) sufficiently indicates that pre-emptor must show that his land is contiguous to the land transferred, that is to say, it is touching with the land transferred. Only then he can maintain his claim, In the case of more than one tenant fulfilling the requirements to claim preernption, in determining the order of inter se priority one of the critena for consideration is “extent of contiguity.” <em>  Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—When in between the land transferred and the piece of land whose owner seeks preemption on the ground of contiguity, a public pathway intervenes, the contiguity is broken and pre-emption can not be allowed. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Pre-emption case be allowed only with respect to that piece of land which is just contiguous to a transferred piece.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is very often noticed that pre-emption under section 96 is allowed to a tenant having land contiguous to one of several plots transferred, and preemption is allowed even in cases where the lands are not in a compact block, which is contrary to the provision of law itself.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If more than one plot of lands are transferred by a sale deed, a tenant having land contiguous to one of the plots, cannot lay his claim of pre-emption beyond that plot, because, the contiguity cannot be stretched to other plot. <em>   Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 96(7)—</strong>One of the several co-sharers is entitled to pre-emptor to the extent of his own share in a pre-emption case.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Eleven co-sharers claimed pre-emption in respect of the land transferred. The trial Court granted the prayer for pre-emption but the lower appellate Court dismissed the whole pre-emption case. As against this order of dismissal one out of eleven co sharers moved the High Court in revision. High Court upheld the order of the Munsif but held that the petitioner before the High Court is entitled to pre-empt only to the extent of his own share and nothing more.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Ruhul Amin Mestory Vs. Fazar Banu, (1969) 21 DLR 647.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Nadabipatra not a deed of transfer—No preemption.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A nadabipatra being merely a deed of disclaimer disclaiming any interest in the properties transferred by an earlier sale deed is not itself a deed of transfer and, therefore, no right of pre-emption can be claimed upon the registration of such a deed of nadabipatra.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Arabullah Vs. Durgaprasad Tribedi (1959) 11 DLR 539.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 96(9)(c)—</strong>Order of pre-emption made by Court is executable for putting pre-emptor in possession of the property.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Order of pre-emption has been made under section 96(7) of the East Bengal State Acquisition and Tenancy Act. Section 96(c) of the Act provides that an order of pre-emption is executable for the purpose of placing the pre-emptor in possession of the preempted land.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Shariatullah Vs. Ashrafun Nessa (1976) 28 DLR (SC) 92.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—In a pre-emption case, delivery of possession would be affected against the purchaser alone and not against the other co-sharers of the holding who were mere parties only to afford them an opportunity for applying for joint or proportionate pre-emption. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Court may place the pre-emptor in possession of the property which vests in him following the order of pre-emption in his favour free from any encumbrances. <em>   Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Pre-emptor steps into the shoes of the pre-emptee transferee and the order of pre-emption can only be executed against such transferee or his successor-in-interest alone and not against anybody. A stranger can be evicted from the pre-empted land only under Or. 2, rules 97 &amp; 98 when it is shown he is just set up by the pre-emptee judgment-debtor. <em>  Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 96(10), cl. (c)—Transfer in favour of sister’s son.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Transfer in favour of sister’s son, he being a relation by consanguinity within three degrees of the donor, cannot be pre-empted.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sale Mohd. Vs. Mosammat Ayesha Khatoon (1968) 20 DLR 376.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 96(10)—</strong>Heba-BiI-Ewaz in consideration of prayer-mat—Prayer mat is not a pecuniary consideration—Transfer not pre-emptible.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Syed Ali Gazi Vs. Akhej Sarder (1968) 20 DLR 433.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.96(10)(a)—</strong>A co-sharer by gift is a co sharer whose interest has accrued ‘otherwise than by purchase’ and when such a co-sharer makes a subsequent purchase in respect of a portion of the same holding he is protected from pre-emption under section 26F(1)(a) of the BT Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held:</strong> A distinction has been made under the provisions of section 26F of the Bengal Tenancy Act between a co-sharer by purchase and co-sharer whose existing interest has accrued otherwise than by purchase. In the latter category falls a co-sharer whose existing interest has accrued by gift. In view of the clear provision of sub-section (I) (a) of section 26F of the Bengal Tenancy Act, the petitioner is not entitled to get any relief because the opposite parties are co-sharers in the tenancy whose existing interest has accrued otherwise than by purchase, i.e., by gift in the instant case.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mansuruddin Vs. Yeakub Ali (1969) 21 DLR 565.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.96(10)(c).—</strong>Love and affection combined with payment of money—Deed interpreted as hiba-bil-ewaz—Pre-emption cannot be claimed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Kanchan Molla Vs. Renu Mia (1960) 12 DLR 479.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Transfer by hiba-bil-ewaz—Price stated in the document not exclusive.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Where a transfer is effected by “hiba-bil-ewaz,” in spite of the value put in the transfer-deed by the transferor of the “hiba-bil-ewaz” and that for the purpose of registration of the deed, the transferee when faced with a pre-emption application by a co-sharer of the holding is not estopped from proving that the price of the land transferred is higher than what has been stated by the transferor of the deed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Azizul Bari Vs. Md. Ismail (1967) 19 DLR 184.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A Nadabi patra, not a transfer. <em>Md. Arabulla Vs. Durga Prasad Tnibedi (1959) 11 DLR 539.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 96(10)(a)—</strong>Father go he land (subject matter of pre-emption) from one ‘C the original owners by purchase—Sons by devolution get the same on father’s death—Sons are co-sharers with the original owners by inheritance.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdul Haque Mia and another Vs. Abdul Rashid &amp; another (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 54.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 96(12)—</strong>Jurisdiction of Court—Subsection (12) of section 96 is referable to territorial jurisdiction of Court for trial of an action for preemption.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abul Hossain Howladar Vs. Pulin Behani Sikdar (1970) 22 DLR 535.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 96(12) read with Civil Procedure Code (V of 1908) Or. 9, r. 13</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">No appeal lies under the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act against an order dismissing an application under Order 9, rule 13 CPC for restoring a proceeding under section 96 of the said Act decreed ex parte.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Haji Karimdad Vs. Insaf Meah &amp; Ors. (1981) 33 DLR 455.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 96(12)—</strong>High Court entitled, on going through the record of the case, to come to a finding that the petitioner is a bonafide cultivator. <em>Chandu Mia Mestory Vs. AKM Wajih Ullah (1981) 33 DLR 134.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 96(13)—</strong>Appeal lies to the ordinary Civil Appellate Court from any order of a Court passed in a pre-emption case under this section—Order passed not disposing of an application for prc-cmption on merits is also an order for the purpose.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abul Hossain Howladar Vs. Pulin Behari Sikdar (1970) 22 DLR 535.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—If the registration of the sale deed takes place when a revision arising out of the pre-emption case was pending in the High Court Division the application should not be rejected even though on the date when it was filed in the original Court the application was premature since during the pendency of the case before the High Court Division document was duly registered.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Jatindra Chandra Urang Vs. Md. Shamsuddin (1982) 34</em><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> <em>DLR 264.</em></span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A Hindu widow having only a life interest has inalienable right to pre-emptor any land to which she is a co-sharer—Reversioner’s right will not be affected as after widow’s death the land shall revert to him.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Tofazzal Hossain Vs. Md. Yunus Ali Biswas (1982) 34 DLR 402.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Deposit of consideration money if does not accompany the application for pre-emption but made later on if the deposit is within 4 months from the date of the registration of the deed or 4 months from the knowledge of transfer, is a sufficient complaisance with law and is a valid deposit under law.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Mafizuddin Sardar Vs. Md. Abdul Jabbar Akhand. (1982) 34 DLR 272.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—An order referred to in S. 96(13) which is made appealable does not fall within the definition of “decree”.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Under section 96(13) of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act an appeal lies from any order under that section and as such in terms of the definition of decree, it shall not include an order under that section. Furthermore, an order under section 96 of the Act, although adjudicates a matter finally does not come within the meaning of ‘decree” as the definition of “order” makes it abundantly clear that a decision of the civil court, does not become a “decree” unless it falls within the definition of “decree”.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>A Jafar Vs. A Hamid (1977) 29 DLR 306.</em><span id="pastemarkerend"></span></p></div></div>
2402	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1951 [Section 97 - 151]</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1981) 33 DLR 412, (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 338, (1981) 33 DLR 412, (1981)33 DLR (AD) 309, (1981) 33 DLR 318, (1981) 33 DLR (AD) 323, (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 338, (1984) 36 DLR 193, (1966) 18 DLR. 293, (1980) 32 DLR 130, (1984) 36 DLR (AD) 79, (1979)31 DLR 421, (19</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  State Acquisition and Tenancy </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u> </u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1951</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Secs. 116 and 117—</strong> For amalgamation and consolidation of a holding steps may be taken on the application by co-sharer tenants or the RO may do so on his own initiative—But in case of subdivision of a joint tenancy it can only be done on application made by co-sharer tenants.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Khairullah Bhuiyan. Vs. Amena Khatun &amp; ors. (1981) 33 DLR 412. </em>(Reversed by decision in 35 DLR (AD) 338).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Words “separation” and “amalgamation” bear specific meaning and their implication explained.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Khairullah Bhuiyan Vs. Haji Nurul Alam Chowdhury (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 338.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 116 and 117 (1)(a)(c)—</strong> Several plots (numbering 5) which were recorded in 4 khatians were amalgamated and consolidated in one khatian-This being a case u/s. I 17(1)(a) and not of sub-division of a joint tenancy as dealt with in section 1 17(1)(c)— Payment of rent at the old rate can not set at naught the amalgamation and consolidation—Civil court can not ignore that order to give effect to a collateral purpose.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Khairullah Bhuiyan Vs. Haji Nurul Alam Chowdhury (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 338.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Section 116 read with section 117(1)(a) of the Stale Acquisition and Tenancy Act provides that amalgamation and consolidation can be taken by the Revenue-Officer, either on his own motion or on an application made to him. Section 1 17(I)(c) contains the provision for sub-division of a joint tenancy for distribution of rent thereof.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">High Court Division was in error in its view that it is a case of sub-division of a joint tenancy as prescribed u/s. 1 17(I)(a) for which an application was required to be filed and in the absence of such an application the Revenue Officer had no authority on his own motion to sub-divide the joint tenancy.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Khairullah Bhuiyan Vs. Haji Nurul Alam Chowdhury. (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 338. </em>(This decision reverses 33 DLR 412).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 117</strong>—In case of amalgamation, consolidation and sub-division of a tenancy Prior notice must be served on the parties concerned.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Khairullah Bhuiyan Vs. Amena Khatun (1981) 33 DLR 412.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Order (effecting a sub-division of a holding) validly made by a competent authority and has been given effect to and further there has been no appeal against the order made u/s. 117—the order remains a validly legal order and a court of appeal while dealing with a matter u/s. 96 for pre-emption cannot ignore the order.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md.. Jabed Ali Vs. Rakhal Chandra Mondal (1981)33</em> <em>DLR (AD) 309.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Sub-division of a holding effected after giving reasonable notice to the parties concerned to appear and be heard is complete. No pre-emption can be claimed after sub-division u/s. 117.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Rais Ali Vs. Imam Hossain &amp; ors. (1981) 33 DLR 318.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—In a mutation case for split up of a Jama notice of the mutation case not having been served on the co-sharers and mutation been effected behind their back; in law that is not valid splitting up of the Jaina and as such the co-sharers have not lost their right of pre-emption under sec. 24 of Act XXIII of 1949.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Abdur Rouf &amp; ors. Vs. Ahmuda Khalutz &amp; ors. (1981) 33 DLR (AD) 323.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 117(I)(c)—”</strong>Sub-division” of a joint tenancy can only be effected on the application of co sharers and by the RO on his own motion—Notice on other co-sharers compulsory.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Khairulla Bhuiyan Vs. Nurul Alam (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 338.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Co-sharers amicably splitting up their jama for facilitating payment of land revenue—A conclusion can be arrived at that the co—sharers have effected an amicable partition---In which case provision of s. 96 of SAT Act can not be invoked.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Haladhar Dutta Vs. Abdul Rob Chowdhury (1984) 36 DLR 193.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—“Separation” means sub-division.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The term ‘separation’ is not a legal term like “amalgamation” or “sub-division”; it is not used in section 116 or 117, but nevertheless it denotes, in general sense, separation of share from a joint- tenancy and falls under, and is governed by clause (c) of section 117.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Khairullah</em> <em>Bhuiyan Vs. Haji Nurul Alam Chowdhury (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 338.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—With the separation from a joint holding other co-sharers cease to be Co-sharers.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Effect of separation of a share from the joint holding falls upon all co-sharers who, after separation, cease to be co-sharers of the original holding. A co-sharer after getting his share separated may get his portion constituted into a new tenancy or he may tag this share with his other land, if any, and if he does so, his case may be referred to as a case of separation and amalgamation for the sake of convenience, though the two terms are quite different. His former co-sharers are not interested in such amalgamation.<em>  Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—For separation of a joint tenancy mandatory provisions as required under clause (c) of s. 117 (1) must be complied with—undivided share of a joint tenancy can not be amalgamated with another independent holding without first having it ‘separated’ under clause (c) of s. 117(I). <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—When a joint tenancy is split up by a RO, thereby taking away the right of the co-sharer to exercise his right of pre-emption—a court of law is fully competent in a pre-emption proceeding to see whether the splitting up order was made according to law as required by s. 117(I)(c). <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 117(a)(b)(c)—</strong>Provisions made for amalgamation, consolidation or sub-division of holding—Amalgamation or consolidation by revenue officer on his only motion or on application—Subdivision can be effected only on application by co sharer tenants.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Haladhar Dutta Vs. Abdul Rob Chowhdury (1984) 36 DLR 193.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 117(3)—</strong>Sub-division may be demarcated and shown on the cadastral survey map. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 141—</strong>Right to apply for setting aside a sale under section 174 (3) Bengal Tenancy Act not affected after the introduction of Chapter V of the Acquisition Act which contains section 141.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The contention raised was that application under section 174(3) of the Bengal Tenancy Act for setting aside sale filed after the introduction of the Chapter V of the East Bengal Slate Acquisition and Tenancy Act is not maintainable and that an application for setting aside a sale after the introduction of Chapter V of the East Bengal State Acquisition and Tenancy Act can only be filed under the Public Demands Recovery Act as contemplated by section 141 of the Acquisition Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held</strong>: The right of action given to a judgment- debtor to invoke the aid of section 174(3) has not been expressly repealed and cannot be also said to be repealed by necessary implication.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sarat Chandra Somaddar Vs. Sumati Bala Haldar (1966) 18 DLR. 293.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Section 141 has no application when the sale had taken place before the introduction of Chapter V of the Acquisition Act and when the demand for which the sale had taken place was not a public demand. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Notice—Proceedings introducing Chapter V of the East Bengal State Acquisition Act is no notice to the Judgment-debtor whose land has been sold.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Proceedings taken as preliminary to the intro- due section of Chapter V of the Acquisition Act cannot be construed as notice to a Judgment-debtor in respect of a sale of a holding held for arrears of rent unless it is shown that the judgment-debtor was, as a matter of fact, aware of the proceedings. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 142 read with section 3(4a) — </strong>Period of limitation for recovery of arrear rents is 5 years in Sylhet district.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Chandpur Tea Co. Ltd. Vs. Joint Secretary (1980) 32 DLR 130.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 143A—Scope of section 143A.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">An application under section 143A of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act is not a Suit for declaration of title but is a proceeding for rectification of mistakes in the record-of-right prepared on the basis of possession in the land in question. The scheme of the section shows the possession is the material question. This was a special provision and this section was inserted after section 143 by EP Ordinance VIII of 1965. It was, however, omitted after a few years by Ordinance No. LXIV of 1975.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Within the scope of section 143A, there is hardly any ground for the Custodian of the Enemy Property appellant to challenge the title of the plaintiff. The learned Judge found that the Custodian of Enemy Property had no document in his possession to claim the property as enemy property. Before the High Court Division no one appeared on behalf of the present Custodian. The learned Judge of the High Court Division having found the plaintiffs prima-facie title and clear possession of the case land, rightly reversed the decision of the lower appellate Court and restored that of the trial Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Assistant Custodian Vs. Bholanath Guha (1984) 36 DLR (AD) 79.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">— The section confers a summary power on the Civil Court for the purpose of correcting mistakes.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Section 143A contemplates a summary power to be exercised by the Civil Court within the prescribed limits. The purpose of introducing this special provision is correcting mistakes.” The special provisions made in section 143A arc intended for a definite and limited purpose.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abu Daud Vs. Ruhul Amin Sardar (1979)31 DLR 421.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Addition of parties in a proceeding u/s. 143A as envisaged in Or. 1 r. 10(a), CP Code not allowable. <em>Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 143A</strong>—A right of easement sought to be confirmed in a proceeding under section 143A is absolutely beyond the scope of investigation under this section.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Prayer in the form of declaratory relief not contemplated in a proceeding u/s. 143A.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Certain prayers have been made in declaratory form with regard to title of the petitioner. Section 143A does not contemplate such relief.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abu Daud Vs. Ruhul Amin (1979) 31 DLR 421.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Section 143(a)—</strong>has authorized a person aggrieved by an order or omission of entry in the record-of-rights finally published under Chapter IV of the Act to file a suit for correction of such record- of-rights in the Civil Court. It is obvious, therefore, that an alternative right has now been provided for a detailed probe into the matter and for rectifying an erroneous entry in a record-of-rights.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Pijush Kanti Chowdhury Vs. Abdar Rashid (1971) 23 DLR 60.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Secs. 144 and 144A—Presumption u/s. 144A—When not possible</strong>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">No record-of-right which was finally published under sub-section (7) of section 144 of the EB State Acquisition and Tenancy Act having been adduced in evidence the question of presumption under section 144A of The East Bengal State Acquisition and Tenancy Act does not arise.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Akrab Ali Vs. Zahiruddin Kari (1978)30 DLR (SC) 81.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 149(4)—</strong>Cultivated or cultivable land which was previously Jalkar (or a part of it) but was not so when the whole-sale State Acquisition was introduced could not be treated as non-retainable khas land—Such raised land continues to form part of the old tenancy and should have been recorded in the name of the person with title and possession thereto.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Ijjat Ali Vs. Golapjan Khatun (1969) 21 DLR (Board of Revenue) 25.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 151(1)(2)—</strong>To a proceeding u/s. 96(T) pro- visions of section 14 of the Limitation Act are attracted in view of section 151 (1)(2) of the SAT Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Sub-s. (1) of s. 151, State Acquisition and Tenancy Act provides that the provisions of section 14 of the Limitation Act shall be applicable to all suits and applications referred to in Part V of the State Acquisition &amp; Tenancy Act. In other words, as stated in sub-section (2) of section 151, subject to the provisions of the Limitation Act which are specifically made applicable by sub-s. (1) to all suits and applications dealt with in Part V of the Act all such suits and applications not instituted within time proscribed thereof in this part “shall be dismissed.”</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Abdul Majid Vs. Sarina Begum (1982)34 DLR 150.</span></em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2403	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">State Acquisition and Tenancy (Amendment) Ordinance, 1956</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1956) 8 DLR 457(461), (1971) 23 DLR 203</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  State Acquisition and Tenancy (Amendment) </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>State Acquisition and Tenancy (Amendment) Ordinance, 1956</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Ordinance III of 1956—</span></strong>validity of, cannot be attacked unless specific case of injury is made out.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Jibendra K Acharya Chowdhury Vs. Prov. of East Pak. (1956) 8 DLR 457(461).</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">R. 218—</span></strong>Settlement of khas land—Settlement made to different persons with regard to different parcels of land are separate settlements—Fact that the Revenue Officer, for the convenience of getting permission, made one reference (of all the settlements) to the Collector will not make them one settlement.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Abdul Majid Vs. Province of East Pakistan (1971) 23 DLR 203.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Under the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act the Commissioner has no general appellate or general supervisory power regarding settlement of khas lands made by the Collector—Therefore order of cancellation of settlement by the Commissioner is without jurisdiction. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2404	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Stay Order</h2>
