<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1955) 7 DLR 473 (475 rg.h.col), (1956) 8 DLR 82</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Stay Order</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Stay Order</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If any step is taken by any subordinate Court having ordinary normal jurisdiction in ignorance of any order of a superior Court, the subsequent orders passed by the subordinate Court are not ipso facto null and void. They will stand unless they are either recalled or are set aside.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Rani Harsamukhi Sinha Vs. Maharaja Sashi Kanta (1955) 7 DLR 473 (475 rg.h.col).</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Although an ex parte order of stay is a valid order it does not ipso facto, nullify all the proceedings of the court of the first instance passed subsequently. If the Court comes to know of the order of the superior court, it should always act on the orders of the superior Court and the question is not a communication only, but is one of knowledge of the Court with this knowledge  be direct or redirect As soon as a subordinate Court is satisfied of the existence of such an order of a superior Court, it must act on it.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Rani Harsamukhi Sinha Vs. Maharaja Sashi Kanta (1955) 7 DLR 473 (475 ri.h.col).</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—It cannot be said that the moment an order for stay of proceedings is pronounced, that operates as staying the hands of the trial Court. The effect of the order for stay passed by the superior Court upon an order of trial Court in contravention of the order for stay is irregular and not a nullity.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Rani Harsamukhi Sinha Vs. Maharaja Sashi Kanta (1955) 7 DLR 473 (475 rt.h.col).</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Where an order, either of stay or of injunction which stands almost on the same footing, has been made by a superior Court, it does not render void all orders made .or acts done by the subordinate Court subsequent to such an order but before it is actually communicated they merely render such subsequent orders or acts voidable.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Almas Khatun Vs. Ezhar Mia. (1956) 8 DLR 82.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2405	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Succession Act, 1925</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1959)11 DLR 40, (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 102 (103),  (1980) 32 DLR 11, (1984)36 DLR (AD) 156, (1983)35 DLR (AD) 102, (1950) 2 DLR 265, (1970) 22 DLR 529,  (1950) 2 DLR 67, (1952) 4 DLR 293, (1961) 21 PLD (Karachi) 141, (1960) 12 DLR 232, (1955) 7 DLR (FC) 156</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Succession</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Succession Act (XXXIX of 1925)</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Void will</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Will—Probate court has the right to go into question of the validity of a will when a bequest made by the will is void.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Braja Bala Saha Vs. Tarapada Saha (1959)11 DLR 40.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Where a bequest provided by a will is a void one by reason of its being contrary to law or morality or opposed to public policy, the probate court can pronounce such a bequest void or otherwise in accordance with the provisions of the Succession Act. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 2—’Probate’—Its meaning.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In substance probate means copy of the will certified under the seal of a Court of competent jurisdiction that a grant of administration to the estate of the Testator (vidc the dcfmition of probate in section 2 of the Succession Act). In the absence of an executor an universal or residuary legatee can apply for letter of administration.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Khitindra Chandra Bhattacharya Vs. Jalada Devi (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 102 (103).</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 29(2)—Garo Customary Law— Succession amongst Garos—Customary Law of Garos, ii can be held to fall within the expression used in sub sec.(2) of sec 29 of Indian Succession Act.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Under the Garo Customary Law, the plaintiffs were not entitled to succeed. The marriage of the sister to the woman’s husband may take place after and not only during his marriage with the first sister.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">When the second sister is married even after an interval from the death of the first wife there would be under the Garo Customary Law a vesting of the whole property in the new heiress.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Customary Law of the Garos would fall within the expression used in sub-section (2) of section 29 of the Indian Succession Act, viz., “any other law for the time being in force.” Consequently, if the requisites were established which were essential for proof of valid custom having the force of law, then a case of succession among Garos whether non- Christian Garos or Christian Gams should properly be decided by this Customary Law. <em>54 CWN (2 DR) 14.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 59—Person capable of making wills</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The petitioner filed a certified copy of Death Register of Begumganj Municipality to show that the petitioner’s father Satish Chandra Roy died at his house in Noakhali as a Bangladeshi citizen in the year 1975. The Tahsildar’s report simply shows that “sons of Satish Chandra are Indian Nationals’. Even if his sons are Indian nationals this fact does not make him an enemy alien or his property an enemy property under the Defense of Pakistan Rules Mere claim of the Asset. Custodian that the property of the deceased testator is an enemy property in respect of which an enemy property case was started in 1978 is not sufficient for coming to a conclusion that the property is an enemy property. In these circumstances the impugned order allowing addition of party cannot be maintained but the matter may be further enquired into.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Niuya Gopal Roy Barman Vs. Pran Gopal Nandi (1980) 32 DLR 11.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 63—Will</strong>—Deposition of attesting witnesses to the document necessary to prove execution of a will.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Paresh Chandra Bhowmick Vs. Hiralal Nath (1984)36 DLR (AD) 156.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—It must be proved that the testator had full understanding as to know what exactly he was doing by putting his signature or mark on the will— Presumption of law as to execution. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 102, 233 and 235—</strong>When the first executor refused to act, the second executor could legitimately file the petition for probate—Second executor being dead, his heirs being his legatees can maintain a proceeding to obtain probate of the will.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Khitindra Chandra Bhattacharya Vs. Jalada Devi (1983)35 DLR (AD) 102.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 191—Gift made in contemplation of death—Gift is effective only if the donor dies—Doctrine of ‘donatio mortis causa’.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The doctrine of <em>donatio mortis causa</em> appears in section 191 of our Succession Act. In accordance with section 191 gifts “made in contemplation of death” are resumable by the donor if he survives and the power to make such gifts is co-extensive with the power of testamentary disposition. It is true that gifts “in contemplation of death” are gifts which are to take effect in case the donor dies, but authority can be found in any commentary for the proposition that although the donor does not say so the presumption in the case of gifts made during apprehension of death is that they are to take effect only in case of death.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Shamshad All Vs. Hassan Shah PLD 1964 Supreme Court 143 = 16 DLR SC 330=1964 (2)PSCR 1 (Kaikaus,J).</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 211</strong>—The interest of an executor in the testator’s property is not an interest in land and although properties worth more that Rs. 100/- had vested in executor under section 211, the deed of appointment by which he appoints ‘S’ as executor in his place could not be said to have created such an interest as would bring the document under section 17(b) of the Registration Act and require registration.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Radha Kanta Pal Vs. Swami Turiananda (1950) 2 DLR 265.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 211(I)—The words ‘as such’ in section 211(1) of the Act explained.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The words ‘as such’ indicate that the vesting of the property in the executor is limited to the purpose of management only as the legal representative of the testator and they do not in any way affect the beneficial interest in the property. The beneficial interest vests in the persons named in the Will as beneficiaries and not in the executor.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Nirode Baran Paul Vs. Ahmed Meah (1970) 22 DLR 529.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 213—Suing without filing the probate</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Plaintiff Sues as a sole legatee under a will without filing the probate but proves that the probate had been taken for recovery of money due, on mortgage of debutter property executed by some co-shebaits being in possession of specific portions on division and managing that portion separately and independently and for the benefit of the deity and for the preservation of the estate. The lower appellate Court modified that decree of the trial Cowl with the direction that in case of default of payment the plaintiff will be appointed receiver to the estate and will realise his dues Out of the income of the estate which fell to the share of the co-shebait defendants.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held</strong>: (a) Section 213 of the Act is no bar when it is proved that probate in fact has been taken, though it has not been proved.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">(b) Mortgage by co-shebaits defendants is valid even though not executed by other co-shebaits as it is found to be for the benefit of the deity and for the preservation of the estate.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">That the other co-shebaits are not interested in the mortgage because of the division and that the debutter itself is not in any way prejudiced by the order because of the appointment of the receiver and the direction made.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Bireswar Ghose Vs. Kumar Vade Kanta Singha Ray (1950) 2 DLR 67</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Bar of section when applies</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The bar of section 213 of the Act does not apply unless, whether he is the plaintiff or the defendant., a person seeks to establish any right as executor legatee, but if he seeks to establish such a right, i.e. cannot succeed unless he proves the grant of p. abate or letters of administration.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Bindu Bala De Vs. Rebati Mohan De (1952) 4 DLR 293.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—To defeat the claim of natural heirs to the property of deceased person the claimant must prove that at the moment the succession opened the property vested in him under a will. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 214(1)—</strong>Execution of decree—Judgment- debtor dying after obtaining decree—Legal representatives should obtain succession certificate as envisaged in s.214(l), Succession Act, before proceeding with execution—Outright dismissal of execution application made by legal representative, for want of succession certificate, neither desirable nor necessary—Execution Courts should give time to legal representatives of deceased decree-holder to obtain succession certificate.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mst. Khatija Begum Vs. Haji Gulzar Ahmed (1961) 21 PLD (Karachi) 141.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 214(1)(6)—Decree-holder dying during the pendency of an execution case— Heirs can proceed with the execution case without taking out a succession certificate.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">An application filed by the heirs of a deceased decree-holder in a pending execution case for proceeding with the execution case cannot be said to be an application for execution of the decree, but it is an application to allow the heirs to proceed with the pending execution case, that is to say, the execution case which had already been started by the decree- holder in his life time.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Though clause (b) of sub-section (1) of section 214 of the Succession Act applies to a case where the heirs of the original decree-holder, after his death, file an application for execution of the decree it has got no application where the application for execution of this decree had already been started by the decree-holder who died during the pendency of the execution case, and his heirs and legal representatives ask leave of the court to continue with the execution case without filing any succession certificate.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Jogendra Kishore Sarkar Vs. Gajendra Kr. Nandi (1960) 12 DLR 232.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 218—Applicant abandoning application for grant of Letters of Administration—Court cannot pursue the application—Conduct of applicant may operate as estoppel.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It cannot be said that if an applicant abandons, or withdraws from the prosecution of an application filed by him for grant of a Letter of Administration, the Court is still bound to proceed with the same and bring it to a conclusion on judicial determination of the points involved or that’ an instrument executed by the applicants as consideration for such abandonment or withdrawal and acknowledging therein either the factum or the validity of a transfer by an agent (such as guardian) or limited owner of some interest to which they are entitled or have a right to succeed in future is illegal. On the other hand, it appears to be well settled that although both the transfer and the agreement to transfer a reversionary interest are void, yet a reversioner may be estopped from claiming the reversion by this conduct if he has consented to an alienation by a widow or other limited heir.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sishu Bala Ghose Vs. Profulla Chandra Mondal PLD 1962 Dacca 490=13 DLR 307 (Sikandar Ali, J).</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 228—Attorney of executor—May apply under the section</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">There is nothing in section 228 of the Act to dcbar an attorney of the absent executor to apply for Letters of Administration with copy of the authenticated copy of the will annexed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sir Roger Thomas. In the matter of, PLD 1962 (WP) Karachi 744 (Inamullah, J.)</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 228, 241, 291—Scope of sections 228 and 241 discussed</strong>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Section 228 does not make provision for the grant of administration to an agent or attorney, while section 241 assumes production by the attorney of the original will. The two sections are intended to apply in very different circumstances, the former where the will has been proved and the latter where it has not been proved at all. The Court while acting under section 228 would grant Letters of Administration without further proof of the will, while under section 241 the will has to be proved.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sir Roger Thomas. In the matter of, PLD 1962 W.P. Karachi 744 (Inamullah, J).</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 230</strong>—The Succession Act does not empower an executor to renounce except in the manner provided in section 230 or by applying for revocation of the grant under section 263.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Swami Turianandha Vs. Dinesh Chandra (1955) 7 DLR (FC) 156.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Under section 230 an executor may renounce orally in the presence of the Judge or by a writing by himself and on such renunciation being made the executor is precluded from ever thereafter applying for probate of the will. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The section is capable of the construction that after the grant there is no power left in the executor to renounce. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 230 and 263</strong>—Applies to cases of renunciation before a grant of probate. Section 230 refers to cases where the renunciation is before the grant of the probate. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Secs. 232 and 237—Will in the custody of a testator and is not found on his death—Presumption.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Where a will is shown to have been in the custody of a testator and is not found on his death, the presumption arises that the will has been destroyed by the testator for the purpose of revoking it. No general rule can be laid down as to the nature of evidence which would be required to rebut the presumption. <em>54 CWN (DR 2) 99.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The expression. since the testator’s death’ occurring in section 237 qualifies only the word ‘mislaid” in the section having no reference to the word ‘lost. Consequently section 237 applies to cases where the will was lost during the life-time of the testator. <em>54 CWN (DR2) 99.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—‘Will’ in section 232 means disposition rather than the original will, otherwise in no case where the will is not in existence, universal or residuary legatee can apply. <em>54 CWN (DR2) 99.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 263</strong>—The Succession Act does not empower an executor to renounce except in the manner provided in section 230 or by applying for revocation of the grant under section 263.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Swami Tunananda Vs. Dinesh Chandra (1955) 7 DLR (FC) 156.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The section is capable of the construction that after the grant there is no power left in the executor to renounce. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—If a person having taken the probate wishes to relieve himself of the responsibilities of the office of executor for a valid reason, he can only do so by asking the court to revoke the grant in his favour under section 263. <em>  Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—There is nothing in section 263 to warrant the inference that it applies only where the whole grant has to be revoked and that it is not applicable to cases where one of the several executors to whom the probate was originally granted has become of unsound mind or too old to act or has left the country. <em>   Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A provision in will giving to each of the executors an unqualified power of resigning and nominating with the consent of the majority of the executors is contrary to the provisions of the Act.<em>   Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The clause conferring that power could be valid only if it means that the resigning or renouncing executor before nominating his successor has to obtain from the court a revocation of the grant in his favour. <em>   Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Executor when desires to be relieved.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If an executor desires to be relieved from the legal status of an executor and expresses a desire to withdraw, the only course open to him is to make an application to the court under section 263, Explanation (d). Until an order for revocation has been passed by the court he will continue in law to hold the status and fill the office of the executor.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Radha Kanta Pal Vs. Swami Turiananda (1950) 2 DLR 265.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Probate—Revocation—Just cause.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Old age or insanity of executor, or that the executor had left the country—Provisions in will giving unqualified power to executor to resign and nominate a substitute, held, contrary to provisions of Act— Proper procedure—First to get revocation and then applying for a fresh probate.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Section 263 provides that the grant of probate or letters of administration may be revoked or annulled by the Court for just cause. Among the instances of just cause mentioned in that section is the case where a grant has become useless and inoperative through circumstances.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Swami Turiananda Vs. Radha Kanta Pal PLD (1955 (FC) 145.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Creditors application praying for revocation of probate—When his interest on account of his loan not affected—No maintainable—If probate obtained on false representation—He can ask for revocation.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A creditor-simpliciter cannot be said to have a locus standi to pray for revocation of the probate for it would be the duty of whoever is the grantee to pay debts first, and his interest cannot be affected by any dispossession made by the deceased.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">But when it is alleged by a creditor that the grant was obtained by means of untrue allegation or by making false suggestion or by concealing from the court something material to the case and when such fraudulent suggestion or concealment would put the creditor in jeopardy such creditor would be entitled to ask for revocation of a probate.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mohd. Majibur Rahman Mia Vs. Naresh Chandra Guha (1979) 31 DLR 213.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 263-265</strong>—The District Delegate has no jurisdiction to entertain and to proceed with the proceeding for revocation of the probate.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">There is no dispute that the will was allegedly executed by the testator and a probate thereof was granted by the District Delegate. The application for revocation of the will has been filed before the District Delegate. Now the question is whether the District Delegate has jurisdiction to entertain the petition and grant revocation prayed for before him. Section 265 provides for High Court powers to appoint Delegate of District Judge to deal with non- contentious cases.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mohammad Chand Mia Vs. Barista Krishna Kunda (1979) 31 DLR 97.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 264(2)</strong>—Deceased Muslim—Issue of Letters of Administration—Court Fees Act Sec. 19-H. Delay in verification of value—Effect.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The High Court has jurisdiction to grant Letters of Administration in a case where the deceased was a Muslim.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The grant of letters of administration need not be delayed because of the omission on the part of Collector to furnish the requisite information under section 19-H of the Court-fees Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">P<em>LR (1960) 1 (WP) 499.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 270</strong>—District Judge can grant probate of Will if person executing it had fixed residence or property within his jurisdiction.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Gour Chandra Saha Vs. The Vicei Chairman, (1969) 21 DLR 535.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 283—</strong>Title to property to be decided in a title suit and not in a proceeding for grant f probate.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Jalil Ansari Vs. Surendra Nath Basu (1969) 21 DLR 331.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Person not interested in the estate of the deceased testator—Cannot claim to be a party in a proceeding for obtaining a probate.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The petitioner calls in question an order of the District Judge allowing the Deputy Commissioner to be made a party in a proceeding under section 283 of the Succession Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held</strong>: If the contention of the Deputy Commissioner is correct and the entries in the record-of- rights are incorrect, he is to seek remedy under the appropriate law. The present proceeding is with regard to the granting of probate on the basis of the will. Persons who claim interest in the property through the deceased are the persons who will be affected by the grant of the probate. Therefore, the Deputy Commissioner is not a person who can claim to be a party in the proceeding.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Abdul Jalil Ansari Vs. Surendra Nath Basu (1969) 21 DLR 331.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The word’ interest’ in s. 283 means interest through the testator—One claiming independently of the ‘will’ cannot be said to have an interest in the property.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sreernati Charubala Sen Gupta Vs. Abul Hashem &amp; ors. (1981) 33 DLR (AD) 254.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 295</strong>—Person opposing the grant of probate or letters of administration is to be too pleaded as defendant.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Priya Bala Majumdar Vs. Na1int Mohan Majumdar (1956) 8 DLR 109.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 299</strong>—District Judge’s decision is subject to appeal to the High Court but not that of the District</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Delegate who has to deal only with non-contentious matters falling under sections 286-288.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It will appear from a reading of the provisions of sections 286, 287 and 288 that a District Delegate cannot finally dispose of a contentious petition for probate and that even in the case of a non- contentious petition in case of doubt; he has to seek directions of the District Judge. He cannot also reject a non-contentious petition for probate.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Samir Kumar Chowdhury Vs. Sachindra Chandra Chowdhury (1968) 20 DLR 766.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 301</strong>—An application for removal of an executor under section 301 of the Act does not lie where the administration was complete and had come to an end<em>. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sachindra Ch. Guha Vs. Naresh ananda Sarasati (1958)10 DLR 534.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Capacities of an executor and of a trustee are distinct and separate and have different legal consequences flowing from them. The true function of an executor ceases when funeral and testamentary expenses, debts and legacies have been satisfied and the surplus, if any, have been invested upon the trusts of the will, for, thereafter the executor sheds his character as an executor and becomes a trustee in the proper sense of that term.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">When the legal estate, if devised absolutely to the legatee, is transferred to the legatee, there is nothing left to administer and the administration is then deemed to have come to an end.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Once an executor always an executor is a correct maxim, for his functions of the executor are confined to the execution of the will. <em>   Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">— In the present case, having regard to the provision of the will the court held that the intention of the testator was to set up a sole shebait and two or three other persons as supervisors over the said sheban, and this function of acting as a supervisor shebait was a function which was distinct and separate from that of an “executor”.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Although in the latter portion of the will the testator has used the words “executor for the purpose of supervision” and “executor supervisor”, the word “executor” in the context does not mean an executor in the strict sense of the term.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The will contained a clause that Ramanath Das and Ashutosh Dhar should contribute Rs. 30/- p.m. It was thereupon urged that until and unless the executors made proper arrangements for setting up an annuity fund for this purpose it could not be said that they had as executors completed the execution of the will:</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held:</strong> Administration under the will does not include the performance of injunctions or directions which have nothing whatever to do with the estate of the deceased. This was not a disposition of the estate by him and, as such, it was not a part of the administration of the estate of the deceased which an executor had to perform. <em>   Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 306</strong>—Section 306 of the Act applies to executors and administrators of the deceased and not the heirs representing the estate of the deceased. <em>PLR (1960)1 (WP) 412.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—‘Personal injury’—Decree in favour of the injured man for such injury—Death of the injured man while an appeal against decree was pending—Heirs entitled to get the decreetal amount and defend the appeal.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">When a suit is instituted by an injured person and a decree is obtained by him the cause of action merges into the decree and the amount instead of being unhiquidated becomes an ascertained sum and heritable.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In the present case the plaintiff instituted the suit for compensation on account of injury caused to the plaintiff by a running truck and obtained a decree against the defendant. As against the decree the defendant filed an appeal and during the pendency of the appeal the plaintiff died and thereupon the legal representatives of the plaintiff entered their appearance in support of the decree. It was however contended that the injury being personal to the plaintiff the cause of action for damages cannot survive after the death of the plaintiff.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Held: </span></strong>The cause of action of the plaintiff after the passing of the decree merged in the decree which was heritable, transferable and enforceable by the heirs of the plaintiff and as such, merely because the plaintiff died during the pendency of the appeal the suit cannot abate.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Pakistan Vs. Mrs. Siddika Khanum (1966)18 DLR 69.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.311—</strong>Will—Executor—in the absence of any direction to the contrary, powers of all executors may be exercised by any of them.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abul Kashem Vs. Sk. Kosimuddin (1974) 26 DLR 173.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.317(3)—</strong>Non-submission of accounts and non-exhibition of inventory—District Judge suo moto cannot make them grounds for revocation of the probate, when they were not taken exception of by any of the interested persons.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Nirod Baran Pal Vs. Nipar Bala Pal (1956)8 DLR 235.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 332, 333—Assent of the legatee— Does not create title—Title vests in the legatee on the death of testator even prior to his assent.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Sections 332 and 333, Succession Act (XXXIX of 1925) do not mean that the legatee has till his assent acquired no interest or right in the legacy. The right, even though an inchoate right until assent, is nevertheless an interest created by the will itself and the assent is only a perfecting act for the security of the executor. The assent thus creates no new title, for, the title vests in the legatee from the moment of the death of the testator, in the case of a specified bequest, under section 104 of the Succession Act, and it cannot, therefore, be said that till the executor has signified his assent the legatee has no interest whatsoever in the subject matter of the legacy.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Jassumal Vs. Central Govt. Reh. Deptt. PLD 1961 Supreme Court 21)6=1961 (1) PSCR 123=13 DLR SC 177. (Hamoodur Rahman, J).</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 372(3)—Certificate can be granted in respect of a portion of a debt.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A certificate can be granted in respect of a portion of a debt or debts due to the deceased creditor and, therefore, in the discretion of the Court two or more certificates can be granted in respect of a debt due to the deceased.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mrs. Sufia Khanam Vs. Abdul Huq Khan (1968)20 DLR 450.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.383</strong>—High Court has no powers to interfere merely because it differs, however profoundly, from conclusions of subordinate Court upon questions of fact or law—Administrative Civil Judge dismissing petition under s. 383, Succession Act, 1925, having found it negative as regards alleged fraudulent nature of proceedings or making of false suggestion or concealment of something material—</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held:</strong> Administrative Civil Judge having jurisdiction has decided question of fact raised before him, whether rightly or wrongly—Interference by High Court in revision under s. 115 CPC in circumstances refused.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Noor Mohammad Vs. Namdar (1969) 21 PLD 205.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 388(2)—Proviso, Appeal against an order passed by a Judge lies to the District Judge and not to the High Court.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It has been provided in the proviso to subsection (2) of section 388 of the Succession Act that an appeal against an order by a Judge who has been empowered by the Provincial Government to discharge the function of District Judge in the matter of succession certificate shall lie to the District Judge and it has further been provided that it shall not lie to the High Court, It is therefore clear that the appeal directly filed in the High Court-is misconceived and not maintainable.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mrs. Safia Khanam Vs. Abdul Huq Khan (1968) 20 DLR 450.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Succession to property—Custom, Force of.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">(Custom in Punjab)—Custom that devolution of property has a preference over the personal law of the parties, is limited to the ancestral property only and not to non-ancestral property and in case of latter, the governing law is the personal law.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mst. Qaiser Khatoon Vs. Mvi. Abdul Khaliq (1973) 25 DLR (SC) 104.</em><span id="pastemarkerend"></span></p></div></div>
2406	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Suit</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>   (1954) 6 DLR 156, (1955) 7 DLR 6,  (1952) 4 DLR 89, (1957) 9 DLRI, (1976)28 DLR (SC) 151, (1965) 17 DLR 187, (1951) 3 DLR 337, (1956)8 DLR 60, (1957) 9 DLR 467, 39 CLJ 140; 32 CWN 1023, (1960) 12 DLR 32, AIR (Cal) 1925 320, (1970) 22 DLR (SC) 371, (1959</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Suit</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Suit</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Suit—Defect in the form of.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Defect in the form of a suit immaterial— Substance to be looked at.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Ramani Bhusan Chowdhury Vs. Mohendra Kr. Saha (1954) 6 DLR 156.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—If the nearest reversioner, without sufficient cause, refuses to institute proceedings or if he has precluded himself from suing or has colluded with the persons who had the prior right to bring suit or concurred in the act alleged to be wrongful, the next perspective reversioner would be entitled to sue.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Haji Yar Ali Khan Vs. Mobarak Ali Chowdhury (1955) 7 DLR 6.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Suit—Maintainability.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">To cure defect of non-maintainability of a suit the court has the option suo moto to direct the joinder of a person as a co plaintiff under Order I, rule 10, of the CP Code even though the amendment was not asked for by the plaintiff.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdus Sattar Howlader Vs. Afeluddin Chokdar (1952) 4 DLR 89</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Suit—Plaintiff’s success depends on his own case</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Plaintiff’s suit—His success depends on his own case and not the weakness of that of the defendant.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>PK Basak &amp; Co. Vs. Gossen &amp; Co. (1957) 9 DLRI.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Suit when expressly barred under a statute</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—Means a suit which falls within the ambit of that statute—If has no application when the suit is outside of what is prohibited.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">When an order purporting to be made under a certain provision of a statute is shown to have been made without jurisdiction or malafide such an order cannot be said to have been made under the said statute and that in such a case the statutory provision seeking to bar a suit challenging the said order is not attracted.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">An order, though purporting to be made under a statute, being malafide or without jurisdiction, is a nullity. Such an order cannot be taken to have been made under the said Statute.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>DIT Vs. Waliullah (1976)28 DLR (SC) 151.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—In a suit for specific performance of a contract against a transferee who took subsequent to the contract sued upon, the burden of proving good faith and Lack of notice is upon the defend it. <em>(1959) 11 DLR 177.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Suit for possession—Title cannot be pleaded in bar of a suit of this nature.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Debendra Mohan Das Vs. Mohd. Afazuddin (1965) 17 DLR 187.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Possessory suit—</strong>Applicability and scope of sec. 9 Specific Relief Act takes out of the creation of the Act rights classed as “incorporeal rights” though they are immovable property. <em>20 CWN 1158: Ref.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The object of s.9 Sp. R Act is to discourage people from taking the law into their own hands however good their title may be. <em>24 (Bom) LR 768: 1922 (Born) 216, ref.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Where the tenant has been dispossessed landlord alone cannot sue for possession. <em>1919 Nag. 126. Contra 1950 AL U 288, 1952 (Pat) 339.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A suit under this section. by a tenant is not barred by the provisions of the <em>Chota Nagpur Tenancy Act. 15 CWN 387 : 13 CU 250; 9 IC 478.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—In a suit for possession under this section, mesne profits cannot be awarded, <em>1927 (Mad) 722 102 IC 661.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Appointment of receiver for collection of mesne profits is without jurisdiction. <em>1937 Sind 161 :170 IC 12.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Independently of this sec. a suit for possession against a trespasser on possessory title is maintainable. <em>49 A. 191 : 1927 (All) 526, 1927 All.669.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—In suits under s.9 question of title is irrelevant. <em>58 C. 29:1931 Cal. 483.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Order 1, r. 3. Suit by trustee—</span></strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">There is no provision in the CP Code enabling the trustees of a trust to sue in the name of the trust. <em>Govt. of the Prov of Bombay Vs. PA Wadia (1951) 3 DLR 337.</em></span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Suit by representative—</span></strong> A person appointed a representative under Or 1, r. 8, is not a party in his personal capacity. On his death, his rights not survive to his heirs. <em>Haidarulla Vs. Gajindha Sukiabaidya (1956)8 DLR 60.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Representative suit—</span></strong> A plaintiff suing in a personal capacity can obtain the benefit of a representative suit. <em>Abdus Sobhan Chowdhury Vs. Faziur Rahman Chowdhury (1957) 9 DLR 467.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A suit for specific performance of agreement to affect a partial partition of joint property is not maintainable. <em>12 CLJ 25</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—In a suit for partition of joint family property all movables and immovables should be joined 22 CWN 669. but if any property is left out it may be partitioned subsequently. <em>39 CLJ 140; 32 CWN 1023.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A suit for partial partition between co-owners of an estate is maintainable since the reasons against the partial partition of joint family property do not apply to the case of co-owners of an estate. <em>12 CWN 540.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Partition suit, nature and scope—In determining the question as to exact nature, characteristics and scope of a partition suit, the allegation made by the plaintiff alone must be considered. The pleas raised by the defendant do not affect the question. Furthermore in a Suit for partition the plaintiff does not seek to enforce a right to a share in the property on the ground that it is a joint property but merely seeks to obtain separate possession of a share therein aid thus seeks merely for a change in the mode of enjoyment thereof. <em>(1960) 12 DLR 329.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In partition suit, the plaintiff can establish his title, if necessary. <em>29 CWN 776.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In a partition suit all the co-sharers arc to be made parties, so a residuary co-sharer cannot question the previous partition. <em>21 CLI 23.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A partition suit must include all the claims relating to the subject-matter. A subsequent suit for account does not lie. <em>468829.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In a partition suit a defendant can ask for the separation of his share too. A Suit for partition remains pending till the passing of the final decree. <em>PLD 1953 (Lah) 545.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Partition suit—rights of defendants inter se</span></strong>—It is no doubt usual in partition suits to decide the shares of all the parties. But where the defendants agreed to have a preliminary decree being passed in favour of the plaintiff for partition of his share without their rights being decided and the preliminary decree was not appealed against, it is not open to the defendants in subsequent proceedings to contend that their rights inter se should have been dealt with.<em> 36 PLD 112.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Partition suit, Court’s power and obligation—</span></strong> The Court has an inherent power to refuse to divide the property by metes and bounds and to adopt such other means as may appear equitable for effecting a just partition. <em>61 MLJ 552.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—In a suit for partition, it is not incumbent on the court to affect a partition of the property only if the parties agree to abide by the partition or agree to the appointment of a particular person as a local commissioner. <em>36 PLD 258. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Partition suit—Right of plaintiff and not of defendant’s subject-matter of suit.—Ii. is the right of the plaintiff that constitutes the subject-matter of a suit. The subject-matter has no reference to the right of the defendant or to the issue which may incidentally arise in the suit. Quite apart from the provisions of the Court-fees and the Suits Valuation Acts, it must be held on general principles that the subject-matter of a suit is the right claimed by the plaintiff in respect of whom he prays for relief. <em>(1961)13 DLR (SC) 191.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Valuation for the purpose of jurisdiction— When not covered by section 8.—In a case which is not covered either by section 8 or by a rule framed by the High Court under section 9 or the Provincial Government under section 3 of the Suits Valuation Act the value for jurisdiction will be the true value of the subject-matter of the suit to be determined by the Court itself. <em>(1961) 13 DLR (SC) 191.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Partition suit—where the plaintiff is out of possession—Court-fee is to be payable on the plaintiffs share and jurisdiction of the court determinable on the value of the plaintiff’s share. <em>(1960) 12 DLR 32g.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—In a suit for partition it is the value of entire property which determines jurisdiction and not of the share which the plaintiff claims in the property. <em>29 CWN 76; AIR (Cal) 1925 320.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Suit for damages by Govt. servant,</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Suit for damages in tort brought by a Government servant against the State as well as Government servant’s right to claim future salary—not maintainable.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Pakistan through General Manager, NWR Vs. MIs. AV Issacs (1970) 22 DLR (SC) 371.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Oral Usufructuary Mortgage—Suit for Redemption</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Both in India and in Burma cultivators, in the teeth of the express terms of s. 59 of TP Act are still wont to obtain loans by delivering their lands to the lenders upon the terms that the lenders may remain in possession until the loan is repaid, and appropriate the fruits of the land towards the repayment of the principal or of the interest due under the loan. Such transactions are usufructuary mortgages within s. 58(d) and unless the instrument of mortgage in such a case is in writing, and the transaction also falls within s. 53-A, the terms of the mortgage cannot be relied on as a ground of attack or of defense by either the plaintiff or the defendant in a mortgage suit, except in cases in which they are embodied in a duly registered written instrument. Accordingly, a suit framed as a suit for redemption of lands which are the subject of an oral usufructuary mortgage cannot be sustained, inasmuch as the plaintiff pleads and relics on the oral mortgage which is required by law to be effected by a registered instrument. The proper course of the mortgagor to take in such a case would be to sue for possession relying on his title. In such a suit, it is not permissible for the defendant to rest his claim to remain in for possession on the oral mortgage which could not be proved. <em>13 R 274 (FB). But see. 14 LR 157 (Rev)— 17 RD 201.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A suit for setting aside a decree is a suit for substantive relief.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Kumudini Welfare Trust Vs. Pakistan (1959) 11 DLR 57.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2407	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Suits Valuation Act, 1887</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1957,19 DLR 190, (1960) 12 DLR (FB) 329 (331), (1961)13 DLR SC) 191, (1954) 6 DLR 466, (1968) 20 DLR 77, (1959)11 DLR 57,(1956)8 DLR 100,  (1961) 13 DLR (SC) 191, (1983) 35 DLR 14 (15), (1967) 19 DLR (SC) 472, (1967) 19 DLR (SC) 483,  (1967) 19 DLR (SC)</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Suits Valuation </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Suits Valuation Act</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;">(VII of 1887)</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 3</strong>—Appeal in land suit or suit concerning interest in land—Forum is determined by valuation determined under the rules and not by market value.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The forum of appeals in land suits or interest in the land for the purposes of section 18 of the Ordinance the determining factor would be the value of original suit determined under rules framed under section 3 of the Suits Valuation Act for the purposes of jurisdiction, and not the market value of the subject- matter of the suit. <em>Maqarrab Khan Vs. MoM. An- war Khan PLD 1964 (WP) Peshawar 228=PLR 1965 (2) WP 168=PLR 1965 (1) WP 527 (DB) (Daud, I).</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 8</strong>—Suit falling under s. 7(iv)(l) Court-Fees Act—Valuation for Court-Fee and jurisdiction is the same.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In a suit for rendition of accounts the plaintiff must state the amount at which he values the relief sought. In such a suit the crucial value is value of the relief and the plaintiff need not state any value for purposes of jurisdiction because it will be the same as laid down in section 8 of the Suits Valuation Act, 1887. The value for purposes of jurisdiction inadvertently stated in the plaint, therefore, cannot be taken to be value for purposes of relief claimed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Suleiman Khan Vs. Muhammad Zaman Khan, PLD 1961 AzadJ. &amp; K48 (DB) (Shah, CJ).</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.</strong> <strong>8</strong>—Valuation in partition suit where the plaintiff is out of possession.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In a partition suit where the plaintiff is excluded from possession section 8 of the Suits Valuation Act now applies and the valuation given for the purpose of court-fees must also be the valuation for the purpose of jurisdiction. The proper method is first to make the valuation for the purpose of court-fees, and then to take that value for the purposes of jurisdiction and not vice versa.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Patak Ch. Haldar Vs. Sademan Howladar (1957,19 DLR 190.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Partition suit where plaintiff is out of possession.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In a suit for partition where the plaintiff is excluded from possession, court-fees must be paid ad valorem according to the market value of the plaintiff’s share in respect of which the suit is instituted and the value for the purposes of jurisdiction must also be determined by the same value which has been computed for court-fees.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Khayertullah Mondal Vs. Katnalakanta Saha (1960) 12 DLR (FB) 329 (331).</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 8 &amp; 11</strong>—Valuation for the purpose of court’s jurisdiction in a partition Suit where plaintiff is in possession is determinable by the value of the plaintiffs share in the entire property.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">[Held by the majority, accepting AR Cornelius, CJ, disagreeing.] In a suit for partition of joint property by a person, claiming to be in joint possession, the valuation for purposes of jurisdiction is determined by the value of the share of the plaintiff in the property and not by the value of the whole property.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In a suit for partition, where the plaintiff is excluded from possession, the plaintiff has to pay ad-valorem court-fees on the market value of the share claimed by him and that value also determines the forum of the trial or appeal. It is difficult to appreciate why in a case for partition, where the plaintiff is in joint possession he must be given the benefit of having his suit tried or his appeal heard by a higher tribunal by valuing his suit according to the value of the entire property sought to be partitioned.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Ajizuddin V. Rahman Fakir (1961)13 DLR SC) 191.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—VaIation of a suit—Plaintiff’s absolute discretion</strong> In a Suit coining under section 7 (IV) (c) of Court-fees Act having, as regards its valuation, no objective standard available, nor have any rules been framed by the High Court under scc9 of mc Suits Valuation Act, plaintiff has a discretion as to the amount at which the relief is to be valued and the court has no power to revise such valuation.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Star Film Vs. Sargam Pictures (1954) 6 DLR 466.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 9—Plaintiff’s discretion to value</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In a suit coming under section 7(iv) (c) of the Court-Fees Act, having, as regards its valuation, no objective standard available, nor have any rules been framed by the High Court under section 9 of the Suits Valuation Act, plaintiff has a discretion as to the amount at which the relief is to be valued and the court has no power to revise such valuation.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Star Film Distributors Vs. Sujan Pictures (1954) 6 DLR 466 (468 rt.h.col),</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Provisions of section 8(c) of the Court-fees Act are independent of section 9 of the Suit Valuation Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The Court is authorized under section 8(c) of the Court-fees Act to hold an enquiry as to valuation of any suit and to assess the same. This is absolutely an independent power consciously given by the legislature to the Court and the legislature must be presumed to have in its mind the provision of Section 9 of the Suits Valuation Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Section 9 of the Suits Valuation Act is not only an independent section but is also contained in a different Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Govt. -of East Pakistan Vs. Maharaja King Bikram (1968) 20 DLR 77.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 9—</strong>Section 8C Court Fees Act, gives the Court power to revise the valuation of any suit. But that does not improve matters as regards cases dealt with in section 7(iv)(c) inasmuch as it does not indicate any method or principle by which the court can revise the plaintiff’s valuation in cases where there is no objective standard.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Star Film Vs. Sargam Pictures (1954) 6 DLR 466.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—In suits for recovery of money or land, there is obviously an objective basis for valuation, namely, the amount of the money to be recovered or the market value of the land.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Kumudini Welfare Trust Vs. Pakistan (1959)11 DLR 57.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Valuation of suit. It is the duty of the Court to enquire into the proper valuation of a suit when it has grounds to consider that the valuation given by the party is not correct. <em>AIR 1925 (Pal) 392 (FB)+AIR 1930 (Cal) 65 (DB).</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 11—Objection to jurisdiction.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Objection as to trial courts jurisdiction to try a suit on the ground that it was undervalued was raised in the trial Court but that Court-while disposing of this objection fell in an error by repeating undervaluation.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">On appeal the lower appellate Court found that on a proper valuation suit was beyond the pecuniary jurisdiction of the trial Court and on that finding remanded the case with a direction that the plaint is returned to the plaintiff for presentation to the proper court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held:</strong> Objection to jurisdiction having been raised in the court of first instance, the court of the Appeal below rightly held that the judgment and the decree of the trial Court were hit by the want of jurisdiction.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Decision of the trial Court regarding valuation made not only for the purpose of court fees but for the purpose of ascertaining the jurisdiction as well is open to correction in appeal.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">But where objection as to valuation was for the first time raised in the second appeal, then in view of the provision of section 11 of the Suits Valuation Act, objection to the jurisdiction of a court based on over-valuation or under-valuation should not be entertained by an appellate Court unless there was prejudice on merits. If the objection as to jurisdiction is taken in the court of the first instance, there is hardly any scope for the application of section 11.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Nagendra N. Sen Roy Vs. Saiyad Ali Jamadar. (1956)8 DLR 100.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The policy underlying sections 21 and 99 CPC and section 11 of the Suits Valuation Act is same, namely, that when a case had been tried by a court on the merits and judgment rendered, it should not be liable to be reversed .purely on technical grounds, unless it had resulted in a failure of justice, and the policy of the legislature has been to treat objections to jurisdiction both territorial and pecuniary as technical unless there has been a prejudice on the merits.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Nagendra N. Sen Ray Vs. Saiyad Ali Jamadar (1956) 8 DLR 100.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">(Per Cornelius, CJ)—</span></strong>As the point of valuation for purpose of jurisdiction was not taken in the Court of first instance, under s. 11 of the SV Act no omission on the ground of over-valuation or under valuation should have been entertained by the appellate Court, i.e. the High Court, even if that Court were of the opinion that ‘the over-valuation or under-valuation thereof has prejudicially affected the disposal of the suit or appeal on its merits”.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Azizuddin Vs. Rahman Fakir. (1961) 13 DLR (SC) 191.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.11</strong>—If no objection as to valuation of a suit is taken either in the trial or appellate court—No further objection will be allowed, especially if the party concerned has not been prejudiced in any mater.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Gopal Krishna Das Vs. Abdul Kadr Mia (1983) 35 DLR 14 (15).</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Supreme Court</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Appeal to the Supreme Court competent, being an order against the Collector even though a departmental appeals, against the Collector’s order, has already been preferred and disposed of by the Board of Revenue.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Messers S. A. Haroon Vs. Collector of Customs, Karachi (1967) 19 DLR (SC) 472.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Person appearing before the Supreme Court being an advocate has to make submission in English language.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Shamsuddin Ahmed Vs. Registrar, High Court of E. Pak. (1967) 19 DLR (SC) 483.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Question of fact—Interference by the Supreme Court on question of fact is permissible not only when apparent blunder or error committed by lower Court but also when the finding is patently absurd and also it is physically impossible.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The Privy Council itself recognized that it would not hesitate to review the evidence in spite of a concurrent finding of the Courts below if “it be shown with absolute clearness that some blunder or error is apparent in the way in which the learned Judges below have dealt with the facts” or “if there had been any principle of evidence not properly applied.” But this at best is a rule of practice only which has gradually developed as a result of the decisions of the Board which are merely illustrative and by no means exhaustive.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Federation of Pakistan Vs. Ali Ihsan (1967) 19 DLR (SC) 251.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Supreme Court—State duty to comply with the order of the Supreme Court— Unseemly hurry in passing the order under review deprecated.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">it is indeed unfortunate that there was an unseemly hurry on the part of the State to pass the second order of forfeiture without first having fully complied with the order of the Supreme Court in letter and in spirit. It was desirable for the State to act in such a manner as to avoid giving any impression whatsoever that it might have acted on a consideration other than purely in the interest of the State and its people.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Tofazzal Hossain Vs. Province of East Pak. (1967)19 DLR 529.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Supreme Court’s ruling—Executive Government’s duty to obey the same in letter and spirit.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">AM Sayem, J— I have been greatly distressed at the manner of implementation, a mere feigning as it is, of the interim order passed by their Lordships of the Supreme Court directing restoration of the press to the petitioner, and the stage at which the impugned order was passed, though the learned Attorney-General insisted that these did not at all concern us and were matters solely between the Supreme Court and some of the respondents.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Tofazzal Hossain Vs. Province of East Pak. (1967)19 DLR 529.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Obiter of the Supreme Court</strong>—Any observation by the Supreme Court even obiter is binding on the High Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>M. Ismail and Sons Vs. Trans Oceanic Steamship Co. Ltd. (1965) 17 DLR 269.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Appeal to the Supreme Court— Point involving inquiry into facts cannot generally be allowed to be raised for the 1st time.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Points involving inquiry into facts or as to which there could have been an answer on facts, if they were raised in the trial Court, cannot in the absence of strong reasons justifying such a course, be allowed to be raised for the first time in appeal.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Whether both parties were ignorant of the law on a particular date is a question of fact which could only be decided after an investigation and there was no good ground for its being allowed to be raised as an additional ground of appeal.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Haji Abdullah Khaiz Vs. Niso Mohammad Khan (1965) 17 DLR (SC) 481.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Appeal by special leave to Supreme Court— Maintainability of objection—Objection not mentioned in the concise statement cannot be raised for the first time at the time of argument.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Taj Din Vs. Mrs. Razia Begum (1973) 25 DLR (SC) 13</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Concurrent finding of fact—When it does and when does not interfere.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The Supreme Court does not interfere with concurrent findings of fact in civil matters, unless that finding is shown to be based on no evidence or upon mis-reading of the evidence. No such error has been pointed out to us.
