Abdul Khaleque (1975) 27 DLR 617.</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S.93A(S)(iii)(c)</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Requiring body is not entitled to any notice to be issued to itonthe question of determination of compensation—Such requiring body is not anecessary party to any such proceeding. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>DIT Vs.Additional District Judge (1977) 29 DLR 87.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—<b>Personto be compensated is a necessary party to the proceeding.</b></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>In the caseof the person to be compensated, he is a party to the proceeding because, it ishe who files an application to the Tribunal for determining compensation. <i>   Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Requiringbody is not a necessary party in proceeding for determination of compensation—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>It isneither an aggrieved party within the meaning of Article 102 of theConstitution. <i>   Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S.93A(5)(b)(ii)—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Tribunal under the Town Improvement Act in assessing compensationdoes not possess the power to grant interest though the power is available whenthe acquisition is under the provisions of Land Acquisition Act. The questionis: could this power be exercised by the Court while acting as such under theprovisions of sections 91A of the Town Improvement Act, <i>1953. (1980) 32 DLR(AD) 92.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 93A (7)and 93A(I) (3)—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Dy. Commissioner and Mdl. Dy Commissioner duly empowered toexercise the functions of the provincial Government under section 93A (1) (3)and form opinion as to the necessity of requisitioning any property. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>DaccaImprovement Truss Vs. Addi. Commissioner, Dacca (1965) I7DLR 323.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—A schemewhich is primarily for the development of a particular area or commercialpurpose does not lose its main character if incidentally it brings some income.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Mansur AliBepari Vs. Province of East Pak. (1962) 14 DLR 520.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S.93A(7)—Notice of acquisition— Notice which does not identify the land to beacquired is bad to that extent.</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The serviceof the order of requisition upon the person affected by it is a pre-requisitecondition which must be satisfied for the purpose of obtaining possession ofthe requisitioned property. Such service of the order postulates that the ordermust convey to the affected per son an i4ea as to what property is sought to beacquired from him and to what extent. It need not set out in any detail theparticulars which may perhaps be required under sub-section (4) (b) of section93A of the Act; but sufficient particulars must be set Out which will enablethe person, from whom the property is requisitioned, to identify the propertyand in ascertain the extent of such requisition.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>It isdifficult to lay down the exact limits as to what those particulars should bebut the order must give sufficient notice to the person affected by it, settingout such particulars which would enable the person concerned to understand whathas been acquired from him.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>In order todetermine whether the order is partly good or totally bad, the test is, whetherthe identifiable land can be separated from that which is unidentifiable. If theidentifiable portion can be so separated, the notice is good in so far as itrelates to such portion which is identifiable. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='line-height:115%;Cambria","serif";'>Mansur Ali Bepari Vs.Province of East Pak. (1962) 14 DLR 520.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Secs. 93Aand 93B</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Acquisitionof land under these sections must precede an order of requisition—Reading therelevant provisions of the Act it is found that sections 93A and 93B of theTown Improvement Act, 1953 are related to the acquisition of land preceded byan order of requisition and they provide almost a self-contained code for thespecific purpose, the third mode of acquisition under the Act. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>BangladeshVs. Abdur Rashid (1980) 32 DLR (AD) 92.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S.101(1)(2)(3)—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Ex-proprietors (from whom the land has been acquired by the DIT)right to have the allotment of the acquired land is not unqualified butdependant on several factors—Having regard to them Board is under no obligationto allot the acquired land to ex-proprietors. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>JahanaraBegum Vs. Chairman, Dacca Improvement Trust (1968) 20 DLR 1013.</span></i></p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span> </div></div>
2414	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Trade Marks Act  (V of 1940)</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1965)17 DLR (SC)163, (1968)20 DLR 289, (1966) 18 DLR 595,  (1969)21 DLR (SC) 114, (1969) 21 DLR 415, (1968)20 DLR 1171, (1969) 21 DLR 945, (1969) 21 DLR 945, (1969) 21 DLR 415, (1969) 21 DLR (SC) 357, (1969)21 PLO (Karachi)376,  (1968) 2O DLR 1171, (197</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Trade Marks</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Trade Marks Act</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;">(V of 1940)</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 2(1)(2)—Trade mark for use in respect of a limited area—perfectly valid.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The words within the ‘Provinces and the Capital of the Federation” mean any place within the Provinces and the Capital of the Federation.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is possible under the Act V of 1940 for a person to apply for the registration of a trade mark to be effective within a limited area if he is not interested in the trade in any other area.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>M/S Crescent Pak Soap and Oil Mills Vs. Deputy Registrar of Trade Marks, Chittagong (1965)17 DLR (SC)163.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 2(1)(e)—</strong> Use of ‘Camel’ mark or design in one kind of product does not deprive another of its use as a mark or design unless it is proved that such will cause confusion in relation to a particular kind. of goods of long standing—By registration of a design of camel it cannot be said that none else can use it as a design.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Merely because the picture of a camel is incorporated as a part of a trade mark registered for other kinds of products, it cannot be said that thereby a person had acquired any proprietary right in the design of device of a camel even when used without any qualifying words or other embellishments.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Unless one can establish a proprietary right as to the mark or design of a camel by a sufficiently long user it cannot be said that it had become associated with the products manufactured by such a person and that if anyone else uses it with other qualifying features there would still be a chance of the customer or user being confused.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Simply because the design of a camel formed part of a mark registered earlier, it cannot be said that no one else can use that design or device as a part of its own trade mark coupled with other totally different words or designs in respect of goods of different nature.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>M/S Crescent Pak Soap and Oil Mills Vs. Deputy Registrar of Trade Marks, Chittagong (1965 17 DLR (SC) 163.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 6—Proviso—Trade mark in continuous use for a long period—Seven years elapsed since original registration— Removal from Register cannot be allowed.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In the application for registration filed on 31.8. 1942 it is stated that the trade mark is in use since 1914 and on that representation the respondent was given the registration. Thus the defendant’s respondent (Sadhana Aushadhalaya) obtained registration of the trade mark claiming user of the same for a period which would entitle him to the protection of the provisions of the proviso to section 6 of the Trade Marks Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The defendant (Sadhana Aushadhalaya) cannot claim any exclusive right to the use of the word “Saribadi” nor can the defendant claim any right to the exclusive use of the word ‘Salsa’. The combination of the words “Saribadi Salsa” is a coining of the defendant company. The defendant company is entitled to the exclusive use of the coined words “Saribadi Salsa” also on the ground that it had been in continuous use by the defendant company since 1914, according to the provisions of the proviso to section 6. Further seven years have passed since the original registration of the mark and as such the defendant company is also entitled to the protection afforded by section 24 of the Trade Marks Act as no acceptable case has been made out of any fraud perpetrated by the defendant company in having the trade mark registered nor does the trade mark offend against the provisions of section 8 of the Trade Marks Act<em>. (Abdullah J.) </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Natun Chandra Sinha Vs. Sadhana Aushadholaya (1968)20 DLR 289.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Proviso and section 24: Trade Mark in continuous use for a long period.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Seven years elapsed since original registration Removal from Register cannot be allowed. <em>Na-</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Natun Chandra Sinha Vs. Sadhana Aushadhalaya Ltd., Dacca, (1968) 20 DLR 289.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 6(1)(d), 10(2)—</strong> The appellant’s amended trade mark “Dentol” together with the portrait of the founder of Sadhana Ausadhalaya was advertised before acceptance with disclaimer.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The respondents objected to its registration on the ground of infringement of their trade marks consisting of words like “Dettol”“Dettolin” and “Dett” which were of the same description and were likely to create confusion in the minds of customers and also that it could not be registered concurrently under section 10(2) of the Act with or without any limitation.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held:</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">1. A condition or limitation that the composite trade mark should contain the portrait of Dr. Jogesh Chandra Ghose, etc. would obviate all possible confusion, if at all, and would be quite consistent in ‘view of the fact that both sets of goods are in concurrent use so far as Pakistan in concerned.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">2. The learned Deputy Registrar was not correct when he thought that any condition and limitation which, if imposed, would not prevent confusion and deception of the public.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">3. We are satisfied that the composite mark together with limitations as indicated may be registered under section 10(2) of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sadhana Ausadhalaya Vs. Reckitt Colman Chiswick (Overseas) Ltd. (1966) 18 DLR 595.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 6(1)(d)—</strong>The word ‘popular” in the present case though refers to quality of the goods yet not hit by section 6(1)(d), being registered as a trade mark with its surrounding settings along with the name of the company.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Trade Marks, Chittagong Vs. Popular Polish house (1969)21 DLR (SC) 114.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 6(1)(e)—</strong>The word “Sagar” has acquired sufficient distinctiveness to be registered as a trade mark.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A Bengali word remains a Bengali word even if it is written in English— The appellant further contended that at least some sort of limitation should be imposed to write the word “Sagar” in Bengali only but not in English.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held:</strong> There is no reason to impose limitation compelling the respondent to write the word “Saga?’ in Bengali only.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>The Singer Company Vs. Amjad Ali (1969) 21 DLR 415.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 8—</strong> Trade mark likely to cause deception or confusion though actual proof of such deception or confusion not forthcoming—Registration thereof shall be refused. The word ‘Livogen’ and the word Livatogen’ likely to cause confusion.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>M/s. Zenith Laboratory Pak. Ltd. Vs. M/s. British Drug houses Ltd., England, (1968)20 DLR 1171.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Secs. 8 and 10</strong>— Words used in two different trademarks are different but their mode of representation similar—No bar to registration.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Pakistan Medical Supplies Vs. MIs. Farbenfabriken Bayer AG. (1969) 21 DLR 945.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 8 and 10(1)—</strong>Registrar’s discretion to. register trademarks with conditions imposed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In a case where the Registrar finds himself unable to grant registration he may, in his discretion, permit registration of such a trade mark subject to such condition as he may consider. This is an enabling provision by which the Registrar in his discretion may grant registration by imposing condition. In doing so, he is to bear in mind the provisions of section 8 and section 10(1). He has also to remember as to whether the case in which such discretion is sought to be exercised in favour of the applicant it could claim honest concurrent use of the trade mark.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>M/s. Zenith Laboratory Pak. Ltd. Vs. M/s. British Drug houses Ltd., England, (1968)20 DLR 1171.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 8 and 10</strong>—Words used in two different trademarks are different but their mode of representation similar—No bar to registration.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The appellant applied to the Deputy Registrar, Trade Marks for registration of his trade mark consisting of the words “P.M.S.’ printed in “a letter cross device within an encircling border.” The respondent claims that the appellant’s trademarks should not be registered as the respondent uses a trade mark consisting of the word “Bayer” in a world famous “letter-cross device” which had been registered earlier and although the two marks “P.M.S.” and “Bayer” are different but the mode of representing them is common. So the respondent’s contention was that this will confuse and deceive the buyers who may purchase the product of “PMS” as that of “Bayer”.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held:</strong> In the absence of legal bar the Registrar is not entitled to impose a condition arbitrarily. He can impose such condition when it is necessary in view of the prohibitions imposed by the statute in respect of registration of trade mark. He can also refuse when reasons direct-him to do so and if an applicant finds that a condition has been illegally or unreasonably imposed on him, he is entitled to prefer an appeal to the High Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The trade mark “Bayer” consisting of live letters and that of “PMS” consisting of three letters are phonetically different and their visual resemblance is not such as would warrant imposition of a condition and there is no likelihood of the public being misled or confused. The two marks being clearly different, the appellant’s trade mark should be directed to be registered.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Pakistan Medical Supplies Vs. M/s. Farbenfabriken Bayer (1969) 21 DLR 945.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 8(a)—</strong> The words “Sagar” and “Singer” are two dissimilar words and will create no confusion if registered as trademarks.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held:</strong> That the word “Singer” is an English word and word “Sagar” is a Bengali word and a Pakistani purchaser is not likely to confuse the Bengali word “Sagar” for the English word “Singer”. Regard being had to the nature of the customer, the article in question and the intelligence of the persons likely to purchase such machines, there can be no likelihood of confusion as between “Singer” and “Saga?’. Moreover, the ideas revealed by the two words are dissimilar. The English word “Singer” connotes one who sings and the Bengali word “Sagar” means “sea”.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>The Singer Company Vs. Amjad Ali (1969) 21 DLR 415.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Respondent’s (which is carrying on its business in Calcutta) goods not available in markets of Pakistan—Mere use of the trade mark by the respondent from an earlier date is no ground to hold that the similar trade mark of the appellant (carrying on business in Pakistan) will cause deception or confusion as contemplated in section 8(a) of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held:</strong> When the appellant applied for registration of his trade mark in 1953 the goods of the respondent were not available in the East Pakistan markets. In the circumstances there was no likelihood of “deception” or “confusion” as contemplated in section 8(a) of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">M/s. Bengal Friends Vs. M/s. Gour Benode Saha &amp; Co. (1969) 21 DLR (SC) 357.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Trade mark likely “to deceive” or “to cause confusion”—Determination of likelihood of deception or confusion—Test—Registration of trade mark can be refused only if already registered trade mark closely resembles one proposed for registration “for same goods or description of goods”—Two marks (“Jeep” with device of a motorcar) identical but one used in respect of motor vehicles whereas the other for threads and yams—Registration of trade mark, in circumstances, cannot be refused.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Kaiser Jeep Corporation Vs. Saber Saleem Taxgile Mills Ltd. (1969)21 PLO (Karachi)376.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Registration of trade mark—Party having prior user of trade mark in Pakistan preferred to party having prior international user but ‘no user in Pakistan.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Where a Pakistan party had been using mark ‘Nabisco’ in Pakistan but objection was raised by a firm to the Registration of the trade mark on the ground that the foreign firm had that trade mark in the international market for a long time prior to the date from which the applicant had been using it though it had not marketed its goods in Pakistan.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held:</strong> For the purposes of registration under the Act, the Tribunal should ordinarily consider the user in this country to which the Act applies. If the case of the appellant is considered on this view of the law, there is not a shred of evidence on the record to establish that the public or a common man in this country will in any way be deceived or confused while purchasing goods under the trade mark “Nabisco’ manufactured by the appellants. The respondents have no market of this trade mark in respect of any goods in this country. They have no reputation and as such there can possibly be no deception or confusion in the mind of the public f this country that the goods manufactured by the appellants belonged to the respondents. In these circumstances the respondents had not established a reputation for their mark upon which an opposition could be founded.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>SM Taufiq Vs. National Biscuit Co. PLD 1962 (WP) Karachi 355; PLR 1962 (2) WP 710. ( Wahiduddin, J).</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 10</strong>— In considering as to whether a confusion is likely to occur we have to bear in mind as to whether such a confusion would occur in the mind of a man of ordinary prudence.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>M/s. Zenith Laboratory Ltd. Vs. M/s. British Drug Houses Ltd., (1968) 2O DLR 1171.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Rectification of trademarks—Principle that dissimilarity in the first syllables of two words would eliminate chances of conflict between them cannot be generalized almost to the point of making it a dictum—Rules of English pronunciation can have no application in non-English speaking country—Test for determining similarity or cause of confusion discussed—Words ‘Saigon’ and ‘Daigon’ were, held closely similar both phonetically and visually as to cause confusion and deception.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Haji Abdul Rahim Vs. Abdul Wahid (1971) 23 DLR (Karachi) 25.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Trade mark—Colourable Limitation of,—</strong> Plaintiffs are manufacturers of batteries under registered trade mark,” 3 Stars’. Defendants were also found manufacturing the same goods under trade mark ‘5 Stars”, both marks being identical in get up, colour and design. The only difference is that the defendants branded their marks ‘5 Stars” instead of ‘3 Stars” of the plaintiff. Further it appeared that the defendants were making all out efforts to resemble their mark with that of the plaintiffs.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held:</strong> Defendant’s goods are colourable limitation of registered trade mark ‘3 Stars” and are likely to deceive customers and cause confusion in course of trade and in circumstances amounted to flagrant infringement of registered trade mark.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Pak. Battery Manufacturing Co. Karachi Vs. Md. Hussain (1970)22 DLR (WP) 118.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Deceptive or misleading trade mark— Tests of—The only test that has to be applied when the Court considering a case under section 10 is the test of identity or resemblance. Even if the applicant could establish a long user, if the respondent could establish no user at all, if there was resemblance between the Marks of the applicant and the respondent, and if there was likelihood of deception, and if the respondent was first in die field and had their Trade Mark registered, the applicant’s Trade Mark could not be registered.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>New Light Chemical industries Vs. Registrar of Trade Marks PLO 1963 Dacca 75=PLR 1961 Dacca 256=13 DLR 657 (DB). (Akbar, .1),</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 10(l)—Applicability—Applies only where a party has registered trade mark for the same description of goods for which other party applies for registration.</strong> Section 10 applies only where any party has established that its trade mark has been registered fordescription of the goods for which the other party had made its application for registration.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">SM Taufiq Vs. National Biscuit Co. PLD 1962 (WP) Karachi 355 =PLR 1962 (2) WP 710. ( Wahiduddin. J).</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Criterion to follow is to ascertain whether a particular trade mark is likely to deceive or cause confusion.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Circumstances when the registration of trademarks should or should not be refused.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Aluminum Products Ltd. Vs. Registrar of Trade Marks. (1958) 1O DLR 251.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Where the marks are plainly calculated to lead to confusion and deception and the similarities are so close as to make it impossible to suppose that such marks were devised independently of each other, the Registrar of Trade Marks would be justified in refusing to register a trade mark. <em>   Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—“Alkacit” and “Alkaseltzer” are not in conflict for registration purpose—All aspects of a question while dealing with an application for registration should be considered and the Registrar is to act in a judicial manner.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>M/s.</em> <em>Pharmapak Laboratories Ltd. Vs. Deputy Registrar of Trade Marks, Chittagong (1967)19 DLR 99.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The words “Master Tailor Thread Brand” and Master Thread Ball Works” are different both visually and phonetically and as such the former can be registered.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held:</strong> The word ‘Master’ or the other words of the appellants’ marks and the words “Master Tailor” of the respondent appear to have no such resemblance as to cause confusion or deception. The meaning of the words and the devices are quite different, each having its own distinctiveness.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Master Thread Ball Works Vs. MA Karim (1969) 21 DLR 388.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Trade Mark—Commodities of two firms when identified by numerals, little difference in the numerals makes all the difference- and therefore, creates no confusion.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Pakistan Soap Factory, Chittagong Vs. Chittagong Soap Factory, Chittagong (1970)22 DLR (SC)400.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S.10(2)—</strong>Court not to interfere with the exercise of discretion by the Registrar unless he is patently wrong.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Alumininum Products Ltd. Vs. Registrar of Trade Marks. (1958) 10 DLR 251</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>—(See under section 2(1 )(2) in the case of Mis Crescent. Pak Soap and Oil Mills Vs. Deputy Registrar of Trade Marks, Chittagong, in 17 DLR (SC)163 above.)</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Phonetic similarity between trademarks—Limitation may be imposed on like trademarks so that no confusion may be caused by their concurrent use.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Where two sets of medicine had similar names, the Court put some restrictions on the use of the trade mark by one of them so as to obviate the chances of any confusion between the two goods and permitted them to be registered concuffently.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sadhano Ausadhalaya Vs. Reckitt Colman. PLD 1965 Dacca 41 —PLR 1965 Dacca 708 (DB). (Asir, I).</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Stay of suit—When may be granted on application under the sub-section.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It cannot be laid down as a general principle that whenever an application is made to the Registrar under section 10(2) of the Trade Marks Act, the Court must stay its hands to enable the party so applying to obtain an order from the Registrar. There may be cases in which an application for stay of the suit may be sought merely for the purpose of delaying the Suit by making an application to the Registrar under section 10(2). This application may be frivolous and devoid of any substance and may have been made after the institution of this suit. when the defendant may have found his position difficult and untenable. To stay the suit in this situation and to wait for the decision of the Registrar which may sometimes take years, would be denial of justice. It may also be noted that the decision by the Registrar in any case is not final and is subject to an appeld to the High Court. Then there may be cases which may involve the determination of other issues apart from those arising under section 10(2) which could only be tried by the Civil Court. The stay of the suit, therefore, cannot be granted as a matter of course merely upon the presentation of an application by the defendant before the Registrar particularly when that application is made after the institution of this suit. The question whether stay should be granted must be answered with reference to the facts of each case. It is a matter within the discretion of the Court and the discretion has to be exercised in the interest of justice. One of the considerations which may determine an exercise of that discretion is the time when the application for stay is made. Another factor to consider would be whether the application for stay is bona fide. Yet another consideration would be the nature of the case itself.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>N. B. Philip Vs. Electric Lamp Manufactures of Pak. PLD 1962 Karachi 191 =PLR 1963(1) WP 510. (Faruqui, J).</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Trade name used for long time— Party acquires a right to make it its trade mark—Limitation placed on use of Trade Mark—When High Court may interfere with discretion of Registrar.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Shipton Tea Company applied for Registration of “Shipton Tea Company” as its Trade Mark, “Lipton Ltd.” objected. The Registrar holding that although the word “Shipton” had been coined with an ulterior motive yet since the Shipton Tea Co. had been using the name as its trading style for a number of years to the knowledge of Lipton without objection to it, accepted the application for the registration of the trade mark subject to conditions in the following terms.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The applicant’s mark to proceed to registration only after the words “Shipton Tea Company” within the circumference of the inner and outer circles have been deleted and the trading style given at the hooting of the various panels of the label is reduced so much in size as to make it lose its conspicuity by ceasing to catch the eye. Further that if and when these labels are printed, the trading style should not e shown in colour different from that of the rest of be descriptive matter.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held</strong>: The exercise of the discretion by theRegistrar under sub-section 2 of section 10 of the Trade Marks Act, 1940 should not be interfered with without sufficient reasons for doing so. The reasons interference in this case were that the discretion I been exercised partly unreasonably and partly ‘ the effect of over reaching the limitations it had been created on the rights of Lipton Limby the acquisition of a right by Shipton Tea to freely use its trade name, The conditions imposed were unreasonable because they aimed snapping the connection between the goods and their manufacturer, or at least at creating an obscurity inconsistently with the object of a trade mark, which is to ensure easy identification of goods with reference to their origin. The limitations were over reached because, whereas Shipton Tea Co was entitled without registering its trade mark to freely use its trade name and to print it in any colour it liked on its goods, so long as its labels did not in any other respect infringe the trademarks of Lipton Ltd., after Its registration the name would be partly suppressed by its deletion from the most important place in the trade mark and partly obscured by the flattening effect of reduced size of panels of labels and turned down colour scheme<em>. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdul Gani Vs. Registrar of Trade Marks PLD 1961 (WP) Karachi 158=1961 (1) KLR 29=PLR 1961 (2) WP 608. (Qadeeruddin I).</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 12 and 13—Disclaimer—Trade mark ‘Saribadi Salsa’ is for the whole of it, and not for any part—No disclaimer as regards the use of ‘Saribadi’ is necessary</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The right to use it being open to all Sadhana Aushadhalaya (appellant) has a right of using the trade mark ‘Saiibadi Salsa’ to the exclusion of all others. The question is whether a disclaimer is necessary to declare that the Sadhana Aushadhalaya has no exclusive right to the use of the word ‘Saribadi’: The answer is Sadhana Aushadhalaya has no exclusive right to use the word ‘Saribadi.’ This is quite clear and Nutun Chandra Sinha (respondent) will not be prejudiced if such a disclaimer, as prayed for by him, is not added. A disclaimer is added to define a right arising out of registration in a doubtful case.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Even without such a disclaimer the respondent (Nutun Chandra Sinha) will be entitled to such rights as will be ensured by a disclaimer. On the other hand, its addition may give rise to an impression that a disclaimer is the remedy whenever someone seeks to make an extravagant claim. To create such a situation will be most undesirable commercially<em>. (A. S. Chowdhury, J., Mahmud Hossain, J.) </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sadhana Aushadhalaya Vs. Nutun Chandra Sinha (1968) 20 DLR 92.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 13 and 24—Disclaimer can be entered into the register at any time—Does not affect the validity of the trade mark— Nor its right to remain on the register</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The entry of a disclaimer on the Register does not necessarily affect the validity of the registration of the trade mark as contemplated by section 24 of the Trade Marks Act nor does it affect the right of the trade mark to remain on the register. Therefore, a disclaimer can always be entered on the register provided the circumstances in section 13 are fulfilled. (Abdullah, J.)</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Natun Chandra Sinha Vs. Sadhana Aushadhalaya (1968)20 DLR 289.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>[See under sec. 6 in the case of Nutun Chandra Sinha Vs. Sadhana Aushadhalaya, in 20 DLR 289 above.]</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 13 and 14—</strong> Disclaimer can be entered into the register at any time—Does not affect the validity of the trade mark—Nor its right to remain on the register.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The entry of a disclaimer on the register does not necessarily affect the validity of the registration of the trade mark as contemplated by section 24 of the Trade Act nor does it affect the right of the Trade Mark to remain on the register. Therefore, a disclaimer can always be entered on the register provided the circumstances mentioned in section 13 are fulfilled.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Natun Chandra Sinha Vs.</em> <em>Sadhana Aushadhalaya Ltd. Dacca, (1968) 20 DLR 289</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 14—</strong> Section not independent of other provisions of Act—Acceptance or refusal of Registrar to be determined in accordance with provisions of Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Kaiser Jeep Corporation Vs. Saber Saleem Textile Mills Ltd.; (1969)21 PLD (Karachi) 376</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 14 and 15(1)—</strong> Application for registration of trade marks if on the face of it satisfies the authority—should not be refused without objection from any quarter.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The proviso to section 15 lays down that in a case of the present nature if it appears to him that it is expedient by reason of any exceptional circumstances, he may cause the application to be advertised before acceptance.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In the present case the application has been refused without any objection from any quarter. The power of refusal on an application before advertisement can be exercised only when the trade mark mark sought to be registered does not, on the face of it, satisfy any of the the conditions laid down in section 6 of the Act. The discretion vested under section 14 cannot be exercised arbitrarily.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Trade Marks, Chittagong Vs. M/s. Popular Polish House (1969) 21 DLR (SC) 114.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 15—Rules framed by the Government prescribing time limit, are enforceable.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Section 84 of the Trade Marks Act authorizes the Central Government to make rules for prescribing the times or periods required by the Act and section 15 merely says that the notice of objection must be filed within the time prescribed, which means prescribed by the Rules. Rules 30 to 35 prescribe the times within which the steps therein specified should be taken.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>M/s. Crescent Pak Soap and Oil Mills Vs. Deputy Registrar of Trade Marks. Chittagong (1965) 17 DLR (SC) 163.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 16(1)—Objection as to the bar of limitation by lapse of time not being raised, the inference is that it is waived.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It was contended that since no objection was filed or evidence produced either within the time prescribed by the rules or in the prescribed manner the inference is there was no objection at all in the eye of the law to the application of the appellant and the same should, therefore, under section 16(1) have been accepted as a matter of course.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held</strong>: This contention does not take into account the fact that the appellant not only did not protest before the Registrar of Trade Marks against the filing of the belated objection, but in fact waived this delay by filing his counter-statement. This amounted to submission to jurisdiction for, the provisions as to notice of opposition and filing of evidence are for the benefit of a party who may well choose to waive the irregularity and join issue on merits.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>M/s. Crescent Pak Soap and Oil Mills Vs. Deputy Registrar of Trade Marks. Chittagong (1965) 17 DLR (SC) 163.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 21, 22—Manufacturer marking trade mark on goods for the plaintiff— Goods disposed of by plaintiff in the market—Manufacturer is not user of trade.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Where the defendant was merely stamping the trade mark on the goods and the labels for the use of the plaintiffs. It is the plaintiffs who went out in the market and sold these goods under their names. It was held that the defendant manufacturer could not be held to have used the mark.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>N. V. Philips Vs. Electric Lamp Manufacturers of Pakistan Ltd. PLD 1962 (WP) Karachi 690. (</em>AS <em>Faruqui, J).</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 37(2<em>)—[</em></strong><em>Sec under section 10(2) in the case of MIs. Crescent Pak Soap and Oil Mills Vs. Deputy Registrar of Trade Marks, in 17 DLR (SC) 163 above.]</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 46(4), 23—.--Trade mark duly registered—’Suo motu’ notice by Deputy Registrar under S. 46(4)—Burden of proof of similarity with another trade mark is on Deputy Registrar—Long use and initial registration are factors to be considered.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Under s. 23 the registration of a Trade Mark is prima-facie evidence that it was validly registered. The burden of proof for rebutting that presumption is on those who question its validity. In this case, the burden has been on the Deputy Registrar himself. He has discharged it by. pointing out phonetic similarity, while conceding that there was no obvious visual likeness. The fact that the similarity on which he has now relied was not initially noticed by him, is a proof against its obviousness. His view, therefore, that there is transparent phonetic similarity is not an adequate rebuttal of the statutory presumption. The weakness of the rebuttal becomes more clear when it is noticed that the trade mark has remained on the Register for about seven years and no consumer or trader thought of any deceptive similarity during this long period.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Bengal Oil Mills Ltd. Vs. Deputy Registrar of Trade Marks PLD 1963 (WP) Karachi 920. (Qadeeruddin Ahmad, J).</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Secs. 74(1) and 76—</strong>Appeal seeking rectification of Register of Trade Marks Registrar of Trade Marks need not be impleaded as party. <em>Haji Abdul Rahim Vs. Abdul Wahid (1971) 23 DLR (Kar) 25.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 84</strong>—[<em>See under section 15 in the case of MIs. Crescent Pak Soap Vs. Deputy Registrar of Trade Marks, in 17 DLR (SC) 163 above..]</em><span id="pastemarkerend"></span></p></div></div>
2415	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Trade Marks Rules</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  17 DLR (SC)163, </p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Trade Marks </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Trade Marks Rules</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rules 30-35</strong>—[<em>See in the case of Crescent Pak. Soap and Oil Mills Vs. Deputy Registrar of Trade Marks. in 17 DLR (SC)163 above.]</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Rule 76</em></strong><em>—Registrar of Trade Marks has got authority to grant an extension of time under rule 76 of the Trade Marks Rules. Crescent Pak. Soap and Oil Mills Vs. Deputy Registrar of Trade Marks, in 17 DLR (SC)163 above.]</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—No express order of extension of time necessary.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">There is nothing in rule 76 to indicate that an express order is necessary for extending the time. The mere fact, therefore, that the opposition was admitted after the lapse of the prescribed time and served upon the applicant by the Registrar himself indicates that the Registrar condoned the delay.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Cresent Pak. Soap and Oil Mills Vs. Deputy Registrar of Trade Marks (1965) 17 DLR (SC) 163.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2416	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Trade Organization Ordinance, 1951</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 294, (1968) 20 DLR (SC) 355, </p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Trade Organization </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><em> </em></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Trade Organization Ordinance</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;">(XLV of 1951)</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 8(1)(b)—</strong>Government is Empowered to direct any company to amend its memorandum of association by deleting any of its articles, etc. as provided in section 8(1)(b) of the Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Bangladesh represented by the Secretary, Ministry of Commerce, Sectt. (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 294.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 12—Does not affect High Court’s writ jurisdiction,</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Section 12 of the Trade Organizations Ordinance, 1951 cannot take away the jurisdiction of the High Court under Article 98 so far as the correction of the acts of the Registrar of Joint Stock Companies is concerned.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mohammad Idrish Vs. East Pakistan Timber Merchants (1968) 20 DLR (SC) 355.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 24——When recognition should not be given—</strong>Knowing that the parties were challenging each other’s right in various Jkigations then pending in the civil courts, the Registrar ought not to have taken any step to recognize either the one or the other group pending the decision of the disputes or done anything which might prejudice the claims of the rival parties in those pending litigations.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The order of the Registrar could have been set aside on the short ground that pending litigations between the parties he should not have granted the impugned certificates.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mahammak Idrish Vs. East Pakistan Timber Merchants Group (1968) 20 DLR (SC) 355.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2417	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Trade Union Act (V of 1965)</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1977) 29 DLR (SC) 117, (1969) 21 DLR 18, (1969) 21 DLR 529, (1969)21 DLR 435,  (1976)28 DLR (SC) 190, (1969)21 DLR 18</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Trade Union </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong>Trade Union Act (V of 1965)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 2(n)—Trade Union of the employees—Constitution of—for collective bargaining.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The right of the employees of an establishment to collective bargaining for their legitimate interest is one of the corner-stones of modern legislations. A trade union of employees has been recognized as a very effective vehicle of such collective bargaining. The East Pakistan Trade Union Act, 1965 which was enacted on repealing the Trade Union Act of 1926 has embodied provisions for constitution of a Trade Union of workers as well as of employers primarily for the purpose of regulating the relation between workers and employers or workers and workers or between employers and employers as wills appear from the definition of a Trade Union as given in section 2(n) of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mohiuddin Khan Vs. Pakistan River Steamers Ltd. (1977) 29 DLR (SC) 117.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Registered Trade Union and recognized Trade Union—their object.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The Trade Union Act makes provision for registered Trade Unions and also for what has been termed in the Act of a recognized Trade Union. The object of the Act as recited in the preamble of the Act is for providing for the registration and recognition of trade unions and in certain respects, for defining the law relating to registered trade unions and recognized trade unions and for matters connected therewith.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mohiuddin Khan Vs. Pakistan River Steamers Ltd. (1977)29 DLR (SC) 117.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—<strong>Recognized Trade Union and registered Trade Union—Difference between the two.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">From the recital in the preamble of the Act it is clear that the legislative intent was that both recognized trade unions as well as registered trade unions which were not recognized should have functions under the Act. A recognized Trade Union must necessarily be a registered Trade Union but a recognized Trade Union appears to have some special advantage in the matter of negotiation and conclusion of agreement with the employer in certain cases, which is .not enjoyed by a registered Trade Union, if not recognized.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mohiuddin Khan Vs. Pakistan River Steamers Ltd. (1977)29 DLR (SC) 117.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 2(n) and (o)—Difference in meaning of the terms ‘Workers’ and “Trade Union” in Act V of 1965 and in Act XVI of 1926.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The expression “Trade Unions Act, 1926” was wider, inasmuch as there could be a combination of workmen and employers for the purpose of constituting a Trade Union, but in the present Act there can be a combination of only workers or employers but not of workers and employers.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Manager, Glaxo Laboratories Ltd. Vs. General Secretary, Glaxo Employees (1969) 21 DLR 18.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 10(2)—</strong>The petitioner (a registered trade union) served strike notice upon the employer—The employer subsequently withdrew the registration— Such withdrawal of registration will not invalidate the strike notice.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The Conciliation Officer was not correct in holding that the strike notice had no validity on account of the withdrawal of the registration, although he is empowered under the first proviso to section 5 (1) of the Labour Disputes Act to satisfy himself as to the validity of a notice of strike before holding conciliation proceeding. Even if no order slaying the operation of the order of withdrawal of registration had been made by the Labour Court, the legal position would not have been different inasmuch as the strike notice was given at a time when the petitioner was a registered Trade Union.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>General Secretary Employees Union Wapda Vs. Government of East Pak. (1969) 21 DLR 529</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 13—Distinctive marks of registered Trade Union.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A registered Trade Union has been given under section 13 of the Trade Union Act, 1965 the status of a juristic person having a perpetual succession with power to acquire and dispose of property and to contract.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mohiuddin Khan Vs. Pakistan River Steamer (1977) 29 DLR (SC) 117.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. (15(d)—Functions which a Trade Union discharges.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">From the provisions in clauses (c) and (d) of s. 15 of the Act it is clear that one of the main objectives of a registered Trade Union is to undertake the prosecution or defense of any legal proceedings for the purpose of securing or protecting any right arising out the relation of any member of the Trade Union to his employer and also for conducting labour disputes on behalf of the Trade Union or any of its members.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mohiuddin Vs. PRS Ltd. (1977)29 DLR (SC) 117.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">— Dispute raised by some workers on behalf of whole body of the workers not maintainable unless such approach is made by a recognized <em>Trade Union. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Manager, Swiss Boring Overseas Corporation Ltd. Vs. Shamsul Huq (1969)21 DLR 435. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 35</strong>—Officer of recognized Trade Union is entitled to negotiate with employer on matters of employment, etc. and as such he is an officer within the meaning of s. 35.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Bangla Tea Estate Vs. Staff Association (1976)28 DLR (SC) 190.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 49(2)—</strong>Registration of a union affected under Act XVI of 1926 is to be treated as registered under Act of 1965.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">An action taken, namely the registration under repealed Act will also be deemed to be an action taken under the new Act so long as it is not proved that the union as constituted cannot be registered under the present Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Manager, Glaxo Laboratories (Pak.) Ltd. Vs. General Secretary, Glaxo Employees (1969)21 DLR 18.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2418	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Trade Union Act (XVI of 1926)</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1968)20 DLR 140, (1966) J8DLR 45, (1968)20 DLR 140,  (1967)19 DLR (SC) 18</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Trade Union </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Trade Union Act (XVI of 1926)</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Recognition granted cannot be revoked unilaterally.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Under the Trade Union Act XVI of 1926 if a recognition was granted to a labour union, registrar: lion of the recognition by the Registrar was not essential to the recognition, and such recognition could not be unilaterally withdrawn.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>EPR W. League Vs. Chairman, East Pakistan. Rly. Board (1968)20 DLR 140.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 11(3)—</strong> Appeal—Limitation—Appeal under sub-section (3) of s. 11—To be treated as suit— Word but deemed to be or treated as suits—Appeal under s. ii, Trade Unions Act, 1926—Covered by s. 14(1), Limitation Act, 1908—Time spent before wrong Court excluded in computing period of limitation.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">General Secretary, P. W. R. Union (Workshop), Lahore Vs. The Registrar, Trade Unions and Another, (1969)21 PLD (Lahore) 1080.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 22(2)—</strong>Industrial dispute between the employers and the employees in the context of the Trade Union Act must be one which is between the employers and the workmen under the employers.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The mere calling of the employees by itself without reference to the employers is not sufficient for the purpose of the qualification of the officers under section 22(2) of the Trade Unions Act. The Industrial Disputes Ordinance and the Trade Unions Act must be read together so as to determine as to whether a particular Union represents workmen of a particular industry for the purpose of raising an in. dustrial dispute.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Chittagong Mercantile Employees’ Association Vs. Chairman, Industrial Court (1966) J8DLR 45. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 28B [and S. 49(2)]—</strong>Considering the facts of the present case with reference to the provisions of the 1965 Act (i. e. East Pakistan Trade Union Act) even if the petitioner (i. e. EPRW Employees League) was granted le. gal recognition by the 1960 Ordinance, that recognition has ceased to exist with the enactment of the East Pakistan Trade Union Act of 1965 and the repeal of the 1926 Act unless and until it is saved by the provisions of section 49(2) of the 1965 Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>EPR W. League Vs. Chairman E Pak Rly. Board (1968)20 DLR 140.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 28D</strong>— Trade Union ceased to be a recognized Union—Possesses no <em>locus standi</em> to raise an industrial dispute.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A Union having ceased to occupy the character of a recognized Union, has no <em>locus standi,</em> either to raise an industrial dispute, on behalf of the members, or to take it to the Industrial Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In the instant case the position was that even if the amended provisions of the Trade Unions Act contained in Chapter Ill-A could not be invoked by the employers then also the duration of the agreement having expired, the appellant Union lost its capacity to represent the workers for the purpose of raising an industrial dispute. It’s only right conceivable could be, as a registered Union, to represent a workman who may be a party to an industrial dispute, by virtue of section 34 of the Industrial Dispute Ordinance, 1959. But to attract that provision, a “dispute” requires to have been raised by a workman himself and not by the Union on his behalf.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Chittagong Mercantile Employees’ Association Vs. Chairman, Industrial Court (1967)19 DLR (SC) 18.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2419	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Transfer of Agricultural Land Act (XXXIII of 1951)</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1969) 21 DLR 918</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Transfer of Agricultural Land </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Transfer of Agricultural Land Act (XXXIII of 1951)</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 4—</strong> If by specific agreement buyer agrees to take necessary steps for obtaining permission he cannot later on say that ii is seller’s duty to obtain permission.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Purnendu Kumar Das Vs. Hiran Kumar Das, (1969) 21 DLR 918.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2420	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Transfer of Property Act 1882</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p align="center" style="text-align:center"><b><u><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Transfer ofProperty Act (IV of 1882)</span></u></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 2(c)—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The doctrineof merger contained in section 111 of the Transfer of Property Act is subjectto section 2(c) which makes it inapplicable to leases created before the Actcame into force. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Tajim AliVs. Saijuddin Khan (1954) 6 DLR 25.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 3—”</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Actionableclaim” includes existing debts payable in future or assignments of benefitsunder contracts for the supply of future goods. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Kazi AbdulAli Vs. Nurul Amin (1955) 7 DLR 406.</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—The words“conditional or contingent” mean that in case of debts or benefits accruingconditionally or contingently the immediate right to recover by action does notarise until the condition has been fulfilled or the contingency has occurred.<i>    Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—The truetest of determining the nature of the claim sought to be assigned should be tosee that the claim when it does accrue partakes of the character of a debt or abeneficial interest in movable property not in the possession, either actual orconstructive, of the claimant which can be recovered by an action. <i>     Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Beneficialinterest in movable property—Right to claim the benefit of a contract.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Right toclaim the benefit of a contract for future delivery of goods sold is abeneficial interest in movable property’ within the definition of actionableclaim and as such assignable. <i>   Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—A enteredinto a contract with B to do certain works; he also entered into a contractwith C under which C agrees to finance A in the execution of his contract workson condition that his advances would be a first charge on the bills due pluscertain interest.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Held:</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> What Apurported to assign was the right only to claim payment for works performedunder the contract. This was not merely a right to sue for breach of contractbut was an actionable claim. <i>  Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Attestation—Personalacknowledgement of signature: </span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>A personal acknowledgement of signature ormark as regards the execution of a deed by an executor within the meaning ofthe section may be either express or may even be inferred from conduct and itis sufficient if it is an acknowledgement of the execution of the deed. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Hari KissanPandey Vs. Nageswari Debi (1956) 8 DLR 65.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Validattestation: </span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>It is sufficient for valid attestation, if the attesting witnessesreceived acknowledgement from the executants of the deed that he put hissignature or mark on the deed though the attesting witnesses themselves did notsee him do it. <i>   Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Registrationis notice when the document is compulsorily registrable.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The doctrineof constructive notice by reason of registration applies only in the case ofdocuments which are compulsorily registrable. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>NagendraChandra Vs. Purameswar Roy (1957) 9 DLR 476.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Constructivenotice</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Notice ofregistration of sale deed is a constructive notice unless proof is given toshow that there was no such notice. <i>  Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Whatever isnotice enough to excite the attention of a man of ordinary prudence and calledfor further enquiry is, in equity, notice of all facts to the knowledge ofwhich an enquiry suggested by such notice and prosecuted with due diligencewould have led. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Dula Mia Vs.Haji Md. Ibrahim (1956) 8 DLR 616.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Registrationa constructive notice<i>. </i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>HochenaddiSk. Vs. Esmail Sikdar (1957) 9 DLR 294.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Aregistered transfer amounts to a notice. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>JaminiMosahar Vs. Md. Majibar Rahman (1953) 5 DLR 22.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—TheTransfer of Property Act not being in force in the region formerly known as thePunjab, the state of the law even after the 1927 amendment of section 3 remainsthe same, viz, that registration by itself does not amount to notice; thequestion of notice is one of fact to be determined on the circuinstances ofeach case. <i>1956 PLR (Lah) 1840.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Wherelicensee is permitted to erect permanent structure and thereafter allowed tocontinue to enjoy the same—License becomes irrevocable. A mud-wall hut is apermanent structure. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Md. AhsanullahVs. Etwari Mia (1962) 14 DLR 776.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—“A personis said to have notice”— When duty to make enquiry is imposed on purchaser ofproperty having tenants on it.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>It wascontended that if a tenant be in possession of land which is transferred it isthe duty of the purchase&amp; to make an enquiry from the tenant as to thenature and incidents of his title.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Held:</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> Immovableproperty in a town or an agricultural estate may have hundreds or eventhousands of tenants on it. ft cannot be the duty of a person who purchaseslarge property to make an inquiry from every one of the tenants of the propertyas to any agreements relating to the property which he may possess.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>A duty tomake enquiry would arise only if there be some circumstance which puts thepurchaser on enquiry. That tenants are in possession of the property which ispurchased is not a fact which by itself will put the purchaser on enquiry, forthis may be and will probably be the normal incident of the property purchased.Property may be in the possession of occupancy tenants, or it may consist ofonly the rent-receiving interest.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Possessionwhich is prima fade lawful does not call for an enquiry. If, however, a personwas in possession without any apparent title, or if the explanation given aboutthe title of such person by the vendor was unsatisfactory there would be goodgrounds for making further enquiry. The purchaser cannot be penalized unless hehas somehow failed in his duty and his duty would not arise unless there issomething in the circumstances which puts a person of ordinary prudence onenquiry. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Abdur Razzakhowlader</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'><i>Vs. Sk.
