Datta (1954) 6 DLR 45.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Refund of the excess paid.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Where there has been excess payment over double the principal, themortgagor on the application of the rule of accounting and refund laid down insection 76(h) of the Transfer of Property Act can ask for a refund of theexcess paid whether or not there was any contract that the usufruct would beset off against interest or interest and a specified portion of the principal. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Keramat Ullah Vs. Manindra Ch. Dana (1954) 6 DLR 45</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 82—Contribution to mortgage debt—Not against mortgagee.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Section 82 applies to mortgagors inter se and gives one mortgagor aright to have the other property contribute to the discharge of the mortgagedebt. This right cannot be availed of against mortgagee or auction purchaser. <i>54CWN (DR-2) 287.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 83—No deposit, when necessary</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Section 83 has no application when by reason of section 26 GBT Act theproperty is free from liability.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>All that section 83 of the Transfer of Property Act says is that theamount remaining due on the mortgage may be deposited. (1981)33DLR11.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 92—Subrogation—</span></b><span style='line-height:115%;Cambria","serif";'>Insurance Company can be subrogated in theposition of the insured and thereby become vested with the right of the latterto sue the person liable originally to the insured. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Trans Oceanic Steamship Vs. All that is required by thesection is that the payment either of the entire sums Secured by the bond orsuch portion as may be outstanding at the time, provided it puts an end to theright to the mortgagee under the bond, and redeems the mortgage in full, willgive rise to a right of subrogation. <i>55 CWN (3 DR) 15.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 95—One of several mortgagors— What connotes</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Section 95 has by Act XX of 1929 been amended in such a way thatsections 92 and 95 of the Act, as they now stand make it clear that the rightof the co-mortgagor redeeming is the “same right as the mortgagee whosemortgage he redeems may have against the mortgagor” occurring in section 92 ofthe Act. “One of several mortgagors” in section 95 means one of several personsinterested in the equity of redemption. <i>55 CWN (3 DR) 15.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—S.100—Charge—Registration of document—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>creating a, when necessary— Unregistered document creating a charge wherethe amount involved is over Rs. 100/- not admissible. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Abdur Razzak liowladar Vs. Sh. Muhammad Shaft (1960) 12 DLR 395.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Charge as distinguished from mortgage.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>A charge comes into existence when property of one person is by act ofparties or operation of law made security for the payment of money to anotherand the transaction does not amount to mortgage. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Abdur Razzak Howladar Vs. Sh. Muhammad Shaft (1962) 14 DLR (SC) 119.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 101—Two mortgages held by same person—Merger of mortgages only whenthey are intended to be so treated.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>A merger of estates takes place when two estates held in the same legalright become united in the same person. Where the capacity in which a person inpossession of the mortgagee’s right is something quite different from thecapacity in which he is in possession of the equity of redemption, the merefact that the two capacities are united in the same physical person cannotresult in a merger. But merger can be held to have taken place only by provingthat the person in whom both the rights vest had intended to treat both therights as one, and not otherwise<i>. Gula Jan Vs. Sahib Gul. PLD 1963 (WP)Peshawar 1 I0=PLR 1964(2) WP 900. (Daud, J).</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Rule of merger.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Section 101 deals only with mortgages and charges; it is inapplicable toa case where a right of rcconveyancc having been reserved by a vendor, thatright is subsequently sold by the vendor to the vendee but this does notnecessarily mean that where see- lion 101 does not apply, the rule of mergershould be applied. The section as it states makes non- merger the rule, andconsequently merger an exception. <i>(1952) PLR (Lah) 196.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 105—Tenant-at-will liable to pay compensation and not rent.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The designation “tenant-at-will” though gives the impression of atenant, it lacks the incidents of an ordinary tenancy, for, a tenant-at-will isnot liable to pay any rent and there being no question of demise or lease inhis case he is not liable for mesne profits or damages like a trespasserbecause his occupation is permissive; but he is liable to pay compensation forsuch USC and occupation<i>. </i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Rai Mohan Chowdhury Vs. Tejendra Lal Roy (1954) 6 DLR 577.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Nowhere in the Transfer of Property Act a tenant-at-will is recognizedas a lessee. Section 105 recognizes only a lease for a certain time, express orimplied, that is periodic leases or leases in perpetuity. </span><span style='Cambria","serif";'> <i>Ibid.</i></span><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Sections 105 and 106</span></b><span style='line-height:115%;Cambria","serif";'>—Purpose of the lease will determinewhether a lease will be governed by the BT Act or the TP Act.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Where the purpose for which a lease was granted was for residential andshop purposes the main fact that part of the lease-hold was agricultural wiltnot take it out of the scope of the Transfer of Property Act, the principlebeing that the purpose of the lease will determine whether a lease will begoverned by the BT Act or the TP Act. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Ramani Mokan Mozumdar Vs. Jasodha KamarNath (1959)11 DLR 253.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Lease—The English rule that a conveyance to operate as a lease mustreserve reversion to the lessor has no application to the Transfer of PropertyAct. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Mohsin and Tahir Vs. Firoze Nana Ghuiam Ali (1958) 10 DLR (WP) 45.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 105—Lease and license—Line of demarcation</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The line of demarcation between a lease and a license will sometimes bevery thin. A lease is a transfer of an interest in immovable property.Ownership of physical property consists of a number of rights and the owner ofsuch property when he creates a lease, transfers to the lessee a part of therights of ownership. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Abdullah Bhai Vs. Ahmad Din (1964) 16 DLR (SC) 169</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—The right of ownership as well as the rights of which it is composedare rights in rem and not in personam and by the lease a right in rem istransferred to the lessee. On the other hand, a “license” will appear from itsdefinition in section 52 of the Easements Act as merely a competence to dosomething which except for this permission would be unlawful. It does notconfer any rights in physical property. There is in the case of a license onlya personal agreement between the licensor and the licensee whereby the licensoragrees not to interfere with the doing of particular acts on property which isin his possession. No right in rem passes to the licensee. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The Criterion for distinguishing between a lease and a license issimple, i.e., whether any right in immovable property itself, a right in rem,has passed to the person concerned. But the determination of this question maybe difficult in the circumstances of a particular case. Where there is adocument the evidence will have to be considered with due regard to theprovisions of sections 91 and 92 of Evidence Act, 1872. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Abdulah Bhai Vs Ahmed Din (1964) 16 DLR (SC) 169.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Government servant occupying Government quarter allotted to him isneither a licensee nor his possession is permissive like the possession of atenant-at-will—He is a lessee from month to month.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Md. Aboo Abdullah Vs. Province of East Pakistan (1970) 22 DLR 392.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Lease and license—Lease creates limited interest in immovable propertywhich is both heritable and transferable—Licence does not create any interestin property; so it is neither heritable nor transferable<i>. </i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Mianjan Ali Vs. Province of East Pakistan (1970) 22 DLR 235.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Ss. 105 and 106</span></b><span style='line-height:115%;Cambria","serif";'>—The essential elements constituting aicase, arc the following; (a) the right must be one as to immovable property;(b) the right must be that of enjoyment of immovable property; (c) there mustbe a transfer of such right; (d) the right of transfer is an interest inproperty; (c) the transfer must be made for a certain time, express or implied,or in perpetuity; (1) the transfer must be one for consideration; (g) theconsideration must be of the particular kind namely, premium or rent, asdefined by the section, either or both of them. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Abdus Sattar &amp; Ors. Vs. Suresh Chandra Das (1980) 32 DLR (AD) 170.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Termination of a lease on quit notice—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Right of occupation is a personal one and cannot create any interest inthe land—This right ceases with the death of either of the parties and hencenot heritable. </span><span style='Cambria","serif";'>   <i>Ibid.</i></span><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 106—Lease for a manufacturing purpose—Notice to quit</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>A lease for the purpose of preparing ornaments being for a manufacturingpurpose, is to be determined by 6 months notice under section 106 of theTransfer of Property Act.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'><i>Mohsin and Tahir Vs. FirozeNana Ghulam Aly (1958) 10 DLR (WP) 45.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Notice to quit—Monthly tenancy.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>When a monthly tenancy commenced from a particular month, it means thatthe tenancy commenced from the 1st date of that month to be terminated with thelast date of every Bengali month. Notice was served on the 4th of Karuck, 1351asking the tenant to quit by the last date of the month of Kartick, 1951.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Held:</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> The notice served was a valid andsufficient notice. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Sri Nath Bhuiya Vs. Gopal Ch. Chattopadhyay (1955) 7 DLR 56</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Notice refused by addressee— Addresses fixed with knowledge of itscontents.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>If a person refuses a notice, he should be affected with knowledge of itcontents. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>If a letter reached the other party and was refused by him, he must beaffected within the knowledge of the letter which he refused to read. If thedefendant has minded to satisfy the court that he got no opportunity to get theletter, it was for him rather than for the plaintiff to call evidence to provewhat he asks the court to accept. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Byramji Hormosji Ghadialy Vs. Mst. Sarabai (1959) 11 DLR (WP) 165.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Monthly tenant—Holding over, has an accruing interest during every monththereafter as a tenant.</span></b><span style='line-height:115%;Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Under the Transfer of Property Act, a tenant holding any premises for amonth has an accruing interest during every month thereafter springing out ofthe original contract and as parcel of it, and oral agreement of leaseaccompanied by delivery of possession is valid for the first month and thereafterthe lessee continuing in possession with the assent of the lessor, expressed orimplied, becomes a tenant by holding over under section 106 of the Transfer ofProperty Act. Therefore, a tenant holding such a tenancy has an interest forthe month with an accruing interest during every month thereafter springing Outof the original contract and as parcel of it.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Such a tenancy is also transferable if allowed under the terms of thelease and under the provisions of law. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Gouri Bala Pal Vs. Kunja Lal Saha (1960) 12 DLR 37.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—On the death of the original tenant the tenancy devolves on the heirsand can only be terminated by a notice to quit. </span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;Cambria","serif";'> <i>Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—A pucca building consisting of 3 rooms and the land on which thebuilding stood and also the open space lying to the west of the building werelet Out and the demised lease-hold is described as consisting of ‘niskar’ land,etc., and the ‘pucca building’ for a term of two years with the option of onerenewal. The lessee failed to exercise the option of renewal and continued Lohold the tenancy as monthly tenant. The plaintiffs determined the tenancy by 15days’ notice to quit after the expiry of the month:</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='line-height:115%;Cambria","serif";'>Held: </span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;Cambria","serif";'>Thenotice to quit is valid, legal and sufficient; the tenancy being a monthlytenancy 15 days’ notice was quite sufficient. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Faizur Rahman Vs. Jogendra Mohan Das (1951) 3 DLR 115.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—An ex-tenant under East Bengal Nonagricultural Tenancy Act cannot claimthe benefit of service of notice. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Nihar Ranjan Pal Vs. Mst. Nurannessa Chowdhurani (1958) 10 DLR 472.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—No notice to quit is necessary as against a sub-tenant. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S<i>k. Md. Amir Ali Vs. Abdur Rahim (1957) 9 DLR 102. </i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—<b>Notice to quit</b>—The other incident of the tenancy which islacking in the case of a tenant-at- will is that a tenant-at-will is notentitled to any ejectment notice as in the case of other tenants and thelandlord may file an ejectment Suit straight away without serving any notice ofejectment on him. If a suit has to be filed against him, Article 139 of theLimitation Act will not apply but Article 144 will apply and this latterArticle also applies to a suit against a trespasser. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Rai Mohan Chowdhury Vs. Tejendra Lal Roy (1954)6 DLR 577.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Monthly tenant—15 days’ notice.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Where a non-agricultural land is held by a nonagricultural tenant asmonthly tenant the provisions of section 106 of T.P.Act will apply and thetenant will be entitled to 15 days’ notice for the purpose of a suit forejectment.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Bengal River Service Ltd. Vs. Sree. Muralidhar Ray (1955) 7DLR 525.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—The provisions in section 106 of the T.P.Act for 15 days noticeexpiring with the end of the month of the tenancy is one and the single rule oflaw and cannot be split up into two—one as to the length of the period ofnotice and the other terminating that period with the ending of the month ofthe tenancy.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'><i>Abdus Sattar Vs. Syed ShahaMd. Hassan Ali Quaderi (1956)8 DLR 316.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—The agreement was to the effect that three months notice will berequired to be served on the tenant for vacating the premises.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Held: The agreement about three months’ notice being contrary to section106, these provisions about 3 months’ notice is to be taken from the date ofservice of notice and after the expiry of three months the tenancy willterminate.<i>    Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—In terms of agreement a 3 months’ notice was served on 12.3.54 askingthe tenant to vacate the house on the expiry of the 1st. day of July, 1954.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Held:</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> This is a valid compliance with theagreement between the parties. Section 106 TP Act has no application in thiscase. <i>   Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—A notice to quit though not strictly accurate or consistent in itsstatements, may be effective, and should be construed not with a desire to findfault in the notice which would render it defective but on the principle thanit is better for a thing to have the effect than be void. <i>    Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Plaintiffs are entitled to get a decree for rent as under section 116of the Transfer of Property Act, defendants would be held to be tenant underplaintiffs by holding over after the termination of the lease. Settlement of anew lease in favour of a third party cannot affect defendants’ right which canonly be terminated by a valid notice under section 106, Transfer of PropertyAct. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Alimas Ullah Vs. Srish Ch. Dam (1951) 3 DLR 526; 1 PLR (Dac) 593.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—In the absence of a valid notice to quit the defendants who are tenantsby holding over arc liable to pay rent. <i>  Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Even supposing that the tenancy was terninated by a lease to a thirdparty then also defendant, though having no lawful title, are tenants  on sufferance and liable to pay rent. <i>    Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='line-height:115%;Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Notice to quit on or before a date, being the date on which tenancyexpires is a good notice.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>In the case of a monthly tenancy where it does not appear from what datethe tenancy commenced, a notice terminating the lease with the end of the monthfollowing is valid and legal. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Satish Ch. Pal Vs. Mst. Mazidan Begum (1958) 10 DLR 271.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Notice need not contain the date of the commencement of the tenancywhen evidence during trial clears the point. Monthly tenancy expires on themidnight of the 30th of each month. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Ramani Mohan Mozumdar Vs. Joshodha Kr. Nath (1959) 11 DLR 253.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—The lease in this case expired on the last day of the month. One monthsnotice given on 3rd August, 1954, and received by the tenant on 8th August1954, the regulating suit having been instituted on 13th November, 1954, washeld in order, not only because it did not contravene section 106, but alsobecause the suit had been instituted more than 3 months after notice ruling Outany possibility of prejudice on the score of the notice not having expired onthe last day of the month of tenancy. <i>1956 PLR (Lah) 112.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Denial of the title of—Forfeiture.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>In a suit for ejectment by landlords the denial of the title of theplaintiff would in law result in the forfeiture of the right of the leaseholdinterest of the defendants. Lessees whose tenancy is terminated by notice undersection 106 of the T.P. Act is estopped in an ejectment suit from setting uptitle subsequently acquired by them in the suit lands. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Bayza Bibi Vs. Debendra Lal Roy (1950)2 DLR 360.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—When the question is whether the lease was for dwelling purpose ormanufacturing purpose.—</span></b><span style='line-height:115%;Cambria","serif";'>Matters to be looked into.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>In order to decide whether a tenancy has been obtained for amanufacturing purpose, one must find the actual purpose for which the lease wasobtained. If a lease of some premises was obtained for the purpose of dwellingand the said premises had been used for manufacturing purpose, it cannot beheld that mere’ user of the building for manufacturing purpose would make thelease a lease for manufacturing purpose within the meaning of section 106 ofthe said Act. Conversely, in the absence of any other evidence to the contrary,a long user for a manufacturing purpose would constitute a good circumstantialevidence that the lease was obtained for such a purpose. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Shaikh Mahmudur Rahman Vs. Amulya Kumar Sarker (1967) 19 DLR 743.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Quit notice—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>After the expiry of the lease period(which provided for 6 months’ notice) period of quit notice shall be asprovided by section 106. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>AK Fazlul Huq Vs. Nibaran Chandra Saha (1967)19 DLR 901</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Notice to quit—</span></b><span style='line-height:115%;Cambria","serif";'>Slight inaccuracies will not render thenotice invalid. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Nehar Ali Biswas Vs. Nazam Negar Rashida (1967)19 DLR 905</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Notice to quit should be interpreted liberally and not found illegalfor slight inaccuracies.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>By the notice the plaintiff has directed the defendant to quit thepremises ‘by the 31st December, 1960.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>It was contended that the word “by” has no legal meaning but itsdictionary meaning is ‘during’ and accordingly the possession of a tenant of apremises during subsistence of the tenancy is a lawful one and as such thetenant could not have been asked to vacate during the subsistence of thetenancy.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Held:</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> The rule of construction of a notice toquit is to put upon it a liberal construction in order that it should not bedefeated by slight inaccuracies on the date of the expiry of the notice. But atthe same Lime the notice must be reasonably certain so that the recipient of itis not misled as to the intention of the notice-giver. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='line-height:115%;Cambria","serif";'>Messers Memon Trading Co. Vs. Messrs Hajee Gaffar Fiajee Habib Janno (1965) 17 DLR677.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Lease—Notice to vacate on or before a date being the date on which thelease terminates is a valid notice.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The landlord served a notice on the tenant (a monthly tenant) on the 1stBhadra under section 106 of the Transfer of Property Act to vacate the premiseon or before the 1St day of Aswin next.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>It was contended that the notice was bad inasmuch as the defendant wasasked to vacate on or before the 1st of Aswin although the lease wouldterminate by the mid-night of 1st of Aswin.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Held: For the fact that by the notice the defendant was asked to vacateon or before the 1st day of Aswin, it cannot be held that the notice was bad. Anotice to quit on or before a date being the date on which the tenancy expiresis a good notice. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Ahmadur Rahman Vs. Sheikh Mafazzal Hossain (1962) 14 DLR 826.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Presumption of due service of notice under the section.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The question is, has the notice been served validly? It has been provedthat it was sent by post to the address of the defendant and that it has comeback to the plaintiff on refusal by defendant to accept service of the saidnotice. The postal cover under which the notice was sent bears the endorsementof the postal peon to the effect that it was refused. It is, therefore, clearthat the appellate Court below has rightly held that the said tenancy wasterminated by a good notice under section 106 of the Transfer of Property Actand that it has been properly served, as required by law. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Sultan Ahmed Vs. Sayed Ahmed (1967) 19 DLR 42.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Suit for ejectment’ of tenant— </span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Sufficiency of noticeunder section 106 T.P. Act determining tenancy in respect of suit premisesbelonging to the wakf estate in his personal capacity but he filed the suit asmutawalli of the wakf estate—</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Held: </span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Notice so served is not valid, legal andsufficient and the suit filed on its basis must fail. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Abdul Hafiz Vs. Syed Md. Kazem (1971)23 DLR 12.</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Period of notice provided in section 106— Has no application whenperiod of such notice is mutually agreed upon. <i>Goalundo Industries Vs.Pakistan (1970) 22 DLR 349.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Termination of a tenancy by service of notice under section 106 of theTransfer of Property Act, does not entitle the Government to evict a tenant bythe summary procedure of Act X of 1953.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The petitioners who were monthly tenants under the Government had theirlease of monthly tenancy terminated by service of notice under section 106 ofthe Transfer of Property Act by the Government. When on demand they refused tovacate the premises, they were sought to be summarily evicted by theapplication of the provisions of section 5 of the Act of 1953. The petitionersthen moved the High Court under Art, 98 of the Constitution of Pakistan, 1962on the ground that invoking the summary provisions of a different Act, namely,Act X of 1953 for evicting the petitioners was wholly unauthorized in law.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Held: </span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The petitioners as monthly tenants of thebuilding who are not Government servants do not come within the mischief Act Xof 1953 and therefore, not liable to be evicted under the provisions of theAct. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Amin Medical hail Vs. Province of East Pakistan (1970) 22 DLR 555.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Printing and publishing business, not a manufacturingbusiness—Type-foundry is, no doubt, a manufacturing business, but where it isjust subsidiary to the printing business which is the principal business, suchtype-foundry cannot acquire the status of manufacturing business. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Shamsher Nessa Sakeba Bwioo Vs. Ali Mohsenuddin Ahmed (1975) 27 DLR 643.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—A wrong number given in the notice to quit issued under sec. 106 TP Actwill not invalidate a suit for eviction, if the party had a clear conception ofthe actual subject of the suit, notwithstanding the wrong description. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Fazilatunnessa Vs. Nowshad Ali (1977) 29 DLR</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> <i>315.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Notice to quit is intended to afford an opportunity to the tenant tovacate the premises without resorting to any litigation and it is only when herefused to vacate that he can be evicted through due process of law. <i>     Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—A liberal construction should be put on notice to quit.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>It is the duty of the court to put a liberal construction in order thatthe notice to quit is not defeated by any slight inaccuracy and the recipientis not misled as to the intention of the notice giver. <i>    Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Monthly tenancy cannot be terminated without notice u/s.106.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>In the absence of legal proof that a valid notice as required undersection 106 of the Transfer of Property Act, terminating a monthly tenancy wasserved on the tenants, a suit for eviction of the tenant is not maintainable inlaw. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Mir Deiwar Hossain Vs. Joynal Abedin (1977) 29 DLR 214</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—If a tenancy is a monthly tenancy the month must either be referable toa calendar month or fixed by contract. <i>    Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Premises at the inception taken for use as a godown—Subsequentconversion of it without the landlord’s consent for manufacturing purpose willnot change its original character. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Hayatunnessa Vs. Abdur Rahman (J974) 26 DLR 342.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—In the absence of a contract or local usage a lease of immovableproperty for agricultural or manufacturing purpose is a yearly lease and 6months notice is necessary. All other leases are to be deemed as leases frommonth to month terminable with 15 - days’ notice. <i>   Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—The tenancy (which was for manufacturing purpose) commenced on 1stFalgoon, 1362 B.S.— Notice to quit the premises by 31st Chaitra, 1382 wasserved u/s. 106 T.P. Act giving 9 months’ time to vacate—Defense contention wasthat the termination of the tenancy should coincide with the year of tenancy.Here it should be on 31st. March, 1382 (i.e. last day of the year of tenancy)</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Held:</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> In place of 6 months’ notice u/S. 106 TPAct the defendant in this case has got 9 months’ time to quit and as suchnotice to quit is valid in law. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Iuman Mia Vs. Zainab Bibi, wife of Haji Abdus Salam (1983) 35 DLR 351</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Notice received by the addressee’s wife’s brother (who had been in theservice of the addressee) on the addressee’s premises is a proper service ascontemplated u/s 106, though he may not be regarded as a member of the family. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Hajee Khabiruddin Ahmed Vs. Md. Salam Kabir (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 271.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Plaintiff was the tenant of the shop room under the Pourashava whotransferred the same to defendant 4 with notice to the plaintiff andinstructing him at the same time to attorn to defendant 4 as his landlordfailing which he was required to vacate the premises—Plaintiff was furtherasked to clear off arrears to the Pourashava—Plaintiff did neither— Notice tothe plaintiff by the Pourashava is a notice u/s.106 and on his failure tovacate the premises he was liable to be evicted. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Md. Zahir Abdullah Khan @ Zahir Abdullah Khan Vs. Abdul Latif (1983) 35DLR (AD) 354.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Tenancy created on payment of rent—A monthly tenancy is terminable by15 days’ notice. The Bangladesh Premises Rent Control Ordinance says, a tenantmeans a person by whom, or on whose account, rent is payable for any premises,and includes a legal representative as defined in the Code of Civil Procedure,and a person continuing in possession after the termination of a tenancy in hisfavour. A glance at the definition along with the definition of ‘landlord’,which is nothing but the counterpart of the tenant, indicates that thedefinition was inserted in the Ordinance only to emphasize the tenant’sliability to pay rent and nothing more, and this meaning becomes clear when weadvert to the second half of the definition of ‘tenant’, which says that italso included a person continuing in possession after the termination of histenancy. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Abdus Satar Vs. Suresh Ch. Das (1980)32 DLR (AD) 170.</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Tenancy-at-will creates a personal relation between the originallandlord and the tenant and is terminable by the death of either—Lease iscreated u/s. 106 TP Act. <i>    Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Terminating a tenancy from year to year—How to be counted.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Whether the notice period of six months as contemplated in the law forterminating a tenancy from year to year under section 106 of the Transfer ofProperty Act must end with the expiry of the year of the lease or with theexpiry of the calendar year and whether the notice terminating the tenancy,therefore, conformed with -the statutory requirement.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>According to the learned Counsel, if the lease is from year to yearwhich, in his opinion, it is, the notice to vacate should have been given sixmonths prior to the end of the year of the lease, and not with the end of thecalendar year. As the kabuliyat was registered on 9th Falgun, 1356 B.S.corresponding to February 21 1950 theperiod under notice should have ended on 8th Falgoon of the year in whichnotice was given. Instead of this, the notice which was served by registeredpost on 25th Aswin, 1366 B.S. asked the appellant to vacate by 30th Chaitra,1366 B.S. As no particular date has been mentioned in the kabuliyat as to whenthe lease commenced, according to Mr. Khondaker, it commenced from the date ofthe making of the lease. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Nur Banu Vs. Noor Mohammad and others (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 182.</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Issue as to sufficiency of notice not having been raised in the courtsbelow, the defendant can not be allowed to raise it now. <i>   Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Sufficiency of notice—as decided by the Privy Council.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>In the case of Benoy Krishna Das, (37 CWN PCi) the terms of the leaseshowed that the lease was “from the 1st day of June, 1921 for the term of fouryears thence next ensuing”. The lease ended on the midnight of 1st June, 1925.Any notice to determine the tenancy thereafter given must be a notice to quitexpiring with the month ending at midnight on the first day of the month. Here,the tenants held over and notice to determine their monthly tenancy was givenon 1st February, 1928. The Judicial Committee held that the notice was a propernotice under section 106 of the Transferor Property Act and it expired on themidnight of 1st March and not on the 29th of February. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Nur Banu Vs. Noor Mohammad and others (1983)35 DLR (AD) 182(183).</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Notice under section returned refused by post office—If notice issufficient for termination of tenancy.</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The question of the presumption of service through the post is obviouslyone that has to be decided upon the facts of each case and seeing the envelopein this case and the postal endorsement thereon, we have no doubt that we areperfectly safe in accepting the presumption that arises under section 114(c) inthis particular case. Therefore the refusal of the notice under s.106 would besufficient to terminate tenancy. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Jaffer Sultan Zaidi Vs. United Commercial Corpn. Ltd. PLD 1962 (WP)Karachi 561 (DB) (Raymond, J) [But see PLD 1963 Dacca 477 ‘DB) 1.</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Notice—plea that notice, was not proper not raised in trial Court—Notallowed to be raised in appeal.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Where the validity of notice was not challenged in lower Court but wassought to be raised for the first time in appeal.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Held</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>: The appellant is not entitled to raisethe question of the validity of the notice of ejectment at appellate stage forthe first time. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Rajabali Vs. Gujrat Bus Service PLD 1961 (WP) Karachi 486 (DB) (AnwarulHaq, J).</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—One month’s notice alleged to have been given to tenant to vacatepremises— Notice for period less than one month— Notice is invalid.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>When the allegation in the plaint was that one month’s notice had beengiven to the tenant to vacate the premises but it was found that the notice wasfor less than one month. The landlord urged that he should be taken to havegiven 15 days’ notice as provided under this section. The Court repelled thecontention and held that as the allegation was of one month’s notice, the factthat it was for a shorter period would be fatal for the suit. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>GA Jaffery Vs. Karachi Port Trust PLD 1962 (Kar) 32 (Wahiduddin, J.)</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Monthly tenancy expiring after 4 months—Tenant continuing in possessionsubsequently—Liable to pay rent.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Where the four months of the lease expired on 24.7.49 and the defendantscontinued in possession without any objection by the plaintiff. Years passedand the plaintiff claimed rent.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Held:</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> That the plaintiff had assented to thedefendants continuing in possession and, therefore, the lease must be held tohave been renewed from month to month because that was the purpose of it asspecified in section 106 of the Transfer of Property Act. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Zahir Ahmad Vs. Seth Sugnichand PLD 1965 (WP) Karachi 195.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Sections 106 and 107—Whether a lease is monthly or yearly, depends uponthe contract.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>It is not at all correct to say that there cannot be a yearly lease forthe purpose of a shop. Whether lease is monthly or yearly, depends primarilyupon the contract by which it was made. It is only in the absence of anycontract or local law or usage that the question of its purpose arises; and therule is that a lease for any purpose, other than for agriculture ormanufacture, must be deemed to be a lease from month to month.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>No doubt section 106 of the Transfer of Property Act draws a line ofdivision between lease for agricultural or manufacturing purposes on one sideand the rest on the other; but it does not interfere with the freedom ofcontract. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Md. Siddik Vs. Rabeya Khatun (1954)6 DLR 250.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Reservation of an annual rent.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The reservation of an annual rent is not by itself sufficient to provein every case that the lease is from year to year. A mere reservation of anannual rent would not make a lease from year to year unless the deed isregistered or where a contrary intention is deciticible from the contractbetween the parties. <i>    Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Where an annual rent has been reserved with a provision for forfeiture,fixing 30th Chaitra every year as the fatal date of default it does not showthat a monthly tenancy was intended. The default of monthly installment has noadverse consequence until the end of the year and this fact is of importance,for it goes to show that the tenant is not to be disturbed even though he hadfailed to pay the rent until the end of the year<i>   Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Ss. 106, 107 &amp; 110</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Kabuliyat being adocument executed by one party only, provisions of sections 106 &amp; 110 willnot apply to it. <i>Nur Banu Vs. Noor Mohd. (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 182.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Ss. 106, 108—Sub-lessee or assignee of lease—Cannot be evicted withouttermination of lease.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Sub-lessee or assignee of lease cannot be evicted without terminatingthe original lease. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Kasim Vs. Chandrabahan PLD 1962 (Kar) 253 (DB). (Wahiduddin. J.) </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Ss.106 and 110—</span></b><span style='line-height:115%;Cambria","serif";'>Where after the expiry of the lease thetenant holds over, the notice to quit should be served considering theprovisions of section 106 read with section 110 of the Transfer of PropertyAct.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Where after the expiry of the original lease, a tenant continues to be atenant by holding over, then as regards service of notice to quit, the terms ofthe original agreement shall govern the same unless a new agreement is made. Itis created quite independent of the original tenancy unless an agreement to thecontrary is to be found<i>. </i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Kobbat Ahmed Vs. Abdul Sabur Sawdagar (1973) 25 DLR 282.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Ss. 106 and 111(g)(e)—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>When the denial oftitle will operate as forfeiture whereby notice under section 106 dispensedwith.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The denial of the title of the plaintiff in order to operate as aforfeiture enabling the plaintiff to dispense with the notice under section 106of the Transfer of Property Act is available when the same is done on anearlier occasion prior to the filing of the suit itself.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Denial of the title of the plaintiff-landlord in the written statementof a suit is not available as a ground for forfeiture, which dispenses withnecessity of serving a notice so far as is required to be provided in that suititself though such a denial may be clearly taken advantage of for otherpurposes as well as in subsequent suits.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The denial of the title of the plaintiff by the defendant in this suit,however, is possible to be taken advantage of by the plaintiff on a subsequentoccasion. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Ahmed Hossain Chowdhury Vs. Mst. Zakia Khatun (1968) 20 DLR 1154.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Ss. 106 and 116</span></b><span style='line-height:115%;Cambria","serif";'>—Lease agreement of a premisesexpired—Tenant continued in possession in absence of renewal of the originallease or further agreement and the landlord accepted the rent— Holding over ofsuch premises by the tenant will be governed not by the original lease but bythe general provisions of section 106 of the Act. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Md. Rafique Vs. Md. Siddique (1970) 22 DLR 56.</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Ss. 106, 117—Agricultural leases— Provisions of s.106 should not beapplied rigorously unless there is notification in official gazette.</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The principles embodied in section106 of the Transfer of Property Actare not to be regarded as being opposed to principles of justice, equity andgood conscience, but at the same time they are not to be applied in all theirrigour to agricultural leases, in the absence of a notification in this behalfunder section 117 of the Transfer of Property Act. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Rajabali Vs. Gujrat Bus Service PLD 1961 (WP) Karachi 486 (DB) (AnwarulHaq, J).</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 107—Lease for indefinite period— Defendant’s liability</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Lease for indefinite period—Implies a life-grant unless it is otherwisefrom words used or conduct of parties. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Swarna Kumari Roy Vs. Sukmal Ch. Roy (1954) 6 DLR 474.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Verbal lease for one year—Lease continues after first year withpossession and landlord accepting rents—Valid tenancy, as holding over.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>A verbal lease for more than one year accompanied by delivery ofpossession is valid for the first year and if the tenant continues inpossession even after the first year and the landlord accepts rent from him, hewill be regarded as a tenant by holding over. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Roshan Ali Vs. Mosammat Abedur Nessa (1962) 14 DLR 583.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Patta executed only by lessor, void and not enforceable.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The paua in die present case was a unilateral document executed only bylessor, and not both by the lessor and the lessee. This unilateral pattaoffends against the provision of section 107 of the Transfer of Property Actand is, therefore, void. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Mst. Laila Begum Vs. Mst. Maleka Khatun (1968) 20 DLR 475.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Extension of the lease without delivery of possession—Invalid.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>After the termination of the original lease an extension of the leasewas granted but as there was no delivery of possession accompanying the lease.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Held:</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> Lease not valid. A lease fornonagricultural purposes for one year or less can be created either by aregistered instrument or by oral agreement But such lease must be accompaniedby delivery of possession as required under section 107 of the Transfer ofProperty Act. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Province of East Pakistan Vs. Sayed Ahmed Miyan (1968) 20 DLR 106.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Even in a monthly lease the lessee not liable to eviction on 15 days notice,if his claim of tenancy is in respect of land.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Defendants purchased plaintiffs shop and took settlement of the land onwhich the shop stood and claimed a tenancy right in respect of the land by oralagreement accompanied by delivery of possession.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>It was contended that such a lease other than for agriculture ormanufacturing purposes shall be decumcd to be a monthly lease and the defendantis liable to eviction by 15 days’ notice.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Held:</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> The defendant in the present case claimedhis tenancy right to the land itself; so he is not liable to eviction on 15days’ notice. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Sara Chandra Biswas Vs. Mozam Sardar (1970) 22 DLR 102.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Unilateral lease document void for offending against provisions of section107 of T.P. Act— Lessor and lessee respectively executed unilateral patta andkabuliyat the same day—The two documents cannot be treated as one for complyingwith the provisions of section 107.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>As each of the documents has not been executed by both the lessor andthe lessee, the lease is void. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Sheik Md. Siddique Vs. Hari Lal Nath (1970) 22 DLR 359.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Lessor created a perpetual lease-deed in respect of somenon-agricultural land in favour of lessee for —The lease-deed (a registereddocument) was executed by the lessor alone and not by the lessee.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Held:</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> No valid deed is created unless thelease- deed is executed by both the lessor and the lessee.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Whether a tenancy will be governed by the Transfer of Property Act or bythe Bengal Tenancy Act will depend upon the purpose for which the tenancy wascreated and not on the actual user of the land. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Syed Imteyazuddin Hossain Vs. Md. Abdal Majid (1970) 22 DLR 451.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Amalnama (not registered) showing lease for 11 years—It is admissibleonly to show that there was a lease just for one year.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>It is urged that the tenant took settlement of the fishery for elevenyears from the ex-rent receiver under an Amalnama. It is, on the other hand,argued that the Amalnama (evidencing a lease of 11 years being an unregistered instrument)cannot operate to create a right in the land.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Held: Although there could not be any lease for all the eleven years inthe absence of a registered instrument but there was still a tenancy for aperiod of one year and it has been found that the rent was paid for the firstyear. Hence he was a tenant for the particular year. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Province of East Pakistan Vs. Nakuldas Mirdha (1968) 20 DLR 769.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Lease, purpose of—Lease created by an unilateral document is not hit bysection 107 T.P.Act where reading the document as a whole it appears that thelease was created for agricultural purposes— Recitals to the effect that if theland remains fallow and unproductive, still the same will not be admitted as anexcuse for non-payment of rent or reduction of the same and if the area of theland is found to be more on survey then the lessee will be liable for higherrent along with the stipulation that the lessee will be entitled to plant treeson the bank of the tank and rear fish therein indicate that the lease createdis for agricultural purposes. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Azizur Rahman Vs. Hedayet Ahmed Chowdhury (1972)24 DLR 11.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—No need of registration of an instrument creating tenancy for a year orless although governed by the Transfer of Property Act. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Province of East Pakistan Vs. Abdul Jalil MoIla (1968) 20 DLR 1223.</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—A lease-deed (10 years in the present case)— Not an agreement of leasewithin the meaning of section 107 of the Transfer of Property Act unless therent to be paid by the lessee is fixed and the deed registered. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Sh. Barket Ullah Vs. Khawaja Mohammad Ibrahim, (1970) 22 DLR (SC) 419.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Unregistered lease-deed of immovable property from year to year isinadmissible in evidence for lack of registration. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Abdul Majid Mia Vs. MW. Nabiruddin Pramanik (1970) 22 DLR (SC) 360.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Oral lease granted—Terms of lease subsequently entered on a memo—Memodoes not require registration.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Where an oral lease of property was granted and subsequently a meno inthe form of a rent note was written to state the terms of the lease, and it wascontended that as rent note was not registered, the lease did not materialize.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Held</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>: It is plain from the rent note itselfthat lease had already been granted and in the circumstances it must followthat it was by an oral agreement accompanied by possession. Such a lease doesnot require to be registered as is provided by section 107, Transfer ofProperty Act. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Zahir Ahmed Vs. Seth Sugnichand PLR 1965 (WP) Karachi 195 (DB) (Faruqui,J).</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Ss. 107, 116—Unregistered lease for more than one year—Lease operatesfor first year—Continuance of lease subsequent to first year by holding overmust. be proved by lessee.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>A lease of immovable property for a term exceeding one year, though madewithout a registered instrument, is valid for the first year; and if the lesseeContinues to be in possession thereafter and the lessor accepts rent from him,a tenancy by holding over, from month to month or year to year, as the case maybe, is created. Such tenancy must be teriminated in accordance with law beforethe lessor can resume possession. But the fact that there has been a lease fora year and that thereafter the lease was continued by holding over, the landlordhaving accepted rents, shall have to be established on evidence. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Boshirullah Vs. Province of East Pakistan PLD 1962 Dacca 126=PLR 1961Dacca 1000 (DB) (Murshid, J).</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Section 107</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—A patta unless executed both by thelessor and the lessee is void under section 107 of the Transfer of PropertyAct. A patta in order to create an interest must be executed by both the lessorand the lessee as required by this section. Where a patta was executed andregistered only by the lessor the patta is void being in contravention of theprovision of section 107 of the Transfer of Property Act. Therefore, thedefendant No. I did not derive, any right title or interest in the land in suiton the basis of the said patta. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Narendra Nath Vs. Abdur Rahman (1974) 26 DLR 45.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 108—Material defect in the property</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The provisions of section 108 of the Transfer of Property Act can beinvoked only if the plaintiff specifics the material defect in the propertywith reference to its intended use. and alleges that the defendant was aware ofsuch defect and not the plaintiff and the plaintiff would not with ordinarycare discover such defect. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Hazi Abdul Karim Vs. Sk. Ali Mohd. (1959) 11 DLR (SC) 313.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Unauthorized structure rose by tenant—Landlord cannot claim damages—Remedies.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The raising of the unauthorized structure or violation of the impliedterms of the provisions of section 108, Transfer of Property Act, 1882, did notin the least entitle the landlord to claim damages unless and until it was alsoproved that the tenant by any of his acts had caused physical injury to theproperty which had resulted in some loss to the landlord. The misuse ofproperty is one thing and wrongful use and occupation of property is anotherthing. The occupation or possession of a tenement can become wrongful onlyafter the tenancy is terminated and not before that. As long as the tenancysubsisted the occupation of the tenant, in the instant case, was not that of atrespasser and no damages could be claimed from him by the landlord simplybecause the tenant was wrongfully making beneficial use of the demised property<i>.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Aslam Fazal Ahmad Vs.
