Ghulam Muhammad PLD</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> <i>1961 (WP) Kar 248 (DB) (Wahiduddin,J.)</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 108(a)(b)_ApPlicabilit3’ of the section—Failure to deliverpossession— Liability for rent.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Section 108(a)(b) of the Transfer of Property Act is applicable to anagreement for lease where it contains a term which entitles the tenant tooccupy the property under it, of which specific performance could be granted. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The tenant stands in the same position as if lease has been granted tohim and the landlord is bound at the request of the tenant to put him inpossession of the property.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Section 108 imposes a clear obligation on the lessor to put the lesseein getting the possession of the property and he cannot avoid responsibility onthe ground that the agreement stipulates that it is in the tenant’s occupationor the tenant has agreed to pay rent in advance.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Where the tenants are under agreement to pay rent in advanceunconditionally from a certain date their liability to pay it continues tillthe time the landlord’s arc called upon to discharge their obligation ofputting the tenants in possession. Any breach of section 108, Transfer ofProperty Act committed by the landlords at a later stage will not absolve thetenants from their liability to pay rent for the earlier period.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>In cases of breach of an agreement for lease the tenant is entitled toclaim damages to be assessed on the actual loss including loss of profit whichthe tenant had suffered on account of the alleged breach. <i>PLR (1960)2 WP 834(FB).</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S.. 108(b)—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>When the lease is not valid, as not beingaccompanied by delivery of possession—a suit for damage against the lessor doesnot lie. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Province of East Pak. Vs. Syed Ahmed Mia (1968) 20 DLR 106.</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 108(d)—Accession during the continuance of the lease</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Section 108(d) of the Transfer of Property Act provides that if duringthe continuance of the lease any accession is made to the property suchaccession (subject to the law relating to alluvian for the time being in force)shall be deemed to be comprised in the lease. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Satya Sudihr Ghosal Vs. Surendra Lal (1954) 6 DLR 497.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 108(e)—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>When entire subject-matter of leasedestroyed by fare section 108(e) of T.P.Act not applicable—Such case governedby general principies of law. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Golam Rahman Vs. Emaratannissa Begum (1970) 22 DLR 126.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Clause (e) of s. 108 of the TP Act provides for instances in which amaterial part of a property is wholly destroyed or rendered substantially andpermanently unfit for use for the purpose it is let, in which case the tenanthas an option to terminate the lease. Sec. 108(c) does not deal with the caseof total destruction of the subject-matter of the lease.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Azizur Rahman Vs. Abdus Sakur (1984) 36 DLR (AD) 195.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 108(f)—Repairs without notice to the landlord.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Section 108(f) of the Transfer of Property Act and also section 18 ofthe Calcutta House Rent Control Ordinance does not entitle a lessee ofleasehold premises to make repairs, however, urgent the repairs may be, withoutgiving notice to the landlord. <i>2 PLR (Dacc) 457.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 108(n)—Trustees or lessors clothed with fiduciary character</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Their disability. Where a lessor reposes confidence in the lessee tofulfill the statutory obligation embodied in section 108(n) of the Transfer ofProperty Act truly and faithfully, there is to this extent a fiduciaryrelationship between the lessor and the lessee and the latter who will not beallowed to put himself in a position where his duty and his own interest comein conflict and to obtain an advantage over the lessor whom he is bound toprotect by giving a timely information of the threat to his proprietary right. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Khan Bahadur Khalilor Rahman Vs. Binoy Ranjan Kanungoe (1962)14 DLR 84</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—When a person puts himself  inthe position of a tenant under another, if the former allows to fall in arrearsand then on a decree oblaincu exparte, himself (i.e., the tenant) purchases theproperty in the benami of some person, he puts himself in relation to hislandlord in a fiduciary position and in purchasing this property (bcnami) inexecution proceedings he acts in violation of the provisions of section 108(n)of the T. P. Act and thus cannot retain the benefit of his purchase.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Held:</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> Section 108(n) of the Transfer ofProperty Act imposes an obligation upon the lessee to notify to the lessor ofany invasion upon his proprietary rights by legal proceedings or otherwise,Dasudar, in the present case, had reposed confidence in Kanungo to fulfill thisstatutory obligation truly and faithfully and to this extent there was afiduciary relationship between them which prevented Kanungo from puttinghimself in a position where his duty and his own interest came in conflict andto obtain an advantage over Dastidar when he was bound to protect by givingtimely information of the threat to his proprietary rights. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Bejoy Ranjan Kanungo Vs. Khan Bahadur Khalilur Rahmwz (1968)20 DLR (SC) 286.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 108(o)(p)—Lease—Restrictive covenant—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Terms of lease prohibiting construction on leased plot of land withoutconsent of lessor— Lessor cannot unreasonably withhold sanction of proposedalteration which constitutes improvement. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Haroon E. H. Jaffer Vs. Sind Industrial Trading Estate Ltd., (1969) 21PLD (Karachi) 227.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 109—Lessor transfers the property leased, rights and liabilities ofthe lessor.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Section 109 of the T. P. Act provides that if the lessor transfers theproperty leased, or any part thereof or any part of his interest therein thetransferee in the absence of a contract to the contrary shall possess all therights, and if the lessee so elects subject to all the liabilities of thelessor as to the property or part transferred so long as he is the owner of it.<i>1952 PLR (Lah) 21.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 110—Computation of period of a lease—Duration of the lease and itsdetermination.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The section provides for computation of period of a lease in order tofind out duration of the lease and its determination. It nowhere refers to anylease which is to conic into effect in a future date but only refers to a leasealready in existence nor does it provide that in case of an agreement wheredate of commencement of a lease is not mentioned it will be assumed that thedate would be the date of execution of the lease. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Bhagabat Ranjan Das Vs. Sidheswar Pakrashi (1957) 9DLR 533</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—When there is no mention of the date of commencement of a lease: </span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>An agreement for lease is not an instrument of lease but it is acontract to bring a lease into being in future. If there is no mention of thedate of commencement of a lease in the contract, either expressly or impliedly,section 110 would not fill up the gap. <i>  Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—The expression ‘time limited’ is not applicable to a monthly tenancy.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The words “time limited” in sec. 110 of the Transfer of Property Actindicate that this provision will apply only to a lease of immoveable propertywhere the lease is for a limited period and the period is expressed and in noother case.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>A monthly tenancy is not for a limited period, but for an indefinitetime subject to termination of the tenancy at the option of the lessee or thelessor.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Provisions of section 110 of the Transfer of Property Act has noapplication in computing the period of a monthly tenancy—and in monthly tenancydate of commencement should not be excluded but be included. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>M. Salim Vs. Shaikh Abdul Latif (1962)14 DLR 186.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 111</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Mortgagee’s interest in the mortgagedproperty subsists so long as the mortgagor has not been paid off—Any derivativetitle from the mortgagee ceases to exist with the extinction of mortgagee’sright in the property<i>. </i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Hasina Begum Vs. Haji Md. Ekramulla (1982) 34 DLR 116.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Interest as lessor is coterminous with the mortgagee’s interest. <i>   Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 111(c)—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>of the Transfer of Property Act providesthat a lease of immovable property determines where the interest of the lessorin the property terminates on or his power to dispose of the same extends onlyto the happening of any event by the happening of such event. <i>  Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 111, (d)—Doctrine of merger</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The doctrine of merger contained in section 111 is subject to section2(c) which makes it inapplicable to leases created before the Act came inforce. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Tajim Ali Vs. Saijuddin Khan (1954) 6 DLR 25.</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Merger of by operation of law and intention of parties.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>But this does not mean that there cannot be any merger where the Actdoes not apply. If the Act does not apply there cannot be any merger byoperation of law, i. e., by the union of the subordinate and superior interestin the hands of the same person.      <i>Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—In such a case the question whether there was a merger or not dependsupon the intention of the parties. It is open to the person, in whose hands thetwo interest unite, to keep them apart or to sink the subordinate into thesuperior interest.<i>        Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 111(g)—Unauthorized alteration.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>An unauthorized alteration of the lease-hold premises by the lessee doesnot Constitute forfeiture within the meaning of section 111 (g) of the Transferof Property Act. <i>2 PLR (Dac) 457.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Tenant’s assertion of higher status of the tenanted premises when doesnot always operate as forfeiture of his tenancy right.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>If a tenant does not deny his liability to pay rent but asserts a higherstatus as a lessee than what is admitted by the landlord, such an assertiondoes not amount to denial of the landlord’s title, nor of the setting up of atitle by the defendant in himself and therefore, that does not operate asforfeiture of his tenancy right. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Abdul Majid Mia Vs. MW. Nabiruddin Pramanik (1970)22 DLR (SC) 360.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 111(g)(2)—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Penalty of forfeiture is incurred onlyafter the defendant has ivpudiatcd the relationship of the landlord and tenantwhich can possibly happen (in a suit where the landlord sought ejectment of thedefendant on the ground of the latter being a tenant under him) after, and notbefore, the defendant has filed his written statement denying the assertedrelationship—As this stage of filing WS comes after the filing of the plaint,the plaintiff, perforce, is under legal obligation, if he wants to eject thetenant under section 106 of the TP Act, to serve notice as required by section106 of the Act—Denial by the tenant in the WS may be availed of in a subsequentSuit .or other purpose. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Ahmed Hossain Choudhury Vs. Musammat Zakia Khatun (1968) 20 DLR 578.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 111(h)—Death of the original tenant</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>On the death of the original tenant the tenancy devolves on the heirsand can only he terminated by a notice to quit. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Gouri Bala Pal Vs. Kunja Lal Saha. (1960)12 DLR 37.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 116—Holding over—Tenants remain in possession of the lease-holdproperty.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The provisions of section 116 of the Transfer of- Property Act arcapplicable where the tenant remains in possession of the lease-hold propertyafter the determination of the lease granted to the tenant and his continuingin possession is assented to by the landlord. A tenant who surrenders does notcome within the meaning of the words “remains in possession” of this section. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Aswini Kumar Poddar Vs. Taraj Ch. Rajbangshi (1954)6 DLR 652.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Tenants by holding over.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Defendants’ lease of certain fisheries under the plaintiffs terminatedin 1341 B. S., but they Continued their possession even thereafter. Plaintiffbrought suit for rent against the defendants for the year 1342 which wasdecreed. In 1346 plaintiff granted a lease of the fisheries to a third partywho failed to secure possession thereof from the defendants. Plaintiffsthereupon brought a suit for rent for the year 1346 to 1349 (with alternativeprayer for damages for use and occupation during the period in suit). Thedefense was the denial of plaintiff’s title to the fisheries.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Held:</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> Plaintiff is entitled to get a decree forrent as, under section 116, defendants would be held to be tenants underplaintiff by holding over after the termination of the lease in 1341 under thesame terms and conditions. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Almas Ullah Vs. Srish Ch. Dam. (1951) 3 DLR 526</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Lessor ‘otherwise assents to his continuing in possession”—Suing forrent held to indicate assent on the part of landlord—Lease renewed from year toyear or from month to month as the case may be. <i>1954 PLR (Lah) 829.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Lessee holding over after the period of lease becomes a tenant.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>An agreement to lease immovable property from year toy or for any termexceeding one year accompanied by delivery of possession, in the absence of aregistered lease deed, is valid for one year and if the lessee continues in possessionwith the assent of the lessor, the lessee becomes a tenant by holding overunder section 116 of the Transfer of Property Act. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>SM Lalita Roy Vs. Rafiqullah Khan (1966)18 DLR 107.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Tenancy right by holding over.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The very fact that the tenant after expiry of the lease was allowed toremain in undisturbed possession of the land (non-agricultural land) for a longperiod (33 years in the present case) and that the holding comprising the suitland was allowed to stand in the municipal register in the name of the tenantwithout any protest from the landlord or the subsequent lessee who took leaseof the land in tenure right clearly indicate that both the landlord and thesubsequent lessee acquiesced in the holding over of the suit land by the tenantand after him by his heirs. Therefore, the tenant’s claim of tenancy right byholding over cannot be denied. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Mastakim Ali Vs. Shafique Uddin Chowdhury (1970) 22 DLR (SC) 395.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—<b>Tenancy right</b>—By open and actual possession for a long period inassertion of tenancy right the tenant acquires limited tenancy right.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Auction-purchaser, in a rent execution case started by the landlordagainst the tenure-holder, acquires only the right, title and interest of thetenure- holder but the tenancy right of any person in the said land remainsunaffected by such auction-purchase. <i>   Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Lessee holding over after the expiry of lease—Effect.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>When a person is in possession of certain land on the basis of lease fora fixed term and continues as such in possession even after the expiry of thelease period the position of that person is not that of a trespasser but of atenant holding over under section 116 of the Transfer of Property Act.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'><i>Banaras Co-operative housingSociety Ltd. Vs. The Chairman, Karachi Development Authority (1970) 22 DLR (SC)431.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Holding over</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Tenancy claimed by right of holding over— Claimant to conclusively proveit—Till this is done Government not called upon to prove compliance withChapter V of Acquisition Act (XXVIII of 1951). </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Province of East Pakistan Vs. Nakuldas Mirdha (1968)20 DLR 769.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 117—Section 117 excludes only agricultural lease.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>There is no indication in section 129 restricting its application onlyto a particular class of las, that is, non-agricultural land, as section 23 ofthe Non-Agricultural Tenancy Act, 1943 has provided. Section 117 of theTransfer of Property Act excludes from its operation only agricultural leasesbut not other dispositions.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Jabed Ali Vs. Abu Shaikh (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 31.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 1 18—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>If an exchange of lands is not effected bya registered instrument, that would not create any interest in favour of anyparty to the exchange as no valid title could be created on the basis of anoral exchange. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Jabed Ali Bepari Vs. Abdul Bari Bepari (1967) 19 DLR 192.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 119—Exchange of property</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>— Provision of s. 119applicable so long as property remains in hands of person to whom it had beengiven in exchange and not after he has parted with same in favour of thirdperson—Exchange of lands between A &amp; B—Exchange deed covenanting ‘if anyloss is sustained by one party due to any factual or legal flaw in title toland, ckh would be liable for any loss sustained by the other”—Liabilitycreated by covenant, held, “personal” and not “running with land” exchanged—Provisionsof s. 119, held, not attracted. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Muhammad Shah Vs. Sher Muhammad, (1969) 21 PLD (Peshawar) 103.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Secs. 122 and 123: Hindu law—Gift.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>It is sufficient for a valid attestation, if the attesting witnessesreceived acknowledgement from the executants of the deed that he put hissignature or mark on the deed though the attesting witnesses themselves did notsee him do it. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Kisan Panday Vs. Nageswari Debi (1956) 8 DLR 65.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Acceptance of a gift under the Hindu Law may be either express orimplied inasmuch as there is nothing in section 122 of the TP Act to say thatit must be express. <i>   Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 123—Rule of Hindu Law—Delivery of possession.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>As regards Hindu gifts to which the Transfer of Property Act applies therule of pure Hindu Law that delivery of possession is essential to the validityof a gift is abrogated by section 123 of that Act. A gift under that Act canonly be effected in a manner provided by section 123. <i>   Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Ss. 123, 129—Oral gift by trustees—Trust not under Muslim Law—Gift isinvalid for want of registration.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Where the trustees of a Trust which was not created under Muslim Lawmade an oral gift of some property of the trust to another trust. It was heldthat the oral gift was invalid for want of registration. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Standard Vacuum Oil Vs. Mir Laik Ali PLD 1962 Karachi 727 (BD).(Qadeeruddin, J).</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 129—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Provision of section 129 is applicable toMuslims only when transferring property by gift. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Jabed Ali Vs. Abu Shaikh, being dead his heirs: Md. Naimuddin and ors.(1983) 35 DLR (AD) 31.</span></i><span style='line-height:115%;Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—S. 129 and s. 117</span></b><span style='line-height:115%;Cambria","serif";'>—Section 129’s application is not to aparticular class of lands. <i>     Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 130</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—The true test for determining the natureof the claim sought to be assigned should be to see that the claim when it doesaccrue, partakes of true character of a beneficial interest in moveableproperty not in the possession, either actual or constructive, of the claimantwhich can be recovered by an action. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Kazi Abdul Ali Vs. Nurul Amin. (1955)7 DLR 406.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 135A—Subrogation.</span></b><span style='line-height:115%;Cambria","serif";'> Insurance company can be subrogated inthe position of the insured and thereby become vested with the right of thelatter to sue the person liable.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Insurance company can be subrogated in the position of the insured andthereby become vested with the right of the latter to sue the person liableoriginally to the insured. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Trans</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> <i>Ocreanic Steamship Vs. Issak HaziShakoor (1960)12 DLR 690.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—In case of Marine Insurance the Insurer having paid up loss sustainedby the assured and being thus subrogated to the position of the assured isentitled to sue tort-feasor ,i.e., the person who has caused the loss, in hisown name. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>East &amp; West Steamship Co. Vs. Queensland insurance Co. (1964)16 DLR(SC) 61.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Even after subrogation the insured can file a suit for recovery ofdamages.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Though section 135A of the Transfer of Property Act only has given rightto the insurer after subrogation to sue on his own behalf but that has nottaken away the right of the insured to file a Suit for and on behalf of theinsurer after getting compensation from the insurer. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>M. Ismail and Sons Vs. Trans Oceanic Steamship Co. Ltd. (1965)17 DLR269.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S. 136</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—It is not incumbent on the landlord tocall and examine the postal peon who delivered the notice at the premises ofthe addressee. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Haji Khabiruddin Ahmed Vs. Md. Salam Kabir (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 271.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Secs. 161 &amp; 164—Gift of property which are capable of division.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Section 161 of the TI’ Act says that a gift of property which is capableof division to two or more persons without specifying their shares or withoutdividing it is invalid but it may be rendered valid if separate possession istaken by each donee of their respective portion of the property or if there isa subsequent arrangement between the donees with regard to the possession ofthe property. Section 164 further says that when a gift is made subject to acondition which derogates from the completeness of the grant, the condition isvoid, and the gift will take effect as if no conditions were attached to it. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Monzurur Rahman Vs. Rema Tea Co. Ltd. (1981) 33 DLR 49.</span></i><span id="pastemarkerend"></span></p></div></div>
2421	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Transfer of Property (Pakistan) Ordinance (IV of 1947)</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>   (1959)11 DLR 57,  (1964) 16 DLR 179, (1959) 11 DLR 57</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Transfer of Property (Pakistan) </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><u>Transfer of Property (Pakistan) Ordinance (IV of 1947)</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The jurisdiction of a civil court cannot be held to be ousted when a suit is brought for the purpose of declaring that it was beyond the competence of the income-tax authoress to act under Ordinance No. IV of 1947.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Kumudini Welfare Truss Vs. Pakistan (1959)11 DLR 57.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 3</strong>—The ordinance does not prohibit from entering into transactions which require to be registered.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Saru Mw Sowdagar Vs. Al-Hajj Jahanara Begum. (1956)8 DLR 616=8 PLR (Dac) 326.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Income-tax clearance certificate for registration of transfer deed cannot be issued unless income tax dues are paid. <em>The State Bank of Pakistan (1964) 16 DLR 179.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Tax liability should be determined by reference to the date when application for clearance certificate is submitted and not by reference to the time when the clearance certificate is issued. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 4</strong>—<strong>Retrospective in operation</strong>—The language of section 4 of the Ordinance makes it clear that it was intended to be retrospective in operation and was meant to cover all transactions of the kinds mentioned in the said section which took place after 14th August, 1947, though the Ordinance came into force on 25.11.48. The words “the certificate prescribed by section 3” do not necessarily mean the certificate as required by section 3. They mean a certificate in terms of section 3.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Kumudini Welfare Trust Vs. Pakistan (1959) 11 DLR 57.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2422	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Transfer of Railways Order, 1962</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1970) 22 DLR 235, (1956) 8 DLR (PC) 19(23)</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Transfer of Railways</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><u>Transfer of Railways Order, 1962</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 7(a)(1)</strong>—Lands and buildings belonging to EP Railway became lands and buildings vested with the Provincial Government after the Transfer of Railways Order came into operation—Provisions of the East Bengal Government Lands and Buildings (Recovery of Possession) Act are applicable to such lands and buildings.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Miajan Ali Vs. Province bf East Pakistan (1970) 22 DLR</em> <em>235.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Trial Court—Its finding</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">An appellate Court would not ordinarily interfere with the finding of fact of a court of first instigate but this principle is not without exception. Where the (1) facts are such that the appellate Court is in a similar position with the original Court to sift and weigh the evidence, when (2) the oral testimony has not received due consideration in the original court; and where (3) the disbelief of witness by the trial court is based on an alleged contradiction which is in reality a mere incapacity of the witness to remember or explain a certain thing—then in all such cases the appellate tribunal would be unfettered to examine the evidence afresh and arrive at an independent decision.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Akbar</em> <em>Abdul Sattar Vs. WL Bogstra (1956) 8 DLR (PC) 19(23).</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2423	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Trust Act, 1882</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1962)14 DLR (SC) 308, (1977)29 DLR 416, (1955)7 DLR 222, (1981) 33 DLR 424</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Trust </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Trust Act (I of 1882)</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 3 &amp; 11—Where Bank to refund excess amount as sufficient “conveyance in trust”.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If the money was transferred to the Bank with the obligation annexed that it would refund any excess amount found due as a result of the settlement of the exchange issue later, there would be a sufficient “conveyance in trust” as by definition a “trust” is “an obligation annexed to the ownership of property and arising out of a confidence reposed in and accepted by the owner, or declared and accepted by him, for the benefit of another, or of another and the owner” vide section 3 of Trust Act, 1882. In the alternative, if the ownership of the money did not pass to the Bank but remained with the plaintiff then it was a case of a deposit by the plaintiff with the Bank, subject to the express condition that a part of it would be paid back to him and a pars appropriated by the Bank, when the disputed question of the rate of exchange was resolved. In these circumstances too the bar of limitation could not be successfully pleaded against the claim.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>S. M. Hanif Ltd. Vs. The Central Bank of India Ltd. (1962)14 DLR (SC) 308.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Secs. 73. 74—Provisions of the section</strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> explained—S. 73 deals with appointment of new trustee and refers to appointment by court<em>. </em></span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Chera Dandi Mela Vs. Md. Yusuf Ali (1978)30 DLR</em> <em>(SC) 310</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 90</strong>—Mortgagee’s purchase of the land in auction sale for arrears of rent ensures to the benefit of the mortgagors.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Auction-purchase of the suit land for arrears of rent by defendant No. 4(a mortgagee) in view of the provision of section 90 of the Trust Act will ensure to the benefit of the mortgagors and their heirs and successors-in-interest.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Afser Molla Vs. Abdul Aziz (1977)29 DLR 416.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Purchase will ensure to the benefit of.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Where the usufructuary mortgagee takes upon himself the burden of paying off rent of the property under mortgage and makes the stipulation that if for any default in payment of rent, the mortgaged property is lost on account of sale for arrears of rent and purchased by the mortgagee or his successor-in interest, that purchase will ensure to the benefit of the mortgagor, specially where the purchase place in relation to a decree for arrears of rent for the period under mortgage.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Safayat Ali Shah Vs. Annada Pro. Ray (1955)7 DLR 222.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—In order that section 90 of the Trust Act, is attracted the co-sharer auction-purchaser must not only be a co-sharer, but must also be guilty of some kind of sharp practice in the transaction in question.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Shefalika Debi Vs. Belaran Debi &amp; ors. (1981) 33 DLR 424.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2424	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Union Parishad &amp; Paurashava &amp; Councils (Election/Taxation) Rules</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1968)20 DLR 282,  (1968)20 DLR 37, (1968) 20 DLR 556, (1967) 19 DLR 259, (1970) 22 DLR 247, (1977) 29 DLR 390,  (1978) 30 DLR (SC) 306, (1979) 31 DLR 140, 1979)31 DLR (AD) 331,  (1979) 31 DLR 119, (1979) 31 DLR 381, (1979) 31 DLR (AD) 296, (1976)28 DLR </p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Union Parishad &amp; Paurashava &amp; Councils</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Union Councils and Town and Union Committees (Election of Chairman) Rules, 1965</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Rules do not provide for obtaining consent of candidate nor provide procedure for withdrawal— Unwilling candidate cannot be considered to be a candidate—A man cannot be elected when he refuses to be so elected—Consent can be express or implied.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mazharul Huq Vs. Additional Commissioner (1968)20 DLR 282.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rule 3—Chairman’s election should be held without delay.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The entire scheme of the Rules with particular reference to rule 3 and rule 15 shows that the Legislature intended that the election of the Chairman 01 LISL he held at the earliest possible opportunity after the Union Council has been constituted under section 57 of the Electoral College Act and that when a Chairman has actually been elected, there should be no impediment in his way from taking over charge of the office of the Chairman from the outgoing.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Chairman, Md. Serajul</em> <em>Huq Vs. Sub Divisional Officer (1968)20 DLR 37</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>R. 5</strong>—Resignation of the Chairman accepted and thereafter another member elected as the Chairman. The fact that resignation was gazetted after the fresh election of the Chairman does not invalidate fresh election of the Chairman.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Shah Badrul Haque Vs. MR Chowdhury (1968) 20 DLR 556.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rule 5 (I)—Where mark is clear for whom vote was cast, some irregularity makes no difference.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The form of voting paper which is prescribed under rule 5(l)is merely for the purpose of facilitating the voters to put their cross marks against the name of a particular candidate they are voting for and the rule does not make it obligatory that the cross mark must be put in column 2. Ii is sufficient compliance with the rule if the mark is clearly put against the name of candidate.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Taleb Ali Vs. Additional Commissioner Dacca (1967) 19 DLR 259.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rr. 8 &amp; 10—</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">The Deputy Commissioner and Divisional Commissioner have jurisdiction to declare a candidate elected as chairman where there has been a failure of election due to contesting candidates getting equal number of votes. <em> Ibid.</em></span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rule 10—Validity of election of Chairman can be challenged before the Tribunal only.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Validity of election of Chairman can be challenged before the Tribunal only. Writ jurisdiction under Article 98 of the Constitution cannot be involved.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is evident from the rules 10,11,12 and l3of the EP Union Councils and Town and Union Committees (Election of Chairman) Rules, 1965 that a particular forum has been established for the resolution of a dispute as to the validity of the election of the Chairman of the Union Council. IL is now a settled rule of law that if a statute or for the matter of that rules framed there under has created a special tribunal for the resolution of a particular dispute, ii is that Tribunal alone which has jurisdiction to decide the dispute. The petitioner having failed to approach the Collector under rule 10 of the Rules for a resolution of the dispute cannot maintain the present application under Article 98 of the Constitution.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Serajul Haq Vs. Sub-Div. Officer (1968) 20 DLR 37.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rule 11—Deputy Commissioner acts in quasi-judicial character—Should not take guidance from any quarter for disposing of an election petition—Decision should be in unambiguous terms.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">We have no hesitation to say that the Deputy Commissioner who in the matter of disposal of an election petition was acting in a judicial capacity should not have under any circumstances taken any guidance from any communication made to him by way of clarification by the Government on the point. He should have acted independently according to his best judgment, knowledge, good conscience and the rules governing the matter. That the Deputy Commissioner acts at least in quasi-judicial character under rule 11 of the Rules is also admitted by the learned Advocate-General.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">We would like to impress on the functionaries who are entrusted with election matters that decision should be given in clear and unambiguous terms touching upon each point involved in the case without leaving anything to be guessed or conjectured. This must be so as very important rights of citizens are involved in election matters.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mazharul Huq Vs. Addi. Commr. (1963) 20 DLR 282.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rule 15</strong>—(Sec under rule 3 in case of <em>Md. Serajul Hoq Vs. Sub-divisional officer (1968) 20 DLR 37).</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><u>Union Councils (Taxation) Rules, 1960</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><u> </u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>R. 43A(2)—</strong>Union Council Lax—Companies and Corporations not entitled to the benefit of exemption provided in rule 43A(2).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The question was whether the word.” person” mentioned in the Government Order dated 16th July, 1966 passed in pursuance of sub-rule (2) of rule 43A of the East Pakistan Union Councils (Taxation) Rules, 1960, includes the petitioners (which arc Limited Companies) for extending benefit of the rule to them also to the effect that they, like an individual, are entitled to exemption of maximum payment of Rs. 500/ as union council tax.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held:</strong> The order obviously means an individual though the word “person” was used and in the operative order the word “person” meant an individual, a natural person. The use of the word “person” in the said Govt. order may be an obvious slip or the word was inartistically used. The word “persons” has been used with the qualifying words “one” preceding it and therefore, in the Context it must be held that “person” in the order meant an individual or natural person and therefore the Companies and Corporations arc not entitled to the benefit of exemptions provided in rule 43A(2).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The two clauses in rule 43A refer to two different purposes and the use of different words “individual” and “person” must be deemed to have been employed to convey two different meanings. Interpreted in its proper context the exemption of maximum payment of Rs. 500/- in the former clause of the proviso to rule 43A seems to have been granted to any individual meaning natural person as opposed to anybody corporate or association of persons like the limited Company or Partnership.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Chittagong Jute Manufacturing Co. Ltd. Vs. Mohara Union Council (1970) 22 DLR 247.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><u>Union Parishad (Election) Rules, 1976</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Election Tribunals are given exclusive power to decide all matters relating to election disputes.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Safar Ali Vs. SDO Sadar North (1977) 29 DLR 390.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rule 16(3</strong>)—Proviso 11—When defect is not of substantial nature correction of the same allowed forthwith before the Returning Officer. The election can not be called in question for non- correction of such defect.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mozammel Huq Vs. Bangladesh (1978) 30 DLR (SC) 306.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rule 35</strong>—Ballot paper issued to voter unless it bears the official mark and the Polling Officer’s initial it shall be rejected, despite the contention that it was otherwise genuine.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdul Aziz Vs. Election Tribunal (1979) 31 DLR 140.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—It is true that a voter has no hand in taking the initial or the official seal on a ballot paper given to him but the Rules make a specific provision in order to be valid a ballot paper shall contain both the initial of the Polling Officer and the official mark. This procedure appears to have been prescribed to guard against any unfair means in ballot paper such as casting of a ballot paper which is not issued to a genuine voter. In view of this provision of the Rules, for the purpose of accepting a ballot paper as valid it must bear both the official mark and the initial of the Polling Officer and for the purpose of rejecting it as invalid absence of either the official mark or the initial of the Polling Officer will be sufficient. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rules 35 and 40(4)—</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Rule 35 speaks of the voting procedure to be observed by the Polling Officer, whereas rule 40 speaks of counting of votes. Sub-rule (4) of rule 40 is a direction to be followed by the Presiding Officer while counting votes. </span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdul Motin Vs. Election Tribunal (1979)31 DLR (AD) 331.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rule 40(4)—</strong>It cannot be that the legislature requires a voter to be vigilant regarding the performance of duties by the Government functionaries.<em>   Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A ballot paper is not to be rejected as invalid if it contains either the official mark or Polling Officer’s initial—It is to be rejected when both these arc absent. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A ballot paper should be treated as valid if it contains either the official mark or the initial of the Polling Officer. <em>   Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rules 48 &amp; 49—</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> Election Tribunal, though happens to be a judicial officer and appointed by the Government does not become a civil court within the meaning of Civil Procedure Code and can not as such grant temporary injunction in an election case.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Sharifullah Vs. Election Tribunal Munsif Court Rajshahi (1979) 31 DLR 119.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—To find out the Status of the Election Tribunal one is to examine the powers conferred under rules 48 and 49 of the Union Parishads (Election) Rules, 1976. Rule 48 corresponds to rule 61A of the Union Parishad and Paurashava (Election) Rules, 1973. Similarly, rule 49 corresponds to rule 61B of the said Rules. Rules 48 and 49 are identical to rules 61A and 61B. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rule 50—Election when can be declared void.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A declaration that the election of returned candidate or election as a whole is void depends on two conditions—(I) failure of any person to comply with or the contravention of the rules, and (2) the noncompliance or contravention must materially affect the result of the election<em>.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Iman Hossain Bepari Vs. Election Tribunal (1979) 31 DLR 381.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>R. 50(2)—</strong>An Election Tribunal acting under R. 50(2) may order recounting of votes.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abul Basher Chowdhury Vs. Habibur Rahman Mia &amp; ors. (1979) 31 DLR (AD) 296.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Election Tribunal may consider and determine whether counting of votes by the Presiding Officer was correct or irregular.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abul Basher Chawdhury Vs. Habibur Rahman Mia &amp; ors. (1979) 31 DLR (AD) 296.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><u>Union Parishad &amp; Paurashava (Election) Rules, 1973</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rules 2(d) and 56(2)—’Election”— What it means.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Interpretation given by the Tribunal is not found to be in accordance with the definition of election as given in rule 2(d) of the Election Rules. Election means an election of a Member, Commissioner, Women Commissioner, Chairman, or Vice- Chairman, as the case may be. This shows that for a person contesting the Chairmanship ‘election’ means election of the Chairman only. It is, therefore, clear that when the question of election of the Chairman arises the election of Vice Chairman or of any member is irrelevant.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Siddique Ahmed Vs. Munsif 1st Court (1976)28 DLR 470.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rule 3(2) (read with r. 4)—Rule 3(2</strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">) does not allow the SDO or any executive officer of the district or sub-division to order recounting of votes which will be illegal—Recording of votes is permitted under r. 40(5). </span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Azhar Mridha Vs. Election Tribunal (1975)27 DLR 307.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rule 10(4)—</strong>Returning Officer Sound to authorize, in the absence of the Presiding Officer, the Assit. Presiding Officer or some polling officer to act in the absence of such Presiding Officer—Failure renders the election void.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Siddique Master Vs. Republic of Bangladesh (1975)27 DLR 240.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rules 15(5) and 59(3)—</strong>Deposit not made in Treasury as required by Rules but in the Civil Court—Not a valid deposit according to law and, therefore, election petition not maintainable.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdul Malek Vs. Election Tribunal (1976)28 DLR 467.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Provision about deposit in the Treasury—mandatory.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">This provision is mandatory and not directory. As such non-compliance of the said provision is notn a mere irregularity but is an illegality.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Abdul Malek Vs. Election Tribunal (1976) 28 DLR 467.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rule 20A</strong>—The rule clearly negatives introduction of fresh candidates to those already in the field. The word candidates which is in plural has been used because of the possibility of more than once candidate left in the field.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is true that the last word in rule 20A is ‘candidates’ which refers to persons in the plural but the expression ‘the poll shall be restricted to the remaining candidates’ is highly significant. This expression clearly excludes the possibility and negatives the idea of introduction of a new candidate or candidates in the field through fresh nominations.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mazharul Huq Vs. Returning Officer (1975) 27 DLR (SC) 11.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rule 21</strong>—When the number of candidates for election is equal to the number to be elected, no election is held and the remaining candidate or candidates are elected uncontested.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mazharul Huq Vs. Returning Officer (1975) 27 DLR (SC)11.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rule 22—Contested election—Poll when held.</strong> Rule 22 relates to contested election. It provides that if the number of the contesting candidates for election as member or commissioner in a ward or constituency, as the case may be, is more than the required number of members or commissioners or that of the contesting candidates for election as Chairman or Vice Chairman is more than one, a poll shall be held.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mazharul Huq Vs. Returning Officer (1975) 27 DLR (SC)11.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rule 27—Non-observance of the requirements of the rule</strong>—Election void. Nonobservance of the formalities regarding the giving of public notice as mentioned in rule 27 of the Election Rules renders an election null and void.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abu Siddique Master Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh (1975)2 7 DLR 239.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rules 27 and 40—”Poll</strong>” means casting of votes and does not mean counting of votes.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Ismail Uddin Vs. Election Commission (1977) 29 DLR 285.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rule 30</strong>—If poll at a polling station could not be held, a fresh election shall be held only in that polling station and not in all the polling stations of a union.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Haji Munir Ahmed Vs. Chief Election Commr (1975) 27 DLR 308.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Disturbance at a particular election poll necessitating fresh poll—Fresh poll must remain confined to the polling station where disturbance took place—All voters in cl. (3) means all voters of that particular polling station.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mahiuddin Sardar Vs. Chairman, Election Commission (1974) 26 DLR 181.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rr. 35-39, 42, 44, 46 &amp; 81</strong>—For election purposes ballot papers are principal pieces of evidence—Non-production of some ballot papers does not render the ballots produced inadmissible.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Ayub Ali Howladar Vs. Election Tribunal (1976) 28 DLR (AD)1.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rule 40—</strong>Votes must be counted immediately after conclusion of the polling—For unavoidable reason if that is not possible it must be done the next day.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Ismail Uddin Vs. Election Commission (1977) 29 DLR 285.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The provisions of rule 40 do not empower the Presiding Officer to take away the ballot boxes to any place outside the centre and then count the votes. These provisions require that the counting should take place at the centre and as soon as the polling is over. There can be no change of time and place according to the will of the Presiding Officer.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If that is done, the sanctity and impartiality of the entire election is affected.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Imanuddin Sarkar Vs. The Election Commission of Bangladesh (1975) 27 DLR 662.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—R. 40(3)(b)—</strong>Election Tribunal scrutinized and recounted ballot papers in the presence of both parties; rejected some that were accepted by Presiding Officer and again accepted some rejected by the P. 0. with the result that the declared chairman was unseated—Tribunal recorded no reason for his acceptance and rejection—Nothing wrong in law.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Nw Hossain Vs. E. Tribunal(1975)27 DLR ‘SC’ 117.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Rules 40, 41—</strong>Taking away of ballot boxes without counting ballots on the conclusion of voting will vitiate the result of election.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Amjad Hossain Vs. Chief Election Commissioner </em>(1975) <em>27DLR 373.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rule 41(5)—</strong>Duty cast upon the Returning Officer under sub-rule (5) of r. 41 of the UP &amp; PE Rules is statutory observance of which the High Court can enforce under Article 102 of the Bangladesh Constitution.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">S Hamidul Huq Vs. Returning Officer (1976)28 DLR 281.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Rule 48—</span></strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Election Tribunal acting as such not competent to issue temporary injunction under Or. 39, Civil Procedure Code. </span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>A. Gafur Vs. Election Tribunal (1977) 29 DLR 111</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Election Tribunal is not clothed with all the powers of a Civil Court constituted under the E. B. Civil Courts Act, 1887. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rule 49</strong>—The last clause of rule 49 of the Union Parishad Rules makes it clear beyond any that the Election Tribunal, although empowered specifically to exercise the powers of the Civil Court in trying election petition, is not empowered to exercise all the powers of the Civil Courts Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>A. Gafur Vs. Election Tribunal (1977) 29 DLR 111.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Civil Courts should steer clear of granting in under Or. 3, r. 1, CP Code when they act as Election Tribunals.<em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Election Tribunal is a creature under the Election law. There is no scope for exercising all thepowers of the Civil Court at the trial of the election petition. <em>   Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rule 52(2)—</strong>In election cases under the Election Rule there is no provision for transposition of a party from one category to another.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Nurul Huq Vs. Election Tribunal (1977)29 DLR 304</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Rule 54—</span></strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Election petition under r. 54 can be filed after the election result is declared in a Gazette. </span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>S. Hamidul Huq Vs. Returning Officer (1976) 28 DLR 281.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rules 56 and 59</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—Petition challenging election can be made only by one who was himself a candidate in the election. </span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>SM Hossain Vs. Election Commr. (1976) 28 DLR (SC) 52.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—In disputes over election the Election Tribunal must give opportunity to all persons who are to be affected by the decision of the Tribunal in such cases—Therefore, it is mandatory that all contesting candidates in the election must be made parties and given opportunity of being heard in an election dispute case. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Rule 56(2)—</strong>Election void in one centre of election can not result in declaring elections at other centers void.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Irregularities occurred in one centre of electioncan not affect the result of election at the other centers.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>SM Hossain Vs. Election Commr. (1976) 28 DLR (SC) 52.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Rr. 56(2): 48 and 42—</strong> An election petition challenging an election can only be made before the Election Tribunal—High Court’s writ doubt diction is not the proper forum to give remedy in such a case.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Moslehuddin Vs. Election Commr (1976)28 DLR 435.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Rule 56A—</strong>This rule provides for bringing all the contesting candidates on record for final adjudication—Candidates of different categories are not to be brought on record.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Siddique Ahmed Vs. Munsif 1st Court (1976) 28 DLR 470.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>R. 57—</strong>Any officer, not necessarily a judicial officer, may be appointed Presiding Officer.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Election Tribunal is appointed by the Election Commission which is a statutory body set up under the Rules and according to rule 57, any officer may be appointed as an Election Tribunal and he need not be a judicial officer, though, mostly judicial officers have been made the <em>Presiding Officers of Election Tribunals. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Shamsul Huq Sikder Vs. Election Tribunal (1975)27 DLR 388.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rules 57 and 60—</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Election tribunal’s Jurisdiction limited and cannot travel beyond that jurisdiction—It is not a court. <em> Ibid.</em></span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—If Presiding Officer of a Civil Court is appointed an Election Tribunal that will not convert it into Civil Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In a particular case the Presiding Officers of Civil Court have been appointed as Election Tribunals but that fact will not authorize the Tribunals to exercise those powers which such officers exercise while they act as Presiding Officers of a Civil Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Shamsul Huq Sikder Vs.
