Election Tribunal (1975) 27 DLR 388.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Rule 57 read with Order 39 CP Code.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Provisions of Order 39, CP Code have no application in terms of an election dispute tried by an Election Tribunal.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Election Laws should be stringently applied to prevent corruption in election.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Nurul Islam Vs. Munsif, Chittagong (1976) 28 DLR 375.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rule 58</strong>—High Courts interference with the finding of the Election Tribunal when justice demands it.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It has been contended that the finding of facts arrived at by the Tribunal on re-examination of ballot papers in presence of the parties can hardly be interfered with under Article 102 of the Constitution.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held:</strong> Firstly, it cannot be said that determination of validity of ballot papers is a question of facts; it is a mixed question of law and facts. As to the High Court’s jurisdiction under Article 102, it should be remembered that writ is a writ and not an appeal. Ordinarily, this Court does not interfere with the findings of a subordinate Court, if the findings are arrived at on consideration of relevant facts and correct appreciation of evidence being free from any unfairness of mind. If the findings are not so arrived at, this Court has got every power to interfere therewith.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Decision of the Appellate Division cannot be interpreted to hold that the ballot papers found valid by the Presiding Officers in presence of the parties can be arbitrarily rejected by the Tribunal.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Nurul Islam Vs. Munsif Chittagong (1976) 28 DLR 375.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Circumstances which necessitate the interference by the High Court with material irregularities by the Tribunal.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In the instant case, the Tribunal acted with material irregularity when it proceeded to examine the ballot papers ignoring the broad fact that the gunny bags containing the election papers were tampered with having a number of stitched-up holes. Again, when, on discovery of apparently tampered ballot papers, so many in numbers, examination of the Presiding Officer was indispensably necessary in the interest of justice, but he arbitrarily refused to examine them and thereby failed to exercise jurisdiction vested in him. Findings arrived at in these circumstances cannot claim any sanctity nor can they be immune from interference.   <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>NuruI Islam Vs. Munsif, Chittagong (1976)28 DLR 375.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—In an orderly election the reports of the Presiding Officer showing performance of duties must be accepted.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">When the election was held in a peaceful atmosphere and scrutiny and Counting of ballot papers were made in an orderly mainer, without any objection from any quarter, reports of the Presiding Officers as to due performance of their duties must be accepted. Otherwise there will be no sanctity of a free election which is a must for running democratic institutions. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Election laws should be stringently applied to prevent corruption in elections.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The facts and circumstances of the case unerringly show that the questioned ballot papers of the petitioner were tampered with by some malicious hand after their dispatch from the local officers. Subsequent act of tampering with the ballot papers cannot be a ground for undoing the election. To do so would be to give premium to corrupt practices. To ensure free and fair election of people’s representatives Election Laws against corrupt practices should be made stringent. In this case the authorities may direct an enquiry as to how the ballot papers were tampered with. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rule 59(3)—</strong>Election petition must accompany a receipt showing deposit as required under rule 15(5). When election petition was filed at the first instance and thereafter deposit by a chalan was shown to have been made—This violates a mandatory provision of law and as such election petition cannot be entertained.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdul Malek Vs. The Election Tribunal (1977) 29 DLR 221.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>R. 60 clauses (a) and (b)—What clauses (a) and (b) provides—’Election as whole’ explained.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Clause (a) of rule 60 provides that election of any returned candidate may be declared void and some other candidate might be declared elected in his place and clause (b) provides that election as a whole may be declared void.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Siddique Ahmed vs. Munsif 1st Court (1976)28 DLR 469.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Under clause (a) election of returned candidate void and some other person elected Under clause (b) election as a whole void.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abul Hayat Vs. Narul Amin (1977)29 DLR (SC) 125.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—R. 60, clause (b)—”Election as a whole void’ explained.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The expression ‘election as a whole’ may be declared void’ means that if the election of a returned candidate for a particular office is declared void but no other candidate is declared elected in his place. then, the election for that office will fall through and a fresh election will be necessary, but this does not and cannot mean that the election to all other offices will also be void.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Siddique Ahmed Vs. Muns 1st Court (1976) 28 DLR 470</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rr. 60 &amp; 62—</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">In circumstances coming under r. 6(1) no necessity for fresh election and in cases falling under r. 60(2) fresh election necessary.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Syed Mofazzal Hossain Vs. Election Commissioner (1976)28 DLR (SC) 51.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Election means to be the final act of selection of a person for a particular office and this right to office is ascertained on the basis of the highest aggregate number of votes which a candidate may have received at different stations set up for the said purpose. <em>   Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rule 61</strong>—Provision that Civil Procedure Code shall, as nearly as possible, be followed is trying g election cases, does not mean that where specific provisions exist in the Rules they shall be superseded by the provisions of C. P. Code—Regarding deposit of money, specific provisions are provided in the Rules and as such they shall strictly be followed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdul Malek Vs. Election Tribunal (1977) 29 DLR 222.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Rules 61A and 61B</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—Election Tribunal not to be treated as a Civil Court except for a specified purpose. </span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Muzahiduddin Ahmed Vs. Munsif, Sunamganj (1976) 28 DLR 189.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The Election Tribunal not being a Civil Court, it has no power to grant temporary injunction under Order 39 rule I of the Code of Civil Procedure. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rule 62</strong>—Presiding Officer in an election is alone competent to recount ballot-papers—Election Tribunal can recount ballot papers only when election dispute can not be disposed of without a recounting of ballot papers in the presence of both the parties.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Amizuddin Ahmed Vs. Election Tribunal (1975) 27 DLR 594</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rule 62(2)—</strong>When election in a particular polling centre is declared void, it does not mean the elections in other polling centers are also void and must be set aside.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Syed Mofazzal Hossain Vs. The Election Commr. (1976) 28 DLR (SC) 51.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Demand for recording reasons the Election Tribunal’s decisions on each ballot over-ruled. Ballots recounted in presence of the parties—no objection regarding formal proof—cannot be raised after closure of evidence. Failure to demand recount before Presiding Officer and giving up demand before Returning Officer—no bar for recount by the Tribunal—Returning Officer not empowered to recount.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Kafezuddin Mia Vs. Election Tribunal (1975) 27 DLR (SC) 118.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Before setting aside the election, Tribunal must decide that its result has been vitiated by some illegalities. <em>SM Hossain Vs. Election Commr. (1976) 28 DLR (SC) 51.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rule 64—Deposit under rule 64 relates to a different matter.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Deposit under rule 64 relates to a different matter. Though the money ultimately went into the Treasury, it would not be possible for the Tribunal to trace it out and connect the same with the case before it. The Election Tribunal got no power to pass any order in respect of any deposit made in the Civil Court, though the Munsif acts as the Election Tribunal.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdul Malek Vs. Election Tribunal (1976) 28 DLR 467.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2425	None
None
2426	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Validation of Law Act, 1955</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1956) 8 DLR 429, (1956) 8 DLR (FC) 91, (1956)8 DLR 457</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Validation of Law </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Validation of Law Act, 1955</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 3</strong>— Section 3 of the Validation Act makes section 223A Government of India (Amendment) Act, 1954, operative from 2nd October, 1955 on which date Validation Act came into force.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>SM Wali Ahmed Chowdhury Vs. Mahfuzul Huq Chowdhury (1956) 8 DLR 429.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Secs. 4 and 5—</strong> Section 5 operates as bar to jurisdiction of courts to call in question validity of Acts declared valid by section 4.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Punjab Province Vs. Malik Khizir Haya Khan Tiwana (1956) 8 DLR (FC) 91.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Validation of Laws Act, 1956 which validates certain existing laws is not prospective and valid in the sense that it validates the existing laws even if they come into conflict with the Constitution for which the legislation could not possibly provide in anticipation.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Jibendra Kishore Acharya Vs. Province of East Pakistan (1956)8 DLR 457.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—It cannot be argued that Articles 4 and 5 of the Constitution which is supreme cannot render pre-excising law void if it is repugnant to and comes into conflict with these Articles of the Constitution because of the provisions of Article 15 and those of Validation Act, 1956. <em>   Ibid.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2427	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Village Courts Ordinance, 1976</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1980) 32 DLR 8,  (1981) 33 DLR 201, (1980) 32 DLR 292, (1980)32 DLR 9, (1980) 32 DLR 221, (1983) 35 DLR 100. </p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Village Courts </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><em> </em></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Village Courts Ordinance</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;">(LXI of 1976)</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 3(i)—Title to immovable property beyond the jurisdiction of Village Courts but possession thereof can be recovered through such Courts.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Civil suits which may be heard by the Village Court have been shown in Part II of the Schedule. Suit for title to an immovable property stands excluded there from; but possession of such an immovable property may be recovered by the Village Court subject to establishment of title by an independent suit as indicated in section 3(3) of the Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdul Hoque Vs. Mokbul Hossain Mollah and anr. (1980) 32 DLR 8.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 5 (Part II of the Schedule)</strong> Party claimed Taka 1000.00 as compensation for forceful dispossession from his property—Transfer of the case by the S.D.O. illegal—Village Court can not decide question of title to the property.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Sekandar Ali Sardar Vs. Chairman, Village Court (1981) 33 DLR 201</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 8—Decisions of Village Courts when cannot be questioned</strong>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The question is whether the Supreme Court or for that matter any Civil Court got jurisdiction to question the decision of a Village Court when the decision is unanimous or by majority of four to one members of the said Court. Section 8 of the Village Courts Ordinance provides that if the decision of a Village Court is unanimous or by a majority of four to one, the decision shall be binding on the parties and shall be enforceable in accordance with the provisions of this Ordinance; but if the decision of a Village Court is by a majority of three to two, any party may, within thirty days of decision, apply to the Sub divisional Magistrate, in the case of an offence specified in Part I of the Schedule of the Ordinance, and to the Munsif in respect of a matter specified in Part II of the Schedule. The impugned decision of the Village Court cannot be questioned by any court, civil or criminal.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdul Hoque Vs. Mokbul Hossain Mollah (1980) 32 DLR 8.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 15 (Part I of the Schedule)—Transfer of a (criminal) case by the S.D.O.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Section 15 of Village Courts Ordinance shows that a Sub-Divisional Magistrate can transfer a case relating to Part I of the Schedule provided the Sub- Divisional Magistrate considers that the public interest and the ends of justice demands Its trial in a criminal court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Sekandar Ali Sarker Vs. Chairman, Village Court (1981)33 DLR 201.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 15(1)—</strong>Village Court’s order decreeing the suit passed in contravention of the S. D. 0’s order staying further proceeding, even if not aware of ii, is illegal—Such decree will have to be set aside by a competent court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Zillur Rahman Sarkar Vs. Abu Bakkar Siddique @ Siddique Ali Pk (1980) 32 DLR 292.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Schedule Part I.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Offence of theft—Village Court can award compensation</strong>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Theft by removal of any movable property which is punishable under section 379 of the Penal Code is triable by the Village Court which may award only compensation. In a suit on similar facts the Village Court may also direct payment of compensation for wrongfully taking or damaging a movable property.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdul Haque Vs. Maqbul Hossain Mollah (1980)32 DLR 9.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Civil Court has no jurisdiction over Village Court’s decision awarding compensation for removal of paddy—Remedy may be sought under Article 102 of the Constitution of Bangladesh. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Village Courts (Amendment) Ordinance (VIII of 1978)</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong>(Schedule Part I)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The Village Court Ordinance provides that a case u/s. 379 BPC was triable by the Village Court when the property involved did not exceed 5000/-</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">By subsequent Ordinance No. 8 of 1978 dated 13.2.78 the value of the property involved in a case u/s. 379 BPC triable by the Village Court was raised to Tk. 5,000/-</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The learned Sub-divisional Magistrate had no jurisdiction to take cognizance of offence u/s. 379 PC on 26.12.76. Offence u/s. 147 BPC is made Ui- able by a Village Court when the persons involved did not exceed 10.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Only 10 persons being involved in the present case on a charge u/s. 147 of the Penal Code the offence is triable by the Village Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abul Kalam Vs. Abdul Mazid (1980) 32 DLR 221.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Village Courts (Amendment) Ordinance (IV of 1979)</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Item 3 of Part I of the Schedule.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Village Court’s jurisdiction to try cases for theft where the property involved is valued at Tic. 5000.00—Magistrate trying a case of theft the value of the property involved being less than Tk. 5000.00—Magistrate has no jurisdiction—The order of Conviction by the Magistrate being illegal provision of s. 529 CrP Code cannot be called in and in support of Magistrate’s order.</p><p><em>Akhtar Rahim Vs. State, Sultan Ahmed, son of Miajan Mollah (1983) 35 DLR 100.<span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></em></p></div></div>
2428	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Wakfs Ordinance, 1962</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1968) 20 DLR 535, (1976) 28 DLR 233, (1977) 29 DLR (SC) 276, (1967) 19 DLR 65, (1975) 27 DLR (SC) 138, (1983) 35 DLR 277, (1984) 36 DLR 56, (1965) 17 DLR 46, (1984) 36 DLR 56, (1977) 29 DLR (SC) 276, (1965)17 DLR 46,  (1970)22 DLR 781, (1976) 28 DLR 333</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Wakfs </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>  <br/></em></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Wakfs Ordinance (I of 1962)</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 27(a) &amp; 52</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">— Administrator’s power to call for account of the wakf property not limited to one year only under section 52 of the Ordinance.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The Mutawalli has been directed to submit accounts of wakf estates annually to the Administra tor. This does not restrict the powers of the Administrator from asking for accounts of wakf estates from the Mutawallis beyond the period of one year, because, in view of section 27(a), one of the powers of the Administrator shall be to investigate and determine the nature and extent of wakfs and wakf properties and calling from time to time for accounts, returns and information from Mutawallis. This is a power given to the Administrator in general and wide terms, and under this provision, if not under section 52(a), the Administrator is given am- pie authority to call for accounts of the wakf estate from the Mutawalli either present or past<em>. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Yar Ali Khan Chowdury Vs. Administrator of Wakfs (1968) 20 DLR 535.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 29 and 30</strong>—Administrator can revise any provision of a Wakf deed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Section 29 read with section 30 of the Ordinance empowers the Administrator to revise any provision of the wakf-deed which has become inoperative owing to efflux of time and changed conditions.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Abdul Jabbar Vs. Asia Khatun (1976) 28 DLR 233.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—When passing an order u/s. 32 (1) the Administrator of Wakfs acts judicially and any such order passed without giving an opportunity to the party affected by the order to be heard will not be a judicial order.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Shaukat Ali Vs. Administrator of Wakfs (1977) 29 DLR (SC) 276.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Section 43 of the Act has no application where there is removal of a Mutawalli under section 32. When a Mutawaili is removed under section 32 the office falls vacant and calls for an appointment.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>A. S Rashid Bakht Mazumdar Vs. Mukhtar Bakht Mazumdar (1967) 19 DLR 65.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—It could not be shown from any provision of the EP Wakf Ordinance that a suit even if it be of a civil nature would not lie in a civil court of ordinary jurisdiction.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Dildar Ahmed Vs. Farroque Ahmed (1975) 27 DLR (SC) 138.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Any matter not envisaged in the provisions of s. 32 for the purpose of removing a Mutwalli from his office, his removal will be illegal.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mrs. Nadira Rahman. Vs. Sayed Mir Hossain (1983) 35 DLR 277.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Section 32 enacts penal measures against the Mutwalli.<em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Proceeding before Wakf Administrator who functions as a court of law should be in keeping with the norm and procedure of a court<em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Removal of a Mutawalli on grounds stated in section 32 of the Wakfs Ordinance. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Administrator’s order passed u/s. 32 is subject to appeal to the District Judge and the latter’s order fell under the revisional jurisdiction of the High Court Division.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Golam Ataher Chowdhury Vs. Administrator of Wakfs (1984) 36 DLR 56.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Ss. 32 &amp; 38</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—Proceedings for removal of Mutawalli by the Administrator arc of civil nature and are to be conducted in a manner obtaining in Civil Court. In the enquiry sufficient materials must be brought on record so as to enable the Appellate Tribunal to examine them and give its decision as to the correctness of the order of removal. Contending parties must have fair opportunity of placing their cases in regard to the dispute. </span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Nuruzzaman Vs. Secretary (1965) 17 DLR 46.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Ss. 32 and</strong> 43—Administrator of Waqfs is a court subordinate to the civil Court or the High Court Division only in respect of orders he passes under sections 32 of the Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Golam Ataher Chowdhury Vs. Administrator of Wakfs (1984) 36 DLR 56.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Ss. 32, 43 and 44</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—An order u/s. 32 removing a mutawalli is appealable before the District Judge whose order is open to revision by the High Court Division. An order appointing a mutwalli u/s 43 is appealable to the District Judge whose order is final. No appeal or revision lies against an order passed u/s. 44. <em>   Ibid.</em></span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Ss. 32 and 44.-</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">When an order passed by the Administrator falls within the scope of s.44 it can not be attacked indirectly by bringing it under section 32 of the Ordinance. <em> Ibid.</em></span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—S. 32(I)—</strong>Administrator of Wakf acts as a civil court regarding removal of  mutwalli.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Shauket Ali Vs. Administrator of Wakfs (1977) 29 DLR (SC) 276.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Sections 37 &amp; 38 read with s. 32 (1)</strong> provide necessary guideline for conduct of proceeding falling u/s 32. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Ss. 32(1) &amp; 61(h)—</strong>It is doubtful whether non-payment of dues of the beneficiaries by the MulawaLli in the absence of convictions more than once under section 61 warrants his removal from office under section 32.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Nuruzzaman Chowdhury Vs. Secretary, Education Department, Govt of East Pakistan (1965)17 DLR 46..</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—S. 32(2)—</strong>The remedy of appeal provided in sub-section (2) of section 32 of the Ordinance is not an adequate remedy to obviate the necessity to have recourse to Article 98 of the Constitution.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">As the remedy of appeal provided in sub-section (2) of section 32 is conditioned by the fact that the appellant has to make over possession before filing the appeal, it is not an adequate remedy within the meaning of Article 98. It is certainly more inconvenient than the remedy provided in Article 98 and in that view of the matter at least it is not an adequate remedy. <em>   Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Right of appeal by a Mutawalli— when available.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Right of appeal conferred under section 32(2) is available to any person who functions as a MutawalIi and is then removed by the Administrator of Wakfs in pursuance of the power given under section 32(1).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The persons who are appointed Mutawalli under sub-section (4) of section 32 as well as under section 43 are entitled to prefer an appeal under sub-section (2) of section 32 if their removal is ordered by the Administrator of Wakfs under the powers conferred on him by section 32(1).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>AJM Asadullah Vs. AKM Ahmad-ul-Huq (1970)22 DLR 781.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 32(2),(3)—</strong>Decision of the Wakf Administrator can be revised by the District Judge u/s 32(2) or on revision by the High Court u/s. 32(3).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Adbul Jabbar Vs. Asia Khatun (1976) 28 DLR 333.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 34</strong>—The words “notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Ordinance” in sec. 34 of the Ordinance do not exclude the attraction of the provisions of sections 37 and 39. If these three sections are read together, the only meaning that appears to follow is that section 34 only gives the power to the administrator to take over possession of any wakf property. The procedure to be followed for doing so has been laid down in sections 37 and 39. The provisions contained in sections 37 and 39, therefore, do not go counter to the provisions of section 34. They are rather supplementary to the provisions of section 34.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Maqbulal Haq Vs. Administrator of Wakfs (1965) 17 DLR 30.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Ss. 34(4) &amp; 43—</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Mutawalli appointed by the Administrator of Wakfs under sections 32(4) and 43 is only to function as a Mutawalli in a stop-gap arrangement as an acting Mutawalli until a regular appointment is made in accordance with the provisions of Muslim Personal Law—Such appointment will not disentitle any other competent person to bring proper action for an appointment of regular and permanent Mutawalli. </span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>AJM Asadullah Vs. AKM Ahmad-ul-Huq (1970)22 DLR 781.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 35</strong>—Appeal provided under section 35 of EP Wakf Ordinance not an adequate remedy.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The provisions regarding appeal provided in section 35 of the Ordinance cannot be considered to be adequate within the meaning of Article 98 of the Constitution. In an appeal under section 35, Mulawalli or any person claiming any interest in the property can only agitate that the property in question is not a wakf property.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Maqbulal Huq Vs. Administrator of Waqfs (1965) 17 DLR 3O.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Mutawalli before being removed must be given an opportunity to be heard which is a personal right to him. <em>AS Rashid Bakht Mazumdar Vs. Mukhtar Bakht Mazumdar (1967)19 DLR 65.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 35 &amp; 50</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—Administrator of Waqfs is authorized to decide whether a particular property is a waqf property or not and his decision can be challenged by the District Judge. <em>Syed Masud Ali Vs. Md. Asmatullah (1980132 DLR (AD) 39.</em></span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 37—</strong>Vexatious application not to be allowed—Power for examination and audit of account under this section limited to 3 years.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The proviso to section 37 of the Ordinance limits the power of examination and audit of accounts to a period of three years prior to the date of such application. From the provisions of this section, it is found no vexatious applications should be allowed to be made by any person interested in a wakf property or putting the ex-Mutawalli or a sitting Mutawalli to the doscomfiture of explaining his conduct with regard to the management of the property for a period of more than three years on charges of maladministration.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Yar Ali Khan Chowdhury Vs. Administrator of Wakfs (1968) 20 DLR 535.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Ss. 37 &amp; 39—[See under section 34 in case of Maqbulal Huq Vs. Administrator of Wakfs in (1965) 17 DLR 30 above.]</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 43—Administrator of Wakfs and District Judge may appoint a person Mutawalli temporarily only I. e., for a specified period.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Under section 43 of the Ordinance the Administrator of Waqfs and in case of an appeal, the District Judge, may appoint a person to act as Mutawalli only for a specified period which he deems fit in the circumstances of the case. It is obvious that the Administrator has been empowered to make a temporary appointment limited to a specified period. He cannot pass an indefinite order of appointment without any limitation as to the duration of the office of the Mutawalli appointed by him. The power of the District Judge in appeal is also similarly limited.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdul Jabbal Vs. Attahar Ali (1965) 17 DLR 246.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A revision to the High Court will lie against the decision of the District Judge in appeal under section 43 of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The Administrator of Waqfs appointed a Mutawalli without notice to the persons interested as required under section 43 of the Ordinance. The petitioner preferred an appeal to the District Judge against Administrator’s order and the District Judge upheld the decision of the Administrator. The petitioners thereafter moved the High Court on revision. It was contended that the District Judge was a ‘persona designata’ and did not act as a Court and as such no revision lies against his order before the High Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held:</strong> There is no real antithesis between the expressions ‘persona designata’ and ‘Court’. Even a persona designata may be a Court which depends upon his powers and the functions which he has to discharge.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In the present case the appeal has got all the ingredients of an appeal and the District Judge is to determine the rights of the parties as contemplated under section 43 of the Ordinance. That being so the revisional application is competent.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Khurshed Alam Vs. Amir Sultan Ali Haider (1969) 21 DLR 799</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—When functions performed are judicial functions even though a Court has been described by official designation it acts as a Court. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The words “District Judge” in section 43 of die Ordinance includes the Additional District Judges also in respect of disposal of appeals under that section. Therefore, an appeal as contemplated in section 43 of the Ordinance could be heard and disposed of by an Additional District Judge and no illegality has been committed in the present case because the same has been so disposed of by the Additional District Judge.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Forrukh Ahmed Vs. Nazir Ahmad alias Badsha Mia (1973) 25 DLR 225</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Administrator’s power of appointing a Mutawalli when there is none or for any other reasonable grounds.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Abdul Jabbar Vs. Asia Khatun (1976) 28 DLR 333.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Administrator can also override the terms of a wakf-deed—</strong>Section 43 of the Ordinance further empowers the Administrator to override the terms of the wakf-deed for appointment of Mutawalli, if there appears to him any impediment to the appointment of Mutawalli in terms of the wakf-deed. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—District Judge—</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Expression ‘District Judge’ as occurs in section 32 of the Wakfs Ordinance means Court and not a persona designata. <em> Ibid.</em></span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—District Judge’s function in disposing of an appeal against an order of Administrator of Wakfs—</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">In hearing an appeal from the order of the Administrator of Wakfs made under this section the District Judge is required to decide a dispute regarding the right to the office of MutawalIl claimed by two or more parties. This he can only do after hearing them and taking such evidence as may be considered necessary and also after hearing arguments on both facts and law which he is supposed to interpret and apply. </span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Amir Sultan Ali Hyder Vs. Md. K Alam (1977) 29 DLR (SC) 295.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—District Judge has the same legal power as the Administrator u/s. 43 in appointing a Mutawalii. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—District Judge’s decision though made final is however open to revision by the High Court. <em>   Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Administrator of Wakf is without powers to remove a Mutwalli, he can, however, appoint one in certain contingencies. <em>   Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—In case of dispute as to who will be the Mutawalli, the Administrator while appointing Mulawalli for a specified period has to refer the parties to a Civil Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Altaf Miah. Vs. Md.</em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> <em>Anwar Hossain (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 108.</em></span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Contest between the two claimants could not be treated as an impediment as contemplated in section 43. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Appointment of Mutawalli u/s. 43 is for a temporary period only—</strong>Mutawalli, appointment of—Principle generally followed in case of vacancy in the office of Mutawalli, a member of the Wakif’s family will be preferred and a senior member in preference of a junior. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—As against the Administrator’s order u/s. 43 appointing a Mutawalli, an appeal to the District Judge will lie, and then a revision against District Judge’s order will lie to the High Court Division.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Golam Ataher Chowdhury Vs. Administrator of Wakfs (1984) 36 DLR 56.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Ss. 43 &amp; 51—</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Appointment of a successor muuiwalli by the Administrator on the basis of an enquiry report by the Inspector of Waqfs—Administrator on the question of successor has to make a decision without referring the parties to civil Suit. </span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Altaf Miah Vs. Md. Anwar Hossain (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 108.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 44—Appointment of official mutawalli by the Administrator.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">By section 44 of the Waqf Ordinance, the Administrator has been empowered to appoint an ‘official mutawalli’, notwithstanding anything contained in this Ordinance or i,i any other law in force or in any deed or instrument, such as waqf deed. According to the waqf-deed, the appellant is a fit person for appointment as Mutawalli, and, in fact, he was so appointed. But provisions of section 44 override all other things contained either in the waqf-deed or elsewhere in this Ordinance. The appellant was appointed mutawalli by the Administrator in terms of the waqf-deed. But in view of the circumstances, as stated, the Administrator modified his earlier order appointing the appellant as mutawalli and proceeded to appoint a committee of five persons to act as Mutawalli under section 44.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Golam Ataher Chowdhury Vs. The Administrator of Waqfs (1984) 36 DLR (AD) 203.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The word “an official mutawalli” in sA4 of the Ordinance include also a number of Mutawallis, whenever found necessary, for the management of the waqf estate. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 47, 49 &amp; 50</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—Mere enrolment of a property as a waqf u/s. 47 or u/s. 49 is not a decision u/s. 50. </span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Syed Masud Ali Vs. Md. Asmatullah (1980)32 DLR (AD) 40.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 47(2) (Ss. 34 and 35).</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">“A person interested in the waqf and “any person claiming any interest in the property”. Difference between the two expressions. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—An application for enrolment can be made by “a person interested in the waqf” and that expression has been defined in the definition clause. But if we refer to section 35, we find that along with the Mueawalli the other person who has been given the right to challenge the notification made under section 34 is “any person claiming any interest in the property”. A comparison of these two expressions in these two sections with reference to the expression used in proviso to section 50 clearly shows three different expressions have been used in the same statute. The Legislature in the same statute has in different context used different expressions. It is a well- accepted principle of interpretation that where different language is used in the same statute different intention is to be presumed unless there is in the context anything to hold to the contrary. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 50</strong>—The expression “any person aggrieved” in sec. 50 means any person who is interested to challenge the order made under this sub-section. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—“In question’—What the word “question” means. The word “question” in section 50 of the Waqf Ordinance means that either there is some challenge or some dispute regarding the character of the waqf property or some determination of the waqf character of the property is in question. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Mere enrolment of a property as waqf under section 47 or 49 is not a decision under section 50 of the Ordinance as to waqf character of the property. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—A petition envisaged under section 50 of the Ordinance lies only when a person is aggrieved by any decision or order of the Administrator.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In the present case, the Administrator’s order was directed against the Mutawalli alone and so far as the Khadims were concerned the order was passed ex-parte and the Khadims were not given the opportunity of being heard.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">This being the position the Khadims has no cause of action for presenting a petition under section 50 as the order was not binding on them.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Administrator of Wakfs Vs. Mohammad Irfan Mia (1968)20 DLR 150.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The Administrator has been authorized to decide whether a property is waqf or not when such a question is agitated. The persons involved in disputing such property may be person not interested in the waqf and person who is a total stranger to the waqf.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Syed Masud Ali Vs. Md. Asmatullah (1980) 32 DLR (AD) 39.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Administrator’s jurisdiction attracted when dispute is whether a property is waqf or not—Then question to be decided by the Administrator within a reasonable time. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Expression “Any person interested” in S. 50 may be a person not interested in the waqf. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Proviso—</strong>”Any person aggrieved” means any person interested to challenge the Order made u/s. 50. <em>   Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 51—</strong>A prospective Mutawalli, upon the death or removal of a Mutawalli, is required to notify the change to the Administrator.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Amir Sultan Ali Hyder Vs. Md. K Alam (1977) 29 DLR (SC</em>) <em>295.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 52</strong>—Every Mutawalli is bound to render accounts for the period he is either singly or jointly in charge of the estate not necessarily for the purpose of detection of mal-administration.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Yar Ali Khan Chowdhury Vs. Administrator of Wakfs (1968) 20 DLR 535.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 53</strong>—Allegation against a Mutawalli about breach of trust is subject to the scrutiny by the auditor u/s. 53—A Magistrate acts illegally if he assumes powers of scrutiny vested in an auditor u/s. 53.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Showkat Rabbani Vs. Md. Showkat Osmani (1983) 35 DLR 176.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A charge of criminal breach of trust against a Mutawalli could only be maintained after an adjustment of account. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Vague allegations against the Mulawalli as to his failure to disburse dues to the beneficiaries or other act of misappropriation by him do not make out a case of breach of trust.<em>   Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 64</strong>—Section 4(1) of the Waqf Ordinance provides for eviction of trespassers to waqf land—In a case where the Administrator of Waqf prayed for eviction of the trespassers under section 64(1) of the Ordinance, the Magistrate has got no jurisdiction to draw up a proceeding under section 107 C.r.P.C. against such trespassers ignoring the specific provision of section 64(1) of the Ordinance which provides for eviction of trespassers.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Hashi Meah Vs. Aminut Islam Chowdhury (1971) 23 DLR 184</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—S. 64(1)—</strong>Where persons alleged to have trespassed into the waqf land are in fact in possession of the land in assertion of their right of claim over the land it is not proper to draw proceeding against them under section 107 CrPC.<em>   Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 83—Administrator has no power to fix rent of a wakf property which is to be done by resort 10 Civil Court.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The Administrator has no authority to assess the rental of the wakf property. On the other hand, under the provisions of section 83 of the Ordinance, whenever it becomes necessary for the Mutawalli or for the Administrator to realise any money due to the wakf property, resort has to be taken to institute a suit or proceeding in a Court either against a stranger to the wakf or against any other person.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Yar Au Khan Chowdhury Vs. Administrator of Wakfs (1968) 20 DLR 535.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 102</strong>—The deed shows that the wafk has earmarked the income amounting to Rs. 19,200/- to be spent for maintenance of his descendants. The Mutawalli has no discretion but to carry Out the direction of the wakif in terms of the wakf deed. This amount is devoted to the purposes of the wakf al-alaulad and according to the terms of the deed ‘applied’ to said purpose.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Director of Taxation Vs. Mehdi Ali Khan Panni (1980) 32 DLR (AD) 140.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—If the Mutawalli or trustee has set apart or deemed to have set apart the income of the wakf-alal-aulad according to the direction of the donor, he has devoted it for the purpose of said wakf, and therefore he has ‘applied’ the income ‘thereto’ for the purpose of the wakf.<em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 102—Provisions in the Waqf Ordinance to be followed excluding those of CP Code.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The Waqf Ordinance being a special statute providing a special procedure to be followed the cognizance of the Civil Court is to that extent excluded. The exclusion is again enacted in section 102 of the Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Syed Masud Ali Vs. Md. Asmatullah (1980)32 DLR (AD) 140</em>.<span id="pastemarkerend"></span></p></div></div>
2429	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Wealth Tax Act &amp; Wealth Tax Rules</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 93, (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 99</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Wealth Tax </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Wealth Tax Act (I of 1977)</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 7(1)(2)—Computation of the Value Assets.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Section 7 of the Wealth Tax Act (I of 1972) gives the power to the Wealth Tax Officer for computation of the value of the assets and it is divided into two sub-sections (1) and (2) but if he does the one he must follow the rules framed for the purpose.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Commissioner of Income Tax, Dacca Vs. Adamjee Sons Ltd. (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 93.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Wealth Tax Officer cans lake recourse to one of the methods of valuation, but not both. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 7(2)—</strong>Computation u/s. 7(I) on the ground of “as the circumstances may require” not permissible.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The discretion that is given by the expression “as the circumstances may require” occurs in sub section (2) and not for sub-section (I). The Wealth Tax Officer in computing under section 7(2) can not take recourse to the discretion given by the expression “as the circumstances my require” for computing it under section 7(1). <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Wealth Tax Rules</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rule 8(3), 8(9</strong>)— Building of the Company come within the definition of the assets, and the single unit of residential house owned and occupied by assessec is excluded.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Commissioner of Taxes, Ctg. Zone, Ctg. Vs. M/s. Free School Street Properties Ltd. (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 99.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rule 8(9)—</strong>Where the nature of the activities of the assessee is business of trading it is rule 8(9) that is applicable and not rule 8(3) of the Wealth Tax Rules. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2430	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">West Pakistan Rules/Ordinances</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1969)21 PLD (Peshawar) 147, (1968) 20 DLR (SC) 300, (1970) 22 DLR (SC) 243, (1965) 17 DLR (WP) 81, (1967) 19 DLR (SC) 370,1965) .17 DLR (WP)1 </p><p><b>Subject:</b>  West Pakistan </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>West Pakistan Government Servants (Efficiency and Discipline) Rules, 1960</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>R. 2(5)—</strong>Expression “misconduct”—interpretation—Violation of Government instructions not relatable to service discipline—Does not constitute ‘misconduct’—Words, “instructions issued by Government” used in r.2(5)(ii), West Pakistan Government Servants (Efficiency and Discipline) Rules, 1960 not to be read separately but with the preceding words “breach of service discipline”—Expression “grave misconduct” appearing in r. 1.8(a), West Pakistan Civil Services Pension Rules, 1963— Interpretation something which must be in nature of an offence with guilty intent—Mere negligence or carelessness—Does not constitute ‘grave misconduct’.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Said Khan Vs. Govt. of West Pakistan (1969)21 PLD (Peshawar) 147.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>West Pakistan Government Servants (Further Usefulness in Public Service) Rules, 1963</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Provision for retirement on completing 55th year of age made by Art. 178(4)(c) can be enforced only prospectively and not retrospectively.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Orders of retirement of the respondents (who are employees under the West Pakistan Provincial Government) from service were passed by the Provincial Administration under the authority of rules framed under Article 178(2) of the Constitution by the Governor of West Pakistan.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The orders were passed after the incumbents in question had passed the stage of 25 years qualifying service or, in some cases, even after he had passed his 55th year of age and before anyone of them had reached the superannuation age of 60.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">On the 23rd of October, 1960, clause (9) was added Lo Article 6 of the Order. By sub-clause (a) of this clause it was enacted that the superannuation age of a person would be the age on which he attains his sixtieth birthday. The position earlier was that the superannuation age had been fixed at fifty-five.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Purporting to act under Article 178(2) of the1962 Constitution, the Governor of West Pakistan made Rules, called the West Pakistan Government Servants (Further Usefulness in Public Service) Rules, 1963.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">On the basis of the Rules framed by the Governor, it was argued that the Provincial Government servants were under the liability of having their cases dealt with in the manner provided by the proviso to rule 4, even under clause (9) of Article 6 of the Laws (Continuance in force) Order.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held</strong>: We arc unable to accede to this argument as correct. It is undoubted true that under the Order the Governor could have framed rules under sub-clause (d) of clause (9) of Article 6, providing for a power to retire officers even after they had passed the two stages of twenty-five years qualifying service and the fifty-fifth year of age. This amounted, however, merely to the possibility of a law being framed, under which the respondents could have become liable to such action. No such liability, could be said to have accrued unless the law had been properly framed and enforced.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Govt. of West Pakistan Vs. Karamatullah Khan Muslim (1968) 20 DLR (SC) 300.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Rule 4, proviso—</span></strong>Proviso to rule 4 violative of Arts. 178(3) and 234 of the Constitution of Pakistan, 1962.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Till the commencing day of the new Constitution, no law existed, under which orders of retirement of the respondents could have been passed, after any one of them had passed the twenty-five years qualifying stage of service or the fifty-fifth year of age, as the case may be. The position clearly was that till that day, the only liability of the respondents was one of being retired at either of the two preliminary stages mentioned above or failing that to continue in service fill the normal superannuation age of sixty.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The proviso to rule 4 must be held to be violative of the provisions of clause (3) of Article 178 and Article 274 of the Constitution, which contain solemn guarantees of continuity of the old terms and conditions, obtaining prior to the enforcement of the Constitution, to the respondents.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Govt. of West Pakistan Vs. Karamatullah Khan Muslim (1968) 20 DLR (SC) 300.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>West Pakistan (Non-Gazetted) Civil Service Pay Revision Rules, 1959</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>R. 18—</strong>Service Pay Revision Rules, 1959 revised the pay scales of all Govt. Servants (non- gazette) giving retrospective effect from 14th October 1955.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Respondents post not being included in the list, Govt. by a notification included his post in the list revising his pay scale in pursuance of the Pay Revision Rules, 1959 but denied to give the benefit of retrospective effect of the revised scale to the respondent with effect from 14th October, 1955.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held:</strong> Government cannot deny the benefit of retrospective effect of the revised pay scale to the respondent.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>West Pakistan Govt. Vs. Abdul Khaliq. (1970) 22 DLR (SC) 243.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>West Pakistan Maintenance of Public Order Ordinance (XXXI of 1960)</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 3 and 5</strong>—When detention is challenged as illegal provision under Article 98 can be invoked. Court not to question the sufficiency of the case which was the basis of the authority’s satisfaction, but the Court can look into the grounds of detention to satisfy itself that on the grounds which are the basis of detention the authority could be satisfied as to the correctness of order of detention and the Court must satisfy itself that authority has not exceeded its limit.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">No reasons for detention have been made out in the present case—Detentions held to be without Lawful authority.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Farid Ahmad Vs. Government of West Pakistan (1965) 17 DLR (WP) 81.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>West Pakistan Union Councils and Town Committees (Election of Chairman) Rules, 1965</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Voter’s reference to the Presiding Officer to show where to mark the ballot paper does not violate secrecy.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The voter’s reference to the Presiding Officer for assistance as to how he should mark his paper clearly does not constitute violation of secrecy. His appearance before the Controlling Officer and the evidence he gave does indeed expose the fact that the disputed vote was cast by him, but this was for a subsequent and collateral purpose, namely, the election petition, and does not, in any way, affect the secrecy under which the vote was cast.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Muhammad Asghar Vs. Altaf Hussain (1967) 19 DLR (SC) 370.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>West Pakistan Use Of Loud-Speakers (Prohibition) Ordinance (XXXI of 1963)</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 2</strong>—The right to use parks for discussion or communication of view on public matters, especially those relating to national affairs, cannot be denied by the State to the citizens, though these rights are subject to the exigencies of law and order and the maintenance of peace and tranquility.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The use of loud-speakers is a necessary accompaniment of public speaking and indispensable instrument of effective public speech. The denial of permission to use a loud speaker means a denial of the right to communicate one’s views and thoughts even to those who want to hear them.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The right of citizen to be heard and to communicate one’s views on religious, political and other subjects is placed in the uncontrolled discretion of the Deputy Commissioner which renders the power conferred violative of the guarantee provided in the ninth fundamental right.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Khawaja Muhammad Safdor Vs. Province of West Pakistan (1965) .17 DLR (WP)1.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2431	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Will</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1949)1 DLR (PC) 5, (1952) 4 DLR 400, (1950) 2 DLR 247 (PC), (1955) 7 DLR (FC) 165, (1960) J2DLR 788,  (1983)35 DLR (AD) 315, (1984) 36 DLR (AD) 156, (1956) 8 DLR 19 (PC), (1956)8 DLR 48 (PC), (1953)5 DLR 197 (PC),  (1957) 9 DLR (SC) 139(148), (1958)10 D</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Will</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Will</u></strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Will When takes effect.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A will takes effect on the death of the executant and during his lifetime is an ambulatory document revocable at any moment, having no legal effect whatsoever. It is a secret and confidential document which the executants is never ordered to produce. In India where a will may be deposited with the Registrar, under the Indian Registration Act, the terms of the Act ensures that the contents remain secret until the death of the executants.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Hubert James Vs. Gulam Husain Paksuma (1949)1 DLR (PC) 5.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Admission made in a will.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The scope of an admission made in a will by living person must be determined by not only with reference to the whole document in which it appears, but also in the light of the fact that the document was not intended to take effect until the death of the person making the admission. There is no justification for treating such an admission as admitting the existence of a partnership effective before the death</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">of the testator with all the consequences which would flow from such a relationship. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Construction of—</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">The rule of construction generally is that a will must be read as a whole to ascertain there from the intention of the Testator and having so ascertained that intention must be given effect to so far as legally possible. </span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Joy Kumar Dutta Vs. Sita Nagh Dutta (1952) 4 DLR 400.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Genuineness Proof—Signature of testator disputed.</strong> Disputed signature appearing to have been written somewhat slowly with small breaks.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Manner of signature not inconsistent with testator’s state of health at the time-No expert evidence adduced to prove genuineness of hand-writing—Their Lordships were not satisfied only upon comparison of disputed signature with admitted signature of the deceased testator that the disputed signature did not look like the accepted ones.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Gamnamaneedi Madhavayya Vs. Gamnamaneedi Achamma (1950) 2 DLR 247 (PC).</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Attesting witness—Evidence of—</strong> Evidence of attesting witness who was a registered medical practitioner of 15 years standing attending on deceased testator—Witness also found to have attested earlier will of the testator—Witness a family doctor of testator for many years—His evidence that will was genuine could not be rejected because he belonged to rival faction in village. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Will executed on Saturday—Testator too ill to get the will registered on the very day—Next day Sunday—Will intended to be registered on Monday but testator dying on Sunday—No adverse inference could be drawn because of non registration of will, specially when the will did not require registration for its validity—Similarly, no adverse inference could be drawn from the fact that the will was not produced till when legatee’s title was impeached. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Mere registration cannot be regarded as to the voluntary nature of execution.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is true that mere registration cannot be regarded as in law, affording sufficient proof of the voluntary execution of the will much less of its being executed while of sound disposing mind by the Testator. Where there are circumstances of suspicion, it is the duty of the courts to accept such evidence with great caution, and only to the extent to which it goes.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Fate Mahamud Vs. Mst. Niamat (1955) 7 DLR (FC) 165.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Proof of registration proceedings raises the presumption that those proceedings were regular and honestly carried out and the evidence of due registration is itself such evidence of execution against the person against whom the document is sought to be proved. <em>   Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—In the courts in India a caution has been sounded to the effect that notwithstanding the value of the decisions in the cases of Tyrrell v. Painton and Pandock Barry v. James Butlim laying down the rule that when a will is sought to be propounded the onus of proof in every case lies on the person seeking to prove the will to satisfy conscience of the court that the instrument so propounded in the court is the last will of the testator, it must not be forgotten that the law is laid down in clear imperative terms by Acts of the Indian Legislature, and it is by the provisions of those Acts that a court must be guided.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Samarendra N Roy Vs. Suresh Ch.
