Roy (1960) J2DLR 788.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Testamentary capacity</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Where the executor died many years after the death of the testator and during his lifetime took no steps to prove the will, the transferees from the heirs of the executor obviously have no locus standi to come before the court for letters of administration especially where they cannot be held to be transferees from a universal or residuary legate.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In such a case although the will is found to be genuine and legally executed and attested, the suit must fail on the ground. that the heirs have no locus standi to file the same. <em>2 PLR (Dac.) 658.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Party setting up a will must prove that the Testator had sound disposing capacity—Presumption as to the testator’s capacity to execute the will.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Biswaswar Das Karmakar Vs. Sasanka Mohan Das Karmakar (1983)35 DLR (AD) 315.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Burden of proof on the person who propounds the will—Caution which a Court must take when the impounder happens to derive some interest under the will. <em>   Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—When a prominent part is taken by the propounded in the execution of the will that may constitute a suspicious circumstance. <em>   Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Mere registration is not sufficient to dispel suspicion—Close examination of evidence of registration is necessary. <em>   Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Delay: in propounding the will may constitute a suspicious circumstance though it may not be a ground for refusing grant of probate<em>.   Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Delay, in case of delay if delay is explained— No adverse conclusion can be drawn against granting probate. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Propounded of the will must himself prove that the. testator who executed the will was in sound mental condition, knew exactly what he was doing.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Paresh Chandra Bhowmik Vs. Hiralal Nath (1984) 36 DLR (AD) 156.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Rules governing proof of due execution of a will. The rules governing proof of due execution of a will which is charged with suspicion were examined by the Privy Council in the case of ‘Harmes v. Hinkson’ as referred to above. It was observed there.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">“Those rules enjoin a reasonable skepticism not an obdurate persistence in disbelief. They do not demand from the Judge, even in circumstance of grave suspicion, a resolute and impenetrable incredulity.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">He is never required to close his mind to the truth.” <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Witness</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">However excellent a judge’s note may be, the cases must be rare where no transcript being available, the appellate Court in a case involving the veracity of a witness can properly disturb the finding of the fact of the trial Judge who made the note.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Akbar Abdul Sattar Vs. WL Bogistra (1956) 8 DLR 19 (PC).</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Credibility—Trial Court considered witness as one of truth and appellate Court not finding reason to disturb that view—Witness to be treated as witness of truth.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Assena Marikar Vs. Alfred Weerasuriya (1956)8 DLR 48 (PC).</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—Advantage of the trial judge in seeing and hearing the witnesses, when of no value.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The advantage of the trial Judge in seeing and hearing the witnesses who deposed before him is perhaps not so great when the evidence is heard on three dates widely separated each from the other and when the judgment is written seven months after the last hearing.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Wills Pillai of Valvetiturai Vs. Thaialpayar (1953)5 DLR 197 (PC).</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Facilities to appear—</strong>No difficulties should be placed beyond the inevitable minimum in the way of persons appearing as witnesses.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Muhammad Saeed Vs. Election Petition Tribunal (1957) 9 DLR (SC) 139(148).</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Appreciation of the evidence.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is not proper for a court not to consider the evidence of witnesses on their merits but to reject them for reasons which should not commend themselves to a court of law. -</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The fact that a certain witness is interested in the result of the suit is no reason why evidence of the witness should be disbelieved.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Kalicharan Das Vs. Tamiruddin (1958)10 DLR 523.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2432	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Words and Phrases [A,B]</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1979)31 DLR 402, (1979)31 DLR (AD) 198, (1968)20 DLR 415, (1968) 20 DLR 174, (1980)32 DLR 99, (1982) 34 DLR 4, (1958) 10 DLR 69, (1959) 11 DLR (SC) 301, (1959) 11 DLR 133, (1959) 11 DLR 412, (1955) 7 DLR (FC) 291, (1952) 4 DLR 222, (1964) 16 DLR (SC) 62</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Words and Phrases</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong><u>Words and Phrases</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><u><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Abandoned Property</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A property is an abandoned property when it falls within the definition of abandoned property as given in P.O. 16/1972—Any property not abandoned can not be taken illegally<em>. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdul Hakim Vs. Secretary, Ministry of Public Works &amp; Urban Development (1979)31 DLR 402.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Accountability—Co-sharer.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Liability to account from legal relationship of agent and principal and trustee and cestui qui trust.— Responsibility to account not only for the amounts which have been actually received but also for that which with due diligence could be received does not rest on a co-sharer with no legal responsibility to undertake it<em>.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Jagna Chandra Nandy Mazumdar Vs. Hemania Shashi Nandy Mazumdar (1956) 8 DLR 121.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Accounts slated and settled.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Where accounts are submitted and accepted as correct, whether in writing or by conduct, presumption arises that accounts have been accepted as correct; even though there was no strict accounting and the liability, therefore, ceases.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Jagna Chandra Nandy Mazumdar Vs. Hemanta Shashi Nandy Mazumdar (1956) 8 DLRJ21 (128 rK. h. cot)</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Accretion to land</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—Accretion to the land of the riparian owner governed previously by the Alluvion and Diluvion Regulation (Bengal Reg. XI of 1825).</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The right of accretion in respect of a property, which was a part of the public domain and to which a riparian owner had previously no right was a creature, originally, of usage and, subsequently, of positive law. This rule was given legislative shape for the first time in Alluvion and Diluvion Regulation (Bengal Reg. XI of 1825);</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdul Mannan Vs. Kulada Ranjan (1979)31 DLR (AD) 198.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—“Accretion” —Accretion from the recess of the river—Accretion belongs to the person to whose estate it accretes.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">River runs through the estate of the defendants—Bed of the river is the land of the defendant— After acquisition of the defendant’s estate bed of the river became the defendant’s private property and unless it is shown by the Government that bed of the river has been acquired by it, presumption is it remains the land of the landlord (defendants.)</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Meser Gazi Vs. Abdul Gani Gazi (1968)20 DLR 415.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—“Acquisition”—Acquisition of citizens’ land—Authority concerned to be careful in the matter of acquisition.</strong> The officers of the Government who are responsible for this type of work, namely acquisition of land for public purposes, must be sufficiently educated, alert and mindful in the performance of their duties, because their actions in such matters affect the rights of the citizens. The discrepancy in the two notices with regard to quantum of land sought to be acquired might lead to very serious consequences. It might have affected the whole building. We do not know what actions have been taken by the authorities concerned against the officers who committed such mistakes or what action they propose to take against the defaulting officers, but we cannot help observe that the administration should he more careful in dealing with the rights of the citizens in matters like this.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Begum Lufunnessa Ibrahim Vs. Prov. of East Pak. (1968) 20 DLR 174</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>“Accrual of the right to sue” and “accrual of the cause of action.”</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The question is, is “accrual of the right to sue” synonymous with “accrual of cause of action” and does the right to sue accrue after one month of service of notice under section 109(1) of the Chittagong Port Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ordinarily the right to sue accrues immediately upon the accrual of cause of action. Thus, in Ballentine’s Law Dictionary (1948 edition) the legal meaning of “accrual of cause of action” is stated to be “the coming or springing into existence of a right to sue”.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>The Trustees of the Port of Chittagong Vs. SadharanB ima Corporation (1980)32 DLR 99.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Acquisition by the Government</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In assessing compensation for acquisition of land under both the Land Acquisition Act, 1894 and the East Bengal (Emergency) Requisition of Property Act, 1948 it cannot be said any longer that compensation can be had for a bigger amount on a more liberal provision under the former Act than under the latter. The matters to be considered in determining compensation, matters to be neglected in determining compensation and the rate at which properties arc to be valued are the same in both the two Acts.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Ismail &amp; 0’S. Vs. Bangladesh (1982) 34 DLR 4.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Government is the sole judge about the existence of urgency in taking possession of the land. If the question of urgency can be agitated, or, in other words, made justiciable in a Court of law, the very object of the Emergency Act will be frustrated.<em>   Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Acquisition for a Co-operative Society—</strong>can not be said to be an acquisition for public purpose—It is not an acquisition for the State or a private party.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Co-operative ownership is not State ownership nor is it a public enterprise. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">‘<strong>Acquisition’ and ‘Requisition’.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The word acquisition of land should be held to cover ‘requisition of land’. <em>Ajit Kumar Das Vs. Prov. of East Pakistan (1958) 10 DLR 69.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Act and subsequent Amendment</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">When a reference is made to any enactment which has been amended by subsequent amendments, the reference to the original Act with its original number would mean the Act as it stands on a particular day with all the amendments.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sui Gas Transmission Co. Vs. Islamic Republic of Pakistan (1959) 11 DLR (SC) 301.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Act of God</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">‘Act of God’ is a mere short way of expressing the proposition that a person is not liable for any accident as to which he can show that it is due to natural causes directly or exclusively without human intervention and that it could not have been prevented by any amount of foresight paid and care reasonably to he expected from him.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdul Rahman Abdul Gani Vs. United Oriental</em> <em>Steamship Co. (1959) 11 DLR 133.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Act (Legislative) and Rules—Conflict between the two.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Where changes in the rules have been effected by a non-legislative body under rule-making power the principle that rules or regulations cannot affect a provision of the Act is applicable even though it has to be considered as embodied in the Act and in case of conflict between a rule and provisions of the Act the latter prevails.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mansur Ali Vs. Member Board of Revenue (1959) 11 DLR 412.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ad-inconvenienti—Doctrine of—Applicability.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The greatest organs and agencies of the state have been consciously and unanimously holding a certain belief, and have been acting upon in numerous respects affecting the most fundamental rights of the entire people. It is beyond conception to tabulate all the vested rights and interests which have developed in consequence of this law. And there are many other laws which have produced extensive effects which cannot possibly be ascertained with exact mess. These circumstances should furnish an argument of almost insuperable character, in favour of upholding what has been the practice hitherto in regard to assent to constitutional laws.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Federation of Pakistan Vs. Tamijuddin Khan (1955) 7 DLR (FC) 291.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">‘<strong>Added land’</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Where Government assesses revenue upon land as being ‘added land’ within the meaning of Alluvion and Diluvion Act and plaintiff claims exemption from an assessment on the ground that it was part of his permanently settled estate, the onus is on the plaintiff to show that the land forms part of his permanently settled estate.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Prov, of Bengal Vs. Jamila Khatun Chowdhurani (1952) 4 DLR 222.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>“Adequate remedy” explained</strong>—Door of prerogative writ not closed unless the alternative remedy is equally inexpensive, expeditious and efficacious—Referring a party to file a lengthy suit when the same remedy can be had by invoking writ jurisdiction, not supportable<em>. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Abdul Karim Khan Vs. Commissioner Khulna Division (1964) 16 DLR (SC) 624.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Admiralty Jurisdiction of the High Court of East Bengal traced.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In 1890 the Admiralty Jurisdiction of the High Court of England was used to be exercised under the Admiralty Act of 1861 of the British Parliament which became the basis of the Admiralty jurisdiction of the High Court of Calcutta. The Admiralty rules framed by the High Court of Calcutta came into operation in June 1912.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Albert David (Bangladesh) Ltd. Vs. Messrs. Nediloyd Lijnen BV (1982) 34 DLR 356.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Jurisdiction of the High Court Division derived from the Colonial Court of Admiralty Act of 1891 and the Courts of Admiralty Act of 1861 of England. <em>   Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—High Court Division is a Court of Admiralty.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Under the Act of 1891 the High Court Division of this Court was declared as the Court of Admiralty. This Court exercises the same jurisdiction as the High Court of England exercised in 1890 under the Admiralty Court Act of 1861.<em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Admission : Admission to educational institution</strong>—Regulated by the express terms of the Prospectus of the Institution and the Government Instructions to the effect that, of the 2 States, each shall have one seat reserved for it in the institution for admission—No vested right accrues to one of the 2 States on the basis that for a long time in the past it has enjoyed the sole right of nominating both the seats for its own subjects.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Miss Nasim Banu Vs. Secy.. Ministry of home and Kashmir Affairs (1970) 22 DLR (WP) 321.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Adverse possession Co-sharers</strong>—What</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">constitutes adverse possession—Long undisturbed possession, payment of rents, enjoyment of profits and open dealings with the property indicate complete ouster of co-sharers.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mokbul Ahmed, Contractor Vs. Md. Idris (1969) 21 DLR 511.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Adverse possession—Co-tenants- </strong>when the interest of a co-tenant is purchased by a third person, such purchaser becomes a tenant in common with the other co-tenants and the possession of such co-tenants cannot, in the absence of clear proof to the contrary, be adverse to such purchaser.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sayed Abul Fazal Vs. Nirode</em> <em>Bala Deb Roy (1956) 8 DLR 181.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Advocates—</strong>Adverse remarks by the High Court Division touching their professional conduct—Expungement of The observations being extraneous to the merit of the appeals and having been directed solely against the professional conduct of the Advocates and the manner in which they had failed to discharge their obligations to their clients and to the Court cannot be kept on record as a part of the judgment and the observations in paragraphs 10-15 in entirety arc expunged.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mohammad Golam Rabbani Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh (1979) 31 DLR (AD) 163.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Affidavit .: Verification of affidavit— where the petitioner is a public trust</strong>— Where a petitioner is a public trust, a wilt petition on behalf of the public trust, when verified by the estate officer of the trust who is conversant with the facts of the case is a substantial compliance with the provisions of rule 4 of Part I of the High Court Rules.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Kumudini Welfare Trust of Bengal Vs. Province of Ease Pak. (1961)13 DLR 693.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">“Affidavit”—Filed by officers and prepared on the basis of records and not on personal knowledge—Cannot be relied on by a Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mritunjoy Paul Vs. Province of East Pakistan (1962) 14 DLR 568.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—An affidavit sworn by a director of a company before one of the commissioners of the High Court at Calcutta who is not authorized to act as a commissioners for oaths and affidavits in regard to proceeding in the Dhaka High Court is receivable in evidence in the direction of Court for the purpose of proceedings in the High Court at Dhaka.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Where such an affidavit had been sworn before a commissioner of the Nigh Court at Calcutta a fresh court-fee stamp cannot be charged on the affidavit when the affidavit is sought to be used in the Dhaka High Court. <em>53 CWN (DR 1) 71.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Agent</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Decree as against the agent without the owner on whose behalf he acted—Can not be passed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Albert David (Bangladesh) Ltd. Vs. M/S.</em> <em>Brosterm Shipping Co. Ltd. (1982) 34 DLR 363.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Agent not bound to carry an order of his principal if it is against law.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Chairman BSM Corp. Vs. Masud (1978)30 DLR (AD) 169.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Court of law must satisfy itself that command given to his agent by the principal is not against law—Court shall give opportunity to the person against whom an order is sought, to show cause that such an order, if passed, will be contrary to law. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Power of attorney agent—</strong>A power of attorney agent cannot be accorded all the rights and privileges which are enjoyed by the member of the legal profession.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Jogesh Ch. Mukherji (1953) 5 DLR 160.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A recognized agent can make an appearance or an application or act on behalf of a party but cannot plead in a court. He can appoint a pleader but he has no right of audience. <em>  Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Substituted agent.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Bank—It's responsibilities when acting on behalf of and on the instruction of a consignee of imported goods who is also its constituent in nominating and instructing a clearing agent.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Clearing agent—<span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Circumstances when someone engaged for clearance of goods by a bank for the benefit of an importer becomes the agent not of the bank, but of the importer. </span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Syed and Co. Vs. MM. Ispahani Ltd. (1958)10 DLR 552</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—“Agent”, ‘contract’ and ‘servant’—Distinction as between these three terms under the law.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>M. Akbar Ali Vs. Mrs. Rezia Sultana Begum (1983) 35 DLR 391.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Agent and Principal</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The general principle is that the act of the agent in the ordinary course of his business binds the principal—But the case will be otherwise if the right of one defendant is quite independent and separate from that of the other.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Seafarers Inc. Vs. Province of East Pakistan, (1968) 20 DLR (SC) 225.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>“Against such party”.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The phrase ‘against such party’ in the proviso to rule 11 of Order 22, C.P.Codc refers both to the respondent on whom service of notice has been dispensed with, and his legal representative. The phrase is comprehensive enough to govern any of the two contingencies, namely, the death of the respondent or the death of his legal representative.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abu Basher Toha Vs. Sujayat All and ors. (1979) 31 DLR (AD) 326.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Aggrieved—Appeal</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>“Aggrieved person”,</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> meaning of.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">There is no hard and fast meaning that could be ascribed to the term “aggrieved person”. The meaning of the term “aggrieved person” is to be determined with reference to the facts and circumstances of each case.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Zamiruddin Ahmed Vs. Government of the People’s Republic of BD. (1982)34 DLR 34.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Alien enemy</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Even a Pakistani can become an alien enemy as defined in section 83 of the Code of Civil Procedure.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">As the Proclamation of Emergency continues and the Defense of Pakistan Ordinance holds the field, any individual who is living in India, whether a Pakistan national or not, without any authority from the Government of Pakistan, is to be considered an “alien enemy”.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Guru Das Saha Vs. Deputy Custodian (1968)20 DLR 683.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Mere residence in enemy country does not make a person an alien enemy.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>SA Latif Vs. JB Dubash (1970) 22 DLR (WP) 210.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>“Amalnama” unregistered</strong>—An unregistered amalnama, though cannot be used as substantive evidence of the lease (for want of registration), can be taken as evidence of the plaintiffs’ possession of the suit lands.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Meser Gazi Vs. Abdul Gani Gazi (1968)20 DLR 415.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Amendatory Statute.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If the amendatory statute is wholly void, the statute sought to be amended is not affected but remains in force. It is as inoperative as if it had never been enacted; or Act sought to be amended is at least, reinstated in its effectiveness upon the established invalidity of the amendment.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Ful Chand Das &amp; ors. Vs. Mohammad Hammad &amp; ors. (1982)34 DLR (AD) 362.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Amicus curiae</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The power lies in a judge of the High Court to hear amicus curiae, where the judge thinks that he requires assistance in deciding a cause, where he is in doubt on point of law. <em>55 CWN (DR 3) 159.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Annulment of intermediate tenure.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Annulment of intermediate tenure by purchaser of superior interest.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">When the purchaser of a superior 1.2terest becomes entitled to an annual intermediate tenure, a demand of rent directly from an under tenant in the presence of the tenure-holders constitutes an effective election to annul the tenure.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Intention of the purchaser of a superior interest to annul the under-tenure and a certificate of possession in the rent suit terminates the tenure from the date of the institution of the Suit, It does not give any retrospective effect to the termination of the tenure from the date of sale.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Amulya Chandra Kendu Vs. Mohendra Nash Biswas. (1979) 31 DLR 75.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>“Any person aggrieved”.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The expression “any person aggrieved” in section 50 (Wakf Ordinance 1 of 1962) means any person who is interested to challenge the order made under this section.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>S Masud Ali Vs. Md. Asmatullah (1979)31 DLR (AD) 250.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Apology offered accepted—The contemnor being an advocate of the Court.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">An application was filed by the appellant tendering unqualified apology. In the application the appellant stated that he genuinely regretted the objectionable statement made by him and surrendered to the mercy of this Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In the circumstances slated above, though we find the appellant guilty of contemnor of Court in view of the fact that he is repentant and has tendered unconditional apology he is let off with a warning.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdus Sobhan Vs. Ayaz Bahadur Khan &amp; ors. (1979)31 DLR (AD) 335.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Appeal—Right to appeal is conferred by statute—</strong>Such right can not be interfered.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Bangladesh Vs. Abdul Mannan (1977) 29 DLR (SC) 17.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Right to appeal as well as of revision when can be claimed—</strong> In the absence of any provision for appeal the power of revision can be invoked in appropriate cases by way of application.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Bangladesh Vs. Abdul Mannan (1977) 29 DLR (SC) 17.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">‘Appeal will be dismissed’ ‘appeal will stand dismissed’. </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">There is a difference between the order ‘the appeal will stand dismissed’ and ‘the appeal will be dismissed’. The former order contemplates a final order to be passed in future and therefore the case has not been finally disposed of.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mohendra Ch. Dey Vs. Gobinda Prasad. (1953)3 DLR 313.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Preferment of appeal unnecessary when the order to be appealed against is infructuous.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Kazi <em>Bahauddin Ahrned Vs. Province of East Pakistan (1963) 15 DLR 5.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">A continuation of the suit.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">An appeal is said to be a continuation of a suit or is included within word ‘suit’.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The legislature when it provides a hierarchy of tribunals for the determination of a dispute is really providing one complete procedure for such determination, proceedings before different tribunals being only steps in this procedure.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>FA Khan Vs. Government of Pakistan (1964) 16</em> <em>DLR (SC) 405.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Appellate Court.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Decision of the lower appellate Court when can be set aside in second appeal.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">When the trial Court after considering the evidence and demeanor of the witness came to a finding which has been reversed by the lower appellate Court without giving due consideration on the proper aspect of the case such decision of the lower appellate Court is liable to be set aside in appeal.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Tanujur Rahman Vs. Md. Altafur Rahman (1969) 21 DLR 877</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Objection as to manner of proof.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">An Appellate Court scarcely entertains any objection as to the mode or manner of proof of and document or object.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Narendra Nath Pal Vs. Abdur Rahman Molla (1974) 26 DL.R</em> 45.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Appellate Division and remand of a case.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Reluctant to remand a case to enable a party to fill up a lacuna.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court is reluctant to remand a case to allow a party, negligent in earlier proceeding in diligently bringing all evidence on record, indulgence to fill up the lacuna and in evidence.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Vice-Chairman Vs. Ghulam Nabi (1975) 27 DLR (SC) 156.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Appellate order.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Presupposes the existence of an original order— No original order, no appeal.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">An appellate order is passed in appeal. An appeal presupposes existence of original order, when there is no original order the question of giving an appellate order does not arise. In law there can be second appeal if it is specifically provided as has been done in this case in article 11 and Article 11(2). The existence of original order is sine qua non of the proceedings. Since there is no original order in these proceedings all the subsequent appellate orders are without jurisdiction and no amount of consent of the parties would confer jurisdiction. This, is a well- settled principle of law. If any authority is needed reliance may be placed on the decision in the case of Kiron Sing and others Vs. Chaman Paswan and others, AIR 1954 (SC) 340.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Monindra Nath Das Vs. Joint Secretary (1978)30 DLR 324.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">‘Apparent good order and condition’</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Goods not properly packed arc not in ‘good order and condition’.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Apparent good order and condition means that apparently, and so far as met the eye, and externally, the goods were placed in good order on board the ship.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Abdur Rahman Abdul Gani Vs. United Oriental Steamship Co. (1959) 11 DLR 133.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">‘Appertaining’—‘Appurtenances’.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The primary sense of the word ‘appertaining’ is much the same as ‘appurtenances’.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Fazlur Rahman Vs. Jogendra Mohan Das (1951)3 DLR 116.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Application of mind.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The order made by the Sessions Judge and Special Tribunal do not show any application of mind and the order indicates that he acted practically at the behest of the Public Prosecutor.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Habibur Rahman Vs. The State (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 55.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Apply</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">What the word ‘apply’ means and how to be understood.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In Webster’s Dictionary ‘apply’ means, amongst others, to place in contact with a thing, to put to use, to devote to a particular purpose, to engage with a close attention. The different categories of meaning given in the dictionary to indicate in case of money that it is to be spent. It also means the money devoted to a particular purpose.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">MA Hal Vs. TCB (1980) 32 DLR (AD) 48.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Approbation and reprobation</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A party can not blow hot and cold in his stand before a court of law.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Nur Banu Vs. Noor Mohammad. (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 182.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Arbitration</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A party to a dispute cannot be forced to go for arbitration in the absence of an agreement to that effect.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">United Aircraft Vs. PIA (1977) 29 DLR 273.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Area of land</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Area of land—conflict between sale certificate and the kabuliat—Circumstances when the latter shall prevail.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Ausaruddin Khondkar Vs. Abdul Kader Molla (1957)9 DLR 238</span></em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—Area of land and share of land.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Document describes both the share as well as the area to be transferred. Which one to prevail when there is a difference between the two.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">To go by the share mentioned in a document as the share sought to be transferred without taking the other parts of the document into account may result in forcing an intention upon the executants of the document which he did not possess. Taking the share alone as the guiding factor where there are in other places in the document a description of the extent of that share sought to be transferred would be unreasonable for, it may well be that the parties understood the share mentioned in the document to comprise only that particular quantity of land and not more.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Safiuddin Kazi Vs. Moslem Ali Howladar (1960) 12 DLR 266.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Boundaries as well as area both are mentioned in the document—In case of difference between the two boundaries to prevail. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—‘Arrears of cess’ and ‘arrears of revenue’ not interchangeable terms. Sale of estate held by Collector for arrears of cess is valid and the amount lying with the Collector on account of revenue could not be regarded as lying under the cess’. ‘Arrears of cess’ and ‘arrears of revenue’ arc not interchangeable terms.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Jogendra Kishor Pal Chowdhury Vs. Prov. of East Bengal (1957) 9 DLR 182.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Arrears of salary.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Declaratory decrees regarding claim to arrear of salary—Government not to avoid implementing decrees—Departments’ practice of evading financial implications of decrees deprecated —Writ jurisdiction not to be made use of for enforcing declaratory decrees.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Govt of West Pakistan Vs. Fazl-e-Haq Musarrat (1960) 12 DLR (SC) 88.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Not a contractual debt—Claim on bounty of Slate—Action at law for enforcement does not lie.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Claim of a public servant, for the payment of sakiry against the State, is not a contractual debt but a claim on the bounty of the State. No action at law lies for its enforcement. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Articles of Association.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Articles of Association determine the scope of the functions of the director of a company—Persons dealing with the directors not bound to enquire into the specific resolutions.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">P.K. Basak &amp; Co. Vs. Gossen &amp; Co. (1957) 9 DLR 1.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Articled clerk.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Two years’ practice in the subordinate courts by a young lawyer just enrolled should more profitably be divided into two parts,—one year in the subordinate court and one year in the High Court Division.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Kazi Habibul Awal, Vs. Bangladesh Bar Council &amp; ors. (1982) 34 DLR 333.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">‘As early as possible’.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The words ‘as early as possible’ cannot but mean ‘as early as possible’ within the terminus adqucm.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Al-Haz Abdur Rahman Bhuiya Vs. Commr. of Narayangonj Municipality (1958) 10 DLR 431.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Assignable claim.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The true test for determining the nature of the claim sought to be assigned should be to sec that the claim when it does accrue partakes of the character of a debt or a beneficial interest in movable property not, in the possession, either actual or constructive, of the claimant which can be recovered by an action<em>. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Kazi Abdul Ali Vs. Nurul Amin (1955) 7 DLR 406.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Attestation to document.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Attestation to document is no evidence as to the recitals and contents thereof.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Basanta Kumar Vs. Santosh Kumar, (1972) 24 DLR 84.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Attestation of a document</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Not a ground to fix the person attesting the document with the knowledge of the contents of the document. <em>(1957) PLR (WP) 311.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Auction-purchaser’s right to the land Purchased.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">When an auction-purchaser has acquired a good title against a judgment-debtor he should not be compelled to part with it merely because he cannot hold his title against another.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Nirod Bala Vs. Monomohan Datta (1954) 6 DLR 559.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Audi alteram partem—</span></strong>Is to be read in every law.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Principle of <em>audi alteram partem</em> unless expressly excluded by law or by the nature of the objects of any particular law, is to be implied to have been provided in every statute.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Dr. Neelima Thrahim Vs. Gov. of Bangladesh (1980) 32 DLR 201.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Award and decree—Arbitrator’s award and Civil Court’s decree stand on the same footing.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">An award made by an Arbitrator is a decree in all purposes and it can be enforced by a Civil Court, as if it was a decree of that Court. The award being a decree, the general principles applicable to execution of a decree will be available here.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Md. Emdadul Haque Vs. NV Co-op. M Society (1974) 26 DLR 120.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">An award is altogether different from a</span></strong> <strong>recommendation.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It appears that the learned Labour Court misconceived the scope of section 34 of the Ordinance and confused between a claim and a right. It appears further that the learned Labour Court proceeded on a wrong assumption that the recommendation of the National Pay Commission is an award.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Manager, Azizuddin Industries Ltd. Vs. Abdus Satter (1979) 31 DLR 58.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">B</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Ballot paper.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Election Commissions jurisdiction to reject ballot papers with extra marks, when acquired.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Extra mark on the ballot paper must enter on the ballot paper before it is put into the ballot box; so that, on this positive finding by the Election Commission, the latter will acquire authority to reject the ballot paper from counting—Without such a finding, the Election Commission could not acquire such authority—This is the dictum of the Supreme Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Mohammad Abdur Rab Vs. Abdus Samad Sarkar, Chief Election Commissioner (1968) 20 DLR 675.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Bank</span></strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">—Its responsibility—Bank bound to make the payment on demand—It is not to arbitrate .in a dispute between two contending parties. </span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Pubali Bank Ltd. Vs. Bangladesh Agricultural Development Corporation. (1982) 34 DLR 104.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—Bank’s claim, after LC opened</span></strong>— Bank’s claim, after irrevocable letter of credit had been opened for its client for import of goods, to the payment of full amount due on such goods is fully enforceable, even though the client wanted the bank that to save his (client’s) interest a new clause be inserted in the letter of credit but in spite of the bank’s efforts to do so the letter of credit could not be amended as goods before the bank’s intimation had already been shipped.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">M/s. Mohammad Usman Brothers Vs. M/s. Muslim Commercial Bank Ltd. (1971)23 DLR 39</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—Bank’s function—Bank’s liability to pay when the position created is one of debtor and depositor</span></strong>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Released amount becomes a deposit and the bank becomes a debtor.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sonali Bank, Vs. Abdul Mannan and ors. (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 21.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Bank and customer—</span></strong>Mutual open account.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">When a person opens a current account with a bank and pays money into it, the bank is a debtor to the customer. If the bank .allows the customer to overdraw the account and he does so, he becomes a debtor to the bank and each party could say that he had a separate account against the other.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Reliance Bank Ltd. Vs. Profulla Kumar Banerje (1953) 5 DLR 69.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—Bank deposit.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Relation created between the depositor and the bank is one of debt.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Mahaluxmi Bank Ltd. Vs. Muhammad Saheb Meah (1957) 9 DLR 133.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">‘Bazars’.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Bazars with some structure on, which are held once in the morning every day, can be acquired under sec. 3(2) of the E. B. State Acquisition and Tenancy Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Yusuf Ali Chowdhury Vs. Prov of East Pakistan. (1959) 11 DLR (SC) 316.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">‘Bed of river’—Doctrine of reformation in situ.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">When a river habitually covers up a land every year during the wet season and the land is not capable of cultivation in the usual way even when dry during the dry season, it is for all purposes the bed of river and it cannot be said that the river has yielded up and abandoned the land. The doctrine of reformation in Situ cannot be attached to such a soil.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Till the land rises beyond ordinary high water mark in such a way as to become fit for cultivation, it is part of the river bed and, as such, public property.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">So long as a land remains part of the bed of a river, no private ownership can attach to it.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Rai Satyendra Kumar Das Bahadur Vs. Province of East Pakistan (1958)10 DLR 39=8 PLR (Dac) 495.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">‘<strong>Beel’ having right of fishery, proprietorship of.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">When the ‘Beels’ have ceased to be parts of rivers, the right of fishing in the ‘beds’ comes to be vested with the owners of the soil underneath.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Province of East Pakistan Vs. Tasiruddin Ahmed (1968) 20 DLR 434.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Benami</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Benami—Transfer cannot be held benami where wills made for being absolved from a debt.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It has been contended that a transfer in consideration of debt is a valid transfer and the same cannot be held to be a benami transaction. It is true that under certain circumstances a valid transfer can be made in consideration of being absolved from a debt. But what is necessary is that the debt must be found to be due. In the case of Mina Kumari Vs. Bijoy Singh it was observed by their Lordships of the Judicial Committee as follows:—</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">‘To the suggestion that the transaction was benami, a complete answer is furnished by the admission that the judgcment-dcbtor owed the plaintiff the amount stated to be the consideration for the sale- deeds and more.”</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Abdul Gafur Vs. Obaidul Hossain, (1968)20 DLR 1150.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Benami transaction</span></strong>—In a suit for declaration of title and restoration of possession, Court can decide if one of the defendants is a benamder for the other defendant regarding the suit land.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sadequr Rahman Chowdhury Vs. Mvi. Abdul Ban, (1970) 22 DLR 858.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Its history and characteristics.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In a bcnami transaction real owner of a property allows it to appear in the name of an ostensible owner, himself remaining the beneficiary of the property. The practice of bcnami developed in the Indian sub-continent long before its conquest by the Muslims and during the Muslim rule the practice of benami received full recognition from the authorities and the Courts as well. That the practice of benami was widely practiced throughout the Sub-continent is evident from the early history of the East India Company.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Nurjahan Begum, wife of Mahmudur Rahman Vs. Mahmudur Rahman Mullick (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 61.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Benamidar and the real owner.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The ostensible owner or the benamidar holds the property in trust for the real owner. Relationship between benamidar and the real owner is that of a trustee and ‘cestui que (rust’. Thus its cestul que trust became the beneficial owner of its property.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Nurjahan Begum, wife of Mahmudur Rahman Vs. Mahmudur Rahman Mullick (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 61.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—Benanii transfers may be classified in two classes of transactions.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Benami transfers may be classified in two classes of transactions. Transfers where the real owner of the property transferred to another without any intention whatever to benefit the transferee and no consideration passing from the transferor formed one class. In such transfers the transferor remains to be the real owner but he holds property in the name of the transferee. The other class consists of transfers where a person purchases property in the name of another person. In such transfers, there is a real transaction and the purchaser who pays the consideration money acquires the property for his own benefit, and the person whose name appears in the deed of transfer merely lends his name to the transaction, and acquires no interest in the property<em>. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Nurjahan Begum, wife of Mahmudur Rahman Vs. Mahmudur Rahman Mullick (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 61.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Benami purchase—Possession of property.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Although the source of purchase money is an important criteria, but it is not conclusive where there are other circumstances showing that the purchaser intended property to belong to the person in whose favour the sale deed is executed. So it is the intention of the parties which practically determines the question as to who is the owner of the property.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Source of purchase money is only to be the criterion in the absence of all other relevant circumstances. Among other circumstances possession of the property has been held to be very important.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Nurjahan Begum, wife of Mahmudur Rahman Vs. Mahmudur Rahman Mullick (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 61.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—Benami transaction—</span></strong>Source of purchase money—Consideration of other relevant circumstances important—Motive for benami.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In a benami transaction source of purchase money an important criterion but it is not conclusive.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Nurjahan Begum, wife of Mahmudur Rahman Vs. Mahmudur Rahman Mullick (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 61.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Bench and Bar—To work harmoniously</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Both the Bench and the Bar are two arms of the same machinery and unless they work harmoniously justice cannot be properly administered. An erring judge and erring contemner are both a danger to the pristine purity of the seat of justice.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Moazzem Hossain Vs. State (1983)35 DLR (AD) 290.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Benefit of Tax-holiday</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Profit of he company being entitled to the benefit of tax-holiday share-holders when receiving dividend are equally exempted from tax.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Commissioner of Income Tax Vs... Mr.</span></em> <em>Masuda Khatun (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 85.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Bias</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Bias—When Judge is disqualified to sit on judgment in a case—Justice not only be done, but should also be shown to have been done</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Where a Judge or a Member of a Tribunal has pecuniary interest however negligible in the subject- matter of the litigation which is pending adjudication before him, he is disqualified from hearing the matter without any further proof of bias in him from any quarters. But where the allegation of bias is based on kinship or relationship, it seems to us that the party alleging relationship between the contesting party and the Judge or a Member of the Tribunal, has to prove that there nature of relationship is such as to afford a reasonable bias for holding that there is a real likelihoods of bias. By this we do not mean to say that we approve of the conduct of a Judge or a Member of a Tribunal who appears to have some interest in the case due to his relationship with any of the contesting parties before him and yet hears the matter even though the parties have consented to his doing so. Justice should not only be done but it should appear to have been done so that people may have confidence in the administration of justice.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Mahbubul Huq Vs. Chief Commissioner of Pakistan (1968)20 DLR 883.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Judge affected by bias when will render the decision void.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In a case where bias on the part of a presiding Judge is based on his pecuniary or proprietary interest in the subject-matter of the proceedings however small that interest may be, that will disqualify the Judge to sit over the proceedings and render his decision void but where such pecuniary or proprietary interest is not involved mere suspicion of bias even if it is not unreasonable is not sufficient to render the decision void.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Syed Akhlaque Hussain Vs. Pakistan, (1969) 21 DLR (SC) 152</span></em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Court having already determined cx pars that the appellant had acted malafide in causing the retirement of the respondent, its subsequent suo mosa rule to show cause why the appellant should not pay Tk. 10,000/- to the respondent is an attempt to regularize its earlier ex-parte proceeding.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Habibullah Khan Vs. Shah Azharuddin Ahmed (1983)35 DLR (AD) 72.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Court should avoid possibility of bias—A matter should not be heard by a Judge where likelihood of bias exists.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Moozzam Hossain Vs. Slate (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 290.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Bill of lading:</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Bill of lading—Burden of proof about misstatement in it (e.g., where the complaint is that the goods had not been shipped) is on the buyer.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is quite correct that although statement in the bill of lading is not a conclusive proof in law if buyer wanted to challenge the fact of shipment recorded in the bill of lading it was their duty to lead evidence in proof of their allegation that the goods had not been-shipped.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It was incumbent on the buyer to prove that the goods had not been shipped. Where this onus has not been discharged it is not possible to hold that the goods were not shipped or the bill of lading was a forged document.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Haji Moosa Haji Omar Vs. Ahmed Abdul Gani (1968)20 DLR (WP) 158.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Master of the ship is liable in case of transhipment—not the person further endorsing the bill of lading in favour of a third party.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Even in cases where the hindrance of the ship’s voyage is not caused by an excepted peril the ship- owner is only liable for delay or failure to deliver and to compensate for terms more onerous to the shipper in transshipment. But this only is the responsibility of the Master of the ship and not of the person who has further endorsed the bill of lading in favour of a third party. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">‘Bill of lading’ and ‘Charter party’</span></strong>— The bill of lading is a document of title to the</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">goods and may as such be transferred to a third party who makes it subject to everything that appears thereon. it is therefore, both transferable and negotiable. Usually as between carrier and shipper, the contract is contained in the charter party and the bill of lading is not evidence of the contract but only a receipt for the goods and at the same time it is also a document which enables the shipper to transfer the goods to a consignee. Therefore, apart from the receipt, the bill of lading in such case is also a document of title.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Abu Bakr Siddique Vs. M. V. Aghia Thalassini (1978)30 DLR 94.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Black Listing.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Blacklisting—No authority can blacklist a person who is not a licensee under that authority.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The expression ‘blacklisted’ used by the Municipality concerning the petitioner really means nothing inasmuch as the petitioner’s business has not been stopped or affected in any way by the expression “blacklisted”. The petitioner is not a licensee under the Municipality and therefore, the Municipality has no authority to blacklist the petitioner.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">M/S  Anwar Asghar Brothers Vs.
