Chairman, Chittagong Municipality, Chittagong (1970) 22</span></em> <em>DLR 201.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Board of Revenue</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Board of Revenue abolished—Its function has been taken over by the Ministry of Land Revenue and Land Reform.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Md. Nehaluddin Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh (1977)29 DLR 91.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Boi Bikri</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The word “Boi-bikri” used in the deed of will by the testator is confined to sale only and does not include a ‘transfer’ which is sale plus other mode of transfer such as lease, mortgage, etc.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">“Boi Bikri” means sale and does not include any other transaction excepting sale.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Nirode Baran Paul Vs. Ahmed Meah (1970)22 DLR 529.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">‘Bonafide mistake’</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Bonafide mistake when cannot be taken—Plea of. A plea of bonafide mistake not having been taken before the High Court Division cannot be entertained by the Appellate Division.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Amaresh Chandra Chakraborty Vs. Bangladesh (1979) 31 DLR (AD) 240.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">‘Bonafide requires’.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">(Sec under section 17(c) EB Premises Rent Control Act. <em>Jagadish Sarkar Vs. Abdul Aziz. (1955) 7 DLR 314.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Bond.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">“All other perils, losses and misfortunes”</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">To be interpreted ejusdem generis.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">General words like all other perils, losses and misfortunes etc. in the insurance policy are to be interpreted ejusdem generis the particular words preceding them. It is manifest that the general words must be restricted to loss or damage caused to the goods by a cause which is akin to or resembling or of the same kind as the particular words preceding them.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">ES. Insurance Vs. Rahman Trading (1976)28 DLR (SC) 109.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Phrase “other perils and losses, etc.” covers loss due to rough weather.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In the present case, the damage was due to the generation of heat by closure of the ventilators and that was done due to rough weather which brought sea-water on deck. This cause is covered by the words other peril and losses etc. in the policy in view of the fact the cause is akin to or resembling or of the same kind as the Loss particularized preceding the general words.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">ES Insurance Vs. Rahinan Trading (1976) 28 DLR (SC) 109.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Bond or negotiable instrument:The relevant text in the document ran as follows</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">“1, Mosiafizur Rahman,—hereby acknowledge the receipt of Rs. 10,000/- from Mr. Md. Azizur Rahman, having borrowed from him today, the 3rd day of January, 1963.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">I promise to pay the said sum to the said Mr. Md. Azizur Rahman or his successors on demand.”</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It was contended that the above text shows that it is merely an acknowledgement of the receipt of a sum of Rs. 10,000/-.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Held:</span></strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> A bare reading of the document would show that it is not so. The petitioner has undertaken in express terms to pay the amount of Rs. 10,000/- to Mr. Azizur Rahman or his successors on demand.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In this document there is a recital of obligation of Mostafizur Rahman to pay the amount to Azizur Rahman or his successors. It, therefore, lacks in the essential quality of being negotiable.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Md. Azizur Rahman Vs. Mustafizur Rahman (l969) 21 DLR 119.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—“Boni judicis est ampliare jurisdictionem “—</span></strong>Judge’s duty to enlarge his jurisdiction for advancement of substantial justice.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If a man has a right he must have a means to vindicate and maintain it and a remedy if he is injured in its excercise and enjoyment. It is pertinent in this connection to refer to another well-known legal maxim boni judicis est ampliare jurisdictionem which means that it is the duty of a judge to extend and enlarge his jurisdiction. This has been interpreted by the superior Courts of England to mean that it was the duty of the judge applying the law to amplify its remedies and without usurping jurisdiction to apply its rules to the advancement of substantial justice.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Kari Palan Mia Vs. State (1983) 35 DLR 118A</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Bonus.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">There is a distinction between ‘share of profits’ and ‘commission’ on the one hand and bonus on the other, the two first expressions relate to a legal right, the last refers generally to an ex gratia payment.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Md. Akbar Abdul Sattar Vs. WL Bogtstra (1956)8 DLR 19 (PC</span></em>).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—Proportionate bonus to employees, working for a year.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Pakistan Petroleum Workers Federation Karachi Vs. Burmah Shell Oil Storage and Distributing of Pak Ltd. (1961)13 DLR (SC) 299.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Basis for assessing—</span></strong>In computing profit and loss for the purpose of awarding bonus the amount spent in payment of salaries, wages and other incidental expenses cannot be overlooked.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Where management did not make any profit in a particular year the workers were not entitled to get any bonus that year.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Saifee Development Corporation Ltd. Vs. Pakistan (1961)13 DLR (SC) 27.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Bonus out of profit—by virtue of 1966 Finance Act, is now taxable. <em>(1982)34 DLR (AD) 85.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—‘Bonus share’ is not exempt from income tax.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Super-Lax—Liability to pay the same—An additional duty of income tax.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Neither sub-section(1) nor 4 (A) of the Finance Act 1968 has given exemption to the bonus shares. On the contrary, section 4(B) expressly provides that nothing contained in sub-section (1) of section 4(A) shall be deemed to exempt the income representing the face value of any bonus or the amount of any bonus issued, paid or declared by a company.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In the present case tax has been levied on bonus shares and it being a super-tax is an additional duty of income tax and it is charged in respect of the total income of the previous year. Therefore, it is covered by clause (c) of item 43 because it deals with “taxes on income.<em>”</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Pak Jute Mills Ltd. Vs. Income Tax Officer (1979) 31 DLR (AD) 178.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Boundary</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Thana boundaries—Like the district boundary (mid-streams) of a big river are to be taken as the Line of demarcation in thana boundaries<em>. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Abdul Hamid Howladar. Vs. Province of East Pakistan, (1972)24 DLR 142.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Boundaries establish identity—Boundaries as well as area both are mentioned in the document—In case of difference between the two, boundaries to prevail.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">There can possibly be no reason to hold that even the description of the land by boundaries was not sufficient to identify the land sought to be conveyed or was a false description of the land. The Privy Council has pointed out that where a land sought to bcconveyed is described by reference to its boundaries that makes the land sufficiently iclentifiable that prevails over the area said to be comprised therein.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Safiuddin Kazi Vs. Moslem Ali Howladar. (1960) 12 DLR 266.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">“Brothels”—Control of profession by municipality.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Municipal bodies power to exclude the retention of brothels from certain specified area—Power to impose a total ban against the constitutional guarantee.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If by the prohibitory order, the profession is not to be practiced within the specified area but at some other place, the persons affected are entitled to some assistance in procuring places of residence for themselves, where they may live and Continue their profession, if they choose. Any attempt to squeeze out the profession or otherwise render it extinct may perhaps be found to be inconsistent with the provisions of the present Constitution, which allow the free practice of professions, subject to the power of regulation.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Mst. Sardaran Vs. Municipality, Lyallpur (1964) 16 DLR (SC) 372.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">“Burden of Proof’</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—</span></strong>Plaintiff must prove his own case and cannot rely on the evidence of the defendants to prove his case.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is well settled that plaintiffs can succeed only on proof of his case and not on the weakness of the defense. In this case the learned subordinate Judge held that plaintiffs failed to prove exclusive possession. In view of this finding, it cannot be held from the evidence adduced on the side of the defendants that plaintiff’s exclusive possession was proved.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Achi Meah Vs. Bacha Mean (1966)18 DLR 313.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Bureaucratic recalcitrance</span></strong>—along with the downright contradictory attitude as also its misleading statements in Court—Entailing hardship on citizens.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">What has particularly shocked us is the manner in which innocent citizens were being harassed and driven from pillar to post.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Al-Haj Md. Mostafizur Rahman Vs. Deputy Commissioner, Chittagong (1982)34 DLR 328.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">‘By land’</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The words ‘by land’ include the words ‘by air’. <em>Fakir Muhammad Punjabi Vs. Federation of Pakistan (1958)10 DLR (SC) 122.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2433	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Words and Phrases [C,D]</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1968) 20 DLR 1158, (1951)3DLR (PC) 121, (1960) 12 DLR (SC) 135, (1968) 20 DLR (WP) 297, (1983)35 DLR (AD) 1188, (1966) 18 DLR 443,  (1975) 27DLR 617, (1979) 31 DLR (AD) 218, (1956)8 DLR 327, (1978) 30 DLR 94, (1980)32 DLR 118, (1958)10 DLR 552, (1984) 3</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Words and Phrase</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p align="center" style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Words and Phrases</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—“Cancel” and “discontinue”—Distinction between the two words,</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The word “discontinue” means interruption of continuance, cessation or intermission. ft does not mean putting an end to something which but for the action in question would have gone on. The latter action amounts to cancellation. This is the distinction between the two words “cancel” and “discontinue” used in sub-section (3) of section 28 of Electricity Act (IX of 1910). The sanction in favour of the petitioner company was continued from time to time until the 30th of September, 1965. No further extension was granted and that amounts to discontinuance of the sanction.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Pabna Electric Supply Co. Vs. Province of East Pakistan (1968) 20 DLR 1158.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Capital expenditure</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">There is no definition of the expression capital expenditure which must be construed in a business sense save in so far as there may be rules of constructions applicable to it.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Mohan Lal Hargovinda Vs. Commissioner of Income Tax CP (1951)3DLR (PC) 121.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—‘Capital expenditure’ it has been said, is that which is spent ‘once and for all’.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">‘It is an expenditure incurred with a view to bringing into existence an asset or advantage for the continuing benefit of the trade.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is money employed ‘for the purpose of acquiring the concern, not for the purpose of carrying on the concern.’</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The land upon which a manufacturer carries on his business is part of his fixed capital. The machinery with which a manufacturer makes the articles that he sells is part of his fixed capital.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Commissioner of Income Tax, E Pak Vs. Luxmi Narayan Cotton Mills (1960) 12 DLR (SC) 135.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Care and protection—Difference between,</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The difference between ‘protection’ and ‘care’ is that protection denotes preservation, whereas care denotes responsibility for welfare.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Fahimuddin Khonkar Vs. Mst. Zaibunnessa (1968) 20 DLR (WP) 297.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">‘Carriage of goods in a ship’—Towage of a dead ship.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ruhul Islam, J.—Towage of a dead turbine ship by a ship-tug can be said to be “carriage of goods in a ship”.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If the expression “carriage of goods in a ship” is given literal meaning, then, unless the cargo is placed on board the ship, there would not be any carriage of goods” as contemplated in the Carriage of Goods by Sea Act, 1925. In view of the nature of the contract which specifically mentioned about the bringing of the TSS ‘PACIFIC ABETO by towing another ship (Tug) the carriage by towing could not be anything but “carriage of goods in a ship.”</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—No cause of action’—Conclusion arrived at from a mere reading of the plaint on its presentation—And the conclusion arrived at after going through the materials on record—Distinction between them.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Saleh Industries Vs. TSS Pacific Abeto (1983)35 DLR (AD) 1188.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">“Censorship</span></strong> “</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The word ‘censorship’ means excision, stop, regulation, control, etc.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Dacca Picture Palace Ltd. Vs. Pakistan (1966) 18 DLR 443.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">‘Chala land’ and nal land’</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Chala lands arc comparatively elevated land fit for construction of residential structures, whereas nal lands are agricultural lands which are comparatively of low level.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Bangladesh Vs. Abdul Khaleque (1975) 27DLR 617.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">‘Char lands’</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Char lands added by gradual accession of the river—The riparian owners of the land to which the char lands are added became the owner of the new char lands.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">AS Aziz Mohammad Vs. Govt of Bangladesh (1979) 31 DLR (AD) 218.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">‘Chargeable’</span></strong>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">(Under Rule 5 of the Bengal Agricultural Income-tax Rules, 1944).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The word ‘chargeable’ merely means exposed in a cont1gcncy which may or may not occur.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Jagadish Ch. Mazumdar Vs. Commr, of Agricultural Income Tax, East Bengal (1956)8 DLR 327.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Charter party and bill of lading</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Consignee not fixed with the knowledge of the contents of charter party—Shipper has no means of knowing what may be in the charter party.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The bill of lading often contains the clause ‘all other conditions as per charter’. Such a clause does not give the shipper notice of the whole contents of the charter party so as to make him liable to perform them.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Abu Bakr Siddique Vs. MV Aghia Talassini (1978) 30 DLR 94.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Arbitration clause in the charter party—No cvidcntiary value as to this clause so far as the bill of lading is concerned. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Christian Law</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Minor—In the absence of father, mother is natural guardian.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It may be accepted that in the absence of the father, the Christian mother is the natural guardian of her minor children. It may also be accepted that it will not be unlawful for her to be the custodian of her ward’s property.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Archana Prasad Nandi Vs. Miss Chilia Randolph (1980)32 DLR 118.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Though a Christian mother as a natural guardian of her minor children can enter into an executor contract of sale in respect of her minor children’s property, in decreeing specific performance thereof the Court will have to be satisfied, inter alia, that the contract has caused to the minor’s benefit. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">CIF Contracts</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The initials CIF stand for the words cost, insurance and freight. Thus if a merchant agrees to sell goods at 30s. per ton CIF. Manchester Docks, that sum will include the price of the goods, premium for insuring them and the freight payable for carrying them to their named destination.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Syed &amp; Co Vs. MM Ispahani Ltd. (1958)10 DLR 552.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Civil rights</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">An invasion of civil rights of another is itself a legal wrong carrying with it liability to repair its necessary and natural consequences in so far as these are injurious to the person whose right is infringed, whether the motive permitting it be good, bad or indifferent. 1 <em>PLR 106.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Circular</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Circulars issued by the Government are for executive guidance and possess no legal force.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Administrator, Zilla Board Vs. Mukhlesur Rahman (1984) 36 DLR 71.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Citizen</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Citizen—When a citizen can be declared an enemy—Circumstances explained.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In the present case Mr. Siddique UIIah who affirmed an affidavit to the effect that he has settled in India does not say as to when he left for India and started permanently residing there, or as to where in that country he is residing. On such allegations, it is not possible for a Court to hold that a citizen has become an enemy.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Shah Ghulam Nabi Vs. Vice Chairman, East Pakistan</span></em> <em>Enemy Property (1970) 22 DLR 48.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Clearing agent</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Circumstances when someone engaged for clearance pf goods by a bank for the benefit of an importer become the agent not of the Bank but of the importer.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Syed and Co. Vs. MM Ispahani Ltd. (1958) 10 DLR 552</span></em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Client.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A client may be understood in the sense of a constituent or customer or one who employs a lawyer or professional adviser and, as such, the possible relationship of a principal and agent cannot be excluded from the connotation of the word ‘client’.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Syed and Co. Vs. MM Ispahani Ltd. (1958) 10 DLR 552</span></em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Collector</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The word “Collector” does not include the Sub- divisional Officer. Where the “Collector’ is directed to do certain thing it cannot be transferred to the Sub-divisional Officer, he being not the Collector.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Khabiruddin Miah Vs. Darastullah Kazi (1969)21 DLR (BR) 27.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Commission.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">There is a distinction between ‘share of profits’ and commission’ on the one hand and bonus on the other. The first expression relates to a legal right, the last refers generally to cx gratia payment.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Md. Akbar Abdul Sattar Vs. WL Bogtstra (1956) 8 DLR (PC) 19.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">“Committee’</span></strong>—Can be used even for an individual—Companies Act (VII of 1913), Table A, Sched. 1. Reg. 91.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">The Pakistan Employees Cooperative housing Society Ltd. Karachi Vs. Ms:. Anwar Sultana (1969)21 PLD Karachi 475.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Common carrier.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">At Common Law after the affreightment ends the common carrier incurs a new liability as an involuntary warehouseman of a bailee if the goods still continue to remain in his custody even by reason of some fault of the consignee and he is bound to take such care of the goods as a prudent man would take of his own goods of the same kind, bulk or value in similar circumstances.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Abdur Rahman Abdul Gani Vs. Mackinnon Mackenzie &amp; Co. (1958) 10 DLR</span></em> 213.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Company—Share-holder</span></strong>—Whether has any interest in “particular piece” of property in which company has an interest.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is highly questionable whether any shareholder of a Company can claim to have an interest in any particular piece of property in which the Company has an interest unless the Company itself is brought into liquidation, and even then the interest is not of a direct nature.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Rai Bahadur Mohan Singh Vs. Rai Bahadur Jodha Mal Kuthalia (1961) 13 DLR (SC) 21.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—<strong>Company in liquidation</strong>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Company in liquidation turns out to be solvent—Creditor’s entitlement.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Where a company in liquidation turns out to be solvent, creditors whose debts carry interest by agreement or otherwise arc entitled out of the surplus assets to payment of interest accruing after time commencement of the liquidation until payment is made of the principal debts at the rate at which by agreement or otherwise interest on such debts is payable.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Chartered Bank Vs. Official Liquidator (1982) 34 DLR 324.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—Company matters—</span></strong>A meeting if called for appointing a Managing Director—Sufficient prior notice of that must be given to the other Directors.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Shamsul Huda Vs. Jalaluddin Ahmed. (1979) 31 DLR 5.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Compensation</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The meaning of ‘compensation’ with respect to a property is the market value of the property.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Jibendra Kishore Acharya Chowdhury Vs. Prow, of East Pak. (1957) 9 DLR (SC) 21(23).</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Suit for compensation arising out of death caused by fatal accident—Appellate Court would not interfere only because it would have awarded different sum—Onus to prove that the amount awarded is excessive is very heavy.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Lim Joo Chiang Vs. Lim Siew Choo (1959)11 DLR 84 (PC).</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—Partial damage of goods</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It was contended on behalf of the defendant that when the plaintiff based his claim on the basis of total loss, constructive or actual, the plaintiff is not entitled to get any decree on the basis of partial loss.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Held</span></strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">: Plaintiff can be awarded a decree for partial loss even if he did not claim it in his plaint which was founded on the basis of total loss.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Even if no notice of abandonment is served, the insured’s whole claim will not be defeated but he would be entitled to recover partial compensation in respect of the damaged goods.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">BR Rakshit &amp; Co. Vs. Federation of Pakistan (1959) 11 DLR 106.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Ship owner’s liability to pay damage for goods shipped where the bill of lading contained the clause that the goods were shipped ‘in apparent good order and condition’.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Abdul Rahman Abdul Gani Vs. United Oriental Steamship Co, (1959)11 DLR 133.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Compulsory acquisition of land by the State—Law enacted by the legislature providing compensation for acquisition of land when such law is violative of the provisions of the Constitution in such matters must be held to be ultra wires.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Compensation of compulsory acquisition—The law ordinarily applicable in such acquisition is Land Acquisition Act (1 of 1884).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Province of West Pakistan Vs. M. Salim Ullah (1966)18 DLR (SC) 378.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Compromise when goes beyond the scope of a suit.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The proper procedure in a case where a compromise went beyond the scope of the suit was to incorporate the compromise in a schedule to the decree and make an order or a decree only in so far as those terms came within the scope of the suit and then that portion would be a perfectly valid and executable decree.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Nagendra Nath Mazumdar Vs. Kshitish Ch. Ghose (1957) 9 DLR 661</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">‘Conditional or contingent’</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The words ‘conditional or contingent’ mean that in case of debts or benefits accruing conditionally or contingently the immediate right to recover by an action does not arise until the condition has been fulfilled or the contingency has occurred.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Kazi Abdul Ali Vs. Nurul Amin (1955) 7 DLR 406.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Constitution—Its interpretation</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">K Hossain, CJ—Constitution should be interpreted as an organic instrument keeping its dynamic character in view. More specifically regard may be had to the political, social and economic conditions and their place in the historical setting and the present international milieu. The decisions of courts of other jurisdiction will serve as a helpful guide, but never an authority.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Mofizur Rahman Khan Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 321.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Constitutional form of Government—</span></strong>Object of a government vis-à-vis right of citizens—Constitutional guarantee, safeguarding rights of citizens—Inviolability of the fundamental rights (Constitution of Bangladesh, Arts. 26 and 27).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Hamidul Huq Chowdhury &amp; ors. Vs. Bangladesh represented by the Secretary Ministry of information (1982) 34 DLR 190.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Principle of exposition of one Act by language of another not applicable to instrument—In construing instrument, intention of parties is the primary consideration.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Constitution of Document.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The principle of exposition of one Act by language of another cannot apply to the Instrument of Accession drawn up by a functionary of the Ministry of State and Frontier Regions. Indeed, the primary consideration in construing an instrument is to ascertain the intention of the parties to the instrument.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Fatoomal Vs. Rehabilitation Commissioner, Khairpur Division (1969) 21 DLR (SC) 291.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Contempt of Court—</span></strong>False and frivolous allegations made in written statement against a sitting Judge of the Supreme Court amounts to gross contempt and tends to interfere with administration of justice.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Abdus Sobhan Vs. Ayaz Bahadur Khan and ors. (1979) 31 DLR (AD) 335.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Contract</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The word ‘contracts’ means written (and not oral) contracts only.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The word “contracts” in Part 1, Section B of the Conciliation Courts Ordinance has been used along with “receipts or other documents”. There are authorities for the proposition that when two or more words which are susceptible of analogous meaning are coupled together noscitur a sociis, they arc understood to be used in their cognate sense. They take, as it were, their colour from each other, that is, the more general is restricted to a sense analogous to the less general.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In our view the context in which the word “contracts” has been used in the aforesaid provision clearly indicates that written contracts are only meant.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Zamiruddin Vs. Havas Khan (1969) 21 DLR (SC) 39.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Fraud or misrepresentation by which a contract is entered into renders it unenforceable in law and the party affected by it can repudiate it even if the original ground of repudiation is found to be untenable.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Karnaphuli Paper Mills Ltd. Vs. Amanullah (1971) 23 DLR 150.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Contract with three persons for sale of a land—One person honoring the contract, the other two refusing—Enforcement of the contract on the ground that the contract is divisible.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Archana Proshad Nandi Vs. Miss Chilia Randolph (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 107.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—In such a position the Court will simply sever the contract and enforce it specifically so as to bind a party to the term of the contract. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—Breach of contract—Compensation.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Irrigation Department being a component of the Government the latter is responsible for any loss caused to lessees of the Government on account of the Department’s unauthorized action.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Mariam Vs. Bangladesh (1978)30 DLR (SC) 247.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Frustration of contract, when can not be pleaded and when compensation for loss suffered to be paid. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Implied condition in.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Implied condition in a contract can be excluded by an express stipulation to the contrary or by a statutory provision.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Pakistan through General Manager, <em>NWR Vs. M/S  AB Issacs (1970) 22 DLR (SC) 371.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Mercantile contract</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Contract is mercantile transaction. Buyer purchasing goods from seller of another country undertaking through his bank to pay for the goods supplied through a bank in the seller’s country. The contract to pay the seller is absolutely obligatory. No direction upon the bank to with-hold payment can be passed—Only exception is in case of fraud of which the bank has notice.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Uttara Bank Vs. Macmeill and Kilburn Ltd. (1981)33 DLR (AD) 298.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The court will not interfere by granting an injunction from performing or discharging the contractual obligations.<em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Specific performance of contract—Suit for.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Plaintiff must conform himself to terms of contract—Plaintiff, asking for relief not covered by terms of contract—</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Held:</span></strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> not entitled to relief prayd for.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Haji Shaista Gui Vs. Haji Duranai (1969) 21 PLD (Prshawar) 185.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Contractual service</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The appointments of the Chairman and the members of a Commission bear no resemblance to appointments to a civil service. These appointments arc ad hoc appointments, hiving all the characteristics of contract appointments bearing little resemblance to appointments to a civil service and may be governed for necessary purposes by the terms of a contract.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Prov. of West Pakistan Vs. Chowdhury Nazir Hossain (1960)12 DLR (SC) 140.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Contribution, suit for—Formal party, if liable.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Where a judgment-debtor brought a Suit for contribution from the other co-judgment-debtors in respect of joint decree for costs.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Held: Where a party is merely a formal defendant and not personally interested in the result of the suit he cannot be made liable to contribute. <em>1 PLR (Dac) 620.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Conversion.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If a man takes the property of another without his consent by abuse of the process of law it is an act of conversion.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Ali Bepari Vs. Nowsher liu Bepari (1951) 3 DLR 87—I PLR 106.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Co-proprietor and co-sharer landlord</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">‘Co-proprietor’ and ‘co-sharer landlord’ are not interchangeable terms. A co-owner in a touji is not necessarily a co-sharer landlord in respect of every tenancy under it. To determine whether a co-proprietor is a co-sharer landlord, the test is whether the tenant is, or but for a special contract, would be, liable to pay him any part of the rent of the holding.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sahasrangsu Kanta Achargya Vs. Rajab Ali Fakir (1954) 6 DLR 77.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Corroboration</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The restaurant was purchased in June, 1936. The plaintiffs claim was that he had paid the purchase money and the defendant was engaged as his employee in the business on the terms that the defendant would be entitled to a share of the profit as remuneration for his services and that the term of the arrangement between the parties were oral. The defendant, on the other hand, contended that both he and the plaintiff were parties in the business. About the month of August, 1936 (2 months after the purchase of the restaurant and eight years before the plaintiff giving evidence in Court) the plaintiff set down in writing in a document (marked Ext. A) what he alleges to be terms of the arrangement and handed over this document to one E, a lawyer and a friend of the defendant. The document Ext. A was not signed but was admittedly written by the plaintiff himself.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Held:</span></strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> A document written in 1936 cannot corroborate evidence to be given by the writer eight years later. The fact that in 1944, when the parties were at arms’ length, the plaintiff gave untrue evidence in the witness box does not afford an adequate reason for supposupporting in August 1936 when the parties were friendly and motive for misrepresentation was non-existent, he deliberately misrepresented an arrangement arrived at 2 months earlier.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ext. A is a most important contemporary document which correctly stated the terms agreed between the parties.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Hubert James Vs. Gulam Hossain Paksuma (1949) 1 DLR (PC) 5.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Co-sharer—</span></strong>Co-sharer, what it means—A co sharer, whatever the extent of his right in the joint property, is a co-owner in every inch of that property to the extent of his share until partition takes place which he can claim as a matter of right.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Mardan Shah Vs. Shah Nasar Khan (1970) 22 DLR (SC) 149.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—Co-sharer’s possession</span></strong>—A co-sharer’s possession is a possession of all other co-sharers— Adverse possession by co-sharer can be claimed by assertion of hostile title—When exclusive title is claimed on the ground of ouster ad-valorem court-fee to be paid in respect of such share.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A co-sharer is Hot dispossessed only because he was kept out of possession as the possession of one co-sharer would be the possession for all.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sashi Kumar Vs. Sreemati Kusum Kumari Debi (1982) 34 DLR 128</span></em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—Co-sharer in tenancy and co-sharer tenant—</span></strong>The expression ‘co-sharer in the tenancy’ and ‘co-sharer tenant of the holding’ are not synonymous—’Co-sharer in the tenancy’ includes ‘co-sharer tenant”. An unrecognized purchaser of a nontransferable holding is a ‘co-sharer in the tenancy’ but not a ‘co-sharer tenant.’</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Basharat Ullah Shaikh Vs. Faizuddin (1956) 8 DLR 367.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Co-tenant.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">See under co-sharer’ <em>Sayed Abul Fazal Vs. Nirodbala Deb Roy (1956) 8 DLR 181.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Counsel’s privilege—</span></strong>Its limits—Derogatory language against Judges of a Court of Record undermines confidence in justice<em>. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">S. M. Huq Vs. Honorable  Judges of High Court, Lahore. (1953) 5 DLR (FC) 216.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Courts. Its meaning</span></strong>—There is no exhaustive definition of a Court in any statute. There are essential certain characteristics which invest a body with the character of a Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A Court is, according to Coke on Littleton, a place where justice is judicially administered and justice is understood, in the forensic world, to be a decision of a binding nature given on a point of dispute in a us between two or more contending parties, by applying the law of the land to the facts of the case, untrammeled by the subjective attitude of the decision-making body in exercise of the judicial power of the state and by following a judicial procedure.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It has, therefore, been sometimes observed that although it is extremely difficult to say what a Court is but ii is comparatively easy to say what a Court is not.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">IDBP Vs. Master Industries (1974) 26 DLR 157.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—An authority, appointed under section 15 of the Payment of Wages Act, is not a court but a persona designata.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Golam Ahmad Vs. Muhammad Ata Karim (1957)9DLR 382.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Tests for determining whether a tribunal is a court or not: (1) ‘acting judicially’ —Acting judicially in order to be a sign of acting s a court, must be acting as a part of the judicial machinery of the State, charged with the duty of determining the rights of one subject against another or questions of right between the subject and the State, and discharging its functions according to the established form of judicial procedure: and (2) When a tribunal acted in a manner similar to that of the court of justice, Its (i) constitution, (ii) functions, and (iii) procedure shall have to be looked into for determining whether it was a tribunal of judicial character. 8 <em>PLR (Dac) 1163.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Court of Appeal— </span></strong>Change of law—Court of Appeal can take notice of law which has changed after institution of the suit.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Mohan Singh Vs. Tan Mia (1970) 22 DLR 593.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Court of facts and issues of facts.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The Court of fact must decide all the issues of fact which arise between the parties so that if the appellate Court takes a different view, the parties are saved from further harassment.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Rakhal Chandra Vs. Benode Haldar (1976)28 DLR 421.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Court—When becomes functus officio.</span></strong> A distinction is to be drawn between a case when the proceeding has terminated and one in which it has not terminated and the court still retains control over it. Whether the court still retains control over the proceeding or not must be determined upon the nature of the proceeding and the order passed therein.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sheik Ayezuddin Vs. Priya Shankar Chowdhury (1954)6 DLR 595.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Jurisdiction of a court over a decision made by an executive authority when the same is authorized by law—The court is not competent to investigate the grounds and reasonableness of such decision.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Ajit Kumar Das Vs. Province of East Pakistan (1959) 11 DLR 243.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Court to protect legislative competency, as regards past action.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is to be observed that endeavor of the Court will be to protect the legislative competency and the attempt of Parliament to validate past actions, so far as canon of judicial interpretation of legislative power under the Constitution permits.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Mafizur Rahman Khan Vs. Bangladesh (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 322.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Court’s solemn duty—to come to a conclusion that the will was not obtained by fraud or under influence.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Paresh Chandra Bhowmik Vs. Hiralal Nath (1984)36 DLR (AD) 156.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Propounded must satisfy the court with convincing reasons where suspicious circumstances exist that the will was the genuine act of the testator.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Paresh Chandra Bhowmick Vs. Ihiralal Nath (1984)36 DLR (AD) 156.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Court—Subordinate Court in relation to an order passed by superior Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If any step is taken by any subordinate Court having ordinary normal jurisdiction in ignorance of any order of a superior Court. the subsequent orders passed by the subordinate Court are not ipso facto null and void, but they will stand unless they are either recalled or are set aside.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Rani Harshamukhi Vs. Maharaja Shashi Kanta (1955) 7 DLR 473 (495 r.h. cot.).</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Although an ex parte order of stay is a valid order, it does not ipso facto nullify all the proceedings of the Court of the first instance passed subsequently. If the Court comes to know of the orders of the superior Court, it should always act on the orders of the superior Court and the question is not a question of communication only but is one of knowledge of the Court and this knowledge may be direct or indirect.  <em>Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—As soon as a subordinate Court is satisfied of the existence of such an order of a superior Court, it must act on it. <em>Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Superior court’s observation and the Lower Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Observations and findings (in an ad-interim injunction matter) by the appellate Court which do not arise for decision of the matter pending before it should not influence the trial Court when the same matter comes before it for final adjudication<em>. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Modern Talkies Vs. Chowrangee Cinema (1976) 28</span></em> <em>DLR 415.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Some of the trappings of a court do not necessarily make a civil court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Mahendra Nath Biswas Vs. Dulal Ratan (1959) 11 DLR 193.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—What is or is not a court—A body whose primary and only object is administrative, executive or arbitral cannot be converted into a court. Essential difference between judicial power and arbitral power—Whether a tribunal is a court depends upon the substance—Incidents of a court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Attorney-General of Australia Vs. The Queen (1958) 10 DLR 9 (PC).</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Court and Tribunal—Difference between them—Authority under the Police Officers (SP) Ordinance is tribunal.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">There is a distinction between a Court and a tribunal. The Court has a clear and distinct connotation whereas a tribunal assumes wide range of character. It may be judicial tribunal, or it may be a domestic tribunal, and in between these are various ranges of adjudicating authority, which arc more often called administrative tribunals.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Bangladesh &amp; ars. Vs. AKM Zahangir Hossain (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 174.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Court Martial</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The Court Martial set up under the Army Act is at best a military tribunal and not a Court as contemplated under Article 109 of the Constitution.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Jamil Huq Vs. Bangladesh (1982) 34 DLR MD) 127</span></em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Court Martial are ad-hoc courts, are out of the ambit of Civil Courts.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The Court Martial is the creation of the Army Act and these are all ad-hoc Courts unlike the Courts as understood by the common parlance. <em>Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Court Martial if constituted legally, any jurisdictional error in procedure—Immune from writ jurisdiction.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If the Court is constituted legally and if the error in procedure has not affected the jurisdiction of the Court then the civil Court will not go into the question as to the sufficiency of evidence because those entirely arc beyond the realm of the writ jurisdiction. These are eminently within the jurisdiction of an appellate Court. <em>Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Court fee</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Pre-emption suit—Decision as to the amount of court-fee on plaint and question as regards jurisdiction of Court should be on merits and not on a prima facie basis with reference to price given in sale deed. <em>(1955) PLR (Lah) 1046.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—‘Cessante Ratione Legis Cessat Ipsa Lex’—Reason to prevail.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Reason is the soul of the law and when reason of any particular law ceases, so does the law itself (Cessante Ratione Legis Cessat Ipsa Lex)<em>. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Kari PaIan Mia Vs. State (1983) 35 DLR 118 A.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">‘Cultivable land’</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The qualifying words ‘cultivable’ indicates that the land must be capable of cultivation without alteration or conversion. It cannot mean a conversion of land from one use to another. The word ‘cultivable’ clearly shows that the legislature never intended to include hat and bazar within clause(ii) of section 20(2)b) of East Bengal State Acquisition and Tenancy Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Yusuf Ali Chowdhury Vs. Province of East Pakistan (1957) 9 DLR 674.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Custody</span></strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">—Question of custody—loses its relevance when the girl concerned is found to be aged over 16 years—She neither being an accused or a witness in the case cannot be held in detention under courts order but is free to go to any place of her liking. </span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Ananda Mohan Vs. Stale. (1983) 35 DLR 315.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Customary Law—Form and applicability</span></strong>: Law of inheritance—Onus of proof—where a party sets up the pica of customary law in preference to personal law—onus is upon the party which sets up the plea.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Mst. Qaiser Khatoon Vs. Mvi. Abdul Huq (1973) 25 DLR (SC) 104.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Onus of proof of the existence of customary law—Onus of proving existence of legal necessity for transfer of ancestral property in Gujjar tribe (NWFP) is on the person who supports transfer.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sarfraz Vs. Md. Khan (1970) 22 DLR (SC) 34.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—Customary Law (Punjab).</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Muslim Jats of Gurdaspur District (West Pakistan) are governed by Chundawand rule of succession—Widow in presence of sons of her husband by another wife entitled to half share of property as widow’s customary estate terminable on her death or remarriage.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Mushtaq Ahmad Vs. Mst. Hakim Bibi (1969)21 DLR (SC) 375.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Customary right—Right of pasturage when can be claimed.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Customary right of pasturage presupposes that it must be in existence on the assertion of that right by the person enjoying the same as of right and not dependant on the consent or otherwise of anybody else.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A Court of Appeal can take notice of law which has changed after institution of the suit.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Mohan Singh Vs. Tan Mia (1970) 22 DLR 593.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—Custom—</span></strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">How ripens into a recognized right and obtains force of law— Burden of proof.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is undoubted that a custom observed in a particular district derives its force from the fact that it has, from long usage, obtained in that district, the force of law. It must be ancient; .but it is not of the essence of this rule that its antiquity must in every case be carried back to a period beyond the memory of man—still less that it is ancient in the English technical sense. Ii will depend upon the circumstances of each case what antiquity must be established before the custom can be accepted. What is necessary to be proved is that the usage has been acted upon in practice for such a long period and with such invariability as to show that it has, by common consent, been submitted to as the established governing rule of the particular district.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Intaj Ali Vs. Yadulla. (1960) 12 DLR 573.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A customary right can exist only in relation to the inhabitants of a district or a locality and it cannot be claimed in respect of the public at large. The custom if established, makes the local law of the district and it creates a right in each of the inhabitants irrespective of his interest in any particular property. If the law has to uphold it as a right, it should be immemorial in origin, certain and reasonable in nature and continuous in use.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Asia Khatun Vs. Sufia Banu. (1955) 7 DLR 71.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Customs officers.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Customs officers do not possess sufficient competency to be entrusted with the duty where the law requires careful consideration of questions of discharging burden of proof.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Collector of Customs Karachi Vs. Haji Usman Haji Ghani. (1959) II DLR (SC) 200 (220).</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Customs Waters.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It means a 12-mile belt of the sea from the base line (of Bangladesh sea coast).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">M. Samboom Asavhame Vs. Bangladesh (1979) 31 DLR 256.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">‘Dakhalkar’</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In the current settlement, 1932 the dependants were recorded as dakhalkar, that person in possession.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It cannot be said that the settlement record does not recognize the tenancy, merely because the word dakhaikar has been used. The entry is to be read as a whole.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Braja Mohan Shaha Vs. Abu Syed (1953) 5 DLR 209.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Dakhilas</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Evidentiary value of dakhilas which are but private documents—Dakhilas in order to carry weight in a court of law has to be proved by the scribe who wrote them by the signature of the excitant and when such signatures are disputed by comparing disputed signatures.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Kalimuddin Sarder Vs.
