Assistant Custodian Enemy Property (1983) 35 DLR 129.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—Its evidentiary value about the question of possession.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Dakhilas cannot be held to be an evidence of hostile possession and ouster of a co-sharer. By mere payment of rent of land a co-sharer cannot exclude another co-sharer’s title to it<em>. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Dr. Jamiar Rahman Asia Bibi Vs. Tajuddin Sikder (1978) 30 DLR 259.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Damages</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Principle for assessment of damages—Place the party who has suffered in the same position as he would have been if he had not sustained the wrong—Assessment of replacement cost should be made on the date when the property was destroyed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">BIWT Corp. Vs. Hellenic Lines Ltd. (1976) 28 DLR 77.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Assessment of the amount of damages for injuries caused to the plaintiff.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The plaintiff suffered a severe injury on his right foot resulting in fractures of bones. This injury was responsible for disabling the plaintiff in regard to his movement for 5 or 6 months, and whatever physical deformity may have been complained of was due to this injury.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Abdul Awal Vs. Mofasiluddin (1975) 27 DLR 629.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—In a suit for damages for the alleged cutting away of the paddy, the main question is whether the plaintiff is in possession of the land and whether the plaintiff grew paddy.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Rakhal Chandra Vs. Benode Haldar (1976) 28 DLR 421.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">“Damages” in case of inevitable accident—Cannot be claimed.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Defendant Vessel Taika Maru in order to avoid accident with a third vessel struck the plaintiff-vessel MV Gai and it was pleaded as an inevitable accident in defense.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Held:</span></strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> The accident was an inevitable accident and the accident Look place in spite of all the efforts of the Master and Sukhanies of the vessel Taika Maru and there was no negligence or absence of good seamanship on the pan of the crew of M V. Taika Maru and that the accident took place in order to avert a more serious accident.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Owners of the Vessel M. V. Gazi Rahi,nani Industries Lid. Vs. Owners and Parties interested in the Vessel MV ‘Taika Maru” (1968) 20 DLR 225.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Damages, suit for—</span></strong>A suit for damages for the use and occupation of land and mesne profit when maintainable.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Plaintiffs brought a suit for recovery of money by way of damages against the defendant on the allegation that they had cut away the paddy grown by the plaintiffs on their land.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Held:</span></strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> The plaintiffs having not filed a suit for declaration of title could have asked for compensation for the reaping away of paddy had they been able to prove their possession and growing of the paddy. Otherwise the plaintiffs in such a suit have to pay for declaration of their title to the land and its recovery from wrongful possession and must show that the suit was filed within the prescribed period of time. The plaintiffs in the instant case filed a money suit where their title was incidentally found by the Courts below. A suit for damages for the use and occupation of land and mesne profit when maintainable where the plaintiffs’ title to the land and the wrongful use and occupation of it by the defendant are proved. </span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Haleman Bewa Vs. Gahar Ali Mondol  (1980) 32 DLR (AD) 136.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—Damages for use and occupation—</span></strong> Title of the suit land found with the plaintiff— Defendant liable to pay damage.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If the defendant had chosen to grow paddy on somebody elses land, they have done so at their own risk and peril and must pay for it. The suit for compensation irrespective of the plaintiff’s possession was maintainable at his instance when he has been able to prove his title in the Suit land.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Gaher Ali Mandal Vs. Manik Sikder (1975) 27 DLR 400.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">“<strong>Day”—Commencement of day under the Bengalee calendar.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A day under the Bengalee calendar starts with the sunrise and continues up to sunrise of the following day whereas a day according to the English calendar commences on the expiry of 12 O’clock at mid-night and Continues up to the following 12 O’clock mid-night.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Surutannessa Bibi Vs. Debendra Nath Barman (1966) 18 DLR 490.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Dearness allowance—Principles on which it is given.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Dearness allowance is given to counteract the rise in prices when it is considered that the stage of revision of the basic wages is not reached, but if a revision takes place with reference to the prices up-to-date there is hardly any justification for the dearness allowance.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Even if it is assumed that while revising the basic wages, dearness allowance may also be given it must be on the ground that the basic wage is raised to meet true rise in prices partially and in order to meet the rest of the rise in prices dearness allowance is given.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Dalmia Cement Co. Vs. Dalmia Cement Factory Workers Union (1958) 10 DLR (SC) 157.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Death Register</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Birth and Death Register—Proof of age.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Birth and Death Register maintained under Act IV of 1873 and the Register of births and deaths kept at the Police Station under the Village Choukidar Act (Act VI of 1870) arc public documents within the meaning of sections 74 and 35 of the Evidence Act. Entries in birth and death registers arc prima-facie proof of statements as to age contained Therein.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Abdul Rahman Vs. Upendra Narayan Majumdar. (1952) 4 DLR 237.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Decree</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If the decree is one without jurisdiction—Whether pecuniary, territorial or in respect of the judgment-debtor—the executing Court can go into the question of excitability.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Hajee Md.</span></em> <em>Ahsanullah Vs. Arafatunessa Bibi (1981) 33 DLR (AD) 17.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—Fraudulent decree—</span></strong>A decree alleged to have been obtained by fraud cannot be set aside without express finding as to the effect that the decree was obtained by fraud.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Mofazzal Molla Vs. Parul Bala Debi (1972) 24 DLR 116.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—Decree when infructuous.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Court not to pass a decree which may be infructuous. No court should pass a decree which is infructuous and can be set at naught at the will of a person who has not been made a party to the Suit.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">F was a necessary party to the suit but due to her absence on account of not impleading her as a party to the suit the entire Suit cannot fail. The plaintiffs can be no suited only in respect of the land in which F has possession and interest.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Fakir Chand Mia Vs. Qumaruzzaman (1974) 26 DLR 233.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—No Court should pass a decree which is infructuous. Person not made party to a Suit.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is one of the established principles of judicial procedure that no court should pass a decree which is infructuous and can be sot at naught at the will of a person who has not been made a party to the suit.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Asadunnessa Vs. Qumaruzzaman (1974)26 DLR 363.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—Merger of</span></strong>: Trial Court’s decree becomes merged in the decree of the appellate Court and consequently after the merger trial Court loses jurisdiction to amend the decree.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sajeda Khatoon Vs. Mostafa Khatoon (1976) 28 DLR 221.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—Decree in a mortgage suit.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In a compromise decree in a mortgages suit where it was provided that on failure to pay single installment the whole amount outstanding would become due and recoverable by sale of mortgage properties and in case of deficiency by sale of mortgagor’s other properties and also from the person of the mortgagor by executing the decree:</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Held:</span></strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> The compromise decree went beyond final decree in directing sale of the properties of the mortgagor not included in the mortgage. But the decree itself could not be held to contain a personal decree as on the date of the compromise the court was not in a position to determine whether any balance would be legally recoverable after the sale. The decree amounted to more than a submission by the mortgagor to consent to a personal decree for the payment of the ultimate balance, if and when any such balances should be found to be due and legally recoverable. </span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Joy Chand Lal Babu Vs. Kamalaksha Chowdhury (1949) 1 DLR 46 (PC).</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—‘Preliminary decree’.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is a completely erroneous view that the pre. liminary decree once passed cannot be amended.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Omed All Sikder Vs. Arman Sikder (1979)31 DLR (AD) 320.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—Decree, void and voidable—Distinction between.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The distinction between void and voidable decree is to be borne in mind. If the decree is voidable then unless it is avoided by a proper procedure, the decree stands, and is to be executed. In this regard wrong exercise of jurisdiction and absence of jurisdiction is to be noticed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Hajee Md. Ahsanullah Vs. Arafatunnessa Bibi (1981) 33 DLR (AD) 17</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Deemed to accrue or arise.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The expression “deemed to accrue or arise” cannot be extended to include income from a nonexistent source of income like irrecoverable loans advanced by the assessee to its customers.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Commissioner of Income Tax Vs. Lackatoorah Tea Co. (1979)31 DLR 396.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Declaratory suit.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—No consequential relief need be sought—Document being forged no consequential relief needed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Faiz Ahmed Vs. KA Wahab (1984)36 DLR 357.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">“Defamatory statement”—</span></strong>defined.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Defamatory statement is a statement which, if published, of and concerning a person, is calculated to lower him in the estimation of right-thinking men or cause him to be shunned or avoided or to expose him to hatred, contempt or ridicule, or to convey an imputation on him disparaging or injurious to him in his Office, profession, calling, trade or business.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Khawaja Nooruddin Vs. Hamidul Huq Chowdhury (1963) 15 DLR 501.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Double standard for ascertaining whether a statement is defamatory—according to the literacy and intelligence of the people concerned.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In a democracy where the mass is conscious of its power, sensitive about the violation of the trust in a person and is vigilant and anxious to enforce its power to bring the culprit to book and the person entrusted with power wants to live up to the expectation of the public or voters and eager to accept the verdict of the people and places his cards on the table for ascertaining the elements whether there has been any defamation, one standard should be used and in a society where the public is illiterate, unconscious of its power and does not know how to enforce its power to bring the betrayers to book the person entrusted being skilled takes recourse to all steps to hood-wink the public, another standard in ascertaining whether there has been any defamation should be used.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In our country most of the people are illiterate and unmindful of the events that happen in the Legislature or of the actions of their representatives. They are not conscious of their power nor do they criticize their representatives or take them to task. Only a handful of them is criticizing—the Press Ling one of them. In such circumstances, in our country, at the present moment, the Press should have more liberty and latitude than it has in other advanced Countries in criticizing the popular representatives and the Government in order to keep them within the bounds, it being the only influential body, at present, in our country. Though the Press may go a bit out of the way, it should not be hauled up for that excess. Human nature being as it is, a man, in power, unrestricted, is expected to go to excess under circumstances.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Khawaja Nooruddin is. Hamidul Huq Chowdhury (1 963)15 DLR 501.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Presumption of law as to falsity and ma lice—Presumption rebuttable. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Damage claimed for defamatory statement— burden that is on the plaintiff. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Comment otherwise fair even though deviates slightly from accuracy not within the mischief of law. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Default order.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—(such as “the case shall stand dismissed’, etc.) when made, different considerations arise— Crucial test is to find the real purport of die order— When after passing an order a court becomes <em>functus officio</em> and when not. Whether an order is a self-executory default order or a conditional order—the court is the best authority to judge.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Hajee Md. Ahsanullah Vs. Arafatunnessa Bibi (1981) 33 DLR (AD) 17</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Apart from this even, if default has taken place by virtue of self-executory order, the Court can review its own order as provided in CP Code. Thus whether the order is final in the sense that with the passing of it the court as far as the question of extension of time is concerned becomes functus officio or whether it is just a conditional order—”the court passing the conditional order is the best authority to judge”—Over and above the court can review its own order under the provisions of CP Code and extend deposit time on the authority of reviewing its own order. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—When part of costs ordered to be deposited out of time does not amount to default.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Tajendra Dhar Vs. Rohini Ranjan Saha (1971) 23 DLR 45.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Delay causing loss</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Circumstances which caused further delay in getting the goods to be taken into account while assessing the loss.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Al-Sayer Navigation Co. Vs. Delta International Traders Ltd. (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 111.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">“Delegated legislation”</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Instructions issued under the Act do not bear the character of delegated legislation.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The instructions which the Central Government issue under Act III of 1956 are not of the nature of delegated legislation at all, for, the. legislature itself having determined that claims were to be filed in respect of the properties left in India by displaced persons, the instructions merely provided as to whom from amongst that class should be treated as entitled to lodge such a claim.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Syed Abdur Rashid Vs. Pakistan (1962)14 DLR (SC) 41.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">“Delegation of legislative power”</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Bestowal of large discretion to executive authority by the legislature under the Arms Act does not amount to delegation of legislative authority.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">District Magistrate, Lahore Vs. Syed Raza Kazim (1961) 13 DLR (SC) 66.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">“Delegation”—</span></strong>Judicial or quasi-judicial administration bodies and Courts can delegate their functions.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Mian Muhammad Sarif Vs. Member, Election Commission, Lahore (1968) 20 DLR (WP)</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—“Delegation” of functions by EIection Commission and Chief Election Commissioner permissible. <em>  Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Delivery of possession.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Certified copy of the writ of delivery of possession supported by the evidence of the decree holder himself and one of the mukabila witnesses is sufficient to establish that delivery of possession was given to the decree holder.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Rakhal Chandra Das Vs. Benccha Khatun (1972) 24 DLR 63.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Symbolical delivery of possession, in the eye of law, has the effect of actual possession so far as judgment-debtors are concerned. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Symbolical delivery of possession would operate as against the judgment-debtor but will be of no avail against a person who was not a party to the proceeding.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">With regard to sale by Court, the position is that, as against the judgment-debtor, symbolical possession obtained by the purchaser would amount to dispossession of the judgment-debtor.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">But with regard to a person who is not party to the suit, physical possession, that is, actual possession, must be established.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Afajuddin Vs. Munshi Sona Meah (1965) 17 DLR 313.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—Delivery of possession—Symbolical</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">X, the owner of the property transferred the suit-lands to Y. Subsequent to the transfer the property was sold in certificate proceedings in which X was a party and not Y, and thereafter symbolical possession was taken against X. Held: Y’s interest not affected by the sale.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The position resolves itself thus: X, the original owner of the suit lands, transferred them to plaintiffs. Subsequent to such transference, there was a default in payment of public dues in respect of the suit lands which were put to certificate-sale where in X was made a party but not the plaintiffs. A delivery of mere symbolical possession of the suit-lands to the purchaser of the certificate-sale will not amount to dispossession of plaintiffs, who were not parties to the certificate-proceedings. Therefore, as against plaintiffs, the only kind of dispossession by the certificate purchaser must be actual physical dispossession.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Afajuddin Vs. Munshi Sona Meah (1965) 17 DLR 313.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—Delivery of possession, Order of— when withdrawn</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Until and unless the order’ of the executing Court recalling the writ of delivery of possession is communicated to the peon charged with the execution of the writ of delivery of possession, the delivery of possession given by him cannot be characterised as ultra vires.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Mozibur Rahman Vs. Jamini Moshu (1955) 7 DLR 82.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Departmental Enquiry</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Departmental enquiry about the conduct of one of its employees—cannot be interfered with by a court of law, as long as such enquiry is held in accordance with procedure laid down and does not violate the principle of natural justice.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Chittagong Port Authority Vs. Sujjat Ali (1984) 36 DLR 181.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A suit in a court of law against a departmental enquiry—Court will follow the same principle of non-interferences long as the departmental rules are observed and principle of natural justice is followed. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Depreciation fund</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A depreciation fund is an absolute necessity in relation to any modern industry and is maintained with a view to provide for replacement of machinery, and this need not be only due to wear and tear over a long period of time; there may be an accident, or certain machinery may suffer from major defects and require replacement for the purpose of proper operation of the company. An accident may occur, such as an earthquake, and for such cases it is necessary that there should be provision available to the company to make good the damage out of its own resources.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A 5 per cent rate of deduction out of the total profits of a company on account of the depreciation fund is one which is in accordance with industrial practice, and is allowed for purposes of assessment of income tax as well.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Zeal Pak. Cement Factory Vs. Cement Labour Association (1960) 12 DLR (SC)1.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Deputation posts</span></strong>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Officers of a Province holding a post on deputation to the Centre cannot validly object if he is reverted to his old post in the Province, cannot set up the plea that his post on deputation was higher in rank, because he does not acquire any right in himself to hold such a post. A reduction from a deputation post is not a reduction in rank.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Pakistan Vs. Fazlur Rahman Khundkar (1959)11 DLR (SC) 253.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">“Determine”</span></strong> —The word shows that the Government cannot act arbitrarily.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The word “determine” in section 4 of the Act shows that the Central Government cannot act arbitrarily and without a factual basis, and the legislature has laid down sufficient norms and standard for the purpose of determination of such rate.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Adamjee Jute Mills Vs. Controller of Imports (1968) 20 DLR 791</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Deviation of ship.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Ship’s owner held responsible for unauthorized deviation of the ship which carried the concerned goods.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In the instant case, the ship instead of proceeding from a North Yemen port to Bangladesh proceeded to the opposite direction to Dar-es-Salam. It was in violation of the bill of lading. There is no doubt that this deviation was unauthorized. The ship owners, therefore, must be held responsible for this unjustified deviation and this deviation is one of the causes of delay.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Al-Sayer Navigation Co. Vs. Delta International Traders Ltd. (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 111</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Discharge and dismissal</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The term ‘discharge’ as defined under clause (I) of section 2 of the Standing Orders, 1965 means “the termination of services of a worker by the employer for reasons of physical or mental incapacity or continued ill-health of the worker or such other similar reasons not amounting to misconduct and the term ‘dismissal’ as defined under clause (g) of section 2 of the said Standing Orders means the termination of service of a worker by the employer for misconduct.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Aminul Islam Vs. James Finlay (1974) 26 DLR (SC) 33.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Discharged</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A “discharged” employee entitled to the benefit of section 11 of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If the employer discharges an employee even on grounds of physical incapacity that too, would amount to a discharge” which will entitle the employee to the benefits contemplated by section 11 of East Bengal Act I of 1952.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">A Sukur Vs. Chairman, 1st Labour Court (1968)20 DLR 520.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">“<strong>Disciplined force”</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Army, navy and air force is part of the disciplined force.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In the Constitution, for the first time, a new conception has been introduced, that of ‘disciplined force’, in the services of Bangladesh.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Jamil Huq Vs. Bangladesh (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 126.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>‘Discrepant statement’ and ‘contradictory statement’</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A discrepant statement is not fatal to the credibility of a witness. A contradictory statement is one which is conflicting and is not reconcilable with other statement either of his own or any other witness. The question in such case is that, it is open to a court of fact either to reject the whole evidence of a witness as untrustworthy or to reject the contradictory part as unreliable or to rely upon that portion, which, in the opinion of the court, fits in with other evidence and die facts and circumstances of the case. The exercise of the power is guided by judicial discretion, and cannot be exercised either arbitrarily or capriciously.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Moyezuddin Vs. State (1979) 31 DLR (AD) 37.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Dismissal</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Dismissal order passed by an authority was set aside by another competent authority—The next superior authority cannot uphold the original order of dismissal as the dismissal order was in existence having been set aside in the meanwhile— A Sub-Inspector of Police was dismissed by the</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Superintendent of Police on a charge of corruption and misconduct. On an appeal by the aggrieved party, the Deputy Inspector-General set aside the order of dismissal and remanded the proceeding for a fresh enquiry. On remand the S. P. again passed an order of dismissal. Thereupon an appeal was again preferred before the DIG who again set aside the order of dismissal and directed a de novo enquiry. Thereafter the matter was taken to the Inspector-General of Police, who by his order dated 18-3-55 upheld the order of the S.P., by whom the order of dismissal, was originally passed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Held:</span></strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> On 18-3-55, when the IGP passed the order upholding the order of dismissal passed by the SP, the dismissal order did not subsist and was of no legal effect at that time, inasmuch as it had been set aside by the order of the DIG and as such the order of  IGP was misconceived. </span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">ASM Shamsul Alam Chowdhury Vs. Province of E Pak. (1962) 14 DLR 553.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—“Dismissal for default’</span></strong> and not a Judgment—Party may be heard.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Mozahar Sikder Vs. Farid uddin Ahmed (1983) 35 DLR 235.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—Dismissal for non-appearance</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Counsel present in Court when the case was called on for hearing—Prayers for an adjournment being refused counsel left the Court for fetching his brief but he found the case on return to have been dismissed for default and the prayer (orally as well by petition) to have the case restored rejected:</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Held:</span></strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> In refusing the prayer for restoration, the Court acted with undue severity and the Supreme Court made an order restoring the case for hearing according to law. </span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Ali Akbar Vs. Khatun Nessa. (1959) 11 DLR (SC) 367.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Dissolution of partnership—Company affairs</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Confidence between the two share-holders completely shook—Dissolution appropriate.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Rahimuddin Ahmed Vs. Bengal Water Ways Ltd. (1979) 31 DLR 82.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Dividend—What it means</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Dividend means the sum of money set aside out of profits of a company for distribution amongst the share-holders.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Commr. of Income Tax Vs. Mrs. Masuda Khatun (1982)34 DLR (AD) 85.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Division Bench</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Division Bench (of the High Court) when on a point of law takes a different view from another Division Bench—Procedure it should follow— Where a Division Bench of the High Court is</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">inclined to take a different view from that in an earlier judgment of a similar Division Bench, one course open to the Court was to “have expressed their doubts regarding the view taken in the precedent case in a Court of co-equal jurisdiction, while yet following that view, and left the matter to be raised in appeal before this Court. The alternative course, under the Rules of die Court, was to refer the matter to a larger Bench.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Province of East Pak. Vs. Serajul Huq Patwari (1967)19 DLR (SC) 281.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Doctrine of Eclipse</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The doctrine of eclipse can be made applicable, although the term does not appear to be self- explanatory only to a pre-constitutional law which is otherwise a good law but, of which, on the enforcement of fundamental rights, life-breath has been taken out. It remains in a state of suspended animation and on the removal of the spell, as it were, it springs back into life, of its own motion without any further legislative effort. If the theory of subject- wise distribution of legislative powers as the only basis of legislative incompetence is accepted, then there can hardly be any case of a law being void ab initio under a unitary constitution.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Reference to the decisions under the American Constitution for the purpose of interpreting the provisions of the Constitution in another country cannot always be useful because of the fact that the Constitutions of the two countries arc drafted entirely in different languages. In the Constitution of the United States there is no such provision as contained in Article 4 of the 1956 Constitution of Pakistan or Article 6 of 1962 Constitution of Pakistan which arc almost in the same terms as Article 13 of the Indian Constitution.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Abdul Majid Bepari Vs. Kashem Ali (1975) 27 DLR 1.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Doctrine of Election</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">What it means. The doctrine of election is based on the principle that the election must be voluntary and not one under duress or compulsion.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Modern Talkies Vs. Chowrangee Cinema (1976) 28 DLR 415.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Doctrine of “indoor management”</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Its meaning. The doctrine of “indoor management’ is to the effect that persons contracting with a company and dealing in good faith may assume that acts within its constitution and powers have been duly performed and are not bound to enquire whether acts of internal management have been regularly done.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In the present case the lessee entered into an agreement of lease on the terms sealed by the Secretary of the Society. It was subsequently contended on behalf of the society that the Secretary was not authorized by the Managing Committee to enter into any contract and as such, the lease was not a valid lease.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Held:</span></strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> As the Secretary was entitled under the by-laws of the Society to enter into contract on behalf of the Society the lessee was not required to enquire whether the Society actually authorized the Secretary to enter upon the contract. Such transaction with the Society is saved by the doctrine of “indoor management’. </span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Pak. Employees Co-operative housing Society Ltd. Vs. Anwar Sultan (1969)21 DLR (14’?) 345.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Document</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The contention was that the document was incorrectly read and interpreted by High Court—But the document not printed or placed on record in appeal in Supreme Court—Objection rejected.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Divisibility of transaction of sale—No presumption on basis of recital in the deed that vendees took the property in specified shares, if consideration was mentioned as a lump sum.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Abdullah Vs. Abdul Karim (1968) 20 DLR (SC) 204.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—Two documents relating same transaction</span></strong>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">When a transaction is made by more than one document, then both the documents should be read together and the cumulative effect should be taken into consideration.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Dr. Habibur Rahman Vs. Md. Mansur (1973) 25 DLR 211.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Documents disputed, admissibility of—in a writ proceeding before the High Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Disputed documents cannot be accepted in evidence without strict proof thereof which is not possible in summary writ proceedings, the proper forum for proving such documents is the Civil Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In writ petitions parties are permitted to adduce evidence by affidavit but that does not mean that the documents annexed with the affidavit by the parties become ipso facto admissible irrespective of the rule of proof as laid down in the Evidence Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Anwar Hossain Dewan Vs. Deputy Custodian Enemy Properties (1969) 21 DLR 938.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—Attestation of document—</span></strong>Attestation of document—is no evidence as to the recital or contents thereof.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Basanta Kumar Basak Vs. Santosh Kumar Basak (1972)24 DLR 84.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Document—Construction of—</span></strong>Principle of exposition of one Act by language of another not applicable to instrument—In construing instrument, intention of parties is die primary consideration.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The principle of exposition of one Act by language of another cannot apply to the Instrument of Accession drawn up by a functionary of the Ministry of State and Frontier Regions. Indeed, the primary consideration is construing an instrument is to ascertain the intention of the parties to the instrument. CPSLA No. K 142 of 1968.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Fatoomal Vs. Rehabilitation Commissioner, Khairpur Division (1969) 21 DLR (SC) 291.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Photostat copies in the Court not entertainable.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In this case instead of giving original copies of the document or authenticated copies thereof as required under the rules, Photostat copies of the documents have been appended which are in violation of the rules, and arc also not readable without the aid of magnifying glass.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Secretary of the Govt. of East Pakistan Vs. Manik Chand Sardar (1968) 20 DLR 908.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—One document executed by several vendors owning different lands—not irregular.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Execution of a common document by several vendors is not irregular, if the lands sought to be transferred have been specifically described in the sale-deed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Ful Chand Das Vs.</span></em> <em>Mohammad Hammad (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 364.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—Execution and registration of— Sufficient to pass title.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Consideration may be a cash consideration or a promise to pay. In either case, title will pass with the execution and registration of the deed. In case of promise to pay consideration, the vendor may have a lien on the properties sold till considerations arc paid but title will pass with the execution and registration of the deed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sardar Menhazuddjn Ahmed Vs. Sudhir Kumar Sinha</span></em> <em>(1958) 10 DLR 621—8 PLR (Dacca) 454.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—Execution and registration not sufficient proof of voluntary execution</span></strong>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Mere registration cannot be regarded as affording sufficient proof of the voluntary execution of the will much less of us being executed while of sound disposing mind. Where there are circumstance of suspicion, it is the duty of the Courts to accept such evidence with great caution.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Per Mohammad Munir, CJ,—Proof of registration proceedings raises the presumption that these proceedings were regular and honestly carried out, and the evidence of due registration is itself some evidence of execution against the person against whom the document is sought to be proved.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Fate Mohammad Vs. Mst. Niamat (1955) 7 DLR (FC) 165.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—<strong>Thumb impression.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Genuineness of executants thumb impression does not exonerate him from proving his knowledge  of the document’s content.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Thumb impression of the executants of a document was found to be genuine by the Finger Print Expert but that alone cannot exonerate the defendant from proving that the said executants executed the Kabala knowing fully the contents thereof.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Tamijur Rahman Vs. Md. Altafur Rahman (1969) 21 DLR 977:</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—Document of transfer of immovable property by a foreigner.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Kabala executed and registered in Bangladesh in 1975—Presumption is the executants was citizen of Bangladesh as no Indian national could transfer any property in Bangladesh (in 1975) by registration.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A kaixila executed and registered in Bangladesh in 1975 created a presumption that the registration authority was satisfied that the execuinni was a valid citizen and national of Bangladesh since an Indian national as such could not transfer any property in Bangladesh by way of any registered deed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The authority in the Government could not question and annual the validity of such title by an executive order. If the Government wanted to claim the title in such property it could only do so by way of an appropriate suit for declaration of title and cancellation of the registered kabala as such.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Sultanuddin Chowdhury Vs. Bangladesh (1980) 32 DLR 252.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Domestic Enquiry</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Domestic Enquiry is not governed by any statutory rules—Principles of natural justice (where do incstic enquiry is held) require that allegation against a person should be brought to his notice and he be given an opportunity to submit his defense.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">MA Hai Vs. Trading Corporation of Bangladesh (1979)31 DLR 326.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Domestic tribunal</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Order passed by a domestic tribunal to what extent subject to scrutiny—A domestic tribunal not bound by the provisions of Evidence Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Bikash Ranjan Vs. Chairman, 2nd Labour Court (1977) 29 DLR (SC) 280.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Domicile of Origin</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Loss of domicile of origin how to be established. To every adult person the law assigns a domicile which is called the domicile of origin and which remains attached to him until new and different domicile takes its place.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">There is absolutely nothing on the record to show that the accused respondent ever became an Indian citizen in substitution of his domicile of origin. Therefore, the domicile of origin remains attached to him.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Onus of proving that a domicile has been chosen in substitution for domicile of origin lies upon those who assert that the domicile of origin has been lost and that the domicile of origin continues unless a fixed and settled intention of abandoning the first domicile and acquiring another as sole domicile is clearly shown.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Superintendent and Remembrance of Legal Affairs, Govt. of Bangladesh Vs. Adyaita Chandra Adhikary. (1981) 33 DLR 314.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Due process of law.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Violation of—Government and its officer’s colossal irresponsibility in discharge of responsibility ‘imposed by law causing great sufferings to an innocent citizen.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Radha Kanta Banik Vs. The Deputy Commissioner of Rangpur (1979) 31 DLR 352=(1957) 9 DLR (SC) 21.</span></em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2434	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Words and Phrases [E, F, G]</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  (1978)30 DLR 304,  (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 162, (1968) 20 DLR 202, (1971) 23DLR 17, (1979) 31 DLR (AD) 296, (1980) 32 DLR 83, (1979) 31 DLR 58, (1977) 29 DLR (SC) 41, (1977) 29 DLR 393, (1977)  29 DLR 62, (1975 ) 27 DLR 76, (1980) 32 DLR (AD) 29, (1979) 31 DL</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Words and Phrase</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  1970-01-01</p><!DOCTYPE html><p> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Words and Phrases</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">“<strong>Earnest” and “earnest money”</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Earnest is something which must be given in the shape of money or some tangible thing at the time of the conclusion of the contract and should be available with the seller for forfeiture in case the transaction fails through the fault of the purchaser.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Earnest money must be paid at the time of the conclusion of the contract; it must be lying with the seller and that it is not the case any promise to pay the amount in lieu of earnest money cannot be treated as such and cannot be forfeited for the breach of the contract.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In a case where the seller besides forfeiting the earnest money has also after notice to the purchaser sold the goods in question, it is his duty to account for the sale proceeds and if the sale proceeds are sufficient to reimburse his claim, he must refund the amount lying with him as earnest money. The seller has no option either to forfeit the earnest money (and keep quiet) or to forfeit the earnest money and reimburse his losses by selling the goods at the risk and cost of the defaulting party; If he exercises the option and the sale proceeds are more than sufficient to meet his claim, then both in equity and law, he is bound to refund the amount of the earnest money forfeited by him<em>. PLR (1960) WP 685.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Easement—Right of way when cannot be claimed.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A right of way, as an easement of necessity, cannot be claimed for a convenient shortcut and for avoiding a cumbrous detour.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Abdul Hamid Vs. Abul Hussain (1978)30 DLR 304.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Educational institution</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Requisition of such institution under the Government authority for the purpose of allowing it to function properly cannot be found fault with.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Deputy Commissioner Vs. Winifred Rubi (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 162.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Rendering service beneficial to the nation— Because of the high charge in tuition fees—not a valid ground to overlook its importance.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The school is in the heart of the city of Dacca and it is catering education for about 2000 students in three shifts. Obviously it is rendering a service to the community in general in training the future generation of the nation. If the fees are high the Court has nothing to do because it is essentially a question of bare economics.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Bangladesh represented by the Deputy Commissioner Vs. Winifred Rubi (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 162.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">“<strong>Election” what the term connotes’.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Election means something more than mere fixation of date and time of election and the making of programme for election.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In its comprehensive sense, ‘election’ embraces the whole procedure whereby an entire process whereof the declaration of a candidate as duly elected is the result. In other words, ‘election’ means all the different steps or stages of the election, commencing from the issue of notification calling upon the constituency or the electorate to elect and ending with the publication of the result of the poll. These steps or stages of election do necessarily include, among others, scrutiny of nomination papers and their acceptance or rejection, declaration of results of the election and the certification of the name of the candidates declared elected.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Serajul Islam Vs. Mr. Farid Ahmed (1968) 20 DLR 202.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Election dispute.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Rejection of a ballot paper, which was cast in favour of a particular candidate, without giving him opportunity against the rejection of the ballot paper offends the principle of natural justice.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Md. Nurul Haque Joardar Vs. Province of East Pakistan (1971) 23DLR 17.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Appeal before the Commissioner while the dispute is pending with the Collector—Not maintainable. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Election Tribunal</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Election petition before Election Tribunal which has powers of a civil court under CPC.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">An Election Tribunal has all the powers of a Civil Court trying a suit under the Code of Civil Procedure for the purpose of trying the election dispute.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Abul Basher Chowdhury Vs. Habibur Rahman Mia (1979) 31 DLR (AD) 296.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Employees in autonomous body</span></strong>— Procedure to follow in domestic enquiry against employees.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Disciplinary action against employees in autonomous bodies do not attract provisions of Articles 133 and 135 of the Constitution of Bangladesh.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The present proceedings arc in relation to autonomous bodies for holding domestic enquiries. In taking disciplinary action against employees engaged in autonomous bodies the procedure prescribed for taking disciplinary action in the service rules should be complied with. The elaborate procedure and requirements which are available in a court of law to an accused or the protection available in accordance with the service rules framed under Articles 133 and 135 of the Constitution of Bangladesh are not binding upon the employer for taking disciplinary action against its employees.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Md. Loqman Vs. BADC (1980) 32 DLR 83.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—Employees of Nationalized Industries.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Employees of Nationalized Industries are not Government servants or persons in the service of the Republic. Even in the case of government servants or persons in the service of the Republic, they are not entitled to the benefit of any recommendation of the Pay Commission unless such recommendations are implemented by the Government by publishing it in the official gazette under Act XXXII of 1975.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Manager, A industries Vs. Abdus Sattar (1979) 31 DLR 58.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Employer and employee.</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Law governing service conditions in statutory corporation.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">We are concerned in these two appeals with the statutory bodies of public character, viz Bangladesh nail Industries Corporation and Janata Bank and in law governing the employees of such bodies may be briefly stated as follows:</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">(a) If an employee is dismissed or his service is terminated in contravention of mandatory statutory provision, the employee has a right of action either in a Superior Court in its writ jurisdiction or in a Civil Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">(b) If the service of its employee’ is terminated in violation of the principle of natural justice the employee has a similar right of action as in (a).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Employee of a statutory corporation is not a government servant or public servant—When an employee of a statutory corporation is entitled for declaration of nullity—Precedent hearing or compliance with principles of natural justice in case of dismissal of an employee of statutory corporation.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">BSI Corpn. Vs. Mahbub Hossain (1977) 29 DLR (SC) 41.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Employees of statutory corporations entitled to challenge wrongful dismissal or termination under writ jurisdiction.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">SM Masood Al-Mamun Vs. Bangladesh (1977) 29 DLR 393</span></em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Act XXXI1 of 1975 passed in order to face challenge on issues of service re-organization, but in the absence of necessary notifications the Government is without any shelter. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—An employee of a statutory corporation is entitled to a show cause notice before he is dismissed. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Employee of a statutory body (here it is a nationalized Bank) may be dismissed without show cause notice in accordance with the terms of his employment.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Shamsuddin Vs. Janata Bank (1977)  29 DLR 62.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Employer and employee—Relation between them in matters of service condition to be governed by natural justice.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In the absence of any statutory provision regulating the service condition the law of master and servant will apply. In the case of the employees who are not governed by the statutory law the minimum requirement is that the principles of natural justice should be followed. It is not the case that a servant can always cling to his office because the employer has a choice.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Kushtia Sugar Mills Vs. Abdul Wadud (1975 ) 27 DLR 76.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Enemy Property</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Appellant after purchase is in possession of the property—before ii could be treated as enemy property the authority concerned must prove that the appellant or his vendors migrated to India before the Enemy Property Law came into operation in 1965.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Abul Khair Miah being dead his heirs: Abul Kashem and others Vs. Bangladesh &amp; others (1980) 32 DLR (AD) 29.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Custodian of the Enemy Property treating a property as being a vested property without lawful basis for treating it as such and leasing out the same to another is unauthorized and illegal.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Hiralal Agarwala Vs. Deputy</em> <em>Commissioner, Bogra (1979) 31 DLR 359.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—<strong>Notification of 3rd December, 1965.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A property being an enemy property cannot be dealt with by execution of a will—The property being but an enemy property the title to the property is not extinguished but only eclipsed—So a suit for Icuers of administration in respect of that property shall not be dismissed but stayed until the time it remains a vested property.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Goutam Ranjan</em> <em>Sen and ors. Vs. Bangladesh and ors. (1981) 33 DLR (AD) 175.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Treating a property as an enemy property on the basis of an enemy property case started in 1978 is not valid in law.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Niuya Gopal Roy Barman Vs. Pran Gopal Nandi (1980) 32 DLR 11.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>‘Entertain’ a suit is not the same thing as “execute a decree”.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The Court below observed ‘the present execution cannot be entertained”. This view is wrong.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In respect of suit the prohibition is against entertaining the same. So far as execution of a decree is concerned, the mandate is that no Civil Court shall “execute any decree”. The word “entertain” cannot apply to the expression “execute any decree.”</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sankar Bank Ltd. Vs. Sultan Bhuiya (1968) 20 DLR 63.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>‘Entertain’</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The word ‘entertain’ means to receive and to take into consideration and, therefore, it signifies initially the duty of the Court when proceeding is sought to be started before it.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Amjad Ali Vs. Asadulla (1952) 4 DLR 165.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>“Entertained the suit</strong>”.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Means that the suit shall not be considered by the Court and not that the filing of the suit is barred.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Dwarika Nath Das Vs. Md. Abdulla (1960)12 DLR 423.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>“Equal protection of law”.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Equal protection of law does not require that absolutely the same rule shall apply to all citizens irrespective of different circumstances. It merely enacts that equal protection and security of the laws should be given to all under like circumstances and conditions in the enjoyment of their civil rights.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Yick Wo Vs. hopkins (1886) 118 U/s. 357 rel. Shaikh Shamsul Huq Vs. Prov. of East Pakistan (1958) 10 DLR 417.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Equitable charge or assignment.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Transactions such as cases of hypothecation or mortgage of movables not in existence at the time of assignments by way of charge on future goods are not governed by Transfer of Property Act and since equity regards that as done which ought to be done, such mortgages or charges arc valid as equitable assignments fastening upon the property as soon as it comes into existence.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Kazi Abdul Ali Vs.
