Nurut Amin (1955) 7 DLR 406.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Equity—Latches.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Equity cannot assist plaintiff where there is undue laches on his part.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The defendant had executed a bainapatra in favour of the plaintiff to sell the suit properties to him on a certain date. It was specifically stipulated in the said contract that the plaintiff would take all necessary steps for obtaining permission for the sale of the properties. But the plaintiff did not take any step for obtaining permission before that date. When after that date he obtained permission and filed a suit for specific performance of contract it was held; equity should not assist where there had been undue latches on the part of die plaintiff.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Purnendu Kumar Das Vs. Hiran Kumar Das (1969) 21 DLR 918.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>“Error</strong> <strong>apparent on the face of the record”</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is not one if it is not self-evident and has to be established by long argument.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mufjalur Rahman Vs Fajal Karim (1976) 28 DLR 303.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">‘<strong>Erroneous decisions’</strong>—and ‘decision obtained with an error apparent on the face of the record’—Review permissible in the latter case. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Evidence—admissibility</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Evidence of PW whose conduct was hypocritical vis-à-vis the plaintiff can also be accepted.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Statement of witness, if hit by the rule of hearsay, is not admissible in evidence<em>.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Nurullah Choudhury Vs. Golam S Kazi (1974) 26 DLR 70.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Misreading or misrepresentation of evidence whereby merits of a decision is affected vitiates the judgment.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Khondkar Mohiuddin Vs. Syed Moin Ahmed (1976) 28 DLR (SC) 85.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Fraud, undue influence need not always be proved by oral evidence—Circumstances may be relied on for the purpose.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Although the onus is strictly on the defendants to prove fraud and undue influence and coercion in the face of the admitted signature of Asghar on the document, we cannot in the mere absence of oral evidence on the subject hold that the case of fraud, coercion and undue influence has not been made Out in the circumstances as disclosed and particularly, when the excitant is dead, who being man of failing health with financial worries reduced himself to a puppet.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">So far as the legality of the mutation effected. it is sufficient to state that this is merely an executive order which cannot confer title.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">SM Lulfullah vs. Bibi Badrunnessa (1968)20 DLR 1019.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Direct evidence having been disbelieved on good reasons, corroborative evidence in connection there  is of no help to the prosecution’s case.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Rahman Baksh Vs. The State (1970) 22 DLR 482.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">“<strong>Evidence Act”.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The Evidence Act’ does not apply in terms to these proceeding under the Workmen’s Compensation Act which arc of a summary nature.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Messrs.</em> <em>Ahmad Brothers Vs. Mahmoodul Hassan Khan (1965) 17 DLR (WP) 49.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Evacuee Laws.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Evacuee Laws</strong>—Evacuee laws enacted by Pakisian; validity extends to the former <em>State of </em>Khairpur.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Fatoomal Vs. Reh. Commr (1969)21 DLR (SC) 291</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Exchange of currency—Relevant date for conversion of foreign currency.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Two irrevocable letters of credit were opened by the defendant Bank, at the request of the plaintiff, a partnership firm. The payment for the goods was to be made at Calcutta on presentation of shipping documents including invoices in duplicate and bills of lading.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The letters of credit were to be available for negotiation to the extent of the amount mentioned by means of bills ‘at sight’ drawn on the plaintiff without recourse, accompanied by duplicate signed invoices and complete sets of “clean” bills of lading. One set of bills was presented for payment to the plaintiff on the 15th September, 1949 and the other set of bill was presented on the 16th September, 1949. The plaintiff refused payment thereof n those date, on the ground that the bills were not clean bills of lading. On the 17th September, 1949. India devalued its currency and the ratio of a hundred Pakistani Rupees became Rs. 143-8-0 of the Indian currency. The State Bank of Pakistan declared public holidays under the Negotiable Instrument Act, following this devaluation and the actual payment was made by plaintiff to the defendant-Bank on the 24th and the 27th of September, 1949, respectively.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The plaintiff did so under protest at the pre-devaluation rate i. e. at par. The suit was instituted on 18-9-55 by the plaintiff contending that the liability to pay in this case was not incurred till the State Bank of Pakistan gave permission to remit the foreign currency to India, as such, the liability must be assessed at the post-valuation rate.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Question arose as to the determination of the relevant date for converting the Indian currency mentionable in the two bills of exchange into Pakistan currency, for the purpose of meeting those bills.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held:</strong> The relevant date for conversion of the foreign currency into Pakistani currency in such case would be the date on which the bill of exchange matured for payment and the liability for payment incurred, that is, the date of conversion of the currency should be the date on which the payment fell due.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>SM Hanif (Dacca) Ltd. Vs. Central Bank of India (1962) 14 DLR (SC) 308.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Exclusive possession</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Exclusive possession may also be used with no higher meaning than ‘sole possession’. <em>54 CWN (2 DR) 191 (1931. col).</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The proposition that the test of exclusive possession is by no means decisive cannot be said to be of general application.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Dhamai Tea Co. Ltd. Vs. Arjoon Kumari. (1979) 31 DLR 433.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Exclusive possession may not be a decisive test in favor of a tenancy, but it still remains a consideration of the first importance. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Executing Court’s jurisdiction</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Decree—Execution of decree—Decree-holder not at a liberty at his own will to strike out execution proceedings.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Joynal Abedin Vs. Nagendra Chandra Majumdar (1971) 23 DLR 124.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>“Ex parte” and “legal proceedings”</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The expression “ex parte” in Article 3 of P0 12 of 1972 governs diverse proceeding—Civil, Criminal, revenue and others. Legal proceedings include suits, cases, prosecution, appeal, revision and review.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The word “ex parte” admits of no other interpretation than to mean an order passed in the absence of any of the contending parties.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Maksud Ahmed Vs. Sunil Kumar (1979) 31 DLR 275.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ex parte adverse finding—payment of compensatory cost.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The adverse findings against the appellant in the judgment cannot be sustained because those were made in the absence of the appellant. In the absence of those adverse findings there could not be any occasion, far less, raising the question of payment of compensatory costs to the respondent.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Habibullah Khan Vs.</em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> <em>Shah Azharuddin Ahmed (1983)35 DLR (AD)72.</em></span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ex pane decree—Requirements of law necessary to pass an ex parte decree—</strong> Court’s duty when called upon to pass a ex-parte decree.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The plaint is no evidence for the proof of the case of the plaintiff. The absence of the defendant who asked for adjournment but refused on reasons assigned therefore cannot give occasion for the plaintiff to obtain ex-parte decree without producing the relevant documents on the basis of which relief is sought for. The Court is bound to apply its mind with reference to the pleadings and satisfy itself as to what should be the proper proof for passing a decree on the basis of the averments made in the plaint.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Bangladesh Vs. Abdul Wadud (1973) 25 DLR (SC) 90.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Non-filing of written statement after several documents obtained for the purpose does not operate as a valid ground for an ex pane decree without complying with the necessary provision of law for such a decree.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It appears to us that Courts below considered that non-filing of written statement by the defendant after obtaining several adjournments absolved the Courts from the responsibility to examine the legality of the claim of the plaintiff. The claim of the plaintiff is based on works which requires measurement and such measurement-books and accounts were not filed; the bill on the basis of which the claim is based was not before the Court and on the top of it the schedule of work, as per tender, was not also before the Court for which the plaintiff was required to undertake the work and the rate of Taka 100.00 for the work of the thousand cft. was not stated in evidence. So we find it difficult to hold that the ex pane decree can be sustained in law.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Bangladesh Vs. Abdul Wadud (1973) 25 DLR (SC) 90.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—When a nullity—Decree fraudulently obtained is a nullity.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Decree-holder by suppressing summons obtained the ex pane decree fraudulently and this finding of fact has been arrived at both by the Appellate Court below and the High Court Division. Such a decree obtained fraudulently is a nullity in the eye of law. It is by practicing deceit and fraud that the decree was obtained and when such fraud and deceit is established, a decree has no existence in the eye of law and it must be set aside.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abul Khair Mia Vs. Abdul Latif (1980) 32 DLR (AD) 167.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ex-post facto</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Ex-post facto law—What is—There is no fundamental difference between retrospective and ex-post facto law. The former expression is used in respect of civil matters and the latter in respect of criminal matters which by their nature arc more serious.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Nabi Ahmed Vs. Home Secretary, Govt. of West Pakistan, (1970) 22 DLR (SC) 20.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Expungement of condemnatory remarks.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Condemnatory remarks about the role of an Advocate in the conduct of a case before a Court in the judgment appertaining to proceedings in relation to that case is permissible—Such condemnatory observation having a serious adverse effect (in the present case the appellant had to tender resignation of the office of Advocate-General) is to be avoided except when urgency of occasion imperatively demands it.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Khalid M. Ishaque Vs. Chief Justice and Judges of West Pakistan High Court (1966) 18 DLR (SC) 366.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Fair wages, living wages, and minimum wages.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A minimum wage is the irreducible amount considered necessary for the sustenance of worker and his family and for the preservation of his efficiency while the living wages is the ideal which enables the workman to provide for himself and his family a measure of comfort also. Fair wage. is between these limits and while for a minimum wages employers’ capacity to pay is not a relevant consideration, it is so in the case of the fair wage.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Dalmia Cement Co. Vs. Dalmia Cement Factory Workers (1958) 10 DLR (SC) 157.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><u>Family</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>“Family”, what the word means.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The explanation of family as given under explanation (b) of section 20 the Act cannot be applied, in the case of the family of waked, for disposal of the portions of the property which devolve on all the legal heirs and representatives of the wakeef. The position of a mutwalli is as good as other legal heirs and representatives of the wakeef. In that view of the matter mutwalli alone cannot reap the benefit of the property set apart as secular property.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Shamsuzzoha Nurul Amin Chowdhury Vs. Province of East Pakistan (1970) 22 DLR 376.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Female witnesses—If their veracity can be questioned on the ground that they are females.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Only because of the fact that all the witnesses are females their statements should not be believed has got no substance. There are no reasons to disbelieve their evidence. If in a house where husband and wife reside and if the husband is killed in that case only witness would be the wife to see the occurrence of killing of her husband.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">There is no law in the country not to believe the evidence of female witnesses and convicting a person relying on their evidence. In this Connection we may refer to cases reported in AIR 1938 Mad. 740 and the case reported in AIR 1963 Supreme Court, page 364 wherein it was held that only because the witnesses are female, their evidence cannot be discarded.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Noor Islam &amp; ors. Vs. State (1984)36 DLR 123.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><u>Ferries and Sairat Mahals</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ferries and Sairat Mahals are vested in the Local Councils under BD Order</strong>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In the case of ferries and other sairat mahals wi. ch have been vested in the Local Councils any pcrin who feels himself aggrieved by anything done by a Local Council in managing any sairat mahal shall seek remedy before the Controlling Authority and not before a Revenue Officer. <em>A Local Council is not a Revenue Officer. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Bangshi Choudhury Vs. Reazuddin (1969) 21 DLR (BR) 31.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Final—’ Decision shall be final’—</strong>Doe s not affect High Court’s revisional power. <em>Anil Das Vs. Mostaque Ahmed (1966) 18 DLR 86.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Final Explained</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Kaikaus, J—It was contended that as the order dismissing the application for confirmation of sale for want of income-tax clearance certificate implied a refusal to confirm this refusal was final and a new application was incompetent.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held:</strong> The word “final” in section 43 of Pak (Administration of Evacuee Property) Act would only mean that a point which has been decided in a proceeding cannot be reagitated. If the application was dismissed on the merits, the merits could not be agitated again, but if the application was dismissed because of want of an income-tax clearance certificate the only point that was decided was that a valid clearance certificate did not exist. That point cannot be agitated again except by way of appeal, review or revision, but the filing of a fresh application which is supported by a clearance certificate is not incompetent.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Ata Ullah Malik Vs. Custodian of Evacuee Property (1964) 16 DLR (SC) 298.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The word ‘final’ (occurring in sec. 29 (6) of the EB Premises Rent Control Act) means that the order of the Rent Controller, subject to the result of an appeal to the District Judge, is Final. it does not, however, take away the jurisdiction of the High Court to interfere with the District Judge’s order under section 115 CP Code.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Azizul Haq Vs. Hanif (1955) 7 DLR 287.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><u>Fiscal Law, liability under</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Principle applicable to it—</strong>The principle of all fiscal legislation is that if a person sought to be taxed comes within the letter of the law, he must be taxed. On the other hand, if the Crown, seeking to recover the tax, cannot bring the subject within the letter of the law, the subject is free from liability, however apparently the spirit of the law might otherwise appear to be.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Ebrahim Paper Mart Vs Assistant Collector of Customs (1956) 8 DLR (WP) 71.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><u>“Fishery”</u></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Right of fishery,</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> what it is and how it accrues—Presumption as to the such right—Where a land is settled, then the presumption is that the land with fishery right belongs to the lessee—Government’s claim of the right of fishery in the water over the land of the lessee—invalid. </span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Province of East Pak. Vs. Tasiruddin Ahmed (1968) 2ODLR 435.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Fishery right may be separately owned from the ownership of subjacent land—When land settled with no reservation as to user of it, presumption is land with fishery right transferred<em>. </em><em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Cannot be acquired.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Rights of fishery in a navigable river are not a profit arising out of land and cannot be acquired under the East Bengal State Acquisition and Tenancy Act. Right of fishery in a navigable river—not an encumbrance. A several fishery is an incorporeal right and cannot be acquired under the EB Stale Acquisition and Tenancy Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Inland fishery falls within the definition of “estate” and “land” and, as such, can be acquired.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Tazammal Hossain Vs. Prov. of East Pak. (1959) 11 DLR 145.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Lease of the land under water.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If a landlord grants a lease of a land to somebody, he cannot claim the right of granting any fishery right in any portion of” the land, which may be under water, in the absence of an express reservation to the effect; and the landlord if he chooses to do so, may grant a lease of the fishery right in respect of land which may be under water to one person and may give a lease of the land itself to another<em>. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Nawab Ali Munshi Vs. Sadagar Bapari (1957) 9 DLR 540.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">“<strong>Fishing right</strong>”</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Fishing right, delivery of possession— delivery of possession in case of a fishery right, when it is no more than symbolic delivery, cannot Oust the person in possession of fishery even though a restraining order was passed upon the person in possession.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Ambar Ali Talukdar Vs. Ajman Ali (1967) 19 DLR 221.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>“Fixed rent”</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The term “fixed rent” does not always connote a permanently fixed rent for all time to come. Its proper construction depends upon the context of the document in which it occurs.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>KB Kishor Acharyya Chowdhury Vs. Prov. of East Bengal (1954) 6 DLR 1(21 rt. h. col.).</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>“FOB contracts</strong>—are contracts where the duty of the seller is to deliver the goods on board ship at his own expense, upon which prima fade the property and risk passes to the buyer, who is liable for subsequent charge, and payment for the goods become due”. (Legal &amp; Commercial Dictionary, by S. D. Mitra)</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">“FOB (free on board) contracts arc contracts where the duty of the seller is to deliver the goods on board ship at his own expense, upon which prima fade the property and risk passes to the buyer, who is liable for subsequent due”. (Haisbury’s Laws of England, 3rd Ed. Vol-34 p. 10).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">“FOB” or “free on board” means on board a ship to be named by the buyer, and the seller’s contractual duly is there and then to pass the property in the goods sold to the buyer. Whether or not the seller in fact passes the property to the buyer on shipment, the risk passes.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The presumption would, therefore, appear on principle to be that in the case of a f. o. b. contract, the seller intends to fulfill his contract and that the property is intended to pass, and does pass, on shipment’ Carger’s Carriage of Goods by Sea, 10th Ed p. 728 (Also see British Shipping Laws, Vol-5, para 395).</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">“It is impossible to assume that commercial practice would condone the right of a seller f. o. b. to betray the original buyer by allowing him to withdraw the goods after delivery to the carrier. It is suggested, therefore, that whether the correct inference in f. o. b. sales is that property passes forthwith subject only to an unpaid seller’s lien, or conditionally upon payment, a retention of the bills of lading by the seller, even if they arc issued to his own order, should not be construed in a manner which is inconsistent with commercial practice. In other words, that any such retention should be regarded in conjunction with the object of securing the purchase price of the goods only.”</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Bismillah Oil Mills. Vs. Messrs Arag Lid. (1982)34 DLR 134.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—</p><p style="margin-top: 0in; margin-right: 0in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">(1)The normal incidence of a f. o. b. contract is that property in the goods passes to the buyer on shipment;</p><p style="margin-top: 0in; margin-right: 0in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">(2)The parties, however, may intend that property shall pass at a subsequent time, as for example, on payment of price and charges and on such event property shall pass at such subsequent time;</p><p style="margin-top: 0in; margin-right: 0in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">(3)Intention is a question of fact and has to be gathered from facts and circumstances of each case.</p><p style="margin-top: 0in; margin-right: 0in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">(4)The mere fact that a f. o. b. contract provides for handing over of bills of lading against payment does not justify a presumption that property is to pass on payment;</p><p style="margin-top: 0in; margin-right: 0in; text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">(5)A retention of the bills of lading by the seller should not be construed in a manner which is inconsistent with commercial practice. Any such retention should be regarded in conjunction with the object of securing the purchase price of the goods only, that is to say, property should be construed to pass shipment subject to unpaid seller’s lien.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Even if the seller has retained the shipping documents for securing the price of goods by providing that the documents shall be delivered on payment, there is a presumption in a f. o. b. contract that property passes on shipment unless a contrary intention has been expressed. <em>   Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Foreign Judgement</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Exception cannot be taken to foreign judgment arrived at on correct view of principles of international law.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Hasham Issaq Vs. Karachi Gas Company Ltd. (1969) 21 DLR (WP) 129.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Forfeiture</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Forfeiture, relief against—Compromise between parties embodied in a decree—Stipulation to discharge the mortgage or to obtain a deed of release by a certain date—Time, if essence of contract and whether relief can be granted against forfeiture. <em>35 CWN (DR-I) 103.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Forgery</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Forgery or fraud—</span></strong>Main ingredient is dishonest or fraudulent intention—Mere interpolation even unauthorized no proof of forgery or fraud— Without proof of bad intention there can be no fraud or forgery<em>. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mir Ghaus Baksh Bizanjo Vs. Chief Election Commission of Pakistan (1970) 22 DLR (WP) 178.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Fraud</strong>—A party to a fraud cannot take advantage of his own fraud.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The contention was that a particular part of a transaction was described as a loan to evade payment of income-lax but it was not actually a loan but an advance payment of rent.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Held: If the parties deliberately chose LO give the transaction a particular form they must take the consequence, a party to a fraud is not allowed to plead his own fraud.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdur Razzak IHowlader Vs. SK Muhammad Shafi(1962) 14 DLR (SC) 119.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—“Fraud”—</strong> when can be presumed in a sale set aside case.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The landlord obtained an <em>ex-parte</em> rent decree against the plaintiff of the present suit, whereupon the plaintiff brought the present suit for setting aside the said rent decree on the ground of fraud.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The following circumstances were found to exist in the present case, namely, that the service of summons was not effected at the address where the plaintiff had been residing, that the landlords were interested in getting and in fact got a decree in excess of the kabuliyat rate coupled with the fact the landlords had not taken the stand that there was a mistake as regards service of summons for which they could not be held responsible.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Santosh Kumar Mitra Vs. Hrishikesh Mondal (1961) 13 DLR 278.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Co-sharer causing the property to sold.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Proof of fraud, as against a co-sharer who has caused a property to be sold—circumstances indicating fraud enough.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Ratanlal Chakraburtty Vs. Shomnath Chakrabartty (1957) 9 DLR 112.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—An <em>ex-parte</em> decree can be set aside by a new action when the Court passing it had been misled by fraud. To sustain an action for setting aside ‘a decree the fraud alleged and proved must be actual positive fraud, a meditated and intentional contrivance to keep the parties and the Court in ignorance of the real facts of the case and obtaining that decree by that contrivance.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Azizur Rahman Vs. Sudhangshu Kumer Mitra (1952) 4 DLR 636.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Fraud on Court as well as on parties</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">As to cases where fraud is committed upon the Court as well as the parties, a Court has inherent jurisdiction to interfere in exercise of its power vested in s. 151 CP Code.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mofazzal Molla Vs. Parul Bala Debi (1972)24 DLR 116.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Matters of inference—Proof of fraud is matters of inference from the facts and circumstances of the case and the evidence as received before the Court. Each circumstance by itself may not mean much, but taking all of them together they may reveal a fraudulent or dishonest plan, on the question at what Lime the persons who have been guilty of that fraud commenced it, the Court is to draw a reasonable inference from their conduct.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Karnaphuli Paper Mills Ltd. Vs. Amanullah, Proprietor (1971) 23 DLR 150.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Fraud on the minority by the majority</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">When an act did amounts to a fraud on the minority in a company an individual member of the company may sue the majority.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Shamsul Huda Vs. Jalaluddin Ahmed (1979) 31 DLR 5.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Remedy.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In case of fraud on a party the only remedy is in a suit. <em>Mofazzal Molla Vs. Parul Bala (1972) 24 DLR 116.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Must specifically be alleged and proved—General averment of fraud will not do.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Ibrahirn Vs. Surendra Kumar Dhar (1957) 9 DLR 16.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—To substantiate fraud, mere allegation of non- vice not enough—Particulars as to person who admitted fraud with other materials must be given as also evidence in support thereof.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sajeda Khatoon Vs. Mostafa Khatoon (1976) 28 DLR</em> <em>222.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Fraud, undue influence—</strong>need not always be proved by oral evidence—Circumstances may be relied on for the purpose.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Although the onus is strictly on the defendants to prove fraud and undue influence and coercion in the face of the admitted signature of Asghar on the document, we cannot in the mere absence of oral evidence on the subject hold that the case of fraud, coercion and undue influence has not been made out in the circumstances as disclosed and particularly, when the executants is dead, who being man of failing health with financial worries reduced himself to a puppet.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>SM Lutfullah Vs. Bibi Badrunnessa, (1968) 20 DLR 1019.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—A fraud: When not a fraud—False representation made to a person who knows it to be false is not such a fraud as to take away the privilege of infancy.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Matira Bewa Vs. Sudhir Chandra Saha (1983) 35 DLR 56.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Vitiates all proceedings.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Fraud vitiates all proceedings—Contravention of the provision of law is no ground for allowing an order obtained by fraud to stand.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Idris Khan Vs. Haji Erfanuddin (1957) 9 DLR 601</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Fraudulent contrivance enough to make an auction-purchase invalid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If the auction sale is brought about by fraudulent contrivance on e part of the decree-holder, then it cannot be said that the auction-purchaser, even though he is not involved in the fraud itself, should be allowed to be protected.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Nijamul Huq Faraji Vs. Panchanan Podder (1969)21 DLR 78.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Fraudulent sales—nothing passes even to a bonafide purchaser for value without notice.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Mazaharul Huq Choudhury Vs. Nagendra L</em><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">al Dey. (1957) 9 DLR 456.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Judgment or order obtained by fraud—Duty of Court to re-call suo molts in appropriate cases— Single Judge may re-call order of Division Bench obtained by fraud. <em>(1955) PLR (Lah) 111.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Plea of—Parties pleading fraud must set forth full particulars of fraud and the case can only be decided on the particulars laid. General allegations are insufficient even to amount to an averment of fraud of which any Court ought to take notice, however strong the language in which they arc couched, may be. <em>Ananta Kumar Bepari Vs. Jamini Mohan Das. (1952) 4 DLR 487.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—D by a fraudulent misrepresentation induced P to execute some documents affecting P’s title to the suit property. P sued D for cancellation of those documents. Defense was that P came to know about the real nature of the transaction much earlier and the Suit was now barred by limitation.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Held: The burden to show that P had clear and definite knowledge of those facts which constituted fraud, at a time which is too remote to allow P to bring the suit, lies heavily on <em>D.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sm. Dhinamoni Bewa Vs. Sm. Saraswaii Namdasi</em> <em>(1953) 5 DLR 334.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Where default in payment of revenue in respect of an estate is made by both the plaintiff and the defendant, and the defendant (a co-sharer) purchased the property in a sale held for such arrears cannot be compelled to reconvey the plaintiff’s share of the property to the plaintiff even though the defendant may have been guilty of fraud. Section 90 of the Trusts Act, 1882 has no application to such a case. <em>53 CWN (DR 1) 3.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>‘From date’</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The Court directed the deposit of money within 15 days ‘from date’.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Held:</span></strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> In computing the period of 15 days, the day on which the order was passed should be excluded. </span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sri Sri Radha Madhav Bigraha Vs. Dhira Urao. (1953)5 DLR 20.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>‘Functus officio’</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;"> The general rule is that once an order is passed and entered or otherwise perfected in accordance with the practice of the Court, the Court which passed the order is functus officio and it cannot set aside or alter the order, however, wrong it may appear to be. The order can be set aside or altered only on appeal. </span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Pujaratana Unnause Vs. Waharekar Somittra Unnause (1952) 4 DLR (PC) 1.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Fundamental Rights.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Question whether the enactment is violative of Fundamental Rights remains suspended till the Emergency is lifted.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Hamidul Haq Chowdhury Vs. Bangladesh. (1981)33 DLR 381.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—With reference to a number of Fundamental Rights enumerated in Part II of the Constitution of 1956, they do not derive their entire validity from the fact of having been formulated in words, and enacted in the Constitution of 1956.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A number of these rights are essential human rights which inherently belong to every citizen of a country governed in a civilized mode.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The concluding words of sub-section (7) of section 2 of the Order of the 10th October, have not the effect of bringing to an abrupt end the proceedings in the petitions before the High Courts commenced by the convicted persons.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>State Vs. Dosso (1959) 11 DLR (SC)1 (43). </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Writ petition based on—Withdrawn and dismissed on abrogation of the Constitution of 1956.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sargodha Bhera Bus Service Vs. Prov. of West Pak. (1959) 11 DLR (SC) 285.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Fundamental Rules</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—Government has unfettered discretion to retire ministerial servants at 55 years of age. Rule 56(b)(i). </span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Pakistan Vs. Liaquat Ali Khan (1959) 11 DLR (SC) 73.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">“Next Below Rule”—</span></strong>An officer out of his regular line should not suffer by forfeiting acting promotion which he would otherwise have received had he remained in his regular line. <em>(1957) 9 PLR (Dac) 1147.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Officiating post</span></strong>—Pay—When an employee is promoted to officiate in a higher post involving the assumption of duties and responsibilities of greater importance he is entitled to the minimum pay of the grade to which he was promoted to officiate Rr. 30 and 35.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Post Master-General, Eastern Circle (EP) Vs. Muhammad Hashim (1971) 23 DLR (SC) 49.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">‘<strong>Garment’ and ‘hose’,</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The words ‘garment’ and ‘hose’ used in the notification [No. SRC 165 (R) 67] in their popular as well as their trade or business sense connote to be articles of dress or covering for human use.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Karnaphuli Rayon Vs. Bangladesh (1976) 28 DLR (SC) 116.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Garment and hoses herein mean wearing apparel for human use.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">‘Garment’ in its dictionary sense may mean an article of dress, a clothing of any object including an inanimate object like rayon yarn cake. But if the notification is read as a whole along with the Schedule it leaves no doubt that garment definitely refers to hosiery goods woven on the knitting machines in the form of some human wearing apparel. <em>  Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>General power of attorney</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A general agent may be one that has authority to act in all matters of a particular nature. The several acts which he may be expected to do for achieving the object may constitute one transaction, but the power that is conferred on him may be general in so far as that contemplated transaction is concerned. Such a power-of-attorney is special for the Stamp Act and general for making the contemplated transaction. <em>PLR (1960)1 WP 504.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>‘Generalia special non-derogant’</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In case of conflict of a general provision with that of a special provision in a constitution, the special provision should prevail. Reference by the President under Art. 162 of the Constitution (1957)9 DLR (SC) I 78;</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Jibendra Kr. Acharyya Chowdhury Vs. Prov. of East Pakistan. (1956) 8 DLR 457.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Government—</strong>What this means—It does not mean an abstract entity—but means a body of persons vested with executive authority of State.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Govt. of Bangladesh Vs. Md. Habibur Rahman (1979) 31 DLR (AD) 151</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Government not to avoid implementing decrees.</strong> Department’s practice of evading financial implications of decrees deprecated—Writ jurisdiction not to be made use of for enforcing declaratory decrees.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Govt. of West Pakistan Vs. Fazal-e-Huq Musarrat (1960) 12 DLR (SC) 88.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Government functionary.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Government functionary in cases where land held jointly by co-sharers cannot gel possession without partition suit—No authority can take possession of a property belonging to several co-sharers on the ground that the authority acquired complete right over the land belonging to some co-sharers; the course open to him is to file a suit for partition.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Anil Kumar Dutta Chowdhury Vs. Province of Pakistan, (1971) 23 DLR 108</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—‘Government Servant’—What the expression signifies.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Government Servant means and includes every person who for the time being is in the service of the Government of Bangladesh or any corporation constituted under any law for the time being in force and every person who on the basis of having at any time been in the service of Pakistan purports to claim any right to employment in the service of the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Bangladesh represented by the Secretary, Ministry of Power &amp; Water Resources Vs. Md. Misfor Au (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 304.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—His status: Legal relationship between the Government and its servant is not an ordinary contract between master and servant—Government’s servant’s position is one of status regulated by law.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Dr. Nurul Islam Vs. Bangladesh represented by the <em>Secretary (1981) 33 DLR (AD) 201 (203).</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Temporary employee with a continuous service for several years stands on a different footing than other temporary employees.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Ismail Hossain Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh (1975) 27 DLR 353.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Punishment for misconduct— </strong>Authority awarding punishment not bound by what the enquiry officer says—where a favorable order has been passed in favor of a delinquent officer, reversal of such order must be based on reasons which should be recorded—An order awarding punishment is always a judicial order.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mir Alauddin Ahmed Vs. Prov. of E Pak. (1974)26 DLR 27.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Placement in certain category—No reduction in rank.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Since the petitioner by a placement (in certain category) have not suffered any reduction in pay or rank, it cannot be said that their reversion has in the present circumstances been done by way of punishment but it has been done to remove a glaring anomaly which escaped notice earlier.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>SM Masood Al-Mamun Vs. Bangladesh (1977) 29 DLR 393.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Employees of Corporations who are </strong><strong>not Government servants</strong>—Provisions of Article 135 of the Constitution of Bangladesh not applicable to them. They can invoke writ jurisdiction in case of violation of any statutory right—In case where the rule of master and servant prevails writ jurisdiction cannot be invoked. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Dismissal of, on ground of corrupt practice.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Sub-divisional Collector of Food after holding an enquiry gave the petitioner benefit of doubt on the charge of corrupt practice and recorded reasons in support of his conclusion. The District Controller without giving any reason as to why he did not accept the finding of Sub-divisional Controller dismissed the petitioner from service—</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Held: </span></strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">The order of dismissal is not legal. </span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mir Alauddin Ahmed Vs. Province of EP (1975) 27 DLR 393.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Promotion of—</strong>Promotion is not made on the basis of seniority only; for other factors, such as efficiency, suitability, honesty, etc. are also to be taken into consideration in the case of a promotion.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Ghazi Md. Ekhlas Mia Vs. Bangladesh (1976) 28 DLR 397</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Claim to arrears of salary—</strong>Not a contractual debt—Claim rests on bounty of State— Action at law for enforcement does not lie.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Govt of <em>West Pakistan Vs. Fazal-e-Huq Musarrat (1960) 12 DLR (SC) 88.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Expression “deemed to be a government servant” does not necessarily mean a government servant. The expression that he is deemed to be a “Government” servant in Annexure “B” has been used for a limited purpose, that is, for the purpose of prosecution in a Criminal Court. He will be treated as a public servant as defined in s. 21 of the Penal Code, and for the purpose of regulating his conduct and taking disciplinary measure, when necessary, he will be subject to the Government Servants (Efficiency and Discipline) Rules. These provisions do not necessarily make him a Government Servant.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Keramat Ali Talukder Vs. Election Tribunal (1979) 31 DLR 1.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Dismissal:</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">No Authority subordinate to one by whom a Government servant is appointed shall be competent to impose a penalty of dismissal against a Government servant.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Province of East</em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> <em>Pakistan Vs. Abdul Latif Talukder (1970) 22 DLR 589.</em></span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—<strong>Punishment awarded for corruption—</strong>Screening Board recommending light punishment— Government awarding higher punishment.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The Appointing Authority awarding a higher punishment (dismissal of the delinquent officer) than that recommended by the Screening Board (which held the enquiry against the delinquent officer) commits no illegality, since it is so authorized by P0 67 of 1972 and in giving higher punishment it is not necessary that the officer concerned should be given notice regarding proposed higher punishment.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdur Rahsid Vs. Bangladesh (1980) 32 DLR (AD) 201.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Government’s right to retire</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Central Government has all the right to retire an officer after 25 years of service without giving any reasons.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Government has unfettered discretion to retire ministerial servants at 55 years of age.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Pakistan Vs. Liaquat Ali Khan (1959) 11 DLR (SC) 73.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Service liable to be terminated by one month’s notice—No drastic action against him was taken after inquiry on charges of misconduct—but his service terminated by one month’s notice— Termination not necessarily mala fid.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdul Karim Vs. Prov. of West Pakistan (1960) 12 DLR (SC) 295.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—<strong>His retirement—</strong>The date was 30.1.73 and thereafter he was on leave for 6 months preparatory to his retirement. This 6 months’ leave is a retirement benefit. An order by the Government suspending him from service passed after 30-1-73 and during the period when he was enjoying 6 months preparatory leave can be held as an order passed when the servant was not in Government service—Therefore, such order passed treating him in service is ineffective and unlawful.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Syed Abdul Ali Vs. Secretary, Establishment Division (1979) 31 DLR (AD) 256.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Relation between a civil servant and the State.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The relationship between a civil servant and the State is essentially contractual though his services would be terminable at the pleasure of the State, but as long as that pleasure was not exercised, there was a binding contract which could be enforced, if necessary, by action against the State.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Pakistan through General Manager, NWR Vs. AV Issacs (1970) 22 DLR (SC) 371.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Government servants violate law.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Here is a case where litigation is being conducted on behalf of the Government by Government officers in utter disregard of public policy and public money<em>. </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>KM Morshed Vs. Executive Engineer (1976)28 DLR 449 </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Grievance.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The word ‘grievance’ defined—Grievance connotes infliction of wrong or hardship on a person, injury or oppression; a cause or source of injury, In modern use something (real or supposed) which is considered a legitimate ground of complaint.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Sh. Allah Diya Vs. Abdul Qadeer (1971) 23 DLR (Lahore) 15.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
2435	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Words and Phrases [H - K]</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'><br/></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Words and Phrases</span></b> </p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Habeas corpus.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Order of imprisonment passed by Military Court—Court’s jurisdiction ofinterference more restricted.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>When the challenge is from an order of a Court Martial set up under theArmy Act to enforce the Military law, the jurisdiction to interfere is more narrowthan in the case of other Court or Tribunal. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Jamil Huq Vs. Bangladesh (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 125.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Court to see the validity of the order</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Jurisdiction of the High Court Division in an application in the natureof habeas corpus, is to see, if a person in custody is there in pursuance ofany lawful authority, and when a person is serving out an order of sentencepassed by a Court or tribunal, the jurisdictional validity of that order couldbe looked at. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Jamil Huq Vs. Bangladesh (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 125.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Habit</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—”Habit”, explained—The word “habit” impliesa tendency or capacity resulting from the repetition of the same act. It meansa persistence in doing an act. a fact which is capable of proof by adducingevidence of the commission of a number of similar acts. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Siddiqullah Vs. The State (1970) 22 DLR 491.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>‘Hakam’</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The word hakam should be regarded in its ordinary sense of judge orarbiter. One who is only a conciliator is neither a judge nor an arbiter. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Mst. Bilquis Fatima Vs. Najim-ul-lkram Qureshi (1959)11 DLR (WP) 93.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>‘Haat’—immovable property.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Rents and profits out of a market arc benefits arising out of the landand, therefore, come within the definition of immovable property under sec. 2,cl. 5 of the General Clauses Act and can be treated separately from the landitself, and can be subject matter of separate lease and mortgage independentlyof the land on which it sits<i>. </i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Prafullah Kumar Sarkar Vs. Kshemada Kinkar Roy (1952) 4 DLR 215.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Haats which are held once a week fall within the definition of vacantnon-agricultural land under sub-clause (iii), clause (b) of section 20(2) EBSA&amp; T Act and, therefore, haats cannot be acquired by the Government undersection 3(2) of the Act. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Yusuf Ali Chowdhury Vs. Prov. of East Pakistan (1959) 11 DLR (SC) 316.</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—‘Haat and Bazar’.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The word ‘cultivable’ clearly shows that the legislature never intendedto include haat and bazar within clause (ii) of section 20 (2) (b). <i>   Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Market as an immovable property means the benefit arising Out of theland in the shape of rents and profits derived from the market itself thoughthe market sits of the land. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Prafulla Kumar Sarkar Vs. Kshemada Kinkar Roy. (1952) 4 DLR 215.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Where the plaintiffs are not interested in all the plots on which thehaat sits,—in some plots the plaintiffs having no interest, they cannotindependently of their title to the land claim a share in that portion of themarket which sits not on their land but on the land of somebody else. If theyor any of them have got no interest in that land they cannot claim it as abenefit arising out of their own land, the right to hold the market being anincident attached to the ownership of the land. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>They also cannot acquire any right by prescription on account of thefact that the haat sits in those plots for a number of years as no such rightby prescription can be acquired. <i>  Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Right of a party to hold a haat—Mere proximity not a valid ground forrestraining another haat to be held. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Mizanur Rahman Vs. Serajuddin Bepari (1981) 33 DLR 212.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Leases of small plots therein—Permission for construction of puccastructures on leased plots cancelled. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Abdul Gafur Vs. Government of East Pakistan (1969) 21 DLR (BR)2.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Hearsay evidence</span></b><span style='line-height:115%;Cambria","serif";'>—Hearsay evidence—Its admissibility orotherwise—Statement made quite apart from its truth is relevant for certainpurposes. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>SM Qamrurzaman Vs. State (1981) 33 DLR 156.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Though hearsay evidence is not evidence of the fact deposed to yet incertain circumstances it can be looked to for some collateral purposes andcannot just be shut out. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>SM Qamruzzaman Vs. State (1981) 33 DLR 156.</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>High Court—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>High Courts several jurisdictions: (1)Original civil jurisdiction, (2) extraordinary original civil jurisdiction and(3) special jurisdiction.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The original civil jurisdiction of the High Court was confined to thetrial of suits arising within the local limits of that jurisdiction. Theextraordinary original civil jurisdiction was given for the removal and trialof suits pending or falling within the jurisdiction of Courts subordinate tothe High Court. Every other jurisdiction of a civil nature conferred by theLetters Patent would be best described as special jurisdiction or as statutoryjurisdictions, since some of those jurisdictions were to be exercised underexisting statutes.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The jurisdiction invoked for affecting an increase of the court-fee mustobviously be described as a constitutional jurisdiction of an original kind. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='line-height:115%;Cambria","serif";'>Ahmad Khan Vs. Chief Justice (1968)20 DLR(SC) 235.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—High Court Division of the Supreme Court—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>High Court Division of the Supreme Court shall 1ave such jurisdiction asis or may be conferred on it by law. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Alhaj Md. Ruhul Amin Vs. Dhaka Municipal Corporation (1984) 36 DLR 1.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—High Court and Subordinate Court: </span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;Cambria","serif";'>SubordinateCourt when amenable to the High Court—explained.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>When one has to consider whether a court is subordinate to the HighCourt within the meaning of section 115 CP Code, it is not enough to show thatit is a subordinate court in the sense of being a court of an inferior grade orstatus, it must be shown that it is subject to some authority of the HighCourt. The word subordinate contemplated by section 115 CP Code is thesubordination, not arising out of the subjection to appellate or supervisoryjurisdiction but the subordination arising out of a statutory provision. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Fatima Khatun Vs. Manindra Madhab Chaki (1969) 21 DLR 856.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—One Division Bench as against another such Bench:</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>A Division Bench of the High Court cannot interpret the Judgement ofanother Division Bench of the same Court. A Court after delivering itsJudgement becomes funcrus officio with regard to that Judgement. The remedylies in moving the superior Court, i.e., SupremeCourt.<i> </i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Chairman, Chittagong Port Trust Vs. Port Trust Workers Union (1969) 21 DLR771.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—High Court’s power of superintendence:</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The power remained in fact except for a short period when First GreatWar was waged and Mahathma Gandhi started Civil Disobedience Movement forliberty—Pakistan’s belated Constitution conferred, though rather lately, thissuperintendence power— Ups and down of Pak. Constitutions—Arrival of 1971, withchaos and confusion—Dark as well as brightest periods of our nationallife—Emergence of Bangladesh as an Independent Sovereign State— BangladeshConstitution promulgated on 16.12.72. Survey shows that except under theMartial Law regimes during Pakistani rule High Court retained its supervisorypower over all subordinate Courts. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>AT Mridha Vs. The State (1973) 25 DLR 335.</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—High Court’s power of superintendence over all subordinate courts,including Courts vested with special jurisdiction necessary—Otherwiseindividual liberty would be at stake. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>After all, freedom, liberty, etc., are the cherished desire of theindividuals. If in the process of a given proceeding the liberty isstrangulated illegally the superior Courts must interfere for the protection ofthe individuals and that interference can be done by, amongst others, thesuperintending power of the High Court and this is more so since Courts arecreated with exclusive jurisdiction by special enactment containing an ousterclause of jurisdiction. If the Special Courts having exclusive jurisdictionwill function beyond the control and superintendence of the higher judiciary—aproposition which it is dangerous to conceive of in a society which is governedby rule of law. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>AT Mridha Vs.
