The State (1973) 25 DLR 335.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—High Court’s superintending power— Guaranteed by Art. 109.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Power of superintendence and control envisaged in Article 109 shall beexercised in the interest of justice who involves a duty on the part of theHigh Court Division to keep all Courts and Tribunals subordinate to it withinthe bounds of their authority. This means the High Court can interfere whennecessary in the interest of justice.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>AT Mridha Vs. The State (1973) 25 DLR 335.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Original Civil Jurisdiction of the High Court.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Ordinary Original Civil Jurisdiction of the High Court is not governedby the Code of Civil Procedure, and it is governed by the Original Side Rules,1914. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Saleh Steel Industries Ltd. Vs. TSS Pacific Abeto (1983)35 DLR (AD) 188</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—High Court Original Side Rules</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Under the Original Side Rules of the High Court the appearance of aSenior Counsel is permissible only if he is assisted by an Attorney who isinvariably an Advocate of this Bar.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Rules 18, 21, 22 and 24 of the High Court Original Sides Rules indicatethat whenever a bill of cost is presented to the Taxing Officer it can only beentertained when it is presented by an attorney.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Govt. of Bangladesh Vs. MR Khan (2976) 28 DLR 215.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—High Court Bar Association Rules. Rr. 29 and 31: Proviso—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Calling of Special General Meeting during summer vacations on shownotice does not contravene any of die rules—In view</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>of proviso to rule 31, it is not necessary to send special notice bypost to every member—Proceedings of the Special General Meeting so convened wasnot irregular and resolution passed thereat was valid. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>President, High Court Bar Association, Lahore Vs. Raja Maula Dad(1970)22 (WP) 201.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Hire-purchase agreement.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>There is a distinction between hiring and acquisition of goods uponpayment of installments and each has different legal consequence.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Where the transaction is a sale, a third party bonafide purchaseracquires a good title to the goods against the owner notwithstanding theprovision that the ownership in the goods would remain with the original owneruntil the entire purchase-price was paid; whereas in a hire-purchase agreementsuch third party cannot acquire a better title against the owner.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The main distinguishing feature of a hire- purchase agreement is that ahirer has a right to terminate the agreement for hire at his pleasure and isnot bound to pay the value of the goods. In a contract of sale for pricepayable by installments, the purchaser has no option of terminating thecontract and returning the goods. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Arabindra Poddar Vs. Shew Ram Das Agarwalla. (1960) 12 DLR 229.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Holding over.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Upon the death of an original tenant in respect of an immovableproperty, the tenancy being one from month to month, the tenancy does not ceaseto exist and the heirs and legal representatives of the original tenant do notbecome trespassers but having continued in possession they become tenants byholding over and have an accruing interest out of the original contract. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Gouri Bala Pal Vs. Kunja Lal Saha (1960) 12 DLR 37.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—The right of holding over, unless conferred by a statute, cannot beimplied or inferred by analogy. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Osman Ali Vs. Sukwnar Majumdar (1978) 30 DLR 250.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>‘<b>Hypothecation’ and ‘pledge’—What they mean.</b></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>A mortgage of moveable, if not accompanied with possession, is calledhypothecation. A pledge is chargeable under Article 6. So far as the questionof hypothecation is concerned the possession over the property is detained tothe owner and only certain right in the moveable property is transferred to thepersons in whose favor the property is hypothecated. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Chairman, National Board of Revenue Vs. M/s. GMG Corporation Ltd. (1983)35 DLR (AD) 262.</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>‘<b>Ignorance of law’—explained—</b> ignorance of law is no excuse’ is atime honored maxim of Roman Law and it means that the effect of a lawpurporting to create a right or impose an obligation cannot be frustrated, orevaded on the plea of its ignorance. It does not mean, that when a law ofprocedure itself provides that a breach of its provision is excusable, on proofof a sufficient cause of such a breach, ignorance of law cannot be consideredas a sufficient cause. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>M/s. Rahman Huq &amp; Co. Vs. Commr. of Income Tax (1975) 27 DLR 403.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Illegal dispossession.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Illegal dispossession by Government officers— An act of extremehigh-handedness.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The petitioner had acquired valid right, title and possession of theproperty in question. As a citizen of the country the petitioner was entitledto due protection of law. When he could legitimately expect due protection fromthe Government for maintaining his rightful possession, he was insteadillegally dispossessed by the Government officers themselves. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Rage Ali Vs. Bangladesh (1982) 34 DLR 185.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Illustration—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> Cannot modify the language of sectionwhich alone is the law. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Aryyasthan Insurance Co. Vs. Nurul Islam Chowdhury (1958)10 DLR 510.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Impleading of parties</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Impleading of parties—Impleading Custodian of Enemy Property in a suitwhen not necessary.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Plaintiff’s property vested in the Government as enemy property. Thiswas subsequently released in his favor on satisfactory proof of his titlethrough an exchange deed of sale. In a suit brought by the plaintiff forejectment of the tenant who was on the properly it was contended on behalf ofthe tenant in assertion of his (tenants) claim over the property that theproperty being an enemy property the suit was not maintainable as the Custodianof Enemy Property was not made a party to the suit.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Held: When the property was released in favor of the plaintiff, there isno difficulty to deal with the case in the absence of the Government or theDeputy Custodian of the Enemy Property as a party in this suit. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Gaustha Behari Banik Vs. Habibullah Majumdar (1970) 22 DLR 846.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>‘<b>Incorporate Company’</b></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>An incorporated company has got the fundamental attribute of a corporatepersonality which is entirely distinct from that of its members, and theproperty of the company is distinct from that of its members whose onlyproperties are their shareholdings. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>New Dacca Industries Ltd. Vs. Quamrul Huda (1979)31 DLR (AD) 235.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Individual</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>‘Individual’, what it means.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The words “individual’, as expressed in section 16(3)(a)(iv) ofIncome-Tax Act means an individual who Is capable of having a wife. It,therefore, means a male individual. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Mst. Akbari Begum Vs. Commr. of Income Tax (1970) 22 DLR 365.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>“Indoor management”—its meaning.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The doctrine of ‘indoor management” is to the effect that personscontracting with a company and dealing in good faith may assume that, actswithin its constitution and powers have been duly performed and arc not boundto enquire whether acts of internal management have been regularly done.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>In the present case the lessee entered into an agreement of lease on theterms settled by the Secretary of the Society. It was subsequently contended onbehalf of the Society that the Secretary was not authorized, by the ManagingCommittee to enter into any contract and as such, the lease was not a validlease.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Held:</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> As the Secretary was entitled under theby-laws of the Society to enter into contract on behalf of the Society thelessee was not required to enquire whether the Society actually authorized theSecretary to enter upon the contract. Such transaction with the Society issaved by the doctrine of “indoor management”. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Pakistan Employees Cooperative housing Society Ltd., Karachi Vs. AnwarSultana (1969) 21 DLR (WP) 345.</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Injunction.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Long possession, even against a rightful owner, injunction willlie—Rightful owner cannot evict him by force but will have to establish hisright by due process in court of law. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Md. Gafar Vs. Azimuddin (1984)36 DLR 242.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Permanent injunction—Plaintiff to prove his exclusive possession andprima facie title.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>In a suit for permanent injunction the plaintiff’s arc required to provetheir exclusive possession in the Suit land and a prima facie title. <i>Md.Gafar Vs. Azimuddin (1984) 36 DLR 242.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>‘Insolvency.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Person adjudged insolvent—Adjudication can be annulled by Court ifpetition was not bonafide or there has been “abuse of the process of Court”. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Abdul Shakoor Vs. Ali Muhammad (1969) 21 PLD (Karachi) 339.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Insubordination.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>When returning of transfer order does not amount to insubordination.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Worker protesting against his transfer order and returning it withendorsement on the margin that his transfer was against the collectiveagreement arrived at between employer and the employees.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Field:</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> Course adopted by the worker was properand he is not guilty of insubordination for returning the transfer order. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Workers of Bata Shoe Co. Vs. Bata Shoe Co. (1971) 23 DLR (SC) 60.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Insurance—Motor insurance policy—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> Conditions in suchpolicy should be construed against insurers and in case of ambiguousexpressions Court should lean in favor of insurance— Breach of condition—Burdenof proof lies upon insurers. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Abdul Majid Khan Vs. Eastern General insurance Co., (1969)21 PLD(Karachi) 363.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Insurance company’s liability</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Insurance company is liable for loss if goods arc proved to have leftwarehouse and put on board ship—Slight evidence is required to proveshipment—Further insurance company’s subsequent declaration that policy coveredalso risks incurred during transshipment is enough evidence of shipment. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Haji Moosa Haji Omar Vs. Ahmed Abdul Ghani, (1968) 20 DLR (WP) 158.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Interest—Payment of, in a suit.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The question whether interest is to be paid to a person or not is to bedecided on the basis of the surrounding circumstances in a case and a decisionin this regard is to be based on the equities of the case. <i>Sk. Shamsul HudaVs. EP WAPDA (1972) 24 DLR 123.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Interest on award money by—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>the arbitrator notcontemplated by E.B. Act XIII 1948. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Province of East Pakistan Vs. Malu Bepari (1973) 25 DLR 440.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>International law and Municipal law.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>It is well settled that where there is municipal law on an internationalsubject, the national Court’s function is to enforce the municipal law withinthe plain meaning of the statute. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Bangladesh Vs. Somboon Asha Vahaen (1980) 32 DLR (AD) 194.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>“International Law”—Succession of international person.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>A sovereign when granting independence has power to impose what termsand conditions he pleases to the taking over of his obligations by the newState. But if nothing is said about a particular obligation then it cannot bedeemed to have been taken over by the new state. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Federation of Pakistan Vs. M/s. Dalima Cement Co. Ltd. (1962) 14 DLR(Sc,) 197.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Interpretation of statutes</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Preamble—When language is not open to doubt, preamble can neitherrestrict nor extend enacting part.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Rights, whether public or private, cannot be taken away or evenhampered by mere implications from language in absence of express words. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Syed Abul Aata Maududi Vs. The State Bank of Pakistan (1970)22 (WP) 178.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Interpretation of penal statute—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> Elementary rule ininterpreting a statute is to give full and accurate effect to every word usedin the statute—To the exposition of penal statute courts arc not to narrow itsconstruction—Courts are not entitled to scan or widen the policy ofLegislature. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The State Vs. Ghulam Jafar (1970) 22 DLR (WP) 244.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>In valid law</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Action taken under an invalid law— Consequence that follows.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>If an action taken under the invalid law was incompetent because the lawitself was invalid, there may be cases where by validating the lawretrospectively the action itself becomes competent with it and no furthervalidation of action is needed. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Mofizur Rahman Khan Vs. Bangladesh (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 321.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Involuntary unemployment—meaning of—It means the inability of theworker to work due to lockout by the employer or as a result of the strikewhich is not an illegal strike or by intermittent period of involuntaryunemployment which means power or machine failure or civil commotion, overwhich neither the employer nor the employees has any control. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='line-height:115%;Cambria","serif";'>Adamjee Jute Mills Ltd. Vs. Chairman, IndustrialCourt, (1969)21 DLR 94.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='line-height:115%;Cambria","serif";'>“Issues”—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Decision on all issues should be given by the trial Court. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='line-height:115%;Cambria","serif";'>Abu Syed Rashid Bakhi Vs. Mukhtar BakhtMazumdar (1967) 19 DLR 65.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='line-height:115%;Cambria","serif";'>‘Jote’</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;Cambria","serif";'>—may meaninterest of a tenure-holder. <i>AjufannessaVs. Safar Miah (1978) 30 DLR (SC) 41.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Judgment must be read as applicable to the particular facts proved.That every judgment must be read as applicable to the particular facts provedor annexed to be proved since the generality of the expressions which may befound there arc not intended to be expositions of the whole law, but governedand qualified by the particular facts of the case in which such expressions areto be found. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='line-height:115%;Cambria","serif";'>Ful Chand Das Vs. Mohammad Hammad (1982)34 DLR (AD) 363.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Judgment-—Foreign Judgment—Foreign Judgment—Exception cannot be takento foreign judgment arrived at on correct view of principles of InternationalLaw. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='line-height:115%;Cambria","serif";'>Hasham Issaq Vs. Karachi Gas Company Ltd.(1969) 21 DLR (WP) 129.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Summary disposal—disapproved. Summarily dismissing a petitionerspetition under Article 98 defeats the ends of justice which is the primaryfunction for which the Courts of law exist—.-Courts of law under obligation tospare that conscientious efforts in reaching their conclusion in adjudicationof matters brought before them in course of judicial process which gives asuitor the impression that his cause has received a fair treatment—Disposal bysummary orders deprives the superior courts of the benefit of the lower courts’views.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Litigants who bring their disputes to the law courts with the incidentalhardships and expenses involved do expect a patient and a judicious treatmentof their cases and there determination by proper orders. A judicial order mustbe a speaking order manifesting by itself that the cowl has applied its mind tothe resolution of the issues involved for their proper adjudication. Theultimate result may be reached by a laborious effort, but if the final orderdoes not bear an imprint of that effort and on the contrary disclosesarbitrariness of thought and action, the feeling with its painful results thatjustice has neither been done nor seems to have been done is inescapable.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>When the order of a lower court contains no reasons, the appellate Courtis deprived of the benefit of the views of the lower court and is unable toappreciate the processes by which the decision has been reached. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='line-height:115%;Cambria","serif";'>Mollah Ejahar ali Vs. Government of EastPakistan (1968) 20 DLR (SC) 221.</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Judicial act—The term ‘judicial act’ is used in contrast with purelyministerial acts. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='line-height:115%;Cambria","serif";'>Diwan Ziaul Huq Vs. Govt. of West Pakistan(1956) 8 DLR (WP) 59.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Judicial, quasi-judicial or administrative tribunal—Whether particularact of a tribunal is judicial or quasi-judicial or administrative.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The question whether an act is judicial, quasi- judicial or administrativeis clouded by a confusion which it is extremely difficult to resolve.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The true question in which character a tribunal acts always is whetherthe act which is complained of is a judicial act and not whether the procedureadopted by the tribunal is judicial or quasi-judicial or whether the dominantor general aspect of the tribunal is that of a judicial, quasi-judicial oradministrative body. A tribunal is not always furnished with the trappings of aCourt, nor will such trappings make its action judicial. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='line-height:115%;Cambria","serif";'>Twig Transport Vs. Sargodha Bhera BusService (1959) 11 DLR (SC) 140.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Judicial power of the Superior Court As distinguished from jurisdictionof the Superior Courts.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Judicial power of the superior courts can never be taken away. Thispower exists as long as the court exists. This power is available even wherethe jurisdiction of the superior courts has been barred.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Judicial power of the High Court cannot be taken away by Martial LawRegulation No.1 which has been passed in pursuance of the Proclamation bysaying no judgment, decision or sentence of a Martial Law Court shall be calledin question in any manner whatsoever including the Supreme Court. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Haji Joynal Abedin Vs. State (1978) 30 DLR 571.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Judiciary—Its independence—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Its power cannot becurbed except by legislative authority.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>In a democratic country with an independent judiciary, the jurisdictionof the superior courts are not to be interpreted to have been taken away, andif it is so intended it may be done by the appropriate legislative orconstitutional authority by express words and not by implication. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Jamil Huq &amp; ors. Vs. Bangladesh &amp; ors. (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 126.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Courtesy that is due to the Superior Courts</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>While mentioning about the superior courts, the subordinate courtsshould not mention in such manner. This attitude of the learned AdditionalDistrict Court is highly deprecated and is noted with disapproval.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The High Court Division cannot in exercise of its jurisdiction undersection 115 CPC alter the finding of facts.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>M/s. Subarna Trading Co. Ltd. Vs. M/S. Overseas Traders (1982) 34 DLR142.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Jurisdiction.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Jurisdiction, ouster of—Specific provisions is always provided in lawwhen depriving a court of its jurisdiction.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Whenever the legislature intended to take away the jurisdiction of theCourt, it did so by express provision. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>AT Mridha Vs. The State, (1973) 25 DLR 335.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Court’s jurisdiction </span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>(in Pakistan) takenaway by contract entered in a bill of lading—Such Court has and locus standi toentertain the suit.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Held</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>: Maintainability of the suit against theagent of the shipper in Pakistan is a question of fact as to whether or not theagent has any liability, and it is to be found by the trial Court. If it isfound that he has no independent liability the trial Court will be competent tostrike off the agent as well. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Swedish East Asia Co. Ltd. Vs. Mohammad Masood Raza (1969) 21 DLR 343</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Discretion cannot be exercised arbitrarily— Court can interfere toexamine reasonableness in exercise of discretion and set aside discretion foundto have been exercised arbitrarily. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Makramullah Vs. Province of East Pakistan (1969) 21 DLR 455.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Ouster of superior court jurisdiction under the </span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Martial Law cases to be effective from 7th June, 1962. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Mehr. Din Vs. Border Area Committee (1970) 22 DLR (SC) 227.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Exclusive jurisdiction clause—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>In a bill of lading,whereby the jurisdiction of local courts in Pakistan is ousted in respect ofany dispute referred to in the bill of lading being opposed to public policyand derogatory to country’s sovereignty is void. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>MA Chowdhury Vs. Messrs; Mitsui OSK Lines Ltd.. (1970) 22 DLR (SC) 334.</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Jurisdiction of the Labor Court—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> Previousnotification superseded by subsequent notification—Previous notification inrespect of territorial jurisdiction of the Labor Court was superseded by asubsequent notification reconstituting the territorial jurisdiction of theLabor Court. It was contended that as the previous notification was supersededby the subsequent notification without any saving clause, all pendingproceedings on and from the date become or in other words cease to have anylegal effect.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Held: </span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>This contention does not in the presentcase hold good because the analogy of a repeal of an Act without providing fora saving clause cannot be applied in case of notification issued by ExecutiveGovernment exercising delegated function. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>M/s. Gammon (East Pakistan) Ltd. Vs. The Chairman, 2nd Labor Court(1971) 23 DLR 148.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—“Jurisdiction”, objection as to— </span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;Cambria","serif";'>When willbe disallowed by appellate Court.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>If objection to the territorial jurisdiction is taken in the OriginalCourt and it is wrongly disallowed the appellate or revisional Court will notentertain the objection unless there has been a consequent failure of justice. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Pakistan Vs. Muhammad Abdul Kuddus (1968) 20 DLR 332.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Jurisdiction of the Court:</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Question of jurisdiction of a court can be raised at any stage so longas that question is not dependant on determination of any issue of fact. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Manager Swiss Boring Over-Seas Corporation Ltd. Vs. Shamsul Huq (1969)21 DLR 435.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Jurisdiction of Industrial Court—</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;Cambria","serif";'>forensuring harmonious relationship.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>In order to bring harmonious relation between the employer and theemployee in the interest of industrial peace the dispute and any mattersrelating to the dispute can also be determined by the Industrial Court. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Nishat Jute Mills Ltd. Vs. Nishat Jute Mills Workers, (1969)21 DLR 27.</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Jurisdiction of the Court—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Ouster of suchjurisdiction can—only is claimed when an order or action is one not done inaccordance with law and bonafide.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Held:</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> It is well settled that the jurisdictionof the Civil Court cannot be completely ousted even in the face of expressouster of jurisdiction in given statute. It has been repeatedly laid down byseveral judicial pronouncements that any provision made in a particular statutebarring the jurisdiction of the Civil Court to call in question any orderpassed or action taken under the statute gives protection to orders which arcmade with jurisdiction, made within the framework of the statute and made bonafide.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Dy. <i>Secretary, Ministry of Commerce Vs. Nizamuddin Ifaider (1985)37DLR 102.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Exclusive jurisdiction conferred on a tribunal cannot be immune frombeing challenged if the tribunal acts illegally, or acts malafide. <i>  Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Ouster of Court’s jurisdiction—not to be readily inferred.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Ouster of Court’s jurisdiction is not to be readily inferred and evenwhere there is an express ouster of the court’s jurisdiction the court stillretains its jurisdiction to see if the order passed was with jurisdiction ormalafide or was in accordance with law. If the order is with jurisdiction andit is in accordance with law then it is not for the court to substitute its ownviews or opinion on the merits for the decision of the authorities concerned. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Board of Intermediate and Secondary Education Vs. Masudul Alam (1976) 28DLR 406</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—In legal parlance, by jurisdiction of a Court, it is generally meant tobe the authority or power which is conferred upon a Court by the Legislature tohear and determine a cause between the parties and to carry the judgment intoeffect. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Govt. of Bangladesh Vs. Sumir &amp; Co. (1976) 28 DLR (SC) 21.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Exclusion of the jurisdiction of the Courts must either be explicitlyexpressed or clearly implied and is not to be readily inferred. Even if thejurisdiction is so excluded the court still retains jurisdiction to examine ifthe provisions of the Act have been complied with or whether the statutorytribunal has acted in accordance with the fundamental principles of judicialprocedure. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Md. Abdul Jabbar Vs. Asia Khatun (1976) 28 DLR 333</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>“Kabala and ekrarnama</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>”—Kabala andagreement of repurchase (ekrarnama) executed in the same sitting—they formcontemporaneous agreements and enforceable in law. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Nurruddin Ahmed Chowdhury Vs. Gunnu Meah (</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>1967) 19 <i>DLR 404.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Kabuliat and Pattah</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Pattah and kabuliat do not create relationship of landlord and tenantunless they are delivered up. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Baburam <i>Mandal Vs. Renuka Bala Roy Chowdhury (1960)12 DLR 517.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>‘Kaimi’</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The term kauni does not import fixity of rent. The word kaimi accordingto Wilson’s glossary is: Relating to what is perpetual; the perpetualsettlement of the revenue, and so conveys the notion of the fixity of rent. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>KB Kishore Acharyya Vs. Province of East Bangal (1954) 6 DLR 1(19).</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—The word kaimi is of the same category as mukarruri but its import isnot exactly the same. The term kaimi imports permanence of occupation but notfixity of rent. The word is not at all appropriate to a tenancy at-will; nor isthe word usually used to create a life-interest. Unless there is anything tocompel the contrary view, it imports an intention to create an estate extendingbeyond the life of the grantee. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Kalipada Saha Vs. Nitya Nanda Saha (1953) 5 DLR 285.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Kaimi means permanence of occupation and not fixity of rein. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Mahbubul Huq Vs. Shaikh Ak- med (1958) 10 DLR 323.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>“Karta</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>”—The term “Karta” in the case of HinduJoint Family means manager. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Commissioner of Income-tax Vs. M/s. Kalimohan Shaha (1962) 14 DLR 258</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Khadem</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Khadem—attached to a mosque—status of, in relation to a property of themosque—possesses no power of transfer by lease, etc. being a mere servant. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Isab Shaikh Vs. Asaruddin Shaikh (1956) 8 DLR 422.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>‘Knowledge’</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>A clear and definite perception of necessity particulars of a fact maybe said to constitute ‘knowledge’ which is, in essence, a question of fact, tobe determined in the facts and circumstances of each case. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Md. Hossain Vs. Amir Hossain (1977) 29 DLR 225.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—What constitutes knowledge. </span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>A precise or exact perception of the necessary particulars of a fact isthe determinant of the ‘knowledge’ which is essentially a question of fact. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Habibur Rahman Vs. Satish Chandra (1977) 29 DLR 178.</span></i><span id="pastemarkerend"> <br/></span></p></div></div>
2436	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Words and Phrases [L, M, N]</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'><br/></span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Words and Phrases</span></b> </p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Labour Court</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Court granting more reliefs than asked for— principle to follow. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The Manager Spencer &amp; Co. (Pak.) Ltd. Vs. Spencer’s Employees Union,(1973) 25 DLR 102.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>‘<b>Labour dispute’</b></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>A registered Trade Union functioning and discharging function of arecognized Trade Union. Some clerks of a Company having been retrenched theircause was taken up by a Trade Union and conciliation proceeding was initiated.The question of retrenchment of these clerks then becomes a labor dispute. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Mohiuddin Vs. PRS Ltd. (1977) 29 DLR (SC) 117.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—A recognized Trade Union preferred over an unrecognized trade union. <i>  Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Land Acquisition Court</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—When making assessmentof compensation acts as an arbitrator— When such a court determines questionpertaining to title in a compensation proceeding, it functions as a court oflaw attracting provisions of CP Code. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Bangladesh Vs. Abdul Mannan (1977) 29 DLR (SC) 17.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Land development</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Development of land by leasing Out the same for construction ofbuildings on the side of a big road is connected with the development ofBangladesh and as such acquisition of such land cannot be objected to.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Development of the land on the side of a big road under a projectappears to be connected with the development of Bangladesh and it was a part ofthe scheme for which the lands were acquired. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Aftabuddin Mullah, Vs. Chairman, Khulna Development Authority (1982) 34DLR 261.</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—If land is acquired for one purpose and is directed to another publicpurpose for which the land is being used is a different one, being outside thepurpose of requisition and acquisition, the requiring body was competent to doit since the other purpose is also a public purpose. <i>      Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Land—dispossession from.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Person in possession of land can only be dispossessed by another havingbetter title.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>When a defendant is in possession he could be evicted only by personhaving a better title than he. In such suit, plaintiff can only succeed byproving his better title over suit land. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Lal Meah Vs. Md. Ibrahim (1976) 28 DLR (SC) 61.</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Landlord and tenant—denial of the landlord’s title—forfeiture.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>In a suit for ejectment by landlords the denial of the title of the plaintiffwould in law result in the forfeiture of the right of the lease-hold interestof the defendants. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Bayza Bibi Vs. Debendra Lal Roy (1950) 2 DLR 360.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>‘<b>Last installment’ and ‘last year’</b>—The expression ‘lastinstallment’ in the 2nd proviso to sub-section (2) of section 2 of the BengalLand. Revenue Sales Act means installment preceding the sale and ‘last year’ inthe same proviso means the year previous to the year preceding the sale and,therefore, when the sale took place on account of arrears of excess of Marchkist of 1950, on 26.6.50, then under the proviso to sub-section (2) of section2 there could not be any sale for arrears of cess due in March. 1950 and thesale held for such an arrear by the Collector was without jurisdiction and thesale is liable to be set aside and declared void. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Abdus Samad Chowdhury Vs. Shamsuddin Ahmed (1960) 12 DLR 385.</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Latches</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The doctrine of latches in Court of Equity is not an arbitrary ortechnical doctrine. Where it would be practically unjust to give a remedy eitherbecause the party has by his conduct done that which might fairly be regardedas equivalent to a waiver of it, or where, by his conduct and neglect, he has,though perhaps not waiving that remedy, yet put the other party in a situationin which it would not be reasonable to place him if the remedy were afterwardsto be asserted—in either of these cases lapse of time and delay are mostmaterial. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>John Ojobo Agbeygbe Vs. Festus Makene Ikomi (1953) 5 DLR 219 (PC).</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—But in every case if an argument against relief, which otherwise wouldbe just, is founded upon mere delay, that delay, of course not amounting to abar by any statute of limitation, the validity of that defense must be triedupon principles substantially equitable. <i>      Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Two circumstances always important in such cases are the length of thedelay and nature of the acts done during the interval which might affect eitherparty and cause a balance of justice or injustice in taking the one course orthe other so far as relates to the remedy. <i>     Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Where a suit struck out and was relisted after a lapse of nine yearsand having regard to the Length of the delay the inadequacy of the explanationof the delay and consequences of setting aside a sale of land as against a bonafide purchaser for value who had been i1i occupation of the land during thewhole period and had apparently altered the buildings thereon— such a suitought not to have been re-listed and having been relisted ought to have beendismissed.     <i>     Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Late delivery—Loss of market</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Damages on account of late delivery of goods carried by theship—Principle for calculating loss for late delivery as in the case of transitby land. Wherever the circumstances admit of calculations as to the time ofarrival and probable fluctuation of the market being made with the same degreeof reasonable certainty in the case of a sea, as of a land, transit there canbe and reason why damages for late delivery should not b calculated accordingto the same principles in both cases. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>In assessing damages only the circumstances resulting from the breach ofcontract are to be taken into consideration. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Al-Sayer Navigation Co. Vs. Delta International Traders Ltd. (1982) 34DLR (AD) 111.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Law</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Question of law, raised—Question of law if not pleaded in the writtenstatement will not debar the court to apply that law, if necessary. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Khan Azizul Hassan Khan Vs. Haji Mohammad Ismail, (1971) 23 DLR (Lahore)15.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Before striking down a law having far reaching consequences, Courtsshould be extremely cautious and act on the principle that the affair shouldprosper, rather than be brought to naught. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Province of East Pakistan Vs. Sirajul Huq Patwari (1967) 19 DLR (SC)281.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Altered during the pendency of the case—Law existing at thecommencement of the trial will govern the case, unless the new law is expresslyor impliedly given a retrospective effect. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Muhammad Alam Vs. State (1967) 19 DLR (SC) 242.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Law, change of :—</span></b><span style='line-height:115%;Cambria","serif";'>Change of law while</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>the case pending in the appellate Court—Appellate Court to give effectto the change. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Sayeedur Rahman Vs. Chief Election Commissioner (1965) 17 DLR (SC) 23.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Durability of, passed by a competent body is permanent. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Sargodha Bhera Bus Service Vs. Prov. of West Pakistan (1959) 11 DLR (SC)285</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—<b>Functions of law.</b></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Official acts affecting rights of the citizens must be based on someprovisions of law—Any such acts done not within the ambit of a lawunauthorized— Dispossessing a Khadim from the privately owned dargah by the SDOnot permissible. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Muniruddin Vs. SDO Chandpur (1975) 27 DLR 382.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Law in force and law in operation</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;Cambria","serif";'>.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Where a law having both force and operation is robbed of its operationby virtue of a judicial finding that its provisions are inconsistent with thosein a major law, such law is as much a law in force, as another law duly enactedwhich awaits a further act of a legislature or competent authority for bringingit into operation. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Prov. of East Pak. Vs. Md. Mehdi Ali (1959) 11 DLR (SC) 318.</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Invalid</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—does not become valid by the mere factthat it remained unchallenged for a long time. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Attorney-General of Australia Vs. The Queen (1958) 10 DLR 9 (PC).</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Legislature’s power—</span></b><span style='line-height:115%;Cambria","serif";'>to make law and also validate actionsretrospectively within certain limits. Shahabuddin Ahmed, J (concurred in by FMunim, J., R Islam, J. and B Haider Chowdhury, J).</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—There is no dispute that the legislature got power to make a lawretrospectively and also to validate actions retrospectively. Retrospectivevalidation may also be conferred upon an Act notwithstanding anything containedin any judicial decision. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Mofizur Rahman Khan Vs. Bangladesh (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 322.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Municipal law and international law—</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;Cambria","serif";'>Municipallaw prevails over international law and courts are bound to administer law asit stands. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Jagadish Chandra Mazumdar Vs. Commr. of Agriculture Income Tax (1956)8DLR 327.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Law of necessity</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>That which is not otherwise lawful, necessity makes it lawful. <i>Referenceby H.E. The Governor General (1955) 7 DLR (FC) 395 (424).</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Presumption as to its validity</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Fair and unobjectionable on its face, conferring absolute powers whichmay be used arbitrarily cannot be questioned because it is likely to bearbitrarily used—but can be questioned when in fact it is so used. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Jibendra Kishore Acharyya Vs. Prov. of East Pak (1957) 9 DLR (SC) 21.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>‘Law’ and statutory public authority’.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The expression “law” as has been defined in Article 152 of theConstitution of Bangladesh means any Act, Ordinance, Order, Rule, Regulation orBye- laws, Notification or other legal instrument or any custom or usage havingthe force of law in Bangladesh. “Statutory public authority” also as has beendefined in Article 152 of the Constitution means any Authority, Corporation orBody the activities or the principal activities of which are authorized by anyAct, Ordinance, Order or Instrument having the force of law in </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Bangladesh. A.Z. Rafique Ahmed Vs. Bangladesh (1980)32 DLR (AD) 84.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Valid law can not be repealed by unconstitutional law.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Valid law can not be substituted or repealed by an invalidunconstitutional law. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Ful Chand Vs. Md. Hammad (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 362.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Validation of invalid law</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Legislature’s power—Law passed for validating an invalid law—tests—inremoving the defect validation of Law does not contravene theConstitution—Conferment of retrospective effect must not encroach judicialpower of the court—Legislature can render Judgments, etc. ineffective byremoving their basis.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The tests of such validation, besides legislative competence, are thatthe defect in the previous invalid law has been removed and the validation oflaw does not contravene any provisions of the Constitution. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Mofizur Rahman Vs. Bangladesh (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 321.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Validity of law does not depend on the malafide or bonafide of a law—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> Circumstances attending changes in different M.L. Regulations mightindicate malafide yet in view of the fact that M.L.R. by which amendments havebeen made to implicate the President in an offence are immune from challenge inany court. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Mostaque Ahmed Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh (1981) 33 DLR 348.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The validity of a validating law—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>is to be judged bythree tests, the first is to see whether Parliament is clothed with thelegislative power on the subject. The second is whether by validationParliament has removed the defect which the Court had found in the earlier law,and thirdly, whether the validating law is consistent with the provision of theConstitution. When all the three tests have been fulfilled, the validation lawmay operate retrospectively, if Parliament so expresses in the validatingdocument. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Mofizur Rahman Vs. Bangladesh (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 321.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—With validating an invalid law legislature can also validate executiveaction—Legislature not empowered to reverse court’s decision as it does notpossess judicial power-Court’s decision binding.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>It is a settled principle of interpretation that the power oflegislature to validate an invalid legislation carries with it the ancillarypower of validation of executive orders or actions but like the validation oflaw, the latter ancillary power is subject to the Constitution.    <i>     Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Law Officer and Govt. Servant.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Both a Law Officer and a Government Servant shall hold office during thepleasure of the President, but in the case of a Govt. servant the President’spleasure is subject to other provisions of the condition as expressed in thewords “except as otherwise provided by this Constitution.”</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>A Law Officer shall hold office only during the President’s pleasure andhe may be removed from office at any time by the President without any reasonsbeing assigned for his removal as has been expressed provided in thePresident’s Order No.6 of 1977. The clear distinction between serviceconditions of a law officer and that of a Government Servant excludes a LawOfficer from falling into the definition of a person in the service of the Republic.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Kazi Abdul Wahab Vs. Bangladesh (1979) 31 DLR 332.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Lawyer</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Gross professional misconduct—Inhuman act— Expulsion.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Interpolations in the figure of 200 raising it to 1200 and in the figure50 raising it to 250, etc. in the letter of appointment whereby the appellantinflated his remuneration established—Though the appellant was enrolled as anAdvocate of the District Court on 3.1.66 he represented himself as a lawyersince middle of 1965.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Appellant is guilty of gross professional misconduct and his dealingswith the respondent inhuman. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Kazi Abdul Khaleque Vs. Kazi Faziur Rahman (1982) 34 DLR 279.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Lease.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>A lease for 99 years is not a lease in perpetuity. <i>MH Khandker,Advocate Vs. Bangladesh (1978) 30 DLR (SC) 1.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Grant of lease by SDO in his discretion in regard to the enemy propertyunder the Defense of Pakistan Rules—High Court when moved under Article 102 ofthe Constitution refuses to interfere with that. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Habibullah Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh (1978) 30 DLR 47.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Lease of premises for residential and nonresidential purposes fallwithin the ambit of Premises Rent Control Ordinance of 1963. Lease ofnonagricultural lands is a subject-matter which has been dealt with in the EBNon-Agricultural Tenancy Act. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>MH Khandker, Advocate Vs. Bangladesh 30 DLR (SC) 1.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—No written document necessary for lease.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Under the Bengal Tenancy Act, no written document is necessary for thecreation of a lease in respect of agricultural lands and, therefore, a tenantcan prove his tenancy independently of a written lease, if any. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Khan Mohd. Biswas Vs.
