Chittaranjan Saha (1955) 7 DLR 60.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Agreement—Lease</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Agreement executed by the defendant alone can not be treated as a formalagreement between the parties.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>A unilateral document unable to decide question of title. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Dhamai Tea Co. Ltd. Vs. Arjoon Kumari (1979) 31 DLR 432.</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Lease-deed—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>executed and registered not by the partycompetent to do it but by a 3rd party on the basis of a letter—No title passes.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Ayaz Bahadur Vs. Abdus Sobhan (1978) 30 DLR 15.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Exclusive possession (by the defendant) for 25 years suggests lease</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Uninterrupted possession of the suit land for 25 years suggests that thedefendant was given exclusive possession suggests a lease. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Dhamai Tea Co. Ltd. Vs. Arjoon Kumari (1979) 31 DLR 432.</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Renewal of lease</span></b><span style='line-height:115%;Cambria","serif";'>.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Original lease of a plot of land belonging to the Govt. Khas Mohalgranted for 29 years contains clause for renewal after expiry of thelease-period. Lessee fulfilled all conditions and duly applied for renewalafter expiry of the original period of lease— The authority is bound in termsto grant fresh lease. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Free School Street Property Vs. Bangladesh (1978) 30 DLR 1.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Determination of the purpose of lease—Law application.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The test to determine whether a lease comes under the Bengal Tenancy Actor under the Nonagricultural Tenancy Act is the purpose for which the tenancyis created. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='line-height:115%;Cambria","serif";'>Sarat Chandra Biswas Vs. Mozam Sardar,(2970)22 DLR 102.</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>“Lease and sub-lease”—difference between</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Under the general law relating to transfer of property a sub-leaseconnotes the transference of only a part of the original lessee’s interest,whereas the transference of the whole of the interest in the lease by thetransferor amounts to an assignment of the lease-hold interest.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The assignee of a lease stands in the place of the original lessee andbecomes a tenant of the original landlord.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>A sub-lessee, on the other hand, is liable only to the sub-lessor, hecannot sue or be sued by the original landlord. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Province of East Pakistan Vs.</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> <i>Muhd. Hossain(1964) 16 DLR (SC) 667.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Lease and license.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Where a person is held to be a licensee and not a tenant in spite of hisexclusive possession of the property.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>When a requisitioning authority allowed people into possession at aweekly rent, when a landlord told a tenant on his retirement that he could livein cottage rent free for the rest of his life, when a landlord, on the death ofthe widow of a statutory tenant, allowed her daughter to remain in possessionpaying rent for 6 months, when the owner of a shop allowed the manager to livein a flat above the shop. In each of those cases the occupier was held to be alicensee and not a tenant, notwithstanding exclusive possession. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Dhamai Tea Co. Ltd. Vs. Arjun Kumari (1979) 31 DLR 432.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Lease and Licence distinguished.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>If the document only permits another person to make use of the propertywhen the same remained under the legal possession of the owner, then theinterest created by the document is a license. If, on the other hand, theagreement grants exclusive possession even for a limited period and forspecified purposes then the transaction would prima facie amount to a lease.The entire set of circumstances relating to be taken into consideration beforeit can be decided whether transaction stipulated is a lease or a license. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Goalundo Fishing Industries Vs. Pakistan, (1970) 22 DLR 349.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Judicial views on lease and license.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>A lease as will appear from section 105 of the Transfer of Property Actis a transfer of an interest in immovable property. During the continuance ofthe lease the right of enjoyment of the property belongs to the tenant and notto the landlord. The right of ownership as well as the right of which it iscomposed is rights in rem transferred to the lessee. On the other hand, a“license” as will appear from its definition in section 52 of the Easements Actis merely a competence to do something which except for this permission wouldbe unlawful. It does not confer any rights in physical property. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Dhamai</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> <i>Tea Co. Ltd. Vs. Arjun Kumari (1979)31 DLR 432.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Line of demarcation between.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The line of demarcation between a lease and a license will sometime bevery thin. A lease is a transfer of an interest in immovable property.Ownership of physical property consists of a number of rights and the owner ofsuch property when he creates a lease, transfers to the lessee a part of therights of ownership i.e., the right of enjoyment of the property, for a period,for consideration. During the continuance of the lease the right of enjoymentof the property belongs to the tenant and not to the landlord.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The right of ownership as well as the rights of which it is composed arerights in rem and not in personam and by the lease a right in rem istransferred to the lessee. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Abdullah Bhai Vs. Ahmed Din (1964) 16 DLR (SC) 169.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—There is in the case the case of a license only a personal agreementbetween the licensor and the licensee whereby the licensor agrees not tointerfere with the doing of particular acts on property which is in hispossession. No right in rem passess to the licensee.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The criterion for distinguishing between a lease and a license issimple, i.e., whether any right in immovable property itself, a right in rem,has passed to the person concerned. But the determination of this question maybe difficult in the circumstances of a particular case. Where there is adocument the evidence will have to be considered with due regard to theprovisions of sections 91 and 92 of Evidence Act, 1872. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Abdullah Bhai Vs. Ahmed Din (1964) 16 DLR ‘SC) 169.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Difference between—Substances to be looked into, not the words used toascertain real intention. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Golam Mohammad Vs. Hajee Amir Ali (1962) 14 DLR 772.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—If an employee is allowed to stay on a piece of land he will (unlessothers along with him are also put on the same land), be in possession of such landto the exclusion of others.<i> </i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>New Dhamai Tea Estate Limited Vs. Arjun Kurmi (1983) 35 DLR (AD) 155</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—A Tea Company requires workers for the purpose of plantation. It isnatural that for ensuring the continuity of service by such workers they shouldbe provided with certain amenities in addition to their salary.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Amenities by way of providing housing accommodation not to be construedas creating a lease. <i>  Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Distinction between these two—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> Lease consists of atransfer in immovable property for consideration and during its subsistence thetenant (i.e. lessee) has exclusive right of possession of the propertyleased—Lessee’s right in relation to the property leased is a right inrem—License is merely a competence or permission to do something which exceptfor this permission will be unlawful—No right in rem passes to the licensee. <i>  Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Leave</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Leave of absence from office cannot be claimed as a matter of right. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S.M. Faruque Vs. Prov. of East Bengal (1958) 10 DLR 562.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Legal adviser</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Duty towards clients asking advice—Obligation to make full disclosure ofinformation in his possession relevant—Failure of obligation—Liability todamages. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='line-height:115%;Cambria","serif";'>Assena Marikar Muhammad Fuard Vs. Alfred Richard Werasuriya (1956)8 DLR 48(PC).</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—“Legal character”—Explained</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>In section 42 of the Specific Relief Act the expression “legalcharacter” or “status” denotes a character or status conferred by law on anindividual or a number of individuals, viewed as a unit of society and notshared by the generality of the community but only by individuals, placed inthe same category of character. The character itself must be conferred by lawon person viewed from the standpoint of membership of the community. It is a“status” or “character” conferred by law. It is not a creature of contract butof law. For example, a minor cannot contract into majority nor can one, who hasattained majority, under law, contract him into minority. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Burmah Eastern Ltd. Vs. B. Eastern Employees Union (1966) 18 DLR 709.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Legal necessity, proof of—in ease of alienation by widow—Lapse of timeis a factor for not insisting on strict proof of legal necessity—Recitals inthe deed afford good evidence. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Mahendra Kumar Vs. Akbar Molla (1977) 29 DLR 6.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Legal payment—payment under protest.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>A payment to be an effective payment must be an unconditional payment.Payment under protest is not a legal payment so as to relieve the person,making the payment, from the consequences of nonpayment. <i>55 CWN (DR 3)166.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Legal Practitioners</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Enrollment of—Dismissal from Government service does not operate as anabsolute bar to enrollment—Order of enrollment once made can be set aside onlyon a subsequent fault after fresh inquiry— Order by one judge cannot be revokedby another judge or other judges. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Din Mohd. Vs. High Court West Pakistan (1957) 9 DLR (SC) 115.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Duty towards Court in matter of adequate preparation ofcase—Professional misconduct. <i>1955 PLR (Lah) 215.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Legal Practitioner—right to appear.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Legal practitioner—Advocate not debarred from representing an oppositeparty, if no confidential information passed to him from the other party.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>If no retainer fee received by Advocate from 1st party and noconfidential information passed to him then the Advocate is not debarred toaccept the brief on behalf of the opposite party and appear in court on hisbehalf. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Syed Azizuddin Vs. Dy. Collector &amp; DSC (1969) 21 DLR (WP) 242.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>‘Leges posteriores priores contrarias abrogant’.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>When two provisions concerning the same subject-matter are inconsistentor contradictory with each other, then according to the maxim <i>leges po sicriorespriores contrariasabrogant</i> the latter will prevail and the doctrine of implied repeal shouldbe brought in and that only if that course is inevitable on the language of thestatute. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Jibendra Kishore Vs. Prov. of East Pakistan (1956)8 DLR 457(493).</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Legislature’s power</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Validity of legislation cannot be challenged upon general principles ofequity and justice unless it violates constitutional provisions. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Messrs. Haider Automobile Ltd. Vs. Pakistan, (1970) 22 DLR (SC) 65.</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Lessee and lessor</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Implies a relationship of tenant and landlord.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>A lessee is, in its ordinary acceptation, no other than a tenant and thelessor, the landlord, and when such terms have been given any statutorydefinitions in any enactment they have not departed from such meanings. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>M.H. Khandker, Advocate Vs. Bangladesh (1978) 30 DLR (SC) 1.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Lessor, lessee and sub-lessee.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Possession of the sub-lessee, not adverse to the lessor, the landlord.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Kader has entered into possession of the suit property through theinstrumentality of the bharatia Subul. Possession of bharatia was not adverseto the owner landlord Upendra. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Satyendra Chandra Banik Vs. Mawlada. Akhtar Bewa (1982) 34 DLR 300.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Letter of credit.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>A foreign exporter or supplier of goods normally requires to be assuredof receiving payment of the goods. He may or may not know the person seeking topurchase the goods. It is, therefore, the normal practice that in order tostrengthen the credit of the purchaser the banker usually intervenes and addsto that credit his own and, assured by the credit of the banker, the foreignexporter usually, in assurance of the credit, ships the goods and draws billsof exchange which are negotiated at that place through that banker and thuspayment is made to the foreign exporter.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Letters of credit are normally described as documentary letters ofcredit. In other words, it is a conditional letter of credit conditioned by theattachment of the documents mentioned therein. A letter of credit of this typeis such a document or order by one banker in one place, authorizing some otherbanker, acting as his agent or correspondent in another place, to honor thedrafts or cheques of a person named in the document, up to the amount stated inthe letter and charge the total amount of the drafts so honored or payments somade to the grantor of the letter of credit.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>For this facility provided for the advancement t. international tradeand commerce, bankers usually take certain precautions in order to securethemselves against the normal risks. The precaution usually is to lake, by wayof collateral security, the goods being imported and the documents relating tothe goods, so that, in the event of the purchaser failing to honor the bills,the banker can recover the amount by the sale of the goods. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>S.M. Hanif Vs. Central Bank of India (1960) 12 DLR 10.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>License</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>“To license”—meaning explained.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>In its specific sense “to license” means to confer on a person the rightto do something which otherwise he would not have legal power to do. A licenseis in the nature of a special privilege rather than a right common to all, andis often required as a condition precedent to the right to carry on business orto hold certain classes of property within the jurisdiction. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Small Town Committee Vs. Firm Md. Sadiq Barkat (1960) 12 DLR (SC) 296.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Licensee</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Although a person who is let into exclusive possession is, prima facie,to be considered to be a tenant nevertheless, he will not be held to be so ifthe circumstances negative any intention to create a tenancy. Words alone maynot suffice. Parties cannot turn a tenancy into license merely by calling itone. But if the circumstances and the conduct of the parties show that all thatwas intended was that the occupier should be granted a personal privilege withno interest in the land, he will be held only to be a licensee. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Dhamai Tea Co. Ltd. Vs. Arjun Kurmi (1979) 31 DLR 432.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Licensee’s claim to stay on another’s land. Occupation of another’sland without any legal basis and merely on the basis of preferring claim tostay on does not create a right to stay on the land as a licensee. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Karwan Bazar hawkers Vs. DIT (1975) 27 DLR 378.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—License and Tenancy</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>“The difference between a tenancy and a license is, that in a tenancy aninterest passes in the land, whereas in a license it does not. Indistinguishing between them, a crucial test has sometimes been supposed to bewhether the occupier has exclusive possession or not. If he was let intoexclusive possession, he was said to be a tenant albeit only a tenant-at-will.Whereas if he had not exclusive possession he was only a licensee this testhas, however, often given rise to misgivings because it may not correspond torealities The test of exclusive possession is by no means decisive”. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Dhamai Tea Co Ltd. Vs. Arjun Kurmi (1979) 31 DLR 432.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Licensor and licensee.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>“Whether an agreement creates between the parties the relationship oflandlord and tenant or merely that of licensor and licensee the divisiveconsideration is the intention of the parties.”<i>   Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Lien.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>A lien is a right which only arises by operation of law and is a rightmerely to retain possession of things already in possession. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Kazi Abdul Ali Vs. Nurul Amin (1955) 7 DLR 406.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Lien or charge—</span></b><span style='line-height:115%;Cambria","serif";'>not in favor of the purchaser but of thevendor—No deed of transfer is effectuated.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>In the case of a lien or charge not in favor of the purchaser but infavor of the vendor the document does not partake the character of a sale.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Where a document provides for a lien on the property for the unpaidconsideration money it is a provision in the agreement against any suchcontract to the contrary in the sale-deed to be executed hereafter and thepossession of the property was made subject to such lien. It does not andcannot make the document a coveryance. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>E.H. Chowdhury Vs. Member, Board of Revenue (1960) 12 DLR 466.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Limited interest</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Limited interest.—may be acquired by prescriptive right.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Hazari Sardar Vs. Mozam Molla (1956) 8 DLR 640.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Transferee (not recognized by the landlord) fl from the original tenantremaining in possession for over 12 years acquired a limited interest of atenant by adverse possession.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>On acquisition of a limited interest by a tenant, the landlord’s rightboth for re-entry as well to sue the original tenant for rent is barred. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Naba Chandra Bangshi Vs. Naba Kumar Bangshi (1960) 12 DLR 552.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>‘<b>Lis’</b></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>‘Lis’ implies conception of an issue joined between two parties. Thedecision of us in the ordinary use of the legal language is the decision ofthat issue. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Dhakeswari Cotton Mills Vs. Convnr. of Narayanganj Municipality (1955) 7DLR 618.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>‘Living’ wage’.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>A minimum wage is the irreducible amount considered necessary for thesustenance of a worker and his family and for the preservation of hisefficiency while the living wage is the ideal which enables the workman toprovide for himself and his family a measure of comfort also. Fair wage isbetween these limits and while for a minimum wage employer’s capacity to pay isnot a relevant consideration, it is so in the case of the fair wage. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Dalmia Cement Co. Vs. Dalmia Cement Factory Workers Union (1958) 10 DLR(SC) 157 (162 1-h.col)</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Local Authority</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Vested and Non-Resident Property Cell not a ‘local authority’--Oneappointed as a tahsilder in the Cell is not a public servant. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Keramat Ali Talukdar Vs. Election Tribunal. (1979) 31 DLR 1.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—The East Pakistan Industrial Development Corporation is a ‘localauthority’ as well as a ‘person’ within the meaning of these expressions inArticle 98(2), and as such amendable to the jurisdiction of the High Court. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Rostom Ali Vs. Chairman and Secretary (EPIDC) (1964) 16 DLR 651.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—What it means—National Bank of Pakistan does not fall within thedefinition of “local authority.”</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The expression “local authority” in Article 98 (2) of the Constitutionmeans an authority which is entrusted with the administration of a local fund.Local authorities are bodies exercising within limited territories included ina Province, power which belong to the Province but which by statute aredelegated to the local authority. A local authority is ordinarily charged withfunctions of self-government and has power of making bye-laws, of imposingtaxation, and of maintaining and administering a local fund.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The National Bank of Pakistan which was set up by a Central Ordinance,bears no resemblance to the recognized conception of a ‘local authority. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Deputy M. Director, N. Bank Vs. Ataul Haq (1965) 17 DLR (SC) 74.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Local investigation (inspection)</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The messengers, deputed to view the land in dispute and report, examinedalso witnesses. The parties were present during the investigation and theplaintiff not only co-operated with the messengers in their activities butrefrained from objection or complaint of any kind when their report wassubmitted to the court. The plaintiff contended that the messengers had gonebeyond their province by examining witnesses instead of confining themselves toa scrutiny of the locus and the results of their own observation and that thisvitiated the judgment founded upon their report:</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Held</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>: The judgment was not vitiated. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='line-height:115%;Cambria","serif";'>Nkwanatahane—Nana Vs. Bchemhene Nana (1950) 2 DLR 201 (PC).</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Loss of market</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Loss of market due to longer voyage through breach of contract—owner ofgoods entitled to damage for loss of market.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>In the case of marketable commodities being carried to market, if theship greatly exceeds the larger estimate of the voyage through breach ofcontract and the cargo owner thereby misses the market, he is entitled todamages for loss of market. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Al-Sayer Navigation Vs. Delta International Traders. (1982) 34 DLR (AD)111.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>“Lost grant</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—<b>Doctrine of</b>—The doctrine of lostgrant can have no application to the case of a right of way exercisable by theinhabitants of a village from time to Lime as such right is not attached to anyestate in land nor is it capable of being made subject of a grant as there areno known grantees. The legal basis of such right lies in custom. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Asia Khatun Vs. Sufia Banu (1955) 7 DLR 71.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Limitation</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Ignorance about the date of an orderaffecting a person, limitation runs from the date of knowledge.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Where a litigant is kept in the dark about the date of his case, it iswrong to say that for a remedial action against it as provided by law, timewould start to run against him from the date of the order and not from the datewhen he comes to know about it.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>If the order was not known to the party concerned then its date forpurpose of limitation should be taken to be the date on which the partyconcerned came to know of it, and the period of limitation should be computedfrom that date (Qaderuddin Ahmed, J.). </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Allahdino Vs. Fakir Mohammad, (1969) 21 DLR (SC) 382.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Maladministration and high handedness.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>It is also singularly unfortunate that a responsible officer like theSub-Divisional Officer should have passed the impugned order without applyinghis mind and without affording the petitioners an opportunity of being heard inthe matter.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>It is a glaring example of extreme high handedness on the part ofresponsible public officials who it appears acted in utter disregard of the lawthey were duty bound to obey.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Such high-handedness if overlooked and allowed to go unchecked mightundermine the confidence of the citizens in the administration and bring a sluron the fair name of the Government. It is a case where we feel the Governmentmay consider instituting a departmental enquiry and take exemplary actionagainst the delinquent officials in the interest of justice and fair play. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Bakul Rani Sen Gupta Vs. Bangladesh (1979) 31 DLR 343.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Malafide.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Malafide is to be alleged with particularity— Assertion of generalnotice not sufficient for providing malafide. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='line-height:115%;Cambria","serif";'>Lt. Col. Farzond Ali Vs. Province of West Pakistan. (1970) 22 DLR (SC) 203.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Malafide charge against Government not sustainable even though what itdoes is hard on a person and its order looks ugly. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Tofazzal Hossain Vs. Province of East Pak. (1967)19 DLR 529.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Malice</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Government order refusing permission to go abroad attacked as malaiseon grounds: (a) similar orders were also passed previously but some such orderswere later withdrawn; (b) petitioner was detained under preventive laws and hisorganization was banned; and (c) while he was under detention, his passport wasconfiscated.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Held:</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> Action of authorities does not indicatemalafides—Fact that previous orders were subsequently withdrawn merely provesthat authorities were all the time critical and watchful in his case. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Syed Abul A’ala Moududi Vs. The Stare Bank of Pakistan (1970) 22 DLR(WP) 59.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Malice in common acceptation means ill-wilt against a person</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>, but in its legal sense it means wrongful act, done intentionally,without just cause. The allegations made by the appellant clearly constitute“malice in law’. Malice in law means a doing of a wrongful act intentionallywithout just cause or excuse. If from any indirect notice the action was takenin total disregard of the judgment in Writ Petition No. 571 of 1979, therespondents must be deemed to have acted maliciously.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>“Between malice in fact and malice in law there is a broad distinction.A person who inflicts an injury upon another person in contravention of the lawis not allowed to say that he did so with an innocent mind. Malice in fact isquite a different thing; it means an actual malicious intention on the part ofthe person who has done the wrongful act”. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Dr. Nurul Islam Vs. Bangladesh. (1981) 33 DLR (AD) 201.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Malice in law—</span></b><span style='line-height:115%;Cambria","serif";'>Action on a legally extraneous orobviously misconceived ground of action is a case of “malice in law”. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Dr. Nurul Islam Vs. Bangladesh. (1981) 33 DLR (AD) 201.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>‘<b>Malikana’</b></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>‘Malikana’ is an allowance which is paid as compensation for giving upthe proprietary right in lieu of which the proprietor ceases to have connectionwith the land and, therefore, although income, is not derived from the land. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Mahendra Nath Bagchi Vs. Commr. Agricultural Income Tax. (1950) 2 DLR20.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Manufacture—What it means.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Manufacture means the change in the character of goods or materialsused, so that new goods or materials come into existence. Even where thedominant work is to repair and in the process some minor or inconsequentialmanufacture of a thing is done, the business does not become a manufacturingone. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Ramjan Ali Vs. Hedayetullah. (1979) 31 DLR(AD). 183.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>‘<b>Marfatdar’.</b></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Acceptance of rent through marfatdar,—no recognition of transfer of atenancy. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Naba Chandra Bangshi Vs. Nanda Kumar Bangshi (1960) 12 DLR 552.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Marginal note of a section</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Side note, although it forms no part of the section, is of someassistance in interpreting the section inasmuch as it shows the drift of thesection. The question whether a marginal note can be referred to for anexposition of the meaning of a section depends upon whether the note has beeninserted by or under the authority of the legislature. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Kalipada Saha Vs. State (1959) 11 DLR 231.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Maritime lien</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>No proof that the ship’s owner or master had committed any tort or theyare responsible for damage to the goods; hence there is no maritime lien.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>In the instant case there was no proof that the owner had committed anytort or the master of the vessel was responsible for damage to the property,namely, the loaded salt, nor has it been contended that our municipal law hasgranted a maritime lien for delay and deviation. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Al-Sayer Navigation Co. Vs. Delta International Traders Ltd. (1982) 34DLR (AD) 111.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>‘<b>Market’</b>—Rents and profits out of a market are benefits arisingout of the land and, therefore, come within the definition of immovableproperty under section 2, clause 5 of the General Clauses Act and can betreated separately from the land itself and can be a subject-matter of separatelease and mortgage independently of the land on which it sits. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Profulla Kumar Sarkar Vs. Kshemada Kinker Roy (1952) 4 DLR 215.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Market as an immovable property means the benefit that arises Out ofthe, land in the shape of rents and profits derived from the market itself thoughthe market sits on the land. <i>       Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Martial Law Courts</span></b><span style='line-height:115%;Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Martial Law Courts being creatures either of the Proclamation or MartialLaw Regulation, have the authority to try any offence made triable by suchCourts. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>State Vs. Haji Joynal Abedin (1980) 32 DLR (AD) 110</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Master and servant</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The general rule is that the master is answerable for the wrong of theservant or agent as is committed in the course of the service and for themaster’s benefit. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Sonali Bank Vs. MA Hakim (1987) 39 DLR 367.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Master entitled to terminate servant’s service</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>By the ordinary law of master and servant, when a servant is guilty ofmisconduct, the master is entitled as of right to terminate his service withoutnotice. Under the general power of master and servant the Secretary of the EastPakistan Industrial Development Corporation could dismiss those who had beentransferred to the East Pakistan Industrial Development Corporation from thePakistan Industrial Development Corporation. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='line-height:115%;Cambria","serif";'>Chairman, EPIDC Vs. Rustom Ali (1967) 19 DLR (SC) 106.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Master and Servant (Employer and Employee).</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Employer’s power to discharge his employee from service cannot bequestioned—Where authority passed the order of termination of employee’sservice without applying its mind—Such order calls for Court’s scrutiny.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>In the instant case the Corporation has found rightly or wrongly theallegations against the petitioner to be serious. The order of suspensionspells out the allegations, indicates the action that is proposed to be taken,namely dismissal from service by the Corporation and has also given anopportunity to the employee to explain his conduct. We do not think that thisorder suffers from any infirmity. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Nazir Ahmed Vs. Bangladesh Jute Industries Corporation (1979) 31 DLR196.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Employer’s power to discharge his employee from service cannot bequestioned—Where authority passed the order of termination of employee’sservice without applying its mind—Such order calls for Courts scrutiny. <i>        Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Master and servant—Relationship</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The three jute mills, namely United Jute Mills Ltd., Meghna Jute MillsLtd. and Chandpur Jute Mills Ltd. were placed under Bangladesh Jute MillsCorporation for administrative purpose—Each of three Jute Mills retained theirseparate entity—An employee working in United Jute Mills remained an employeeof that mill even after the said Jute Mill was placed under the Bangladesh JuteMills Corporation. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Md. Motahar Hossain Khan Vs. Bangladesh Jute Mills Corporation (1984) 36DLR (AD) 282.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—The employee in the United Jute Mills for gross financial irregularitywas dismissed after an Enquiry Committee formed at the instance of the MillAuthority found him guilty of the charge. The relationship between the millauthority and the employee is that of a master and servant—As such his dismissalcannot be held illegal by the High Court Division in exercise of its writjurisdiction. <i>      Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Whether relation which subsists between master and servant is or is notapplicable in case of Private Corporation. Mandamus is the proper remedy toprevent further illegal exclusion from office in a private corporation when theright thereto is clear (English and American Law). </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>B.S.I. Corpn. Vs. Mahbub Hossain (1977) 29 DLR (SC) 41-42</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Master and Servant—English Law</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>An order of mandamus will lie to compel the restoration of a person toan office or franchise, whether spiritual or temporal, of which he has beenwrongfully dismissed, provided the office or fran-. chise is of public nature,as, for example, to the office of mayor, etc. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>B.S.I. Corpn. Vs. Mahbub Hossain (1977) 29 DLR (SC) 41-42</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Master and Servant—</span></b><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>What it means.</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>In case of pure master and servant cases, which mean cases in whichthere is no element of public employment or service, no support by statute,nothing in the nature of an office or a status which is capable of protection?If any of these elements exist, then whatever the terminology used, even thoughin some aspects the relationship may be called that of master and servant,there may be essential procedural requirement to be observed, and failure toobserve them may result in a dismissal being declared to be void.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>B.S.I. Corpn. Vs. Mahbub Hossain (1977) 29 DLR (SC) 41-42</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Any law enacted by a delegated authority in regard to terms andconditions of service equally enforceable—Regulation relating to terms andconditions of service framed by a statutory body has statutory force. <i>    Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—A contract for exclusive personal service does not necessarilyestablish the relation of master and servant.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Relationship of master and servant is characterized by a contract ofservice express or implied, between the master and servant. A contract ofservice is one in which a person undertakes to serve another and to obey hisreasonable orders within the scope of the duty undertaken. Whether or not a particularcontract is a contract of service is a question of fact depending upon theterms of the engagement, the method of remuneration and the power ofcontrolling and dismissing the worker, although none of these factors is byitself conclusive. <i>   Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Right founded upon a contract of service between the two is incapableof enforcement by action in court. <i>     Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Where an office has got a public character, it is no longer one whichcomes within the category of master and servant relation. <i>     Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—In case of such public service when terms and conditions of service areregulated by statutory provisions, rule of master and servant does not prevail.<i>   Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Office is one of public character, but is governed by contract ofemployment—In case of breach of any terms of contract no action forreinstatement lies. <i>    Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Dismissal of an employee holding a statutory office by giving acharge—Where principle of natural justice involved. <i>    Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—But simple termination of service without giving a blame or stigma,even though illegal or irregular, will not attract the operation of theprinciple of natural justice in such a case. <i>   Ibid.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Dismissal of the servant by the former— Employees of a Corporation arcsubject to the rule governed by usual relationship between master and servant.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The Supreme Court of Pakistan held the ordinary law of master andservant is applicable to the servants of the Corporation who were not regulatedby any statutory rules. Since the plaintiff was not entitled to anyconstitutional protection, his dismissal order which was passed in compliancewith the principle of natural justice could not be challenged inasmuch as thelaw of master and servant was applicable to him. He was found guilty afterproper enquiry. His master did not want to keep him in service and he was notdismissed arbitrarily. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Small Industries Corpn. Vs. Abul Hossain (1975) 27 DLR 96.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Matrimonial disputes—Difficulties of courts while considering mattersarising out of—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> A court of law provides at the best animperfect</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>instrument for the determination of the rights and wrongs of the mostpersonal and intimate of all human relationships, that of husband and wife. Nooutsider, however, impartial, can enter fully into its subtle intricacies offeeling and conduct. But when a case involving such questions arises the Courtmust do its best to judge dispassionately between the parties though it maysometimes be left with a doubt whether with the imperfect means at its disposalit has achieved perfect justice. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>CeciI Weldron Andrew Vs. Helen Andrew (1957) 9 DLR 682 (PC).</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Maxim</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>: <i>audialteram partem</i>; no one shall be condemned unheard—Permission to go abroadrefused without affording applicant any hearing— Refusal, held, offends againstrule in maxim <i>audi alieram partem.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Abul Aala Moududi Vs. Stare Bank of Pakistan (1970) 22 DLR (WP) 59.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>‘<b>May’</b>—Usually used in permissive sense, but may also be used inimperative sense.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>It is true that ordinarily the word ‘may’ is used in a permissive or anenabling sense. But this is not universally true. There arc cases in which itis used in the imperative sense. In support of the proposition that whenstatutes authorise persons to do acts for the benefit of others or for publicgood or the advancement of justice, the use of the expression “may” has acompulsory force.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='line-height:115%;Cambria","serif";'>Commissioner of Income Tax Vs. Messrs.Surridge, (1968) 20 DLR (WP) 282.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>“May” and “shall</span></b><span style='line-height:115%;Cambria","serif";'>”—<b>connotationof.</b></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The word “may”, according to its natural meaning, is a permissive orenabling word and imports discretion. But it is not always so. Where a statutedirects the doing of a thing for the sake of justice or the public good, theword ‘may is the same as the word “shall”.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Again the word “shall’ does not necessarily imply a mandate and that itis the legislative intent that determines their real import. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Tofazzal</span></i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> <i>Hossain Vs. Province of E. Pakistan(1966) 18 DLR 736.</i></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Merger—Doctrine of</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The question whether there was a merger or not depends upon theintention of the parties.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>It is open to the person in whose hands the two interests unite to keepthem apart or to sink the subordinate into the superior interests. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Tajemali Vs. Saijuddi Khan (1954) 6 DLR 25.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—When the immediate landlord of an occupancy holding is a proprietor orpermanent tenure holder and the entire interest of the landlord and the rightsin the holding became united then only merger takes place. But where theoccupancy holding and the immediate Taluka right is held by the same personthere cannot be any merger. In the first case, the maintenance of the twoseparate rights in the same person would be redundant. But in the second casethe two separate rights can and must be deemed to co-exist. There could havebeen no merger of the raiyati interest of the defendants with the Talukainterest subsequently acquired by them. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Benoy Bhusan Saha Vs. Abdul Majid, (1968) 20 DLR 826.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Military law—a separate law.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Our military law is a system of law or jurisprudence which existsseparate and apart from the law which governs our judiciary in its ordinary andgeneral jurisdiction. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Jamil Huq Vs. Bangladesh (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 126.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>‘Minimum wage’</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>A minimum wage is the irreducible amount considered necessary for thesustenance of worker and his family and for the preservation of his efficiency.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Dalmia Cement Ltd Vs. Dalmia Cement Factory Workers Union (1958) 10 DLR(SC) 157.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Minor</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Minor’s right to action against hisadversary with regard to transfer of property during his minority—Minor actingas a plaintiff and as well as when acting as a defendant.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>No adverse interest can be claimed against a minor during his minorityand it can only be claimed against such minor when he attains majority. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Abbas Sheikh Vs. Abu Hossain Sarkar (1978) 30 DLR 407.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>‘Minor’s interest in a suit—</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Suit for damages byheirs of the deceased—If wife of the deceased is non-suited on technicalground, its consequence may prejudice the interest of the heirs who all areminors which a Court should not allow. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Amer Vs. Haji Ismail (1971) 23 DLR (Kar.) 1.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Minor and lease.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The creation of a lease necessarily involves a contract. Such a contractif made by a minor, is void. A void contract is an agreement not enforceable bylaw. But though the contract was void, if it was followed by delivery ofpossession, the grantee or his assignee can maintain his possession against allexcept the true owner. It is not the law that because the lease is void, thegrantee can be ousted by any aggressor without title. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Julfikar Joardar Vs. Abdul Kuddus Ban (1953)5 DLR 305.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>“<b>Misdescription” of the cause title.</b></span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Misdescription of the cause title, made upon amendment, should not standin the way of the success of the application. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Abdul Malek Vs. Abdur Rahman (1967) 19 DLR 318.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Misdescription of party’s name in a suit—where not fatal.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The general rule is that a company must sue or be sued not in the namesof its agents or servants but in its own corporate name; but where, however,relief really sought is by or against the company and the error is merely oneof the misdescription, the suit though nominally by or against the agent, maybe treated in substance to be one by or against the company. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Haji Shaikh Afzal Hossain Vs. Bhabani Prosad Shaha (1961)13 DLR 639.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Money sale and rent sale—difference between the two</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—There is a well-demarcated and well-defined distancing between moneysale and rent sale under the Bengal Tenancy Act or the Public Demands RecoveryAct. In case of former what passes under the auction sale is right, title andinterest of the judgment-debtor whereas under the latter the holding passessubject to certain protected interests and if there is encumbrances they couldbe avoided in terms of the Act. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Julfu Molla Vs. Noab Ali (1975) 27DLR 442.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Auction-sale not binding on a party not impleaded in the saleproceeding and auction sale altogether a nullity—The two are different—A salewill not be binding on a party if it was a money sale and if it had the effectof rent sale, it will be binding on the party. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Faziul Huq Mondal Vs. Hatem Gasu (1976) 28 DLR 361.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Mortgage</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Rule of Priority—Some of several mortgaged properties sold in auctionfor public dues— Mortgagee for his dues at the first step to proceed againstproperties not sold for public dues. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>M/s. Tnpura Modern Bank Ltd. Vs. Islam Khan, (1971) 23 DLR 22.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—Mortgage and charge—Distinction.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>A charge does not create any right in the property but only creates aright of payment out of the property specified. It is a <i>jus ad rem</i>, right to a right, as distinguished from a <i>jus in rem</i>, a right in respect of thething itself. Whereas a mortgage is a transfer of an interest in immovableproperty, as a security for the loan, a charge is not a transfer of anyinterest in the property, though it is nonetheless a security for payment ofthe amount. The right to recover the amount in question is not itself,immovable property. The right to have possession of the properly can arise onlyif a specified interest is actually transferred which can be done by way ofmortgage, whereas no such interest is transferred in favor of the charge-holder. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Muhammad Nawaz Khan Vs. Muhammad Amin, (1969) 21 PLD (Lahore) 622.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>—When the mortgagor loses his right over the property mortgaged.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Endorsements of the mortgage-deed showing payments of interests due onthe mortgage by the mortgagor do not save time if such endorsements by themortgagor arc made after he had lost his right and interest in the mortgagedproperty through execution of a rent-decree by the landlord. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Madan Chand Gouthy Vs. Mohd. Nurul Huda (1979) 31 DLR 372.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Mukarrari.</span></b></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>The word ‘kaimi’ is of the same category as ‘mukarrari’ but its importis not exactly the same. The term ‘kaimi’ imports permanence of occupation, butnot fixity of rent. This word is not at’ all appropriate to a tenancy-at-will,nor the word usually used to create a life-interest. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Kalipada Saha Vs. Nitya Nanda Saha (1953)5 DLR 285.</span></i></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'> </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><b><span style='Cambria","serif";'>“Mukti-Patra”</span></b><span style='Cambria","serif";'> (deed of release) confers no title.</span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Mukti-patra cannot confer title on any party in regard to any landunless it is supported by a registered deed of transfer. Therefore, purchasefrom a person who claims title to the land on the basis of a mukti-patra doesnot confer any title to such purchaser. </span></p><p style="text-align:justify;text-justify:inter-ideograph"><i><span style='Cambria","serif";'>Abdul Gafur Sardar Vs.
