Mofizuddin Shah (1981) 33 DLR 418.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Where an Act repealing, in whole or in part, a former Act is itself repealed, the last repeal dock not revive the Act or provisions before repealed, unless words be added reviving them. <em>   Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Reports of parliamentary commission</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Reports of Parliamentary Commission and other facts within the contemplation of the Legislature when passing the Act—Judicial notice to be taken.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Govindan Sillappah Vs. Punchi Banda Mudayaka (1953)5 DLR 521 (PC).</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>“Require”—Explained</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The word “require’ involves something more than a mere wish and involves an element of need to some extent at least.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>M/s. Bunman’s Builders Vs. Land Acquisition Deputy Collector, (1962) 14 DLR 671.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>‘Reserve’</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The word ‘reserve’ in Rule 2 Sch. II of the Business Profits Act has been used in its plain ordinary meaning. It has been used in a much wider sense than in the Companies Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">According to the plain and dictionary meaning of the word ‘reserve’ there must be some setting apart of the amount for some special or general purpose by a person or a body authorized under the Articles of Association of the Company to allocate the funds for particular purposes.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>R. Sim &amp; Co Vs. Commr. of Income Tax East Bengal (1956) 8 DLR 208.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em> </em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Retrospective effect</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Retrospective effect of the statute, applicability of statues is presumed to be applicable to cases and facts coming into existence after their enactment unless there is clear intention to give them retrospective effect.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Nabi Ahmed Vs. Home Secretary, Government of</em> <em>West Pakistan (1970) 22 DLR (SC) 20.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Retrospective effect to a statute may be given either by express words or the same may be inferred from the language employed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Income Tax Officer Vs. Sulaiman Bhai Jiwa, (1970) 22</em> <em>DLR (SC) 113.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—An act which is invalid when it is done cannot be legalized by legislature giving it retrospective effect.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>C.I.E. Vs. Adamjee Mill (1978) 30 DLR (SC) 284.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">‘<strong>Retrospective operation’—Construction of the term</strong>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The term ‘retrospective operation’ is ambiguous because it is applied both to the fact that a particular enactment operates from before its date or so as to affect pre-existing rights and to the problem of construction which may be presented by an enactment as to whether it extends backwards or not.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">When an enactment extends backwards, by its own clear language, it operates retrospectively. It is only when the intention of the Legislature does not lie on the surface that a question of interpretation arises and, in such a case, in deciding whether the enactment concerned is intended to operate retrospectively certain well-known principles are followed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Commr. of Income Tax East Pak Vs. Redhashyam</em> <em>Agarwalla (1960) 12 DLR I (PC).</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Legislature cannot validate an invalid law where it lacks power to pass that law.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Constitution not retrospective—Fundamental rights—Validity of pre-Constitution law, when in clash with the fundamental rights under the Constitution laws, must remain unaffected unto the date the Constitution came into force.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Jibendra Kishore Acharyya Vs. Prov. of East Pakistan (1956) 8 DLR 457.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Revenue Court—Order of.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Revenue courts order holding the plaintiff to be a tenant can be challenged in civil Court in a subsequent Suit.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Karam Ali Vs. Raja (1955) 7 DLR (FC) 90.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Not to go behind the decision of civil court.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It is not permissible for the revenue courts to go behind the decision of civil courts and re-open matter already decided by competent judicial authority. In a suit for rent whether the claim was based on a civil court decree, it was altogether wrong to enter on enquiries whether that decree had been rightly given or not.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Hayat Vs. Bati &amp; ors. (1953) 5 DLR (FC) 4.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Revenue record</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">With regard to the revenue records they are presumed to relate to the state of things prevailing at the date on which they are prepared. <em>(1956) PLR (Lah) 1909.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Review</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—Of a decision</span></strong>—any order passed on such review is without jurisdiction when an appeal or revision against the decision itself was pending before a superior authority and the law prohibits reviewing when an appeal or revision is pending. Question of knowledge or lack of knowledge about pendency of appeal or revision irrelevant, the bar to review being complete.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Ghulam Mohi-ud-Din Vs. C.S. Commissioner, Lahore (1964) 16 DLR (SC) 655.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—Of an order</span></strong>—passed in revision by an authority to which the power of revision was delegated—if permissible under law.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Majority view (per S.A. Rahman and Hamoodur Rahman, JJ.) was that such authority has no power to review its own order. The power of review in this context cannot be regarded as ancillary to the revisional power conferred on the delegatee. A power of review is a creature of the statute and it cannot be said that a delegatee exercising revisional powers under sub-section (2 of section 20 of the Displaced Persons (Compensation &amp; Rehabilitation) Act have inherent power to review orders passed in his capacity as a delegatee.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mst. Zainab Khatoon Vs. Mian Ghulam Shabbir (1964) 16 DLR (SC) 712</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Right of review can be exercised only in case of excusable failure on the part of a party to bring to the notice of court new and important matters of error.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abu Said Md. Idris Ali Sikdar Vs. Monoranjan Bagchi (1970) 22 DLR 214.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Review and appeal</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—Scope of—The appellate jurisdiction is wider than its jurisdiction of review and that an erroneous view of evidence or mw is ordinarily not a good ground for review.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Mailer not raised in the original court, should not ordinarily be allowed to be raised in appeal.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Allahdino Vs. Fakir Mohammad (1969) 21 DLR (SC) 382.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Review and revision</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—Joint Registrar has no independent power of review—Whenever he exercises the power of review he acts as a Registrar exercising power u/s 135(2). Once the Joint Registrar exercises the power of review which is one u/s 135 (2), Registrar cannot review once again u/s 135(2).</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Registrar of the Co-operative Societies took the view that application can be filed a second time under section 135(2) of the Bangladesh Co-operative Societies Act and that this section does not limit his power of review to only one occasion.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Section 135 was not amended to give this power to the Joint Registrar. This power of review and revision has been given to the Government and the Registrar. It is therefore clear that the Joint Registrar in disposing of the first application for review acted as the Registrar under section 135(2). Registrar’s power of review was exhausted thereafter and he became functions officio and was left with no power to review or revise his order already made in review or revision.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Progati Khudra Babashayee Samabaya Samity Ltd. Vs. Bangladesh (1979) 31 DLR 152.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Revision petition</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">—A revision petition may be treated as a memorandum of appeal and vice-versa.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If a petition for revision has been filed when an appeal should have been filed or vice-versa, that is not sufficient for depriving a party of a remedy which has been sought under a wrong nomenclature. The object of the petitioner was to have the impugned order examined by the High Court and the circumstance that the petition was described as a petition for revision and not as a memorandum of appeal cannot, on any reasonable ground, be considered fatal for the case of the petitioner. It is open to the High Court to treat a petition for revision as a memo of appeal and a memo of appeal as a petition for revision.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>LA Collector Rawalpindi Vs. Li. Gen. Wajid Ali Khan Baki (1960) 12 DLR (WP) 10</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Right—</strong>A right to transfer a property or any interest in a property is itself a right. It is a proprietary right.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Contract—proprietary right—Right arising out of a contract to reconvey on the happening of certain event is a proprietary right—A third party when entitled to a benefit arising out of a contract.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Aftabuddin Miah Vs. Kudrat Ali Miah (1982) 34 DLR 51</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Where there is a right though the right is short of legal title person holding such right entitled to remedy.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In a suit for specific performance of contract unless the decree is executed and the Kabala obtained no legal title vests in the decree holders. Apart, however, from legal title to-a property, there may be various species of possessory or other legal rights created on the property which can be enforced. Once there is a legal right, the remedy will be available according to the right. It could not be said that when a transferee is in possession of a property in part performance of a contract and that contract has been affirmed by a decree for specific performance, the transferee after the decree does not acquire an interest in the land. He can lawfully maintain and protect hi possession and interest in the property.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Dr. Mohd. Hossain Vs. Abdul Malek Khan (1980)32 DLR (AD) 24.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Right to sue “means a right of obtaining from Court on adjudication of the matter in dispute—When the right to file suit is unaffected and postponed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>The Trustees of the Port of Chittagong Vs. Sadharan Bima Corporation (1980) 32 DLR 99.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Right of an elected member cannot be abridged arbitrarily by the enactment—The member or the body must be heard before the right is taken away.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdur Rashid Vs. Government of Bangladesh (1980) 32 DLR 109</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Right of way—Customary—Presumption from long and continuous user is that enjoyment was as of right, unless shown otherwise.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Akshaya Ch. Majumdar Chowdhury Vs. Haranarayan Majumdar Chowdhury (1956) 8 DLR 90.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Where a customary right of way is set up and user for 30 years is proved; the presumption would be <em>prima facie</em> that it was as of right.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">This presumption may however be destroyed by proof either of the fact that the alleged rights were enjoyed under an express or implied permission from the owner of the lands over which the burden is sought to be imposed, or by showing that enjoyment was interrupted on account of adverse interference of such a duration as supports an inevitable inference that the enjoyer acquiesced in the interruption and abandoned his right.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In a case for establishment for customary right from a long and Continuous user the Court is competent to presume that the plaintiff enjoyed the pathway as of right.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Akshaya Ch. Majumdar Chowdhury Vs. Haranarayan Majumdar Chowdhury (1956) 8 DLR 90.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—It is a well settled principle of law that in a case for establishment of custom the plaintiff must prove the following items : (I) ancient (ii) continuous (iii) peaceable (iv) reasonable (v) certain and compulsory.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Akshaya Ch. Majumdar Chowdhury Vs. Haranarayan Majumdar Chowdhury (1956)8 DLR 90.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Right of fishery not a profit arising out of the soil—</strong>Right of fishery in a navigable river cannot be acquired under East Bengal State Acquisition and Tenancy Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Right of fishery in a navigable river is not an encumbrance within the meaning of section 2(10) of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Tazammal Hossain Vs. Prov. of East Pakistan (I95)j II DLR 145.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">‘<strong>Right of being heard’—</strong>Appeal---involves the right of being heard. Natural justice that no one should be condemned or deprived of the property without being heard.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Chief Commr. Karachi Vs. Mrs. Din Sohrab Kairaic (1959) 11 DIR (SC) 113.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The principle that no man shall be deprived of his property without an opportunity of being heard is not alone limited to a judicial proceeding, but extends to all proceedings which may affect the person or property of a person. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Rights and obligations of the parties in a suit—determination of—</strong>Rights and obligations of the parties in a suit as a rule are determined as they are on the date the suit is filed unless the Legislature provides otherwise.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Krishnaranjan Chowdhury Vs. Hem Chandra Das Chowdhury (1957) 9 DLR 159.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rules of Business of the Government (Central)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Non-observance of the procedure laid down by the Rules and Instructions, if not provided with penal consequence provided they are faithfully, honestly and substantially followed (even though not technically and strictly) will not annul the actions and proceedings of the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Messrs Nabi Baksk &amp; Sons Vs. Pakistan, (1970) 22 DLR (WP) 99.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rules—</strong>Rules can only be framed in accordance with the statutory authority. <em>Aminul Islam Vs. Bangladesh Biman Corporasion.(1982) 34 DLR 63.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Rules cannot be called in aid to defeat the clear intention of the Legislature <em>United Industrial Bank Vs. Mohonbashi Sahs. (1959) 11 DLR  (SC) 369.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Framed by a non-legislative body cannot affect the provisions of law enacted by a Legislatress.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Mansur Ali Vs. Member Board of Revenue E. Pak. (1959) 11 DIR 412.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Rules and forms—Rules and forms under the authority of an Act can be referred to for the purpose of interpretation of the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Aryyasihan Insurance Co. Vs. Nurul Islam Chowdhury. (1958) 10 DLR 510.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rules of Indian States—</strong>Not sovereign princes in true sense and privileges under the International Law not applicable to them.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Jagadish Ch. Mazumdar Vs. Commr. Agriculture Income Tax E. Bengal (1956)8 DIR 327.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Rules of Indian States enjoying sovereign status are not immune from the law enacted by Indian Legislature. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;"> </span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rule of law—</strong>Anything done, if done without any lawful authority, is wholly illegal.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A body formed by an executive fiat which adopted a resolution for uniting two independent colleges into one having no legal basis the resolution adopted is without any valid authority and illegal.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>MA Samad Vs. Sub-Divisional Officer (1977)29 DLR 198.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">‘<strong>Sajjadanashin’,</strong> the term explained— Succession to the office of Sajjadanashin is regulated by custom. One recognized mode is, murids appoint the successor to office after death of the former.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Matlabur Rahman Vs. Madan Meah Chowdhury (1981) 33 DLR (AD) 286.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>‘Salami’</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Where settlement of lands were not for any fixed terms, salamis paid to the assesses by the cultivating raiyats fall within the scope of income assessable to income-tax under the Bengal Agricultural Income Tax-Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mahendra Nath Bagchi Vs. Commr. Of Agricultural Income Tax, E. Bengal (1950)2 DLR 209.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Salami is directly derived from the land compensation for the use of it.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Salami is agricultural income in cases where leases are for relatively small areas of lands for purpose of cultivation for periods which are fixed. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>“Salary”</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The definition of the word “salary” will include a servant who is on leave without pay, for a period of time as also a servant who is under suspension for a contingent period, receiving lesser payment without doing any work. The aforesaid classes persons are both “in service” and in the habit of “salary” as an incident to their service.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A person, who is under suspension in respect a Government service, is not in a different position from a servant, who is on leave without pay.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The expression “salary” is co-related to term “service” or being in ‘service’ and postulates habit or a recurring procedure. The expression “in also connotes a continual or habitual process, notwithstanding casual interruptions.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">This definition will, however, exclude a person receiving a “pension” as he is no longer “in service”.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mukhlesur Rahman Vs. SDO, Narayanganj (1962) 14DLR 762.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Arrears pay—An-ears pay can be claimed from local bodies but from the date when administration of a particular institution (in the present case schools of Sylhet district) is taken over by Government, such claim is not sustainable.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Chairman, Local Board, Habiganj, Sylhet Vs. Md. Nurul Islam Tarapdar (1967)19 DLR 207.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sale</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">When transaction is made by more than one document, all such documents should be read together and the cumulative effect should be taken into consideration—If the intention is for 6ut and Out sale, the transaction should be so considered.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Habibur Rahman Vs. Md. Mansur (1970) 22 DLR 505.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sale certificate—</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">By sale a property is transmitted from one person to another, and the sale certificate is a certificate to show that such a trans mission has taken place. It may be merely an evidence of title or may be called a deed of title, in the sense that it shows that the holder of it is the owner of what previously belonged to another. It is not a deed of title in the sense that it shows the creation of a new right. </span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Kalipada Saha Vs. Nitya Nanda Saha (1953) 5 DLR 285 (287 1-h.col).</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The sale certificate may be a deed of title; but the kabuliyat which created the lease is the basic deed of tide and inspite of the sale, the terms as to rent, duration and other matters will be regulated by the kabuliyat by which it was created. The kabuliyat is not an antecedent document but constitutes the very essence of the title. <em>   Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Salus Populi Supreme Lex.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Governor-General’s right to take action on the plea of <em>salus populi supreme lex</em> or from the doctrine of necessity.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Reference by H.E. The Governor General (1955) 7 DLR (FC) 395(399).</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">‘<strong>Same Business’</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Question arose whether the freight earning business as well as the jute brokerage business constitutes the “same business’ within the meaning of section 24(2) of the Income-tax Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Held:</span></strong> As the vessel has, in fact, been used for carrying goods of others ii is clearly a separate business.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>M/s. Ludlow Pakistan Co. Ltd. Dacca Vs. The Commissioner of Income Tax (1970) 22 DLR 89.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>‘Sanction’,</strong> Purpose of sanction to prosecute an officer is to ensure that no unnecessary harassment is caused.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>A.K. Reazul Karim Vs. State (1984) 36 DLR (AD) 113.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Sarasori jote</strong>—Meaning a tenancy-at-will. <em>Kalipada Saha Vs. Nityananda Saha (1953) 5 DLR 285.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Seniority in service</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Service Rule in the present case provides for promotion as a result of examination aid further that in order to claim seniority amongst different groups of successful candidates he must be already in service of the department—Date of examination for promotion is not the real date but the date of selection for appointment.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Nazir Ahmad Vs. Pakistan, the Secretary, Ministry of Communications (1973) 25 DLR (SC) 28.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Servant’s suit against dismissal does not lie.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Except a suit for damages for money compensation, no other Suit would lie, nor the servant is entitled to any other relief such as his reinstatement to service or a mere declaration that the service was wrongly terminated by the master.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Hasan Ali Vs. Manager, Amin Match Works Ltd. (1967) 19 DLR 307.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Service</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">R was appointed by the Chief Accounted of K Industries which after emergence of Bangladesh was taken out as abandoned property and placed under the Management of BCI Corporation. The Corporation appointed R as the Administrator of Industries. Later Rs services were terminated by the Corporation.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held:</strong> Corporation could only terminate his service as the Administrator and not his substantive post as the Chief Accountant of K Industries.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>BCIC Vs. Sk. Abdur Rashid. (1980) 32 DLR (AD) 133.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—An undertaking taken from a person in the service of the Republic, when illegal..</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The Office Memorandum shows that the petitioner was appointed temporarily to be qualified for substantive appointment after passing qualifying examination.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">His service was liable to be terminated during the period of temporary appointment on the ground— of unsatisfactory performance or any act or omission prejudicial to good order and discipline in a person in the service of the Republic.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The Office Memo demanded an undertaking by the petitioner to the effect that the service may be terminated at any time without assigning any reason.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held:</strong> The petitioner being a person holding a civil post in the service of the Republic the demand for undertaking in the above terms is <em>ultra vires</em> of the Constitution and illegal and as such this undertaking has no legal basis and no legal force.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Jahurul Hoque Vs. Chairman, National Board of Revenue (1980) 32 DLR 13.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—2nd. show-cause notice as a constitutional protection in case of termination of service cannot be insisted on in case of any employee under a statutory authority.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Manager Personnel Division Vs. Md. Sazahan Miah (1983) 35 DLR 224.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Servant’s services liable to be terminated by one month’s notice. No action against him was talc- en after inquiry on charges of misconduct—Service terminated by one month’s notice—Termination not necessarily mala fide.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdul Karim Vs. Prov. of West Pak. (1960) 12</em> DLR <em>(SC) 295</em>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Service condition</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Appointment to officiate in a service is not the same thing as a temporary post—Distinction between the two explained.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Ismail Hossain Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh (1975) 21 DLR 353.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Appointment to a different cadre of higher rank not a promotion.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A person in a lower service if selected by the Public Service Commission for appointment to any established cadre of higher rank then this appointment is of course a promotion in general sense, but this is not a promotion according to service rules. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Condition of service-what this expression means.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The condition of service includes remuneration, leave, pension and rights relating to disciplinary matters.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Zainal Abedin Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh (1982) 34 DLR 77.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Seniority in service—Meaning of seniority in service means actual length of service which can not be determined by a legal fiction as a person’s length of age can not be determined by a legal fiction. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Service discipline—</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Attempt to get round the superior officer’ order even though indirectly amounts to misconduct. </span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Nehaluddin Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh (1977) 29 DLR 91.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Dismissed from service—</strong>When such a dismissal is held illegal.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">While taking disciplinary action against an employee the Instruction of the Bangladesh Bank is to be followed in conjunction with the Regulations of the Bank—Any deviation whether in following the Instructions or the Regulations will result in injustice and wrong to the employee of the Bank.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Bangladesh Bank Vs. Tarique Ahmed (1985) 37 DLR 143.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Dismissal from.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Two proceedings were drawn up against the appellant, one of which called for major punishment, such as dismissal from service and another which was drawn up on 4.5.77 called for minor punishment. The appellant was dismissed from service in relation to the proceedings drawn up on 4.5.77, which being illegal cannot be sustained in law.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>AZ Rafique Ahmed Vs. BCSIR (1980) 32 DLR (AD) 83.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Efficiency bar</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Crossing of efficiency bar and increment of salary cannot be withheld unless there is an unsatisfactory report.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>M.A. Rashid A.E. BWDB Vs. Ministry of Power, Water Resources and Flood Control. (1979) 31 DLR 339.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Government—Servant—</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Confirmation of probationers, in the discretion of the employer Probationers remain as such till appointed to a permanent post—Nor can he claim, when permanently appointed, to be confirmed from the date of the original appointment as probationer though, in usual course, confirmation takes place from the date of original appointment—confirmation is also dependent upon various circumstances<em>. </em></span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Muhd. Naseem Ahmad Vs. Miss Azra Feroz Bakht (1968) 20 DLR (SC) 79.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><em>Service-holder, temporary</em></strong>—Appointment was temporary and on an ad-hoc basis for 6 months till the time he was selected by the Public Service Commission for regular appointment—No approval from the Public Service Commission— Appointee’s service was however extended for another six months and thereafter his service was terminated as per appointment letter.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Held :</span></strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> Appointment validly terminated. <em>M.R. Chowdhury Vs. Bangladesh (1977) 29 DLR 325.</em></span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—On commencement of President’s Order 115/72, the employees of the Bangladesh Television Corporation have become employees of the Government no matter their service conditions have not yet been determined. Existing terms and conditions of service do not include the right to trade union activities which has been denied by the statute governing the employees in question.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>G.S. Television Vs. Chairman. 2nd L Court (1977) 29 DLR 329.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Service-holder—</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Dismissal from service— Employee of a statutory corporation.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Employee of statutory corporation cannot be placed in the category of relationship subsisting between master and servant and therefore before his dismissal from service of the corporation he is entitled to a show-cause notice—Such employee does not acquire the status of government or public servant.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Managing Director Vs. Hafizuddin Ahmed (1977) 29 DLR (SC) 39.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—M (Respondent herein) was an employee of the Bangladesh Small Industries Corporation, a statutory corporation—Relation between them whether is one of Master and Servant.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Bangladesh S.I. Corporation Vs. Mahbub Hossain Chowdhury (1977) 29 DLR (SC) 41.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Pay Commission—</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Pay Commission’s recommendations regarding the pay structures of different categories of employees—Acceptance and implantation of such recommendations by the Government—No Government’s commitment regarding acceptance of the recommendations. Government’s freedom of action regarding the Pay Commission’s recommendations. </span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>SM Masood Al-Mamun Vs. Bangladesh (1977) 29 DLR 393.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Service and Promotion.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Pay—Officiating post—When an employee is promoted to officiate in a higher post involving the assumption of duties and responsibilities of greater importance he is entitled to the minimum pay of the grade to which he was promoted to officiate.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Post Master General, Eastern Circle (EP) Vs. Muhammad Hashim (1971) 23 DLR (SC) 49.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Service on Probation—</strong>When the probationer continues in his service, even after the expiry of the probationary period and further receives increments of salary—discharging him from service after the expiry of probationary period is illegal.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Probation period subsisted to a maximum period of 3 years, after which the probationer is either to be confirmed or discharged—Here in the present case, after the lapse of 3 years no order either confirming or discharging was passed—No show cause notice served on him as is contemplated under Article 135 of the Constitution—Such order of discharge illegal.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mustafa Aziz Vs. Principal, Momenshahi Cadet College (1977) 29 DLR 104.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Punishment for neglect of duty—</strong> Offence which requires minor punishment.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">Bangladesh represented by the Secretary, Ministry of Public Works Vs. Md. Matiur Rahman (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 285.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Removal from—with retrospective effect</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">An order removing a person from service with retrospective effect from the date of his suspension is illegal but it may be deemed to be valid from the date of the impugned order.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Bangladesh Vs. A. Rahman Molla (1975) 27 DLR 429.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Service—Retirement under invalid</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">law—Law made valid later on—Person whose retirement declared invalid because of the defect of the law under which retirement order was made can be retired by a subsequent valid law with retrospective effect—Court is not powerless to see and be satisfied that subsequent order not passed malafide, in colourable exercise of the authority.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Even in a case where retirement is made under the amended law and the order expressly shows that it has been made in the public interest, yet the court shall have power to see whether the order is in colorable exercise of power or is malafide or whether it has been made by person by whom it was purportedly made or the person who made it had authority or jurisdiction to make the order.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mofizur Rahman Khan Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh (1982)34 DLR (AD) 323.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Security of</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Employees (of a local body) without statutory right—Employees under a Municipal Committee (in the present case Collecting Sarkers) whose posts do not carry any legal guarantee to the tenure of service hold the posts at the pleasure of the Committee and liable to be dismissed at any moment.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Munshi Abdul Jabbar Vs. Barisal Municipal Committee (1968) 20 DLR 1186.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Appointment on probation—confirmation delayed—remedy of the appointee.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held:</strong> The High Court was not correct in its interpretation of rule 5 of the University of Peshawar (Recruitment, Discipline, Punishment and Appeal) Service Rules, and its finding of automatic confirmation in favor of the respondent was erroneous.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Further held:</strong> Contract or no contact since the respondent was allowed to serve the university for 16 years his service should not be vanished in thin air and since his service has been brought on regular basis with effect from 5th September, 1961, he should be confirmed from that date.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>University of Peshawar Vs. Syed Bashir Ahmed (1971) 23 DLR (SC) 9.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Termination of: Employees affected by termination not persons in the “service” of Pakistan but were appointed by PIDC—Thcir services terminated on the ground that they were no longer required— Services in such cases are governed by the terms and conditions of employment—Ordinary law of master and servant to be followed.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held:</strong> The respondents were in the employment of the PID. Corporation and were not persons in the “service of Pakistan’. The terms and conditions of their service were not governed by any statutory rules.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">There was an allegation about the inefficiency of the respondents in the office note, but the orders by which their services were terminated were not founded on the said allegation and therefore it cannot be said that their services were terminated by way of penalty merely because an allegation about their inefficiency was made in the office note.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Secretary, EPIDC, Dacca Vs. Md. Serajul Hoque (1973)25 DLR (SC) 80.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Service matter—Cases of dismissed employees other than Govt. servants arc covered by the law of master and servant—Employer competent to terminate employees without serving notice or assigning reasons in exercise of rights reserved by employer under personnel regulations.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Cholera Research Laboratory, Dacca Vs. Md. Mozzammel Huq (1973) 25 DLR 260.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Tenure of the office of public servants</strong>—How long the public servants would be continuing in service is a matter to be determined by the State.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Any protection does not divest the Parliament or the supreme law-making body to regulate the conditions of service, as in the instant case, fixing age of retirement.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Abdur Rashid Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh (1978) 30 DLR 40.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Suspension from service—</strong>Before an order of suspension against a public servant is passed he should be given an opportunity as a matter of right to explain allegations against him.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Shaikh Abdul Quader Vs. Chairman, BADC (1978</em>) 30 <em>DLR (SC) 96.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Condition when conversion to Selection Grade was sanctioned.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The government structure that was existing in 1961 when the conversion of Selection Grade was sanctioned, was different from the governmental structure enticed in the Constitution of 1956.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Golam Mowla Vs. Bangladesh (1977) 29 DLR 422.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Selection Grade—</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Promotion in the Selection Grade does not include a contingent matter like the prospect of promotion—Further the appellant having retired from service he has no subsisting right envisaged u/s. 42 of the Specific Relief Act. </span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Golam Mowla Vs. Bangladesh (1977) 29 DLR 422.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Terms and conditions of—</strong>A regulation relating to the terms and conditions of service framed by a statutory body in exercise of the legislative powers conferred upon it, if made within the ambit of such power, has statutory force and the violation of such a regulation may, in an appropriate case, be nullity.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>B.S.I. Corpn. Vs. Mahbub Hossain (1977) 29 DLR (SC) 41.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Pakistan Supreme Court case on the question of relationship between employer and employee in statutory corporations.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Whenever a person or a body is invested with a legal authority to determine a question affecting the rights of another, his authority is coupled with a duty of acting judicially and of observing the principle of natural justice. <em>   Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Service terminated.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A’s service was terminated by the Management of the Company in which he was employed on the ground that his service was no longer required. On evidence it has been established that A’s service had been terminated because he took active part in union affairs.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held:</strong> His service has been improperly terminated.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Hyas Khan, Manager Vs. Third Labour Court, Khulna (1972) 24 DLR 250.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Termination of</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Dismissal of an employee of statutory corporation. Before an officer or employee of a statutory Corporation is dismissed or removed from service or his service is terminated, he should be given an opportunity to show cause against the proposed action and that he shall not be condemned unheard.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>MA Hai Vs. TCB (1979) 31 DLR 326.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Termination of; Authority can terminate service under service condition without resort to penal measures—Ordinary law of master and servant to apply.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It was open to the competent authority not to have recourse to disciplinary action but to terminate the services of the employee by notice in accordance with the conditions of his employment.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">As long as the action to dispense with the services of an employee is in accordance with the terms on which he was employed, it is wholly immaterial whether the reason for the termination was misbehavior or some other reason.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The terms and conditions of employment of the respondents were not regulated by any statutory rules but were governed by their contracts of employment. That being so, the ordinary law of master and servant was applicable and under that law the Corporation was entitled to terminate the services of the respondents without giving them any opportunity of showing cause against the proposed termination, particularly when the impugned orders themselves do not show that their services were terminated by way of penalty.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Secretary, <em>EPIDC. Dacca Vs. Md. Serajul Hoque (1973) 25 DLR(SC) 80.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Service of an employee—Witnesses examined should be in the presence of the employee with his right to cross-examine. Grounds should be given when higher punishment than recommended by the Enquiry Officer is inflicted.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>MA Hai Vs. TCB (1980) 32 DLR (AD) 48.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Termination of service (even of a temporary employee) on grounds which cast aspersion. etc. on his character—Opportunity to show-case against his dismissal should not be denied.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Abdur Rasheed Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh (1978) 30 DLR 231.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—Transfer of service-holder Contracts of personal service is not assignable</strong>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">It has been contended that power of transfer is implicit in the employer. As a general proposition this may be correct. But here the appointment letter stipulates “that the employee will be liable to be transferred in any gardens under the BTIMC.” But in the present case the respondent has not been transferred to any garden under the BTIMC. On the contrary, his service has been transferred to a new Company which happened to purchase the tea garden which once belonged to the BTIMC and which now is the new employer. The respondent was not party to the agreement of transfer and he could be an employee if he consents either expressly or impliedly. Hence the impugned order of transfer was without his consent.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em><span style="line-height: 115%;">General Manager, Bangladesh Tea Industry Management Committee vs. F Chowdhury (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 27.</span></em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Service-tenancy—Resumption of.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">There is a distinction between the grant  an estate burdened with a certain service and that of an office, the performance of whose duties is remunerated by the enjoyment of certain lands. In the former case the Zamindar is not ordinarily entitled to resume, while in the latter case, he may do so where the office is terminated. Thus, the position is that in the case of a grant of an office remunerated by land, the land is prima facie resumable, but in the case of a grant of a land being burdened with service, the land is <em>prima facie</em> not resumable, but the terms of the grant or the circumstances in which it was made may establish a condition of the grant that it was resumable and the onus of making out such a condition would always be upon the granter.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Panchanon Behara Vs. Fate Mahmud Fakir (1955) 7DLR 139.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>“Shall”</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—The word “shall” is not always obligatory; it may, in certain circumstances, be directory.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Muhammad Abdus Salam Vs. Chairman, E.P. Election Authority (1965) 17 DLR 191.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—‘Shall be final’</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Revision to the High Court under section 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure would lie only on those cases where no appeal lays, which, in other words, means where the decision of the lower Court is final. The mere fact that the statute has expressly stated that the decision of the District or Subordinate Judge shall be final does not oust the jurisdiction of the 1-ugh Court to interfere under section 115 of the Code.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Afsaruddin Bhuiya Vs. Wazid Ali Khan (1952) 4 DLR 442; Azizul Huq Vs. Hanif (1955) 7 DLR 287.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—‘Shall be indefeasible’</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The word ‘shall be indefeasible’ mean ‘liable lo be defeated’ and not ‘shall be void’.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Kesarmal Vs. N.K.V. Valiappa Chettiar. (1955) 7 DLR I (PC).</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Share and area</strong>.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Document describes both the share as well as the area to be transferred—Which one to prevail when there is a difference between the two.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">To go by the share mentioned in the document as the share sought to be transferred without taking the other parties of the document into account may result in forcing an intention upon the executants of the document which he did not possess. Taking the share alone as the guiding factor where there are in other places in the document a description of the extent of-that share sought to be transferred would be unreasonable, for, it may well be that the parties understood the share mentioned in the document to comprise only that particular quantity of land and not more.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Safiuddin Kazi Vs. Moslem Ali Howladar. (1960) 12 DLR 266.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—‘Small Industries Corporation’—</strong>Is a local authority and before it dismisses an employee the latter is entitled to a precedent hearing. <em>BSI Corpn. Vs. Mahbub Hossatn (1977) 29 DLR (SC) 41.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>“Sovereign act”—What the expression connotes.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The expression ‘sovereign act’ is applicable only to acts committed in relation to other states or aliens and is inapplicable to a case where the Government is acting in relation to its own citizens. In the latter case the Government has authority to act only in accordance with the Municipal law.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Pakistan Vs. Md. Yaqoob Butt (1963) 15 DLR (SC) 369.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>“Special Bench</strong>”—Special Bench (of a High Court) when takes a view on a question of law different from that of another Special Bench, procedure to follow.—Utmost care necessary to preserve the high authority of the High Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Being charged with the high I unction of interpreting and pronouncing upon the validity of laws and being thus itself a source of law, the High Court should avoid giving a decision directly inconsistent with that given by itself earlier, and thus speaking with two voices on a point of law, where no question arose of resolving inconsistency between two or more earlier decisions.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Province of East Pakistan Vs. Sirajul Huq Patwari (1967) 19 DLR (SC) 281.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Special statute</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In cases where the jurisdiction of the civil court is excluded by a special Statute the court has inherent jurisdiction only to see whether the Special Act under which the special tribunal acted applied to the case and not because contravention of the provisions of the Special Act is alleged.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Ataulla Sowdagar Vs. Daliluddin Ahmed. (1953) 5 DLR 503 (506 rt.h.col).</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Stamp reporter.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Stamp reporter has no power to correct irregularities in the original decrees.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Patak Chandra Halder Vs. Sadernan Hawladar (1957) 9 DLR 190.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Time-barred appeal—Stamp Reporter to return the memo of appeal—Party’s responsibility.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The duty of the Stamp Reporter is nothing more than to report the sufficiency of the stamp fixed on the memo of appeal and to report if it is in time but he has n power to retain a time-barred appeal in his hand. The moment the memo of appeal is returned it becomes incumbent on the party to explain as to why the said memo of appeal could not be filed in due time.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Province of East Pakistan Vs. Md. Habibur Rahman, (1973) 25 DLR 254.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>“Standing Orders”—Rule 21 and 23.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Workman removed from service under rule 21, though for misconduct might be dismissed under rule 23. Its effect.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Although rule 23 of the Standing Orders provide that an employee found guilty of misconduct may be dismissed without notice or without salary in lieu of notice, yet it is open to a Company not to enforce any such penal provision and under this rule the Company instead may proceed to terminate the service of the employee by a discharge notice tinder rule 21 of the Standing Orders and where therefore an employee even though guilty of misconduct has been discharged under rule 21, provisions of rule 23 will not be attracted to such a case.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Glaxo Laboratories (Pak) Ltd. Vs. Pakistan (1962) 14 DLR (SC) 17.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>‘Stare decisis’</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">— The fact that for a quarter of a century no one attacked the patent invalidity of an Act and that a series of decisions all proceeded on the assumption that it was a valid law is not a cogent reason to disregard the conclusion convincingly arrived at that consistently with the Constitution the validity of the impugned provisions could not be sustained. </span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Attorney General of Australia Vs. The Queen (1958) 10 DLR 9 (PC).</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—When it cannot successfully be invoked—The mere fact that some Courts of the country have for a few years adopted a particular interpretation of a legal provisions, is, by no means a sufficient reason for maintaining that interpretation, if it is clearly opposed to some general principles. The principle of ‘stare decisis is not applicable to a case where only some of the Courts in a country have taken a particular view and that too for a comparatively short period.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>MA Chowdhury Vs. Messrs. Mitsui OSK Lines Ltd. (1970) 22 DLR (SC) 334.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>State as a litigant—</strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Has no higher status than an ordinary citizen—Its obligation in implementing court’s decree.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Once a decision has been given by a court of law, the State, as a party to the proceedings, stands on the higher footing than an ordinary litigant and its duty to honor the court’s decree in the letter and the spirit would be too obvious to require any emphasis. Indeed the State might be thought to have higher and more direct responsibility in maintaining the authority of the courts and that responsibility is clearly inconsistent with a deliberate design to avoid implementing a solemn decree awarded by a court.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Govt. of West Pak. Vs. Fazl-e-Huq Musarrat (1960) 12 DLR (SC) 88.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>—State policy of education—</strong>Under the directive principles of State, these are not enforceable in court of law.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">As for the state policy of education the learned Judges have taken upon themselves an enquiry which is neither arrantcd by law in the Constitution nor by the arguments of the parties. It is for this reason that the constitutional mandate provides in the chapter on Directive Principles of State Policy that these are not enforceable in the Court of law.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Bangladesh Vs. Winifred Rubil (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 162.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>‘Status quo’ means the existing state of things at any given time.</strong> [<em>See Wastom’s Law Lexicon, 14th Ed.I (1969) PLD (Kar) 350.]</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Statute—</span></strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">Special statutes which makes provision for appeal against its decision—It is that procedure that must be resorted to in an appeal as provided in the statute itself and riot otherwise.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Where appellate authority is provided by the statute, any omission or irregularity committed in the course of the proceeding under the statute will be a matter for that authority and not for a court of law.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Md. Abdul Jabbar Vs. Asia Khatun (1976) 28 DLR 333.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Statutes are to be interpreted prospectively, unless the language of the statutes makes them retrospective, either expressly or by necessary intendment.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">“It is a fundamental rule of English Law that statute shall be construed so as to have a retrospective operation unless its language is such as plainly to require such a construction; and the same rule involves another and a subordinate rule to the effect that a statute is not to be construed so as to have created retrospective effect than its language renders necessary”.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A. <em>Mannan Vs. Kulada Ranjan (1979) 31 DLR (AD) 195.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Statutory Corporation—</strong>establishment of, when necessitated.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The most likely field for State enterprises in an expanding economy is where private enterprise in new industries is shy and where the risks arc great. This is one of the major motives for establishing a public corporation, and other forms of Government enterprise. <em>Mahbub Hossain (1977) 29 DLR (SC) 41.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Stay order</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Order passed during the subsistence of stay order—void.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">An order passed by an inferior Court during the subsistence of a stay order made by a superior Court is an absolute nullity. <em>PLR (1960) 2 WP 751(FB).</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Stock Exchange</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Deposit of money in the Stock Exchange made by a member of the Stock Exchange to satisfy claims of other members when becomes a debt and amenable to the orders of the Court—Time factor, under the Rules, whereby the deposit becomes debt.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Mrs. Purviz ceased operations as a broker in January 1961. The application by the plaintiff for the deposit into the Court was made in February, 1962, that is, after period of one year. The Forward Contract Rules which regulated the transactions of the Stock Exchange, Karachi and contain provisions for settlement of forward contracts, show that these contracts are to be settled at the end of each week or at the latest at the end of each month; this means any forward contracts by Mrs. Purviz should have been settled long  the application in February, 1962 was made. Consequently, Mrs. Purviz had become entitled to withdraw the whole of her deposit of Rs. 15,000 from the Karachi Stock Exchange.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">From this fact it follows that the deposit had assummed the character of a debt due from the Exchange to Mrs. Purviz and, therefore, the Stock Exchange cannot be allowed to hold on to the security deposit and as such amenable to the orders of the court restraining Mrs. Purviz from withdrawing the aforesaid sum.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Karachi Stock Exchange Vs. Kurban Ali M. Merchant, (1973) 25 DLR (SC) 82.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Submergence</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">When the land is sublimated and is not capable of being possessed by anyone, the rightful owner must be deemed to be constructively in possession.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If title is transferred during the submergence, the transferee, and not the transferor, must be deemed to be in possession from the date of the transfer. It makes no difference whether the transfer is by a private treaty or by a court sale.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Rahij Uddin Sarkar Vs. Monser Ali Shaikh (1953) 5 DLR 344.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Subordinate legislature.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Rules made by a subordinate legislature, if <em>ultra vires</em>—(Income Tax Rule 9).</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Held: Learned Judges have fallen into an error of law in coming to the conclusion that the provisions similar to those contained in rule 9(2) of the Income Tax Rules can only be made by a legislative enactment and not by subordinate legislation made by National Board of Revenue.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The law itself has given the power to the National Board of Revenue to determine the percentage by prescribed rules and Rule 9 is such a rule. The judgment of the High Court Division is wrong.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>M/S. Everett Orient Lines Inc. Vs. Commissioner of Income Tax Chittagong Zone. (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 342.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Succession to property—Custom, Force of.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">(Custom in Punjab)—Custom that devolution of property has a preference over the personal law of the parties, is limited to the ancestral property only and not to non-ancestral property and in case of latter, the governing law is the personal law.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Mst. Qaiser Khatoon Vs. Mvi. Abdul Khaliq, (1973) 25 DLR (SC) 104.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>‘Such term’.</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">A relative term like the word ‘such’ is normally to be construed as applying to the next precedent antecedent and not as extended to or including others more remote.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Al-Haj Abdur Rahman Bhuiya Vs.
