Messrs. <em> Ibid.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong> </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Ss. 3 &amp; 10</strong>—”Arising out of the employment”—The workman working in railway yard while going to hospital for obtaining fitness certificate required for his permanent employment met with an accident from a collision with an engine—</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong><span style="line-height: 115%;">Held:</span></strong><span style="font-size: 12.0pt;"> In the circumstances the accident can be said to have arisen out and in the course of employment. </span></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Divisional Superintendent of Pakistan Western Railway Vs. Ali Zaman 1967) 19 DLR (WP) 7</em><em>1967) 19 D</em><em>2.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 4</strong>—Death resulting from injury—Some kind of casual relationship between the injury and death is all that is necessary.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The case on behalf of’. workman was that the workman suffered some injuries while carrying a heavy load of the employer on 3rd October, 1955. He was admitted in the hospital and was discharged there from on the 25th October 1955. The evidence disclosed it that he had suffered some internal injuries in the spinal cord, could not resume his normal avocation after discharge from hospital and died on 3rd Nov., 1955. It was contended in these circumstances on behalf of the employer that the case of death of the workman had not been established upon the evidence and, therefore, no compensation can be claimed on the evidence led in this case.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Held:</strong> The cause of death in the case of workman under the provisions of Workman’s Compensation Act has not to be established with such particularity as in a criminal case.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">There must be some kind of casual relationship between the injury and the death and not that the death must be directly and specially attributable to the particular injury caused.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Adam Ltd. Vs. Unisa Khatoon (1960) 12 DLR 858.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Payments made towards medical expenses of an injured worker cannot be deducted from the compensation payable to him under the Workmen’s Compensation Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>AKM Shamsuzzaman Khan Vs. Chairman EPRTC (1972) 24 DLR 94.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 10(1)—</strong>Delay in claiming compensation would be condoned where after the accident the workman has been re-employed on the same terms.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Delay in the respondent’s claim for compensation was condoned by the Commissioner and compensation in the sum of Rs. 2,520.00 was awarded to the respondent for injuries sustained by him.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">In the instant case, the delay is nearly two and a half years of the occurrence of the injury. But the workman was re-employed by the appellant on the previous terms and conditions. Following the Lahore, Bombay and Calcutta decisions, I would hold that this re-employment was sufficient cause for the respondent in not bringing his application for compensation within the prescribed period of one year.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>M/s. Indus Glass Works Vs. Safiruddin, (1968) 20 DLR (WP) 224.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 11</strong>—A fan in a part of the installations of a house, consequently, it should be included in a ‘building’ and the painting of the casing of a fan would amount to repairs within the meaning of the Schedule.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">The ground level should be the level of the ground surrounding the building and not of the floor after the level has been raised from the ground. 1952 PLR (Lah) 822.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>S. 30</strong>—High Court cannot review a finding of fact In an appeal under section 30 of the Workman’s Compensation Act the High Court cannot review a finding of fact unconnected with law arrived at by the Commission.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Adam Ltd. Vs. Unisa Khatoon (1960)12 DLR 858.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Appeal against Commissioner’s order. Appellate Court can go into question of fact when it is necessary to determine questions of law.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Messers Haji Obi Mia Vs. Sekandar Ali (1958)10 DLR 299.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—In an appeal under section 30 of the Act, the High Court cannot review a finding of fact unconnected with law arrived at by the Commissioner on evidence.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Muslim Cotton Mills Vs. Din Islam (1959)11 DLR 165.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">—Whether the accident arose in the course of the employment is a question of law.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">If the facts are admitted and the only question to consider is whether the accident arose out of and in the course of the employment of the workman, the question to be determined is not a question of fact but one of law. <em>1953 PLR (Lah) 605.</em></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><strong>Writ Jurisdiction</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Writ jurisdiction can not be invoked by the Municipal Corporation to nullify decision of the Controlling Authority.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">When the Ordinance says that the Municipal Committee must obey the direction of the Government and that direction is given by the Controlling Authority, any attempt for nullifying the decision of the Controlling Authority tantamount to disregard the very provisions of law and would amount to usurpation by way of writ jurisdiction. The law says the decision of the Controlling Authority shall be final.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">Municipal Committee could not maintain a writ petition and the High Court erred in law in setting aside the order of the Controlling Authority.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;">No writ petition is maintainable at the instance of a Municipality against any decision of the Controlling Authority. Any other view will lead to absurd position, namely, the Controlling Authority’s direction can be challenged by a municipality by invoking the writ jurisdiction and thereby dismantling the statutory structure.</p><p style="text-align: justify; text-justify: inter-ideograph;"><em>Dacca Municipal Corporation Vs. Sonali Bank (1982) 34 DLR (AD) 247.</em></p><p><span id="pastemarkerend"> </span></p></div></div>
